headline: American Solo Sailor May Change a Culture
text: At 3 a.m. Wednesday, Ryan Breymaier had been prone on a two-inch foam pad for barely 30 minutes when the call came for him to get up. He was delivering the 60-foot racing sailboat Hugo Boss from Newport, R.I., to Manhattan as training for the Imoca Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race, in which he and Pepe Ribes of Spain will sail across the Atlantic against four other teams starting Sunday.

headline: Police Search for Upset Teenager Who Sank Into the Hudson

She laid her phone and wallet on a rock on the bank of the river. She walked into the water and sank beneath the surface.

N.S.A. Collecting Millions of Faces From Web Images

headline: Another Slog for Mets, but This Time, It’s Worth It
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets were asking much of Jacob deGrom without much to offer him in return. Their bullpen was depleted and their spirit broken after a loss in 14 innings the night before, and now they were asking him to pitch deep into their game against the Philadelphia Phillies, to be effective and efficient and essentially carry the team.

headline: A Soldier Is Missing. What Comes Next?
text: When the United States Army in eastern Afghanistan discovered that one of its soldiers, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl, was missing in action, it began a frantic search. As detailed in the classified military logs given to WikiLeaks by Pfc. Bradley Manning, now Chelsea Manning, the initial hunt for the captured sergeant included surveillance drones, armed checkpoints and infantry raids on suspected militant strongholds. Intercepts of Taliban communications included in the military records reveal that the militants immediately thought to use the capture for propaganda purposes, and derided American forces for looking in all the wrong places. Andrew W. Lehren

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (AMC) HALT AND CATCH FIRE Set in Texas during the 1980s tech boom, this new series stars Lee Pace (“Lincoln,” “Pushing Daisies”) as Joe McMillan, a former IBM salesman who enlists the help of a has-been computer engineer (Scoot McNairy, above left, with Mackenzie Davis and Mr. Pace) and a talented computer science student (Ms. Davis) to reverse-engineer an IBM PC. The story is fiction, but based on the actual technology race of that decade, in which companies were trying to create their own version of a PC. With AMC’s “Mad Men,” focusing on the ad executive Don Draper, ending next year, the network “seems to be looking for another period drama that can seduce viewers with old-fashioned customs and atavistic sins,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Joe, like Don, is handsome, suave and moodily enigmatic, a salesman who pitches his product with passionate intensity.” Unfortunately, “Halt and Catch Fire” doesn’t seem to carry the same panache. “The period music is fun, but there is nothing particularly glamorous about high-tech Dallas. Most of all, the early 1980s are not a distant enough memory to cast a retro glow.”

headline: Tony Awards Predictions: Leading Actress in a Musical
text: Do you think Kelli O’Hara will score a big upset next Sunday and win the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for Broadway’s “Bridges of Madison County”? Or will front-runner Jessie Mueller and “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” emerge dominant, with the show winning the Tony for best musical over “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder”? As we survey the 800 Tony voters this week for our annual predictions story, we’re adding new voices to the mix: Yours.

headline: Administration Defends Swap With Taliban to Free U.S. Soldier
text: WASHINGTON — Top Obama administration officials pushed back on Sunday against Republican criticism that a deal freeing the last American held prisoner in Afghanistan could allow dangerous Taliban leaders to return to the fight, might encourage terrorist groups to seize American hostages and possibly violated a law requiring notification of Congress.

headline: Love-Struck Hero in a Quandary: The Other Woman’s a Real Doll
text: The music for the ballet “Coppélia” abounds in vitality, color, melody, folk energy, innocence, narrative charm and youthful freshness in each of its three acts. You seem to breathe more deeply when listening to it; your head clears. The composer is Léo Delibes; his 1870 score has several features that have never been surpassed in the ballet repertory. In the overture (and again in Act II), a sweet, high, ravishing violin melody suddenly takes the air after a soft horn introduction, like the answer to a prayer or light after darkness. What mazurka and what czardas are more irresistible than those here? In the Act I variations on a Slavic theme, the fast-cascading joy of one rapid string phrase squeezes the heart.

headline: Six Climbers Are Missing on Mount Rainier
text: VANCOUVER, Wash. — Six climbers were missing and presumed dead on Sunday in an avalanche or fall on Mount Rainier in Washington State, in what could be the worst accident on the mountain in decades.

headline: A Lawman With a Lot to Deal With, Including Himself

He’s Sheriff Walt Longmire, and if he’s upset that shows like “The Following” and “True Detective” get more attention than his does, he’s not letting on.

headline: Another Ending for Arsenio Hall
text: The February announcement that Arsenio Hall’s syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken. CBS Television Distribution, which owns the show with Tribune Media, has announced a cancellation because of a ratings decline among the viewers most advertisers pay for in late night, people between the ages of 18 and 49. (The ratings leader in that group is Jimmy Fallon on NBC.) Mr. Hall, left, who had a hit syndicated late-night show in the early 1990s, revived the franchise with some fanfare in September, and he scored some early impressive ratings. But the late-night scene had become intensely crowded, with as many as 10 shows fighting for a shrinking number of viewers. The ratings drop set in motion a pattern of downgrades from a host of local television stations, which began relegating Mr. Hall’s show to little-watched hours of the night. In February, his old friend Jay Leno appeared on the show with a letter confirming a second year. The ratings slide forced CBS’s syndication division to rescind that decision.

headline: Yankees’ Robertson Fails, Making Twins’ Hughes a Winner
text: Even though Phil Hughes was once an 18-game winner for the Yankees, had been an All-Star and had helped them win a World Series as an important relief pitcher, things could hardly have ended worse for him in the Bronx. A 4-14 record last season, including a 1-10 mark at home, made him the target of loud booing by fans who were only too happy to see him leave.

headline: Relevant? Nurturing? Well, So’s Your Old Man
text: When our young daughters first decided to play on top of our Honda minivan, parked in our driveway, my wife was worried. But to me, it seemed no less safe than chasing a ball that frequently ended up in the street. And they loved the height, the novelty, the danger. So I let them stay. They never fell. And with the summer weather here, playing on the car is once again keeping them occupied for hours.

headline: Mermaids’ Flashlights, and Other Illuminations
text: The graceful sight of a lighthouse — preferably on a cliff with ocean waves crashing onto the rocks below — is more than a postcard symbol of summer. It’s a reminder of what happens when nature turns violent. In “Light House,” performed at the Invisible Dog Art Center on Friday, the choreographer Anne Zuerner drew on movements from the natural world, both calm and forceful.

headline: Skirball Announces  Its 2014-15 Season
text: Classic Shakespeare, Canadian acrobats and a GPS-led trek are among events planned for the 2014-15 season at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University. Highlights include “King Lear,” from Sept. 29 to Oct. 12, presented by Shakespeare’s Globe, the company behind Broadway’s recent productions of “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III”; Quebec’s high-flying troupe Cirque Alfonse (Oct. 13 to 19); and the Joshua Light Show Festival, a psychedelic mix of music, light, dance and projections (Oct. 23 to 25). Next spring, a three-week run of “Remote New York” is to guide participants through the city with GPS instructions delivered via headphones. More information: nyuskirball.org.

headline: For Ensembles and Singers, a Night of Backbreaking Labor
text: The NY Phil Biennial presented a diptych of New York premieres dedicated to manual labor on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Julia Wolfe’s “Anthracite Fields” (2014) commemorates the Pennsylvania coal miners whose work fueled the industrial revolution. Steven Mackey’s “Dreamhouse” (2003) examines the process of building a house. Both works feature singers and an ensemble mixing acoustic and amplified instruments; both express unease with the American culture of comfort and consumption.

headline: A Composer’s Sensual Side
text: During the composer and conductor Pierre Boulez’s tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 1970s, he challenged the repertorial status quo and reached out to new audiences with events like the Rug Concerts, where patrons lounged on cushions while listening to contemporary music.

headline: Hachette Chief Leads Book Publishers in Amazon Fight
text: As a young book editor at Little, Brown & Company in 1992, Michael Pietsch paid $80,000 — $45,000 more than the next-highest bidder — for a postmodern novel by a little-known writer named David Foster Wallace.

headline: Showcasing Music Till the Sun Comes Up
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Caetano Veloso, the bossa nova elder statesman, was holding court here on Saturday evening, floating his baritone voice and easy guitar over an amphitheater audience that swayed and sang along as he offered a slightly raunchy paean to his native Brazilian sounds.

headline: Returning to Ice, Rangers Have Spring in Their Strides
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After the Rangers’ first practice since their triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in the Eastern Conference finals, their coach spoke to the news media Sunday under a makeshift tent in front of their training complex. With the warm sunshine outside and a breezy spirit inside, the scene had the feel of a September training camp. The Rangers, though, have games ahead in June as they make their first Stanley Cup finals appearance in 20 years.

headline: Library Reveals Details and Costs of Upgrade Plan
text: The New York Public Library’s revised renovation plan — to upgrade the Mid-Manhattan Library and create more public space in its flagship Fifth Avenue building — is expected to cost about $300 million, according to library officials who outlined new details of the project in interviews.

headline: A Post-Punk Band in Early Metamorphosis, Luxuriating in Unease
text: There is great meaning in the post-punk reaction, as there is always great meaning in the reaction of any child toward unstable parents. That reaction wasn’t confined to one period of time. It didn’t stop in, say, 1981. Punk, behind sound, is declarative and self-annihilating at the same time. It wants to assert itself and to disappear, and has done so, in regular overlapping cycles, all over the place, for all kinds of reasons.

headline: No-Trump Outscores the Major at Eastern States Regional
text: At the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month, the winners of the main pair event on the second day, May 22, were Augie Boehm and Donald Simmons of New York City. They finished 0.75 match points ahead of Deborah Murphy of San Francisco and Gary Donner of Bluffton, S.C. Third were R. Jay Becker of New York City and Ron Smith of Las Vegas.

headline: Duda Homer Leaves Mets Delighted, if Exhausted
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies were already familiar with each other, as division rivals, but on Sunday, as they entered extra innings for the third time in three days, they seemed to understand each other on a deeper, more intimate level.

headline: Kind of Test
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t had an Andrea Carla Michaels Monday puzzle since March, but she’s back with a phonetic hint theme that unfurled itself slowly for me.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Goddess of Democracy
text: A 33-foot-high statue became a mute yet powerful actor in the final drama on Tiananmen Square in 1989, reinvigorating the student protests and infuriating Communist Party leaders who crushed the demonstrations, and the statue, five days after its birth.

headline: A Digital Agency Draws a Pair of Aces in Brazil
text: AN acclaimed advertising creative team that has been celebrated for several successful campaigns is joining a digital agency on a fast growth curve to help it grow faster.

headline: The Story of Gay America, via Personal Interviews
text: David Isay, the founder of the nonprofit oral history group StoryCorps, tried for many years with little success to raise money for a project to collect stories from the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning community.

headline: Down on Modi’s Farm
text: India’s new prime minister has a lot of new seed to plant.

headline: Inside the Fixing: How a Gang Battered Soccer’s Frail Integrity
text: ROVANIEMI, Finland — A man arrived at the police station here in 2011 with an unusual tip. He told the police that a Singaporean man was fixing matches with the local professional soccer team. The police were incredulous.

headline: Can the Market Stave Off Global Warming?
text: Is cap and trade the best chance for stemming climate change, or are other methods needed?

headline: Sex Crimes That Shouldn’t Be
text: As creatures who are both participants in public life, and individuals with private lives and concerns, we are constantly challenged to balance our own needs and rights against the public good. In many cases, that challenge comes down to weighing the societal benefits of transparency against the need for for personal privacy. The most familiar and heated debates of late, of course, involve high-tech government spying without consent from individuals — surveillance that in many cases extended to the unsuspecting person’s bedrooms.

headline: A River Runs Through Their Pictures and Lives
text: More than half a century since Inge Morath photographed the Danube, nine young female photographers will follow her footsteps and add to her legacy.

headline: America’s Highways, Running on Empty
text: WASHINGTON — IF you think your commute is getting worse, it’s probably not your imagination. And no, it’s not because there are more cars on the road. The potholes, the stalled construction projects, the congestion — it’s because the highway trust fund is almost empty and, without a fix, could run out of money this summer.

text: Books, we are told, are relics that have reached their sell-by date, put out by an industry that is a desiccated shell of its former self.

headline: Amazon and a Mattel Unit Plan a ‘Content Hub’ Focusing on Children
text: LOS ANGELES — “Fireman Sam,” a cartoon aimed at preschoolers, has long been a hit overseas. Now Mattel and Amazon are teaming up to sell the yellow-hatted hero to American children — a potentially controversial experiment that, if successful, could create a new model for marrying television shows with related merchandise.

headline: Lee Chamberlin, ‘Electric Company’ Actress, Dies at 76
text: Lee Chamberlin, an actress whose career took off when she joined Bill Cosby and Rita Moreno on the funky 1970s children’s show “The Electric Company,” died on May 25 in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 76.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 2
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: The Vanishing Cry of ‘Repeal It’
text: It was supposed to be so easy this election year for Republican congressional candidates. All they would have to do was shout “repeal Obamacare!” and make a crack about government doctors and broken websites, and they could coast into office on a wave of public fury. The failure of the Affordable Care Act was simply assumed.

headline: Emerging From the Shadows Cast Across a River
text: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — It takes little prodding to draw stories from Larry Manuel about how, before they were the subjects of films and supernatural sightings, Johnny Cash and Elvis Presley were just two musicians trying to make it along the Mississippi River.

headline: Israel Warns Against Embracing Newly Reconciled Palestinian Government
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called on the international community on Sunday “not to run to recognize” the new Palestinian government scheduled to be sworn in Monday, saying it “rests on Hamas,” the militant Islamic faction that Israel and much of the West deem a terrorist organization.

headline: With South Bronx Trail, a History and a Culture Will Be Clearly Marked
text: Casa Amadeo on Prospect Avenue, a Latin record store on the National Register of Historic Places, is perhaps the only place in the city where one can worship at a shrine dedicated to the Puerto Rican composer Rafael Hernández.

headline: Popular Demand
text: June arrives with a different Final Four, as the Miami Heat take on the San Antonio Spurs in the N.B.A. Finals — a rematch of 2013.

headline: In GPS Battle, Russia Sets Restrictions of Its Own
text: MOSCOW — The deputy prime minister in charge of Russia’s space programs said Sunday that he had started to impose restrictions on Global Positioning System base stations here, as retribution for the refusal of the United States to allow similar base stations on American territory that would improve the accuracy of Russia’s navigation system.

headline: On Inequality Denial
text: A while back I published an article titled “The Rich, the Right, and the Facts,” in which I described politically motivated efforts to deny the obvious — the sharp rise in U.S. inequality, especially at the very top of the income scale. It probably won’t surprise you to hear that I found a lot of statistical malpractice in high places.

headline: Ann B. Davis, 88, Dies; Comic Actress Played Maid on ‘Brady Bunch’
text: Ann B. Davis, the comic actress best known as the wistful, wisecracking live-in maid on the long-running ABC sitcom “The Brady Bunch,” died on Sunday in San Antonio. She was 88.

headline: Lewis Katz’s Vision for the New Jersey Nets Went Unrealized
text: In November 1999, Lewis Katz stood on a high school stage in New Jersey’s largest city and told an audience of students, local politicians and a smiling President Bill Clinton, “The New Jersey Nets are coming to Newark — remember that.”

headline: Bad Food in School Cafeterias
text: Republicans on a powerful House committee have balked at requiring all schools to serve healthy lunches in the coming school year. The action drew a well-deserved rebuke from the first lady, Michelle Obama, who has focused public attention on combating obesity among young people through exercise and better nutrition. Let’s hope the Senate holds out against such inanity.

headline: A Vote on Medical Marijuana
text: The New York State Assembly easily approved a law legalizing medical marijuana last Tuesday, and there appear to be enough votes to pass similar legislation in the State Senate if that chamber’s leaders agree to allow a vote. They ought to do so before the legislative session ends on June 19. The bills would make the drug available, under tight regulation, to patients who, in many cases, do not get relief from other medications.

headline: As Antics Subside, Both Cuomo and the Left Claim the Last Hurrah
text: COLONIE, N.Y. — Weeks of intense negotiations between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and an impatient, insurgent left resolved themselves shortly before midnight on Saturday in a stormy night of brinkmanship and shuttle diplomacy.

headline: Encouragement (Sort of) About Press Freedom
text: UPDATE June 2, 2014:  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear the appeal from James Risen, a reporter for The Times who has been ordered to testify in the criminal trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official.

headline: Yes, All Men
text: As I drove my son back to college last week, where he’ll take a summer chemistry course, he said something that struck me: “I believe it’s very important for everyone to be a feminist.”

headline: Insider-Trading Inquiry Could Rattle Icahn’s Efforts to Shape His Legacy
text: For decades, Carl C. Icahn has enjoyed the spotlight.

headline: Scots Are Divided Over Independence, and Its Economic Costs
text: BEITH, Scotland — The case for tearing apart the United Kingdom was made on a recent evening at a community center in this small town near Glasgow. More than 200 people were packed into folding chairs and standing along walls lined with posters promoting an independent Scotland, like the one with the word “Aye” emblazoned on a Scottish flag. A disco ball hung overhead.

headline: Pitching for Fun, and for a Future
text: EL PASO — It is early on a Wednesday afternoon, and most of the schoolchildren have been called to their buses. From his spot in right field — beneath the Woofdeck, close to the stand that sells nachos in a dog dish for $10 — Jeff Francoeur has been roasting in the blistering desert heat.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 1, 2014
text: June 1, 2014

headline: Trying to Reclaim Leadership on Climate Change
text: At the end of his first year in office, President Obama flew to Copenhagen and made a big promise: that the United States would cut its greenhouse gas emissions substantially by 2020 — a bold and risky pledge that hinged on a balky Congress to make it possible. His efforts became bogged down within months, and Mr. Obama’s pledge to the rest of the world soon looked like a pipe dream.

headline: At Ukraine’s Perilous Border, Law Is Dispensed by Men in Masks
text: KRASNYY LUCH, Ukraine — Just over the bridge here, near a crumbling blue electric station, a white sign with plain blue letters informs travelers that they are about to enter foreign territory: “Luhansk People’s Republic, Independent State.”

headline: With Mixed Showing, U.S. Gives Its Coach a Win to Study
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Jurgen Klinsmann has been preparing for World Cups long enough to know not to show his hand two weeks before the opening game. Not to reporters, certainly. But not to his players, either. So he tinkers with his lineups and his tactics, and he generally keeps his opinions to himself.

headline: Visitors Fault Sept. 11 Museum’s Portrayal of Islam
text: After the vivid audio recordings, diagrams and personal artifacts that take visitors minute by minute through the Sept. 11 attacks, and before the images of recovery workers combing through rubble, a small section of the National September 11 Memorial Museum is devoted to explaining Al Qaeda and terrorism.

headline: Experience at Muirfield Helps a 22-Year-Old Win in a Playoff for His First PGA Title
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — It felt like October all over for Japan’s Hideki Matsuyama, who played the final round of the Memorial Tournament with Australia’s Adam Scott, his International team partner at last year’s Presidents Cup.

headline: Census Records Shed a New Light on Some of the Mayor’s Forebears
text: Bill de Blasio’s mother was born in the house on East 17th Street in Manhattan. His grandmother, great-grandmother and other relatives lived there, too, at the start of the 20th century. Now, newly-digitized records from a 1905 New York State census have filled in some of the gaps in the congenial Italian heritage that he says grounded him, while his German-American father struggled with alcoholism and ultimately killed himself.

headline: At Least 13 Are Wounded by Gunfire Across New York City
text: The victims were at outdoor celebrations or cookouts with friends. In one case, a teenager was wounded on a basketball court; two others were struck while walking together in memory of a 15-year-old killed by gunfire four years before.

headline: Will the Kingdom Stay United?
text: In September, Scots will vote on whether Scotland will remain in Britain or become an independent nation.

headline: Underdog Seeks Jump From Second to Spoiler
text: The horse does not look the part of one of the top 3-year-olds in the country. The trainer oversees only four horses, and his fortunes took such a horrible turn two winters ago that he had none to work with. The owner has a passion for racing but lacks a budget to match.

headline: Rangers, Despite Odds, Have a Lot in Their Favor
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings have met twice in the playoffs since the Kings entered the N.H.L. in 1967, but they have never met in the Stanley Cup finals. That will change Wednesday when the finals begin in Los Angeles.

headline: Before Brief, Deadly Spree, Trouble Since Age 8
text: LOS ANGELES — It was the summer of 1999, and the parents of Elliot O. Rodger were battling over the boy’s deep and puzzling psychological problems as they struggled through a divorce.

headline: Etihad Nears Deal for a Stake in Alitalia
text: PARIS — After more than five months of negotiations, Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi confirmed on Sunday that it was nearing an agreement that could lead to a sizable investment in Alitalia.

headline: An Ideal Place, Except for All the Dead Bodies
text: There are little-known plays by well-known writers that, when once viewed, strike you as being unjustly, even criminally neglected. Eugene Ionesco’s “The Killer” is not one of them. Au contraire! This is the kind of rarity that theater aficionados may be eager to see until they have the misfortune of seeing it.

headline: Women’s Hats on a Harlem Bus
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 11
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Prisoner Trade Yields Rare View Into the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, has offered both a rare insight into the insurgent group’s inner workings and a diplomatic first in the long Afghan war: a negotiated agreement between the highest levels of the American government and the pinnacle of the Taliban command.

headline: Trial Begins for Queens Democrat Charged With Bribery, Extortion and Fraud
text: Malcolm A. Smith wanted to be the mayor of New York City so badly that he, a Democratic Queens state senator and onetime Senate majority and minority leader, was willing to run as a Republican in a city where Democrats hold a 6-1 edge.

headline: Next Move for Fisher: Coaching, or Maybe Politics
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The first time Derek Fisher arrived in New York, in 1996, a wide-eyed rookie with the Los Angeles Lakers, he did not enjoy any of the city’s restaurants, visit Central Park, take in any theater or hop to any clubs.

headline: Planned Celebration for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Just Got a Whole Lot Bigger
text: HAILEY, Idaho — It looked as if it was going to be a big weekend here in the Wood River Valley in Central Idaho.

headline: Panel to Create Plan to Reduce Number of Mentally Ill People in New York City Jails
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has asked several of his commissioners and aides to provide him with a plan by September to reduce the rate of incarceration among New Yorkers with mental illness.

headline: Drama Desk Embraces ‘A Gentleman’s Guide’
text: The Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” led the trophy tally with seven on Sunday night at the Drama Desk Awards, which honor Broadway and Off Broadway productions. “Gentleman’s Guide,” a strong contender in next weekend’s Tonys competition, won for outstanding musical, outstanding actor (Jefferson Mays), featured actress (Lauren Worsham), director (Darko Tresnjak), lyrics, book and projection design. “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” followed with three awards, including for actress in a musical (Jessie Mueller as Carole King), sound design and featured actress (Anika Larsen, who tied with Ms. Worsham). Robert Schenkkan’s “All the Way” won for outstanding play and actor (Bryan Cranston as Lyndon B. Johnson), with other top awards for plays going to Audra McDonald (“Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill”) for best actress and “Twelfth Night” for outstanding revival and director (Tim Carroll). In the musical category, “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” took honors for outstanding revival and actor (Neil Patrick Harris as Hedwig, who shared the award with Mr. Mays). Featured acting awards went to Reed Birney (“Casa Valentina”), Celia Keenan-Bolger (“The Glass Menagerie”) and James Monroe Iglehart (“Aladdin”).

headline: K.K.R. Shuts Stock Hedge Fund
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts made waves in the fall of 2010 when the investment giant poached a trading team from Goldman Sachs to set up a hedge fund focused on stock trading.

headline: Is Global Warming Real? Most Americans Say Yes
text: The Obama administration announced new regulations Monday meant to reduce carbon emissions and combat climate change.

headline: Major Malfunction: Revisiting Challenger
text: Thirty years ago, on Jan. 28, 1986, seven astronauts “slipped the surly bonds of earth to touch the face of God.” America’s space program was never the same.

headline: Challenger, Columbia and the Nature of Calamity
text: They died as they slipped the surly bonds of Earth. The last words of that sentence, haunting words, were written by John Gillespie Magee Jr., an American airman and poet who enlisted in the Royal Canadian Air Force in 1940, before the United States entered World War II. He was killed the following year in a midair collision over England. He was all of 19.

headline: Boy, 6, Dies After a Stabbing in Brooklyn
text: Mikayla Capers and her best friend, Prince Joshua Avitto, wanted to get Icees. The two hopped in an elevator on Sunday at the Brooklyn housing project where they lived. A man got on after them, pulled out a knife and stabbed the children, the police said, in an attack that left residents stunned.

headline: With Ukraine Still Unsettled, Obama Sets Off to Soothe European Friends
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama leaves for Europe on Monday night cautiously optimistic that the crisis in Ukraine has turned a corner, but he will find himself face to face with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for the first time since the two squared off in a Cold-War-style showdown in Eastern Europe.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Can Geekiness Be Entertaining?
text: Season 1, Episode 1: The premiere of “Halt and Catch Fire,” which aired on Sunday on AMC, owes much to that long-ago first episode of “Breaking Bad.” A couple of mysterious, broody guys are drawn together against their better judgment. Together they set off on a scheme both hyper-technical and legally dubious, one that seems certain to tear apart everything else in their lives. And we get to witness their tricks through a parade of luscious, barely comprehensible montages.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap:  Blood and Gore Are so Entertaining
text: Season 1, Episode 4: Up until now, the “Penny Dreadful” recaps have focused on what just happened, not what may be around the fog-shrouded corner. But one plot point that has been hovering around the edges comes just shy of bursting to the surface in this episode, “Demimonde,” to the point where it can’t really be ignored anymore. (As before, here lie spoilers galore.)

headline: Kings Go the Distance, and Then Some, to Reach the Finals
text: CHICAGO — The Chicago Blackhawks, the defending Stanley Cup champions, won two straight games to force Sunday’s Game 7 on their home ice. A year ago, they sliced through the Los Angeles Kings in five games on this very stage, the Western Conference finals.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. 2, Turkey 1
text: The United States national team defeated Turkey on a sunny spring day at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., in its second exhibition game ahead of the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

headline: With New Palestinian Government Come Many Questions, and Some Answers
text: The new Palestinian government sworn in on Monday in the West Bank city of Ramallah, will be led by Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah and is to consist of 16 other ministers, some handling more than one portfolio. Four are from the Gaza Strip and were barred by Israel from attending the ceremony. The government grew out of a reconciliation pact signed between the Palestine Liberation Organization, dominated by the secular Fatah faction, and Hamas, the militant Islamic movement that has ruled Gaza since 2007.

headline: New Therapies for Bowel Diseases
text: Decades ago, I met a surprisingly quiet, withdrawn young man. Surprising because I knew his bright, vibrant wife and wondered what had attracted her to him. He barely participated in conversations even at friendly family gatherings.

headline: After Interruption, No Stopping Sharapova at French Open
text: PARIS — Maria Sharapova looked as if she might be bowing out of the French Open in the fourth round to Samantha Stosur — until she heard a call.

headline: Study Examines Efficacy of Taxes on Sugary Drinks
text: A new study of how taxes might be used to curb consumption of sugary drinks suggests that applying a tax based on the amount of calories contained in a serving rather than its size would be more effective.

headline: Word of the Day | annotate
text: annotate •\ˈa-nə-ˌtat\• verb

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 2, 2014
text: “I tell people it’s like a funnel. You’re at the small end of the funnel for so long, and then suddenly the world opens up. It takes time to get used to it.”

headline: Tales of Army Discord Show Tiananmen Square in a New Light
text: BEIJING — On a spring evening in 1989, with the student occupation of Tiananmen Square entering its second month and the Chinese leadership unnerved and divided, top army commanders were summoned to headquarters to pledge their support for the use of military force to quash the protests.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) A HARD DAY’S NIGHT (1964) When this film from the director Richard Lester had its debut, Bosley Crowther of The New York Times was astounded. “I wouldn’t believe it either, if I hadn’t seen it with my own astonished eyes,” he wrote of this first fiction film of the Beatles, adding that it “has so much good humor going for it that it is awfully hard to resist.” The film stars the Fab Four poking fun at Beatlemania in a plotline that takes viewers through the misadventures before a big show. “And all the way through the picture, there are frenzied episodes of the Beatles’ encounters with squealing fans and with reporters who ask silly questions, all in a facile, witty vein,” Mr. Crowther wrote. “But more than this, it’s a fine conglomeration of madcap clowning in the old Marx Brothers’ style, and it is done with such a dazzling use of camera that it tickles the intellect and electrifies the nerves.” Above, Mr. Lester at the train window with the Beatles.

headline: Corrections: June 2, 2014
text: NEW YORK

headline: Anger in China After McDonald’s Patron Beaten to Death
text: The beating death of a woman in a McDonald’s restaurant in eastern China has triggered widespread anger over the slow response of witnesses and condemnation of a fringe religious group that the police say influenced the attackers.

headline: China’s Solar Panel Production Comes at a Dirty Cost
text: Updated, 7:23 a.m. ET| Although China may be a cheaper place than Europe for producing solar panels, the savings come at a higher cost to the environment, a new study says.

headline: Marathon Oil Sells Norwegian Unit for $2.1 Billion
text: LONDON – The exploration and production company Marathon Oil said on Monday that it would sell its North Sea oil business in Norway to a Norwegian oil producer for $2.1 billion in cash.

headline: As Poles Focus on Belonging to Europe, Their Love for the U.S. Has Cooled a Bit
text: WARSAW — “Poland is the most pro-American country in the world — including the United States,” goes a quip, well known here, from an American foreign policy expert more than a decade ago.

headline: Roche to Pay Up to $350 Million for DNA Sequencing Business
text: LONDON – Roche, the Swiss drug and health care diagnostics maker, said on Monday that it would pay as much as $350 million for Genia Technologies, a privately held DNA sequencing company.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade
text: In “Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade,” Eric Schmitt and Charlie Savage report on the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.

headline: A River Changes Young Women’s Photography, and Their Lives
text: Inge Morath grew overwhelmed with panic one day in 1958, as she was on the road to the source of one of Europe’s largest rivers, the Danube.

headline: Are Your Parents Too Overprotective?
text: Do you feel your parents are always watching over you — worried you will get hurt or in trouble? When you were younger, did your parents give you free reign to explore the neighborhood or woods with your buddies — or did you always feel that you were on a short leash?

headline: GlaxoSmithKline in $350 Million Cancer Drug Venture
text: LONDON – Adaptimmune, a biotechnology company, said on Monday that it had reached a deal that could be worth more than $350 million to develop an early stage cancer drug with the pharmaceutical maker GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: A King Makes a Powerful Change, for Stability
text: MADRID — King Juan Carlos of Spain said Monday that he was abdicating in favor of Crown Prince Felipe, his 46-year-old son, explaining in an address to the nation that it was time for a new generation to “move to the front line” and face the country’s challenges.

headline: Coal Comfort
text: I recently had a discussion with someone who felt disappointed in Obama; he had not, this person complained, lived up to the high hopes of his supporters. My response apparently came as a surprise: I’m liking Obama more and more as he slogs through his second term.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Scott Anderson on the Lasting Pain of Conflict in Srebrenica
text: Scott Anderson, a war correspondent and novelist, wrote the June 1 cover story about life in Srebrenica, where genocide occurred during the breakup of Yugoslavia. Anderson is the author of the novel “Moonlight Hotel” and is working on a book about World War I. His last article for the magazine was about a man who killed his parents when he was 14.

headline: For Bonds, This Time is Different
text: Bloomberg has an interesting piece on how high bond prices and low yields have been shocking investors who relied on old models. Some of this, I suspect, is because many people still — after all these years — haven’t wrapped their minds around the implications of a zero-lower=bound economy and the risks of a low-inflation trap.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: June Is for Hockey Heroes
text: Good morning on this fair Monday.

headline: Separatists Attack a Border Guard Headquarters in Eastern Ukraine
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Several hundred separatist fighters mounted a coordinated assault against a border guard headquarters in the eastern city of Luhansk on Monday, holding it under siege for more than 12 hours in what appeared to be an attempt to eliminate the strategic control center for the region’s long and porous border with Russia.

headline: Q. and A.: Chen Guang on the Soldiers Who Retook Tiananmen Square
text: In the spring of 1989, Chen Guang was a 17-year-old soldier with the 65th Group Army, which was instructed to clear student protesters from Tiananmen Square. The 65th Group Army, based north of Beijing in Hebei Province, made two attempts to enter the capital, the first on May 20 after the declaration of martial law. That attempt failed, after thousands of Beijing residents swarmed the streets and halted their convoy. The second, successful, attempt was on June 3, and Mr. Chen was among the first soldiers to make it past the blockades of protesters and enter the Great Hall of the People with thousands of weapons he had secretly transported on a public bus.

headline: Celebration, and Lingering Tensions, as India’s 29th State Is Born
text: HYDERABAD, India — On Monday, the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh officially split in two, and India’s 29th state, Telangana, was born. President’s rule — the interim government of united Andhra Pradesh — lifted in the new state, and the first popular government of Telangana came into power.

headline: Pinpointing Another Reason That More Hispanics Are Identifying as White
text: Recently, I wrote about new research that showed that a net 1.2 million Hispanics changed their racial identification from “some other race” to “white” between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.

headline: Calling an Ordinary Health Problem a Disease Leads to Bigger Problems
text: As any parent knows, babies spit up. It’s gastroesophageal reflux, a pediatrician will explain — milk leaking backward from the stomach. When I was a pediatrics resident, my hospital constructed foam wedges for infants to sleep on. The thinking was that infants who were sleeping at an angle would be less likely to have milk come back up.

headline: Japan’s Dai-ichi Life to Consider Investments in United States
text: LONDON – The Japanese insurer Dai-ichi Life said on Monday that it was considering investments in life insurance companies in the United States, but it declined to confirm media reports that it was weighing an acquisition of Protective Life of Alabama.

headline: A Question of Family Ties Between G.E. and Alstom Law Firm

headline: Answers to Questions About the New Palestinian Government

The transitional government of 17 ministers grew out of a unity pact reached in April between the Palestine Liberation Organization, which is dominated by the mainstream Fatah faction, and its rival Hamas, the Islamic militant group that has controlled the Gaza Strip since 2007. As Ms. Rudoren reported, the development has alarmed Israel and could prompt reactions from the European Union and the United States.

headline: Pakistani Premier in Delicate Dance With India
text: Pakistan’s prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, returned home from New Delhi to faint praise and considerable criticism, the latter suggesting that his 30-hour sojourn in Delhi to attend the swearing-in ceremony of Prime Minister Narendra Modi last week had been his riskiest gamble yet in improving his country’s relations with India.

headline: On the Verge | The Swedish Takeover of L.A.
text: Throngs of Swedes eager to escape the land of the midnight sun are traveling to the land of eternal sunshine. Blame the obvious (weather), the logistical (Norwegian Air Shuttle’s new direct flight from Stockholm) or the sartorial (Acne Studios’ opening of a West Coast outpost); whatever the reason, Los Angeles has become a new home away from ‘Holm for many Swedish creatives. “Without fail, every single day there’s a bunch of Swedes in the lobby,” says Fredrik Carlstrom, who ensconced himself at the newish Ace Hotel while overseeing the recent launch of Austere, a nearby Scandi-centric retail showroom and event space. Come late next year, downtown L.A. will also house AYD (short for “All Your Dreams”), a Nordic-influenced members club designed by Andreas Fornell (formerly Acne’s in-house architect). AYD will boast Swedish chefs (Adam & Albin of Matstudio in Stockholm) and club “ambassadors” like the pop icon Robyn. “A lot of people are skipping New York and going straight to L.A.,” says Patrik Berger, who co-produced the Swedish duo Icona Pop’s massive 2012 hit “I Love It.” “It’s all in L.A. when it comes to pop music.”

headline: Allman Brothers Band Announces Final Concerts
text: When the Allman Brothers Band pulled into the Beacon Theater in March, it was set to play what it said was the last of its annual New York residencies at the hall. But when Gregg Allman, the band’s singer and keyboardist, fell ill toward the end of the run, the final week of sold-out concerts were canceled, with a promise that the band would make them up. The question was whether that would happen before the end of the year, when, word from around the group had it, the Allmans were planning to disband (something Mr. Allman denied in interviews).

text: David Villa, a veteran Spanish striker who has lifted the Champions League and World Cup trophies in a title-filled career, joined New York City F.C. on Monday as the Major League Soccer club’s first player.

headline: Burying the Hatchet in a Bid for Relevance
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The last time 50 Cent appeared at Hot 97 Summer Jam, in 2004, he was the most popular rapper of the day, the most feared, and in some circles, the most hated. But what could have been a coronation was instead a fiasco: Some old enemies started trouble in the crowd, sending chairs flying toward the stage, which 50 Cent and his crew sent flying right back before walking off with a harrumph and a ban from future Summer Jams.

headline: Video: Rico’s Lechon, a Filipino Tradition
text: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: Clip From HBO’s ‘112 Weddings’
text: A clip from the HBO documentary, “112 Weddings,” in which a longtime wedding videographer explores the challenges couples face in their marriages years after the wedding day.

headline: Secret Global Strike Kills 2 Malicious Web Viruses
text: WASHINGTON — Federal agents over the weekend secretly seized control of two computer networks that hackers used to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. In doing so, the Justice Department disrupted the circulation of two of the world’s most pernicious viruses and turned a 30-year-old Russian computer hacker into a most-wanted fugitive.

headline: Asparagus, Green Beans and Potatoes With Green Mole Sauce
text: Mole sauce, which is thickened with nuts or seeds, is as wonderful with vegetables as it is with meat or fish, something I was reminded of recently when I had a main dish of mole with vegetables at El Naranjo, the chef Iliana de la Vega’s restaurant in Austin, Tex. Green mole especially lends itself to vegetables. At this time of year I’m buying asparagus and green beans. They should not be too crunchy – five minutes was just the right amount of cooking time.

headline: Whole-Wheat Seeded Loaves
text: This is a whole-wheat adaptation of Jacquy Pfeiffer’s seeded bread from “The Art of French Pastry.” The seeds and the flaked oats are soaked overnight before they’re mixed into the dough. This allows them to absorb moisture and softens them, so that the bread is wonderfully moist, and the seeds won’t be hard on your teeth when you bite. Soaking the seeds also breaks down phytic acid and protease inhibitors, which allows the nutrients to be more readily absorbed by the body. This is a two-day recipe, as you must allow time for soaking the seeds overnight.

headline: Rice Pilaf With Pistachios, Almonds and Spices
text: There are sweet and tart flavors at play here, especially if you use barberries, but apricots also have a tart edge to them. Rose water makes the pilaf wonderfully fragrant. The dish is inspired by a number of Persian rice pilafs, but it’s simpler, and calls for much less butter than an authentic Persian pilaf. I’ve made it with plain basmati rice, but I also like to use a purple jasmine rice mix that Alter Eco packages.

headline: Seeded Chocolate-Chip Oatmeal Cookies
text: If you want to indulge in chocolate-chip cookies that taste like chocolate-chip cookies but have some wholesome ingredients thrown in, here’s your recipe. I use as much chocolate in these as I use in Sherry Yard’s Quintessential Chocolate Chip-Cookies (isn’t it great that chocolate offers us healthful phytonutrients?) but I’ve reduced the sugar by 25 percent and added a good measure of rolled oats and sunflower, chia and pumpkin seeds. I’ve made the cookies using half whole-wheat flour and using all unbleached all-purpose flour, and I prefer the whole-wheat version – and not just because it’s healthier:The nutty flavor of the flour complements the nutty flavor of the seeds. You could soak the seeds, but you’ll have to take the time to dry them completely in a low oven; otherwise they will contribute too much moisture and the cookies won’t brown properly.

headline: Yogurt With Mixed Seeds, Toasted Oatmeal and Ginger Syrup
text: The inspiration for this breakfast yogurt comes mainly from an amazing breakfast yogurt and fruit bowl I had at the Elizabeth Street Café, a Vietnamese-French bakery and restaurant in Austin, Tex. Its baker, Jennifer Tucker, is exceptionally talented: Anyone who can pull off croissants that incorporate whole-wheat flour and seeds while remaining flaky, light, and small has my immediate attention.

headline: Chemical Weapons Treaty Does Not Apply to Petty Crime, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that Congress had not meant to authorize prosecutions of minor crimes under a chemical weapons treaty.

headline: Paulo Ferro’s Math Challenges
text: Our challenges this week were suggested by Paulo Ferro, who teaches math in Portugal and has written secondary math textbooks used in Spain. Each of the puzzles requires breaking and reassembling in some way. Let’s give them a try.

headline: A Woman I Regarded as a Hero, and New Doubts
text: While I was traveling in Vietnam and Burma, a story at Newsweek hit home. It charged that Somaly Mam, an activist against human trafficking in Cambodia, had fabricated elements of her background. Somaly has been a hero of mine, and I’ve written about her in my column, first in 2008 and most recently in 2011.

headline: Nicholas Kristof Should Give Readers a Full Explanation About Somaly Mam
text: A recent Newsweek cover story calls Somaly Mam the “Holy Saint (and Sinner) of Sex Trafficking.” It details the ways in which the Cambodian activist against sex trafficking fabricated at least some parts of her own story and the dramatic, heartrending stories of girls she said were sold into sex slavery.

headline: Democrats in Coal Country Run From E.P.A.

Billings were not disclosed. The campaign, the first such effort for Albania, will carry the theme “Go your own way.”

headline: Measuring the Apology of Network Rail in Britain
text: This is the second apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change.

headline: Hospital Charges Surge for Common Ailments, Data Shows
text: Charges for some of the most common inpatient procedures surged at hospitals across the country in 2012 from a year earlier, some at more than four times the national rate of inflation, according to data released by Medicare officials on Monday.

headline: Morning Views
text: Republican candidates are continuing to run against Obamacare, but will it work? The vast majority of Americans want the law improved, but not repealed, The New York Times editorial board says: “That sentiment conflicts with the Republican playbook, which party leaders are suddenly trying to rewrite. The result has been an incoherent mishmash of positions, as candidates try to straddle a widening gap between blind hatred of health reform and the public’s growing recognition that much of it is working.”

headline: The Perils of a Circumstantial Insider Trading Case
text: Insider trading is all about propitious timing. And trades by the golfer Phil Mickelson and William T. Walters, a high-rolling gambler, just before the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn made an unsolicited offer to buy Clorox in 2011 have all the signs of a potential violation: a quick increase in the stock price that made their risky call options worth millions of dollars. But timing alone is not enough to establish insider trading. So moving from suspicion to proving a violation requires much more than just timely trading and vague connections between a potential source and profitable trades.

headline: The Computer Code for Parental Feelings of Inadequacy
text: I’m starting to feel really guilty about coding.

headline: ScienceTake | The Longest Migration
text: Point to point, a zebra herd in Botswana and Namibia travels farther than any other African mammals, researchers say.

headline: Cause Marketing Effort Is Centered on the Negroni
text: The designation of weeks or months for cause-related marketing purposes has become so familiar that they now seem, in most instances, to fade into the woodwork. When almost every week or month is a “Week” or “Month,” they can lose their power to motivate consumers to become donors or lend a helping hand.

headline: What’s Black and White and Travels 310 Miles?
text: Given all the attention that has been paid to migrations of wildlife in Africa it’s a surprise to find a new one, not to mention one that is the longest of any on that continent.

headline: The Right and Misogyny
text: My column yesterday joined the crowded debate over the cultural significance (if any) of the Santa Barbara killer’s radioactive, misogynistic, sexually-frustrated rage. That debate has gone in any number of directions, but it’s often slipped into some well-worn right-left grooves, with writers on the feminist left tilting at capital-p Patriarchy and “traditional masculinity” and conservative commentators dismissing their arguments as victimology and ideological overreach. And as in another recent controversy, on rape and campus life, I’m a little dissatisfied with my own side’s approach: In their haste to critique too-sweeping indictments of masculinity/male privilege/”rape culture”/etc., it seems to me, some conservatives risk foreclosing the possibility that misogyny might be a real cultural problem, to which a certain amount of moral outrage and a certain kind of structural critique might both be healthy, legitimate responses.

headline: Spain’s King Juan Carlos Abdicates

Here are some things to know about the rule:

headline: Barbro Lindgren Wins Children’s Literature Prize
text: The Swedish author Barbro Lindgren was awarded the 2014 Astrid Lindgren Memorial Prize, the literary world’s largest award for children’s literature, at a ceremony at the Stockholm Concert Hall on Monday. The prize, which is named for the Swedish author and editor, who died in 2002, has been given annually since 2003, and is meant to honor a writer, illustrator or storyteller for a lifetime’s work. It includes a cash award of five million Swedish krona (about $748,000).

headline: Oliver Stone Plans a Film About Edward Snowden
text: LOS ANGELES – Oliver Stone, one of Hollywood’s most provocative directors, will make a movie about one of the world’s most divisive figures: Edward Snowden.

headline: The Scene | Holland’s Opus
text: Thanks to its quaint streets and picturesque canals, The Hague, a jewel of a city in South Holland, has long attracted a discerning international crowd. And with this month’s reopening of the renovated Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis, home to Vermeer’s “Girl With a Pearl Earring,” there’s more reason than ever to go. At the exuberantly packed antique store Il Mondo Stijl, tulipieres are transformed into lamps with oversize red shades, next to an Italian cachepot in the style of a Persian warrior and Capodimonte porcelain parrots. Rich with jewels of a different sort, Herman Romberg makes Tahitian pearl necklaces and turquoise drop earrings for a clientele that includes Queen Maxima and other members of the Dutch royal family. For those in search of culinary indulgence, there’s South of Houston, a French-American restaurant that serves dry-aged beef and elegant desserts. But perhaps The Hague’s grandest attraction is the Hotel Des Indes. Built as a palace in 1858, it has retained its Old World glamour — mirrored walls and marble columns — and it’s an ideal place to savor the city’s Dutch strawberries and Austrian sacher tortes.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Milestones Fall at Englishtown Drag Races
text: Weather conditions were perfect for record high speeds and close racing at the National Hot Rod Association’s Summernationals drag races at Englishtown, N.J., on Sunday. Richie Crampton achieved a milestone for himself and the sport with his Top Fuel victory. Crampton, an Australian competing in his ninth N.H.R.A. event, defeated the points leader, Doug Kalitta, in the final. In the process, he scored his first career Top Fuel victory. The N.H.R.A. said he became the 100th different driver to win in the Top Fuel category, in an official history that dates to 1963.

headline: The Sweet Surprise of Dry Riesling
text: Updated | July 8, 2014

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: No Nation Has Lowered Obesity Rate in 33 Years
text: Nearly 30 percent of the world’s population is overweight or obese, and not one country has reduced its obesity rate in 33 years, according to a new study combining three decades of data from 188 countries, published in The Lancet last month.

headline: On the Move Because of Global Warming
text: Light-colored species of butterflies and dragonflies in Europe like the heat, while dark-colored ones retreat northward to cooler areas. Because of climate change, lighter species are taking over areas once dominated by their darker counterparts, researchers report in the journal Nature Communications. Lighter insects can reflect sunlight more easily and prevent their bodies from overheating.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 30-June 1, 2014
text: • Elliot Rodger’s parents struggled for years to engage their troubled son with the world, the Times reported yesterday. The perpetrator of the May 23 rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., was described as a high-functioning autistic child prone to depression and anxiety who once had a panic attack so severe he had to be permanently withdrawn from school. “He wasn’t just a little withdrawn,” a family friend and spokesman said. “He was as withdrawn as any person I ever met in my life.”

headline: Podcast: Tattoos for Healing
text: Breast cancer survivors find the start of their new lives in a tattoo artist’s work.

headline: A Way With Words and a Spice Rack
text: I remember the first time I was in the kitchen with Maya Angelou. It happened in Sonoma, Calif., some 40 years ago. A mutual friend had been invited to spend a week, and I trailed along. Ms. Angelou maintained a home in that Mediterranean-looking town of red tile roofs in the wine country, complete with a guest suite in which we were comfortably ensconced. At dinnertime we walked up to the main house.

headline: Businesses May Have to Wait to Offer Employees a Choice of Health Plans
text: For small businesses that want to offer employees health insurance, there aren’t a lot of reasons to buy that coverage on the new Small Business Health Options, or SHOP, exchanges created by the Affordable Care Act. In fact, there are only two.

headline: After Nadal and Ferrer, Spanish Tennis Talent Pool Looks Thin
text: PARIS — The future of Spanish tennis may not be Spanish in the future.

headline: Growing Up on Raw Foods
text: Meals for Levi Bowland are pretty much the same every day. For breakfast, it’s melon. For lunch, a heaping bowl of coleslaw and three bananas. Dinner involves more fruit, and a salad.

headline: Hopes for Impact of Carbon Rules in U.S. Are Modest
text: The new carbon pollution rules the Obama administration announced on Monday will help spur the natural gas industry and renewable energy like wind and solar power, but executives and analysts said they did not see the nation’s reliance on coal disappearing anytime soon.

headline: Music Camp for Kids, Vacation for Parents
text: For parents potentially worried about sending their kids away to camp, one newcomer is simultaneous vacations – in Jamaica.

headline: A Favor for Grandpa? But This Is America
text: Now that he has landed a junior position at the prestigious Century magazine in New York, Slava Gelman, the restless, thwarted hero of Boris Fishman’s “A Replacement Life,” decides it is time to become an American.

headline: The Forests of the Ocean
text: The secret to finding unsuspected beauty, artists and naturalists will tell you, is in knowing how to slow down and really look. The writer and photographer Josie Iselin certainly knows how to do that, as she shows in her beguiling new book, “An Ocean Garden.”

headline: On Separate Islands, Crickets Go Silent
text: In 2003, a number of male field crickets on the Hawaiian island of Kauai were born without the ability to chirp.  Two years later, the same thing happened on Oahu.

headline: Justices Enter Into Dispute Over Districts Alabama Set
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider challenges from Democratic lawmakers who say the Alabama Legislature packed minority voters into a few districts, diluting their voting power.

text: The bar for winning our annual found poetry contest just keeps getting higher.

headline: Lurking Just Beneath This Surface ...
text: “Next Time on Lonny” is a Web series — a first season of six episodes appeared in 2011, and a second season begins on Tuesday. There was every reason for “Lonny” to be lost in the slush pile of short comedy videos online, but for one thing: Ben Stiller liked it. So if you want to know what Mr. Stiller thinks is funny, you can see for yourself over the next four weeks at maker.tv and on YouTube.

headline: Gallery | Julian Wasser’s Photographs of the California Dream, and its Underbelly
text: On the cover of “The Way We Were” (Damiani Books, $60) — the first monograph by the legendary lensman Julian Wasser — a vast cloud of smoke issues from Steve McQueen’s pursed lips. Coming from a veneer so tough — collar starched, eyes concealed behind dark glasses — it’s the single note of expression, the breath the only proof the man is man and not made of wax. Herein lies the unreal reality of Wasser’s California: in this exhalation is all the nostalgia of a dream once dreamed. And despite the misty-eyed title of his book capturing the heyday of L.A. celebrity and counterculture, “the fact is, everything you heard about living in Los Angeles in the early ’60s was really true,” the photographer says. “It was a golden age and a hopeful time.”

headline: How Cats See in the Dark
text: Q. Does the slit shape of a cat’s pupil confer any advantages over the more rounded pupils of other animals?

headline: Is Andrew Cuomo Liberal?
text: New York’s Gov. Andrew Cuomo has spent almost four years trying to carve out a comfortable central spot in the state’s political spectrum. He is now known as a fiscal conservative who lowers taxes (even on the rich) and cuts costs (even for struggling communities), and as a social progressive who supports gun control and gay marriage

headline: E.P.A. Unveils Plan to Slash Pollution
text: The Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Gina McCarthy, announced a plan that aims to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.

headline: Isabel Toledo’s Beauty and Fitness Regimen
text: Born in Cuba and raised in West New York, N.J., Isabel Toledo, 54, has been designing a namesake women’s wear line since 1984. Aside from dressing Michelle Obama on occasion and collaborating with Lane Bryant, Ms. Toledo designed the costumes for the Broadway musical “After Midnight,” for which she’s been nominated for her first Tony Award (the ceremony is Sunday). She lives and works with her husband, the illustrator Ruben Toledo, in Manhattan. BEE SHAPIRO

headline: Doctors Aren’t Strongly Republican Anymore
text: American doctors have shifted their political support away from Republicans toward Democrats, according to a study released on Monday.

headline: The Serious Playfulness of a Rising Composer, and How It Has Spread
text: Few composers have seen their American reputations rise as swiftly in recent years as George Benjamin’s. Buoyed by the ecstatic international reaction to his 2012 opera, “Written on Skin,” which is to have its New York stage premiere next year, his newfound status is such that it was perfectly reasonable for him to be one of just two composers whose influence was celebrated by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s over the weekend as part of the NY Phil Biennial.

headline: The Nipple Artist
text: A tattoo parlor in Finksburg, Md., has become an unlikely destination for breast cancer survivors.

headline: A Tattoo That Completes a New Breast
text: FINKSBURG, MD. — A tattoo parlor here has become a mecca for an unlikely crowd: women with breast cancer.

headline: Two Royal Ballet Dancers to Skip Russian Tour in Protest
text: Two Royal Ballet dancers have decided not to join the Royal Ballet’s upcoming tour to Russia, as a protest against the antigay legislation supported by President Vladimir V. Putin. The company would not name the dancers or give their rank, although The Independent described them as “senior” company members.

headline: May the World Be Their Oyster
text: On a recent Friday afternoon, the Broadway actresses Ingrid Craigie, Gillian Hanna and June Watson took a car to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to view Kara Walker’s “A Subtlety.” They stepped into the shuttered Domino Sugar Factory, pausing to view the enormous central figure, with its African features and Aunt Jemima kerchief, crouched sphinxlike at the far end of the floor.

headline: Exploring the Photographic Spirit
text: Raised on family tales of an old haunted farmhouse, Elizabeth Moran grew up to join relatives turned ghost-hunters in Memphis.

headline: Ciro de Quadros, 74, Dies; Leader in Ridding Latin America of Polio
text: Dr. Ciro de Quadros, a Brazilian epidemiologist who navigated war zones and reimagined outmoded public health practices to lead an immunization campaign that eradicated polio in Latin America and the Caribbean, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 74.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ Ahead of Tony Awards
text: After the Tony Award winners are announced on Sunday night, what will happen to ticket sales for two of Broadway’s most-nominated musicals, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” and “After Midnight”?

headline: When Coral Reefs Thrive, So Does Variety in Fish
text: The fish that live off the Malay Archipelago, between Southeast Asia and Australia, are among the most diverse in the world. Now researchers are reporting that the area owes its diversity to the stability of coral reefs over the past three million years.

headline: Brave, New and Lifted by Magic
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Shakespeare’s late romance “The Tempest” itself undergoes a sea change in the inventive production of the play at American Repertory Theater here. The magic of Prospero has a razzle-dazzle allure in this freshly reimagined, steampunk-stylish production, directed and adapted by Aaron Posner and Teller (of the magic-meisters Penn and Teller) and featuring songs judiciously culled from the Tom Waits catalog.

headline: Filing by Computer: A Pillow Helped
text: I was in a $6-an-hour motel in Oakdale, on Long Island, about 50 miles from Times Square. It was going to be my first time.

headline: Velocity, Vulnerability and Youth
text: The School of American Ballet, founded by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein, is 80 years old this year. Inevitably, the anniversary calls for a staging of “Serenade,”  the first ballet choreographed by Balanchine on American soil, for the school’s annual workshop showings. There are three performances; I caught the second, on Saturday evening. “Serenade” began the program of Balanchine dances; excerpts from his one-act “Swan Lake” and the third act of “Coppélia” followed; the finale was the last movement of “Western Symphony.”

headline: Facing Jail: Highlights From a Reporter’s Career

text: Nearly everything about Salesforce.com is remarkable.

headline: A Star-Gazing Palace’s Hazy Future
text: James Lick, a piano manufacturer and land baron in 19th-century California, wanted to build himself a pyramid, but a friend persuaded him to leave his money to science. And so it came to be that Lick was buried under a telescope on Mount Hamilton, 30 miles south of San Francisco.

headline: New Costumes for a Balanchine Classic
text: New York City Ballet recreates costumes for its new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

headline: A ‘Midsummer’ Costume Redo
text: Figuring out how to remake 104 of the costumes that the designer Barbara Karinska created more than a half-century ago for the fairies and foolish mortals of George Balanchine’s ballet “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” for Tuesday night’s opening performance required detective work, millinery archaeology and a scavenger hunt for material that eventually led to three continents.

headline: Automating Cybersecurity

headline: Less Carbon, More Energy
text: The Environmental Protection Agency’s new rule sets a goal for each state based on its carbon dioxide emissions divided by its electricity generation. A chart showing where each state stands.

headline: Q. and A.: Liu Heung Shing on Photographing Tiananmen
text: The Hong Kong-born photojournalist Liu Heung Shing, who shared a 1992 Pulitzer Prize for documenting an attempted coup in Russia, now lives in Beijing, where he devotes most of his time to organizing photo exhibitions and editing books on historical photos of China. His own photos from China are themselves an archive of the country’s astounding changes since the death of Mao Zedong. His images for Time magazine and The Associated Press in China in the late 1970s and early 1980s have been collected in “China After Mao.”

headline: Listen Up | Hercules and Love Affair Makes a Case for House Music
text: “America has never fully had its house music moment,” says Andy Butler — better known by his moniker Hercules and Love Affair — via Skype while vacationing in Brussels. “In Europe, it’s another story. I feel it’s a rite of passage for people to go to the discotheque.” Butler is an American through and through (he got his start D.J.ing around Denver and attended Sarah Lawrence College), but you wouldn’t know it from Hercules and Love Affair’s distinctly Continental sound. “Audiences there have a tradition of integrating dance music in pop culture,” he explains. Indeed, Butler’s breakout hit, 2008’s “Blind,” had its biggest reception in Italy, and was received warmly in Britain as well. If there’s anyone in a position to get statesiders dancing, though, it’s Butler — thanks especially to his energetic third album, “The Feast of the Broken Heart,” just released on Big Beat/Atlantic Records.

headline: The Overwhelming Maleness of “Silicon Valley”
text: Since its premiere, “Silicon Valley” has prompted discussion of sexism in the actual Silicon Valley. The show’s season finale offers perhaps its best illustration yet of the male-dominated nature of the tech industry — but whether that illustration will rise to the level of critique remains an open question.

headline: Miranda Lambert, Country’s Sophisticated Radical
text: MIRANDA LAMBERT

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Effectiveness of Chrysler’s Air Bag Recall
text: Chrysler has repaired only about 13 percent of the 745,000 Jeep sport utility vehicles affected by a 2012 recall, and now the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether the automaker’s attempt to fix an air bag-related problem is working.

headline: Target Gives a Defense of Its Efforts on Security
text: In advance of next week’s annual shareholders’ meeting, Target on Monday defended its management and oversight of customer data despite the extensive hacking it experienced last year.

headline: Why Democrats Have Little to Lose in Taking On the Coal Industry
text: The Obama administration’s proposal Monday to reduce carbon emissions from coal-fired power plants is already being characterized by Republicans as the latest salvo in a “war on coal.”

headline: Boutique Inns, Chain Hotels and the Business Traveler

headline: For Now, Sponsors Unlikely to Cut Ties With Phil Mickelson
text: Professional athletes can earn millions of dollars by advertising everything from soda to mutual funds. But those lucrative endorsement deals can disappear — quickly — if a brand decides that its chosen superstar may no longer be good for its image.

headline: Thai Protesters Flash ‘Hunger Games’ Salute to Register Quiet Dissent
text: Having banned public protests, Thailand’s military faces a new challenge: how to treat citizens who make a three-fingered salute, a sign of resistance borrowed by opponents of last month’s coup from “The Hunger Games,” The Bangkok Post reported.

headline: Food Matters | David Shrigley Puts His Twisted Spin on the Interior of the London Restaurant Sketch
text: “Less death and defecation. Fewer swear words. A lot of things about cooking.” These principles have much to recommend them, the artist David Shrigley explains, when you are redesigning a restaurant.

headline: Judge Dismisses Legal Challenges to Defunct Library Plan

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 10
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ex-Brooklyn Prosecutor Charles J. Hynes Accused of Misuse of Funds
text: A New York City Department of Investigation inquiry has implicated Charles J. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, in the improper use of money seized from drug dealers and other criminal defendants to pay a political consultant more than $200,000 for his work on Mr. Hynes’s unsuccessful re-election campaign last year.

headline: Mixed Drinks for Shaken Passengers
text: I’M a lucky person. By the age of 33, I’ve had the pleasure of visiting four continents, 30 countries and more than 100 cities all over the world. I once traveled for 21 days straight, visiting three continents in three weeks, with more than 18 hours’ worth of time zone changes.

headline: Report Calls for Huge Investment in Energy Development
text: LONDON — Enormous amounts of capital investment — up to $2.5 trillion a year — will be needed to supply the world’s energy needs through 2035, according to a report released Monday by the International Energy Agency, the intergovernmental organization based in Paris.

headline: ‘Vanishing Island’
text: Although it’s only 80 miles from New Orleans, the Isle de Jean Charles feels much farther away. It’s literally at the end of the road, connected to the mainland by a little two-lane strip of asphalt with water lapping at its edges.

headline: A U.S. Midfielder Goes on the Offensive
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Several times during the United States national team’s match Sunday against Turkey, midfielder Michael Bradley drifted so far forward that he was lined up with striker Jozy Altidore near the Turks’ penalty area. At that point, Bradley had almost stopped being a midfielder and was essentially a third forward.

headline: The Writing Workshop Glossary
text: Most writers, at some point in their lives, join a writers’ workshop, a weekly gathering of a dozen or so scribes who read one another’s work and offer constructive criticism in a group setting. They hope that by sharing their material and receiving feedback they will improve their craft. But take it from me, putting your work out there for critique can be a difficult – and even mysterious – process. Here is a glossary that can help you understand the terms you may hear in a workshop:

headline: Massachusetts Sues Fannie and Freddie Over Foreclosure Law
text: Martha Coakley, the attorney general of Massachusetts, filed suit on Monday against Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in an effort to force the federally owned mortgage finance giants to comply with a state antiforeclosure law passed in 2012.

headline: Smoke in the Water
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — NO ONE is exactly sure when Duke Energy’s coal ash pit adjacent to the Dan River in north-central North Carolina began leaking toxic coal ash into the waterway. What is known is that by the time the leak was discovered, in early February, more than 39,000 tons of coal ash and millions of gallons of contaminated water had spilled into the river near the town of Eden, N.C. — making it the third largest coal ash spill in American history.

headline: The Theater Beyond the Clintons

headline: Birds Leave Nest Involuntarily, and Oakland Fumes
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — It started as a well-intentioned attempt by the United States Postal Service here to rid its trucks of bird droppings: A tree trimmer was hired to prune the lush ficus trees that grow next to the post office’s parking lot, not far from City Hall. But in the course of the job, five baby black-crowned night herons fell from their nests and were injured.

headline: The Art of Focus
text: Like everyone else, I am losing the attention war. I toggle over to my emails when I should be working. I text when I should be paying attention to the people in front of me. I spend hours looking at mildly diverting stuff on YouTube. (“Look, there’s a bunch of guys who can play ‘Billie Jean’ on beer bottles!”)

headline: Subway Expands Its Slate of Original Web Shows

headline: Health Experts See Benefits in Push to Cut Pollution
text: The Obama administration contends that its new plan to cut carbon pollution from power plants will not just fight climate change, but will also quickly improve public health, preventing up to 100,000 asthma attacks and 2,100 heart attacks in the first year the rules take effect.

headline: Strategy and Objectives for Gaining Soldier’s Release Shifted Over Time
text: WASHINGTON — For two and a half years, the Obama administration maneuvered to make a deal to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl the start of a larger peace process for Afghanistan, one that would ease the American exit from the country.

headline: Freedom for Sgt. Bergdahl, at a Price
text: It would be extremely coldhearted not to feel relief that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is back in American hands after being held captive by the Taliban for nearly five years. American soldiers need to know their government will not abandon them if they are taken prisoner, especially with the war in Afghanistan in its prolonged final stage.

headline: Pilgrim’s Pride Raises Its Bid for Hillshire, Topping Tyson
text: Updated, 10:27 p.m. | Pilgrim’s Pride has raised its takeover bid for Hillshire Brands, people briefed on the matter said Monday, turning up the heat in a battle over the maker of Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park hot dogs.
