text: After a presidential election on Tuesday and continued diplomatic maneuvering, the United States’ approach in the three-year crisis.

headline: The World Cup Draw Is Unfair. Here’s a Better Way.
text: The controversy over December’s World Cup draw — in which France’s placement was hotly debated and United States fans were left bemoaning their fate — was symptomatic of the system’s fundamental flaws.

headline: Mets Lose Lead in 8th and Game in the 9th
text: CHICAGO — As the night wore on, and the Mets and the Cubs entered the eighth inning of a one-run game, the fans at Wrigley Field waited quietly. They had no reason to cheer, but no reason to leave. The game was still somehow anyone’s to win, because the Mets were just as inexplicable as their Cubs. Both teams were talented enough to get runners on base, and inept enough to strand most of them there.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 6:45 P.M. (Starz) WHITE HOUSE DOWN (2013) A police officer and former soldier (Channing Tatum) interviewing for a job with the Secret Service (he doesn’t get it) finds himself in the White House at the very moment it is overrun by a paramilitary group in this action-adventure directed by Roland Emmerich. Jamie Foxx (above right, with Mr. Tatum) plays the president, who needs saving — from the terrorists, and from big business — if only for his workable peace plan for the Middle East. And Maggie Gyllenhaal, James Woods, Richard Jenkins, Lance Reddick and Jason Clarke portray the administration’s team players. The film “is as demented and entertaining as promised, and a little less idiotic than feared,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Emmerich “makes the opening siege unsettling enough to grab your attention and then, once he has it, begins folding in lighter moments — one-liners, cartoonish bits of business, laughably impossible situations and stunts — that ensure that at least this American collapse doesn’t end up feeling too heavy.” He “gives it the pow,” she added, “while Mr. Tatum provides the pulse.”

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York
text: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday and Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: In New Jersey, a Republican Nominee Will Try to Hold On to a Congressional Seat
text: A wealthy insurance executive beat a perennial conservative candidate in the Republican primary in New Jersey’s Third Congressional District Tuesday, a result that may frustrate Democrats hoping to take advantage of its closely divided politics.

headline: Corrections: June 4, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Yankees Still Searching for Runs and Victories
text: During the first four games of the Yankees’ current homestand, Manager Joe Girardi often referred to the dearth of power hitters in his lineup as the team scored only eight runs and lost three times.

headline: Wave of Minors on Their Own Rush to Cross Southwest Border
text: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — After a decade apart, 13-year-old Robin Tulio was finally heading to the border to be with his mother. A maid, living illegally in Baltimore, she had decided the time was right to smuggle her son into the United States.

headline: Egypt: Sisi Wins With 97 Percent
text: Egypt’s elections commission on Tuesday formally declared the former defense chief, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the winner of last week’s pro forma presidential election with nearly 97 percent of the vote. Turnout was about 47 percent of eligible voters, far short of what he had sought to prove he had a mandate to lead and less than the 52 percent who voted in the 2012 election won by Mohamed Morsi, whom Mr. Sisi overthrew last year. Foreign observers have said the election fell short of international standards.

headline: Yemen: Deadly Fighting Flares
text: The most recent flare-up in the long-running fight between the Yemeni Army and Shiite insurgents in the country’s north has killed hundreds of people in the past three weeks, local officials said Tuesday. The clashes, in Amran Province, began when the rebels sought to claim new territory closer to the capital, said Ahmad al-Bakry, the province’s deputy governor. He said more than 500 people had been killed, including 100 rebels and 20 soldiers in the past two days. The toll could not be independently verified. On Monday, the government sent jets to bomb rebel areas after rebels came close to taking over a government checkpoint, Mr. Bakry said. A Houthi rebel leader, Ali al-Bikhiti, linked the violence to grievances over governmental neglect. “What is happening in Amran is a revolt against injustice,” Mr. Bikhiti said.

headline: Saudi Arabia: MERS Toll Revised
text: Saudi Arabia revised sharply upward the number of cases of the new MERS virus within its borders and said it had been fatal in more than 40 percent of the cases. After a review of medical records, the country’s total number of cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome since the virus was isolated in 2012 is now 688, up from 575; the death toll is 282, not 190. The country has had a surge of cases since March — many apparently originating in hospitals — but they seem to be falling off, an adviser to the Health Ministry said. That surge led to the dismissal of the health minister, and on Monday, his replacement dismissed the deputy health minister who has been the public face of the country’s response. The deputy, Dr. Ziad Memish, was recently  profiled in The Lancet for his preparations for the annual visit to Mecca by up to three million Muslims. Most of the 133 new cases are from March and April, suggesting that many were either not tested or not reported.

headline: Where Bergdahl Disappeared
text: Maps of where Bowe Bergdahl was stationed and the initial operations to find him.

headline: Growth Has Been Good for Decades. So Why Hasn’t Poverty Declined?
text: The surest way to fight poverty is to achieve stronger economic growth. That, anyway, is a view embedded in the thinking of a lot of politicians and economists.

headline: Jury Announced for Guggenheim Helsinki Museum Design Competition
text: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and Helsinki city officials announced details of an open international design competition on Wednesday for a proposed new 130-million-euro museum along the South Harbor of the Finnish capital.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Democrats Shouldn’t Dream in Mississippi, Where a Runoff Looms
text: After a night of surprising regional shifts in voter turnout Tuesday, neither Thad Cochran, an incumbent Republican senator in Mississippi, nor Chris McDaniel, a state senator backed by Tea Party groups, appeared to reach the 50 percent necessary to avoid a runoff in Mississippi’s Republican Senate primary.

headline: G.O.P. Nominee for Governor Faces an Uphill Climb in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Neel Kashkari, the newly named Republican nominee for governor of California, has a big task ahead of him: start remaking a party that does not hold a single statewide office, wields almost no power in the State Legislature and has suffered a seemingly inexorable erosion of its share of the state’s registered voters, now at just over 28 percent.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 4, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Dufry to Buy Duty-Free Rival for About $1.7 Billion
text: LONDON – Dufry, the operator of duty-free and other airport retail locations, said on Wednesday that it would pay 1.55 billion Swiss francs, or about $1.73 billion, to acquire its Swiss rival, Nuance Group.

headline: Obama, Seeking Unity on Russia, Meets Obstacles
text: BRUSSELS — President Obama started his day in Warsaw struggling to convince his friends in Central and Eastern Europe that the United States is being tough enough with Russia. He ended his day in Brussels, still struggling, but this time to persuade America’s core Western allies to stay tough with Russia.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | New U.S. Effort to Aid Unaccompanied Child Migrants
text: In “New U.S. Effort to Aid Unaccompanied Child Migrants,” Julia Preston writes about problems caused by the numbers of unaccompanied young people crossing the border.

headline: The Big Dig
text: Shucked or steamed, clams are easier to enjoy all summer long than you think.

headline: How Jurgen Klinsmann Plans to Make U.S. Soccer Better (and Less American)
text: Even before he exiled the most accomplished and iconic player in United States soccer history and before his presumptive top goal scorer went nearly an entire season without scoring goals and before he knew whom, exactly, his team was actually going to play, Jurgen Klinsmann was sure he was going to lose.

headline: Iran Offers a Window to the West
text: Earlier this year, Getty Images asked the photographer John Moore if he wanted to see how open Iran’s new president was to Western news media. Mr. Moore, a senior staff photographer for Getty, was game. He had been there once — 10 years ago — to cover parliamentary elections. This time, Getty encouraged him to follow his own interests and itinerary. He decided on a road trip.

headline: When Do You Write by Hand?
text: Do you take notes in school, write letters, keep a pen-and-paper diary or do any other kind of regular writing by hand, or do you type almost everything?

headline: Border Guards in Ukraine Abandon Posts
text: CHERVONOPARTIZANSK, Ukraine — Border guards here, near the Russian border in eastern Ukraine, fled their posts for fear of attacks by separatist militias on Wednesday, helping open a strategic corridor for the transport of goods, contraband and war material from Russia that could lead to a widening of the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Analysis of President Obama’s Speech
text: Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, was in Warsaw with President Obama reporting on the president’s speech commemorating the 25th anniversary of elections in Poland that led to the end of Communist rule. You can read Mr. Baker’s article on nytimes.com and follow him on Twitter - @peterbakernyt.

headline: Through Miss India and Its Critics, Two Approaches to Women’s Empowerment
text: When Nisha Pahuja began filming the Miss India pageant in 2008, she envisioned the documentary as a portrait of India careening towards modernity through the lens of the pageant contestants.  But over time, Ms. Pahuja found herself drawn to another side of the story: India’s protest movement against these beauty contests, led largely by conservative religious groups here.

headline: Carlyle in Talks for Majority Stake in French Campsite Operator

headline: Militants Attack Pakistani Army, Killing 6 Soldiers and Setting Back Peace Talks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Suspected Islamist militants attacked the Pakistani Army near a high-security military complex and along the Afghan border on Wednesday, killing six soldiers and three civilians in separate attacks that offered the clearest indication yet that faltering peace talks with the Taliban had effectively collapsed.

headline: Crowds Gather in Hong Kong for Anniversary of Tiananmen Crackdown
text: HONG KONG — Tens of thousands gathered at a central park in Hong Kong on Wednesday to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, even as a stifling security presence in Beijing and elsewhere in mainland China appeared to forestall protests.

headline: Sallie Krawcheck Opens an Index Fund Focused on Women
text: When Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former big bank executive, bought a women’s network last year, she said she wanted to “move from advocacy of women to the smart business of real investment in women.”

headline: Taliban Deftly Offer Message in Video of Freed U.S. Soldier
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban seem loose, almost offhand, on camera as they wait for the American Black Hawk to land. Two fighters walk their hostage, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, out to American troops, greeting their enemies eye to eye as they quickly shake hands. They wave as the Americans retreat back to the chopper.

headline: The Path to Workers, and Their Stories, in Abu Dhabi
text: Last month, Ariel Kaminer wrote about the harsh conditions that construction workers faced during the building of the New York University campus in Abu Dhabi. A reporter on the Metro desk, she usually measures her travel expenses in subway fares. Here she tells of the challenges and rewards of reporting a story that is far from her usual beat.

headline: TV Apps Are Soaring in Popularity, Report Says
text: When it comes to online video, people may not want to cut the cord. Instead, they want to take the cord with them. People are streaming broadcast television on their smartphones in record numbers, according to Adobe’s state-of-the-industry report on digital video viewing.

headline: Kristof Recalls a Bloody Day in Beijing
text: “To be an American on the square this morning was to be the object of fervent hope and inarticulate pleas for help,” Nicholas Kristof wrote on the day of the bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square 25 years ago today. He and his wife, Sheryl WuDunn, won the Pulitzer Prize for their coverage of the democracy movement in China and its suppression. We asked Nicholas, now a Times Op-Ed columnist, to recall the events of that day. We include some of his articles from that tumultuous time.

headline: Why I’m Rethinking My Investment in E-Commerce
text: I have been selling furniture and accessories online for about six years. Two years ago, we realized that we needed to upgrade our website if we wanted to keep up, so we went out and hired a company to rebuild it from scratch. We went with a developer that works with the popular Magento platform, and the site came out very well. As a matter of fact, it won an award from one of the magazines that give out awards.

headline: Lithuania Moves Closer to Joining Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — The looming deflation. The rising tide of anti-European populism. The near-record unemployment.

headline: Musée Picasso in Paris Names New President

headline: The Department Store Wars Are Heating Up
text: The war chests are growing in the department store world, in case you hadn’t noticed. Today Richard Baker, the owner of Hudson’s Bay Company, the Canadian department store chain that bought Saks Fifth Avenue last summer (and also owns Lord & Taylor) told WWD he planned to invest “$40 million” in the group’s digital activities this year — this on top of the $1 billion new-ish president Marigay McKee told me earlier has already been allotted to revamping the Saks chain over the next five years.

headline: Morning Agenda: BNP’s Secret Weapon Misfired
text: BNP Paribas, under investigation for doing business with Sudan and other countries that the United States has blacklisted, is weeks away from having its parent company plead guilty to the crime. But several months ago, BNP thought it had a secret weapon to avoid that fate altogether, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write. BNP showed prosecutors a memo that the bank thought would explain and possibly mitigate its conduct.

headline: A Tupac for Everyone

Mr. Kreidler was assisting Wilson as he brought his play “King Hedley II” to Broadway, but really he was there to learn whatever Wilson wanted to teach him. And that morning, the subject was Tupac Shakur.

headline: Tony Award Predictions: Leading Actress in a Play
text: Will Audra McDonald make history Sunday by winning her sixth Tony Award, the most ever in acting, for her performance as Billie Holliday in “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar and Grill”? Or do you think LaTanya Richardson Jackson will prevail in the race for best actress in a play, for her star turn as Lena Younger in “A Raisin in the Sun”? And where does the intense competition in this category leave Cherry Jones, who delivered a much-discussed portrayal of Amanda in “The Glass Menagerie”?

headline: Morning Views

The online retail giant is blocking or slowing the sales of Hachette’s books — including the imprint Little, Brown. Amazon wants “to get the best deal for itself,” writes The New York Times editorial board, “while it squeezes publishers, annoys its customers and hurts authors by limiting their sales.”

headline: A Hybrid Camera That May Be All You Need
text: SHOPPING for a camera used to be a fairly simple proposition, even just a couple of years ago. Sure, there were a lot of models, but you were either buying a cheap and compact point-and-shoot digital camera or an expensive and big digital camera with interchangeable lenses, known as a digital single-lens reflex.

headline: Bold Sounds: Orchestras Honored for ‘Adventurous Programming’
text: ASCAP, the performing rights organization that collects royalties for composers, songwriters and publishers, and the League of American Orchestras, a service organization for the country’s symphonic ensembles, announced Wednesday that 27 American orchestras would receive the 2013-14 ASCAP Awards for Adventurous Programming. The awards are to be presented at a ceremony during the league’s national conference, which is being held in Seattle, Wednesday through Friday.

text: Welcome to Op-Talk, a new service from The New York Times with a big mission: To bring you, our readers, the most interesting opinion and commentary from all over.

headline: Desire in High Gear
text: Here is your Urban Dictionary lesson of the week: A “village bicycle” is slang for a local slut — everyone in town has ridden the bike, you see. The term has a double meaning, though, in Penelope Skinner’s play “The Village Bike,” making its American debut in an MCC Theater production. In the play, Becky (Greta Gerwig) is pregnant and hormonal and her sex drive is healthier than ever, but her husband seems to have completely lost interest in sex. Adventures ensue when she turns to pornography and then buys a used bike (an actual one) from a man known for his promiscuity.

headline: Three Sweet Spots for Camera Shoppers
text: BUYING a camera means mentally preparing yourself for two things: an investment that can range from a couple of hundred dollars to several thousand dollars, and, potentially, a multiday dive into thousands of specifications, reviews and opinions to figure out which one to buy.

headline: Obama Backs Ukraine’s New President
text: President Obama met with President-elect Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine in Warsaw and offered the United States’s support to Kiev.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 8
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Incumbent in Mississippi Runoff Aims for More Than Just G.O.P. Votes
text: FLOWOOD, Miss. — Senator Thad Cochran’s supporters opened Mississippi’s Republican Senate runoff on Wednesday by signaling that they would treat the race like a general election and seek the votes of Democrats and independents during the three-week campaign against State Senator Chris McDaniel.

headline: In Unusual Collaboration, Police and Prosecutors Team Up to Reduce Crime
text: With murders having reached a low point in Manhattan, the Manhattan district attorney’s office and the Police Department have begun an unusually close collaboration aimed at driving down other crimes, chief among them grand larceny, domestic violence and cybercrime.

headline: When Courts Consider Evidence, Abortion Supporters Win
text: At a time when burdensome restrictions enacted in Republican-led states are threatening women’s access to abortion care, it is all the more vital that courts scrutinize phony claims that new laws actually protect women’s health and safety.

headline: New York City Soda Fight, in Court, Tests Agency’s Power

headline: Victory in Syrian Election Is Show of Assad’s Control
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Wednesday celebrated his overwhelming victory in a deeply disputed election, asserting his confidence and defiance in the Syrian conflict as supporters savored his success in thwarting the United States.

headline: East Northport, L.I.: Good Schools, Good Neighbors
text: When Erin Chavez, a college history teacher, and her husband, Daniel, a special-education teacher, moved to East Northport with their two young children two years ago, they had chosen their house mainly for its low price, convenient location and good school system. They got warm and friendly neighbors in the bargain.

headline: Risking a Health Insurance Strategy the I.R.S. May Not Approve
text: When it came time to renew his company’s health plan last fall, Jerry Eledge found himself in a bind that many small-business owners know all too well.

headline: Overruled, Judge Still Left a Mark on S.E.C. Agenda
text: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | Jed S. Rakoff is a maverick jurist who picked a three-year fight to make the Securities and Exchange Commission tougher on a Wall Street bank.

headline: Venice Mayor Is Arrested on Corruption Charges
text: ROME — The Italian authorities on Wednesday arrested the mayor of Venice and more than 30 others in a political corruption case linked to the city’s multibillion dollar flood-protection project. The arrests came only weeks after investigators revealed an embarrassing corruption scandal involving projects for next year’s Milan Expo.

headline: The Fight Against Fake Drugs
text: In November 2008, children in Nigeria taking a medicine called My Pikin Baby Teething Mixture began to die. The syrup was counterfeit, the standard glycerin replaced with cheaper diethylene glycol, which looks, smells and tastes the same. But diethylene glycol is an industrial solvent, which attacks the central nervous system, kidneys and liver. The medicine killed 84 children before it was pulled from pharmacy shelves.

headline: Feeling For | Modern Basics Dyed With Ancient Medicinal Plants
text: Blandine de Verdelhan and Marie-Louise Mogensen, the France- and Denmark-based designers of Baserange, have made it their mission to produce minimal, functional clothing and underpinnings as sustainably as possible. The duo’s latest offering, debuting exclusively on Net-a-Porter today, is a capsule collection that highlights what de Verdelhan calls “a key part of the environmental footprint of making garments”: dye. The six-piece assortment gets its striking shade from woad, a medicinal plant in the broccoli family that the designers discovered in a workshop in a village near Toulouse, France. The ancient species was a key component of southern France’s economy during the Medieval and Renaissance eras; royalty and high society, including Napoleon, favored it for its distinctive blue hue. It’s also known for the anti-inflammatory and healing properties it provides when applied to the skin, and is unusual in the way that it continues to “live” as a garment ages. “The color grows stronger as you wash the material, and, if left in the closet, it will become irregular,” explains Verdelhan. “It’s such a beautiful, particular blue, and is quite important in Toulouse. There, all the shutters are painted in this color. It’s quite lovely.”

headline: Dozens of Gang Suspects Held in Raids in Manhattan
text: Police officers in body armor swooped into two Manhattan housing projects at dawn on Wednesday in simultaneous raids aimed at scores of suspected gang members indicted on charges of planning and carrying out tit-for-tat gun battles stretching back to the 2011 murder of an 18-year-old basketball star.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘I want to be a pilot’
text: This poem, by  Kayla C., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from an Opinionator essay, “Parenting the Non-Girlie Girl.”

headline: Colon Cancer Screening Saves Lives
text: Widespread screening for colorectal cancer has helped prevent an estimated half-million cases of the disease since the mid- 1970s, a new study suggests.

headline: Dalit Protesters In Delhi Sit-In Brush With Police
text: NEW DELHI – Just before 6 a.m. on Wednesday, several police officers entered Jantar Mantar, the site of frequent protests in the capital.

headline: New York vs. Los Angeles: Rivalry Revived
text: LOS ANGELES — They are the two largest cities in the United States, divided by 3,000 diagonal miles of North American continent and a chasm of conflicting stereotypes. Theirs is a complex relationship.

headline: Travelport, Backed by Blackstone, Files for an I.P.O.
text: Travelport Worldwide, a travel services company backed by the Blackstone Group, filed on Wednesday to sell shares in an initial public offering.

headline: Channing, Abraham and Mullally to Join ‘It’s Only a Play’ on Broadway
text: The Tony Award winner Stockard Channing, the Oscar winner F. Murray Abraham and the Emmy winner Megan Mullally will join Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick on Broadway in a newly revised version of Terrence McNally’s 1980s comedy “It’s Only a Play,” the producers said on Wednesday. The show centers on an anxious playwright (Mr. Broderick); his best friend (Mr. Lane), who has left theater for television; the producer (Ms. Mullally) and a diva star (Ms. Channing) of the playwright’s new show; and a hypocritical drama critic (Mr. Abraham). The ensemble will also include Micah Stock as a coat check attendant; casting for the roles of the play’s director and a taxi driver will be announced later. The production, which reunites Mr. Lane and Mr. Broderick years after their starring roles in Broadway’s “The Producers” and the 2005 revival of “The Odd Couple,” will begin performances in late summer at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater and open on Oct. 9. Jack O’Brien will direct.

headline: Decent Draw and Rising Hopes for California Chrome
text: There has always been a sense of destiny surrounding California Chrome — his owners called him their Kentucky Derby horse as soon as he hit the ground. They were right, and after the colt won the Preakness Stakes, too, the air of inevitably has only thickened.

headline: The New Face of ‘Networking’
text: The anemic labor market has forced the unemployed into various contortions in their efforts to get a job. The latest: joining a special social network so that maybe, someday, they can work for Zappos.

headline: Would You Try This Health Insurance Strategy With Your Company?
text: In March, we interviewed Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel, a doctor who advised the Obama administration on the Affordable Care Act. Dr. Emanuel had just published a book in which he predicted that within a decade, private employers would largely abandon providing health insurance to employees. This, he said, would happen even though such coverage benefits from a big tax break.

headline: Hillary Speaks! But Oh So Carefully.
text: And now we enter the Period of Parsing. What you are about to behold will make all prior textual analyses — of scripture, of scrolls — look like halfhearted child’s play.

headline: Iran’s Leader Says Obama Has Removed Military Option
text: TEHRAN — Speaking from a stage decorated with a banner proclaiming “America cannot do a damn thing,” Iran’s supreme leader on Wednesday asserted that the Obama administration had taken the option of military intervention to resolve conflicts off the table.

headline: Exclamation Points for the Ear
text: The way the jewelry designer Lisa Salzer of Lulu Frost sees it, the return of chandelier earrings can be credited to the Céline fall runway, where they dangled solo in every single look. “Elongated, sculptural single earrings really signal a move away from delicate and dainty styles,” Ms. Salzer said. “My take is to do one long style with a simple stud on the opposite ear.” The designer Lizzie Fortunato is similarly inclined, citing the oversize earrings in Marni’s spring collection. “I’m a fan of merging the ‘statement’ and ‘delicate’ trends,” she said. These summer-friendly styles can ease you into the trend. They’ll look glamorous worn together, but for an added dose of cool, pair one with a bitty stud — lest you look as if you have lost one earring.

headline: S.E.C. Drops Insider Trading Case Against Health Care Executive
text: Updated, 2:05 p.m. |

headline: A Separatist Militia in Ukraine With Russian Fighters Holds a Key
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Surface-to-air missiles pilfered from army bases. Defectors from Ukraine’s elite special forces. Russian fighters who slipped across a porous border.

headline: On Tiananmen Anniversary, China’s Military Touts Its Strength
text: The New York Times reported this week that there was discord throughout the People’s Liberation Army — even up to the ranks of the general staff — during the protests of 1989. Officers and soldiers argued over how to handle the demonstrations and what orders to obey. After soldiers carried out the massacre of civilians on June 3 and 4, 1989, killing hundreds, possibly thousands, of people, top military officers sought reassurances from Communist Party leaders that the army would never be deployed again for internal unrest.

headline: In Valeant’s Bid for Allergan, an Opaque Business Model Is Revealed
text: On Wall Street, financial engineering masquerades as vision. When it works, you get to be called the Oracle of somewhere or other. If it works for only a short period, you can still get rich. What a country.

headline: Pharrell Williams at the Apollo Theater
text: Mr. Williams performed Tuesday night at the storied Harlem theater.

headline: In Our Pages: June 5
text: 1939: France Says No to Aggression

headline: A Curriculum to Strengthen Students Against Cyberbullying
text: The Facing History School in New York City takes a unique approach to cyberbullying, based in part on its partnership with Facing History and Ourselves, a professional development organization that integrates the concepts of identity, community, responsibility, decision-making and participation into all aspects of its curriculum. By looking at case studies about social injustices, students try to understand the circumstances and decisions surrounding these events and then relate that back to their own experience and communities.

headline: Wasserstein & Co. to Buy Back American Lawyer
text: Updated June 5, 2014, 1:21 p.m. |

headline: Daddy Dear
text: New picture books about fathers include Gianna Marino’s “Following Papa’s Song.”

headline: How Not to Pay the Price for Free Wi-Fi
text: Part of globe-trotting nowadays is flitting from one free Wi-Fi network to the next. From hotel lobby to coffee shop to subway platform to park, each time we join a public network we put our personal information and privacy at risk. Yet few travelers are concerned enough to turn down free Wi-Fi. Rather, many of us hastily give away an email address in exchange for 15 minutes of free airport Internet access.

headline: Daniel Nardicio: Closing a Gay Generation Gap
text: On a recent afternoon in his Chelsea office, the gay night-life producer Daniel Nardicio turned to a lithe go-go boy wannabe named Lorenzo Ashkenazi, 23, and handed him a colorful jockstrap from the label C-IN2.

headline: Finding Inspiration for a Civil Rights Museum
text: The National Center for Civil and Human Rights in Atlanta, which opens to the public on June 23, is one of several new museums in the South dedicated to civil rights.

headline: Nicholas Kristof on Tiananmen Square
text: Nicholas Kristof remembers the unlikely heroes of the protests 25 years ago.

headline: Tiananmen Square, the Turning Point That Wasn’t: A Q. & A. With Nicholas Kristof
text: Natalie Kitroeff, an editorial assistant, asked Nicholas Kristof to look back at  his reporting from Tiananmen Square, the site of pro-democracy protests in China 25 years ago, to reflect on what he might do differently now and how much has changed, or not changed, in China and in his own  world view.

headline: Bergdahl’s Fellow Soldier Speaks Out
text: In an interview with The Associated Press, Gerald Sutton, a former Army specialist who served with Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in Afghanistan, said Sergeant Bergdahl was a deserter.

headline: Data Readings Converge to Show an Economy Regaining Momentum
text: For months, the weather has dominated discourse about the economy. Analysts attributed the dearth of shoppers, the weak employment numbers and the overall decline in economic activity to the cold and snow in the eastern half of the nation, the freakish storms in the South and Midwest, and the drought in the West.

headline: An Unusual van Gogh Work at a German Museum – His Ear
text: A model of Vincent van Gogh’s left ear — you know, the ear — is on display at a German museum, with plans to eventually bring it to New York.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Suitcase Entrepreneur
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Boehner Calls for More Action on V.A. Scandal
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday demanded that President Obama do more to fix what Mr. Boehner called “the abject failure” of the Department of Veterans Affairs to meet the needs of the country’s soldiers returning from battles abroad.

headline: Year-End Roundup, 2013-14 | Math, Science, Health and Technology
text: One of many short videos in The Times’s Science Take series.

headline: Image of the Day: June 4
text: The soccer World Cup tournament will begin in Sao Paulo in Brazil on June 12.

headline: The Anatomy of a Political Direct-Mail Solicitation
text: The envelope is emblazoned with “Dick Morris” and “Stop Hillary Now” and features a picture of Hillary Clinton with the title “Yes, she’s running.” There is little to suggest that it, or the fund-raising solicitation inside, comes from the Republican Party, let alone the Republican Party in the Virgin Islands.

headline: Watches Win NATO Support
text: James Bond gets all the glory, but Pussy Galore wore it best. There she stands, in a still from the imperishable “Goldfinger,” atop the wing of a light plane, wearing a taut sleeveless satin waistcoat and snug black pants, her Icy Hot profile framed by a honeyed mane that was the actress Honor Blackman’s glory.

headline: T Toasts Gucci’s Charity with Beyoncé
text: WhoFrida Giannini, the creative director of Gucci, and Deborah Needleman, the editor in chief of T, hosted a sharply dressed crowd to fete the first anniversary of Gucci’s Chime for Change charity initiative. James Franco and Blake Lively, two faces of the brand, were in attendance, as were the writers Malcolm Gladwell and Marianne Pearl and the Russian street-style stars Miroslava Duma and Anya Ziourova. Attendees craned their necks and hoisted their smartphones to catch a glimpse of Solange Knowles, who was the D.J. for a portion of the festivities, and the evening’s guest of honor, none other than T’s new cover star, Beyoncé.

headline: Vernon Davis Breaks His Silence Over Fantex I.P.O.
text: Vernon Davis, a tight end for the San Francisco 49ers, has enough on his mind already, starting with scoring touchdowns and avoiding injuries.

headline: Are Young People Sheltering in School?
text: The notion that young people can seek and find shelter from a bad economy by staying in school is a myth. The more nuanced reality is that young people can shelter in school — if they can afford it. Most cannot.

headline: After Bribery Scandal, High-Level Departures at Walmart
text: Thomas A. Mars, formerly the chief administrative officer for Walmart in the United States, stepped down. José Luis Rodríguezmacedo Rivera, once the general counsel at Walmart’s Mexican division, quietly left the company. And H. Lee Scott Jr., who was Walmart’s chief executive, will retire from the board this month.

headline: Hillshire Must Decide Whether to Be Target or Suitor
text: Everyone is asking how Hillshire Brands can get out of its acquisition of Pinnacle Foods in light of two competing bids for Hillshire for more than $6 billion. Instead, perhaps the question should be whether Hillshire even wants to exit the Pinnacle deal, and if so, what is the price it would have to pay Pinnacle for such relief.

headline: Janelle Monáe on Daily Devotionals, Electric Bicycles and Afro-Futurism
text: Janelle Monáe is both a major pop star and a bona fide style icon. With her signature bouffant hairdo and mildly androgynous tailored suits in sharp monochrome patterns, she is simultaneously retro and futuristic, a strikingly recognizable (and vaguely alien) figure in the cultural landscape. Originally from Kansas City, Kan., Monáe first gained recognition for her 2007 concept EP “Metropolis: Suite 1 (The Chase)” (loosely inspired by the Fritz Lang film “Metropolis”) and burst into pop stardom in 2010 with “The ArchAndroid,” then followed that up with last year’s “The Electric Lady.” Mixing references with abandon, her music channels the otherworldliness of the funk icons Curtis Mayfield, Parliament and Earth, Wind and Fire and the icy cool of Grace Jones, David Bowie and Prince, while incorporating her contemporary collaborators Big Boi (of Outkast) and Erykah Badu. Yet her influences reveal a warmth and depth beneath her stylized public persona. She shared them in advance of a concert for Celebrate Brooklyn tonight.

headline: The Rangers’ Adventures in the Stanley Cup Finals
text: The cartoonist Bob Eckstein takes readers through each of the Rangers’ 10 trips to the Stanley Cup finals, beginning in 1928.

headline: Wheelies: The Loose Lug Nuts Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Cosmos Up Next for Red Bulls in U.S. Open Cup
text: The Red Bulls were idle last weekend in Major League Soccer and the club’s coaches and players thought Sunday’s match at New England would be its last one until the end of June.

headline: The Great Experiment
text: What if: you gave the poorest workers a raise of 61 percent? Not now, but phased in, starting next spring, over seven years. It would kill the economy, yes? Or maybe it would give so many people at the bottom so much more money that they could buy more stuff and eat out and get beyond the social safety net, raising everybody’s standard of living.

headline: Happenings | Love and Marriage on the Roof of the Wythe Hotel
text: Church, like home, is where you find it. During New York’s Pride Week at the end of this month, gay couples looking to get married will find a church in the unlikeliest of places: on the rooftop of the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Andrew Tarlow, one of the hotel’s founders, came up with the idea of putting a pop-up wedding chapel on the sixth-floor terrace as a tribute to the members of the L.G.B.T. community who live in the neighborhood, especially those who had worked with him for many years at his nearby restaurant Diner.

headline: Start the Presses
text: It’s a fundamental human impulse to want to know more than you can hear over the back fence. Curiosity about people, places and events that matter but cannot be seen from where you stand has civic, commercial and prurient origins. In his new book, Andrew Pettegree argues that this need to know led to the establishment of postal routes, private back channels and, eventually, newspapers.

headline: New York vs. L.A. in Stanley Cup
text: An intense final pits New York against Los Angeles for the first time in hockey as the Rangers and Kings face off in the championship. Three story lines to follow.

headline: Tiananmen Vigils in Hong Kong and Taiwan
text: Outside mainland China, tens of thousands of people gathered to mark the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters 25 years ago in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square.

headline: Sara Lee’s Breakup Is Starting to Pay Off
text: Voracious buyers are finding the meat on Sara Lee’s bones. The old consumer conglomerate broke itself up into the meat-focused Hillshire Brands and the coffee roaster D.E Master Blenders 1753 in 2012 after spurning takeover offers worth about $12 billion, according to news reports at the time. It looked like a raw deal — until now.

headline: No Longer Updating
text: This blog is no longer being updated. Please go to nytimes.com/video/the-new-york-times-minute/ for the latest episodes of the Times Minute.

headline: In Elections Across the World, Democracy Is a Matter of Definition
text: LONDON — These have been heady days for those who like to ponder whether there is such a thing as a one-size-fits-all election, whether democracy, in other words, is indivisible.

headline: The Triple Crown Winners, Fit to Print
text: Twelve horses have won the Triple Crown, with American Pharoah’s victory in 2015 the most recent. A look back at how The New York Times covered these rare triumphs.

headline: Appeals Court Ruling in S.E.C. Case Will Curb Judicial Power Over Settlements
text: In the tug of war between a few federal district judges and regulators, score one for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Two Players on the Rise, but Only One Will Make It to the Final
text: PARIS — When Simona Halep and Andrea Petkovic played in last year’s final of a tournament in Nuremberg, Germany, Halep was ranked 58th and Petkovic 103rd.

headline: Breakdown: Death at the Track
text: A 2012 investigation by The New York Times revealed a pervasive culture of drugs and lax regulation in the U.S. horse racing industry.

headline: BNP Paribas Faces Capital Hit, but Not a Dire One
text: As the United States authorities prepare to punish BNP Paribas, the doubts about the French bank’s financial strength are growing.

headline: Via Tablet or Smartphone, Learning With MOOCs
text: MASSIVE Open Online Courses — or MOOCs — are a snowballing revolution in education.

headline: In Amsterdam, a New Food Tour
text: Visit a snoepwinkel (candy shop) to taste several varieties of Dutch liquorice, sample smoked sausages at a slagerij (butcher shop), and eat herring “the Amsterdam way” (served with chopped onions, a pickle and a Dutch flag on a toothpick that doubles as your fork) during the just-launched Jordaan Food Tour from Eating Amsterdam Tours.

headline: Columbia Names Editor and Publisher for Global Reports Series
text: Columbia Global Reports, a new Columbia University publication devoted to book-length reporting projects, now has an editor and publisher.

headline: The Rangers’ Adventures in the Stanley Cup Finals
text: When the Rangers meet the Los Angeles Kings in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals on Wednesday night it will mark the 11th time in the club’s long, and often unsuccessful, history that it has made it to the championship round.

headline: When a Family Gets Away, Its Problems Make the Trip
text: Emma Straub’s bustling new novel is about a New York family’s two-week idyll in a house on the Spanish island of Mallorca. It’s also about a different kind of break: infidelity. The book is full of couples, and all of them have to cope with some kind of cheating during the course of the story. Even its youngest, most petulant character, a sharp-eyed teenager named Sylvia Post, has been betrayed by her high school boyfriend and rewarded with an Adonis of a Spanish tutor as compensation.

headline: In His Words | The Art of Inscrutability
text: On the cusp of a big James Lee Byars show, the artist Anish Kapoor remembers the lamentably unsung American sculptor.

headline: The Gun Report: June 4, 2014
text: Throughout its 25 years, “The Simpsons” has been revered for its biting social commentary, pointing out the foibles of American society with laser-like accuracy. It’s had its political moments too, taking on gay marriage, immigration, the environment, elections, drug addiction — and, in November 1997, guns.

headline: Coldplay Holds at No. 1
text: Coldplay holds the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s album charts for a second time, in a week of poor music sales.

headline: With a Flair for the Dramatic, Doughty Fuels the Stoic Kings
text: LOS ANGELES — Not many players with two Olympic gold medals and a Stanley Cup title are overlooked or misunderstood. But such has been the plight of the Los Angeles Kings’ Drew Doughty.

headline: Eimear McBride, a Debut Novelist, Wins Baileys Fiction Prize
text: The Irish author Eimear McBride has won the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction for her debut novel, “A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing.”

headline: Clip: ‘Borgman’
text: A scene from the film directed by Alex van Warmerdam.

headline: Street Style in El Raval, Barcelona
text: El Raval in Barcelona is a district with a worn-in feel, from the secondhand shops to Sant Pau del Camp, one of the city’s oldest churches. Deh André, shown, was recently in El Raval, in a secondhand outfit from head to toe (except Nike hightops bought new). Mr. André, a Brazilian, has lived in Barcelona six years and has one style rule: always wear colors. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Concrete Shoes Are So Last Season
text: The term “sleep with the fishes” is given a surreal visual interpretation in the dark, haunting drama “Borgman.”

headline: Europe Gets Negative Interest Rates. What Does That Even Mean?
text: First there was ZIRP. Now get ready for NIRP.

headline: Magical Forest, Comic Mishaps
text: George Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” which New York City Ballet opened on Tuesday at the David H. Koch Theater, is two dances in one. The first half sweeps through Shakespeare’s comic play: Titania fights with Oberon over her page. Butterflies and fairies, many of them adorable children, swirl across the stage. The mischievous Puck wreaks havoc with two pairs of lovers and transforms poor Bottom into a donkey.

headline: An Icon They Clicked On
text: On Monday night, the fashion world gathered to congratulate itself.

headline: Letting a Mighty Nave Breathe, in Full View of a Neighborhood
text: Workers are digging the foundation for a twin-towered apartment building that will obscure the great flying buttresses and stained-glass windows of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights.

headline: Zara, Where Insiders Look for an Edge
text: When they’re not tending clients or updating inventory at the Albright Fashion Library, a supplier of fresh-from-the-runway looks to stylists, socialites and film companies, Lindsay Carr and Yael Quint like to poke around the Internet for credible approximations of their favorite high-end labels. Their jobs afford them plenty of chances to beg, borrow or buy at a discount any number of lust-worthy items from the likes of Balenciaga, Givenchy or Céline. But on a recent spring morning, Ms. Carr was turned out top to toe in Zara.

headline: Donna Karan: Milestones
text: A look at Ms. Karan’s life and career as she steps down as chief designer of Donna Karan International.

headline: Seek and Ye Shall Find a Hottie
text: What good Christian doesn’t love that sublimely spiritual moment on Sunday when the priest or minister says, “And now, let us pray — but first let’s see if we can fix Angela up on a date”?

headline: An Elusive Hand at the Goldman Pairs
text: The Goldman Pairs has been contested annually in New York City since 1929, making it the world’s longest-running bridge tournament. The winners of the 86th event, held on May 24 and 25, were George Krizel of Feasterville-Trevose, Pa., and Albert Shekhter of New York City. They finished 1.12 match points ahead of Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Greg McKellar of Kingston, Ontario. Third were Michael Polowan of New York City and Richard Schwartz of Lords Valley, Pa.

headline: Recollections of Warriors, Redeployed Into Dance
text: WASHINGTON — During naval service in the Middle East, Paul Hurley lost a leg. Now he’s joined a dance company.

headline: In a First, Test of DNA Finds Root of Illness
text: Joshua Osborn, 14, lay in a coma at American Family Children’s Hospital in Madison, Wis. For weeks his brain had been swelling with fluid, and a battery of tests had failed to reveal the cause.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Single Dose of Antibiotic Found Effective in Quelling MRSA
text: A single infusion of an antibiotic can clear serious bacterial skin infections — including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA — just as effectively as the 10-day regimen now used to treat patients, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Convict Arrested in Stabbing of Brooklyn Children
text: A man with an extensive criminal record who was released from prison less than two weeks ago was arrested Wednesday night in connection with the stabbing death of a 6-year-old Brooklyn boy, hours after investigators used forensic evidence to identify a suspect, the authorities said.

headline: Germany Begins Inquiry of U.S. in Surveillance Case
text: BERLIN — Germany’s federal prosecutor announced Wednesday that he had begun a formal investigation of what he called “unknown” members of American intelligence agencies on suspicion that they had eavesdropped on one of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphones.

headline: Who Says a Woman Needs a Boyfriend for a Great Shirt?
text: The demography of Orchard Street circa Canal Street is changing rapidly, but it’s still home to as many Chinese-owned restaurant-supply stores as boutique tie-makers, which may explain the Asian woman peering quizzically through the window of Alexander Olch’s five-month-old shop one recent afternoon.

headline: Two Paths to the Great Outdoors
text: Right by the front door of the new Will Leather Goods store in NoLIta are a few bowls full of candies. Reach in. Grab a few. I took some Bit-O-Honeys. They were chewy, a little oily, and lasted long, designed for a stroll.

headline: Donna Karan Exudes Calm in the Chaos
text: When the fashion designer Donna Karan debuted her most recent collection in February, it was a high-voltage affair: a specially commissioned film by Steven Sebring playing in the background as models strutted on stage in negligee-like outfits paired with square-shouldered jackets and tall boots. In the audience, a smattering of boldface names: Katie Holmes, Trudie Styler and Rita Ora, all sheathed head to toe in Donna Karan.

headline: Joni Ernst Fights for Dirty Water in Iowa
text: Joni Ernst, the winner of the Iowa Senate Republican primary on Tuesday, has a briefcase full of the usual shopworn, hard-right policies: no same-sex marriage, no reform of immigration, no federal minimum wage, no Education Department, no progressive tax code. She still clings to the idea of private accounts for Social Security.

headline: The Fall of Narcissism
text: If there’s any psychological diagnosis that has captivated our national imagination over the last five years or so, it’s narcissism — an alleged epidemic that’s supposed to be turning America’s youth into loud-mouthed, hyperentitled, participation-trophy-demanding monsters. But some are starting to question whether it’s really the scourge it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Works by New Talents, Taken to a Power of One
text: Part of the pleasure of the inaugural NY Phil Biennial, an 11-day exploration of new work that ends Saturday, has been getting to know the Philharmonic’s players better. Take Sumire Kudo.

headline: A Gas Cache, Now Under Shaky Ground
text: LOPPERSUM, the Netherlands — Deep below the cow pastures and farming villages in this picturesque northeastern corner of the Netherlands lies an extraordinary resource: Europe’s largest source of natural gas, known as the Groningen gas field.

headline: Pharrell Williams at the Apollo Theater
text: Mr. Williams performed Tuesday night at the storied Harlem theater.

headline: Justices Reject Call to Halt Gay Marriages in Oregon
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a request to halt same-sex marriages in Oregon. The court’s one-line order gave no reasons for declining to issue a stay.

headline: Melodrama, Feats of Aerial Daring, and Mom
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Live theater is one of the few places where creaking can be a pleasant sound. It can come from a door temporarily concealing a bad guy, or it can come from a play content to traffic in plot twists that wouldn’t have shocked your great-grandmother.

headline: Events and Sales Starting the Week of June 5
text: Openings

headline: Behind an N.B.A. Finals Rematch
text: A three-peat for LeBron James and the Miami Heat or a shot at redemption for Tim Duncan and the San Antonio Spurs? The sports columnist Harvey Araton on the finals encore.

headline: Many Answers, Still More Questions
text: It can be tempting to say — and some critics have — that Ronald K. Brown creates the same piece over and over. There are undoubtedly common elements, both structural and thematic, running through his work: a fluent, hybrid language of African-based and modern dance; a preference for patchwork musical playlists; an allegiance to the realm of the spiritual. Each of his dances, in one way or another, is an expression of praise.

headline: Young Composers Catch the Philharmonic’s Ear
text: It was a bit like a reality television show called “The Composer,” or “Philharmonic Idol,” or perhaps just “Survivor.” After more than 400 composers ranging in age from 9 to 84 had submitted their scores, six finalists were chosen to come to Avery Fisher Hall to hear the New York Philharmonic play their pieces.

headline: N.R.A. Backs Away From Article Criticizing Advocates of Carrying Guns in Public
text: The National Rifle Association is distancing itself from an article on its website that called demonstrations by gun rights advocates who brandished weapons in public “scary” and “weird,” and that said such advocates had “crossed the line from enthusiasm to downright foolishness.”

headline: Encircling Rome, On and Off the Road
text: When Gianfranco Rosi arrived at the Venice Film Festival in September with his fourth feature-length film, the documentary “Sacro GRA,” he was happy just to be there. It was the first year that Venice, the world’s oldest film festival, had admitted documentaries, and prizes were the furthest thing from his mind.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The parent company of Carl’s Jr. and Hardee’s said the minimum wage in California is so high ($9) that it’s harder to come up with profitable business models. Guess they won’t be expanding into Seattle, where the minimum wage is set to rise to $15. No loss.

headline: A Tea Party Edge in Mississippi
text: Jonathan Martin on the race in Mississippi as G.O.P. Senate candidates prepare for a runoff.

headline: A Satellite Show at the Venice Architecture Biennale, Hosted Through (and Inspired by) Airbnb
text: Much of this year’s Rem Koolhaas-curated Architecture Biennale in Venice, which opens this weekend, explores the 20th century. But the Airbnb Pavilion, a satellite three-day pop-up exhibition opening tonight and organized by Fabrizio Ballabio, Alessandro Bava, Luis Ortega Govela and Octave Perrault, a group of students and recent graduates of the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London, investigates a distinctly 21st-century phenomenon: the way people loan out their apartments in the newfangled “sharing economy.”

headline: When Parents Need Help with the Facts of Life
text: China’s 1.35 billion people have to come from somewhere, so it’s a fair guess that Chinese people have had a lot of sex.

headline: T-Mobile and Sprint Zeroing In on a $32 Billion Merger
text: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed on the terms of a deal to join forces.

headline: Small Record Labels Ask Regulators to Intervene in YouTube Dispute
text: Independent music groups, angry with YouTube’s demands over licensing terms, have asked government regulators in Europe and the United States to intervene on their behalf.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: The Best Off-Field Story Lines
text: Being a soccer fan in the United States requires more knowledge than it used to. In honor of a special World Cup issue of the magazine on June 8, the 6th Floor blog will publish a series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like a true fanatic — or at least a European.

headline: Lara Logan Returns to Work on ’60 Minutes’
text: Lara Logan has quietly returned to work at “60 Minutes,” CBS News confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: India’s Feudal Rapists
text: WHEN a distressed father is reporting his daughter’s disappearance to a policeman in India, there are some questions he doesn’t want to hear. “What is your caste?” is one of them. Yet, the father, Sohan Lal, said this was the first thing the police asked him last Tuesday, when he begged them for help. After revealing his low-caste background as a Shakya, Mr. Lal said the officers mocked him and refused to lift a finger.

headline: Sales at John Derian, Judy Ross Textiles and Sferra
text: During John Derian’s annual sale, some decoupage is up to 60 percent off, and select tabletop items, bedding and decorative accessories are up to 50 percent off, through Saturday (John Derian decoupage dome paperweights, originally $60, are $25; John Derian six-inch-square Vide Poche plates, originally $70, are $28); 8 East Second Street (Bowery), 212-677-3917, johnderian.com.

headline: And There Was Light
text: When Ronald Olthof and his partner, Sofie Suiker, decided to buy a home, their first instinct was to find an old building they could renovate. An abandoned industrial space, maybe.

headline: Coaxing a History from Board and Beam
text: ARROWSIC, Me. — The flourish that most delights Henry Petroski about his handmade house here is the way its builder “eased” the edges of the boards that form the cabinets, lintels, doors and door bracings. These subtle details were among the clues that set Mr. Petroski on a quest to learn about the man who employed them.

headline: Mortars and Pestles: Developing a Crush
text: Using a mortar and pestle “isn’t always that practical,” said Marc Meyer, the executive chef and co-owner of Cookshop and several other restaurants in Manhattan. Even so, he said: “I insist on it for certain things, like garlic. I like the way garlic comes out when it is completely smashed: It becomes a purée and seems to dissolve into whatever you’re making.”

headline: Decorator Underground
text: Manhattan building superintendents are rarely asked about how they decorate their subterranean apartments, combining tenants’ castoffs and souvenirs of faraway homelands against backdrops of rusty pipes and industrial gray walls. When the photographer Gesche Würfel set out to interview the workers for a book, “Basement Sanctuaries” (Grey Matters/Schilt Publishing, $20), “They were very happy about the recognition, that somebody was interested in their life,” she said. In her images, houseplants and pet birds survive on little sunlight, and paintings and photos of tropical waterfronts and Paris landmarks are hung alongside trash cans, exercise equipment and laundry machines. The supers told her that the spaces can be tricky to protect. “Every time I maintain it, people steal my paintings from me,” one said. But another super has managed to attract tourists to his well-appointed home. “It brings them to tears to see the basement,” he said. Information: 31-20-528-69-12, schiltpublishing.com.

headline: Not Really an Ocean Apart
text: It has been 40 years since the French furniture company Roche Bobois planted a flag in the United States, but only recently did it invite an American to design for its collection. On Thursday, the company is introducing two chairs by Stephen Burks, a New Yorker, that riff on consumer tastes in different parts of the world. Called Traveler, the chairs come in a European version with a canopied tubular metal structure and leather upholstery ($11,800 with canopy) and an American version in wood and fabric ($11,800). Mr. Burks said the first chair expresses a “micro-architectural moment” and celebrates craft, whereas the second signals deep, satisfying comfort: “It’s like a giant pillow,” he said. But don’t take these ideas too literally, he added. “There is so much diversity within cultures, it would be a gross exaggeration to say, ‘I’ve summed up Europe in a chair, or summed up America.’ ” Available in September. Information: roche-bobois.com.

headline: Tea for Two and Visible to All
text: Hiroshi Sugimoto is a celebrated chronicler of the monotonous, the frozen and the familiar. He has photographed seascapes, modernist buildings and wax figures of famous people. But the 66-year-old Tokyo artist, who maintains a second studio in Chelsea, where he sat down with a reporter last month, also has a deep feeling for the ritualized performances of his homeland. He has produced and directed his own versions of the traditional Japanese puppet theater called bunraku, and the building he designed for his multidisciplinary Odawara Art Foundation in Japan will have a noh theater stage perched 100 meters above the sea when it opens in 2016.

headline: Raphael Fruhbeck de Burgos, Citing Illness, Withdraws from Conducting
text: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, the veteran Spanish conductor, has cancer and is giving up conducting immediately on the advice of his doctors, the Boston Symphony Orchestra said on Wednesday.

headline: Taking One Room at a Time
text: Department of Decoration made its debut last month at a dinner party at the High Line Hotel. Tables were set with powder-coated flatware and serving trays, smooth slab ceramic plates and printed table linens, all created by the husband-and-wife team of Brian Kaspr and Payton Cosell Turner, who already make wallpaper under the name Flat Vernacular.

headline: Design Treasures Once Destined for Archives Now Can Be Yours
text: “In architecture,” Christopher W. Mount said, “people always think of the final product.” A longtime museum curator, Mr. Mount is hoping to interest design fans and collectors in the means to that end: The Christopher W. Mount Gallery in Los Angeles, which has opened inside the Pacific Design Center, will offer maquettes, design drawings, photographs and other artifacts by prominent figures related to architecture and design.

headline: When the Landline Is a Lifeline
text: AT&T and Verizon are pushing hard to shift traditional landline service, which has mostly operated over copper lines, to a system of Internet-based phones by around 2020. If the Federal Communications Commission approves the switch as is, it could come as a shock to the 96 million Americans who still rely on landlines.

headline: Cooperstown on the Field, Behind the Scenes
text: In Cooperstown, N.Y., while the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is waving pennants in honor of its 75th anniversary, Tauck will offer virtual behind-home-plate access to sports celebrities and special events in a four-day trip.The Tauck Baseball Event, July 31 to Aug. 3, offers guests third- and fourth-row seating at a 75th anniversary concert featuring Paul Simon as headliner. An after-hours tour and talk at the Baseball Hall of Fame includes a keynote address and question and answer session with the “Baseball” documentary filmmaker Ken Burns, who designed the trip with Tauck.

headline: Missing Japan, Balanced in Brazil
text: Among the first generation of Japanese laborers who immigrated to Brazil more than a century ago, Haruo Ohara photographed a world where man sought harmony with tradition and nature.

headline: Don’t Show Me the Money
U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,310 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Dr. Pharmacist
text: After Asiya Khatu smashed her finger in a door, she was treated by a pharmacist, not a doctor. (This is a clip from a forthcoming short documentary from Nicholas Kristof and Adam B. Ellick.)

headline: The Ambiguities of the Bergdahl Case
Libya: Swiss Red Cross Worker Is Killed
text: Gunmen in the central Libyan city of Surt fatally shot a Swiss man working for the Red Cross on Wednesday, the organization said in a statement. The man, Michael Greub, 42, was leaving a meeting with colleagues when their vehicle came under attack, it said. No possible motives were disclosed, but foreign workers and diplomats have come under increasing threat from armed groups that have operated with impunity in Libya since its revolt in 2011. The killing came amid intensifying violence in the eastern city of Benghazi, where a self-proclaimed army leader, Gen. Khalifa Hifter declared war on Islamist militias almost three weeks ago. He was lightly wounded Wednesday when a suicide bomber drove an explosives-laden truck into a base where the general was staying east of Benghazi. Four of his guards died in the attack, according to one of the general’s aides.

headline: Canada: Prostitution Bill Targets Clients
text: The government of Canada introduced legislation on Wednesday that would criminalize buying sexual services but would not, in many situations, make selling them illegal. The bill follows a Canadian Supreme Court ruling in December that overturned most laws governing the sex trade on the basis that they violated prostitutes’ constitutional right to security. While Justice Minister Peter MacKay said the bill aimed to focus on pimps and the customers of prostitutes, he added that prostitutes who offered their services in public areas where children might be present would, in most cases, be fined. The bill would also make advertising sexual services a crime. Some lawyers for prostitutes argued that the measure did not address the court’s concern about prostitutes’ safety.

headline: Assad’s Soft-Focus Vision for Syria, as Seen on YouTube
text: As unexpected as it might have seemed three summers ago, when hundreds of thousands of Syrians jammed the streets demanding that President Bashar al-Assad just “leave,” his landslide re-election, confirmed shortly after polls closed on Wednesday, surprised no one. Given that his supporters, in regions of the deeply divided nation now under government control, openly boasted of voting early and often, and that his opponents largely ignored the contest, the huge margin of victory was entirely believable.

headline: Collecting Wood for Pennies
text: With no jobs available, Anwa Begum dives for driftwood to sell as firewood.

headline: Netflix Points at Verizon for Delays in Streaming
text: WASHINGTON — Being partners with Netflix does not mean that Netflix is on your side.

headline: The T.M.I. Pregnancy
text: Becoming a mother was so simple when I became a mother. Pregnancy was treated as a natural experience. You peed in a cup, and then once a month the obstetrician pressed his stethoscope against your belly and you watched his face for a smile.

headline: Sterling Agrees to Sale of Clippers, and to Drop Lawsuit
text: Donald Sterling, the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner who was barred for life by the N.B.A. for racist comments, decided Wednesday to consent to the $2 billion sale of the team engineered by his estranged wife, Rochelle, his lawyer said.

headline: With 2014 World Cup, Soccer Ascends to Role as Premier Ad Platform
text: THERE is a saying that Brazil is the country of the future, and always will be, and the jest has been reworked to proclaim soccer as the American sport of the future that will also never fulfill its potential.

headline: China Financier Defends Companies’ Deals
text: SHANGHAI — A billionaire Chinese financier, responding to an article in The New York Times about deals that his companies made with the relatives of some of China’s senior leaders, said Wednesday that a company he co-founded was helping the family of China’s president, Xi Jinping, dispose of some of its assets last year when the company bought a stake that the family held in a state-backed investment firm.

headline: G.M. Report on Recalls Is Expected Thursday
text: General Motors on Thursday will release the results of its three-month internal investigation into the events leading up to this year’s recall of 2.6 million small cars with defective ignition switches.

headline: Scholars’ Bid to Criticize Israel’s Actions Is Rejected
text: A resolution critical of Israel failed to win approval from a leading scholarly group, the Modern Language Association, the group said on Wednesday, after an overwhelming majority of its members declined to vote.

headline: At Belmont Park, Savoring the Other Sides of the Track
text: The stalwarts of Belmont Park shuffled toward the front benches some 50 minutes before post time, a procession of walking canes and tinted sunglasses, plastic bags treated as briefcases and jeans pulled high enough to make belly buttons disappear.

headline: A Bonus California Chrome Can’t Win
text: The six horses who could have won the Triple Crown from 1997 to 2005 must not have heard Visa USA executives whisper to them: Win the Belmont Stakes, and we will send a $5 million bonus to your Cayman Islands account. For most athletes, that would have been motivation enough. But these horses run for glory and carrots, not cash. They heed their jockeys, not sponsors.

headline: A Proud Career That Seemed to Curdle
text: Many moons ago, in the early 1980s, tenant organizers traveled to Downtown Brooklyn to hear the new fire commissioner talk of a plague of arson that had turned so many apartment buildings in so many neighborhoods into bonfires.

headline: Puerto Rico Debates Who Put Out the Lights in Mosquito Bay
text: VIEQUES, P.R. — Sitting on a small boat in Mosquito Bay, a tapestry of stars above him, Mark Martin, a field researcher, scooped water into a canister. He studied the liquid for some sign of why, suddenly and inexplicably, one of the world’s most famous bioluminescent bays had dimmed.

headline: Can the Minimum Wage Be Too High?
text: On Monday Seattle raised its minimum wage to $15 an hour. But can the city afford it? Will it lead to job losses, as some predict, or be a model for national reform?

headline: In Race for Rangel’s Seat, Top Rivals Promise Job Growth in Struggling Areas
text: With less than three weeks to go until the Democratic primary for Representative Charles B. Rangel’s seat in Congress, he and his top rival, State Senator Adriano Espaillat, courted voters on Wednesday by promising to bring sorely needed jobs to the struggling Harlem and Bronx neighborhoods that make up much of their district.

headline: Spurs and Heat Are Starting Where the What-Ifs Left Off
text: SAN ANTONIO — Now that the Miami Heat and the San Antonio Spurs have arrived here, ready to reprise their riveting seven-game N.B.A. final of a year ago, among the many questions worth considering is one that is perhaps the simplest.

headline: British Bank Regulators Pine to Win a Big Case
text: When Credit Suisse agreed on May 19 to plead guilty and pay $2.6 billion for conspiring to help Americans avoid taxes, it was yet another day of dreary headlines for bankers around the world.

headline: Inquiry Urged on Site Called Mass Grave of Irish Babies
text: DUBLIN — The government and the police are coming under increasing pressure to open an investigation into allegations that a Roman Catholic religious order secretly buried up to 796 babies and toddlers born to unmarried mothers in a septic tank over several decades.

headline: Let’s Give Mississippi Less
text: When was the last time the nation turned its attention to Mississippi?

headline: Clarifying, and Tightening, Patent Law
text: Two recent unanimous Supreme Court decisions should reduce abusive and frivolous patent litigation by raising the standards by which judges decide such cases. The number of cases has increased sharply in recent years.

headline: For Rivals, a Rare Aligning of Form and Draw
text: PARIS — In an age of great rivalries in men’s tennis, Rafael Nadal versus Andy Murray has been the one that keeps getting away.

headline: Children on the Run
text: Along the southern border, particularly in Texas, a rising influx of young unauthorized migrants crossing the border with their parents — or, more alarmingly, alone — has overwhelmed the Border Patrol and sent the federal government scurrying for a coordinated response. Its first action was the right one: the creation of a top-level task force including the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Department of Health and Human Services to care for the unaccompanied children.

headline: Bettman Addresses N.H.L. Players’ Efforts to Hide Concussions
text: LOS ANGELES — Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday that the N.H.L.’s concussion protocol was working, and that the league was serious about enforcing it.

headline: Mary Soames, Daughter of Churchill and Chronicler of History, Dies at 91
text: Mary Soames, the last surviving child of Winston Churchill, lived a storybook life and chronicled it in her own well-received books. After her family announced her death at 91 on May 31 in London, Prime Minister David Cameron called her “an eyewitness to some of the most important moments in our recent history.”

headline: Standing Up to Mr. Putin
text: President Obama’s decision to commit $1 billion to bolster security in Central and Eastern Europe sends important messages to both NATO allies and President Vladimir Putin of Russia. The crisis over Russia’s annexation of Crimea has calmed down a bit, and some Europeans, like France, seem eager to put it behind them. But Mr. Putin has shown he cannot be trusted. The alliance needs to be honest with itself and take full account of his ruthless unpredictability as it plans security arrangements for the future.

headline: Democrats See a Break in a Gain for the Tea Party in Mississippi
text: WASHINGTON — It is a major headache for the national Republican Party and perhaps the biggest break Democrats have been handed in this difficult election year: a three-week runoff campaign in Mississippi between a party elder, Senator Thad Cochran, and the sometimes unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel.

headline: Recalibrated Finalists Renew Their Rivalry
text: For the second straight year, the Miami Heat and the San Antonio Spurs will meet in the N.B.A. finals, and it will again be easy to cast them as polar opposites: the old-school Spurs with their homegrown crop of stars — Tim Duncan, Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili were all drafted by San Antonio — against the modern mercenaries from Miami, including the transplants LeBron James and Chris Bosh.

headline: There’s a Kind of Hush
text: SITTWE, Myanmar — Few people have fought as courageously for human rights as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate who stood up to the generals here in Myanmar.

headline: Don Zimmer, Who Lived Baseball for 66 Years, Dies at 83
text: Don Zimmer, the stubby, Popeye-muscled baseball lifer with the unforgettable jowls whose passion for the game endured through 66 years as a player, manager, coach and adviser, died on Wednesday in Dunedin, Fla. He was 83.

headline: Ex-Rangers Coach Hailed for His Role in a Success Story
text: Glen Sather, the Rangers’ general manager, clearly made the right call last June when he hired Alain Vigneault to replace John Tortorella behind the bench. Sather made an equally wise decision a decade ago when he tabbed Tom Renney to resurrect the franchise.

headline: To Lure Bostonians, New ‘Pop-Up’ Bus Service Learns Riders’ Rhythms
text: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Katie Pasciucco, 34, an account manager at a software company, is a typical Boston commuter. Her door-to-door trip to work is just 4.5 miles but takes at least 50 maddening minutes.

headline: Criticism Over Troop Withdrawal Emerges From Beyond G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Criticism of President Obama’s announcement that American forces would leave Afghanistan by the end of 2016 has begun to come not just from his Republican adversaries, but also from another quarter: former military officers and civilian officials who worked for years to develop and defend his administration’s strategy in Afghanistan.

headline: Word of the Year
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The book that Ed Sessa commemorates in today’s puzzle was a game changer for me.

headline: A Data-Driven Commute
text: The “pop-up” bus service Bridj made its debut in Boston, hoping to offer a quicker alternative for commuters by using algorithms to adapt its routes.

headline: Just Mill About, You Know, as Any Crowd Would Do
text: The orders are as impossible as they are imperious: “Do try and merge.”

headline: A Belmont Who Fought for Racing and for Soldiers
text: Horse racing fans are eagerly awaiting Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, the race that will decide whether California Chrome will join racing royalty like Seattle Slew, Secretariat and Omaha as a Triple Crown winner. But a little more than a hundred years ago, racing was threatened, and the Jockey Club president, August Belmont Jr., decided to save it.

headline: Yuri Kochiyama, Rights Activist Who Befriended Malcolm X, Dies at 93
text: Yuri Kochiyama, a civil rights activist who formed an unlikely friendship with Malcolm X when he was still promoting black nationalism and later cradled his head in her hands as he lay dying from gunshot wounds in 1965, died on Sunday in Berkeley, Calif. She was 93.

headline: Maxine Greene, 96, Dies; Education Theorist Saw Arts as Essential
text: Maxine Greene, a teacher and education theorist who promoted the arts as a fundamental learning tool and in nearly 50 years at Teachers College, Columbia University, became its resident Pied Piper, known for her persuasive scholarship, her vivid writing and her imbuing teaching with a spirit of endless adventure, died on May 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: Karlheinz Böhm, Actor-Turned-Humanitarian, Dies at 86
text: Karlheinz Böhm, an Austrian actor turned humanitarian whose early reputation rested on numerous portrayals of princely heartthrobs and one role as a serial killer who films the agonies of his female victims, died on May 29 in Grödig, Austria, near Salzburg. He was 86.

headline: Mets Are Benefiting From Competition at Shortstop
text: CHICAGO — When the Mets called up Wilmer Flores last month, Manager Terry Collins challenged Ruben Tejada to be better. While Tejada had made little progress at shortstop, he had not been pushed by anyone trying to take his job. But now that Flores felt more comfortable at shortstop, he would be Tejada’s competition.

headline: French Open Ball Kids Carry Gear and a Tune
text: PARIS — Spectators arriving early at Roland Garros encounter an unusual sight each morning: more than 200 children singing and chanting as they run down a wide walkway that leads past the empty stadium of Philippe Chatrier Court.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York
text: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 4, 2014
text: June 4, 2014

headline: Behind P.O.W.’s Release: Urgency and Opportunity
text: WASHINGTON — Weeks before a Black Hawk helicopter lifted off in the dying light of eastern Afghanistan, carrying with it an American soldier who had spent five years in the hands of the Taliban, American officials grew increasingly worried that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s life might be in jeopardy.

headline: Jets’ Breno Giacomini Walks the Line on Offense
