text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Sitting at his locker Wednesday afternoon, Breno Giacomini traced an imaginary line on the inside of his stall. He then placed his index finger on top of that line.

headline: Higher Minimum Wage Gains Support
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s about-face on raising the minimum wage in New York has increased hopes among the city’s lowest-paid workers that their pay will soon rise sharply.

headline: In Bribery Trial, Lawyer Says Queens State Senator Was Entrapped
text: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — It was Valentine’s Day 2013 at Sparks Steak House in Midtown Manhattan, and gifts were exchanged.

headline: Senators Show Frustration After Briefing on Ex-P.O.W.
text: WASHINGTON — White House officials failed Wednesday night to quell rising anger and frustration in both parties on Capitol Hill after a senators-only classified briefing about President Obama’s decision to free five Taliban prisoners in return for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who military officials say walked off his base in Afghanistan five years ago.

headline: 25 Years Later, Student Leaders Witness Freedoms Fought for in Tiananmen
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Wu’er Kaixi took a microphone beneath a portrait of the Chinese revolutionary Sun Yat-sen and began firing up the crowd around him.

headline: For Yankees, a Loss Overshadows Their Defeat
text: Around the sixth inning of the Yankees’ loss to the Oakland Athletics on Wednesday, Derek Jeter was told of the death of Don Zimmer. Suddenly, any attempt to come back in the game became much more difficult. There was grief to overcome in the Yankees’ dugout.

headline: State and Local Officials Vow to End Homelessness Among Veterans
text: WASHINGTON — More than 80 state and local officials committed to try and end the problem of homelessness among veterans by the end of 2015, the Obama administration announced Wednesday, news that comes amid a scandal over medical care for veterans.

headline: U.N. Official Urges Syria to Finish Chemical Arms Disposal
text: Acknowledging that Syria will miss the June 30 deadline for eliminating its chemical weapons, the top United Nations official overseeing the arsenal’s eradication said Wednesday it was “very, very critical” for Syria to export the final shipment, which is packed and ready to go but is trapped in an area contested by insurgents in the civil war.

headline: Man Shoots and Kills 3 Canadian Mounties
text: OTTAWA — A man shot and killed three members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in Moncton, New Brunswick on Wednesday night and wounded two others.

headline: Hamas Looms Over Latest Israel-U.S. Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — For allies who speak often of their unbreakable bonds and constant communication, this has been a season of static between Jerusalem and Washington. The latest eruption was over the announcement this week that the United States would work with a new Palestinian government that emerged from reconciliation talks with Hamas.

headline: A Familiar Ring for Members of Heat and Spurs
text: Championships can define careers. Bill Russell’s 11 rings are often used as a trump card in arguments about greatness, while Charles Barkley’s and Patrick Ewing’s reputations suffered because those stars never won it all.

headline: In Downtown L.A., a Stylish Design Gallery for Special Guys
text: The puzzlingly named Please Do Not Enter is the newest intriguing venture to launch in downtown Los Angeles, that burgeoning mecca of all things cool and compelling. A cross between a gallery and a boutique, Please Do Not Enter offers a collection of contemporary goods that have been carefully curated by its French founders Nicolas Libert and Emmanuel Renoird for an audience of “progressive minds.” Both are art collectors with a special affection for design and architecture, and the space is like an extension of their lives.

headline: Surrealist Photographs of Life’s In-Between Moments
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Two Artists Who Want to Be Your Friends
text: The first image in the debut monograph of the Los Angeles-based artist duo of Arturo Sandoval III and Samuel Albert Borkson, a.k.a FriendsWithYou — called “We Are FriendsWithYou” (Rizzoli, $55) — is a group of cute little clouds with black beady eyes and tiny red smiles. The characters are from their short film “Cloudy.” “It’s like a very simplistic, reduced form that everybody can relate to,” Borkson explains. “It reminds you of childhood, it reminds you of your creativity, how people can look at the clouds and dream up whatever they want.”

headline: The Great Hamstring Saver
text: This article appeared in the June 8, 2014 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: The World Cup Is Bad for Brazil, Many Brazilians Say
text: The World Cup, the championship tournament of the world’s most popular sport, gets underway on June 12 in São Paulo, Brazil. In advance of the tournament, few Brazilians see hosting the event as advantageous for their country, a new survey shows.

headline: Word of the Day | phoenix
text: phoenix •\ˈfe-niks\• noun

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Arachnophobia
text: The Challenge: Can you solve the medical mystery of a woman who develops a sore on her leg and then fever, nausea and chest pain?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 5, 2014
text: “I don’t have any headaches anymore. It’s almost like a rebirth.”

headline: Q. and A.: Wu’er Kaixi on Tiananmen’s Hopes and Taiwan’s Achievements
text: For the two student leaders most wanted by the Chinese government after the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protest movement, Taiwan has become a home in exile. Wu’er Kaixi and Wang Dan now live in a place that has undergone the sort of democratic transition they hoped would happen in mainland China 25 years ago.

headline: In South Korean Voting, No Clear-Cut Victory for Either Party
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Local election results on Thursday showed the main opposition party winning nine of 17 races for big-city mayors and provincial governors in what was seen as a referendum on the leadership of President Park Geun-hye.

headline: Kings Climb Out of Hole as Rangers Fall Into One
text: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Kings are affectionately called the L.A. Cockroaches by some players and fans because they refuse to die. On Wednesday night at Staples Center, the Kings again showed uncanny resiliency as they overcame a 2-0 deficit and defeated the Rangers, 3-2, in overtime in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Obama’s Warsaw Workout Finds Its Way to the Internet
text: BRUSSELS — It may not be the same thing as having his telephone calls tapped by the National Security Agency, but President Obama got a taste of what it is like to have his privacy violated on Wednesday.

headline: A Lifer Who Stood Up for His Players and His Teams
text: Baseball lost a little bit of its soul on Wednesday with the death of Don Zimmer, a character for the ages.

headline: Dismay at Failure of Swap to Rescue More Hostages
text: WASHINGTON — Elaine Weinstein received a message from the White House on Saturday morning telling her to be ready for a phone call from a senior Obama administration official.

headline: Cubs Blunder, but Not Enough for a Mets Victory
text: CHICAGO — Curtis Granderson hit a ground ball into the Chicago Cubs’ shift in the fifth inning Wednesday night, and for another team, it would probably have been a routine play.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 4:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) INCENDIES (2011) The adult children (Mélissa Désormeaux-Poulin and Maxim Gaudette) of an Arab woman, Nawal (Lubna Azabal, above), living in Canada travel to an unnamed country that closely resembles Lebanon to seek out a brother they never knew existed on the instructions of Nawal’s last will and testament. In the process, they learn that their mother, a Christian, had fallen in love with a Muslim and fled her hometown, becoming in succession a student, an activist, a clandestine militant, a political prisoner — and more. The director Denis Villeneuve “tells Nawal’s story in a way that is both subtle and emphatic, and Ms. Azabal, portraying Nawal from hopeful youth to despairing middle age, gives a performance that is all the more powerful for the restrained, unshakable sense of dignity she brings to it,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, based on a play by Wajdi Mouawad. “The depth and complexity of her anger is both a product and a mirror of her native country’s self-destructive pathology, and as the full horror of her life is disclosed, she becomes, in her children’s eyes and the audience’s, as grand and tragic as the heroine of an opera.”

headline: A More Militant Protest Demands Reforms From Beijing
text: While most eyes were on the huge vigil in Hong Kong’s Victoria Park to mark the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, a separate demonstration by more ardently anti-Communist Party protesters drew several thousand people across the harbor on Wednesday night, highlighting the different approaches to confronting Beijing’s rule of the territory.

headline: Corrections: June 5, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Alibaba to Take Stake in Chinese Soccer Team
text: HONG KONG — The e-commerce giant Alibaba Group agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $200 million for a stake in a Chinese soccer team, its latest in a recent spate of acquisitions.

headline: Indicted German Financier Freed in Italy
text: FRANKFURT — A German hedge fund manager wanted on securities fraud charges in Los Angeles has been released from an Italian jail, his lawyer said, in what appeared to be a serious setback for United States prosecutors.

headline: Henkel to Buy French Detergent Maker for $1.3 Billion
text: LONDON – Henkel of Germany said on Thursday that it would pay 940 million euros, or about $1.3 billion, for the Spotless Group, a French maker of laundry detergent and other home care products, from funds advised by the European private equity firm BC Partners.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 5, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Libelous (Trivial)
text: But funny.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Crowds Gather in Hong Kong for 25th Anniversary of Tiananmen Killings
text: In “Crowds Gather in Hong Kong for 25th Anniversary of Tiananmen Killings,” Keith Bradsher reports on commemoration events in China.

headline: ING Moves Ahead With I.P.O. of Insurance Unit
text: LONDON – The Dutch financial services company ING Group said Thursday that it would hold a long-anticipated initial public offering for the NN Group, its European and Japanese insurance and investment management arm.

headline: Who Is Your Favorite Pop Diva?
text: The music world has been graced by many a pop diva. Whitney Houston, Madonna, Aretha Franklin, Mariah Carey, Jennifer Lopez, Diana Ross, Barbra Streisand and Lady Gaga have all reigned the stage at some point. Is Beyoncé queen now?

headline: Missing Japan, Balanced in Brazil
text: It doesn’t matter that oceans are vast, deep and imposing. For much of history they have had to be crossed by force or necessity.

headline: Web Editor Detained Over Photo Linking Mao to Fringe Sect
text: A Beijing-based web editor has been detained by the authorities on suspicion of posting a doctored photo that linked Mao Zedong with a fringe religious group accused in a high-profile murder, a lawyer said.

headline: Xinjiang Hospital Asks Staff Not to Fast During Ramadan
text: A hospital in a city in the western region of Xinjiang that was the site of deadly ethnic unrest in 1997 has asked its staff members not to skip meals during Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting that begins on June 28, the local health department said.

headline: I.P.O. Values Zoopla Property Website at About $1.6 Billion
text: LONDON – The Zoopla Property Group, a British property listings website, could be valued at more than 1 billion pounds when it goes public in London later this month.

headline: New York Today: No School, but Why?
text: Good soggy Thursday morning to you.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Teenage Sunburns Raise Melanoma Risk
text: The risk of developing the deadliest form of skin cancer may be closely tied to sun exposure in youth, a new study suggests.

headline: Two Workouts for the Mayor
text: Two personal trainers, Justin Gelband of modelFIT and Will Torres of Willspace, explain workouts designed especially for Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: A de Blasio Workout: New Routine, No Sweat
text: The very tall man, watched closely by a pair of police officers in business attire, stripped off his sweatshirt and windmilled his arms. He rolled his head in circles, stretching his neck.

headline: As D-Day Tribute Nears, Leaders Maneuver Over Ukraine
text: LONDON — Veterans began gathering on Thursday on the Normandy beaches — some of them perhaps for the last time at such a major commemoration — to observe the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings of World War II, even as their political leaders grappled anew with the conflict’s legacy of East-West division.

headline: Memories From Normandy
text: Beginning on June 6, 1944, more than 150,000 Allied troops landed on a broad stretch of beaches on the coast of Normandy, in German-held France. Entrenched behind concrete walls and bunkers were more than 50,000 German soldiers. Seventy years later, four veterans of the largest amphibious invasion in history recall their experiences.

headline: Goldman Bolsters M.&A. Team in Asia
text: HONG KONG – Goldman Sachs is ramping up its mergers and acquisitions team in Asia amid a surge in deal volume in the region, according to an internal memo sent on Thursday.

headline: Exiled Rally Leader Says He Slipped Into China
text: BEIJING — Despite the ramped-up security for the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, an exiled former protest organizer whose name and picture are on the Chinese government’s 1989 list of the 21 most-wanted students managed to slip back into the country undetected this week, he said Thursday.

headline: 1914: James Joyce Hears an Army
text: “First Glimpses” offers a look at the first times famous people or things appeared in the pages of The New York Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: What I’m Looking for in a New Partner
text: I’ve always been a solo achiever. I’m an only child, and at school I excelled at individual sports like long-distance running.

headline: Why People Hate Taking Surveys
text: It’s not easy to be a pollster these days. As polls have proliferated, the job of legitimate survey researchers has become increasingly difficult. Unfortunately, those of us who are trying to conduct quality surveys are painted with the same brush as those who are not.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Interest Rates Unchanged
text: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low, even as Britain’s economy continues to gather strength.

headline: Daily Report: Sprint and T-Mobile Move Closer to Merger
text: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed on the terms of a deal to join forces, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced report.

headline: Philippines Reports Chinese Ship Movement Around Disputed Reefs
text: MANILA — China is moving ships around disputed reefs in the South China Sea that could be used to reclaim land and build structures, President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines said on Thursday.

headline: Morning Views
text: The number of children crossing the border between Mexico and the United States illegally has doubled each year since 2011, with 60,000 more expected to arrive this year. This — The New York Times editorial board says — is not a security crisis, but a humanitarian one. “Young people are being pushed out of their homes, not pulled,” the board writes, citing increasing civil unrest in Mexico and parts of Central America. “They are fleeing for their lives.”

headline: Accel’s Breyer to Partner With Venture Capital Firm in China
text: SHANGHAI – James W. Breyer, the venture capitalist who made a fortune with an early bet on Facebook, is putting some of his winnings to work in China, partnering with Beijing-based venture capital firm to invest in Chinese technology start-ups.

headline: In Our Pages: June 6
text: 1914: Giant Warships Not Needed

headline: European Central Bank Breaks New Ground to Press Growth
text: FRANKFURT — Banks typically make money on the cash they park at a central bank. Now the European Central Bank wants them to pay for the privilege.

headline: No Time Off for Good Behavior
text: Is it a problem that “Orange Is the New Black” essentially treats prison like a bad day in high school, the kind that includes both a scary walk to the principal’s office and an embarrassing visit to the school nurse?

headline: Young Love, Complicated by Cancer
text: “The world is not a wish-granting factory.” That line, from “The Fault in Our Stars,” is undoubtedly true, and it is also true that the movie, like the book before it, is an expertly built machine for the mass production of tears. Directed by Josh Boone (“Stuck in Love”) with scrupulous respect for John Green’s best-selling young-adult novel, the film sets out to make you weep — not just sniffle or choke up a little, but sob until your nose runs and your face turns blotchy. It succeeds.

headline: Tony Award Predictions: Readers (and Boldface Names) Weigh In
text: So said Anna Wintour, Condé Nast artistic director and editor-in-chief of Vogue, about the race for best actor in a musical as part of our Tony Award predictions series this week. At our invitation, Ms. Wintour, Oscar and Tony winner Liza Minnelli, Emmy Award winner Jim Parsons, and television host Kelly Ripa joined a few dozen of you in offering predictions.

headline: Amazon Boycott Gets a Helping Hand From Stephen Colbert
text: Stephen Colbert went after Amazon Wednesday night, literally giving the retailer the finger on his Comedy Central show. Twice.

headline: Talking Rebranding and Logos With Loewe’s Jonathan Anderson
text: Rebranding of heritage names has become something of a fashion trend recently, what with Hedi Slimane’s conversion of Yves Saint Laurent’s ready-to-wear to Saint Laurent Paris; Pinault-Printemps-Redoute’s transformation into Kering, complete with little owl pictogram: Celine’s new minimalism courtesy of Phoebe Philo, and so on. The latest entrant into this group is LVMH’s Loewe, under the creative directorship of Jonathan Anderson (aka J Anderson, iconoclastic Young British designer), which unveiled its new logo and typeface yesterday.

headline: Energy Choices
text: Nate Silver got a lot of grief when he chose Roger Pielke Jr., of all people, to write about environment for the new 538. Pielke is regarded among climate scientists as a concern troll – someone who pretends to be open-minded, but is actually committed to undermining the case for emissions limits any way he can. But is this fair?

headline: China Sentences Scores in Xinjiang for Acts of Terror
text: BEIJING — Chinese courts in the northwestern region of Xinjiang sentenced 81 people on terrorism and other charges on Thursday, according to the state broadcaster China Central Television. The sentences are part of a widening crackdown in the region after a spate of deadly violence in China for which the authorities have blamed foreign-backed Islamist separatists.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Talks Climate Change at Summit
text: Good Thursday morning. Political controversies over a prisoner swap with the Taliban and the scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs are still swirling in Washington, but on this warm and gloomy day, President Obama has a busy agenda across the pond.

headline: Israel Expands Settlements to Rebuke Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — Israel says it is moving ahead with the planning and construction of hundreds of Jewish settlement homes as retaliation against the new Palestinian government, which has been accepted by the United States and much of the world even though it is supported by Hamas. The announcement enraged the Palestinians and flouted international opinion.

headline: Where Have All the Couriers Gone?
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Video and Updates on G.M. Internal Recall Investigation
text: As my colleague Bill Vlasic reports, Mary T. Barra discussed the findings of an internal investigation into why it took General Motors more than a decade to recall about 2.6 million small cars with defective ignition switches. The auto company says the problem has caused at least 13 deaths, but lawyers bringing suits against G.M. say the toll is at least 60.

headline: A Little Something Special
text: Small, delicate pieces of jewelry, meant to be mixed and worn every day, are sentimental talismans of a particular moment in time.

headline: G.M. Inquiry Cites Years of Neglect Over Fatal Defect
text: WARREN, Mich. — A sweeping internal investigation of General Motors released on Thursday condemned the company for its decade-long failure to fix a deadly safety defect, one that led to “devastating consequences,” including at least 13 deaths.

headline: Morning Agenda: Sprint and T-Mobile Near a Deal of Their Own
text: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed to a deal of their own. The operators, Sprint and T-Mobile, which have long contemplated a merger, finally settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal that is likely to be announced this summer, DealBook’s David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write. The merger would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T. Under the terms of the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan’s SoftBank, would acquire T-Mobile for about $40 a share in cash and stock, a 17 percent premium to Wednesday’s price. Accounting for regulatory uncertainty, the early terms of the deal also include a breakup fee of more than $1 billion that Sprint would pay to T-Mobile.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘In the Night’
text: This poem, by Emma J., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Travel article, “A Big Sur Bath by the Light of the Moon.”

headline: Canadian Police Seek Suspect in Killing of Officers
text: OTTAWA — A full day after a heavily armed gunman killed three police officers and wounded two others, Moncton, New Brunswick, largely remained under siege on Thursday night.

headline: If the Serial Killers Don’t Get Him, the Fast Food Will
text: Calls to literacy come in many forms, most of them smug and self-defeating. Then there is the cult-film director John Waters’s advice. In his one-man show “This Filthy World,” he instructs audiences, “If you go home with somebody, and they don’t have books,” don’t sleep with them.

headline: A Long-Ago Blackout Burns Brightly
text: When Kim Rosenstock, Michael Mitnick and Will Connolly first staged their musical “Fly by Night” as Yale School of Drama grad students in 2009, it was nothing if not a DIY proposition.

headline: A Brawny Vegetarian Soup Holds Its Own With Meat Lovers
text: Renee Ruder and her meat-loving family (her husband and their three daughters, 7, 9 and 11) have asked for help adding more vegetable-based meals to their weekly menu, and with making the most of their new C.S.A. (community supported agriculture) share. I am leading the way, holding a crash course in creating substantial vegetarian meals using pantry staples, the seasonal vegetables that come every week in the C.S.A. box, and ingredients from nearby supermarkets.

headline: With Group of 7 Backing, Obama Gives Russia One-Month Ukraine Deadline
text: BRUSSELS — With the backing of other world leaders, President Obama effectively set a one-month deadline for Moscow to reverse its intervention in Ukraine and help quash a pro-Russian separatist uprising or else he said it would face international sanctions far more severe than anything it had endured so far.

headline: 36 Hours in Canberra, Australia
text: To stand atop a Canberra hilltop is to contemplate the stark charm of the Australian bush: vast grassy fields, swaths of eucalyptus forest and Instagram-worthy sunsets. This outpost is Australia’s national capital — not, as is commonly thought, the glitzier city of Sydney, three hours’ drive north. In Canberra, there are no beaches or iconic opera houses, and European chic is best sought an hour’s flight away in Melbourne. But what the “bush capital” lacks in big-city tousle, it makes up for in big-sky beauty, breezy civic pride and a decidedly hipster underbelly. Set on an artificial lake and spread across a valley between mountain ranges, Canberra is the Brasilia of Australia, designed by the American architects Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahony Griffin, who won a competition in 1911 to create the country’s political heart because Sydney and Melbourne couldn’t stop bickering about their own fabulousness. A year after the city’s centennial celebrations and with a steady influx of artists and gastronomes, Canberra is best appreciated with deep intakes of mountain air and an ear tuned to the calls of sulphur-crested cockatoos and crimson rosellas.

headline: Anatomy | ‘The Fault in Our Stars’
text: In Anatomy of a Scene, Josh Boone narrates a sequence from “The Fault in Our Stars” featuring Shailene Woodley, Ansel Elgort and Nat Wolff.

headline: The Burden of Being Messi
text: In much of Argentina, where Lionel Messi lived until he was 13, native speakers replace the “y” sound with a “sh” sound. Yo, the personal pronoun for “I,” becomes “sho,” and calle, which other Spanish speakers would pronounce “ka-yay,” becomes “ka-shey.” The sound gives Argentine Spanish a slurry softness that resembles aspects of the Portuguese spoken in Brazil. More important to this story, that “sh,” and the fact that Messi has retained it all his life, has at times been the sole lifeline between the greatest soccer player in the world and the country he plays for.

headline: Democrats Are Weary in Wake of Bergdahl Case
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s handling of the Bergdahl prisoner exchange has renewed frustration among congressional Democrats about the administration’s relations with its allies on Capitol Hill, and prompted criticism that the White House failed to prepare the lawmakers for the politically explosive case.

headline: Exclusive Clip: Yves Saint Laurent
text: Yves Saint Laurent (Pierre Niney) prepares his models backstage for his first show after his well-publicized split from Dior. Yves’ muse Victoire (Charlotte Le Bon) surprises him with a new haircut.

headline: In West Bengal, Communists’ Defeat Signals a Larger Loss
text: One afternoon in April in Baruipur, a rural expanse on the edge of Kolkata, Sujan Chakraborty, a leader of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), presided over a meeting with party workers before he set out to campaign on foot, days before the parliamentary election vote was held there.

headline: Mary Barra of G.M. on Internal Report
text: In an internal investigation, General Motors cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to address a safety problem that the company links to 13 deaths and 47 accidents.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank Gets Serious About Fighting Deflation
text: The European Central Bank has seemed hopelessly behind the curve for ages, its leaders sitting on their hands as their continent seemed to drift inexorably toward Japan-style deflation.

headline: When Plans Go Out the Window
text: Four years ago, when Finnerty Steeves bought her sunny Greenwich Village studio for $380,000, she thought she would remain there for the rest of her life.

headline: How the Recession Reshaped the Economy, in 255 Charts
text: Five years since the end of the Great Recession, the private sector has finally regained the nine million jobs it lost. But not all industries recovered equally.

headline: The Age of Online Memory
text: The poetically-named “right to be forgotten” has been much discussed recently, after a European court ruled last month that E.U. residents can force Google to remove certain embarrassing search results about them. Indeed, according to a Time magazine article published yesterday, Google is receiving 10,000 requests per day to be ‘forgotten’ in Europe. Neither the decision nor the volume of interest among Europeans in exercising this new “right” will affect Americans directly, but they may feed into a bigger conversation about memory and forgetting at a time when so much about our lives is recorded online.

headline: Fears for Sergeant’s Life Led to Secrecy About Swap, Obama Official Says
text: WASHINGTON — A senior Obama administration official said Thursday that the operation to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was kept a closely held secret because of fear that splits within the Taliban could lead gun-wielding guards to kill the soldier before he was turned over to American forces last weekend.

headline: 1964: D-Day Remembered
text: OFFICIAL INVITATION — The engraving above is the frontispiece of an invitation to the commemorative ceremonies of the 20th anniversary of D-Day sent to distinguished persons by the D-Day Commemorative Committee, an official French group which is headed by Minister of Cooperation Raymond Triboulet. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 5, 1964.

headline: Newly Elected Parliamentarians Take Oath in Sanskrit
text: NEW DELHI -— At least two dozen newly elected members of India’s lower house of Parliament, which had its second meeting on Thursday, took their oaths in Sanskrit, India’s traditional language that harkens back to its ancient civilization.

headline: Suspect in Brooklyn Stabbings Is Charged With Murder
text: The man arrested on Wednesday night in connection with the stabbing death of a 6-year-old Brooklyn boy was charged on Thursday with murder, the police said.

headline: Putting a Price Tag on Nature’s Defenses
text: After Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, the United States Army Corps of Engineers got to work on a massive network of levees and flood walls to protect against future catastrophes. Finally completed in 2012, the project ended up costing $14.5 billion — and that figure didn’t include the upkeep these defenses will require in years to come, not to mention the cost of someday replacing them altogether.

headline: In Store | A Cozy New L.A. Design Nook
text: One gets the feeling that Scott Barry and Brooke Intrachat would not be at all upset if you visited their new L.A. store Ouli simply to collapse into the buttery silver leather beanbag pouf (their design) and page through the adjacent copy of The Gentlewoman. In fact, with its exposed wood ceiling and feathery floral arrangements, Ouli is designed to feel more like a cozy, well-appointed living room than a gallery. “People come in and say, ‘what is this, a meditation center?'” says Barry.

headline: Karl Ove Knausgaard Brings His Struggle to Brooklyn
text: About 30 minutes before the start of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s event at the relatively small and narrow Community Bookstore in Park Slope on Wednesday, people packed the entire space in a scene more reminiscent of the calm before an indie-rock storm than an author appearance. Ezra Goldstein, an owner of the store, approached a microphone. “Don’t get excited,” he said. “This is just a sound check.”

headline: Harper Lee Lawsuit Is Dismissed
text: Updated, 5:59 p.m. |

headline: New Access to a Nicaraguan Island
text: The government of Nicaragua is betting that a new $10 million airport will boost tourism on Ometepe Island, a Unesco Biosphere Reserve known for its towering twin volcanoes.

headline: Three Things Students Wish Teachers Knew
text: As the school year winds down, I thought it would be helpful to hear from students in the vein of “Five Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew” and “Three Things Parents Wish Teachers Knew.” I spoke with and emailed over a hundred students in grades kindergarten through 12, enrolled in independent and public schools all over the country, and asked them to think back on the past year and come up with just one thing they wished that their teachers knew. The top three:

headline: Josh Boone Narrates a Scene From ‘The Fault in Our Stars’
text: In this video, Josh Boone narrates a sequence from “The Fault in Our Stars,” featuring Shailene Woodley, Ansel Elgort and Nat Wolff. In the scene Isaac, played by Mr. Wolff, gets revenge on his ex-girlfriend with cartons of eggs and some friendly encouragement.

headline: Ryan Carson of Treehouse, on When Titles Get in the Way
text: This interview with Ryan Carson, chief executive of Treehouse, an online interactive education platform, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Facts & Figures: Before and After ‘Obamacare’
text: Although few Americans say the Affordable Care Act has helped them, the uninsured rate has declined significantly since the law took effect, and appears to be leveling off at around 13.4 percent.

headline: Strasbourg Music Festival Closes, Cites Poor Ticket Sales
text: The Strasbourg Music Festival has closed its doors just days before Sunday’s opening concert. France’s oldest classical music festival, the event was scheduled to run through June 15 and feature prominent artists such as the pianist Krystian Zimerman and the conductor Sir John Eliot Gardiner, leading the English Baroque Soloists.

headline: Gannett Would Unlock Value by Splitting Off Publishing Unit
text: A breakup of Gannett is inevitable. Gannett, the owner of USA Today and other newspapers, is not getting much credit for the transformation of its television segment. As Time Warner sets its publishing arm free this week, a Breakingviews analysis suggests Gannett should do the same.

headline: When the Teacher Is Depressed
text: The toll that a mother’s or father’s depression takes on children has been well documented: Children of depressed parents may become anxious or withdrawn, may have trouble regulating their emotions or dealing with challenges, and may develop behavior problems or even become depressed themselves.

headline: DNA Test Indicates Camel-to-Human Transmission of MERS
text: In the clearest evidence yet that the MERS virus can be passed directly from camels to humans, genetic sequencing has shown that a 44-year-old Saudi man who died of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome in November had a strain virtually identical to that in one of the camels in his herd, researchers said on Wednesday.

headline: Moving On by Moving Around
text: Caregiving is a delicate dance, with a gradual shift in who is leading and who is following. One partner is, often, a frail, widowed mother, upended by the loss of her husband and living in the family home, too big, costly and difficult to maintain.

headline: D-Day, 70 Years Later: A Frenchman Says, ‘Merci’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lennon Manuscripts Go for Nearly $3 Million in Auction
text: More than 100 John Lennon manuscripts — including short stories, poems and line drawings – have sold for $2.9 million, more than double the pre-sale estimate, at Sotheby’s in New York, Reuters reported.

headline: Clinton’s Hectic Pace Acts as Retort to Health Fears
text: It was roughly 7 a.m. the day after Hillary Rodham Clinton had left her job as secretary of state. She had been up for a while and called a friend. “O.K., I’m rested!” Mrs. Clinton told her friend.

headline: Wheelies: The Audi Flagship Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Living With Cancer: Chronic, Not Cured
text: At the end of yoga sessions for cancer patients, we are told to say to ourselves, “I am whole, healed and healthy in this and every moment.” Perversely, since in yoga we express aspirations as if they were already so, the sentence reminds me of people who congratulate me on being “cancer free.” Stable disease often goes unrecognized.

headline: Listen Up | The Smooth, Psychedelic Sounds of Glass Animals
text: Dave Bayley, the frontman for the quirky new Oxford, England-based band Glass Animals, says his original life plan was to become a doctor. In fact, Bayley insisted on finishing his degree in medicine at King’s College London before officially forming Glass Animals with three of his high school friends, Drew MacFarlane, Edmund Irwin-Singer and Joe Seaward, in 2012. It was a second beginning of sorts: Bayley had published some of the quartets demos on the Internet in 2010, but had removed them almost immediately when they proved too popular. “People started getting in touch,” says Bayley. “We didn’t know what it was like to be in a band. We didn’t know anyone in a band at all, so we freaked out and took everything off the Internet.”

headline: The Fault in the Cobalt Ignition Switch
text: Diagram of the faulty metal pin that led to the G.M. recall of 2.6 million Chevy Cobalts.

headline: Statements on Shooting in Canada
text: A witness and spokesman for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police described the scene on Wednesday night after three police officers were killed by an armed man still at large in Moncton, New Brunswick.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Offers Rules to Govern Fast Trading
text: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | The stock market has transformed in the last decade into a place dominated by high-speed traders zapping orders to many exchanges, while regulators have been slow to react.

headline: In Terms of Fans, the Heat Have Already Beaten the Spurs
text: Some of the commentary around the N.B.A. finals assumes that most Americans are rooting for the Spurs to beat the Heat. That makes sense. The Spurs are a likable group, with an older core of players perhaps chasing a last title. And they’re trying to dethrone a team that was built in large part on big-name free agents, including one who took his “talents to South Beach.”

headline: Abstract Painter’s Afterlife, Reborn
text: Raymond Spillenger, who died in November at the age of 89, was among the very last of the first- and second-generation Abstract Expressionists. There can’t be many others remaining, and few more obscure than Mr. Spillenger, who left scant traces. Some of his paintings hang — or have hung — at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, at the Contemporary Arts Museum in Houston and at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, and his name is mentioned in a few of the reference books. That’s about it. Mr. Spillenger’s reputation, or lack of one, is a reminder that the great art movements rise and then fall — with Abstract Expressionism eased aside by Pop, in turn overtaken by Super-Realism, Minimalism and all the other isms — and that from any one moment, often only a handful of names survive, some for good reason, some just from luck or self-promotion.

headline: Before Arrest, a Long String of Violent Acts
text: Just before dawn on Wednesday, a man thought by the police to be Daniel St. Hubert sat on a bench in a Chelsea subway station. Two weeks before, Mr. St. Hubert had been released from a five-year term in prison for trying to strangle his mother with an electrical cord.

headline: Deutsche Bank Warns Investors on Currency Investigation
text: LONDON – Deutsche Bank warned investors on Thursday that continuing investigations by financial regulators into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets could have a “material” financial effect on the bank.

headline: G.M. Internal Investigation Report
text: The results of an investigation overseen by Anton R. Valukas, a former United States attorney, into the company’s handling of a defective ignition switch.

headline: Dither, a Guitar Quartet, to Play at the Noguchi Museum
text: When the Miser’s not out scouring the city on your behalf for all things cheap, he’s been known to do a little pickin’ on the guitar, an instrument he was inspired to adopt as a teenager, predictably enough, by the great Jimi Hendrix. But the Miser was much less interested than his peers in learning Hendrix’s soulful solos by rote and much more taken with how he made music out of sonic “mistakes” — feedback, static, effects — and a general irreverence toward proper technique.

headline: Obama on G.I. Release at Group of Seven
text: President Obama said he makes “no apologies” for seeking the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in a prisoner swap with the Taliban and defended the exchange, which has dogged him on his European trip.

headline: Image of the Day: June 5
text: The World Environment Day is celebrated every year to spread awareness about pressing environmental issues.

headline: Today in Small Business: Women in Manufacturing
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Biggest Champion of a Sprint-T-Mobile Deal: SoftBank’s Chief
text: Sprint and T-Mobile have seemingly, inexorably been heading toward a merger agreement for more than a year. And such a deal has had no more outspoken advocate than Masayoshi Son, the Japanese billionaire who controls Sprint.

headline: Bergdahl Is Said to Have History of Leaving Post
text: WASHINGTON — A classified military report detailing the Army’s investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in June 2009 says that he had wandered away from assigned areas before — both at a training range in California and at his remote outpost in Afghanistan — and then returned, according to people briefed on it.

headline: Homecoming Queen
text: As party tricks go, Jennifer Lopez has the best and most effective one: Regardless of her milieu, she comes off as if she’s slumming. Making records and having songs on the radio? That’s not something she appears interested in doing particularly often, even though she’s welcomed when she does. Making movies? Here and there, sure, but nothing notably great in years. Appearing on television? On “American Idol,” she had twice the wattage of anyone else around her.

headline: Australia Doesn’t Seem So Far Away
text: Here is the choice: a bottle of brown HP sauce, with London’s Houses of Parliament in sky blue on the label and a secret recipe (tomatoes, tamarind, dates, molasses, malt vinegar, mysterious spices) dating from the late 19th century, or a ramekin of mayonnaise laced with a house-made sambal of bird’s-eye chiles, fish sauce and palm sugar.

headline: The Triple Crown Eleven
text: Horse racing fans are used to the disappointment. Eleven times a horse has come into the Belmont Stakes having won the first two legs of the Triple Crown in the years since Affirmed captured the last one in 1978. Eleven times, it didn’t happen. Each came with such possibility, and each left with heartbreak. When Spectacular Bid was outgunned down the stretch by Coastal in 1979, no one knew the drumbeat of failure that was ahead, that would become the unofficial background music of the Belmont.

headline: Scottish Independence Debate Will Reach Edinburgh Fringe Festival
text: When David Bowie was named best British male solo artist at the Brit Awards in February, his acceptance speech, read on his behalf by Kate Moss, included the plea “Scotland, stay with us,” and he thus entered the divisive public debate over Scottish independence, which will come to a vote in September. Mr. Bowie’s phrase is the inspiration for “All Back to Bowie’s,” a freewheeling and decidedly political presentation by a group of Scottish artists, including David Greig and Cora Bissett, that is planned for this summer at the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe. The show will include poetry, music and more in a variety format that will be different at each performance.

headline: Barra Addresses G.M. Employees
text: The General Motors chief executive, Mary T. Barra, presents the findings of an internal investigation into the company’s faulty ignition switches.

headline: Jessye Norman: By the Book
text: The singer and author of “Stand Up Straight and Sing!” cried when she read Marian Anderson’s autobiography, “My Lord, What a Morning”: “She blessed this earth by walking upon it.”

headline: Al Jazeera Journalists Speak From Behind Bars in Cairo
text: Speaking to reporters during a recess in their trial in Cairo on Thursday, two Al Jazeera journalists, wearing prison whites and shouting from inside a cage, denounced a prosecutor’s claims that they had facilitated terrorism and sought the downfall of the Egyptian state by reporting on current events before their arrest last year.

headline: Maria Sharapova in French Open Final Again; Another Phenom Awaits
text: PARIS — It had almost become routine. Maria Sharapova was in the French Open semifinals again. Maria Sharapova forgot how to serve again. Maria Sharapova lost the first set again.

headline: Year-End Roundup, 2013-14 | Language Arts, Journalism and the Arts
text: This week, we are looking back at all the lesson plans we published during the 2013-14 school year.

headline: BNP Paribas Executive May Leave in Deal With Regulator
text: Under pressure from the United States authorities, the giant French bank BNP Paribas is considering cutting ties to one of its most senior executives, a rare concession that points to the severity of an investigation into the bank’s dealings with Sudan and Iran.

headline: The Dangers of ‘Brain’-Speak
text: The “brain” is a powerful thing. Not the organ itself — though of course it’s powerful, too — but the word. Including it in explanations of human behavior might make those explanations sound more legitimate — and that might be a problem.

headline: Dunford, Commander in Afghanistan, Is Picked to Lead Marine Corps
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is nominating Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the commander of American and allied forces in Afghanistan, to lead the Marine Corps as commandant, the Defense Department said Thursday.

headline: Australia, the World Cup’s Unluckiest Country
text: Among the thousands of draws that Australia could have received, its actual first-round grouping is the worst one possible.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 7
text: The 2014 World Cup begins next Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Titillation or Illumination on The Times’s New ‘Sin Beat’?
text: Mosi Secret’s new beat — sin in New York City — has already resulted in a big spread in last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, an article in The New York Observer and a lot of Twitter traffic.

headline: Group of 7 Leaders on Russia
text: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Russia will face tougher sanctions from group members if President Vladimir V. Putin refuses to work with Ukraine’s new government.

headline: To Some, Taliban Prisoners Are Gitmo’s Most Famous Five
text: WASHINGTON – They have in recent days become known as “The Dream Team,” the “Taliban Five” and the “Crown Jewels” of the captives held in the military prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Brazil Posts Double Win with Simultaneous Soy Boom and Deforestation Drop
text: Brazil is considered a front runner as it hosts the World Cup, but on the long-troubled boundary between its agricultural frontier and the Amazon rain forest the country is already a big winner, according to a paper being published in the journal Science on Friday. Just savor this line for starters:

headline: Play About Lester Bangs to Get World Premiere
text: The world premiere of “How to Be a Rock Critic,” a play based on the life and words of the influential music writer Lester Bangs, will cap off the 2014-15 season at Center Theater Group in Culver City, Calif.

headline: Mexico, the World Cup’s Luckiest Country
text: Mexico finished far behind the United States in the two rivals’ World Cup qualifying group — and made the tournament only because the United States scored late in a match it did not need to win.

headline: Burwell Wins Confirmation as Secretary of Health
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday confirmed the nomination of Sylvia Mathews Burwell to be secretary of health and human services, which will make her responsible for delivering health insurance to more than one-third of all Americans.

headline: Newest Cabinet Member Is Never Far From Her Roots
text: HINTON, W.Va. — When President Bill Clinton had thrashed out his first difficult budget with advisers, he turned to one of his younger aides for the final word, a seal of approval. “Sylvia, are the folks in Hinton going to think we’ve done right by them?” he said.

headline: Germany Leans Toward Allowing Fracking
text: BERLIN — In a potential shift in German energy policy, the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel is preparing a framework that would let energy companies extract oil and natural gas by the controversial practice of hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

headline: There Is No Such Thing as a ‘Clean’ Execution
text: Several commenters took exception to a line in a Taking Note post last week about Ohio’s moratorium on executions, which followed a series of botched attempts there and elsewhere to kill inmates using lethal injection.

headline: Less Than Half of New York City’s Applicants for Pre-K Get Their Top-Choice School
text: Fewer than half of New York City children seeking a free prekindergarten seat received one in their top-choice public school for the next school year, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Thursday.

headline: Aquino on China’s Move in Disputed Seas
text: President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines criticized China for moving ships capable of reclaiming land around the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

headline: International Criminal Court to Focus on Sex Crimes
text: THE HAGUE — Alarmed by the growing evidence of the abuse of women during conflicts, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court has pledged to step up the court’s investigation and prosecution of sexual and gender-based crimes, including in cases that may involve offenses other than explicit physical brutality.

headline: Senators Reach Accord Easing Worries Over Veterans’ Health Measure
text: WASHINGTON — In the wake of a revelations that officials at veterans hospitals across the country have been manipulating patients’ appointment times by creating secret waiting lists, two senators reached a bipartisan accord on Thursday to give authority to the acting Veterans Affairs secretary to fire senior officials and to expand access for veterans who do not live near medical facilities or have experienced long waits.

headline: Wedding Q. & A.
text: Addressing an Unwelcome Split

headline: In the Belmont Stakes, a Rested Commanding Curve
text: Terry Finley is a West Point graduate who served as an Army captain and an airborne Ranger. He began forming horse racing partnerships under the name West Point Thoroughbreds in 1991. Experience has taught him to cope with pressure and strip emotion from decisions.

headline: When Brides Were Often Teenagers
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Study Finds College Girl Weds Later” appeared on June 1 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.)

headline: Modern Love | Beyond Years
text: Tim and Sarah McEown never saw their 22-year age difference as an obstacle in their relationship, until Tim had a heart attack.

headline: Company Fined $21 Million for Selling Parts to Iran
text: A unit of Fokker Technologies of the Netherlands, a leading aerospace company and Pentagon contractor, has agreed to pay $21 million in penalties to settle accusations that it repeatedly violated American sanctions on sales of aircraft parts to Iran and Sudan, the United States government announced Thursday.

headline: The Way They Were
text: Pierre Bergé responds to a new film about his consuming yet caustic relationship with Yves Saint Laurent.

headline: The Challenges of Negotiating With Goliaths
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about negotiating with bigger businesses. Deirdre Lord, who owns the Megawatt Hour, has been negotiating with several large potential clients. She wondered whether the process is particularly challenging only for smaller companies just starting out.

headline: In a Small Bag, She Packed All Our Hopes (Updated With Podcast)
text: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actor Harry Lennix in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below or subscribe on iTunes or Google Play Music.

headline: A Slowly Roasted Fish to Serve With Portuguese White Wines
text: Sometimes I take the “What if?” approach to cooking and have had more successes than errors. A few weeks ago I decided to roast some stunningly fresh ocean perch whole. But what if, instead of my usual hot-roasting method, I wrapped the fish tightly in parchment and put it in a slow oven? I was risking $18 worth of fish and the prospect of takeout for dinner. I guessed that the fish, about two pounds, might need an hour and reasoned that succulence might define the end result.

headline: NYT Sports E-mail Signup
text: Sign up for NYT Sports, a regular digest of news, highlights and context from New York Times staff.

headline: Staying True to Native Grapes
text: Of all the historical wine-producing countries, Portugal is the most overlooked.

headline: More Fathers Who Stay at Home by Choice
text: Otis Johnson said he never fathomed becoming a stay-at-home father. But soon after he was laid off from his factory job in 2009, his first of two children arrived. And even when his job prospects improved, he made the calculation that millions of mothers had made before him: “By the time I get a paycheck, it all goes to day care, or I can stay home and raise my own children.”

headline: This Weekend: Three Original Series
text: If you’re in the mood to watch some TV this weekend, be sure to check out the second season of “Orange Is the New Black” on Netflix, the new comedy “Spooked” on Hulu or the new drama “Power” on Starz.

headline: Susan Spencer-Wendel, Memoirist About Living and Losing Life, Dies at 47
text: Susan Spencer-Wendel, a former newspaper reporter who wrote a best-selling memoir about living life to the fullest after learning she had an incurable muscle-wasting disease — and wrote most of it on a smartphone with her right thumb — died on Wednesday at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 47.

headline: Sweden Returns Ancient Andean Textiles to Peru
text: One of the world’s most precious troves of looted antiquities — brilliantly colored burial shrouds from an Andean civilization that flourished a thousand years before Columbus — is on its way back to Peru for a ceremonial handover in Lima.

headline: Bodies Politic
text: While on a state visit to Warsaw to mark the 25th anniversary of the end of communism in Poland, President Obama took time out to pump some iron in a hotel gym — though not a lot of it. A leaked video showing him grunting and grimacing under the weight of what appeared to be a modest set of dumbbells drew attention from observers who seemed underwhelmed.

headline: In Wake of Telecom Consolidation, Few Deals Are Left
text: Telecommunications bankers are running out of deals to pitch.

headline: Texas Republicans May Endorse Gay ‘Reparative’ Therapy
text: Over the past few years the march toward marriage equality has been slow and steady, and the reality-based community has recognized that there is no stopping or reversing the process.

headline: Stuyvesant Town Lenders Move to Prevent Investor From Seizing the Property
text: Despite the turmoil that has racked Manhattan’s largest apartment complex over the past eight years, Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village is still an object of desire for speculators, investors and the tenants who make it their home.

headline: The Gun Report: June 5, 2014
text: When most people think of Google Glass, they imagine Sergey Brin bopping around town sporting wiry, futuristic spectacles that make phone calls, go online and record everything you see. A growing number of people equate the new technology with concerns over privacy violation—so much so that Glass pioneers, who are easily identified by their headsets, have been discriminated against in public settings. Few equate the burgeoning technology with guns. But that may change.

headline: Iran Offers a Window to the West
text: Given a chance, and a week, to visit Iran, John Moore took to the road in central Iran to see daily life in a place that has opened a bit to the West.

headline: ‘Upfront’ Market for TV Ad Sales Begins to Move
text: Madison Avenue and big television networks are starting to make deals for the purchase of commercial time ahead of the 2014-15 season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: A Hollywood Sexual-Abuse Suit Is Dropped
text: LOS ANGELES — Michael Egan, the accuser in a series of Hollywood sex-abuse lawsuits, has dropped his complaint against David Neuman, a former Disney television executive.

headline: The Rush to Demonize Sgt. Bergdahl
text: Four months ago, Senator John McCain said he would support the exchange of five hard-core Taliban leaders for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. “I would support,” he told CNN. “Obviously I’d have to know the details, but I would support ways of bringing him home and if exchange was one of them I think that would be something I think we should seriously consider.”

headline: Hard-Boiled
text: Halfway through “Mr. Mercedes,” billed as Stephen King’s first hard-boiled detective novel, a fedora makes an appearance. It’s a winking gift to the retired cop hero, Bill Hodges, from his first client, Janey Patterson. “Every private dick should have a fedora he can pull down to one eyebrow,” she tells him. Hodges tries it on for size, as do Jerome (his teenage Watson) and even Janey herself. No one seems to hang on to it for long. Then, at a critical point in the story, it disappears in a flash.

headline: Man on a Mission
text: Jimmy Carter may be the most pious man ever to have occupied the White House. He was “born again” at age 11 and has taught Sunday school for decades. His penchant for godliness has ranged from prophetic — he was most likely the only businessman in 1950s Plains, Ga., to refuse to join the White Citizens’ Council — to priggish: As president, he once told civil servants who were “living in sin” that they ought to get married.

headline: The Poster Child for Menopause
text: When Sandra Tsing Loh started her book “The Madwoman in the Volvo,” her aim was to capture the experience of what she calls the “triple-M generation:” the menopausal, middle-aged mother.

headline: Tanaka (9-1) Stops the A’s, and the Yankees’ Slide
text: Early in the season, even when the Yankees’ starting rotation was at the vanguard of their success, there was always an extra jolt of excitement when Masahiro Tanaka took the mound.

headline: Mary Anthony, Choreographer and Teacher of Modern Dance, Dies at 97
text: Mary Anthony, a modern dancer celebrated since the 1940s for the lyricism and drama in her choreography but even better known as a teacher of some of American dance’s leading performers and choreographers, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: Peter Glaser, Who Envisioned Space Solar Power, Dies at 90
text: Peter Glaser, who in the late 1960s envisioned a way to harness limitless solar power in space and transmit it for use on Earth via invisible microwaves — a notion so intriguing that the government spent $20 million studying it, only to conclude that it was too complex and expensive — died on May 29 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 90.

headline: Harvard Confirms Book Is Bound in Human Skin
text: Scientists at Harvard have confirmed that a 19th-century French treatise in the university’s libraries is almost surely bound in human skin, thus ending months of uncertainty and setting off a torrent of online Hannibal Lecter (get it?) jokes.

headline: Accident Prone
text: Elizabeth McCracken knows how loss can melt reality, forever altering a person’s sense of time. In “An Exact Replica of a Figment of My Imagination,” a deeply affecting memoir about the stillbirth of her son, she tells us that she sought to write “a book that acknowledges that life goes on but that death goes on, too, that a person who is dead is a long, long story.” In her new collection, McCracken gives brilliantly splintered life to just that kind of story: These pages are filled with sudden deaths and lingering ghosts, some passings that are imminent, others that are uncertain or inferred.

headline: An Education
text: Translated books make up only about 3 percent of titles published in America, so I’m ecstatic to see the Korean writer Kyung-sook Shin’s rising popularity. Her previously translated novel, “Please Look After Mom,” hit the New York Times best-seller list and is now available in more than 20 countries.

headline: An Inner Life
text: “What Is Visible,” a fictional biography, opens with two disparate glimpses of one life. A year before her death, elderly Laura Bridgman meets a busy-handed child named Helen Keller. Next we witness a much earlier historic encounter when Laura, at 12, meets Charles Dickens. The elder Laura is grumpy; the adolescent loops between self-aggrandizement and epic self-doubt. We’re asked to forgive all, because of circumstances more dire than any invented by Dickens or borne by Keller. As a baby, Laura suffered an illness that took her sight, hearing, and senses of smell and taste.

headline: REPLAY
text: With an eye on today’s events, looking anew at historical sports photographs from The New York Times.

headline: Asia Society Museum Director to Lead Hirshhorn
text: Melissa Chiu, the Australian-born, veteran director of Asia Society Museum in New York has been chosen to lead the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, a Smithsonian division that is trying to regain its footing after a series of bruising fights over finances, leadership and direction.

headline: Snatching Atari Back From the Grave, Again
text: It’s a fitting symbol for Atari that the most attention it has received in years occurred when one of its products, a notorious flop, was excavated from a landfill in April.

headline: ‘Citizen Koch’ and the Politics of Big Money
text: Part of the impact of “Citizen Koch” comes from juxtaposing average Americans with the moneyed interests that grip today’s political process. When we see a Republican in Wisconsin weighing her dissatisfaction with her party and her stance on abortion, it’s an inspiring sight of a citizen at work, grappling in good faith with the situation at hand. It’s a world away from the documentary’s portrayal of Americans for Prosperity, the conservative advocacy group funded by the billionaires David and Charles Koch.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Burning Woman
text: If menopause just made you want to kill someone, it wouldn’t be so bad. The problem is, it makes you want to kill someone you love. And then it makes you want to love someone who’s a complete and utter moron. And there you have it: the story of half the divorces in America.

headline: Over There: Daughters of Liberty
text: ON A WAR’S FRONT LINE, FROM A WOMAN’S VIEW

headline: A Passionate Symbol, Even Without the World Cup
text: In “Waste Land,” Lucy Walker’s Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, the Brazilian photographer Vik Muniz trekked around a garbage dump and collaborated with its workers in the name of art. It was topical, revelatory and inspirational. In “This Is Not a Ball,” directed by Mr. Muniz and Juan Rendón, the artist has another project — a piece for the 2014 World Cup (less than a week away!) involving 10,000 balls — but the process of documenting it only bogs down this film.

headline: New Bug Found in Widely Used OpenSSL Encryption
text: Security experts are still trying to plug the hole left by Heartbleed, the bug found in the widely used OpenSSL encryption protocol, with some 12,000 popular domains still vulnerable, according to AVG Virus Labs.

headline: A Taste of Charleston, Old-School and New
text: Rain was falling in fits and starts on a late afternoon in downtown Charleston, and sodden azalea blossoms were scattered across the sidewalk along Queen Street.

headline: Chic Stops in the Suburbs of La Paz, Bolivia
text: For the first time in a long time, La Paz is having a moment. And the center of the city’s gentrification is now the Zona Sur — made up of four adjoining suburban neighborhoods — which sits 1,000 feet lower and is noticeably warmer than the far more visited colonial city center, a 15-minute taxi ride away. Pushed along by a culinary project from Claus Meyer, co-founder of Noma in Copenhagen, the well-heeled area has seen an influx of modern additions that the Andean city has long lacked.

headline: For Kentile Floors Sign, Star of Brooklyn Skyline, the End Seems Near
text: The language of the plans recently approved by the New York City Buildings Department seems unambiguous:

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Judging a Fan’s Soccer I.Q. by His Jargon
text: We continue our series of crib sheets designed to help readers watch the World Cup like a true fanatic — or at least sound like one. Learn the right phrases to yell at the screen while watching the matches.

headline: Heaven and Earth, Sized to Grasp
text: Paper is the mother lode of the Morgan Library & Museum, and one of the great through lines of civilizations everywhere. Nearly every Morgan exhibition, whether of prints, drawings, rare books or musical scores, enlarges the understanding of paper as a means of expression, both personal and cultural. Right now, windows are being opened there by two delightfully focused exhibitions that center on artists using paper to different ends, in different centuries and parts of Europe.

headline: A Star Client List and a Magic Touch
text: A valentine from one friend to another, “Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon” is not entirely kidding about that title, or at least its tone. Directed by the comedian Mike Myers, this clubby documentary lauds the swellness and shrewdness of the talent manager Shep Gordon with the help of celebrities and the sunnily mellifluent subject himself.

headline: On View | Henrik Vibskov, Fashion’s Renaissance Man, Showcases His Fine Art
text: With the Paris men’s collections just a few weeks away, the Danish fashion designer Henrik Vibskov is busy at work. But it’s not just clothing that’s on his mind. When he spoke to T, he was busy putting the finishing touches on “Vibskovski;72 II,” his new solo exhibition at the Cologne art space Ruttkowski;68. He’d also submitted the first proposals for a collaboration with his fellow Nordic multihyphenate Björk, a supersize restaging of her album “Medúlla.” And then there’s the fragrance he’s developing, the upcoming art exhibitions in Moscow and Seoul, a set design for this month’s Roskilde Festival and a handful or so of other projects in progress listed on the pink sticky notes on his computer.

headline: At a Wedding, You Are What You Wear
text: I’m going to a wedding this summer, which means once again I am dealing with the sleeve problem. You ladies of a certain age know what I am talking about. There comes a time in your life, even if you have a personal trainer and are taking your meals in the gym, when the muscles and skin on your inner upper arms give up. It’s as if they’re saying: “Oh, the hell with it. Where’s the bar?” They’re just hanging off the bone, exhausted.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, Israel, South Korea and France.

headline: At Museum Born of Politics, New Chief Faces Economics
text: A little over a year ago, El Museo del Barrio, the oldest museum in the United States devoted to Latino art, had the equivalent of a nervous breakdown in public.

headline: Pining for a Burnished Time, Long Ago and Far Away
text: As in politics, so in art: Some movements want to hasten us into the future, some want to turn back the clocks to a supposedly better time. “The Pre-Raphaelite Legacy: British Art and Design,” a small exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a modest introduction to one of the 19th century’s most interesting backward-looking groups.

headline: A Few Carcasses Here, a Few Landscapes There
text: The lines between museums and galleries have become blurry, with major Chelsea dealers mounting scholarly, historical exhibitions. But it takes more than just great material to achieve a “museum quality” show, as you are reminded at the Paul Kasmin Gallery exhibition of 16 paintings by the Belarus-born Expressionist Chaim Soutine (1893-1943).

headline: The Parent Trap
text: At the end of a long birthday party, my son put his hands around my nephew’s neck. (The boys are 7 and 4.) My brother-in-law yelled at my son before my husband had a chance to address the situation. My husband demanded we leave immediately. My son, who has some special needs, got upset and began screaming that he hated his uncle and called him selfish and stupid. A subsequent talk with my sister did not go well. She downplayed her husband’s yelling and thinks we should have corrected my son for his outburst. I disagree. No one yells at my son but me. Ideas?

headline: ‘Common Spaces’
text: The Kitchen

headline: Jay DeFeo
text: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: sunburned teenagers, MERS and MRSA. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Ibrahim El-Salahi: ‘Selected Works, 1962-2010’
text: Skoto Gallery

headline: Joyce Robins: ‘Paint and Clay’
text: Theodore:Art

headline: Fund Manager Sets Goats Grazing in Blighted Detroit
text: To most of the world, the solution to debt-ridden Detroit is money. But for one hedge fund manager, it’s goats.

headline: What I’m Reading
text: On my nightstand right now is a stack of books about soccer. They were part of my plan to write a column called, at least in my own mind, “How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the World Cup.” (Columnists don’t choose the headlines).

headline: Shoo-Ins Are Few in Heated Tony Race
text: IN a departure from recent Tony Awards seasons, when popular musicals like “The Book of Mormon,” “Once,” and “Kinky Boots” were dominant, voters for Sunday’s prizes are likely to spread them around. But among which shows? Which performers and artists? Making predictions is unusually difficult this year, with few clear-cut favorites, more wild cards than usual and some fierce races involving Hollywood stars, veteran stage actors and past Tony winners.

headline: Clip: ‘Edge of Tomorrow’
text: A scene from the film featuring Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt.

headline: Killed in Action by Aliens, Over and Over Again
text: Tell me if you’ve heard this one before. A man wakes up and quickly realizes that he’s repeating yesterday, down to the last meal, salutation and conversation. He’s trapped in a kind of time loop. He can’t escape, but, he realizes, he can change. That may not make sense, given the logic of the space-time continuum, but it works just fine in fiction because, well, it’s fiction. To put it another way, “There are no paradoxes in time travel, there can’t be.” Or so says a character in Robert A. Heinlein’s 1964 novel, “Farnham’s Freehold,” about space, time and the apocalypse.

headline: Celebrating in Prospect Park
text: Celebrate Brooklyn!, in its 36th year, will put on a series of free concerts by an all-star lineup.

headline: For Father’s Day in London, a Brawnier Tea
text: In honor of Father’s Day on June 15, the Milestone Hotel in London’s Kensington neighborhood is offering “Gentleman’s Afternoon Tea.”

headline: Guggenheim Abu Dhabi Plans a Preview Show
text: The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, one of three museums being built on the windswept Saadiyat Island in the capital of the United Arab Emirates, has been a quieter presence than the two other institutions there. The Louvre Abu Dhabi, designed by the French architect Jean Nouvel, which is scheduled to open next year, and the Zayed National Museum, created by the British architect Norman Foster and to be completed in two years, have each had exhibitions at Manarat Al Saadiyat, the island’s exhibition and visitor center, offering previews of their institutions. Now it is the Guggenheim’s turn.

headline: The Islands Treasured by Offshore Tax Avoiders
text: Did you know that United States companies earned $129 billion in 2010 in three small groups of islands?

headline: Clip: ‘Obvious Child’
text: A scene from the film, featuring Jenny Slate and Jake Lacy.

headline: Right Guy Is Just One in a World of Choices
text: We first encounter Donna Stern, the 28-ish heroine of Gillian Robespierre’s “Obvious Child,” doing standup in a ratty Brooklyn club, putting her own idiosyncratic spin on the currently popular style of boundaryless, confessional, body-conscious humor. Donna is played by Jenny Slate, whose résumé (“Saturday Night Live,” “Parks and Recreation,” “Bob’s Burgers”) reads like a Google map of the modern comic universe and who easily juggles the sweet and nasty sides of her temperament.

headline: Pro Wrestlers Add Heft to Campaign for Better Parenting by Fathers
text: THE Advertising Council is joining forces with World Wrestling Entertainment on a public service campaign promoting the importance of men being better fathers.

headline: A Regent of Retro and Future
text: Every narrative needs a tension, and in the kinetic, fantastical saga of Janelle Monáe’s career, it boils down to the tug-of-war between abandon and control. At the Prospect Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, she was wheeled onstage in a straitjacket, her posture and pompadour briefly evoking the Bride of Frankenstein. Breaking free, she headed straight into “Givin Em What They Love,” a prowling funk processional whose title refrain lands somewhere between a boast and a pledge.

headline: A Home Invader, Creepily Charismatic
text: There is no one who resembles a sleeping princess, a fairy godmother or a dashing romantic savior in the Dutch filmmaker Alex van Warmerdam’s malevolent adult fairy tale, “Borgman.” The story’s magic is black, its perfidy driven by evil spirits.

headline: Theater Listings for June 6-12
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 6-12
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for June 6-12
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Days After a Federal Seizure, Another Type of Ransomware Gains Ground
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It has been mere days since federal agents seized control of computer networks used by hackers to infect victims with CryptoLocker, a piece of malware known as “ransomware,” which encrypts the contents of computing devices so hackers can demand a ransom to decrypt it.

headline: Unanswered Questions From G.M.’s Report
text: Matthew L. Wald, a Times business reporter, had three unanswered questions after the release of an internal investigation into General Motors’ ignition switch problems.

headline: 70 Years After D-Day, Veterans Return to Normandy
text: With the youngest participants in the 1944 storming of five Normandy beaches now 88, these anniversary commemorations may be, for many, the last memorial pilgrimage.

headline: A Scary Experience With Edible Marijuana
This Week’s Movies | June 6, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.”

headline: European Central Bank on Inflation Fight
text: The European Central Bank president, Mario Draghi, announced several measures to fight low inflation and boost the euro zone economy.

headline: Fixes After BP Spill Not Enough, Board Says
text: HOUSTON — Federal safety regulators warned on Thursday that another disastrous offshore oil well blowout could happen despite regulatory improvements in the four years since a BP well explosion in the Gulf of Mexico killed 11 workers and dumped millions of gallons of oil into the sea.

headline: With Obama and Putin in France for Dinner, Hollande Leaves Room for Seconds
text: PARIS — Gourmand though he may be, it seems highly improbable that President François Hollande of France was moved by appetite alone to host two successive dinners here on Thursday night.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for June 6-12
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Discusses Russia, Syria and Iraq
text: In her memoir “Hard Choices,” Hillary Rodham Clinton writes about the United States’ troubled “reset” with Russia, says her vote authorizing the war in Iraq was “wrong,” calls Syria a “wicked problem” and gives a timetable of the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to CBS News, which obtained a copy of the book before its publication next week.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for June 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Book Fight: Amazon vs. Publishers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dance Listings for June 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Verizon Challenges Netflix’s Warning Messages Blaming It for Slow Streaming Service
text: Verizon fired back at Netflix on Thursday after it was revealed that Netflix showed its customers an error message blaming Verizon’s network for slowing the streaming of Netflix’s programming.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 6-12
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tea Party Dead-Enders
text: The Tea Party is five years old this election season, which means it’s done teething and spitting up on itself, but still prone to temper tantrums, irrational outbursts and threats to take its toys and storm off if it doesn’t get its way.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 6-12
text: SPROUTFEST

headline: In Brazen Strike, Sunni Militants Storm Central Iraqi City
