text: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of Sunni militants stormed the central Iraqi city of Samarra early Thursday, taking control of neighborhoods and government buildings in a siege that provoked a panicked government counteroffensive to prevent the loss of the town.

headline: The Climate Domino
text: Maybe it’s me, but the predictable right-wing cries of outrage over the Environmental Protection Agency’s proposed rules on carbon seem oddly muted and unfocused. I mean, these are the people who managed to create national outrage over nonexistent death panels. Now the Obama administration is doing something that really will impose at least some pain on some people. Where are the eye-catching fake horror stories?

headline: Spare Times for June 6-12
text: Museums and Sites

headline: The Political War
text: Pity Abraham Lincoln. Everything that should have gone right for the Union cause in the spring of 1864 had, in just a few weeks, gone defiantly and disastrously wrong.

headline: Where Bigfoot Roamed
text: As a comedian, Bobcat Goldthwait can seem like a colicky baby, spitting punch lines punctuated by random screams. As a filmmaker, however, he’s more focused and less predictable, channeling his choleric style into pointed satires on American society that sometimes hit their marks with uncomfortable directness.

headline: It Takes Some Heat to Create Movie Stars
text: Until it disintegrates in an explosion of sentimentality, “Trust Me” qualifies for what could be called “The Day of the Locust” award. That imaginary honor, named for the Nathanael West novel, would be bestowed on the year’s nastiest, most stomach-turning movie about no-holds-barred Hollywood wheeling and dealing. Such films are usually box office poison, but they still are made, perhaps because they give their creators a chance to vent.

headline: Clip: ‘Ping Pong Summer’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Michael Tully.

headline: It’s 1985 All Over Again
text: From its revenge-of-the-nerd narrative to its soaked-in-nostalgia style, “Ping Pong Summer” revisits the 1980s with such slavish affection that you suspect its writer and director, Michael Tully, of being notably transformed during those boom-box-blighted years. The film fairly beams with the afterglow of lost virginity.

headline: Shifts in Wireless Market May Sway a Sprint Deal
text: WASHINGTON — In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more.

headline: President Obama Was Right
text: Americans don’t have a common ancestry. Therefore, we have to work hard to build national solidarity. We go in for more overt displays of patriotism than in most other countries: politicians wearing flag lapel pins, everybody singing the national anthem before games, saying the Pledge of Allegiance at big meetings, revering sacred creedal statements, like the Gettysburg Address.

headline: Did Colorado Go Too Far With Pot?
text: Was the move to legalize marijuana done too quickly? Do changes need to be made to their approach?

headline: Nigerian Sect Kills Villagers Along Border
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The Boko Haram men, disguised in army uniforms, gathered the villagers together and promised them protection.

headline: Back Where He Belonged: An All-Satchmo Day
text: MAYBE it was the 50th anniversary of “Hello, Dolly” having knocked the Beatles off the top of the pop charts (May 9, 1964), but it occurred to me recently that with a little advance work, I could spend an entire day in New York with Louis Armstrong.

headline: Louis and Lucille Armstrong’s Creole Red Beans and Rice
text: Courtesy of Louis Armstrong House Museum Time: 6 hours

headline: Key Questions in the Release of Bowe Bergdahl
text: Sorting out the facts and the controversy surrounding the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.

headline: Steven H. Scheuer Is Dead at 88; He Put the TV Review Before the Show
text: Steven H. Scheuer, a television critic who helped change how newspapers reviewed programs and thus how viewers decided what to watch, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: House Democrats Set Off to Energize the Faithful, With a Focus on Women
text: CHICAGO — It is a politically gloomy midterm election year for Democrats, but Representative Nancy Pelosi and some of her House colleagues were on a roll this week.

headline: Researchers Race to Save Coral in Miami
text: MIAMI — With dredging set to begin this weekend in the Port of Miami, researchers are scrambling to salvage a much larger than expected trove of delicate corals that were not in the original marine life rescue plan for the undersea area.

headline: Belatedly, Europe Takes On Low Inflation
text: After months of doing too little, the European Central Bank on Thursday announced a series of policies to bolster the euro zone’s frail economy and avert deflation, which would weaken it even further.

headline: Where Some May Say No Thanks for the Memories
text: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — On the embankment of the lake at the heart of this city in the Urals, a half-built shopping center is slowly being turned into a monument to a man and an era that few in Russia remember fondly at all, even in the man’s native region.

headline: A Horror Story Borrows From History
text: The director Ti West, whose credits include the very fine horror movie “The House of the Devil,” has a talent for dread. He’s so good at raising the little hairs on your neck and keeping them on alert that you can only feel let down when he doesn’t deliver a movie that makes good on his setup. That’s the case with his latest, “The Sacrament,” a neo-exploitation flick that shifts from the unnerving to the hollow after it becomes evident that Mr. West is more interested in showing how his characters die than how they lived. It doesn’t help that he seems to encourage you to wish the worst on at least some of them, notably a troika that serves as this tale’s metaphoric blind mice.

headline: Clip: ‘The Sacrament’
text: A scene from “The Sacrament,” directed by Ti West.

headline: Soaring, and Souring, in Postseason Spotlight
text: LOS ANGELES — The Kings’ Justin Williams, a decent offensive producer in the regular season, is a monster during the playoffs. The Rangers’ Rick Nash, a big-ticket goal scorer in the regular season, has been virtually unable to score in the postseason.

headline: Remembering D-Day With Their Brothers in Arms
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Every morning, Lieutenant Michael Settanni wakes up next to his bunkmate, Cpl. Ben Gebbia, in a modest room in a home shared with about 350 other military men.

headline: An Old Warplane’s Do-Over Flight in France
text: Revisiting the skies it last braved during World War II, the New York-based war horse known as the Whiskey 7 was back over Normandy on Thursday, once again opening its doors and letting parachutists jump into the frigid air outside, 70 years after its — and the world’s — most famous invasion.

headline: Clip: ‘The Case Against 8’
text: A scene from the documentary.

headline: After Heartbreak, Time for Results
text: Rapid, aggressive police work led to the arrest on Wednesday of a suspect in the shocking stabbings of two children in a Brooklyn public-housing elevator on Sunday.

headline: A Tale That Nearly Had No End
text: As gay men living in California, Ben Cotner and Ryan White were “flabbergasted,” Mr. White recalled, by the passage of Proposition 8, their state’s 2008 ballot measure to deny the right of same-sex couples to marry. They didn’t expect it to win.

headline: On a Team of Stars, Only One Plays Like It
text: Sometimes, you really can predict baseball — at least when Masahiro Tanaka pitches. Those other days are the troublesome ones for the Yankees.

headline: Chester Nez, 93, Dies; Navajo Words Washed From Mouth Helped Win War
text: To the end of his life, Chester Nez recalled the first message he sent over the radio while serving at Guadalcanal: “Enemy machine gun nest on your right. Destroy.”

headline: A Legal Chess Game Leading to ‘I Do’
text: Opening in theaters before airing on HBO on June 23, “The Case Against 8” follows the legal challenge to Proposition 8, the 2008 referendum that banned same-sex marriage in California. Because the Supreme Court effectively nullified the ban last year — the decision said the initiative’s supporters lacked the standing to appeal a federal ruling striking it down — this documentary from Ben Cotner and Ryan White is less a work of immediacy than of backstage intrigue.

headline: Some See G.M. Report as Powerful Ammunition for Change
text: WASHINGTON — The chief for regulatory affairs is gone. So is a senior lawyer and two midlevel engineers. Two safety executives were also let go. The list is long — at least 20 in all — of those dismissed or disciplined by General Motors for their role in the company’s failure to correct a deadly safety defect in millions of its small cars.

headline: At French Open, Simona Halep Carries the Hopes of Romania
text: PARIS — One of the quirks and delights of the Grand Slam tournaments is that the historical tennis figures are often still here on site, playing in the senior events, watching from the stands or the commentary booths, hobnobbing in the hallways and presidents’ boxes.

headline: Bond Rally Is Squeezing the Trading at Big Banks
text: Wall Street’s biggest firms this year made an extraordinary wager that they probably now regret.

headline: Surviving a German Trading Floor, Ruefully
text: In “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jordan Belfort cuts short an explanation of his work, because, he says, we probably couldn’t follow the details. “Master of the Universe” attempts that explanation but offers a sobering antidote to irrational exuberance and a psychological case study in the financier’s mind-set. This indefatigable tell-all documentary from Marc Bauder cedes the floor to Rainer Voss, a German ex-trader who tells us with clarity about how it all works.

headline: How to Meet Cute in France: Whimsical Stabbings, Genial Strokes
text: Life doesn’t proceed as methodically as in the screenplay of a skillfully plotted commercial film. Unforeseen events interrupt the flow and destroy the symmetry. The randomness of life and the capriciousness of human nature were recurrent motifs in French New Wave movies of the 1960s and ’70s. And in “2 Autumns, 3 Winters,” the Gallic filmmaker Sébastien Betbeder’s breezy, lighthearted homage to the films of Jean-Luc Godard and others, fate keeps stepping in to alter the destinies of its three principal characters, Arman (Vincent Macaigne), Benjamin (Bastien Bouillon) and Amélie (Maud Wyler).

headline: Shooting Leaves One Dead at Seattle Pacific University
text: SEATTLE — A man armed with a shotgun opened fire on the campus of Seattle Pacific University on Thursday afternoon, leaving three people wounded and one dead before being taken into custody, the Seattle police said.

headline: Woman in an Endless Coma, Circled by Endless Debate
text: Thought and feeling are never far apart in the films of Marco Bellocchio. From his precocious beginnings in the 1960s with “Fists in the Pocket” and “China Is Near,” Mr. Bellocchio, now 74, has explored weighty ideas — about Italian society and politics, about the struggle between faith and secularism in the modern world, about authority, idealism and sexual desire — with passionate, at times melodramatic, ardor.

headline: The Complex Battle to Achieve the Perfect Dirt
text: A week before the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes, a tractor with wheels practically the size of horses towed a grader along the track while a worker on the back checked the depth of the dirt’s surface every couple of feet.

headline: For a Decade, G.M. Response to a Fatal Flaw Was to Shrug
text: Just six months ago, a group of senior General Motors executives gathered to review a series of PowerPoint slides concerning a question that had been smoldering inside G.M. for a decade: Should the company recall hundreds of thousands of small cars because of a dangerous defect?

headline: Playing Ball in the Shadow of Warfare
text: If nothing else, “The Only Real Game,” a documentary about baseball in Manipur, in northeastern India, serves as an antidote to the Disney film “Million Dollar Arm,” which also involves baseball and India. Here, America’s game is played with armed troops looking on and with very little prospect of a happy ending.

headline: Faces of an Immigration System Overwhelmed by Women and Children
text: SAN ANTONIO — This is what it looks like when an immigration system is overwhelmed by tens of thousands of women and children from Central America.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 8-14, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Girl, 7, Recovering From Elevator Stabbing
text: Her best friend is dead, stabbed to death on Sunday by a strange man who followed them into an elevator in a public housing project in East New York, Brooklyn. A suspect is in custody, his history of violence and mental illness now the subject of intense scrutiny.

headline: Clip: ‘Burt’s Buzz’
text: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Syria: Assad Praises Election and Iran
text: A day after his re-election in a disputed vote, President Bashar al-Assad said on Thursday that the 73 percent turnout the government reported in the vote sent a message that Syrians were “determined to manage their own affairs,” brushing off criticism of the vote and calls for an internationally brokered political transition. Syria’s state news agency reported that Mr. Assad, who made the comments during a meeting with a high-ranking Iranian official, Alaeddin Boroujerdi, also praised Iran’s nuclear program, the subject of intense international negotiations. Iran says the program is for civilian purposes, while the United States says it is a military program. Mr. Boroujerdi was part of a delegation of election observers from Iran — a country that has provided considerable support to ensure the survival of Mr. Assad. The Iranian delegation declared that the election, in which the president garnered 89 percent of the vote, was free and fair. Mr. Assad’s opposition has denounced the election as a farce.

headline: Missed Out on Millions, but He’s the Spartan Sort
text: The word “icon” is given quite a workout in “Burt’s Buzz,” a documentary about the man whose likeness adorns Burt’s Bees products. It’s to the film’s detriment. Not only is the word overused these days, but it also has no business being applied to a pitchman for a product line that may have fans but is hardly a dominant cultural force. The film, by Jody Shapiro, seems so hagiographic that when it finally gets around to its 20 minutes’ worth of interesting stuff, you’re not sure whether to trust it.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Camels and Livestock Are to Be Tested for Traces of a Virus
text: The authorities in Saudi Arabia, alarmed over the rising human death toll from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus, said they would start testing the kingdom’s entire population of camels and other livestock next week, Saudi newspapers reported Thursday. The Arab News quoted Fahd Balghuneim, the agriculture minister, as saying the tests to determine the extent of infection would be conducted via blood or mucus samples. Saudi Arabia has in the past few days adopted a more aggressive response to the virus, known as MERS, which originated in the country two years ago and has been linked to camels, which spread the virus to humans. On Tuesday, the Health Ministry said a review showed that the death toll was 282, 92 more than reported a day earlier, and it announced that the deputy health minister had been relieved. On Wednesday, in the clearest evidence yet that MERS can be passed directly from camels to humans, research published in The New England Journal of Medicine said genetic sequencing had shown that a Saudi man who died of MERS in November had a strain virtually identical to that in one of the camels in his herd.

headline: Events on Long Island for June 8-14, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Tense Search, Chilling Note and an Arrest in Brooklyn Stabbings
text: Around 8 p.m. Wednesday, a man paused at a corner in Ozone Park, Queens, and scrawled letters and symbols on a stop sign:

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 5, 2014
Crossing Borders Through Cinema
text: “Filmistaan” celebrates the power of cinema to bridge divides, but the mirth doesn’t entirely travel in this Bollywood production about an aspiring actor, Sunny (Sharib Hashmi), who is kidnapped by Pakistani militants. While the film mixes genres in the inimitable Bollywood style, that premise, at least, is played for laughs.

headline: Bringing Blood to the Neighborhood
text: In the 1980s, Hong Kong cinema came up with its own version of a comic monster movie. It was no “Ghostbusters,” but “Mr. Vampire,” mixing traditional Chinese folk tales of “hopping vampires” with action and humor, proved successful, spawning numerous sequels.

headline: Witness Says Senator Was ‘Marginalized’
text: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — Malcolm A. Smith was feeling “marginalized,” as his State Senate colleague put it at his bribery and wire fraud trial on Thursday.

headline: Rushing Headlong Into the Hurly-Burly
text: Hearts beat fast in the thrilling new “Macbeth” that has transformed the Park Avenue Armory into a war zone, and every breath starts to feel like a gasp. Rob Ashford and Kenneth Branagh’s galloping British-born production, which opened on Thursday night with Mr. Branagh in the title role, saturates everyone in it in adrenaline. Make that everyone watching it, as well.

headline: Language Originally Known As Mocha
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Every now and then, people write to me asking for advice on constructing and, although I sadly no longer have time to actually collaborate with constructors, I always enjoy discussing the aspects of construction. Once in a while, among those who write to me, there emerges a truly nice person with charmingly good manners, who is not only smart but loves the process of learning and furthermore, puts it to good use.

headline: Astros End Trend By Selecting Pitcher Out of High School
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — In 1991, the Yankees selected Brien Taylor, a high school left-hander, with the first overall pick in baseball’s amateur draft. His failure to make the majors scared teams away from showing similar faith in a prep pitcher in the 22 drafts that followed.

headline: A Culture of Child Rape in Liberia
text: Looking for a villain in Jessica Vale’s documentary? There’s competition. Obviously, in “Small Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story,” about a 7-year-old rape victim in Liberia, there is the man who attacked her so brutally that her genitals were mangled and covered in scar tissue. He was a 20-year-old cousin. She was left with a fistula requiring numerous surgeries to repair, if it could be fixed at all.

headline: Navy Pilots Under the Gun
text: At last it’s come along: the “Reefer Madness” of gay rights. In D M W Greer’s supposed drama “Burning Blue,” a military official worries aloud that if man-on-man sex among its fighter pilots is not punished severely, the Navy could be perceived as being run by a “perverse cult.”

headline: What Experts Say About the Belmont Stakes
text: Some respected veterans of the horse racing world were asked to assess Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, in which California Chrome could end the sport’s Triple Crown drought. Some quotations have been condensed.

headline: Shaken, G.I.’s Hometown Waits for All the Facts
text: HAILEY, Idaho — From the time of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s capture five years ago, Zaney’s River Street Coffee House has been ground zero for information about and support for the soldier and his family.

headline: He’s Just Like Her Ex-Boyfriend, Down to the Tattoo
text: Alfred Hitchcock disliked whodunits; he felt viewers became too bound up in guessing the solution. That principle holds true for the director Jane Weinstock’s “The Moment,” a psychological thriller that shrouds its mysteries in layers of hallucination and unreliable narration.

headline: A Journey for the Soles and the Soul
text: The Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain, where, legend holds, the Apostle James is buried, has drawn pilgrims since the Middle Ages. So it’s not as if the most popular Camino de Santiago, the 500-mile Camino Francés, which starts at St.-Jean-Pied-de-Port in the Pyrenees, needs any publicity. Still, “The Way,” Emilio Estevez’s 2011 film about four modern-day hikers — one played by his father, Martin Sheen — introduced many to the trek and its meditative pleasures.

headline: Debating the Possibility of Winning by a Nose Patch
text: California Chrome’s owners would be ecstatic if a nose — and perhaps a nasal strip — makes the difference in the one-and-a-half-mile Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: What I’ve Been Watching
text: Now it can be told: All of the recent Times columnist forays into interactivity and transparency — the reader Q&As, the reading lists — have been building up to this week’s launch of our new Op-Ed app, which offers readers an all-access pass to the high-stakes, occasionally drug-fueled world of Times opinion journalism.

headline: War’s Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing
text: After his fourth combat tour, to Afghanistan in 2011, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, a proud member of the Army Special Forces, came home alienated and angry. Once a rock-solid sergeant and devoted husband, he became sullen, took to drinking, got in trouble with his commanders and started beating his wife.

headline: Cracking Down on Illegal Mortgage Referrals
text: A federal agency is aggressively going after mortgage, title and real estate companies that it believes are violating laws prohibiting payments or incentives for customer referrals.

headline: On the Road, and on the Run
text: The first stage of Italian neorealism documented wartime destruction and endemic poverty; the second, rosier stage added a touch of fantasy; the third recorded the spiritual emptiness of Italy’s economic miracle. Dino Risi’s “Il Sorpasso” (1962), originally released in the United States as “The Easy Life” and newly out from Criterion in a dual-format edition, is of that third stage.

headline: Billionaire Issues Statement About Times Article
text: The billionaire Chinese financier Xiao Jianhua, the subject of a New York Times profile on Wednesday, said he did not make money through his political connections but by following Warren Buffett’s value investing strategy.

headline: Rangers Put Aside Turnover That Led to Overtime Loss in Game 1
text: LOS ANGELES — The Rangers said they had no concerns about Dan Girardi, whose turnover led to Justin Williams’s overtime goal in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Surrounded by Nature
text: A petite and picturesque Upper West Side penthouse, with a lush wraparound terrace that replicates the Old World charm of a European garden yet provides forever views of Central Park and the evolving cityscape to the south, is poised to enter the market at $3.995 million. The monthly maintenance for the light-filled two-bedroom two-bath unit, PHC, is $3,468.

headline: Global Times Editor Apologizes to Chinese Veterans Over Online Post
text: The editor of a prominent Chinese newspaper has apologized after saying in a tweet suggesting that some soldiers in China’s 1979 war with Vietnam shirked participation in “dare-to-die” squads that carried out risky, suicidal missions.

headline: N.I.H. Seeks $4.5 Billion to Try to Crack the Code of How Brains Function
text: The National Institutes of Health set an ambitious $4.5 billion price tag on its part of President Obama’s Brain Initiative on Thursday, stamping it as an effort on the scale of the Human Genome Project.

headline: Lowly Cubs Sweep as Mets Fill Bases but Don’t Clear Them
text: CHICAGO — With the crack of Anthony Rizzo’s bat, there was no doubting what would happen next. No doubt the ball would land in the bleachers in right-center field to put the Chicago Cubs ahead. No doubt the Mets would strand base runners with the game still in reach. And no doubt that the crowd would sing “Go, Cubs, Go,” the team’s anthem.

headline: He Was a Different Person
text: Susan Ullman has worked for better support services for Special Operations troops after her husband, a sergeant in the Army Special Forces, committed suicide.

headline: Breaking Down a Bid for History at the Belmont Stakes
text: The horses for the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the Belmont, which will be run at 6:52 p.m. Saturday, and both are picking California Chrome to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978. The morning-line odds were set by Eric Donovan of Belmont Park. (The trainers are pictured.)

headline: My Travels With Brazil’s World Cup Curse
text: An animated storybook by the magazine’s contributing illustrator, Christoph Niemann, about a World Cup game from 64 years ago that still haunts Brazil.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 6, 2014
text: “We broke these guys. We need to do our best to send them back into the civilian sector as whole as possible.”

headline: The Workout | Becoming Rocky Balboa
text: Andy Karl plays Rocky Balboa in the Broadway adaptation of “Rocky.” He shares some of the strength- training moves he uses to stay in shape for the show’s workout montages and fight scenes.

headline: Tavi Forever
text: From tween blogger to feminist editrix to Broadway actor, Tavi Gevinson is embarking on her next project: being a grown-up.

headline: The Workout: Becoming Rocky Balboa
text: Not many Broadway stars have to dodge punches on stage. But for Andy Karl, it is all in a night’s work.

headline: Word of the Day | franchise
text: franchise •\ˈfran-ˌchiz\• noun and verb

headline: Openness on Israeli Issues Seen in Survey of Iranians
text: JERUSALEM — An unusual survey of Iranian public opinion indicates that 40 percent of Iranians would be willing to give up any ability to produce nuclear weapons in the future in return for the full removal of sanctions.

headline: Girls’ Night Out With Jamaican Spice
text: There is no Lily at Miss Lily’s 7A, a hyper-stylized Jamaican restaurant that opened by Tompkins Square Park last month, namesake of a place on Houston Street. What there is is an exuberantly clashing Caribbean color scheme, some retro reggae album covers, bottled jerk sauces and waitresses in short shorts.

headline: In Thailand, Growing Intolerance for Dissent Drives Many to More Authoritarian Nations
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Thailand, long the liberal bastion of Southeast Asia, has traditionally been a haven for refugees from its less democratic neighbors. Now, in the wake of a recent coup, a small group of Thai intellectuals are making the reverse journey — heading to Cambodia and other more repressive nations as their own country cracks down on dissent.

headline: As in Past, Underdog Goal Is to Exploit Divisive Party
text: With a ticket led by State Senators Wendy Davis of Fort Worth and Leticia Van de Putte of San Antonio, Democrats are hoping to break a political drought that has lasted since 1998, the last time a member of their party held statewide office.

headline: Facing the Law, but Running to Uphold It
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Halfway Houses Meet Fraction of Demand for Former Inmates
text: When Terry Pelz, a former warden with the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, testified against a prison gang leader, Mark Fronckiewicz, in the 1993 capital murder trial of a fellow inmate, he had choice words.

headline: North Korea Detains 3rd American in New Threat to Relations With U.S.
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A municipal worker from Ohio on a tour of North Korea has been detained there for unspecified illegal acts, making him the third American known to be currently held in the isolated country and threatening to further aggravate its tense relationship with the United States.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: PIRATE PICTURES The comedian Greg Proops takes his humor to the high seas as host of this monthlong festival, which begins with Frank Lloyd’s silent version of “The Sea Hawk” (1924), about a British noble (Milton Sills) sold into slavery who escapes and turns himself into a pirate king. Henry King’s “The Black Swan” (1942), starring Tyrone Power as a swashbuckler intent on cleaning up the Caribbean after he’s named governor of Jamaica, follows at 10:15; Frank Borzage’s “The Spanish Main” (1945), in which a Dutch ship’s captain (Paul Henreid) turns Caribbean pirate and kidnaps the future bride (Maureen O’Hara) of a corrupt Spanish governor (Walter Slezak), at midnight; Felix Feist’s “Pirates of Tripoli” (1955), with Henreid as a buccaneer trying to help a deposed Arab princess (Patricia Medina) reclaim her throne, at 2 a.m.; Sidney Salkow’s “The Golden Hawk” (1952), with Rhonda Fleming and Sterling Hayden as pirates who join forces against yet another corrupt Caribbean governor, at 3:30; and Lew Landers’s “Hurricane Island” (1951), about a captain (Jon Hall) searching for the fountain of youth alongside Ponce de León (Edgar Barrier), at 5.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Killing of Three Mounties in New Brunswick
text: OTTAWA — A man suspected of fatally shooting three Canadian Mounties and wounding two others, putting a Canadian city under a virtual siege, was arrested early Friday, the police said.

headline: George J. Armelagos, Anthropologist Who Told Skeletons’ Tales, Dies at 77
text: George J. Armelagos was a reader of bones.

headline: A ‘Modern-Day Knight’ Who Helped Fleeing Tiananmen Activists
text: HONG KONG — WHEN tens of thousands of people gathered in Hong Kong this week to mourn the military carnage against protesters in Beijing 25 years ago, Chan Tat Ching stood among them, holding a candle and bowing to honor the dead.

headline: A Solution to Horse Racing’s Medication Problems
text: On-track pharmacies have the potential to restore racing integrity in America.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 8-14, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Corrections: June 6, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Events in Connecticut for June 8-14, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Bear Rescue Plan Delayed by Permit Problems
text: When a group of international animal welfare advocates reached an agreement with a Chinese bear bile farm in April to turn it into a sanctuary, they planned to transport 28 of the sickest animals to their rescue center for treatment. That plan has hit a snag because it is taking longer than expected to obtain a government permit for the bear transfer.

headline: Journalist Detained in Shenzhen Said to Be American
text: A journalist based in Hong Kong who was arrested last week by the Chinese police is an American citizen, people close to the case said Friday.

headline: In Vietnam, Paying Communities to Preserve the Forests
text: KALKILL, Vietnam — Before the patrollers spotted the interlopers, they heard the sounds of illegal logging.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing, June 6, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Young Love, Complicated by Cancer
text: In “Young Love, Complicated by Cancer,” A. O. Scott reviews the film “The Fault in Our Stars.”

headline: Populist Party Fails to Capture Seat in British Parliament
text: LONDON — Despite momentum from a surprisingly strong showing in recent European elections, the populist right-wing United Kingdom Independence Party failed to win its first seat in the British Parliament when it finished second to the Conservative candidate in a special election, according to results announced Friday.

headline: What Was Your Favorite Field Trip?
text: Have you ever taken a field trip that broadened your horizons — or taught you something that you would have never learned from a textbook? Perhaps you visited a Buddhist temple, a butterfly conservatory or a historic cemetery? Or maybe you just took a class trip that was really fun?

headline: Horse Racing Fades in Italy
text: The immaculate racetracks of Naples loomed like coliseums in the mind of Marco Casino.

headline: British Video Game Retailer Raises $203.4 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Game Digital, the British video game retailer controlled by the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Friday that it had raised about $203 million in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: On 70th Anniversary, the Memories of D-Day Are Replayed at Normandy
text: VIERVILLE-SUR-MER, France — At Camp Dog Green, recreated just a few miles inland from where combat raged on and around the Normandy beaches in June 1944, soldiers in American uniforms and nurses with the Red Cross insignia on their breast pockets mill among the drab green tents, tuning their tinny radios to the music of Glenn Miller. They appear to be just waiting for orders.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Don’t Fear the Mosquitoes
text: Good morning to you on this clearing Friday.

headline: Best of Both Worlds? Northeast Cut Emissions and Enjoyed Growth
text: Some critics of the Environmental Protection Agency’s new requirements for power plants argue that forcing emissions reduction will curtail economic growth. But the recent experience of states that already cap carbon emissions reveals that emissions and economic growth are no longer tightly tied together.

headline: Awkward Diplomacy as Leaders Gather
text: BÉNOUVILLE, France — As President Obama wrapped up a four-day European trip on Friday, the violent conflict over Ukraine seemed to move toward a new phase of diplomacy, but it remained unclear whether the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, was genuinely willing or able to call off a pro-Russian uprising across his border.

headline: Vietnam Says Video Shows Chinese Ship Intentionally Sinking Boat
text: Vietnam has released a video that it says shows a Chinese fishing boat intentionally ramming into a smaller Vietnamese fishing boat, causing it to sink.

headline: Suicide Bomb Hits Convoy of an Afghan Candidate
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bombing on Friday struck a convoy of vehicles carrying one of the candidates in Afghanistan’s presidential runoff election next week. The candidate, Abdullah Abdullah, escaped unharmed, but at least six other people were killed.

headline: One More Senior Official Reportedly Kills Himself
text: Depression and suicide reportedly claimed another Chinese government official this week, bringing to at least 15 the number of officials said to have committed suicide in the last 18 months, according to Chinese news media.

headline: Daily Report: Changes in Wireless Market May Influence a Sprint Deal
text: In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Plotting the World Cup Coverage
text: Andrew Das, an assistant sports editor, will fly to Brazil this weekend to prepare coverage of the World Cup soccer tournament, which begins on Thursday. We asked him what readers can expect.

headline: It’s Not Too Soon to Pay Attention to Senate Polling
text: Just five months until November’s midterm elections and already early polling results have countered some expectations. In Arkansas, the Democrat Mark Pryor is showing surprising strength in a red state, and in North Carolina, Kay Hagan is trailing as an incumbent in a battleground state. We won’t know how accurate polling is until after the election, so for now, the very relevant question is, How much should we care about early polls?

headline: Morning Views
text: President Obama’s opponents have pounced on the decision to trade five Taliban leaders in exchange for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. This is yet another example of the hypocrisy which “now pervades the Republican party and the conservative movement,” The New York Times editorial board writes. “The critics seeking political advantage don’t care about the life or mental state of a particular soldier, or of a principle of loyalty that should provide comfort to any soldier in danger of capture. They live only for the attack.”

headline: Morning Agenda: S.E.C. Takes on High-Speed Trading
text: S.E.C. TAKES ON HIGH-SPEED TRADING  |  Regulators have been slow to react to changes in the stock market, which in the last decade has evolved into a place dominated by high-speed traders. Now, the Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to update the market’s rules for the new era, DealBook’s William Alden writes. On Thursday, Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the S.E.C., unveiled a sweeping package of recommendations for new rules and other changes geared toward strengthening the structure of the market and improving disclosures for investors.

headline: For Some Retirees, a Second Act Is Easier Than Expected
text: NEVER in a million years did Cheryl Delaney expect to spend her retirement working with the elderly. Her entire career had been in the financial sector — as a bank officer and loan administrator, in collections and finally as an office manager at Fidelity Investments in Boston. Changing bedpans was not on her bucket list.

headline: Struggling to Understand ‘Slenderman’
text: Slenderman, a fictional character said to have inspired two young Wisconsin girls to stab a third, continues to disturb America. Beyond the obviously upsetting nature of the crime, many are asking what — if anything — it says about contemporary society that a figment of the Internet’s imagination might have driven two children to violence.

headline: Soaring Past Low Expectations
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Giant, pallid and fleshy, the faces of Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum are plastered all over Los Angeles. On billboards, buildings and buses, their mirrored-sunglasses-wearing selves seem to be promoting their new movie, “22 Jump Street,” everywhere.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Season 2 Begins in a More Menacing World
text: Episode 1, Season 2: O.K., so maybe The Litch had started to feel too comfortable, its Secret Santa and movie nights making it seem more Smith College common room than women’s minimum-security prison.

headline: Singing Nun Wins Italian TV Talent Show
text: ROME — She trilled and thrilled millions of YouTube viewers with songs by Alicia Keys, Cyndi Lauper and Bon Jovi. She belted out a duet with Kylie Minogue, both of them clad in black, albeit with vastly different approaches to style.

headline: We Are the World (Cup)
text: PARIS — At dinner recently, one of my 5-year-old twins announced that he intended to learn Croatian.

headline: Vodafone Reveals Direct Access by Governments to Customer Data
text: LONDON – A number of governments have the ability to tap directly into the communication network run by the British telecommunications company Vodafone, a level of surveillance that elicited outrage from privacy advocates when the company disclosed it on Friday.

headline: Remembering Operation Bluestar on Its 30th Anniversary
text: Thirty years ago, on June 6, 1984, the Indian Army open fired on the Akal Takht, the shrine inside the Golden Temple of Amritsar, one of the holiest sites for India’s Sikh community, in the state of Punjab.  Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, the militant Sikh leader with a popular following in the state, had occupied the temple with armed followers.

headline: In Our Pages: June 7
text: 1939: New York’s ‘Woman of 1939’

headline: 217,000 Jobs Added, Nudging Payrolls to Levels Before the Crisis
text: After a series of peaks and valleys that confounded optimists and pessimists alike this year, the American economy seems to have settled into a healthy, if not spectacular, pace of job creation.

headline: China Will Deport Detained Artist, Australia Says
text: BEIJING — An Australian artist born in China who was detained shortly after publicizing images of a replica of Tiananmen Square he made out of ground pork will be deported from China, Australian officials said on Friday.

headline: Subway Hero Rescues Wedding Ring
text: Dear Diary:

headline: What’s News in Washington: D-Day Remembrance
text: Good Friday morning from Washington. It has been a week focused on veterans of war and prisoners of war and it concludes with commemorating the beginning of the end of the last World War.

headline: In Jobs Report, Two Milestones
text: This morning’s jobs report has two important labor market milestones. First, the total number of nonfarm jobs has finally climbed back above its pre-recession level. This comes fully six years and four months after employment last peaked, meaning that it has taken longer to recover from this recession than in any previous post-World War II downturn.

headline: Vanishing Into the Role
text: Six years ago, the Australian actor Guy Pearce played an unusual but crucial role in “The Hurt Locker,” Kathryn Bigelow’s Academy Award-winning Iraq drama. Appearing at the beginning of the film, Mr. Pearce was a bomb expert who seemed set to be a primary character. As it turned out, his performance was limited to a single scene, but its impact set up the film’s high-stakes authenticity.

headline: On Set | Tavi Gevinson Grows Up
text: Writer, actress and Rookie editor in chief Tavi Gevinson talks coming of age, Kanye and her dream interview subject.

headline: Quick Action Kept School Shooting Casualties Down, Police Say
text: SEATTLE — Students at Seattle Pacific University gathered on campus Friday in small prayer circles and at large candlelight vigils to mourn the violence that exploded in a science and engineering building, when a young man walked in with a shotgun on Thursday afternoon. One student was killed and two others were wounded. One of them remained hospitalized Friday in serious condition after hours of surgery.

headline: Good News on Jobs. Why Aren’t We Happier?
text: We did it, America! Six and a half years after the Great Recession began, and five years after it ended, we have now regained all the jobs lost during the downturn. Huzzah!

headline: For Miami Heat and Spurs, Hot Arena Plays Big Role in Game 1
text: SAN ANTONIO — As the temperature began to climb inside AT&T Arena Thursday night, the failure of the air-conditioning system seemed to be nothing but an annoyance.

headline: Buying a Guaranteed Retirement Income, for Some Peace of Mind
text: Many workers long for the sense of security that only an old-fashioned pension can provide. The big insurers are well aware of this, and that’s why many of them are offering new ways for investors to buy and build a pension on their own.

headline: Found Poetry Favorite | ‘The Elvish Doings in the Forest’
text: This poem, by Libbie, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a dance review, “There’s Brightness When the Fog Clears.”

headline: A Four-Month Streak of Sturdy Job Growth
text: The United States economy has added more than 200,000 jobs in each of the past four months, the Labor Department reported Friday.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | May 2014
text: On the first Friday of every month we publish a collection of articles about teenagers featured in The New York Times.

headline: The Politics of the P.O.W. Coverage
text: The story has dominated the headlines for a week — the dramatic swap of an American prisoner of war for five Taliban prisoners.

headline: Trying to Go Legit, Despite the In-Laws
text: The first intimation that “Power,” a new series starting Saturday on Starz, is not about the West Wing or the building of the Hoover Dam comes in the opening credits.

headline: Interview With a Torturer
text: LONDON — In 1997, in the newly democratic South Africa, a black female psychologist met a white male convict in Pretoria Central Prison. The psychologist, Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, had just completed a doctoral fellowship at Harvard and had returned to the country to serve on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The man she had asked to meet was Eugene de Kock, a former policeman nicknamed “Prime Evil,” who had led a covert counterterrorism unit dedicated to the torture and killing of anti-apartheid activists.

headline: Private Jobs Have Recovered. Government Jobs Still Lag.
text: The United States economy has finally exceeded its pre-recession employment peak, as many analysts of today’s jobs report have noted. But that milestone obscures two very different stories — in the private and public sectors. The public sector — federal, state and local government — still isn’t close to returning to its pre-recession employment levels.

headline: 5th Batch of Clinton-Era Papers Is Released
text: WASHINGTON — The National Archives unsealed about 2,000 documents from the Clinton administration on Friday, the fifth such release in recent months of memos, transcripts and speeches that had been withheld from public view.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic: ‘I’m Never Satisfied’
text: The Swedish soccer star talks to Wm. Ferguson about growing up an outsider in Sweden, the motivational power of anger and missing the World Cup — despite being the best.

headline: Obama and Putin Meet Briefly Over Ukraine
text: BÉNOUVILLE, France — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held private talks with President Obama and with the newly elected leader of Ukraine on Friday as both sides in the violent conflict in Eastern Europe tried to ease a geopolitical showdown that has shaken the post-Cold War order.

headline: New Fire Commissioner Returns to a Challenged Department
text: In a room deep inside Fire Department headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn, flat screens line the walls, tracking every fire and emergency medical incident in New York City. The last time Daniel A. Nigro was in this operations hub, before his retirement as chief of department a year after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, the room had all the technological grandness of a broom closet.

headline: The World Cup Hairdo Hall of Fame
text: In his travels throughout Brazil in anticipation of the World Cup, Christoph Niemann, the magazine’s contributing illustrator, found soccer fever so intense that he couldn’t help seeing famous footballers — and their hair — wherever he looked.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Letters: ‘My Accidental Jihad’
text: ‘My Accidental Jihad’

headline: Nazism
text: WHY THE GERMANS? WHY THE JEWS?  Envy, Race Hatred, and the Prehistory of the Holocaust  By Götz Aly  Metropolitan/Holt, $30.

headline: The Top Shelf of Journalism Books
text: This week, David Carr, The Times’s Media Equation columnist and a culture reporter, reviews “The Invention of News,” by Andrew Pettegree. I asked Carr and a few of his colleagues to recommend their favorite books about journalism.

headline: Going Native
text: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Fire on the Mountain
text: Michael Koryta is a fearless stylist who has put his hand to ghost stories, historical novels, killer-thrillers, revenge tragedies, morality tales and detective stories. He’s now swinging from the high wire with THOSE WHO WISH ME DEAD (Little, Brown, $26), a heart-thumping backwoods adventure that sends two creatively sadistic killers into Montana’s Beartooth Mountains, where they spark a monster forest fire to flush out the only witness to their crimes: Jace Wilson, a 14-year-old boy. Jace was just trying to escape his reputation as class coward when he dived into a quarry near his Indiana home. But when he swam into a dead man — and spotted the killers flinging a second victim into the water — Jace knew he was going to die. Reborn with a new name, he finds himself among the “bad kids” in a grueling wilderness survival course, parked there when his parents couldn’t be persuaded to put him in a traditional witness protection program. Jace’s hunters, the Blackwell brothers, are heartless sociopaths whose professional detachment is etched in their unnervingly precise grammar and careful diction. (“The way they say things. Like they’re alone in the world. Like it was built for the two of them and they’re lords over it.”) There will be no mercy from that quarter.

headline: Border Crossings
text: In “The Italian System,” a wry, knowing story in Francesca Marciano’s first collection, “The Other Language,” the unnamed protagonist is planning a lifestyle guide for Americans. Seven years earlier — a period that evokes the scent of a fairy tale — she had moved to New York from Rome on a whim, having secured a place in a creative writing workshop at the New School. She fell in love with the city and so has never left, despite the fact that this place she adores hasn’t exactly opened its arms to welcome her. She found work as a language teacher, initially telling herself this is simply “a way to pay the rent.” But, as is often the way with the quotidian, “teaching became her real job and she forgot about other aspirations.” And yet those aspirations don’t quite disappear. In the fresh new days of spring, she determines to put together a book, “The Italian System,” about how to live a Roman life in New York.

headline: Acting the Brute
text: We humans often like to trumpet our uniqueness among all the world’s biodiversity. We pride ourselves on our exalted, big-brained status and our resulting separation from everything else we lump together as “nature.” For Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson, the salient feature of our distinction is neither the power of language nor the potential for extreme acts of creativity nor even an opposable thumb. It is, rather, our “singular capacity for violence.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: NO EASY DAY: The Autobiography of a Navy SEAL — The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden,  by Mark Owen with Kevin Maurer. (New American Library, $16.) The May 2011 raid on Abbottabad, Pakistan, is the heart of this boots-on-the-ground account, but Owen (a pseudonym for Matt Bissonnette, a former member of the SEALs who served 13 consecutive combat deployments) also details the formation and evolution of one of the military’s most elite units.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CAN’T WE TALK ABOUT SOMETHING MORE PLEASANT?, written and illustrated by Roz Chast. (Bloomsbury, $28.) This scorchingly honest, achingly wistful graphic memoir looks at the last years of Chast’s nonagenarian parents.

headline: As the World Turns
text: One recent morning, I helped my son search for his misplaced shoes. They were nowhere to be found, so I took a peek under the couch. This was a rash move. The bend and twist required for ­under-couch viewing set off a wicked spin of dizziness, as I feared it would.

headline: B.A.s and I.O.U.s
text: We’re having the wrong conversation about higher education in our country. So argues Suzanne Mettler in her ­provocative new book, “Degrees of Inequality,” based on the eight years she spent studying a college system that she argues works well for those born into well-off families but few others. Tuition rates of $50,000 or more at private four-year colleges? The trillion-plus dollars Americans collectively owe on college loans? In ­Mettler’s ­telling, those should be the least of our worries when considering the “caste system” that is now higher education in the United States.

headline: Publish or Perish
text: Let’s be honest, no one likes literary wunderkinder. Twenty-­eight-year-olds are bad enough. Twenty-eight-year-olds whose first books become blockbusters? That’s just irritating. Joel Dicker, the 28-year-old Swiss author behind “The Truth About the Harry Quebert Affair,” doesn’t even have the decency to write dreck. His darkly comic debut thriller (already a blockbuster in Europe!) is unimpeachably terrific.

headline: Talking Talent | An Artist’s Directorial Debut
text: Andrew Levitas has the Midas touch. The 36-year-old artist, one of only a handful of American painters to ever study at the prestigious Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts in Paris, had never made a movie before he cast Garrett Hedlund and a whole slew of Oscar darlings (Amy Adams, Jennifer Hudson, Richard Jenkins, Terrence Howard) in his directorial debut, “Lullaby.” On June 13, his semi-autobiographical film about family and mortality will prove that the New York-based multihyphenate can write and direct the way he paints — with the confidence of a seasoned veteran and the vulnerability of a true artist.

headline: Settling Scores
text: It’s 1794 in London. In the dark Virginia & Baltick coffeehouse, huddling in the pungent shadow of tallow candles, four rich men are hatching a plan to marry off their daughters. Risen from the underbelly of the city, wheeling and dealing, they’ve made their fortunes in cloth, fur and timber. They’re successful and wealthy, but now they want sons-in-law with titles who will produce “grandchildren of a certain kind.”

headline: Conrad in Vietnam
text: Ward Just is both a writer’s writer and an astute tracker of human souls under duplicity and duress. He writes incisively, with striking imagery and with deep knowledge of how people in power behave, from ambassadors coping with the world’s hot spots to Midwestern community leaders suppressing a local crime. Like many distinguished novelists, Just was a journalist first, covering Washington, London and Saigon before the release of his first novel in 1970. “American Romantic,” his 18th, is one of his finest. It has all the qualities Just’s regular readers look forward to, yet it’s an equally good place to be introduced to his work.

headline: California Pioneers the Court-Aided One-Day Divorce
text: MARISSA YORK, a real estate broker in Manhattan, used a $50 online do-it-yourself divorce kit when she and her husband of more than nine years decided to part ways. Their breakup was relatively amicable, she said, so she figured they could save money by avoiding lawyers. “We didn’t want to drag it out over months or years,” she said.

headline: Bright Young Assistants
text: “My Salinger Year,” Joanna Rakoff’s breezy memoir of being a “bright young assistant” in the mid-1990s, opens with her decision to leave graduate school, desert her nice college boyfriend and move to New York to write poetry. Almost immediately, she falls for an overbearing aspiring novelist, takes a poorly paid job at a famous literary agency and lands in an unheated apartment in Williamsburg. “I wanted to be extraordinary,” she admits. Instead, she joins a legion of “girls” from comfortable backgrounds determined to live uncomfortably, at least briefly, in vague pursuit of Art.

headline: Leaders Meet to Honor D-Day
text: President Obama joined President François Hollande of France and others for a dinner while in Europe.

headline: Young and in Debt in New York City
text: For young people, moving to New York City hasn’t made much mathematical sense for decades. The jobs don’t pay enough, the internships don’t pay at all, and the rents are prohibitive by any sane standard.

headline: Jackie Robinson and Nixon: Life and Death of a Political Friendship
text: Here in Yankee Stadium’s locker room after Game 5 of the 1952 World Series, Senator Richard Nixon of California, Republican nominee for vice president, congratulates Jackie Robinson on the Brooklyn Dodgers’ 6-5 win over the Yankees. (The Dodgers ultimately lost in seven games.)

headline: Inside the List
text: Spotted: The actress and singer Lea Michele, who plays Rachel Berry on “Glee,” has a book on the advice, how-to and miscellaneous list: “Brunette Ambition,” her breezily memoiristic style guide and advice manual for women, is No. 13 in its second week. Among other things, Michele reveals she once tried to cover up an outbreak of acne using a strategy she’d seen on TV. It didn’t go well: “Hilariously,” she writes, “I thought I had picked up a great concealing trick from ‘Sex and the City,’ when Carrie uses a black eyeliner to turn a zit into a beauty mark. Brilliant, except my skin was so bad I needed about 16 beauty marks. I went out with my girlfriends with black dots all over my face thinking I had the world fooled. They took one look at me and asked, ‘What . . . did you do to your face?’ ” These days, Michele more often opts for a homemade facial mask and the services of a professional dermatologist to keep her skin clear. She also goes without makeup if possible. “Whenever I can, I give my skin a vacation,” she says. “It’s nice to remember what I actually look like.”

headline: Fashion’s Embrace of Reality TV
text: The fashion/reality TV love affair is still going strong

headline: This Is What a Cursed Soccer Stadium Looks Like
text: The place was built for a coronation, a colossal theater where hundreds of thousands could bear witness and celebrate. When Maracanã opened in 1950, in the heart of Rio, it was the world’s largest stadium, the site of what Brazil was certain would be its first World Cup championship. And things started well enough: The host country breezed through to the final match, where, because of tournament rules at the time, it needed only a draw against Uruguay to win the whole event. With little more than 10 minutes to go, the score was 1-1, and the fans were on edge. Then the Uruguayan winger Alcides Ghiggia put them over with a sudden strike. “Only three people have, with just one motion, silenced the Maracanã,” he famously said later. “Frank Sinatra, Pope John Paul II and me.”

headline: Reply All: The 5. 25.14 Issue
text: CAN THE NERVOUS SYSTEM BE HACKED?

headline: Who Made That Autocorrect?
text: “How fast will new Word 6.0 fix typos? How fast can you make them?” asked an advertisement in a computer magazine from October 1993. The newest version of Microsoft’s word processor came with a brand-new feature called AutoCorrect. Type in “SHip teh cartons friday,” and the program would correct your text to “Ship the cartons Friday.”

headline: The World Cup Soundtrack
text: The volume rattles the bones. The gyrations evoke scenes of lustful abandon. In some of funk’s most explicit forms, tracks sprinkled with the prerecorded sounds of machine-gun fire exalt the drug gangs still in control of some of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas. On certain nights, the bass from the amps resonates from the hillside slums into the bastions of the privileged classes, as if to remind them: Rio doesn’t belong just to you.

headline: Sleep Now, Die Later
text: The perils of napping; Clay Aiken vs. Henry Clay.

headline: Help! I’ve Fallen, and I Don’t Want Help
text: I was on the subway when another passenger passed out. The train made an emergency stop, and medical responders assisted the person, despite her screaming — after she came to — that she wanted to be left alone. If the woman was saying she did not want to be helped, even if in critical condition, is someone ethically allowed to obey her and let her suffer? Or would it be a crime to let her suffering continue? ELISABETH BUCHWALD, SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Where the View Gets a Standing Ovation
text: “I’ve got to be where my spirit can run free,” sings the lost-soul title character in the hit Broadway revival of “Pippin.” “Got to find my corner of the sky.”

headline: Pakistan Suspends License of Leading News Channel
text: LONDON — The Pakistani government on Friday suspended the broadcasting license of Geo News, a popular television channel, in a major escalation of Geo’s dispute with the country’s powerful Inter-Services Intelligence spy agency.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Burt Was Ousted
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Former Investment Banker Joins Vatican Financial Watchdog
text: The Vatican has turned to a European banker to help oversee its financial watchdog.

headline: Give Kids Your Undivided Attention — or No Attention At All
text: Here is what I wish I’d known, from 14-some years into this parenting gig: Leave the children alone when you must and then really be with them when you can. Or, to put it slightly differently: Alternate fully engaging with fully ignoring them. There is, of course, an implied “instead of” here — instead of half paying attention to them all the time (cough smartphone cough).

headline: Thoughts on Dark Pools and Michael Lewis
text: The new Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into high frequency trading and so-called dark pools — as announced yesterday by Chairwoman Mary Jo White — is long overdue. As speed has become the most important factor in getting the absolute best price, high-frequency traders have gained advantages over other investors that are undeniable. Some of these firms almost never have down days anymore. More and more, the average investor has to feel that the game is rigged.

headline: Not Just an Easy Commute
text: Midtown East does not usually make an apartment hunter’s shortlist.

headline: Déjà View
text: Vaux Le Vicomte, a quieter but equally majestic alternative to Versailles, has undergone a simple yet spectacular restoration. The wooden doors blocking the view through the north and south arcades of the chateau have been removed, reinstating the original transparency between the interiors and the grounds proposed in the 17th century by the architect Louis Le Vau and the royal gardener André Le Nôtre. vaux-le-vicomte.com

headline: Summer Reads, Courtesy of JPMorgan
text: JPMorgan Chase provides advice to clients across the globe on complex financial matters.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Fault in Our Stars,’ ‘Edge of Tomorrow’ and ‘Obvious Child’
text: In this video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “Obvious Child,” “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Edge of Tomorrow.” Read all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Gone With Barely a Trace
text: The flamboyantly decorated Windsor Arcade of 1901, on Fifth Avenue from 46th to 47th Street, spread a layer of Beaux-Arts frosting over the site of a gruesome hotel fire, and presents a cautionary tale for anyone wrestling with memory and monuments.

headline: Biking Just Beyond the Big City
text: As passionate cyclists and campers, Bronx residents Lukas Herbert and Laura Willis have introduced friends to their avocation and hope to see their fellow city riders discover the joys of multiple-day bicycle touring. But they know an impediment exists.

headline: ‘The Invasion of Europe From the West Has Begun’
text: PARIS — As 160,000 Allied soldiers began to swarm the Normandy beaches on June 6, 1944, an ocean away New York Times editors scrambled to put out a special 6 a.m. edition heralding a seminal moment of World War II.

headline: For Missing Major Crown, Djokovic Must Dethrone a Dominant King
text: PARIS — Novak Djokovic knows that the road to his first French Open title goes through Rafael Nadal. It is a road he has not crossed before, but one he knows he can cross.

headline: Family-Friendly Tax Reform and The Poor
text: Having promised them some time ago, before a week of travel left me behind on blog posts, I hope to have responses up next week to some of the recent macro-level liberal takes on “reform conservatism” — from E.J. Dionne, William Galston, and my colleague Tom Edsall, among others.

headline: World Leaders Honor D-Day Anniversary
text: President François Hollande of France and President Obama spoke to veterans at the Normandy American Cemetery at Omaha Beach on the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landing.

headline: D-Day’s Wheels Roll Again
text: ÉTRÉHAM, FRANCE — Like many families spending part of this summer on the road, Kevin and Brenda Goodwin of Felixstowe, England, are taking their holiday in a big R.V. with two beds, a kitchen, a bathroom with a shower and a pair of bicycles lashed to the front.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Iran Reach Out Tentatively

headline: Egypt’s Election: A View From Cairo
For Another Kind of Platform
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expanding wireless coverage in stations across New York, but for now there’s still a good chance of getting caught on a platform with nothing new to read or see on your phone. If you find that possibility horrifying, you might consider downloading Tunnel Vision, an app that turns the subway map into a fount of information about both New York and the subway system itself.

headline: For de Blasio, Deals, Drama and (Maybe) Progress
text: If you have been in or around Downtown Brooklyn in recent days, you may have found yourself noticing a darkened haze in the color of the local mood ring. On Tuesday, activists gathered in Borough Hall to grieve over the fate of Long Island College Hospital, which is to be converted into a condominium site with some sort of health care facility, though it is uncertain how much of one. The hospital effectively closed last month, leaving residents in surrounding areas worried about curtailed services, in particular the prospect of waiting a dangerously long time for an ambulance. On May 31, a man in Red Hook did die after what was reported to be a long wait, and though it was unclear whether a direct connection existed, the episode served as a dramatic confirmation of the community’s apprehension.

headline: Classical Playlist: John Adams, Handel, Lewis Spratlan and More
text: LEWIS SPRATLAN: ‘Apollo and Daphne Variations’; other worksBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductorEliot Gattegno, on soprano and alto saxophones(BMOP/Sound)The American composer Lewis Spratlan, born in 1940, gained wide attention in 2000 when a concert version of Act II of his opera “Life Is a Dream,” which was completed in 1978 but had never been staged, won the Pulitzer Prize for Music. This welcome new recording from the impressive Boston Modern Orchestra Project offers three ingeniously written and distinctive Spratlan works. “A Summer’s Day” (2008) uses a simple, dreamy Celtic tune at the start as a jumping-off place for an elusive, complex suite that ruminates on the tensions below the surface of an inviting day. In his Concerto for Saxophone and Orchestra (2006), Mr. Spratlan finds a gripping, fresh approach to what might seem an awkward classical music genre; the music evolves from mystical musings to raw, jazzy vehemence. “Apollo and Daphne Variations” is like a Spratlan version of a Schumann suite, with alternating episodes of whimsy, frenzy and innocence. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Video: The Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid Won’t Save Much Green
text: Subaru and Prius owners are fiercely loyal to their rides. Subie drivers (who often dwell in polar vortex regions) pledge their allegiance to the Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive flag. The evangelical hybrid camp is more obsessed with fuel economy than getting places quickly. Conversely, it’s unwise to off-road a Prius, and the only way to guarantee lofty m.p.g.s in a Subaru is coasting from a mountain summit.

The restaurant, while bigger, is still cozy: a dozen tables with a view into the kitchen, where gusts of flame kick up as Salvatore Urso deglazes a pan.

headline: U.S. and European Job Markets Take Different Paths
text: MORE than five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September intensified a credit crisis, the labor market in the United States has almost recovered — at least as measured by the number of unemployed people. But in most of Europe, the number of jobless workers remains substantially higher than it was then.

headline: Happenings | The Beloved Bangkok Eatery Bo.Lan Pops Up in New York
text: So many pop-ups happen solely for marketing purposes these days that it’s refreshing to find one that reflects the original intent behind the concept: fleeting, spontaneous pleasure. This weekend, New Yorkers can rejoice in the news that, apropos of nothing, one of Bangkok’s most beloved eateries, Bo.Lan, is operating an outpost in a massive, tumbledown art studio opposite the UPS hangar on Greenwich Street. On Saturday and Sunday, the wife-and-husband chef duo of Bo Songvisava and Dylan Jones (their restaurant’s moniker is a Kimyeification of their names) will dish up a tasting menu of regional Thai specialties for an intimate group of strangers.

headline: Cooking With Nuts and Seeds
text: For years, nutritionists have been urging us to eat nuts in place of high-carb and sugary snacks. Regulators allow purveyors of peanuts, almonds, walnuts, pistachios, hazelnuts and pecans to make claims that these nuts, as part of a diet low in saturated fats and cholesterol, may help reduce the risk of heart disease.

text: WASHINGTON — The State Department is financing a new 24-hour satellite television channel in the turbulent northern region of Nigeria that American officials say is crucial to countering the extremism of radical groups such as Boko Haram. The move signals a ramping up of American counterinsurgency efforts to directly challenge the terrorist group, which abducted nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls in April.

What this means for investors and the markets that depend on their money is intriguing.

headline: Bill Cunningham | A-twirl
text: Like a rainbow-colored tornado, a woman on Eighth Avenue was spinning what appeared to be 45 hula hoops. On Wednesday, family night at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, hula hoops were revived for the kindergarten set. Last Saturday, more than 5,000 picnickers boarded ferries at Battery Park for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic held at Liberty State Park. It was a preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.

headline: Move Over, Penguins, Marathon Coming Through
text: At the tail end of the most bone-chilling winter in recent years, I left New York for Antarctica, the coldest and driest place on earth, where the sun never completely sets.

headline: Lost in Time in England’s Northeast
text: My gateway drug to serious Anglophilia was horses — the British Pony Club Manual of Horsemanship, my English saddle made by Barnsby — but the addiction was truly about words. What, for example, could “Hounds, gentlemen, please” possibly mean? This was a sign along the roadside near the stable where we kept my horse outside St. Louis. I turned it over in my mind for months before I understood that drivers were being asked to slow down if foxhounds were in the vicinity.

headline: In Argentina, Wine, Art and Altitude
text: Our friends love modern art but don’t really drink; my companion and I are closer to the reverse. So as we researched places where we could travel and all come away happy, Colomé, in northwest Argentina, stood out. It’s a mountain winery with a contemporary art museum and sounded like the perfect two-couple compromise — a little bit high culture, a little bit grand cru.

headline: A Starter Kit for Military Collectors
text: To the Army, it was known simply as the G503 or the quarter-ton, but to millions of soldiers it quickly became the jeep, a coinage generally linked to a character from the Popeye cartoon strip, Eugene the Jeep. Today, wartime jeeps are ubiquitous at military vehicle shows, and they are starting point for most people getting into the collecting hobby.

headline: Austrian Journalist Convicted in Holocaust Restitution Case Vows to Appeal
text: PARIS — Stephan Templ, an Austrian journalist convicted of defrauding the Austrian state of about $748,000 in a Holocaust restitution case, vowed Friday to appeal to the European Court for Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, after a high court in Vienna sentenced him to one year in prison and two years of probation.

headline: Extravagant Wedding Cakes Rise Again
text: Reports of the demise of the wedding cake have been exaggerated.

headline: Obama Aide Defends Remarks on Bergdahl’s ‘Honor’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, found herself in a familiar predicament this week: under fire from Republicans for statements she made about a murky sequence of events involving Americans in a distant land.

headline: I Was Promised Flying Cars
text: AS an astronomy-obsessed kid in the 1970s, I subsisted on a steady diet of science fiction. It promised a future filled with technological wonders: talking computers, bionic limbs, flying cars. Forty years later, though much of that future has arrived, it’s still missing what I consider its most important ingredient. Sure, we’ve got the iPhone’s Siri, and the Food and Drug Administration just approved a prosthetic arm controlled by signals from the brain — but where are our smooth-gliding flying machines, our Landspeeders (“Star Wars”) and airborne DeLoreans (“Back to the Future”)?

headline: A Player Who Is Rarely at a Loss for Words
text: PARIS — Ernests Gulbis entertained on and off the court in his run to the semifinals of the French Open, his best showing at a Grand Slam event. Gulbis spoke candidly and memorably throughout the tournament.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring George Takei and Tracey Emin
text: George Takei, “Star Trek” alum, announcer for “The Howard Stern Show” and gay activist whose documentary, “To Be Takei,” hits theaters in August, takes on Tracey Emin, a rabble-rousing English artist who rose to fame in the 1990s with confessional works like “Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995.” A moving series of her digital neons, “I Promise to Love You,” is on view now at the Cosmopolitan Hotel in Las Vegas. A musical inspired by Takei’s childhood incarceration in U.S. internment camps comes to Broadway this fall.

headline: A Good Man With Pepper Spray
text: And the only thing that can stop a bad man with a gun is a good man with…pepper spray! So it went in the attempted mass shooting at Seattle Pacific University Thursday, when a gunman opened fire in a campus hall. One student was killed, several others injured. But it could have been far worse had not a student campus monitor, Jon Meis, pepper-sprayed the shooter and put him a chokehold.

headline: Big Ticket | $30.4 Million for a Midtown Three-Bedroom
text: Another of the glassy three-bedroom aeries in the popular A line at the Extell Development Company’s 90-story Midtown tower, One57, sold for $30,449,175 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. For now, the monthly carrying costs for the 4,483-square-foot condominium, No. 61A, are a mere $7,545, thanks to a tax abatement.

headline: In Britain, Child’s Weight Leads to Parents’ Arrest
text: LONDON — The parents of an 11-year-old boy were arrested in Britain on suspicion of neglect and child cruelty after authorities grew alarmed about the child’s weight.

headline: Inequality, Fertility and the Rich
text: In my post earlier today on the distributional impact of a new child tax credit, I noted that the benefits to richer families under a plan like Senator Mike Lee’s would diminish if, in pursuit of revenue neutrality, the plan phased out its expanded tax credit at higher income levels. (The current child tax credit has a phase-out that begins at $110,000 for married joint filings.) But as a coda, it’s worth noting that to the extent that family-friendly policy actually boosts fertility — a highly uncertain question, to be sure — egalitarian liberals might want to think twice about a child tax credit phase-out, because then they wouldn’t reap the potentially egalitarian benefits of higher fertility in the upper class.

headline: Drifting Back to the Real World
text: Richard Strauss, born in Munich 150 years ago this Wednesday, must have laughed over the condemnations, even from many critics, of his opera “Salome” after its 1905 premiere in Dresden. Before long, of course, this succès de scandale was playing to eager audiences across Europe. The royalties Strauss earned paid for his bucolic villa in Garmisch.

headline: Booed in the ’60s, but Time Will Tell
text: It’s anyone’s guess what Jimmy Giuffre was thinking when he improvised the stark, intriguing solo clarinet pieces intended for his 1962 Columbia album, “Free Fall.” Along with the five that made the cut, there were five others that saw the light of day some 35 years later, as bonus tracks on an overdue reissue. Small gems of oblique investigation, they bear titles that seem to hint at Giuffre’s state of mind; among them is one with a lonesome air, played in shadowy subtones, that he called “Time Will Tell.”

headline: D-Day Combat Vehicles
text: Images from a 70th anniversary D-Day rally of military vehicles in and around Normandy, France.

headline: Double Strawberry Cheesecake
text: Melissa Clark makes a stunner of a dessert: a lighter, more flavorful double strawberry cheesecake made with goat cheese and red wine.

headline: A Strawberry Cheesecake That Is Red and White and Pink All Over
text: Picture a strawberry cheesecake: white and creamy cake on the bottom, bright red berries on top. Maybe the berries are fresh and ripe and leak a little of their tart juice onto the dense cake below. More likely, the berries are sealed in shiny, syrupy goop. Either way, you get a separation of strawberries and cream, with the two playing off each other in juicy-creamy succession.

headline: Two Paths to the Same Destination
text: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was approaching a group of his wedding guests who were smoking on a terrace of the American Museum of Natural History. Those familiar with the stern side of Mr. Denton, who was married at the museum on May 31 to Derrence Washington, might have thought they would be reprimanded. Instead he grinned and said: “We’re gathering everyone for a group photo. We have a guy up there.”

headline: Not a Happy Camper
text: I’m about to thrust my child into a four-week-long situation that I know, from experience, to be a total misery. Of course, I’m not going to tell her this. Introducing children to new and potentially life-altering experiences necessarily means trying to convince them that terrible things are just fine, even good.

headline: The GT40, Born of Ford’s Feud
text: The Ford GT40 meets all the requirements for a platinum-grade collectible: It’s gorgeous, it has great bloodlines as one of the most successful endurance-racing cars of the 1960s and it’s rare (with just over 100 built).

headline: Shoe Companies Show a Red Card to Black Soccer Cleats
text: Over the years, soccer has gone through a number of memorable, if often regrettable, fashion trends. There was the alarming popularity of short shorts; the odd fixation on puffy, bloused jerseys; the bumblebee sock phase (not to be confused with the leg-warmer sock craze); and, in what was surely the sport’s couture low point, a brief dabble with the unitard.
