text: It might seem that Pho Maxia, a new Vietnamese restaurant in Westbury, epitomizes the word “no.” There are no reservations, no credit cards, and no liquor license.

headline: Group of Catholic and Orthodox Officials Endorses Marriage for Some Priests
text: In a step that is sure to fuel the debate over mandatory celibacy, a high-level group of Catholic and Orthodox officials is calling on the Vatican to allow married men to serve as Eastern Catholic priests in North America.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Reisinger Knockout Teams
text: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a very popular event. Recently, though, the number of entries has dropped noticeably. This year, six teams took part in a round robin on Memorial Day in New York City at the end of the Eastern States Regional.

headline: Prancing Into History of One Golden City
text: A vibrant performance of Mozart’s “Prague” Symphony capped the concert of the American Classical Orchestra on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall and, with it, the ensemble’s season.

headline: A Composer Beyond His ‘Twilight Zone’
text: Even the most obscure composers can have a remarkably large presence on YouTube. While researching the music of Marius Constant, whose works I was admittedly not familiar with before Wednesday evening, I was surprised to find hundreds of results on YouTube. But maybe that’s not unexpected after all, considering he composed the theme to the television classic “The Twilight Zone.”

headline: From a Wistful Queen, Longing and Regret
text: Divadom, like the price of gold, thrives on scarcity. The most elaborate mystiques and fervent cults build up around singers one rarely hears live. Any artist sounds better in a mixture of memories and hopes than in life.

headline: Who Will Be the Next David Beckham?
text: Really sexy. Super-foxy. I mean, that body.

headline: Wishing His Listeners Luck, a Pianist Dives In
text: Speaking to the audience that packed Lincoln Center’s Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday night for his adventurous recital titled “Liszt Inspections,” the probing Italian pianist Marino Formenti ended his introductory comments with two words of encouragement.

headline: Secular Group, on Eve of Big Meeting, Fires Top Official Who Elevated Its Profile
text: Atheists and nonbelievers from across the country will muster on Capitol Hill next week for a summit meeting organized by the Secular Coalition for America, a growing alliance of groups that has been giving the religious right an intensifying case of heartburn by lobbying for the separation of government and religion.

headline: ‘Plane Wreck at Los Gatos’
text: The folk singer Barbara Dane released this version of “Plane Wreck at Los Gatos” in 1973.

headline: A Work Is Rushed to a Debut, by Design
text: The work that opened the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall was selected for performance only two days earlier. There was not even time to list it in the program.

headline: An Artful Stealth Theme, Returning on Padded Feet
text: The jazz drummer Jeff Ballard tends to close the distance between himself and the other musicians he plays with. His drumming is active, busy, rarely loud and constantly shuffling pattern and timbre: He’s often trying to connect with, illustrate and magnify whatever else is happening around him.

headline: A Country Negotiation in Brooklyn
text: Short of outright heckling, there probably aren’t many more dispiriting things you can shout at a performer from the crowd than “Are you on Spotify?”

headline: James and Air-Conditioning Are Expected to Return for Game 2
text: SAN ANTONIO — When LeBron James noticed during warm-ups that AT&T Center was warmer than usual Thursday night for the start of the N.B.A. finals, he did something unusual for a creature of habit: He cut his routine short and sat on the scorer’s table, waiting for the game to start.

headline: A Selection of Documents From the National Archives
text: Here is a selection of the roughly 2,000 documents released on Friday. Subjects include Rwanda, policies toward gays in the military, the Oklahoma City bombing and Vice President Al Gore’s presidential campaign.

headline: State Street Financial Literacy Test
text: A series of questions was posed to 2,880 investors in the first quarter of 2014 in 16 countries globally.

headline: Q. & A. | Hans-Ulrich Obrist on Curating the Swiss Pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennale
text: As if summer travelers needed any more incentive to descend on the sinking city of Venice, tomorrow the 14th International Architecture Exhibition of the Venice Biennale opens to the public. This year’s edition, directed by Rem Koolhaas, gets back to the basics of modern architecture, with dozens of exhibitions at national pavilions that delve into formative moments of the 20th century. The Swiss Pavilion is headed by Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the omnivorous curator and co-director of exhibitions and programs at the Serpentine Galleries in London. In it, Obrist has brought together two 20th-century figures whose research has influenced architectural thinking in their own time and since: the Swiss political economist Lucius Burckhardt and the English architect Cedric Price. Here, Obrist walks through the genesis of the pavilion’s exhibition “A Stroll Through a Fun Palace,” whose title refers to Price’s great unrealized construction, “Fun Palace,” and Burckhardt’s concept of “Strollology.”

headline: Russia Releases Greenpeace Ship
text: MOSCOW — Russian prosecutors released a Greenpeace International ship nearly nine months after seizing it following a high-seas protest at the first offshore oil platform in the Arctic, the organization announced Friday.

headline: Hacking Into Prime Time With Attitude
text: “I love seeing the insides of things,” Mackenzie Davis said, tucking her bleached bob behind her ears, a giraffe’s neck expanse above her slashed and safety-pinned Bart Simpson T-shirt. “It just fascinates me and always has.”

headline: Dazzling a Prince, Slowly, Gently, on Point
text: Your world is not the only world: That’s the lesson of Romantic ballet. And when a grown woman moves from one world to another, she herself is transformed. In Prokofiev’s “Cinderella,” not only does the title character’s dream come true, but she becomes her dream version of herself.

headline: Giving a Satirist of the Third Reich the Last Laugh
text: The Nazis kept a long list of writers to settle scores with, but one in particular inflamed them: the left-wing satirist Kurt Tucholsky. In magazine articles and comic poems, he took aim at nationalists, militarists and fat cats. He dipped his pen in a special, distilled venom to describe Hitler and his followers, whom he ridiculed as “little people” in the refrain of “Die Mäuler Auf!” (“Mouths Open!”), one of his most famous poems.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Picking a Winner
text: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. If, as a World Cup follower, you remain a free agent without any national-team loyalties, use this chart to help you arrive at a winning team.

headline: Eviction Battles Imperil a Queens Art Haven
text: Battles between artists and landlords are nearly as plentiful in New York City as galleries themselves.  But a recent spate of attempted evictions and other conflicts in a three-story brick building in Ridgewood, Queens, is buffeting a young outpost of the art world just as the area is earning a reputation for affordable studio space and vibrant openings.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: An internal investigation at General Motors into a faulty ignition switch concludes that there’s been an 11-year history of failures at the company. But the company’s C.E.O. said there is no proof of a conspiracy to hide the issue. Meanwhile, the faulty ignition switch — which costs less than a dollar to replace — has been blamed for more than a dozen deaths, led to recalls of millions of vehicles and resulted in a multi-million-dollar fine.

headline: Carl Icahn Discloses Stake in Family Dollar
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor who has taken on the likes of Apple and eBay, has identified a new target: Family Dollar Stores.

headline: Knausgaard Tour Arrives in Manhattan
text: “So, it’s the Beatles, right?” asked a passer-by on Thursday night to the crowd lined up outside McNally Jackson bookstore in SoHo for a conversation between Zadie Smith and the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard. People started queuing at about 4 p.m., two hours before the scheduled start of Mr. Knausgaard’s second New York City event in three nights to promote his six-part autobiographical novel “My Struggle.” (The third volume to be translated into English was published last week.)

headline: Graduating to Hit Shows
text: It was a sitcom about Philadelphia-area third graders who reunited in their late 20s, and it was spun from the fertile minds of David Crane, a creator of “Friends,” and Jeffrey Klarik, a writer-producer of “Mad About You.” In the fall of 2006, “The Class” was the new CBS show with the season’s highest hopes. It was not to be dismissed.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius in Kansas
text: I’ve been on the road within Europe for the last couple of days, not much time to seek out new music. So a really nice minimalist performance from one of my standing favorites; I love watching the evident joy of the performers:

headline: A Deadline for Goats to Get Out of Detroit
text: The campaign by the hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel to let goats graze in Detroit has hit a snag.

headline: Bracing Beethoven Interpreter
text: The inaugural NY Phil Biennial, perhaps the most ambitious and extensive contemporary-music festival yet overseen by an American orchestra, has understandably claimed lots of attention. But starting Wednesday, the New York Philharmonic presents the first of three programs over three weeks featuring the distinguished pianist Yefim Bronfman, artist in residence this season with the orchestra, as soloist in the five Beethoven piano concertos and the “Triple” Concerto for Violin, Cello and Piano.

headline: Texts and Context, at the Modern
text: Although it was 100 years ago that Gertrude Stein’s “Tender Buttons: Objects, Food, Rooms” was published, her Cubist writings about interior space evoked through light, emotions and memory, keep appearing in different guises, seeming just as contemporary now as when they were written. An exhibition opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art has adapted its titled from a phrase in “Tender Buttons.” Called “Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions,” it brings together 16 works by 13 artists, all of which have entered MoMA’s collection over the past few years but are only now on view there for the first time.

headline: In Its 10th Year, a Brooklyn Debut
text: Over the past decade, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has developed a reputation for its powerhouse dancing and glamorous repertory, which skews toward the work of high-profile European choreographers. Its 10th anniversary brings a couple of firsts: first appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and first season under both a new artistic director, Alexandra Damiani, and new associate choreographer, Crystal Pite, who will create two new pieces for the troupe over the next three years.

headline: Unflinching View at a Festival
text: “Private Violence,” Cynthia Hill’s gripping documentary film about domestic violence against women opens the 25th anniversary of the Human Rights Watch Festival on Friday with the cinematic equivalent of a brass-knuckled punch in the face. The film tells the stories of Deanna Walters, a North Carolina woman trying to escape an abusive husband, and Kit Gruelle, a dedicated advocate for battered women who championed Ms. Walters’s quest for justice after she was kidnapped and relentlessly brutalized in her husband’s truck during a four-and-a-half-day cross-country trip. When a North Carolina prosecutor decided that the severity of her beatings only a qualified as a misdemeanor Ms. Walters, with Ms. Gruelle’s encouragement, filed kidnapping charges.

headline: Northside Festival Booms in Brooklyn
text: It’s just another four nights in Brooklyn, only more so. Clubs are full of local bands and selected visitors; there’s more music than anyone could possibly attend. The sixth annual Northside Festival, expanding each year, promises some 400 bands playing in Williamsburg and Greenpoint from Thursday through Sunday. There are free but ticketed shows (with an online R.S.V.P. to the festival) at McCarren Park, to be headlined, on Saturday, by Thee Oh Sees, playing typically brief, frenzied sets of manic garage rock, and on Sunday by Chvrches with their gleaming synth-pop conundrums. Music badges, for $80, encourage club hopping, but are subject to capacity limits; strategic fans may want to choose particular shows.

headline: A Rebranded Vice President
text: HBO’s dramas are known for throwing surprises at viewers, but the shocker of the year may have come last week on one of its comedies: Selina Meyer got a haircut. Selina, the vice president and title character of “Veep,” walked into the office “rebranded,” as she put it, sporting a new, shorter look. “I never knew you had so much neck,” one member of her inner circle said. Another, out of earshot, was less kind. “It’s the worst use of scissors since my failed vasectomy,” he said.

headline: Tyra’s Next Top Show, Yoko Ono’s Touchy Prints and Altuzarra’s Latest Milestone
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: Photos from France, Central African Republic, India and Afghanistan.

headline: Nazi Art-Looting Case May Proceed, Court Rules
text: A federal appeals court in California issued a potentially far-reaching decision Friday that allows the victims of Nazi-related looting and their heirs to press ahead with legal efforts to reclaim stolen artwork.  The case involves two large portrayals of Adam and Eve by the 14th-century master Lucas Cranach the Elder that were taken from the prominent Jewish Dutch dealer Jacques Goudstikker in a forced sale and are now in the collection of the Norton Simon Museum in California. Goudstikker’s daughter-in-law, Marei Von Saher, has been trying to reclaim the dyptich for years but has repeatedly run into legal stumbling blocks.  In a 2-to-1 decision, though, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed a lower court’s decision and permitted Ms. Von Saher’s lawsuit to proceed.  The diptych was recovered and returned to the Netherlands after World War II, when the Dutch negotiated a partial settlement with Goudstikker’s widow, which did not cover the work. The Norton Simon bought the paintings in 1971 from a collector. In 2012, a district judge ruled against Ms. Von Saher, saying that the United States had fulfilled its obligations to restitute the art, and that any effort to alter the Dutch resolution of the case would interfere with the federal government’s sole authority over foreign policy. But the appeals panel noted that the United States had signed two international agreements — one in Washington in 1998, and another in Terezin, Czech Republic, in 2009 — intended to remove obstacles to the recovery of possessions stolen by the Nazis.  The Norton Simon released a statement saying it “remains confident that it holds complete and proper title” to the paintings and that it would “continue to pursue, consistent with its fiduciary duties, all appropriate legal options.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Taking a Stand, on Stools
text: “The Vagina Monologues,” Eve Ensler’s classic paean to women and their genitalia, is always a bit of a feminist rally: part humor, part outrage. That spirit of celebration and defiance runs through “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” the Spanish-language version of the show at the Westside Theater, where the ebullient Daphne Rubin-Vega is bringing an extraordinary warmth and vivacity to the proceedings.

headline: Uber’s True Valuation Will Be About Timing
text: Talk about getting rich quick. Uber’s fund-raising round, announced Friday, made it worth $17 billion just five years after the car service company started.

headline: Under Cover: Ronaldo, Messi and Neymar: Capturing Soccer’s Biggest Stars
text: Every four years, people around the world grab their noisemakers, don their team jerseys and gather in stadiums, living rooms and local bars to watch the World Cup. How can such an expansive and consuming event be covered in a 60-page magazine issue? And then how do you boil that into a single cover image?

headline: Nowhere to Turn
text: The killing of six people by a troubled 22-year-old in Isla Vista, Calif., last month is only one of the most recent in a string of shootings by young, disaffected men. Such episodes are a trauma for the communities that are hit, especially the families of the victims and the perpetrator. But they also cause a shiver of dread in certain parents all over the country, particularly those with teenagers and young adult children who seem capable of violence: Could my boy ever do that?

headline: Facebook Under Fire for Temporarily Blocking Pages in Pakistan
text: LONDON — Facebook said on Friday that it had blocked users in Pakistan from access to the pages of a popular Pakistani rock band and several left-wing political pages, drawing sharp criticism from free-speech activists who accused the American company of caving in to government censors.

text: PARIS — “Uh, where’s the grunt?” Chris Evert asked on the eve of the women’s final at the French Open.

headline: Prayer Meeting Shows Pope’s Larger Vision
text: VATICAN CITY — From the earliest days of his papacy, when he walked slowly into a grand reception hall in the Apostolic Palace for his first meeting with a curious diplomatic corps, Pope Francis has promoted a fairly conventional foreign policy agenda: fight poverty, pursue peace, bridge ecumenical or interreligious divisions and protect the environment.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 6
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a tribute to Maya Angelou, a peek at Belmont Park and a memorial for a young stabbing victim.

headline: Is Softball Sexist?
text: OVER the next three weeks, baseball players from around the country will compete in three regional tryouts for a chance to make it onto the United States baseball team. These are among the most elite, dedicated and talented athletes in their sport, and the best of them will go on to play against teams from Japan, Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, Venezuela and Taiwan in the World Cup tournament held in September in Miyazaki, Japan. But the team receives almost no attention, and many of its members weren’t even able to play their sport in high school. These baseball players are women.

headline: 12 Contenders Who Just Missed Out on a Triple Crown
text: When a chestnut colt named Affirmed won the Triple Crown in 1978, he was the third horse to do so in six years, and it seemed that achieving the holy grail of horse racing was no longer so arduous a quest.

headline: Hard Lessons From Belmont
text: I’VE been fooled by the Belmont Stakes before.

headline: Syria: Drought Adds to Woes, U.N. Says
text: The supply of safe water in Syria is now one-third of the level it was before March 2011 when the civil war began, Unicef said Friday in a report that warns of new levels of suffering because of a worsening regional drought. The report said the 9.6 million Syrians affected by the conflict, half of them children, are at increased risk of disease because the water scarcity has compounded problems caused by damage to water and sewage systems. Parts of Syria have received the lowest levels of rainfall in more than half a century, the report said, and most parts of the country have only received half the average rainfall of a normal year. The drought also threatens to put new pressures on Jordan, Lebanon and Iraq, where Syrian refugees are already straining the water supply.

headline: Festival Draws Stars of Christian Preaching (Not as Seen on Television)
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Quick: Name a famous American preacher.

headline: Where to Watch the World Cup in New York
text: A guide to finding a place to watch the world’s game.

headline: Where Should You Watch the World Cup in New York City?
text: Outside Brazil, there is probably no better place to watch the World Cup than the world’s city — New York. The usual spots, like The Football Factory, in Manhattan, and Woodwork, in Brooklyn, will be showing the games, of course, but every four years, the list of places to watch grows longer. Tapas bars are transformed into cheering sections for La Roja. Italian spaghetti joints become filled with passionate Azzurri fans. And bars typically crowded with American football loyalists draw fans of that other brand of football.

headline: Buying Upstate New York Land, V.A. Closes Chapter in Building Cemeteries
text: WASHINGTON — As the Allies gathered in France on Friday to honor the Americans who stormed the beaches of Normandy 70 years ago, a final resting place for World War II veterans had just been carved out of fields of grasses and clover in upstate New York.

headline: Roundup: Can New E.P.A. CO2 Rules Have a Climate Impact?
text: A prime challenge in trying to limit the human influence on the climate is that the atmosphere is a commons. One country’s actions limiting greenhouse gas emissions can be rendered moot if others don’t act, as well.

headline: Report Finds Higher Risks if Oil Line Is Not Built
text: WASHINGTON — If the Keystone XL pipeline is not built — and more oil from the Canadian oil sands is moved by rail — there could be hundreds more deaths and thousands more injuries than expected over the course of a decade, according to an updated State Department analysis of the contested project that was released Friday.

headline: Vows | Coming Home Again
text: Tiffani Faranda and Michael Hermalyn grew up on the same street, shared a first kiss, and were always friends. And they say their marriage will always have traces of their third grade friendship.

headline: Taxi Driver Solidarity
text: CHICAGO — Never timid in its rush to expand, Uber, the app-based car service, skirted city law when it told drivers in its UberX ride-sharing program last month that they could start picking up passengers at O’Hare International Airport.

headline: Hot Spots: All in the Family
text: Politicians run ads heavily featuring family members to soften their image and present a positive front. Plus, who will run an ad denouncing a politician’s young child?

headline: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles in 2 Actions
text: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions – one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States.

headline: P.O.W. Deal Gives Qatar a Victory, and a New Test
text: DOHA, Qatar — The five hardened Taliban militants were quickly whisked in a fleet of cars to the shoulder of a highway on the outskirts of the capital just as they arrived. There, out of the public eye and under the watchful gaze of Qatari security, they exchanged warm hugs with a welcome delegation and then once more were whisked off into hiding.

headline: I Approved This Message; My Family Delivered It
text: WASHINGTON — Still relatively early in the 2014 election cycle, candidates are trying to introduce themselves — or reintroduce, as the case may be — to voters. And amid a panoply of negative spots, image mavens and ad wizards have found a way to try to help their politicians cut through the clutter: family, family, family. A look at some of the latest ads that feature kin (appealing parents, cute children) in supporting roles.

headline: Internet Giants Erect Barriers to Spy Agencies
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Just down the road from Google’s main campus here, engineers for the company are accelerating what has become the newest arms race in modern technology: They are making it far more difficult — and far more expensive — for the National Security Agency and the intelligence arms of other governments around the world to pierce their systems.

text: Let’s talk about tax reform.

text: DETROIT — To the legal department at General Motors, secrecy ruled.

headline: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles
text: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions — one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States. The largest recall announced on Friday involves the warning-chime issue and includes about 69,500 of the automaker’s newest pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, including 57,500 in the United States. The models affected by the recall are the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra light-duty pickups, the 2015 Silverado and Sierra heavy-duty pickups and the 2015 Chevrolet Tahoe, Suburban and GMC Yukon and Yukon XL S.U.V.s. The air bag problem affects 36,000 vehicles in North America, including 31,500 in the United States. The models covered by the recall are the 2012 Buick Verano and the Chevrolet Camaro, Cruze and Sonic.

headline: Day of Reckoning for N.C.A.A.
text: I began writing about the N.C.A.A. two and a half years ago, more or less by accident. Assigned by The New York Times Magazine to imagine a scheme in which athletes in the revenue sports — football and men’s basketball — get paid, I was awakened for the first time to inequities in the world of big-time college sports. Of course I knew that the coaches were getting rich while the players were getting nothing; everybody knew that. But I didn’t think that much about it. Neither did most fans, I would venture to guess.

headline: Seattle Leads the Way
text: The new $15-an-hour minimum wage approved this week in Seattle does more than guarantee a raise to tens of thousands of workers in the city. As the highest minimum in the nation, it changes the terms of the minimum-wage debate and expands the realm of the possible in setting new minimums.

headline: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Emphasizes Her Softer Side
text: In Hillary Rodham Clinton’s first bid for president in 2008, her campaign seemed determined to make a powerful point: She was strong. She was tough. She was ready to lead.

headline: Wanting to Believe in California Chrome
text: Thirty-seven years ago, Richard Migliore first felt the magic of a Triple Crown. He was a 13-year-old exercise rider fibbing about his age to work out a filly at Belmont Park. He saw the newspapermen, as they were called then, clamoring around Seattle Slew’s barn.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Money Troubles
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey already has a famous traffic jam on the George Washington Bridge tarnishing his reputation as a Republican comer and putting a damper on his ambitions for higher office. His latest budget difficulties, which have caused him to backtrack on a promise to repair the state’s pension system, adds one more stain to his résumé.

headline: Stabbing Case Shows Lapses in Treatment for the Mentally Ill
text: During much of his five years of incarceration for choking his mother with an electrical cord, Daniel St. Hubert was prone to aggressive outbursts and violence, assaulting inmates and correctional workers. It took three years before he was even deemed psychologically fit to stand trial.

headline: Plan to Build Ice Center in the Bronx Stalls Amid a Feud
text: An ambitious effort to convert the Kingsbridge Armory into a national ice sports center has stalled in recent weeks amid a bitter feud and two lawsuits over future profits and control of the development group behind the project.

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Collision Course
text: The recent collapse of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks has sharpened tensions and put the two sides on a collision course. The feuding Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, formed a government this week, prompting Israel to retaliate with plans for hundreds of new housing units in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The Palestinians threatened unspecified countermeasures. It is clearly time for all sides to think hard about where this is headed.

headline: Kings Work on Ice, but Most Live on the Beach
text: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — When the Los Angeles Kings won the Stanley Cup two years ago, the trophy’s first postgame trip was to a small bar near the beach, within walking distance of nearly every player’s home.

headline: Gunman Attacks Georgia Courthouse and Dies in Firefight, Authorities Say
text: CUMMING, Ga. — A man was shot to death on Friday by law enforcement officials after he brought an arsenal, including an assault rifle and a large supply of ammunition, to the county courthouse here and tried to mount what the authorities described as a “frontal assault” on the building.

headline: Obama Nominates Ambassadors to France and Ireland
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday nominated Jane D. Hartley, the chief executive officer of an economic consulting firm, to be ambassador to France, once more propelling a campaign fund-raiser into a prominent diplomatic position.

headline: Show Up at Dinner
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — We have what seems like a minitheme in today’s puzzle by John Lieb, and this cluster of cross-referenced clues is pretty much what almost kept me from finishing the puzzle.

headline: Many Bettors at a Loss Since the OTBs Closed
text: For decades, they were outposts for the self-identified degenerate, the moldering province of otherwise antisocial men with crumpled newsboy caps on their heads and racing forms tucked beneath their armpits.

headline: U.N. Chief Picks Jordanian Prince for Rights Post
text: GENEVA — United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday nominated a veteran diplomat and relative of Jordan’s royal family to be the agency’s next high commissioner for human rights.

headline: In Some States, Emissions Cuts Defy Skeptics
text: The cries of protest have been fierce, warning that President Obama’s plan to cut greenhouse gases from power plants will bring soaring electricity bills and even plunge the nation into blackouts. By the time the administration is finished, one prominent critic said, “millions of Americans will be freezing in the dark.”

headline: Egyptian Election Law Helps to Block Opposition
text: CAIRO — The military-appointed interim president of Egypt on Friday issued an election law that experts say all but eliminates the chance of parliamentary opposition to his successor, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who installed the interim government.

headline: Sons of Major Leaguers, but Not Always Stars
text: On July 2, 1903, Jack Doscher took the mound for the Chicago Cubs. The son of Herm Doscher, a third baseman and outfielder in the early days of the National League, Jack is believed to have been the first son of a former big leaguer to play in the majors.

headline: For Fans in Bronx, Jennifer Lopez’s Homecoming Was Overdue
text: Since releasing her debut studio album, “On the 6,” an ode to the subway line she rode growing up in the Bronx, Jennifer Lopez has leaned on a narrative that has followed her through forays into singing, dancing and acting. And a hit single, “Jenny From the Block,” became a catchy moniker for the performer.

headline: In Fraud Trial, F.B.I. Agent Testifies That Senator Funneled Money to Lawmakers
text: WHITE PLAINS — A real estate developer from Rockland County came to New York City dangling tens of thousands of dollars in cash and checks and slowly began to set a trap. State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, federal prosecutors tried to demonstrate on Friday, took the bait.

headline: Rangers’ Moore Set to Return From Suspension for Game 2
text: LOS ANGELES — The Rangers expected one lineup change for Game 2 on Saturday, while two others remained uncertain.

headline: In Debate, Rangel Irritates His Main Challenger, Along With the Moderator
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel and his main challenger, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, lashed out at each other on Friday during their first televised debate: Mr. Rangel accused Mr. Espaillat of running a racially based campaign and Mr. Espaillat charged that their district had suffered under Mr. Rangel’s leadership.

headline: Warfare’s Never-Ending Story
text: The world looked back to the future last week as 18 national leaders gathered to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the D-Day invasion that triggered the end to World War II’s apocalyptic ravaging of Europe.

headline: California: Tree Trimmer Won’t Be Charged
text: No charges will be brought against Ernesto Pulido, a tree trimmer in Oakland who knocked five baby herons from their nests a month ago while trimming trees for the United States Postal Service. The case was investigated by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which said Thursday that “no further action is warranted.” Mr. Pulido could have faced a $15,000 fine and six months in jail for violating the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918. “I’ve never been happier,” Mr. Pulido said. The birds are expected to fully recover. Two will be released on Saturday.

headline: Karen DeCrow Dies at 76; Feminist Lawyer and Author Led NOW
text: Karen DeCrow, who was president of the National Organization for Women during the 1970s, a turbulent period in which she helped lead campaigns for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment and against sex discrimination in education and sports, died on Friday at her home in Jamesville, N.Y., a suburb of Syracuse. She was 76.

headline: Two States Repeal Education Standards
text: The governors of Oklahoma and South Carolina signed bills within the past week repealing the Common Core state standards, guidelines for children’s achievement in reading and math between kindergarten and high school graduation. Both states had been among the 46 and the District of Columbia that had adopted the standards, written by a group of educators and other experts convened by the National Governors Association and the Council of Chief State School Officers. But as resistance grew in their states, lawmakers moved to replace them with standards developed within the states. Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed that state’s bill last week, and Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma signed a bill on Thursday that would require educators in the state to set new standards to replace the Common Core.

headline: Neither Player Nor Bat Was Ready for the Fog
text: The broken air-conditioning system at San Antonio’s AT&T Center on Thursday in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals was highly unusual, but those saunalike conditions did not compare to the Fog Game during the Stanley Cup finals on May 20, 1975, between the Buffalo Sabres and the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Newly Pro, and Adding Experience to Mets’ System
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mets have tried to restock their organization with young, talented positions players, using their first-round picks from 2011 to 2013 on the high school prospects Brandon Nimmo, Gavin Cecchini and Dominic Smith. None have reached Class AA yet.

headline: Andrei N. Mironov, Soviet-Era Political Prisoner and Activist, Dies at 60
text: MOSCOW — After Andrei N. Mironov was killed in Ukraine by artillery fire on May 24 while working with an Italian photojournalist, news accounts described him as an interpreter for foreign journalists there.

headline: A Rough Guide to Brooklyn for Conventioneers
text: With Brooklyn making its bid to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention, borough boosters are already getting set to roll out the red carpet. Here’s a rough draft of the welcoming committee’s visitors’ guide.

headline: Bernard Telsey: The Shows Must Go On
text: As one of more than 800 Tony Award voters, the casting director Bernard Telsey gets invited to every new Broadway show that is eligible for an award, so he’s a regular at Sunday matinees — most of them a quick walk from his Hell’s Kitchen brownstone. Indeed, Sunday is hardly ever a day off: He is always fielding requests from producers and directors obsessing over their theater, television and film projects. But Mr. Telsey, 54, has become adept at carving out time for his wife, Anne Marino, an executive with Tommy Hilfiger; their sons Daniel Marino, 25, who lives in Brooklyn, and Felix Telsey, 14; and the family’s Maltese poodles, Wally and Louie.

headline: Champions Bested by a Grueling Race
text: Since 1978, 12 horses who won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness have failed to capture the Belmont, one missing glory by a nose, others in a landslide.

headline: Russian State Media Focuses Attacks on Kerry’s Spokeswoman
text: The rhetorical sniping between Russian and American officials over the separatist uprisings in Ukraine appeared to escalate a notch this week when state television channels controlled by the Kremlin devoted an unusual amount of time to reporting on, and so amplifying, recent attacks by Russian bloggers on a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 7, 2014
text: “No hard feelings, but my job is to make their job hard.”

headline: U.S.’s Young Players Expected to Contribute Now and Lead Later
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — When Jurgen Klinsmann was given a contract extension through 2018 by U.S. Soccer in December, it allowed him the luxury of keeping an eye on the long-term future of the national team. His roster for the 2014 World Cup reflects that, introducing a new generation of American players.

headline: A Shaken-Up Lineup Stirs the Yankees’ Offense
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Contemplating a week’s worth of offensive feebleness, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi opted for something familiar to try and shake out some hits to begin a 10-game trip.

headline: Your Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team in the World Cup
text: For those who like the pageantry but couldn’t care less about the tactics, a guide to picking a team in the World Cup and finding a place to cheer among your newfound compatriots.

headline: Watching the World’s Game, in the World’s City
text: On a gloriously sunny afternoon recently, Lunasa, an East Village pub, was packed seven deep at the bar, as three TVs showed the day’s big games. Soccer games, that is, in Germany, Portugal and England.

headline: Fire Breaks Out at TGI Friday’s Near Rockefeller Center
text: A fast-moving fire at a restaurant near Rockefeller Center on Friday night sent flames and smoke shooting into the night sky as diners ran for the exits and dozens of firefighters rushed to extinguish the blaze, the authorities said.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) ENOUGH SAID (2013) Julia Louis-Dreyfus, in a Golden Globe-nominated role, plays Eva, a divorced massage therapist in Los Angeles who finds her life emptying out as her daughter (Tracey Fairaway) prepares to leave for Sarah Lawrence College. Then she meets Albert (James Gandolfini, above, with Ms. Louis-Dreyfus), another divorced parent of a college-bound girl, and although he isn’t her usual type, Eva suddenly finds herself falling for this funny, tender and sexy slob. Enter Marianne (Catherine Keener), a glamorous bohemian poet and Eva’s new client — who, Eva finds out a little too late, also happens to be Albert’s former wife. And so Eva listens to Marianne’s complaints about her ex — he’s a bore and a loser, clumsy in bed and unable to take care of himself — and surreptitiously tries to correct the faults in Albert that caused their marriage to disintegrate. “The real genius of ‘Enough Said’ is that it takes this entirely plausible anecdotal circumstance and unlocks both its farcical potential and its latent profundity,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this “small miracle of a movie” written and directed by Nicole Holofcener. “This movie will make you laugh and leave you in tears. Some of the pathos is the accidental byproduct of seeing Mr. Gandolfini, so playful and alive, in one of his final major movie roles and feeling once again the loss of his remarkable gift. There is also the pang of the empty nest, that mixture of grief and pride that is the special anguish of modern parents. But there is also something deeper. The ache that ‘Enough Said’ leaves behind comes from the blunt force of truth.”

headline: No Pockets, No Problem
text: Space Billiards is a pool hall of the sort that feels nocturnal on even a bright day. But it is not a dour place, and it isn’t filled with unsavory hustlers. In its slightly manic, neon-noir way, it exudes a quirky sense of cheer. Simple strobe lights jitter across walls. A seemingly endless string of dance hits plays. The wall behind the red couch is covered with small mirrors. At some tables you’ll find cheap American beer; at other tables, bottles of OB Lager and soju, the beer and liquor of South Korea.

headline: The ‘Oz’ Moment
text: I’ll never forget eyeballing Ebbets Field for the first time. I had seen photographs in the sports pages, and grainy images on TV. And I had seen grass before, even growing up in Brooklyn. Still, I was totally unprepared for what the verdant playing field looked like in person in what, in a few years, the NBC peacock would introduce as living color.

headline: Tribal Elder of the Fields
text: Lounging on the thick grass in Strawberry Fields, Jimmy Peters gazed up at the penthouse apartment of a new luxury high-rise on West 57th Street.

headline: Posey’s Late Homer Lifts Giants Past Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mets and the San Francisco Giants were tied in the eighth inning Friday night. But after San Francisco’s Angel Pagan drew a leadoff walk and moved into scoring position, the Giants were so confident that they had their closer, Sergio Romo, start to warm up.

headline: Corrections: June 7, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: No More ‘Banging on the Shutters’
text: The suspense was getting to just about everyone.

headline: Poroshenko Takes Ukraine Helm With Tough Words for Russia
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Petro Oleksiyovych Poroshenko, a pro-European, billionaire confectioner, was sworn in on Saturday as the fifth president of Ukraine, promising to put an end to a separatist insurrection in the east that has divided the country for months.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Know Your Superstars
text: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. For sports fans who want to know who the Lebron James of soccer is, here are world soccer stars and their analogs in American sports.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times cautions American officials dealing with the Palestinian Authority’s new unity government, a coalition of the extremist Hamas and more moderate Fatah factions. “Many experts say that if there is ever to be an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement,” the editorial board writes, “the Palestinians must be united. But the United States has to be careful to somehow distinguish between its support for the new government and an endorsement of Hamas and its violent, hateful behavior.”

headline: Tracy Morgan Critically Hurt in New Jersey Car Crash
text: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan finished a stand-up comedy show in Delaware on Friday night and headed back to New York City with several other comedians. Around 1 a.m., a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of their luxury van, overturning it and setting off a chain reaction that involved four other vehicles.

headline: Five Experts Evaluate E.C.B.'s Policy Shift
text: “We think this is a significant package,” Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday. He was describing the measures the bank had announced to combat the euro zone’s crippling combination of slow growth and superlow inflation.

headline: Is My Landlord Responsible for the Damage?
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Camp: Love It or Hate It? Readers Comment
text: From Not a Happy Camper, in the Styles section:

headline: Two New Legal-Themed Documentaries
text: I’ve spent the past weekend at the Berkshire International Film Festival in western Massachusetts, and I want to recommend two terrific law-related documentary films I saw there. One is directly law-related: “The Case Against 8,” the story of the federal court case that led to the invalidation of California’s Proposition 8 and to the arrival of marriage equality there. The film, by Ben Cotner and Ryan White, is now playing commercially in New York and Los Angeles, will soon open elsewhere, and will be shown on HBO on June 23 (disclosure: I had a tiny consulting role in the making of the film, actually a discussion of Supreme Court procedure over a cup of coffee with the filmmakers.)

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Milwaukee Suburb Tries to Cope With Girl’s Stabbing
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — At Horning Middle School last week, some girls painted cat whiskers on their faces with liquid eyeliner, in tribute to a fellow sixth grader who loved cats but who lay in a hospital recovering from 19 stab wounds that the authorities say were inflicted by two friends who had lured her into a park to kill her.

headline: Across Iraq, Insurgents Show Reach in Attacks
text: BAGHDAD — Militants attacked a university in the western city of Ramadi early Saturday, forcing students and professors to flee gunfire and shelling, while in the capital, at least 48 people were killed by car bombs in an apparently coordinated series of explosions.

headline: A Golfer Who Lived Large and Played Larger
text: TUSTIN, Mich. — Near a horse-and-carriage crossing in this small town, the golfing bon vivant Walter Hagen lives on, his memory carefully cultivated by a retired couple who never saw him swing a club.

headline: Variety: A Vowel-less Crossword Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — We haven’t seen many of these vowel-less crossword puzzles in The New York Times since records have been kept of these things (there have been five since 1997, if you count this one), and we haven’t seen one since 2006. But if you wait long enough, I’m told, everything comes back into style, and Arthur Schulman, who created the first four, has a new vowel-less crossword for us.

headline: Gay Pride Promotions
text: Companies such as Hilton, Kimpton and American Airlines have long marketed to the gay community. This month in a most public display of affection, Marriott International, a company with conservative Mormon roots, is wrapping three of its Washington, D.C., hotels in photo banners, including Jason Collins, the N.B.A.’s first openly gay basketball player, and Geena Rocero, a transgender model. The campaign urges travelers to share photos on Instagram under #LoveTravels @MarriottIntl.

headline: A Vow to End Hollow Nods and Salutes
text: After the release last Thursday of the internal report on General Motors’ failure to recall thousands of defective cars for more than a decade, Mary T. Barra, the chief executive, addressed the company’s employees. In her remarks, Ms. Barra projected an earnest and urgent desire to reform the company’s culture, which she said was permeated by “bureaucratic processes that avoided accountability.” That culture meant no one took responsibility for faulty ignition switches in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars that were ultimately responsible for at least 13 deaths.

headline: With Nuclear Talks Sputtering, U.S. and Iran Plan Meeting
text: WASHINGTON — Senior American officials plan to meet in Geneva on Monday and Tuesday with an Iranian delegation in an attempt to advance the stalled nuclear talks, the State Department announced Saturday.

headline: Performing Without Net: Stars of YouTube Take to the Stage
text: A capacity 12,500 tickets were sold. More than 70 performers appeared on three stages. There were 150 security guards, a necessity whenever swarms of shrieking teenage girls assemble. Coke sponsored a live web stream of the festivities.

headline: Resurgent Maria Sharapova Holds Off Simona Halep to Win French Open
text: PARIS — Before the women’s final at the French Open on Saturday, much of the discussion was about Simona Halep’s year.

headline: Obama Plans Steps to Ease Student Debt
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday will take executive actions to ease the burden of college loan debt for potentially millions of Americans, in a White House event coinciding with Senate Democrats’ plans for legislation to address a concern of many voters in this midterm election year.

headline: When Sources May Have Lied
text: Somaly Mam described having been trafficked into a brothel as a young girl in Cambodia, then escaping and helping others—and she came to run a couple of organizations in Cambodia that battled forced prostitution. She wrote an autobiography, was feted at the State Department and Kennedy Center, and celebrated by journalists. Including me. I wrote one column about her life story in 2008 after her autobiography was published in the U.S., and made several references to her after that, most recently in 2011.

headline: Stumped? Invoke the 5-Minute Rule
text: This interview with Victor Allis, chief executive of Quintiq, a software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Planting for Profit, and Greater Good
text: A lemon tree springs from the soil in Jason Aramburu’s backyard in Berkeley, Calif., alongside rose bushes, birds of paradise, strawberry plants and squash blossoms. The garden is thriving, but its upkeep requires almost no effort from Mr. Aramburu. Instead, a foot-high soil sensor does much of the work.

headline: For Afghan Lovers, Joy Is Brief, Ending in Arrest
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — His Juliet thinks she is pregnant with her Romeo’s child.

headline: LeBron James Shows a Growing Willingness to Take the Lead on Social Issues
text: SAN ANTONIO — It is easy now, as Donald Sterling has thrown up his hands in surrender, to forget what it was like April 26, in the hours after a bombshell of an audio recording was released. The outrage over the racist rants was instantaneous — except from where it might have been expected to be greatest. The N.B.A., it seemed, was stunned into near silence.

headline: Britain Frees Pakistani in Inquiry
text: LONDON — The British police on Saturday released the Pakistani political leader Altaf Hussain, four days after he was arrested on suspicion of money laundering, but said that he remained under investigation.

headline: U.S. Crew Is Arrested on Honduras River Job
text: MEXICO CITY — When Robert Mayne, a marine salvage expert, sailed from Florida to the Mosquito Coast of northeastern Honduras, he carried with him a business plan that would allow him to make some money while helping the poverty-stricken people of the region.

headline: After California Chrome’s Belmont Defeat, Owner Stands on an Unseemly Soapbox
text: Steve Coburn was the picture of cheerful equanimity before California Chrome, the horse he partly owns, took the long walk Saturday evening onto the dirt track of Belmont Park, burial ground of Triple Crown dreams.

headline: In Newly Released Clinton Papers, Ire Over Speeches
text: WASHINGTON — Bill Clinton’s speeches as president were notoriously long, exemplified by his State of the Union addresses, which were wordier than any other president’s in the modern era.

headline: Haiti in Transition
text: Dissatisfaction with rebuilding efforts since the 2010 earthquake is stirring political unrest in Haiti, and the president and Senate are locked in a standoff over an overdue election.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 8
text: “With low inflation, it is more difficult for debt to come down and for economic growth to come back, so you could have a period of stagnation."Reza Moghadam, the director of the European department at the International Monetary Fund in Washington. Economists are worried that an outbreak of ultralow inflation across the 18-nation euro zone is doing more harm than good.

headline: Attitudes About Work
text: Readers discuss some of the factors that make people love or hate their jobs.

headline: The Fixer Offense in Soccer
text: The passionate rivalries of World Cup soccer will soon be enthralling sports fans across the globe, along with throngs of fanatic gamblers placing untold millions in bets.

headline: Stop Holding Us Back
text: This month, more than three million high school students will receive their diplomas. At more than 80 percent, America’s graduation rate is at a record high. More kids are going to college, too. But one-third of the nation’s African-American and Latino young men will not graduate.

headline: Pot Rules
text: WASHINGTON — IN the last chapter, I covered how not to get high. In this one, I will cover how to get high.

headline: Dear Millennials, We’re Sorry
text: AMONG Americans age 40 and older, there’s a pastime more popular than football, Candy Crush or HBO.

headline: Detroit’s Fight Against Blight
text: At one level, a new report about blight in Detroit can be seen as a cartographic inventory of the abandoned homes, vacant lots and rundown industrial sites that have spread through the once-thriving Motor City like a metastasized cancer. But there is another way to look at this important document: as the starting point for fresh conversation about what needs to be done to stabilize and revive Detroit and other declining cities around the country.

headline: Haiti Elections in Doubt as Ex-Presidents Stir Pot
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — When he returned to Haiti from exile three years ago, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former priest turned president turned deposed president, promised to stay out of politics. Yet the political party he founded and continues to inspire has routinely sent thousands of people into the streets to protest the current government, demanding the resignation of the prime minister.

headline: Stjepan Hauser
text: Stjepan Hauser is a Croatian cellist and half of the group 2Cellos, which is known for its covers of popular rock songs. A YouTube video of the duo playing AC/DC’s “Thunderstruck” has gotten more than 18 million views so far.

headline: Madam Secretary Made a Difference
text: WHEN politicians have trouble spinning their own glories, that’s a problem.

headline: The Ghosts in the Machine
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — A SURPRISING number of knife attacks on and by teenagers have appeared in the national news in recent weeks, but in terms of sheer tragic weirdness, nothing can match the case of two 12-year-old Wisconsin girls who stabbed a classmate 19 times, nearly killing her — and then said they did it to appease someone called “Slenderman.”

headline: How to Beat Malaria, Once and for All
text: MAE SOT, Thailand — MALARIA is a seasonal disease; with tropical rains come the fevers. In the news media, malaria is also seasonal. Every spring around World Malaria Day we hear about its devastating effects, including deaths in the hundreds of thousands. This year the reports were encouraging: Infections have been reduced and many lives saved. In May, researchers reported in Science that yet another potential malaria vaccine may be around the corner. Malaria seems to be on the retreat.

headline: A View From Gitmo
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — THE week’s national debate around the exchange of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Afghans imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay found me at the American base in Cuba for meetings with my clients. Here, too, the swap is the talk of the town — among prisoners, among guards and between the two groups.

headline: There Is No Alternative
text: IF the excerpts currently circulating in the press are any indication, Hillary Clinton’s latest memoir will resemble pretty much every recent political memoir from a potential presidential candidate: That is, it will be chloroform in print.

headline: The Biology of Risk
text: SIX years after the financial meltdown there is once again talk about market bubbles. Are stocks succumbing to exuberance? Is real estate? We thought we had exorcised these demons. It is therefore with something close to despair that we ask: What is it about risk taking that so eludes our understanding, and our control?

headline: Obama on Obama on Climate
text: WHEN it comes to dealing with the world’s climate and energy challenges I have a simple rule: change America, change the world.

headline: Starting Out Behind
text: Today’s young people, ages 18 to 24, should have been the lucky ones. They were preteens or teenagers when the recession hit in late 2007, with high school and college still ahead. Unlike those who had to enter the work force in the depths of the downturn, they had time, or so it seemed, to wait out the weak economy.

headline: The War on Coal Already Happened
text: I’m trying to pull together some thoughts about interests and ideology in the fight over climate policies, and found myself wondering what exactly is at stake in the supposed “war on coal”. And the answer is, surprisingly little — at least as far as jobs are concerned. Here’s total employment in coal mining (the earlier numbers are from Historical Statistics of the United States, Millennial Edition; the later from the FRED database):

headline: When a Shared ID Leads to a Grim Predicament
text: We live, it has been said many times, in the era of oversharing. Sometimes this produces awkward situations. Other times, it produces something much worse.

headline: Watchful Eyes in Booth Certify the Action on the Track
text: The time that elapsed from when the track announcer Tom Durkin, in his signature cadence, declared that “the horses have reached the starting gate” until the “official” sign was posted on the infield video board was a matter of minutes.

headline: Wind? Biofuels? Get Real, a Contrarian Says
text: Every so often we need someone to put in a kind word for the devil, if only to remind us of unpleasant facts. On energy policy, we need someone willing to declare flat out that “if oil didn’t exist, we would have to invent it. No other substance comes close to oil when it comes to energy density, ease of handling, and flexibility.”

headline: In South Sudan, a Ghost of Wars Past: Child Soldiers
text: BENTIU, South Sudan — Stretched out on a tarp on the floor of a makeshift hospital on a dirt road outside this town, a soldier in a leg cast was laughing and joking with other wounded fighters. His smile was broad and innocent, his voice not yet changed by puberty.

headline: Child Migrants Strain Makeshift Arizona Shelter
text: PHOENIX — Immigration officials overwhelmed by a flood of women and children from Central America who illegally crossed the border from Mexico are moving hundreds of unaccompanied boys and girls this weekend to a makeshift detention center in Nogales, Ariz.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 8
text: The Taliban released a video on Wednesday of their handover of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl to American troops, and it quickly went viral. The exchange — five Taliban prisoners were released from Guantánamo Bay in exchange for Sergeant Bergdahl — drew criticism from some lawmakers, who disagreed with President Obama’s decision. The story was made murkier when soldiers who served with Sergeant Bergdahl called him a deserter and some blamed him for the deaths of six to eight soldiers who were killed in a search mission for him.

headline: The Astros Are on the Verge of Winning for Losing
text: The Houston Astros picked first in the draft for the third year in a row on Thursday.

headline: With ‘She Knows a Band,’ an Agent Is Born
text: When I was 18 years old, I walked into a nightclub in Highland, Ind., with a woman 10 years my senior who was my teacher at the Barbizon modeling school in Chicago. (“Be a model, or just look like one!”) My grandmother had signed me up for the class. She hoped honing my table-setting skills might land me a suitable husband, and if I learned the Dior turn along the way, that would be nice, too. My Barbizon teacher’s presence matters only inasmuch as her looks allowed me into Club Dimensions sans ID. She bore a passing resemblance to Snow White (alabaster skin, glossy black hair, matte red lips). We were new friends, and I’d driven to her house in Highland for a visit from my apartment in suburban Chicago.

headline: After a Girl’s Accusation, the Questions Pile Up
text: The first scene of “Conviction,” the new play by Carey Crim, begins with a celebration, as two couples toast a successful high school production of “Romeo and Juliet” directed by Tom Hodges, one of the husbands. But the scene ends on a dark note, as Tom takes a phone call from the school principal and frowns. Ominous music fills the air, and the play soon turns tense and gripping.

headline: Online Learning Goes to Harvard
In Pitching Veggies to Kids, Less Is More
text: One of the fiercest marketing battles in the world takes place in kitchens and at dining room tables across the world. The sellers are parents, trying everything to persuade their children to eat their vegetables.

headline: ‘As Though the Other Good Horses Weren’t There’
text: Steve Wolfson is the son of Louis Wolfson, the owner of Affirmed, the 1978 Triple Crown champion. He formerly directed the operations at Harbor View Farm in Florida, where Affirmed was bred. Wolfson, 73, shared his memories of Affirmed and discussed issues facing the thoroughbred racing industry with Tom Pedulla.

headline: Affordable Housing That’s Very Costly
text: Abington House, at 500 West 30th Street near the High Line in West Chelsea, is a new luxury residential building and, like a lot of new luxury developments in Manhattan, it’s extremely expensive. The cheapest two-bedroom apartment now listed there rents for $5,850 a month. That gets you only one bathroom; a two-bed, two-bath can run as high as $8,695.

headline: Kings’ Resilience Rests, Quietly, With Jonathan Quick
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — As N.H.L. fans seek a definitive statement on the Los Angeles Kings’ resilience, the best place to look may be the quietest corner of their dressing room.

headline: Playoff Overtime Isn’t the Grueling Slog It Used to Be
text: Many sports have overtime, extra time or extra innings. But in hockey, extra periods of play have traditionally been a physically grueling ordeal, sometimes stretching into the next morning.

headline: Alexander Shulgin, Psychedelia Researcher, Dies at 88
text: Alexander Shulgin, a chemist who specialized in the creation of and experimentation with mind-altering substances, and who introduced the controversial drug popularly known as Ecstasy for potential therapeutic use, died on Monday at his home in Lafayette, Calif., east of Oakland. He was 88.

headline: Bird? Plane? No, but the Same View for Tennis Matches
text: PARIS — On a gray day at the French Open, thousands of spectators watched Roger Federer sit for a changeover on Philippe Chatrier Court. A moment later, a miniature jet the size of a small automobile appeared over the rim of the stadium.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 5
text: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Remembering Maya Angelou
text: Former President Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and the first lady, Michelle Obama, eulogize Maya Angelou at a memorial service in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: More Scrutiny, Still Spectacular
text: A 30 percent rise in stocks made 2013 a fruitful year for the owners of American businesses, the shareholders; while the growth in rewards was less generous for top employees, their compensation was still enormous. Average total pay for the 200 most highly paid chief executives tracked by Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, rose 6 percent, to $20.7 million.

headline: What Hillary Rodham Clinton Did
text: My Sunday column takes aim at the commonly heard narrative that Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State was glamorous but didn’t really achieve much or leave any legacy. I think that’s completely wrong, and that she did have a significant impact–just not the usual kind. I think this is an issue that is going to spark more debate this week following publication of Clinton’s book on Tuesday and as the presidential campaign approaches. So let me know if you agree, or where you think she did–or didn’t–have impact.

headline: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
text: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: The Pay at the Top
text: 200 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business.

headline: An Elusive Jackpot
text: If you were Marissa Mayer of Yahoo, making nearly $25 million for one year’s worth of work — not to mention getting $50,000 in company-paid personal security — the gender pay gap would probably not be a major concern. Women scaling the heights of corporate America tend to have compensation packages that are as jaw-droppingly gigantic as men at a similar level.

headline: A Hamlet Wrapped in Yarn
text: Walk through downtown Oyster Bay these days and you’ll find 48 trees, 34 lampposts and four kiosks wrapped in bands of green, royal blue, purple, light blue and yellow crocheted yarn.

headline: Cruz Fires Up G.O.P. Delegates in Texas
text: FORT WORTH — After patiently waiting in a line that snaked outside the doorway of a cavernous exhibit hall on Saturday, John Justice was just a few feet from reaching his goal — being photographed with Ted Cruz, the United States senator and Tea Party favorite.

headline: Unfamiliar Name Becomes Hurdle for Hispanic Candidate
text: With the chances of Texas Democrats winning a statewide office in November hinging on a higher turnout among Hispanics, the only Hispanic on their statewide ticket goes by the last name Van de Putte.

headline: Belmont Stakes: Tonalist Denies California Chrome the Triple Crown
text: Tonalist, ridden by Joel Rosario, won the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday at Belmont Park, denying California Chrome his shot at becoming the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978.

headline: Concealed Weapons, and the Sanctity of Marriage
text: One man is standing on a bridge, poised to jump. Everything has gone wrong in his life. Another man, passing by, recognizes him from his college days and casually calls out his name. Everything in the second man’s life has gone right. Everything except his marriage. Maybe, in Murray Schisgal’s “Luv,” these two old pals can help each other.

headline: Voter Turnout as Big as Texas? Not Really
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: In Paris, the Ultimate Rivalry Begins Its Next Chapter
text: PARIS — Despite smashing that racket in the semifinals, Novak Djokovic has been determined to keep the mood lighter at this French Open, and he stayed true to his plan on Saturday.

headline: It’s Good to Be a Female C.E.O., if You Can Get There
text: Female executives and their pay have been making headlines lately, from Yahoo to General Motors to The New York Times. We know that women face many obstacles on their way to the corner office (just 4.9 percent of chief executives at the 1,000 biggest companies are women), but do they continue to be treated differently once they arrive there? The answer is yes — but in different ways than the female employees below them.

headline: Willie Nelson Rode on Bus but Called Another Home
text: The entertainer Willie Nelson has a ranch in Texas and a residence in Hawaii, but the place that he calls home is a bus named Honeysuckle Rose.

headline: Sharpton Warns Against Race-Baiting in New York Contest
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton sent out a stern warning on Saturday against race-baiting in the contest for the 13th Congressional District in New York.

headline: Charity in Mexico Takes More Than Good Intentions and Cash
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — When 40 children with special needs were removed from an orphanage here last month, officials at the facility said that employees looked on helplessly, unable to get a clear reason.

headline: Deep in the Heart of Prospero
text: The shipwreck that opens Shakespeare’s “Tempest” is often staged with billowing sails, splintering masts and despairing sailors lurching across heaving decks amid blasts of rain and wind. Yet that is not the way the play begins in the current production by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

headline: After Thrill of Triple Crown Bid, Frustration for Delayed Passengers
text: The first train arrived an hour before post time for the opening race, pulling into a creaky rail station unaccustomed to the crowd.

headline: Strike One
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K, here’s the thing: There are times when the creative vision of a puzzle maker outpaces that of some of the technology that exists to support that vision. And because there are many third party programs and apps with which to download The New York Times Crossword — programs and apps that The Times does not control — not everyone will have the same experience. I might have alluded to that yesterday, when I was driving myself crazy trying to think of a way to explain this puzzle. I feel better now, so here we go.

headline: Baby-Boomer Misery Confronts a Funnier Future
text: What’s so great about licking postage stamps, anyway? Audiences at Hartford Stage will be forgiven if they don’t stop to think this through as Mark Nelson, playing the first of the four title characters in Christopher Durang’s “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” waxes rhapsodic about stamp-licking. His brilliant, showstopping rant about the vanished joys of yesteryear — coonskin caps, Dinah Shore, rotary-dial telephones, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, handwritten letters and, yes, even the icky, glue-backed stamps for posting them — bursts forth in a torrent that vanquishes any and all cavils.

headline: Seeking National Glory, Clubs Tap Global Talent
text: The champions of premier French and British club leagues defended their titles this year by doing the usual: importing world-class talent.

headline: Urged to Multiply, Iranian Couples Are Dubious
text: TEHRAN — In their early 30s, married, and with prospects for successful careers, Bita and Sherag could be contemplating the logical next step in their lives: becoming parents.

headline: Though Not Quietly, Kentucky Moves to Cut Reliance on Coal
text: BURGIN, Ky. — The E. W. Brown power plant rides like an ocean liner on a rolling ridge in Kentucky, its smokestacks and plumes visible across fields of corn and cattle for miles around.

headline: Giants Series Gives Mets Another Look at What They Lost in Pagan
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Angel Pagan keeps his World Series ring, the one he won with the San Francisco Giants in 2012, in his house, in a secure location he does not readily divulge. Every now and then, he takes it out and admires it. The ring motivates him.

headline: Behind the ‘Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team’
text: As a nation of immigrants, Americans tend to have more choices than most when it comes to rooting for a team in the World Cup. You get the United States — that’s your safety school, so to speak. Unfortunately, the U.S. national team never figures to go very deep into the tournament. So you can choose to root for your ancestors or, if you want, a team that speaks to you, and not your national or ethnic pride. If that’s your chosen course, this is a chart for you.

headline: Fresh Legs Stamp Out a Coronation
text: The gates popped open Saturday, and 11 horses charged past the grandstand for a mile-and-a-half marathon nicknamed, fittingly, the Test of the Champion. All eyes were on California Chrome, in pursuit of the first Triple Crown since 1978. There appeared to be little to worry about as jockey Victor Espinoza spurted him along the rail and glided him into the first turn almost easier than he had in his six previous races, all victories.

headline: Seeing Squalor and Unconcern in a Mississippi Jail
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Open fires sometimes burn unheeded in the solitary-confinement units of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, a privately run state prison in Meridian, 90 miles east of here.

headline: Bergdahl Was in Unit Known for Its Troubles
text: The platoon was, an American military official would assert years later, “raggedy.”

headline: Cleveland Clinic Chief Out of Running for V.A.
text: WASHINGTON — Dr. Delos M. Cosgrove, the chief executive of the Cleveland Clinic, said Saturday he had been considered by President Obama for the job of secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, but had withdrawn his name and would stay at the clinic.

headline: Outside Money Floods Alaska in Senate Race
text: ANCHORAGE — A big part of being an Alaskan is harboring a suspicion of all things Lower 48. It’s an inclination that runs so deep that locals have a proper noun to describe everywhere else — Outside.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Book ‘Hard Choices’ Portrays a Tested Policy Wonk
text: The rollout of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s new book, “Hard Choices,” as a prelude to a possible 2016 run for the White House, has had all the subtlety of a military operation ramping up to full speed: the leak of the Benghazi chapter to Politico late last month (presumably to get talk about that hot-button topic out of the way early), the cover story in the latest issue of People magazine, the wall-to-wall lineup of television interviews this week, a grueling cross-country book tour.

headline: Portraying Horse as Hero, Soon Fallen
text: Heading into the Belmont Stakes, California Chrome was the undisputed story.

headline: As Bowe Bergdahl Heals, Details Emerge of His Captivity
text: WASHINGTON — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has told medical officials that his captors locked him in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, and while military doctors say he now is physically able to travel he is not yet emotionally ready for the pressures of reuniting with his family, according to American officials who have been briefed on his condition.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 7, 2014
text: June 7, 2014

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Meet the New Clone, the One With the Flannel Shirt
text: Season 2, Episode 8: As I watched Saturday’s installment of “Orphan Black” for the second time, something continued to bother me. The introduction of Tony, a transgendered clone played by Tatiana Maslany, is certainly a surprising development and another intriguing variation on the show’s central themes of individual identity within a select group and nature vs. nurture.

headline: Hope Wilts as Tradition Stays Strong
text: The traditional blanket of white carnations placed on the winner of the Belmont Stakes was made with 445 flowers painstakingly glued to a seven-foot-long velveteen quilt by Tony Green, who felt deep in his bones on Saturday morning that California Chrome would win the Triple Crown.

headline: Handwriting on Wall for Yankees as Ball Flies Over It
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The pitch was down, almost at Salvador Perez’s shoe tops, just where Yankees starter David Phelps wanted it. Then Perez swung and drove the ball where Phelps never expected, toward the Kansas City Royals’ bullpen in left field.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 8, 2014
text: “Anybody with a lot of children is either very rich or very irresponsible. There is no other way.”

headline: U.S. Displays Improvement Across the Field and a Breakthrough at the Front
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — After struggling with a scoring slump dating to last year, Jozy Altidore hit his stride Saturday with two goals in a convincing 2-1 win over Nigeria that could give the United States national team momentum for its arrival in Brazil for the World Cup.

headline: The Intimacy of Anonymity
text: Thanks to Facebook and Instagram, oversharing one’s personal life feels as authentic as reality TV. Right now anonymous posts hold the key to the truth.

text: Joanna Amy Brooks and Marcus Andreas Klostermeyer are to be married Sunday afternoon by Cantor Leslie Friedlander at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
