Shufelt of Wilmington, Vt., and the late Elizabeth D. Shufelt. The Rev. Joseph M. McShane, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Fordham University, who was a friend of the bride’s father, performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Kings Again Take the Lead Only When Necessary: At the End
text: LOS ANGELES — Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals was decided in overtime. Game 2 on Saturday night at Staples Center went to double overtime, more than four hours after the first puck was dropped. Eighty-two shots were fired on goal. When the last one eluded the outstretched glove of Henrik Lundqvist, the Los Angeles Kings grabbed a stranglehold on the series.

headline: Steve Coburn Lashes Out at Racing Industry, Capping an Emotional Five Weeks
text: Steve Coburn was afforded five weeks of fame beyond the clichéd 15 minutes, and he made the most of his time in the limelight.

headline: Corrections: June 8, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: On the Scene at the Belmont Stakes
text: An estimated crowd of 100,000 attended Belmont Park on Saturday to watch California Chrome run for the Triple Crown.

headline: Giants Rally in Ninth to Send Mets to Fifth Straight Loss
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Mets catcher Anthony Recker stood still, his hand on his hip, staring blankly into the distance. The Mets were clinging to a 4-3 ninth-inning lead over the San Francisco Giants, the best team in baseball.

headline: World Cup Crib Sheet: Very Important Charts
text: We complete our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. To see which team asked for a Jacuzzi in every hotel room, and more, check out the charts below.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: Hugh Jackman on His Hosting Plans
text: For complete coverage of the Tony Awards, including performance videos, predictions and an interactive ballot, please visit The Times’s Tony Awards special section.

headline: A Plea to the Daughters of Title IX: Why Don’t More Women Coach?
text: When I first registered my daughter, Lily, for soccer five years ago, I made a conscious decision to take a back seat. I wouldn’t volunteer to be the head coach. Instead, I would take a role as an assistant/orange-slice dispenser. The plan was for me to lend support, but not loom too large over my daughter.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 68TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Hugh Jackman, above, will sing and dance his way across the stage of Radio City Music Hall as host of this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway. Performers include the nominees Neil Patrick Harris and the cast of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” Sutton Foster and the cast of “Violet,” and Idina Menzel, in a song from “If/Then,” as well as Alan Cumming in a reprisal of his Tony Award-winning role from “Cabaret.” Other highlights include a 10th-anniversary celebration by the cast of “Wicked”; Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight and Fantasia in performance with the cast of “After Midnight”; Sting in a work from his coming musical, “The Last Ship”; and Jennifer Hudson in a number from “Finding Neverland,” a Harvey Weinstein project.

headline: In Our Pages: June 9
text: 1889: The Tonquin Railway

headline: How Much Should We Pay For Art?
text: “How do we decide, as a capitalist society, what creative expression is worth?” That question, posed by Ester Bloom at The Billfold, gets more vexed every day. In a time when more and more art is available for free online, we as a society have to figure out how to value and support it.

headline: At Swearing-In, Ex-General Vows ‘Inclusive’ Egypt
text: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover here nearly one year ago, was sworn in as president on Sunday, testing the bet that a new strongman can overcome the economic dysfunction and political polarization that bedeviled Egypt’s three-year experiment with democracy.

headline: 3 Inmates Escape in Quebec in Latest Helicopter Jailbreak
text: OTTAWA — Three men escaped from a Quebec jail on Saturday night aboard a helicopter, the second aerial breakout in the province in 15 months.

headline: A Half-Century of Guiding Young Scholars in Harlem
text: Edouard E. Plummer works out of a room inside a Harlem public school that would be spacious — if it were a storage closet. Still, he has found a way to pack its shelves and cover its walls with a growing testament to a half-century of achievements that rival those of headmasters at the swankiest prep schools.

headline: Nadal Denies Djokovic, and Defies Belief, Once Again
text: PARIS — After all the consecutive victories and the confidently clenched fists, after the new hires and the new attitude, the 2014 French Open was just another red-clay rerun for Novak Djokovic.

headline: Critics of P.O.W. Swap Question the Absence of a Wider Agreement
text: WASHINGTON — When the heads of the two major intelligence committees criticized the Obama administration on Sunday for swapping Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five members of the Taliban, they homed in on one part of the deal that the White House has struggled for a week, unsuccessfully, to explain. The question is why the five were released without any commitments to a larger agreement, under which the Taliban would renounce international terrorism, and begin a process of reconciliation with the government of Afghanistan.

headline: Sisi Ascends to the Presidency
text: Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi was sworn in Sunday as Egypt’s president.

headline: Is It Possible to Be a Male Feminist?
text: Who is the male feminist? Perhaps we should first ask: Does he even exist?

headline: ‘Calvin and Hobbes’ Creator Returns, Briefly
text: Bill Watterson, the creator of “Calvin and Hobbes” who retired in 1995 and withdrew from the public eye for almost two decades, has finally returned to drawing comic strips, if only for a brief moment. Last week, Mr. Watterson was the ghost artist for a handful of panels on Stephan Pastis’s “Pearls Before Swine” for a storyline in which Mr. Pastis is replaced as the artist of the strip by a second grader named Libby.

headline: Rift Deepens in Britain Over Claims of School Infiltration Plot by Islamic Extremists
text: A dispute over how to combat the threat of homegrown Islamic extremism in British schools has provoked a political crisis, prompting the personal intervention of Prime Minister David Cameron, a public apology from one senior minister and the resignation of an adviser to another.

headline: Border Makes China and India Bristle, Even as They Seek Closer Ties in Trade
text: NEW DELHI — China’s state news media has welcomed India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, as a pragmatic new partner on economic matters, noting that as a regional leader, he made four visits to Beijing seeking investment and even went to the trouble of printing his business cards in Chinese characters, in the auspicious color of red.

headline: In Egypt, Back to Rule By a Strongman
text: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover in Egypt nearly one year ago, was sworn in as the country’s president on Sunday. The reactions to Sisi’s election ranged from downright joyous to cautiously optimistic to unapologetically cynical.

headline: Terrorists Attack Airport in Pakistan, Killing 13
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — In a ferocious terrorist assault that stretched into Monday morning, suspected Islamist militants infiltrated Pakistan’s largest international airport in Karachi, waging an extended firefight against security forces that resulted in 23 deaths and shook the country’s already fragile sense of security.

headline: Rangers Fume Over a Tangle in the Crease
text: LOS ANGELES — Whether a play included goaltender interference, perhaps the most disputed penalty in hockey, is not reviewable by replay officials, despite frequent pleas to make it so. The Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist became the latest to issue that request, after Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night.

headline: Tonalist’s Owner Savors Victory but Offers Some Criticism of His Own
text: Robert Evans was gracious Saturday evening when a reporter relayed the sour-grapes comments from Steve Coburn, one of California Chrome’s owners.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Vanity Fair Ad Gives Life to What Killed the Cat
text: SCHWEPPES, for many years, sold tonic water as “curiously refreshing.” Hendrick’s gin staged a “theater of curiosities” and billed its unusual website as a “Curiositorium.” And it is, of course, common knowledge what curiosity did to that cat.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’ Take Top Honors
text: Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The Times, and Eric Grode, a writer and critic for The Times, live-blogged the 68th annual Tony Awards.

headline: Trying to Stop Fight at Staten Island Bar, Man Dies After He Is Punched
text: Closing time was approaching early Sunday morning at the Drunken Monkey, a Staten Island bar with a reality television claim to fame, when a group of stragglers began fighting.

headline: At Vatican, Day of Prayer With Focus on Uniting
text: VATICAN CITY — In a richly symbolic ceremony, Pope Francis oversaw a carefully orchestrated “prayer summit” with the Israeli and Palestinian presidents on Sunday as Jews, Christians and Muslims offered invocations for peace in the Vatican gardens.

headline: Andy Murray Picks Amélie Mauresmo as His New Coach
text: PARIS — It was the French Open’s best off-court chess match: Andy Murray versus the news media on the topic of his new coach.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 9
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: From China, With Pragmatism
text: As an American Fulbright lecturer living in Beijing, I am regularly confronted with “lost in translation” ethical conversations. At a recent lunch with United States Embassy officers and local Chinese intellectuals, we had a complete cultural breakdown over red envelopes.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Goes Back to Sleep, Squandering a Solid Start by Kuroda
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — On a partly cloudy Sunday morning, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi led more than a dozen reporters down a hallway to the visitors’ dugout at Kauffman Stadium and sat down. Ever optimistic, Girardi then cited run-scoring doubles by Brian McCann and Carlos Beltran the previous two nights as encouraging signs for his club’s struggling offense.

headline: Five Killed in Las Vegas Shootings
text: Two police officers and another person were killed in a shooting rampage on Sunday morning in Las Vegas, the authorities said.

headline: Philharmonic’s Contemporary Foray Ends, With a Promise of More
text: Avery Fisher Hall looked to be about half-full for a concert by the New York Philharmonic on Friday night, the orchestra’s next-to-last program for the inaugural NY Phil Biennial, conducted by the vibrant German-born composer Matthias Pintscher. The Philharmonic, the institutional curator of this bracing festival, may have hoped that every event would attract capacity crowds; some, in smaller halls, did.

headline: A Paragon of Honor, With a Little Time Off for Love
text: Akshay Kumar has made a career of playing Indian Everymen, sweet goofballs who succeed accidentally while upholding traditional values. He may cut down villains — there’s plenty of fighting in movies like “Chandni Chowk to China” and “Singh Is Kinng” — but he honors mothers and aunties and helps the poor.

headline: For Audience and Young Composers, a Chance to See Works Take Flight
text: “I want to clarify the articulation in the oboes in measure four,” George Manahan, the music director of the American Composers Orchestra, announced to his players on Saturday evening, before they began Andy Akiho’s “Tarnished Mirrors.”

headline: Teenage Angst Trumps Sci-Fi at the Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — Social media came of age in Hollywood over the weekend.

headline: Stacked Deck
text: Dealing with the Taliban over American P.O.W.'s.

headline: T h r e e  S t r i k e s
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — All is forgiven, Tom McCoy. You can come home now.

headline: A Lowly Scorned Shopgirl Takes On the Upper Crust
text: However current the issues of income inequality, a living wage and an arbitrary criminal justice system may be, “Within the Law” reminds us that they have long been fodder for popular entertainment.

headline: Good With the Scalpel, but Lacks People Skills
text: Reading “The Dinner,” by the Dutch author and misanthrope Herman Koch, was rather like being stabbed in the eyeball with a hot needle. The book was such a huge international best seller that Mr. Koch is demonstrably not alone in his fascination with all things loathsome about humanity, and “The Dinner” did tell a propulsive tale. It is a hard act to follow, but say this about his new novel, “Summer House With Swimming Pool”: This is a book in which someone actually does stick a hot needle in his own eyeball. The blood, pus and pain that follow are lovingly described.

headline: Dutilleux and Ravel Mingle With Sir Mix-a-Lot
text: SEATTLE — It has been quite a spring for the Seattle Symphony.

headline: More Than Just the Father of a Famous Actor
text: Robert De Niro, one of the most respected and successful actors of his generation, ended up in a very different field from his father, the painter Robert De Niro Sr. But he knows that one thing is true for all artists no matter what the discipline: Talent isn’t enough. What separates someone at the top from countless skilled contemporaries who spend their careers in semi-obscurity has as much to do with serendipity as it does with ability.

headline: A Shoeshine Box, With a Luster All Its Own, Emerges From the Shadows
text: A 1930s shoeshine stand bedecked with gilded knobs and beaded fringe, which was once exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art — where it played a role in a famous director’s ouster — resurfaced last month and is headed back into the public eye.

headline: Persistence Can Be Its Own Reward, Even for a Confrontational Band
text: There must be a positive lesson to be extracted from the story of Eyehategod. This band from New Orleans has endured 26 years — through opiates, hurricanes, homelessness, jail and probation. It has survived a name that has never gotten any less puerile; the recent death of a drummer, Joey LaCaze, who helped define its angry and sensuous sound; touring whenever possible; recording a lot less often; and a kind of artfully antisocial behavior.

headline: Tracy Morgan, Still Critical, Is ‘More Responsive’
text: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan remained in critical condition on Sunday after he was injured in a crash in New Jersey over the weekend. Mr. Morgan, 45, a former cast member of “Saturday Night Live” and “30 Rock,” had several serious injuries, including a broken leg, a broken femur, a broken nose and several broken ribs, his publicist Lewis Kay said on Sunday. He was hurt when a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of the luxury van he was riding in as he left a comedy show in Delaware around 1 a.m. on Saturday. Mr. Morgan is expected to remain in the hospital for several weeks, Mr. Kay said.

headline: Focusing on a Mystery, and Their Own Dramas
text: When a series follows one murder investigation for an entire season, the conceit can sometimes look like a European refinement. “Broadchurch,” “Spiral” and “The Fall” are just a notable few of the many imported shows that proved so broodingly intense that it sometimes seemed as if networks and basic cable here could never catch up.

headline: Biggest Master Point Winner at Eastern States Regional
text: John Kranyak of Las Vegas won more master points (78.7) than anyone else at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month. He had three firsts and one second in four Swiss Team events.

headline: A Work Moves, Even if Some of the Figures Do Not
text: “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier,” the four-week performance series that has been running at Danspace Project in St. Mark’s Church since May 21, has mostly evaded providing a clear, defining image of DD Dorvillier. “A Catalogue of Steps” rearranged fragments from her early works. The “Solo Performances” over two weekends were created and performed by people other than Ms. Dorvillier. And on Friday, when she debuted her own work, also called “Diary of an Image,” she gave over the first part of the piece to stationary silhouettes of other dancers.

headline: Governors Ball
text: Scenes from the music festival on Randalls Island.

headline: A Mix of Fact and Imagination, ‘As Seen on Radio’
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s opera house must have hosted plenty of Valkyries in its time. But Jeanine De Bique is almost certainly the first to stride onstage accessorized with a broom and dishwashing gloves, singing about how much she hates her job.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Bows Out of World Cup Ceremony
text: Jennifer Lopez will not perform as planned at the opening ceremony of the 2014 World Cup in São Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday because of what FIFA officials are calling “production issues,” The Associated Press has reported. Ms. Lopez was scheduled to appear alongside the rapper Pitbull and the Brazilian star Claudia Leitte for a performance of “We Are One (Ole Ola),” the official song of the soccer tournament, before the opening match between Brazil and Croatia. All three artists perform on the recording of the track, which was released in April and written and co-produced by Pitbull. A replacement for Ms. Lopez has not been announced.

headline: ‘Pass It On’
text: As soon as I saw a photograph of an African soccer ball, stitched together from old rags in the geometric patterns so familiar to us, I wanted to tell its story.

headline: Pass It On
text: This short video shows how a Congolese man turns scraps into a soccer ball for village children, so they can play the sport they love.

headline: An Invasion of Color at Chelsea Art Gallery
text: The famously chromophobic Chelsea got a shock of color on Thursday night: lime green, sunshine yellow, orange and spring green on the walls of the Gemini G.E.L. at Joni Moisant Weyl Gallery, defying conventional wisdom that galleries must be white. The masterminds were two architects known for shaking up hotels and houses with bold hues: Peter Stamberg (who held court in a fluorescent orange jacket from Joe Fresh) and Paul Aferiat (in pink seersucker), founders of Stamberg Aferiat & Associates.

headline: Aftermath of the Karachi Airport Attack
text: The scene at the airport in Karachi, Pakistan, after militants stormed past security, firing automatic weapons and hurling grenades.

headline: When Offenders Get On With Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Noncompete Clauses Increasingly Pop Up in Array of Jobs
text: BOSTON — Colette Buser couldn’t understand why a summer camp withdrew its offer for her to work there this year.

headline: After Period of Turmoil, Riverside Church Elects New Leader
text: Riverside Church, one of the nation’s most prominent liberal Protestant pulpits, on Sunday elected as its new senior minister the Rev. Dr. Amy K. Butler, making her the first woman to head the church in its 84-year history.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Taxidermy Meets Arts and Crafts
text: A hobby that saw its heyday in Victorian Britain is enjoying a revival in London.

headline: As a British Pastime Is Revived, Some Critters Get Second Lives
text: LONDON — “Now pull the skin up over the skull like a hood,” Margot Magpie instructed her students. They were hunched over wooden tables, each holding a scalpel in one hand and a white mouse, gutted, in the other.

headline: End of Altidore’s Slump Lifts U.S. Hopes
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As the United States national team prepares for the World Cup in Brazil, it is riding the momentum of a three-game winning streak and perhaps a dose of newfound confidence from its starting striker, Jozy Altidore.

headline: Peaceful Nonreconciliation Now
text: MAALE SHOMRON, West Bank — JOHN KERRY’S failed Middle East peace effort has made it clear that a negotiated political agreement is impossible at the moment. The two-state formula enjoyed decades of exclusive stardom, in which its appeal thwarted all innovative and alternative thought.

headline: Shifts in Charity Health Care
text: Health care reform was supposed to relieve the financial strain on hospitals that have provided a lot of free charity care to poor and uninsured patients. The reform law, known as the Affordable Care Act, was expected to insure most of those patients either through expanded state Medicaid programs for the poor or through subsidized private insurance for middle-income patients, thereby funneling new revenues to hospitals that had previously absorbed the costs of uncompensated care.

headline: Reconstruction Planned for Infamous Townhouse in Greenwich Village
text: The house at 18 West 11th Street is one of Greenwich Village’s most famous. It has been a home to literary and Broadway royalty, the site of a deadly accidental bombing by Weatherman radicals and, once rebuilt, a sweet neighborhood fixture with a stuffed Paddington Bear wearing seasonal outfits in its angled picture window.

headline: Tipped Into Poverty
text: When Senate Republicans recently blocked a vote to raise the federal minimum wage, they snubbed the estimated 27.8 million people who would earn more if the measure became law. The hardest hit are the roughly 3.3 million Americans who work for tips, nearly three out of four of whom are women. Workers in predominantly tipped jobs — including restaurant servers, bartenders, hairstylists — are twice as likely as other workers to live below the poverty line. They need a raise, and Congress should give it to them.

headline: A Model for Juvenile Detention Reform
text: States are sending fewer and fewer children to juvenile correctional facilities, partly in response to research showing that locking up young people increases the risk that they will eventually drop out of school and become permanently entangled with the justice system.

headline: A Triple Crown Tradition Prevails at Belmont Stakes Despite Sour Grapes
text: California Chrome’s co-owner Steve Coburn was upset, and so were the multitudes who had their hearts set Saturday on a victory by the colt in the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes and the first Triple Crown in 36 years. But, like all of us who at one time or another need to heed the guiding, loving hand of a spouse, the voluble cowboy should have listened to his wife, Carolyn, and just zipped it when the cameras were in his face.

headline: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business
text: Julia Roberts’s smile is insured. So are Heidi Klum’s legs, Daniel Craig’s body and Jennifer Lopez’s derrière. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance.

headline: Ebola Gets Worse in West Africa
text: The World Health Organization warned last Wednesday that the epidemic caused by the deadly Ebola virus in West Africa, which had seemed to be waning, has recently taken a turn for the worse. The afflicted nations and their neighbors will need to redouble their efforts to contain a virus for which there is neither a cure nor a vaccine.

headline: Ready for Spotlight, a Course Is Restored to Its Shaggy Self
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — As one of the country’s first golf resorts, Pinehurst has long been viewed as an American cradle of the sport. The resort’s showcase golf course, known as Pinehurst No. 2, hosted its first major event more than 100 years ago and evolved into a masterpiece of the nation’s best-known golf architect, Donald Ross.

headline: In Crown Heights, Once Torn by Race Riots, a Friendly Game of Soccer
text: The World Cup may be days away, but in Brooklyn, the Crown Heights Cup game on Sunday may be almost as important. In some ways, it is more important.

headline: Religious Constriction
text: I am both shocked and fascinated by Americans’ religious literalism.

headline: Netflix Investors to Vote on C.E.O.-Chairman Split
text: Netflix has had its share of battles of late, including opposing Comcast’s proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable and pointing fingers at Verizon for some instances of its streaming video service’s being slowed. But the online video titan has also quietly faced restiveness among some of its shareholders.

headline: In Texarkana, Uninsured and on the Wrong Side of a State Line
text: TEXARKANA, Tex. — On a hazy, hot evening here, Janice Marks ate a dinner of turkey and stuffing at a homeless shelter filled with plastic cots before crossing a few blocks to the Arkansas side of town to start her night shift restocking the dairy cases at Walmart.

headline: Tyson Is Said to Win Battle for Hillshire Brands
text: Updated, 8:18 a.m. | In the battle for Jimmy Dean sausages, it appears that Tyson Foods has won.

headline: Interests, Ideology and Climate
text: There are three things we know about man-made global warming. First, the consequences will be terrible if we don’t take quick action to limit carbon emissions. Second, in pure economic terms the required action shouldn’t be hard to take: emission controls, done right, would probably slow economic growth, but not by much. Third, the politics of action are nonetheless very difficult.

headline: At Rio’s Beaches, Kicks Go Over Net
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The most impressive move in Brazilian sports has nothing to do with soccer, takes place on sand and is known, delightfully, as the Shark Attack.

headline: An American Life, Lived in Shadows
text: TULSA, Okla. — Ignacio, a father of four, bounces along in his pickup truck, driving at exactly the speed limit through an aging suburb. The clock says 6:44 a.m. Religious pendants hang off the mirror. His teenage son sits beside him, chatty if half-awake, as they approach an apartment building for a day of roofing in dire heat.

headline: Brazil’s Other Favorite Sport
text: Born on Copacabana Beach in the 1960s, futevolei is a uniquely Brazilian sport.

headline: Are Reparations Due to African-Americans?
text: Would they compensate for a history of racial injustice? Would they be fair or practical? How would they be implemented?

headline: Face of the N.C.A.A., Battered Early and Often
text: INDIANAPOLIS — A large oil painting hangs in the office of Mark A. Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A. It depicts a boxer in a gym preparing for a bout, a team of trainers huddled around him.

headline: Port Authority Land Purchase Is Boon to Bayonne, and Christie
text: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced in June 2010 that it had purchased a 131-acre tract of land on the waterfront in the city of Bayonne for $235 million, the deal seemed like an auspicious one for the agency.

headline: Five Dead in Shooting Rampage in Las Vegas
text: In a shooting rampage that left five people dead, two assailants killed two Las Vegas police officers on Sunday at a pizza restaurant and fatally shot a third person at a nearby Walmart before dying in a suicide pact, the authorities said.

headline: Day After Catcher Is Sent to Minors, Mets Are Swept Again in Trip Finale
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It was only the seventh inning, but David Wright was perhaps the Mets’ last hope. He was given a rare day off, but the Mets were a run behind the San Francisco Giants with two outs and the tying run on first base.

headline: Degree? Check. Enthusiasm? Check. Job? Not So Fast.
text: He pulled the maroon robes over his shoulders and straightened his cap, his body tingling with that nothing-can-kill-this-day kind of vibe. Then he heard his mother calling his name — Jelani! Jelani! — and suddenly he was standing, then shouting, then high-fiving his fellow college graduates.

headline: 3-Pointer No Longer Domain of Small Players in N.B.A.
text: SAN ANTONIO — Bob McAdoo, with his graceful, high-arcing jumper, was a rarity for an N.B.A. big man. At 6 feet 9 inches, he could pull shot blockers like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Artis Gilmore and Bob Lanier out near the top of the key and shoot over them or drive past them. Three times, McAdoo led the league in scoring, and in 1975, he was named the N.B.A.’s most valuable player.

headline: A Proud Swirl of Sound and Spectacle
text: The parade could be seen and heard several blocks away from Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, where determined visitors armed with folding chairs and coolers had been lining the route since early Sunday morning. Red, white and blue flags fluttered like capes from the backs of people heading toward Bryant Park. Salsa music pumped from the floats and coursed through the streets. Cheers rose above the roar of Midtown traffic.

headline: A Proud Swirl of Red, White and Blue
text: Spectators lined Fifth Avenue to watch the 57th National Puerto Rican Day Parade, a start-of-summer tradition in New York City.

headline: For Buffalo, Few Points on the Ice but Plenty in the TV Ratings
text: The hockey fans of Buffalo are proving that their passion for the sport does not wane, even when the Sabres have a miserable points percentage — the worst in their history.

headline: Stretching the Limits Seems to Suit the Kings
text: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Kings’ relentless run this postseason may be the most inexplicable one in the 121 years of the Stanley Cup.

headline: Morris A. Adelman Dies at 96; Saw Oil as Inexhaustible
text: Morris A. Adelman, an energy economist who marshaled free-market principles and hard data in arguing that the world’s oil supply was not running out, died May 8 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 96. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he taught and researched for 65 years, announced the death on May 15.

headline: Time Inc. to Set a Lonely Course After a Spinoff
text: Sometime late next year Time Inc., the company that all but created the modern magazine business, will leave its home of more than five decades, the Time & Life Building in Rockefeller Center, and head to new quarters in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Video Gaming’s Big Expo, and G.M.’s Shareholder Meeting
text: G.M. HOLDING SHAREHOLDERS’ MEETING

headline: Free Music, at Least While It Lasts
text: Late last Thursday, I stopped at the fruit stand and some big, vivid red grapes caught my eye. The vendor said a two-pound bunch would be $6, which seemed steep. I was about to tell him as much, and then came to my senses and gave him the money.

headline: David Nadien, Philharmonic Concertmaster, Is Dead at 88
text: David Nadien, a violinist whose appointment as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic raised eyebrows because of his thriving career as a studio musician, died on May 28 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Japan Seeks to Squelch Its Tiny Cars
text: SHINSHIRO, Japan — Toshie Yamada’s “kei,” with its pint-size engine and tiny wheels, looks more like a Fisher-Price toy car than a regular truck. But don’t underestimate her Nissan NT 100 Clipper microtruck. At a recent farmers’ market, where she sells orchids from her flower farm here in central Japan, she loaded up a mountain of crates, buckets and a folding table before hopping in and zipping away.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 8, 2014
text: June 8, 2014

headline: The Well-Followed on Social Media Cash In on Their Influence
text: Good thing social media did not exist during the era of “Mad Men.” It might have put Don and Peggy out of business.

headline: Reuniting With Mother at the Zoo
text: Dear Diary:

headline: G.M. Report Illustrates Managers’ Disconnect
text: WASHINGTON — The report released last week on how General Motors failed for years to recognize a safety defect in millions of small cars contained no new scientific or engineering insights. What it did was reinforce a point about the sociology of management: From cars to space shuttles, from offshore oil wells to nuclear reactors, the people who make the decisions are often out of step with the mechanical details.

headline: Sterling’s Ban and Fine Won’t Change, Silver Says
text: SAN ANTONIO — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Sunday that the process of removing the Clippers owner Donald Sterling from the league was nearing an end, even though Sterling had a lawsuit pending against the league and had not signed a term sheet that his wife, Rochelle, agreed to with Steve Ballmer for a $2 billion sale.

headline: War Gear Flows to Police Departments
text: NEENAH, Wis. — Inside the municipal garage of this small lakefront city, parked next to the hefty orange snowplow, sits an even larger truck, this one painted in desert khaki. Weighing 30 tons and built to withstand land mines, the armored combat vehicle is one of hundreds showing up across the country, in police departments big and small.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Vanessa’s Sin and Obsession
text: Season 1, Episode 5: When Vanessa set out to flirt with Victor Frankenstein earlier in “Penny Dreadful,” she cooed a few lines of Wordsworth at him, from the “Intimations of Immortality,” to be precise. In “Closer Than Sisters,” the first episode to air since Showtime announced that the show has been renewed for a second season, she switches over to another Romantic poet, John Keats – and appears to be setting herself up for the worst kind of immortality.

headline: 2014 Tony Awards: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’ Are Named Top Shows
text: Overcoming death-defying odds — modest ticket sales, little-known stars and limited appeal to tourists — “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” won the Tony Award for best musical on Sunday night, in a ceremony that stood out for spreading the wealth among many shows. As for performers, one reigned supreme: Audra McDonald made history by winning her sixth prize for acting, the most ever.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Joe Reveals a Scar
text: Season 1, Episode 2: Is “Halt and Catch Fire” a mystery, or is it a procedural? The second episode of AMC’s new drama about the dawn of the personal computer industry dances upon this question.

headline: Popular Demand
text: As government and internal investigations into the ignition-switch defect have built since the February recall of Cobalts and other General Motors models, Cobalt owners have remained loyal to the brand.

headline: Judge Voids Expansion of Discount Drug Program
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has struck down a new rule requiring drug companies to offer certain drugs at discounted prices, saying the Obama administration had no authority to issue the rule.

headline: James and the Heat Coolly Even the N.B.A. Finals
text: SAN ANTONIO — The air-conditioning system at AT&T Center was in working order Sunday night, and so was LeBron James.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 4
text: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday June 9, 2014
text: “It’s impossible to understand what it is to move when you have nothing. To risk everything — losing your bed, your sense of community — for an uncertain benefit? There’s no way you want to risk that.”

headline: Word of the Day | scintilla
text: scintilla •\sin-ˈti-lə\• noun

headline: World’s Oldest Man, Though Only Briefly, Dies at 111 in New York
text: Alexander Imich, a Polish-born psychic researcher who was certified the oldest man on earth, died Sunday morning at a senior residence in Manhattan. He had turned 111 on Feb. 4.

headline: Not the Movies, but Real Theater
text: “You’re asking people to care about something that may not affect their lives, may not even affect their children’s lives,” Anderson Cooper said, introducing the CBS broadcast of the Tony Awards on Sunday night.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) HILLARY CLINTON: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE — ONE ON ONE WITH DIANE SAWYER In an interview at her home in Washington, Mrs. Clinton (above right with Ms. Sawyer) discusses her new book, “Hard Choices,” as well as the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the aftermath of the concussion she sustained in 2012 and whether she will release her medical records if she runs for president in 2016.

headline: Steve Coburn’s Proposal Aside, Belmont Field Is Traditionally Small
text: California Chrome headed back to California after Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, in which he failed to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978, but the debate about the format of the three-race series continued.

headline: In Communist Party Parlance, Adultery Has Many Names
text: The Communist Party regularly employs a variety of muffled euphemisms for sexual misdeeds: moral corruption, dissolute lifestyle and the like. But in a rare display of lucidity, China’s top antigraft body actually used the Chinese word for adultery — tongjian (通奸) — last week while announcing the expulsion of a party member.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times editorial board supports a settlement in a lawsuit between the Justice Department and the State of Ohio over care in juvenile correctional facilities. “Ohio will sharply reduce and eventually end solitary confinement,” the board writes, citing statistics indicating higher likelihood of mental problems and suicidal behavior in youngsters forced to endure it. “The Justice Department’s settlement with Ohio puts states on notice that solitary policies need to change. If adopted nationally, the principles in that settlement would go a long way toward humanizing juvenile detention.”

headline: Golf’s Mona Lisa Got a Buzzcut
text: The world’s best golfers will compete for the U.S. Open at Pinehurst. The resort’s landmark course recently got a makeover, and its new look is anything but manicured and green.

headline: Corrections: June 9, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Lloyds Sets Price Range for TSB Unit Below Book Value
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group announced on Monday the price range for the initial public offering of its TSB Banking Group unit, one that is below what analysts think is the book value of the business.

headline: Britain’s Man Group to Acquire Pine Grove Asset Management
text: LONDON – The British hedge fund manager Man Group said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Pine Grove Asset Management, a hedge fund manager based in the United States.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Social Media Celebrities Meet Their Biggest Fans
text: In “Performing Without Net: Stars of YouTube Take to the Stage,” Brooks Barnes writes about social media celebrities appearing at events with their fans.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, June 9, 2014
text: Can animals can have a tangible effect on children’s health and well-being?

headline: Cinven to Buy Spanish Fiber Optic Network Operator
text: LONDON – The European private equity firm Cinven said Monday that it had agreed to pay 510 million euros, or about $696.8 million, for Gas Natural Fenosa’s fiber optic network operator in Spain and Latin America.

headline: China Accuses Vietnam of Ramming Ships to Stop Rig
text: China says that Vietnamese ships have rammed Chinese vessels 1,416 times since a dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea flared up in May and that Vietnam has used “frogmen” to attempt to disrupt China’s controversial exploratory drilling operations.

headline: Photographing a ‘Difficult Love’ in South Africa
text: I first encountered the South African photographer Zanele Muholi two winters ago in her native country. I was so shy and in awe of her work that I half-hoped she wouldn’t remember that last encounter. As the foremost chronicler of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa, Ms. Muholi is an artist and activist, advocating for rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people on a continent where they are under attack.

headline: What Are Your Experiences With Internet-Based Urban Legends?
text: Do you know any scary or strange stories that are presented on the Internet as true? Do you believe the stories are real or made-up?

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Borden on Klinsmann as the Coach and Change-Agent of American Soccer
text: Sam Borden, European sports correspondent for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story about the German coach of the U.S. men’s national soccer team, Jürgen Klinsmann.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Ain’t No Sunshine
text: Good dreary Monday morning to you.

headline: Daily Report: Businesses Struggle to Obtain Insurance Against Cyberattacks
text: Julia Roberts’s smile is insured. So are Heidi Klum’s legs, Daniel Craig’s body and Jennifer Lopez’s derrière. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance, Nicole Perlroth and Elizabeth A. Harris report.

headline: In Our Pages: June 10
text: 1939: Sun Sets Fire to Girl’s Hat

headline: Assault on Pakistan Airport Signals Taliban’s Reach and Resilience
text: LONDON — Only a week ago, the Pakistani Taliban appeared to be on the ropes. Violent rivalries had split the insurgency in two. Peace talks with the government had collapsed. Military jets had pounded militant hide-outs in the tribal belt.

headline: Kabul’s City on the Hill
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Just south of the city center is the most famous of Kabul’s many dun-colored mountains. It is called TV Hill, after the telecom and broadcast antennas that crowd its peak like needles in a pincushion. One of the most visible signs of the Western presence in Afghanistan, it is hailed as a symbol of post-Taliban progress.

headline: The Challenges of Enforcing Customer Service Policies
text: A gate agent stopped me recently as I was boarding a flight to Dallas. After inspecting my carry-on bag, she asked me if it would fit.

headline: How to Pay for Only the Health Care You Want
text: One reason health insurance is expensive is that most plans cover just about every medical technology — not just the ones that work, or the ones that are worth the price. This not only drives up costs, but also forces many Americans into purchasing coverage for therapies they may not value. But there’s no reason things couldn’t be different, and better for consumers.

headline: Minimum Wage: Who Makes It?
text: Minimum-wage increases could appear on the ballot in as many as 34 states this year. President Obama has also proposed increasing the federal minimum wage to $10.10, from $7.25. Who makes the minimum wage, and who would be affected by any of the proposed increases?

headline: Prison for 5 in Murder of Journalist
text: MOSCOW — Moscow’s highest criminal court on Monday sentenced five men to prison, including two to life sentences, for the 2006 murder of the investigative journalist Anna Politkovskaya, but left unsolved the question of who ordered the killing, the highest-profile attack on a Russian journalist of the last decade.

headline: Europe’s Age of Diminished Expectations
text: Joe Weisenthal informs us that Spanish bond yields are now about the same as US yields. This is telling us two things, one good, one bad. The good news is that investors no longer have much fear of a euro crackup any time soon. The bad news is that they expect Europe to remain depressed for a long time.

headline: Chinese Ex-General Warns U.S. Over Magazine Article
text: “A reminder to the Americans puffed up with pride and arrogance, making threatening gestures: Do not be ultimately defeated by our lethal trump weapon in your absent-mindedness.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Tyson’s Winning Bid for Hillshire
text: TYSON SAID TO WIN BATTLE FOR HILLSHIRE  |  It appears that Tyson Foods has emerged victorious in the battle for Hillshire Brands, the maker of Ball Park hot dogs and Jimmy Dean sausages, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Hillshire, which is also home to its namesake lunch meats, is expected to declare Tyson the winner of a bidding war, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. The decision will conclude a two-week contest between Tyson and Pilgrim’s Pride, both giants in the poultry industry.

headline: Meanwhile, On the Health Front
text: You still encounter people claiming that Obamacare has been a disaster, that more people have lost insurance than gained it, etc., etc. But the reality is that it has already made a big dent in the number of uninsured; and the quality of insurance has gone up, too, because canceled policies were canceled because they offered little real protection.

headline: Merck Bids $3.8 Billion for an Edge in Hepatitis
text: Updated, 8:32 p.m. | Merck will buy the biotechnology company Idenix Pharmaceuticals for $3.85 billion in an effort to bolster its arsenal of potential drugs in the competitive arena of hepatitis C treatments, the companies announced on Monday.

headline: Disappointed Immigration Applicants Sue Canada
text: Lili Feng and her husband first drew up the plan for their family’s future in March 2010. Their goal, like that of thousands of other wealthy Chinese, was to move via the investor immigration program to Canada, which they believed offered the best combination of public safety and education for their three daughters.

headline: The Shift to Safer Chip-and-PIN Credit Cards
The World According to Renzo
text: Paris is for lovers and New York for dreamers, but when you’re a classy canine accustomed to life’s finer things, getting there can be for the dogs.

headline: From DigiFest to the Tonys, Fashion’s Major Missed Opportunities
text: For an industry that has made something of an art out of leveraging events — from the World Cup to the Super Bowl, the Oscars to Cannes — this weekend was, it seems to me, a shocking lost opportunity for fashion. The industry missed out on both DigiFest NYC, haven of all things young and up-and-coming, and the Tony Awards, the ultimate high-culture draw. In both cases, it was a striking, and arguably shortsighted, absence.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Lee Allan joined Gage, Minneapolis, as the agency’s design director. She succeeds Kenny Friedman, who left to join Flor, Chicago, as executive creative director. Ms. Allan had most recently been creative director at Go East Design, St. Paul.

headline: Q. and A.: Yang Yong on Documenting the Damage to China’s Rivers
text: As a geologist for a state-owned company, Yang Yong saw firsthand both the beauty of China’s rivers and the damage done to them by the country’s rapid development. In 1992, he set out to document the degradation of China’s waterways on his own, and has since widely explored rivers across China, particularly in the south and west of the country. His photographs of the Jinsha River, the Yangtze River’s upper reach, which flows through Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan Provinces, show vividly how that critical waterway has been harmed by the development of mining and hydropower. In an interview, he discussed what led him to this line of research, what his exploration of China’s rivers has revealed and how rapid development affects people living along these waterways.

headline: A Remark in France Is Assailed as Racist
text: PARIS — Activists vowed on Monday to file a criminal complaint against the founder of the far-right National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, after he used an apparently anti-Semitic pun about ovens to dismiss one of his Jewish critics.

headline: No Alarm Before Waters Rose, Say Survivors of Dam Flood
text: On Sunday evening, two busloads of engineering students on a field trip to the hilly northern state of Himachal Pradesh stopped on the national highway between the towns of Shimla and Manali, struck by the beauty of the Beas River, nestled between the hills.

headline: An Ancient Form of Wrestling Fades in Mumbai
text: MUMBAI — At 5 a.m. five days a week, 15 traditional Indian wrestlers, known as pehlwan, meet at Mahatma Phule Akhara, one of the largest gyms dedicated to the sport left in Mumbai.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Turns to Student Debt
text: Good Monday morning from a cloudy Washington.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘metallicity’
text: This poem, by Hannah Llorin, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Science article, “The Archaeology of the Stars.”

headline: At Belize Lodge, Lessons in Coffee and Cocktails
text: Aspiring chocolatiers, baristas and mixologists may find inspiration in Belize this summer.

headline: Foreign Mergers Expand Ranks at Big Law Firms
text: The number of lawyers at the country’s largest law firms rose last year, but the increase was largely because of mergers with foreign firms, not domestic hiring, according to a new survey from The National Law Journal.

headline: Family Dollar Adopts Plan to Keep Carl Icahn at Bay
text: Family Dollar Stores has battened down the hatches days after the activist investor Carl C. Icahn declared the discount chain his latest target.

headline: Understanding Ed O’Bannon’s Suit Against the N.C.A.A.
text: In the court of public opinion, the N.C.A.A. has been on trial for quite some time now.

headline: Analog Devices to Buy Smaller Chip Maker for $2.45 Billion
text: Analog Devices, a chip maker that supplies technology for cars, wind turbines, medical devices, video surveillance and smartphones, has agreed to buy the Hittite Microwave Corporation, a smaller rival, for about $2.45 billion in cash.

headline: Ad Age Campaign Offers a Look at Roads Not Taken
text: A leading advertising trade publication is promoting itself by enlisting some well-known industry executives to suggest the rewards of readership.

headline: The Life-Hack Bias
text: Life hacking — the practice of optimizing one’s home, time and behavior for maximum efficiency — has been a topic of popular discussion for long enough that it now inspires mockery. Witness a recent LinkedIn article that advocates (facetiously, one assumes) the “interesting lifehack” of using a wooden spoon to block areas of one’s computer screen from view. “While it is too early to talk about the long-term effects of the spoon,” writes Joachim Bauernberger, it is “bound to disrupt our relationship with technology as we know it.”

headline: The Nuts and Bolts of Automotive Photography
text: Photographs of cars are easy to take for granted. Every time a new model comes out, it is accompanied by a bombardment of images not unlike the wartime dumping of propaganda leaflets. They’re everywhere.

headline: 15 Crazy Facts About BuzzFeed That Will Totally Blow Your Mind
text: T’s culture issue looks at the numbers behind Jonah Peretti’s empire of cat pics and other click bait. Here, some of the highlights — presented, naturally, in the style of BuzzFeed.

headline: By the Numbers | Thanks for Sharing
text: Even if you’ve never taken its “Which Disney Princess Are You?” quiz or scanned a listicle like “21 Smells ’90s Girls Will Never Forget,” you are likely aware that BuzzFeed is the mother lode of goofy, meme-y click bait. Its nearly 400 daily posts bring in over 130 million unique visitors a month — the kind of traffic coveted by any website, even if the means are often derided. Another enviable asset? BuzzFeed’s $46 million in venture capital. But the eight-year-old site’s founder, the viral-content guru Jonah Peretti, 40, isn’t satisfied with just being the king of workday distractions. With the help of editor in chief Ben Smith, BuzzFeed has been making a play for serious journalism, with political scoops and breaking news stories percolating inside offices named after Internet-famous cats. With its profit margins still a closely guarded secret, it’s hard to know what the payoff will be, but the value is in the clicking.

headline: Lisa Feldman’s Yogurt and White Bean ‘Ranch’ Dressing
text: Lisa Feldman, the director of culinary services atthe schools division of the food services company Sodexo, understands that where there is ranch dressing, there are kids who will eat vegetables. Lisa is working to devise menus for schools that meet or exceed the Department of Agriculture’s Healthier US Schools Challenge requirements. With a deep understanding of the ingredients that school lunch programs have to work with, she developed a white bean and yogurt salad dressing base. The mixture will make a dressing that has much more nutritional value, considerably less sodium, and none of the additives in the long ingredient list on a bottle of commercial ranch dressing.

headline: White Bean and Yogurt Green Goddess
text: I’ve always had a weakness for green goddess dressing. It has that creamy appeal that ranch dressing also has, with the heady flavor and fragrance of fresh tarragon, which is the key to its flavor. The base is modeled on the bean and yogurt salad dressing base that the Sodexo chef Lisa Feldman has introduced to school lunch programs. Serve it as a dip with spring vegetables like artichokes and asparagus or with crispy salads.

headline: Yogurt and Bean Dressing With Thai Flavors
text: This version of Lisa Feldman’s yogurt and bean dressing is based on her slightly sweet Thai ginger dressing. Sriracha sauce, I’ve noticed, has become the go-to condiment for many chefs. It contributes just enough spice and pungency to the mix (you can add more if you want more heat). I like to serve this with grains, and as a dip or a dressing for crispy salads.

headline: Yogurt and Bean Dressing With Cilantro and Lime
text: One of my favorite variations on Lisa Feldman’s bean and yogurt dressing base is her cilantro-lime dressing. Blend cilantro into just about any dressing, purée, sauce or soup, and I’ll be there with a spoon. I use a little more cilantro and lime juice than Lisa calls for, to achieve a pale speckled-green mixture that is slightly zingy; add a small green chile if you want a bit more spice.

headline: Bean and Yogurt Caesar Salad Dressing
text: Lisa Feldman’s bean and yogurt base is a great solution for a creamy Caesar salad dressing if you don’t like the idea of using a raw egg. Parmesan is added to the mix, and I also use an anchovy fillet, which you can omit if you wish. But the anchovy and the Parmesan are what make this resemble a Caesar dressing.

headline: Time Inc. Stock Falls in Its Debut
text: Shares of Time Inc., the magazine company that began trading Monday after being spun off from Time Warner, got off to a rough start, falling nearly 7 percent before recovering somewhat.

headline: Outsmarting Breast Cancer With Evolving Therapies
text: Over the past few decades, changes in the treatment of breast cancer amount to a revolution in patient care. And it’s not over yet. There was a time when the standard approach was a radical mastectomy, which involved removal of not just the breast, but all the lymph nodes in the armpit and underlying muscles in the chest wall. This approach has been replaced by less extensive surgery that, through decades of clinical trials, has proved to be equally effective at treating patients, as well as safer and less disfiguring. Even simple mastectomies, in which most nodes and the muscles were left intact, have become far less common. Dr. J. Dirk Iglehart, director of the Susan F. Smith Center for Women’s Cancers at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, estimated that he now performs a tenth of the number of mastectomies than when he entered the field in the 1970s.

headline: Food Curated | The Mandarin’s Tea Room
text: At the Mandarin’s Tea Room, Timothy Hsu walks tea novices through the ancient Chinese art of tea appreciation.

headline: The Mandarin’s Tea Room
text: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: Photographing a ‘Difficult Love’ in South Africa
text: Zanele Muholi has been an activist using photography to champion the rights of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa.

headline: What a Merged Sprint and T-Mobile Would Look Like
text: With Sprint and T-Mobile having agreed in principle on the terms of a deal that would see the third- and fourth-largest wireless carriers in the United States join forces, eyes are already turning to Washington, where regulators will have to assess whether a combined company would be good for consumers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Should Your Data Be in the Cloud?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: James Reigns, Despite Unrelenting Siege
text: It was a good day to be king, from a sun-drenched clay court at Roland Garros in Paris to a restoratively air-conditioned hard court in San Antonio. About 11 hours apart, Rafael Nadal and LeBron James demonstrated why they are the ruling monarchs of their time and possibly all time.

headline: Ping-Pong Redux
text: Our challenge this week was proposed by Dan Bennett and Avery Pickford, who teach math at The Nueva School near San Francisco. Dan Bennett came up with the idea way back when he was a grade school student, and both Mr. Bennett and Mr. Pickford worked on developing it further for use in their classrooms.

headline: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria Declares ‘General Amnesty’ for Prisoners
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria issued a decree on Monday granting “a general amnesty” for all crimes except “acts of terrorism,” Syrian state television reported, raising tentative hopes among Syrians with relatives in detention.

headline: Russians Find Few Barriers to Joining Ukraine Battle
text: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — It was at a barbecue outside a city in southern Russia, this Russian war veteran recalled, that he and some friends met an envoy for the separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine. They were fighting for their families, the envoy said, against the “neo-Nazis and ultranationalists” who had seized power in Kiev in a February coup.

headline: California Chrome’s Co-Owner Apologizes for His Outbursts
text: Two days after a nationally televised outburst about how fresh horses had deprived horse racing of a Triple Crown champion, Steve Coburn, a co-owner of California Chrome, apologized to those affiliated with the Belmont Stakes winner, Tonalist, and to the horse racing world.

headline: Brazil on Edge as World Cup Exposes Rifts
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s list of feats since ending authoritarian rule in the 1980s is as long as it is varied, including antipoverty programs pulling millions into the middle class, the democratic election of presidents who suffered indignities under the dictatorship and the surging growth of tropical agriculture to help feed the world.

headline: Bang on a Can Teams Up With the Jewish Museum
text: The new-music collective Bang on a Can will begin a yearlong relationship with the Jewish Museum, the museum announced Monday, and neither institution is wasting time getting started.The first concert is a free performance on Tuesday by the Asphalt Orchestra, Bang on a Can’s idiosyncratic marching band, as part of the Museum Mile Festival. The performance, outside the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street, begins at 6 p.m.

headline: Laundry App Start-Up Gets New Financing
text: The venture capital firm Canaan Partners has led a $10.5 million round in Washio, which makes an app for on-demand laundry and dry cleaning services, both companies said on Monday.

headline: How G.M.’s Lawyers Failed in Their Duties
text: In the aftermath of the savings and loan scandal, Judge Stanley Sporkin asked how a once-prominent financial institution could engage in a pattern of misconduct. “Where were the professionals when these clearly improper transactions were being consummated?” he asked.

headline: Image of the Day: June 9
text: A man taking a bath at a railway station in Jammu, Jammu and Kashmir, as a heat wave swept across northern India.

headline: Talk of a Kinks Reunion Heats Up
text: The signals are mixed, but talk of a Kinks reunion, first hinted at in the British press in December, heated up over the weekend when Ray Davies, the group’s singer and principal songwriter, told The Sunday Times of London that he had been discussing the possibility with his brother, Dave Davies. “I met Dave only last week to talk about getting back together again,” he told the paper. Although the two generally composed separately during the Kinks’ heyday, Ray Davies said that he would like to write some new songs with his brother.

headline: Video of Mass Sexual Assault Taints Egypt Inauguration
text: CAIRO — A video showing a mass sexual assault on a nearly naked woman in the midst of inaugural celebrations for Egypt’s new president is testing his pledge to curb an epidemic of such attacks, with captured scenes of a police officer with a gun in his hand struggling against a crowd of men to extricate the victim.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: The Battle at Castle Black
text: Here be spoilers … and the world’s softest anvil.

headline: Entertainment | The Dreamer
text: Richard Linklater had an idea to make a film about boyhood. All it would take was 12 years and a whole lot of thought about the meaning of time.

headline: N.C.A.A. Settles One Video Game Suit for $20 Million as a Second Begins
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The N.C.A.A. has reached a settlement to pay $20 million to current and former college athletes who sued over the use of their likenesses in video games, the league said Monday. The announcement came as a higher-profile video game lawsuit, filed by the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon, began in federal court here.

headline: Detroit Automakers Pledge $26 Million to Help Save City’s Art
text: CHICAGO — The Detroit Institute of Arts announced Monday that the nation’s three major automakers would donate a combined $26 million to help save the city’s art collection, bringing the city a step closer to completing a deal aimed at coming out of bankruptcy by fall.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ricciardo Breaks Through in Formula One
text: Daniel Ricciardo scored his first career victory in Formula One, passing Nico Rosberg with three laps to go in the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal on Sunday. Ricciardo’s win was also the first this season for the Red Bull Infiniti team. His teammate, Sebastian Vettel, the defending series champion, collected third place behind Rosberg.

headline: Audit Shows Extensive Medical Delays for Tens of Thousands of Veterans
text: More than 57,000 patients have been waiting more than three months for medical appointments at hospitals and clinics run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, and nearly 64,000 others have been enrolled in the system for a decade but have still not been seen by doctors despite their requests, according to a nationwide audit released Monday.

headline: Greece Replaces Finance Minister in Cabinet Shuffle
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece on Monday replaced his finance minister as part of a sweeping government shuffle intended to re-energize his coalition after its weak performance in European Parliament elections last month.

headline: How Black Turnout Could Decide Senate Control
text: Black voters will play an outsize role in this year’s fight for control of the Senate. Mississippi, Louisiana and Georgia are the three states where African-Americans represent the largest share of the population, and North Carolina isn’t too far behind, at seventh on the list.

headline: Listen Up | Sofia Coppola’s Music Man Strikes Out on his Own
text: “That’s the ‘Blade Runner synth,'” Brian Reitzell notes, pointing to the hulking ’70s-era Yamaha CS-80 keyboard in a corner of his L.A. recording studio. “And this is the ‘Terry Riley organ,'” he continues, brushing the keys on another vintage Yamaha, the YC-45-D, before moving on to a sleek ’80s-era PPG Wave 2.2. “I remember being 12 years old and playing a chord on this at Guitar Center in San Francisco, and feeling like I was being transported to heaven on Mars,” he says. These three machines are but a few of the vintage instruments crammed into the room where Reitzell – one of today’s pre-eminent film and TV soundtrack composers and music supervisors – creates his evocative scores. “This is only a fraction of the things that I have,” Reitzell adds. “And there’s nothing in here that’s new!”

headline: Driver Charged in Crash Involving Tracy Morgan Had Not Slept in 24 Hours, Prosecutors Say
text: The Walmart driver whose truck collided with a van carrying the comedian Tracy Morgan and other performers had not slept for more than 24 hours before the crash, New Jersey prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: Merger Market Shows Signs of Froth
text: The merger market is showing symptoms of overheating. Global deal volume is up sharply this year – up 63 percent according to Bernstein research and 71 percent by Thomson Reuters’ tally. Monday’s announcements, meanwhile, hint at “toppiness.”

headline: Bobby Jindal’s Bergdahl Questions, Answered
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, one of a long list of Republican politicians who yearn for national office and who grab the national spotlight by pandering to the far right, received applause from fellow Republicans on Friday by attacking President Obama over the decision to trade five Taliban prisoners for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

headline: How Audra McDonald Won Six Tony Awards
text: On Sunday night, Audra McDonald won her sixth Tony Award for acting, more than any other performer. Her achievement is all the more remarkable in that she has worked in just nine Broadway productions since she first appeared in “The Secret Garden” two decades ago.

headline: With ‘Stay Lit,’ Writers Persevere in a Hostile World
text: Writing is scary. It is especially scary now, as advances shrink, publishers fight with Amazon, and the death of the novel is forecast with ever-increasing frequency. It’s a time when it would make a lot of sense to quit — and a time when simply not quitting is becoming its own art form.

headline: Antigovernment Obsession Preceded Las Vegas Shootings
text: LAS VEGAS — Before 6 on Sunday morning, just hours before they killed two police officers and a civilian in a display of antigovernment violence, Jerad and Amanda Miller left their two beloved cats with Kelley Fielder, the next-door neighbor with whom they had been staying. Ms. Miller, 22, promised to return later. Mr. Miller, 31, did not. He gave Ms. Fielder a tearful hug, and said, “I got to do what I got to do.”

headline: Russia and Ukraine Meet on Natural Gas Pricing Dispute
text: BRUSSELS — Russian and Ukrainian officials failed to reach a solution early Tuesday to a dispute over energy that has exacerbated tensions and led to concerns about cutoffs of natural gas to the European Union.

headline: 1972 Grateful Dead Film to Be Screened in Theaters
text: This year’s installment of an annual Meet-Up event for fans of the Grateful Dead will be a big-screen showing of a rare television recording the group made during its European tour in the spring of 1972. Fathom Events and Rhino Entertainment will present “Grateful Dead Meet-Up at the Movies: Beat Club 4/21/72” at more than 360 movie theaters around the country on July 17.

headline: Raw Food Families Provoke Powerful Reactions. Why?
text: In this era of organic, farm-to-table eating, it’s not surprising that raw food diets — that is, meals consisting solely of fresh fruits, vegetables, seeds, nuts and sprouted grains — would gain an ardent following among some families. I wrote about this trend, and children who subsist on entirely raw fare, in Growing Up on Raw Foods for the Well.

headline: Using iPhoto’s Contact Sheet Feature to Save Paper
text: Q. In iPhoto ’11 on OS X Mavericks, is there a way to print certain pictures in an album with their names and dates showing and have it print several photos per page, to save paper?

headline: Malnutrition: Starving Children Lack Crucial Gut Bacteria
text: When children are starving, the bacteria that live in their intestines may determine whether they can be saved, scientists working in Bangladesh are reporting. And they say it may become imperative to find a way to give children bacteria as well as food.

headline: Christie’s Chief of Staff Says He Knew Nothing About Idea to Close Lanes to Bridge
text: The chief of staff for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey testified on Monday that he had no knowledge in September of the decision to close several traffic lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Catfish Whiskers, pH Detectors, Help Track Prey
text: Japanese sea catfish have an unusual advantage when hunting in pitch-dark waters, a new study reports: Their whiskers can detect minute changes in the water’s acidity.

headline: Corruption Claims Cast Cloud on Qatar’s World Cup Bid
text: DOHA, Qatar — As far as the soccer-mad rulers of this wealthy emirate are concerned, the British are just being sore losers and bad sports with all their complaints about corruption, slave labor, an epidemic of worker deaths and, let’s not forget, the extreme heat associated with Qatar’s successful 2022 World Cup bid.

headline: Remixing the Two Dots Soundtrack
text: The makers of the Two Dots game have invited members of the public to remix its theme song.

headline: The Male Disappearing Act
text: “My husband disappeared 18 days ago.”

headline: 5 Sentenced in Russian Journalist Murder
text: Lawyers and the family of Anna Politkovskaya reacted to the court sentencing of five men convicted of killing the Russian journalist in 2006.

headline: Do-Nothing Congress? These Members Did Something (Annual Reports)
text: Public approval of Congress has fallen to record lows. Members have introduced little legislation and passed even less. But a small but growing number of lawmakers have taken to explaining to constituents, in great detail, that they have indeed been doing something.

headline: The Vulnerable Democratic Coalition
text: Responding to my Sunday column, which compared the Democratic Party’s diverse presidential-level majority to fin-de-siecle Austria-Hungary and cast Hillary Clinton as the lone political figure capable of playing Emperor Franz Josef and holding the fractious imperium together, Jonathan Chait tweeted that the argument “needed 3000 words to be remotely persuasive.” Consider this post, then, an attempt to add some of the missing words, with a focus on the Democratic coalition’s potential 2016 weaknesses more than Hillary Clinton’s unique role within the party (which I’ll mention below, but think is mostly self-evident).

headline: Rosetta Getty’s Art-Inspired Sophomore Collection
text: Today, Rosetta Getty will present her sophomore collection to a host of fashion editors at the Chelsea Arts Tower in Manhattan. It’s fitting that the designer chose the art gallery condominium to set the scene for her resort 2015 outing: this season, like last, she sourced inspiration from one artist and one artistic muse. The personal style of Betty Parsons — the gallerist, artist and proponent of the Abstract Expressionist movement — infuses the set of sensible and effortless separates. And the palette of Jackson Pollock — specifically, his “Mural” painting, originally commissioned by Peggy Guggenheim in 1943 — informed Getty’s mostly chartreuse, black and white color choices for the season. Even Pollock’s relaxed, fluid brush strokes come into play in the L.A.-based designer’s laid-back silhouettes.

headline: Next-Best Thing to Living Next Door to Your Idol
text: During a break in a concert in the Bronx, Victor Goines, a jazz saxophonist and clarinetist, realized that he wanted to spend more time in that very place — a lot more time. Being there would put him close to people he idolized, like Duke Ellington, so he decided to spend $25,000 to buy the land behind the stage.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 3-June 9, 2014
text: How many of the news stories below did you follow this week? How well can you do against others taking the quiz?

headline: Back Home, Rangers Seem Lost
text: The Rangers played their first home game in the Stanley Cup finals in two decades, but the magic of 1994 did not fill Madison Square Garden on Monday night. Mark Messier sent encouraging words before the game, but there was no Messier on the ice, no Mike Richter in the nets, no Brian Leetch bursting down the ice on a rush.

headline: Psy Teams Up With Snoop for ‘Hangover’ Video
text: Can viral media success be engineered? Good question.

headline: More on Kristof, Bergdahl and Risen
text: Here are some developments or commentary on three subjects I took up last week:

headline: Killing a Patient to Save His Life
text: PITTSBURGH — Trauma patients arriving at an emergency room here after sustaining a gunshot or knife wound may find themselves enrolled in a startling medical experiment.

headline: Cambodia’s Beating Heart, Draining Blood to Save a Patient, Witch-Hunts and Child Abuse
text: Tonle Sap, a lake that pulses through southeast Asia, could be saved by a computer model; E.R. doctors in Pittsburgh plan to treat a dying patient by replacing blood with saline; Emily Bazelon reviews “The Witch-Hunt Narrative” by Ross E. Cheit, which challenges the common wisdom surrounding child abuse.

headline: A Possible Way to Save a Disappearing Leonardo
text: A new technique for tracking paper degradation could help save a fading Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece from the early 1500s.

headline: Spiders’ Webs Hum With Information
text: Like strings on a guitar, spider silks can vibrate along a wide range of frequencies, transmitting information about prey, other spiders and even the condition of the web itself, researchers say.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
text: 1 QUIET by Susan Cain. Crown. Introverts — one-third of the population — are undervalued in American society. (1)

headline: Riddle by Riddle, a Murder Confession Unspools
text: The news from college friends tends to be the stuff of weddings, children and jobs. In “The Antiquarian,” the delightfully macabre first novel by the Peruvian writer Gustavo Faverón Patriau, the narrator, Gustavo, receives a rather more alarming update: His closest friend from his university days, Daniel, has murdered his fiancée, Juliana, by stabbing her 36 times, attempting to burn her body and leaving her in the trunk of his car while trying to kill himself with a gunshot to the head. He fails and lands in a psychiatric ward.

headline: Proposal to Split Netflix’s Chairman and C.E.O. Roles Fails
text: New York City Comptroller Scott M. Stringer had hoped that huge support for a proposal last year to split Netflix‘s chairman and chief executive roles would have carried over to this year’s shareholder election.

headline: Making the Best Iced Latte
text: The secret to the iced latte served at Go Get Em Tiger and G&B Coffee in Los Angeles, one of the finest coffee drinks in the country: homemade almond-macadamia milk.

headline: 6 Innovative Iced Coffees
text: Maybe it’s the heat, but coffee professionals who never put sugar in their espresso and believe milk is for cereal will loosen up when it comes to summer drinks. Here, in no particular order, are six iced coffees (actually, five iced coffees and one from a chilled keg) that are inventive, refreshing and delicious.

headline: The Best Iced Latte in America?
text: LOS ANGELES — If coffee were a religion, Charles Babinski and Kyle Glanville would be two of its high priests.

headline: Ask Well: Do Monogamous Women Still Need a Pap Smear?
text: Question:

headline: American Held in North Korea Described as Family Man
text: An Ohio municipal worker seized by the authorities in North Korea while he was visiting on a tourist visa last month was described by his lawyer on Monday as an avid traveler, devoted husband and father to three young children, who was anxiously missed by his family.

headline: At E3 Gaming Convention, Microsoft Shifts Emphasis of Xbox One Console to Games
text: LOS ANGELES — The latest video game consoles can play Internet radio, Netflix movies and YouTube video clips. But Sony and Microsoft, gearing up for a blistering battle in retail stores this holiday season, are reassuring consumers that their consoles are very much about games, too.

headline: G.M. Suits Will Proceed as One Case in New York
text: A panel of federal judges handed General Motors a modest but meaningful victory on Monday, consolidating the pretrial phase of more than 80 lawsuits against the company into a single proceeding in Manhattan — the venue sought by the automaker.

headline: ‘All the Way’ and ‘Of Mice and Men’ Recoup on Broadway
text: Two plays that brought Hollywood star power to Broadway this season have recouped their initial investments.

headline: Podcast: Witch-Hunts and Child Abuse
text: Emily Bazelon talks about “The Witch-Hunt Narrative” by Ross E. Cheit, which challenges the common wisdom surrounding child abuse.

headline: 2nd China Army Unit Implicated in Online Spying
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The email attachment looked like a brochure for a yoga studio in Toulouse, France, the center of the European aerospace industry. But once it was opened, it allowed hackers to sidestep their victim’s network security and steal closely guarded satellite technology.

headline: Summer X Games Style
text: The annual sports event held in Austin, Tex., drew a crowd with eclectic style.

headline: McCartney, Citing Doctors’ Advice, Postpones Start of American Tour
text: Paul McCartney, having canceled his tour dates in Japan and South Korea last month because of illness, has now postponed the first seven dates of the American leg of his “Out There” tour, his spokesman announced Monday.

headline: Chrysler and Honda Issue Recalls
text: Chrysler is recalling almost 24,000 vehicles in two actions for problems with the electrical and cruise control systems, and Honda is recalling about 1,000 of its 2013 Fit compact cars because a drive shaft could break.

headline: Abuse Cases, and a Legacy of Skepticism

headline: With Credibility on Line, World Cup Turns to Technology
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The man from the goal-line-technology company left no margin for error, which was probably a good thing given his line of work.

headline: Revolving Doors at Hospitals
text: Everyone on the ward fell hard for the patient in the room at the end of the hall. Her roommate was loud, demanding and a complete nuisance — nobody spent more time in that part of the room than was absolutely necessary. But the gently smiling, impeccably mannered little 90-year-old, admitted to the window bed with a touch of pneumonia, was a big favorite.

headline: Handwriting Loses Ground, Healing Tattoos, Telescopic Legacies
