headline: Leaving Searchlight Behind, Reid Is Moving to Las Vegas
text: For decades, Searchlight, Nev., has been synonymous with Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic leader whose birthplace has fueled scores of elegiac floor speeches, campaign events and even a book, “The Camp That Didn’t Fail,” a history of the tiny mining town where he was raised.

headline: Cocktail Culture | One Negroni for Every Month of the Year
text: For the fourth annual Negroni Social at the Rooster Bar at the rustic Italian restaurant Nostrana in Portland, Ore., the chef Cathy Whims recruited 11 of her female chef friends to contribute riffs on the quintessentially Italian cocktail. “I don’t know a chef that doesn’t adore a perfect Negroni,” explained Whims about her decision to recruit talent from the kitchen side of the house to dream up cocktail recipes. “As an aperitivo, the Negroni opens up your palate, kick-starts your digestion and prepares you for the meal ahead of you. It actually makes you think about all the flavors your are experiencing, and I think that’s part of why it lends itself to being so relevant to chefs developing their own versions.”

headline: Scene City: After the Tony Awards, the Partying Begins
text: Broadway’s big night goes on till morning, at various after-parties.

headline: Police and Witnesses on Las Vegas Ambush
text: The Las Vegas police and witnesses described the rampage in which a married couple fatally shot three people before killing themselves.

headline: If Virginia Doesn’t Expand Medicaid, Blame This Guy
text: Considering what residents of New York have been through in recent decades, they might have thought no other state (except maybe Illinois) could outdo them in cynicism about their state government. In Albany in 2009, for example, a politician now on trial for bribery (Malcolm Smith) was briefly deposed as Senate president by two other senators who were later convicted of crimes (Hiram Monserrate and Pedro Espada Jr.) as party control of the chamber hung in the balance.

headline: Governors Ball Festival Style

headline: Neko Case at Governors Ball Music Festival 2014
text: Looking for this season’s “festival style”? It’s not only festivalgoers who experiment; some of this summer’s best looks can be seen on stage. Neko Case, who performed at last weekend’s Governors Ball on Randalls Island, explained her style inspiration.

headline: Rethinking the Colorful Kindergarten Classroom
text: Imagine a kindergarten classroom. Picture the vividly colored scalloped borders on the walls, the dancing letters, maybe some charming cartoon barnyard animals holding up “Welcome to School!” signs.

headline: Strong Senate Polls in Iowa and Georgia Give G.O.P. Slight Lead
text: For the moment, the Republicans appear to have the slightest edge in the fight for control of the Senate.

headline: A Closer Connection for Smartphone Games and Soundtracks
text: Mobile phone games have come a long way since the late 1990s. Back then, the No.1 game — and maybe the only game on a device — was the ultrabasic monochrome maze puzzle, Snake.

headline: In Sports, It’s a Marathon, With Sprints in Between
text: Benjamin Hoffman has designed Times sports pages since 2004. Here, he talks about the unique challenge of producing the Sunday section, using this past weekend’s as an example.Deadlines were blown, tempers flared and compromises were made.

headline: A Reporter Fits Cancer Into Her Busy Schedule
text: Purveyors of pop culture have a way of discovering a subject simultaneously. This is apparently the moment for the realization that young people can get cancer just like older ones. The top film at the box office over the weekend was “The Fault in Our Stars,” a weeper about two teenagers with cancer, and on Tuesday night ABC Family introduces “Chasing Life.”

headline: Detroit Sends Hedge Fund Manager and His Goats Packing

text: Photos from Pakistan, Brazil, Yemen and Afghanistan.

headline: Disparate Lives That Intersect
text: The emotional weather is as volatile as the changeable skies in “When January Feels Like Summer,” an engaging, buoyantly acted romantic comedy by Cori Thomas at Ensemble Studio Theater. In Ms. Thomas’s sweet-tempered play, the lives of a handful of problem-plagued New Yorkers intersect in surprising but satisfying ways, leading to unexpected alliances.

headline: Of Fish, Monsoons and the Future
text: AKOL, CAMBODIA — As the sun rises on Tonle Sap Lake, fishermen head out from floating villages like this one, past half-submerged mangroves and flooded shrub land, to check their nets, much as they have for centuries.

headline: Cambodia’s Declining Catch
text: The Tonle Sap, one of the world’s most productive freshwater ecosystems, is in trouble. A group of researchers is working with local fishermen to figure out how to save it.

headline: Academy Museum Struggling to Recover
text: Maybe only in a city as art-packed as New York could a place like the National Academy, whose Beaux-Arts mansion rises on Fifth Avenue right next door to the Guggenheim Museum, seem as modest and obscure as it does.

headline: GoDaddy to Tap Public Markets With I.P.O.
text: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | GoDaddy, the domain name registration giant, plans to sell its shares to investors in an initial public offering.

headline: A Boy and Girl Meet Face to Face, Even When They’re Not in the Same Room
text: “Blink” is everything you want in a relationship play: funny, painful, affecting. This is all the more remarkable when you consider that its two characters, young social misfits named Sophie (Lizzy Watts) and Jonah (Thomas Pickles), rarely address each other. It’s a risky mode of storytelling, but the playwright, Phil Porter, makes it pay off beautifully.

headline: Seeing Obstacle-Filled Path to Mars
text: Since the triumph of the moon landings more than four decades ago, presidents have made grand pronouncements about the next adventure for NASA astronauts, one that would culminate with humans on Mars. But each time, those ambitions faded, unfulfilled.

headline: The Governors Ball Music Festival 2014
text: Scenes from the New York Governors Ball photo diary of Aurelie Pellissier.

headline: Taking Her Tony Home
text: Jessie Mueller never expected to outgrow the Chicago theater scene. She grew up in a family of actors in Evanston, Ill., and loved nothing more than watching her parents dress up for local awards banquets when they were nominees. She went on to win acclaim there for roles in “Carousel” and “She Loves Me,” once even borrowing a dress for a prize ceremony that her mother had worn years earlier.

headline: A Festival With a New York Heart
text: Every well-planned festival holds a skein of tangled story lines. This year’s Governors Ball — the fourth annual event, presented Friday through Sunday with 68 acts on four stages on Randalls Island — was, first of all, about hometown New York City pride. It had a headlining set on Sunday by Vampire Weekend and a much-anticipated, fully rewarding set on Saturday by the Strokes, as well as a lineup dotted with other New York City bands, notably a recharged TV on the Radio.

headline: The Slow Lane
text: Q. Why do medicines with codeine tend to cause constipation?

headline: Future Fossils: Plastic Stone
text: Plastic first became widespread in the mid-20th century. Since then, about six billion tons have been manufactured. Much of that has ended up as trash, and nobody knows what will become of it.

headline: Outrage at ‘Epidemic’ of Sexual Assault in Egypt
text: Women’s rights activists in Egypt were outraged Monday after video was posted online that appeared to show a brutal sexual assault in Tahrir Square in Cairo during celebrations of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s election victory.

headline: And Even More on Climate Change
text: Last week, the big news was that the Obama administration had unveiled a new Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon emissions from United States power plants 30 percent by 2030.

headline: A Veteran Becomes a Rookie
text: In his nearly three months as team president, Phil Jackson has made it very apparent — in word and deed — that he wants to rebuild the Knicks by relying on his own network of associates and alliances. He has gone so far as to underscore the importance of his “inner circle,” although it might make more sense to refer to his inner triangle.

headline: A Photographer’s Summer of Luck in San Francisco
text: Fifty years ago, San Francisco was the setting for cultural and political upheaval. And Arthur Tress was the lucky young photographer who captured it.

text: The British capital is staking a claim as a global leader for financial technology start-ups.

headline: An Unlikely Friendship
text: Social scientists tell us that soldiers fight for one another more than for any other reason. Defending your unit has been shown to exceed a willingness to die for family, cause or country, and even the fear of capture. Yet unit cohesion in battle is a tricky thing to measure, let alone compare.

headline: European Leaders Face Voter Impatience After Elections
text: BERLIN — If there is one thing her admirers and detractors agree upon, it is that Chancellor Angela Merkel moves deftly, and in these past few years of European crisis stuck stubbornly to policies despite dire predictions that they could lead to the end of the shared currency, the euro.

headline: Does Royalty Still Have a Meaningful Role?

headline: Rik Mayall, British Alternative Comic, Dies at 56
text: Rik Mayall, an actor, comedian and writer whose work on “The Young Ones” and other television series helped define alternative comedy in Britain in the 1980s, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 56.

headline: Turns Out That Guy in the Painting Really Is Rembrandt, Analysts Say
text: LONDON — After months of cleaning and painstaking scientific investigation, art specialists in Britain have apparently concluded a decadeslong debate over the authenticity of a self-portrait by Rembrandt, saying on Tuesday that it was genuine.

headline: A Quiet Cheer for Solitude
text: See Hillary run.

headline: Facts Are Murky on Location of Dead Babies in Ireland
text: TUAM, Ireland — That 796 children, mainly babies, died at St. Mary’s Mother and Baby Home between 1925 and its closing in 1961 is not disputed. A local historian, Catherine Corless, says she researched the death certificates. What troubled her was that she could find burial records for only one child and wanted a plaque to commemorate the lives of the others.

headline: More Airports Adopt Free Wi-Fi
text: ATLANTA — Steve Parker, sitting in the atrium at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport last week, was about to dig into his bag for a hot spot device when he noticed a poster nearby.

headline: Controlling the Narrative
text: I used to be a polemicist. I was an editorial cartoonist, and wrote what I called “artist’s statements” to accompany my cartoons each week, which over the two terms of the George W. Bush administration lengthened and sharpened from rants into something more like essays. I became practiced at using language as a weapon. My role models were hilarious, elegant and brutal humorists from Mark Twain and H.L. Mencken through Hunter S. Thompson and Matt Taibbi, who raised American invective to an art form. This is a fine and honorable tradition when practiced with a certain amour-propre and panache, but in the last couple of decades it’s become our dominant mode of public discourse, degraded by hacks and amateurs who ape its cruelty but are rhetorically illiterate and tone-deaf to humor. They’re just parroting talking points with profanity.

headline: Obama on Helping Students Pay Off Loans
text: The president announced three actions to help young Americans pay off their student loan debt.

headline: Obama, Noting Own Student Debt Burden, Expands Repayment Cap and Pushes Bill
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Monday intended to lessen the college loan burden on nearly five million younger Americans by capping repayments at 10 percent of the borrowers’ monthly income.

headline: Children ‘Aged Out’ of Immigration System Won’t Get Special Priority, Justices Rule
text: A divided Supreme Court ruled on Monday that children of immigrants who lost their places in the slow-moving immigration system because they turned 21 before their parents received their immigrant visa could not be given special priority.

headline: Seeking to Renew Balance in a Site’s Dual History
text: CÓRDOBA, Spain — The Mosque-Cathedral of Córdoba, considered one of the world’s architectural wonders, is often portrayed as a symbol of coexistence between Muslims and Catholics.

headline: Introduced to Monty Python, on the Concorde
text: MY parents made the mistake of getting me a Eurail pass when I was 19 years old. I haven’t stopped traveling since. I’ve been flying for work for about 40 years. I’m an attorney, specializing in protecting trademarks and designs and ideas. That means I have to meet with my clients face to face.

headline: Competition Is Stiff to Manage Tech Billions
text: When Microsoft went public in 1986, its chief executive and largest shareholder, Bill Gates, wound up with a broker at Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street firm that had led the company’s initial public offering.

headline: North Korea: U.N. Attracts Threats for Plan to Monitor Human Rights
text: North Korea on Monday threatened “ruthless punishment” against South Korea for playing host to a United Nations office that will monitor the human rights situation in the North. In May, South Korea accepted a request from the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights to open a field office in Seoul. On Monday, North Korea said that raising a “racket” over a “nonexistent human rights issue” was a politically motivated campaign to defame its government. It said the United Nations office and its staff would “not be excepted from being targets” of its punishment. In March, a panel of United Nations investigators published a report documenting what it called systematic and widespread human rights violations against political prisoners and others in the North. The United Nations has said it hopes that a field office in South Korea, where a large number of North Korean refugees have settled, will aid its investigation of human rights abuses in the North.

headline: Making Holidays of Brazil’s World Cup Games
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — To work or not to work? Regardless of where anyone here stands on the logic of Brazil’s spending billions of dollars in preparation for hosting this year’s World Cup, the question as opening day approaches is hugely pertinent.

headline: Israel: General Has Hopeful View About the Nuclear Talks With Iran
text: As Iran and the United States began two days of talks in Geneva on Monday to advance the stalled negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear activities, a top Israeli intelligence official said he believed that Iran was serious about ensuring the success of the negotiations. The assessment of the official, Brig. Gen. Itai Brun, the chief analyst of Israeli military intelligence, appeared more optimistic than that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who has persistently warned against what he has called a bad nuclear deal with Iran. General Brun, speaking at Israel’s annual Herzliya Conference on policy and security, said that Iran was abiding by a temporary agreement with major powers, and that economic pressures on the country “are leading it toward a dialogue, which we view as serious, on a permanent agreement.” The temporary accord expires on July 20, and diplomats have said significant obstacles remain in achieving a permanent agreement to guarantee that Iran’s nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.

headline: T.S.A. Charts a Rise in Guns at Checkpoints
text: LOTS more of our fellow travelers are packing for the airport, so to speak. So far this year (as of the end of last week), the Transportation Security Administration has found 892 guns in passengers’ carry-on bags at security checkpoints. That’s a 19 percent increase from the comparable period of last year, when the total was 750 guns.

headline: Argentina: Vice President in Court for Questioning in Corruption Case
text: A simmering political scandal took a dramatic turn on Monday when a judge forced Vice President Amado Boudou to appear in a Buenos Aires court to answer questions about whether he had used his influence as economy minister to take ownership of a company that printed the nation’s currency. Mr. Boudou, 51, is accused of using a frontman to purchase shares in the printing company, which was awarded a government contract and later nationalized. He has denied the allegations and has accused news organizations of conspiring against him. The judge, Ariel Lijo, rejected Mr. Boudou’s call for the session to be broadcast live on television. The judge is expected to announce his decision later this month on whether to file criminal charges against Mr. Boudou.

headline: Time Warner Said to Seek a Big Stake in Vice Media
text: Time Warner is in talks to buy a large stake in Vice Media for as much as $1 billion, a deal that could include providing Vice with the television network HLN, people with knowledge of the negotiations said on Monday.

headline: Pope Francis Meets With Peres and Abbas
text: Pope Francis, the Israeli president Shimon Peres and the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas spoke after a peace prayer meeting in the Vatican gardens.

headline: A Museum Devoted to Movies Is Still Writing Its Own Script
text: LOS ANGELES — In the dim light of a gutted department store, through the dust of nearby construction, Kerry Brougher sees a flickering movie future filled with “hundreds of different cinemas.” For tiny screens. Vast ones. Theaters yet to be conceived.

headline: After a Short, Furious Battle, a Rich Offer for Hillshire
text: Just over three weeks ago, Hillshire Brands was focusing on shoring up support for its planned takeover of Pinnacle Foods despite vocal shareholder opposition.

headline: Progress on Transgender Rights and Health
text: Progress on civil rights typically comes in incremental steps that discard old policies for new approaches advancing fair treatment. The Obama administration recently took such a step by reversing a 1981 policy that excluded gender reassignment surgery from coverage under Medicare.

headline: Mona Freeman, First ‘Miss Subways,’ Dies at 87
text: Mona Freeman, who had never ridden a subway when she was crowned New York City’s first Miss Subways in 1941 — an appointment that led to a modest career as a film and television actress — died on May 23 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 87.

headline: Pakistan’s Latest Crisis
text: In its increasingly violent effort to destroy the Pakistani state, the Pakistani Taliban have attacked, among other targets, army headquarters in Rawalpindi, a naval base in Karachi, an air base in Kamra and an airport in Peshawar. The brazen assault over the weekend on the international airport in Karachi takes the campaign to a new level, striking at the country’s largest city and one of its most important commercial centers. Though militants and gangs operate freely there, Karachi is home to Pakistan’s central bank, a stock exchange and its hopes for desperately needed economic resurgence.

headline: Peres, at 90, Is Ready to Leave the Israeli Presidency, but Not to Retire
text: ROME — Reaching the end of a red carpet after landing here for the latest of his more than 60 trips abroad as Israel’s president, Shimon Peres faced the group of journalists awaiting him.

headline: More Voting Games in Ohio
text: Someday, after they figure out how to appeal to a broader swath of the electorate, Republicans will probably be embarrassed by how much time they have spent making it harder for Americans to vote. For now, though, the beat just goes on. In a misguided effort to hold on to power despite an ever-shrinking base of older white voters, Republican lawmakers around the country continue to impose all sorts of barriers to the ballot box.

headline: Why Uber Might Well Be Worth $18 Billion
text: It was described as “nuts,” “insane” and “idiocy.”

headline: The New Right
text: Conservatives generally believe that capitalism is a machine that cures itself. Therefore, people on the right have been slow to recognize the deep structural problems that are making life harder in the new economy — that are leading to stagnant social mobility, widening inequality and pervasive insecurity.

headline: Walmart Reorganizes E-commerce Personnel
text: Walmart announced two high-level changes to its e-commerce team on Monday, as it pushes to ramp up its online business and compete with its archrival Amazon.

headline: Battle Over Fracking Poses Threat to Colorado Democrats
text: DENVER — An impassioned national debate over the oil-production technique known as fracking is edging toward the ballot box in Colorado, opening an election-year rift between moderate, energy-friendly Democrats and environmentalists who want to rein in drilling or give local communities the power to outlaw it altogether.

headline: As World Cup Nears, American ‘Football’ Fans Adapt Foreign Traditions
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Even if the fans known as the American Outlaws had not been clumped noisily together at one end of the stadium at the United States-Nigeria soccer match here Saturday, they would have been impossible to miss.

headline: The Latest Tea Party Piñata
text: About three weeks ago, Representative Jeb Hensarling, a Republican from Texas who is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, gave a speech to the Heritage Foundation. Hensarling is a Tea Party favorite. His core view is that better government is less government, and that there is nothing government can do that the private sector can’t do better.

headline: Does Soccer Need FIFA?
text: How can the world's most popular sport avoid the traps of corruption?

headline: Cup Chase Puts Gaborik Back on the Garden’s Ice
text: Marian Gaborik is a man of few words and many goals.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 9, 2014
text: June 9, 2014

headline: Frick Seeks to Expand Beyond Jewel-Box Spaces
text: Joining a trend toward major expansions, the Frick Collection, known for its intimate, jewel-box galleries, will announce on Tuesday plans for a new six-story wing that will increase its exhibition space, open private upstairs rooms, and offer views of Central Park from a new roof garden on East 70th Street.

headline: In Britain, School Report Cites Division Over Islam
text: LONDON — A report released on Monday concluded that pressure from fundamentalist Islamic school board governors had created a culture of “fear and intimidation” among senior staff members in a number of British schools said to have been the targets of a campaign to impose Islamist views on parts of the educational system.

headline: Plan to Refill Highway Fund Stokes Conflict in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — With federal highway funds just weeks from depletion, the struggle to replenish the Highway Trust Fund has linked Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, the majority leader, with one of the Republicans’ brightest stars, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky — and pushed against the bipartisan leadership of the Finance Committee — with the clock ticking.

headline: For Western Oil Companies, Expanding in Russia Is a Dance Around Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — Like many chief executives of American companies, Rex W. Tillerson of Exxon Mobil didn’t attend the major business forum in Russia last month, at the urging of White House officials. But the company’s exploration chief, Neil W. Duffin, did.

headline: Stuyvesant Town, Former Middle-Class Bastion, Awaits Mayoral Help
text: To discover a vaguely affordable apartment in Manhattan is like falling down a fire escape into a bed of clover.

headline: Scant Support for Elite New York High Schools’ Admissions Options
text: Civil rights advocates have long complained about the relatively small number of black and Hispanic students in New York City’s most selective high schools. Mayor Bill de Blasio, during his campaign last year, complained about it, too.

headline: Plan B Eased Clippers Deal: Sterling’s Diagnosis
text: LOS ANGELES — At 7 on a Saturday morning, four weeks after her life had erupted in scandal, Rochelle Sterling was awakened by a ringing phone.

headline: Secretive Classroom Activity
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Pamela Klawitter has a theme that originally confused me, but it turned out to be a lot simpler and more elegant in execution than I thought, mainly because I am the queen of overthinking things. Not only that, but Ms. Klawitter’s theme takes advantage of one of the meaner tricks in crossword constructing, which actually made the “Aha!” moment even more fun than usual.

headline: Supreme Court Rules in Favor of Electronics Plant in Poisoned Water Case
text: WASHINGTON — Landowners who say a North Carolina electronics plant poisoned their drinking water missed a filing deadline, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

headline: Democrats See Winning Issue in Carbon Plan
text: WASHINGTON — He is a Democrat in a marquee Senate race, pressed by a strong Republican in a state with a challenging political environment. So when a new proposal to limit power plant emissions was seen as posing a threat to allies of the Obama administration, Senator Mark Udall of Colorado acted quickly: He embraced the plan.

headline: Facebook Hires From PayPal to Focus on Messaging
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It couldn’t be any plainer if it were in a post by Mark Zuckerberg himself: Facebook, which was built on the idea that people want to share information with dozens of friends and acquaintances, is getting serious about more private communications.

headline: Colleges and Evangelicals Collide on Bias Policy
text: BRUNSWICK, Me. — For 40 years, evangelicals at Bowdoin College have gathered periodically to study the Bible together, to pray and to worship. They are a tiny minority on the liberal arts college campus, but they have been a part of the school’s community, gathering in the chapel, the dining center, the dorms.

headline: For Virginia’s Don Beyer, Obama Is Still a Positive
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — In an election season when many congressional Democrats are avoiding President Obama as if he were a quirky relative at a family reunion, Don Beyer has cast himself as an unrepentant advocate.

headline: Tapes in State Senator’s Trial Reveal Quid Pro Quo Arrangements
text: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — State Senator Malcolm A. Smith had a Plan A and a Plan B.

headline: Selling With Nostalgia, Post-Boomer
text: NOSTALGIA, according to the saying, isn’t what it used to be. That is increasingly true on Madison Avenue, as advertisers — seeking to evoke warm feelings and fond memories in consumers — adjust the timelines for how far they look back.

headline: Mickelson Takes Heart in a Change of Course
text: Two missed eight-foot putts, a drive into the left rough that created a double bogey, a 6-iron plunked into a greenside bunker and three putts from five feet above the cup for a double bogey, another drive off a hospitality tent followed by a 3-iron into a tree branch and a double bogey, two 3-wood tee shots into thick, heavy rough that led to two double bogeys, untimely three-putts and a missed green with a wedge on a 121-yard hole.

headline: The Captain Is in the House, but It’s Not 1994
text: At the airport gate Monday, there was a man wearing a pilot’s hat and a blue No. 11 Rangers jersey who was boarding passengers and playing air hockey and posing for iPhone photographs, oh, please, just one more. His head was shaved like Mark Messier’s, and he sounded like Mark Messier and he squinted when he smiled just like Mark Messier — wait, it really was him, wasn’t it?

headline: State Senator’s Resignation Deepens Political Turmoil in Virginia
text: The resignation of a Democratic state senator in Virginia that flipped control of the Senate to Republicans set off charges on Monday of an unseemly deal and threatened Gov. Terry McAuliffe’s chances of expanding Medicaid under the president’s health care law.

headline: Tanaka’s Matchup Against Ex-Teammate Falls Through
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Masahiro Tanaka could not have known it when he boarded his flight to Seattle on Monday afternoon: His pitching matchup on Tuesday night with Hisashi Iwakuma, his former teammate with Tohoku Rakuten in Japan’s Pacific League, was not going to happen.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 3
text: Momentum is possibly one of the most coveted commodities entering a major tournament like the World Cup — that and a healthy roster.

headline: At Junior’s Site, Bidders See Brooklyn, Too, as a City of Spires
text: Strolling the bluffs of Brooklyn Heights in the 1850s, Walt Whitman would gaze out at the metropolis growing across the river.

headline: Border Agency Replaces Head of Internal Affairs
text: The federal Customs and Border Protection agency has replaced its top official in charge of internal affairs, James F. Tomsheck, citing an effort to strengthen investigations, particularly into episodes involving shootings and other use of force by border agents.

headline: Mets’ Murphy Discusses Fatherhood at White House Meeting
text: Mets second baseman Daniel Murphy, who earlier this year was criticized on New York sports talk radio for going on paternity leave, spoke about being a father at the White House on Monday as part of the Working Families Summit.

headline: New Safety Standards Set for Baby Food
text: The Food and Drug Administration announced Monday that it had set new safety standards for infant formula. The rules require manufacturers to screen products for salmonella, which can cause fever and diarrhea, and cronobacter, a potentially lethal germ that thrives in very dry places, like powdered milk and baby formula. The F.D.A. said that companies must also test products for nutrient content and demonstrate that they support “normal physical growth.”

headline: Oklahoma: Another Base to House Young Immigrants
text: Immigration and health authorities will open a shelter at Fort Sill, an Army base in Lawton, for unaccompanied minors caught crossing the southwest border illegally, Obama administration officials said Monday. About 600 youths will be sent there in the coming days, with the number expected to grow to 1,200. About 1,200 minors who were apprehended without parents are in a shelter at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, and 575 are at Naval Base Ventura County near Oxnard, Calif. The authorities also set up temporary holding cells in Nogales, Ariz., to process the youths for deportation proceedings.

headline: Myles J. Ambrose, Nixon Drug Czar, D.E.A. Midwife, Dies at 87
text: Myles J. Ambrose, who was President Richard M. Nixon’s first drug czar, but who resigned before he could take the helm of the new government arm he had helped shepherd into being, the Drug Enforcement Administration, died on June 3 in Leesburg, Va. He was 87.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 10, 2014
text: “People are worried about how much has been spent. But once we see the first game, the parties will start.”

headline: Answering Readers’ Questions About Immigration
text: As Americans continue to debate border security, deportation policies and the possible path to citizenship for people living in the country illegally, the Obama administration is facing a political crossroads as it tries to cope with an immigration system that is overwhelmed.

headline: USA Hockey Permits Use of Safety Feature Resembling Warning Track
text: USA Hockey, the sport’s governing body in the United States, announced Monday that it had permitted use of the Look-Up Line, an orange warning track painted on the ice designed to reduce paralyzing neck injuries that could result from collisions into the boards. However, the measure fell short of mandating its use in American ice rinks.

headline: U.S. Team Hits Practice Field Soon After Touching Down in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The United States national team arrived in Brazil early Monday morning, and the players were on the field for their first training session by that afternoon. If that seems like a quick turnaround after a 12-hour, two-leg, overnight travel itinerary that began in Jacksonville, Fla., consider that Tim Howard, the starting goalkeeper, actually was surprised at how long it took for the team to get to work. “With Jurgen, I’m surprised we weren’t out here earlier,” Howard said.

headline: I Am Someone, Look at Me
text: Hailed as the 21st century’s answer to Proust for his controversial six-volume autobiographical work, “My Struggle,” Karl Ove Knausgaard responds to his sudden celebrity with this essay on his tortured relationship with fame — its intense lure, its perils and the Scandinavian culture that condemns its pursuit. Translated by Ingvild Burkey.

headline: On One Kings Lane, a Trove of Treasures from Venice Curated by Fortuny
text: Design enthusiasts who weren’t fortunate enough to visit Venice this week for the opening of the Architecture Biennale (and might be suffering from a touch of Instagram envy), can at least fake the experience via an upcoming sale on One Kings Lane. Mickey and Maury Riad, the two brothers who run the century-old Venetian textile house Fortuny, were invited by the site to shop the town’s various islands to assemble a massive home-accessories sale of over 200 items, which begins tomorrow. A tag sale of the brothers’ own personal collection will also debut on the same day.

headline: Raf & Ruby
text: At the top of their creative fields, the fashion designer Raf Simons and the artist Sterling Ruby have succeeded at something almost more elusive and unexpected: a true, collaborative brotherhood.

headline: Google Adds Graffiti to Its Art Portfolio
text: PARIS — There’s a portrait of an anonymous Chinese man chiseled into a wall in Shanghai, a colorful mural in Atlanta and black-and-white photographs of eyes that the French artist JR affixed to the houses of a hillside favela in Rio de Janeiro. These are among the images of more than 4,000 works included in a vast new online gallery of street art that Google is unveiling here on Tuesday.

headline: Poll Shows Path to Citizenship Is Favored
text: While 62 percent of Americans favor a path to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally, Republican voters are sharply split on the issue going into the November elections, according to a nationwide poll published Tuesday by the Public Religion Research Institute and the Brookings Institution, nonpartisan research groups in Washington.

headline: Word of the Day | polemical
text: polemical •\pə-ˈle-mi-kəl\• adjective

headline: L.A. Kings Led by Top Players Once Again
text: The Garden was ready. The capacity crowd — wearing special blue Stanley Cup finals T-shirts — was loud and prepared for the Rangers’ first home game in the finals since 1994. But the experienced Los Angeles Kings, who had never won a playoff game at Madison Square Garden, spoiled the party.

headline: Will Ed O’Bannon Change the N.C.A.A?
text: The implications of O’Bannon v. N.C.A.A., a class-action lawsuit that could change the economics of college sports.

headline: Video Notebook: Rangers Lose Game 3
text: Brad Richards talks about the Rangers’ 3-0 loss to the Kings at Madison Square Garden and what it means for the rest of the Stanly Cup finals.

headline: A Turn for the Worse at Home
text: After losing the first two games of the Stanley Cup finals in overtime in Los Angeles, the Rangers were blanked, 3-0, by the Kings at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 9:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (2005) Tim Burton’s sugar rush, based on Roald Dahl’s book, stars Johnny Depp as an oddly sinister candy maker and Freddie Highmore (above, with Mr. Depp, left, and David Kelly) as a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn’t? Despite burdening Willy Wonka with a psychological back story, “there is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka’s world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The real lesson of ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ is — or should be — that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.”

headline: Taliban Hit Airport Again After Pakistani Airstrikes
text: LONDON — Retaliating against a new wave of military airstrikes, Pakistani Taliban gunmen on Tuesday attacked security forces at Karachi’s international airport for the second time this week, underscoring their capacity to create mayhem in the country’s largest city.

headline: China Complains About Plutonium in Japan
text: China has complained that Japan has 640 kilograms of plutonium that it did not report to the International Atomic Energy Agency.

headline: Corrections: June 10, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Xi Urges Greater Innovation in ‘Core Technologies’
text: Even when President Xi Jinping of China urges his country’s scientists to blaze a trail into the future, he dwells on the defeats and humiliations of the past.

headline: Test Yourself | History, June 10
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Euronext Value Could Reach About $2.4 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON –IntercontinentalExchange, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said on Tuesday that it expected the initial public offering of its Euronext unit to value the business at up to 1.75 billion euros, or $2.38 billion.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Bold Counterpunch Shows Taliban’s Lasting Strength
text: In “A Bold Counterpunch Shows Taliban’s Lasting Strength,” Declan Walsh reports on an attack at Pakistan’s largest international airport.

headline: Despite Critics, China Asserts Democratic Progress in Hong Kong
text: A week after roughly 100,000 people turned out in Hong Kong in a protest directed at China’s Communist leadership, Beijing has issued a ringing defense of its oversight of the territory, crediting the central government with everything from combating the SARS epidemic to promoting democratic reforms and ensuring Hong Kong’s economic success.

headline: ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike Kills 5 Special Operations Soldiers in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Five American Special Operations service members and at least one Afghan soldier were killed when a United States Air Force B-1 bomber unleashed an airstrike on their position in southern Afghanistan, in one of the deadliest instances of friendly fire in more than a decade of war, Afghan and American officials said Tuesday.

headline: Imperial Tobacco Plans I.P.O. of Logista Distribution Unit
text: LONDON – The British tobacco manufacturer Imperial Tobacco Group said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its Compañía de Distribución Integral Logista Holdings distribution unit in an initial public offering in Spain.

headline: Does Live Theater Offer Something You Just Can’t Get Watching Movies or TV?
text: Do you ever go to the theater to see live performances? Do you enjoy watching plays or musicals? Have you ever seen a Broadway or Off-Broadway show?

headline: A Photographer’s Summer of Luck in San Francisco
text: Arthur Tress was one lucky young photographer. Mr. Tress, a 23-year-old New Yorker, happened to visit his sister in San Francisco in the summer of 1964, when big news kept breaking.

headline: High-Profile Conference to Draw Attention to Sexual Violence in War
text: LONDON — The Hollywood star Angelina Jolie and the British foreign secretary, William Hague, opened a high-profile gathering here on Tuesday intended to combat the increasing prevalence of sexual violence in war zones, with Ms. Jolie calling for an end to a “culture of impunity” among perpetrators.

headline: Silicon Valley Tries to Remake the Idea Machine
text: Like any supersecret lab that’s supposedly trying to invent the future, Google X looks rather nondescript from the street. Besides the occasional hot pink driverless car parked out front, the facility is an archipelago of unmarked, low-slung, redbrick buildings, more Sunset Park than Silicon Valley. Inside, however, whiteboards offer clues about what exactly the future — at least as Google sees it — might look like. And while some diagrams — including one with parts labeled “snooze” and “set time” — suggest more mundane inventions, others, like one outlining a “space elevator,” seem a bit more ambitious.

headline: Support for Blind University Aspirant Turns to Censure
text: Li Jinsheng, a massage center owner, was among the first blind people to take the “gaokao,” or nationwide university entrance examinations, after the government, in a major turnaround in April, allowed blind people to do so. But Mr. Li says he failed.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Head Trip
text: Updated, 10:19 a.m.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Taystee Gets Her Moment
text: Season 2, Episode 2: Could it be that we’ve found the most compelling storyline – and it’s not Piper?

headline: In South Carolina, Graham Prevails Without a Runoff
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, once thought to be among the Republican incumbents most vulnerable to a Tea Party challenge this year, easily dispatched six primary opponents on Tuesday, capturing well over 50 percent of the vote and avoiding a runoff.

headline: Finally, a Pollution Index Beijing Can Love
text: Transparency is a popular catchphrase these days in China, with ordinary people demanding more of it from their officials. In this regard, pollution is one area in which there has been some progress, even if the polluting activities themselves remain a chronic problem across the country.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times editorial board condemns the “brazen assault” carried out by Taliban militants on the international airport in Karachi, Pakistan, this weekend. “One has to assume the militants will stop at nothing until the state is utterly destabilized and they have taken control,” the board writes, calling on Pakistani political and military leaders to recognize the Taliban threat and quickly devise a strategy to protect the nation’s people. “Time to find a solution is fast running out.”

headline: Daily Report: Report Implicates 2nd Chinese Army Unit in Online Spying
text: Just weeks after the Justice Department indicted five members of the Chinese army, accusing them of online attacks on United States corporations, a report released on Monday offers more evidence of the breadth and ambition of China’s campaign to steal trade and military secrets from foreign victims, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Bergdahl Prisoner Swap Stirs Concern
text: Americans have serious misgivings about the prisoner swap that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from captivity in Afghanistan, and most disapprove of President Obama’s failure to inform Congress ahead of the exchange with the Taliban, according to two new national surveys.

headline: Applying the Lessons of ‘Moneyball’ and ‘Golden Motions’ to Your Business
text: As the founder of a business intelligence software company, it can be hard to explain my job to those outside my industry. Whenever I catch up with friends or family members, I can see the question coming a mile away: “What exactly does your company do again?”

headline: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
text: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants spilling over the border from Syria on Tuesday seized control of the northern city of Mosul, Iraq’s second largest, in the most stunning success yet in a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.

headline: If Robots Drove, How Much Safer Would Roads Be?
text: Human error is the culprit in 93 percent of automobile crashes — including the pileup last weekend that left Tracy Morgan in critical condition, caused, prosecutors say, by a truck driver who had been awake for 24 hours.

headline: A Case Study in Lifting College Attendance
text: Sydney Nye was a straight-A student with an SAT score high enough to apply to any college in the country. When her senior year of high school in Wilmington, Del., started about nine months ago, she had dreams of becoming a chemical engineer.

headline: Arm Syria’s Opposition
text: Washington — In February, I resigned as the American ambassador to Syria, after 30 years’ foreign service in Africa and the Middle East. As the situation in Syria deteriorated, I found it ever harder to justify our policy. It was time for me to leave.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Closer Look at Uber’s Valuation
text: A CLOSER LOOK AT UBER’S VALUATION  |  When the car ride service Uber was valued on Friday at $18.2 billion, some called the figure “nuts” and “insane.” After all, it was hard to believe that a four-year-old company that exists on an iPhone could be worth more than longstanding institutions like Alcoa and Tiffany, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. But a look at the basic math suggests that Uber’s valuation might still be too low.

headline: In Our Pages: June 11
text: 1889: His Royal Highness on High

headline: Intersection | Detroit’s Industrial Chic
text: In the historic Eastern Market neighborhood of Detroit, local style is inspired by the industrial surroundings.

headline: Who Ordered Politkovskaya’s Murder?
text: Almost eight years after the gruesome murder of Anna Politkovskaya, one of Russia’s most respected investigative journalists, Moscow’s highest criminal court has finally sentenced five men to prison, two of them for life. The court ruled Monday that these men were part of a conspiracy to assassinate Ms. Politkovskaya in her apartment block on Oct. 7, 2006. These convictions signal some progress in Russia’s glacial investigations of the murder, but the case is not closed.

headline: In Performance: Tony Award Winners
text: On Sunday night Tony Awards were given to two actors who recently participated in a small concert produced by The New York Times as part of a special Tony Awards edition of the In Performance series.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, including a couple I don’t recall seeing before. Add these to your watch list.

headline: New And Not Improved
text: OK, we’re obviously in for a lot of breathless hype about the new conservatism, as supposedly exemplified by Room to Grow, which self-consciously lays out what are supposed to be bold new conservative policy ideas. One thing you don’t find amid the hype, however, is much actual description of the new ideas in question. That’s because the ideas don’t bear too much scrutiny.

headline: What’s News in Washington: In Six States, It’s Primary Day
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s book “Hard Choices” comes out today, kicking off her much-anticipated book tour, furthering speculation about her intentions for 2016 and consuming a whole lot of political oxygen. But on the ground it remains midterm season, and it is primary day.

headline: The Release of Bowe Bergdahl
text: President Obama makes a controversial prisoner swap.

headline: Madame Tussauds Fits Maya Angelou
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Rejects Valeant’s $53 Billion Offer
text: Updated, 12:42 p.m. |

headline: Fashion Awards: Beyond Vogue and Up With Men’s Wear
text: For the last few years, Vogue has had something of a lock on the fashion awards market — ever since American Vogue introduced its fashion fund award with the Council of Fashion Designers of America in 2003, which was followed by “Who Is on Next?,” the Italian Vogue/AltaRoma prize established in 2005; the British Vogue and the British Fashion Council designer award in 2008; and the Fashion Design Council of India and Indian Vogue award in 2012. Well, now GQ is getting in on the act.

headline: Who’s Your Mommy? We Don’t Know — Yet
text: Over a year ago, despite my many doubts, I agreed to become a sperm donor for my good friends, Tori and Kelly. Saying yes, it turns out, was the easy part. It took nearly a year of failed attempts before Kelly conceived. For the round of I.V.F. that finally worked, moreover, both of my friends decided to harvest eggs. The clinic then transferred the two best resulting embryos, one from each woman, to increase Kelly’s odds of conceiving.

headline: Israel Parliament Elects Ex-Speaker as President to Succeed Peres
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Parliament on Tuesday elected Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician and former minister and Parliament speaker, as the country’s next president, ending what many here described as the most unseemly race in Israel’s history for what is largely a ceremonial post.

headline: The Pundits and the President
text: This seems to be the season for centrist Obama-bashing. He’s ineffectual, we’re told, a drag on his party, Democrats are complaining (although none on the record), and so on.

headline: How Has Parenthood Informed Your Writing Life?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Mohsin Hamid discuss how fatherhood has influenced their work.

headline: Police Statements Cloud Alleged Rape and Murder Case, Analysts Say
text: In the span of two weeks, the Indian police have offered different versions of the alleged rape and murder of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh State who were found hanging from a tree on May 28, in an event that invited widespread censure of the state government and a rebuke from the United Nations in India, as well as a statement from its secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

headline: Despite Clash in Ukraine, Cease-Fire Talks Advance
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The foreign ministers of Russia, Poland and Germany on Tuesday signaled progress toward a cease-fire in Ukraine, even as up to 40 separatists were reported to have been killed in a fierce battle for control of an airport in the east of the country.

headline: The Rabbi Cardinal O’Connor Never Knew: His Grandfather
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — In his 16 years as the Catholic Church’s top official in New York, Cardinal John Joseph O’Connor was a staunch friend and defender of the Jewish people.

headline: Bosnia’s Cup Debut Turns Part of St. Louis Into Sarajevo West
text: ST. LOUIS — The whiteboard propped on the sidewalk read “Sretno Zmajevi,” or Good Luck Dragons, referring to the nickname for the Bosnian national soccer team. And the message rippled down the street.

headline: Banksy Confesses: He Made the Eavesdropping Mural
text: LONDON — In a rare exchange with the public, the elusive graffiti artist Banksy has acknowledged painting a mural depicting secret agents eavesdropping on a telephone booth, which appeared in April in the city of Cheltenham, where one of Britain’s intelligence agencies has its headquarters.

headline: Walkabout: Transit Strike Threatens to Disrupt World Cup
text: Cup Half-Full With the World Cup set to start in São Paulo on Thursday, Brazil is facing the latest in a series of obstacles and frustrations in hosting the games: a transit strike in the city that threatens to disrupt the opening. (BBC)

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Born Alive’
text: This poem, by Joanna Gerber, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Science article, “Space Ripples Reveal Big Bang’s Smoking Gun.”

headline: In Shareholder Address, G.M. Chief Vows Safety
text: DETROIT — General Motors’ chief executive, Mary T. Barra, told shareholders on Tuesday that the company was making major changes in its operations in the wake of an internal investigation of its recall of defective small cars.

headline: After 7 Months, British Hacking Case Heads to the Jury
text: LONDON — With one of Britain’s most riveting trials — a seven-month courtroom marathon that exposed the inner workings of the tabloid news media and the personal lives of two friends of the prime minister — nearing its conclusion, the judge gave this reminder to the jury: “No one is so powerful they can ignore the law.”

headline: New Works and Programming by Laurie Anderson to Highlight New York Live Arts Season
text: Commissioned works by Kyle Abraham and RoseAnne Spradlin, among others, as well as the third annual Live Ideas mini-festival, to be programmed by the composer Laurie Anderson, are among the highlights of the 2014-15 season at New York Live Arts, the Chelsea dance theater directed by the choreographer Bill T. Jones. The season, which Mr. Jones announced Tuesday, will include 71 performances by more than 22 artists and ensembles, including the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company.

headline: Does Obama’s Unpopularity Matter?
text: My last post offered 1400 words in response to a Jonathan Chait tweet; now let me offer a few more in response to his actual rebuttal to my recent column on why the Democrats need Hillary Clinton to hold their presidential majority together. Here, from his latest post, is a two-part argument that I’m overstating the significance of President Obama’s stuck-in-the-40s approval ratings for his party’s fortunes in 2016. First, because of the Republicans:

headline: Chobani’s Science Lesson
text: The Greek yogurt company Chobani raised hackles last week with a message under some of its lids that read, “Nature got us to 100 calories, not scientists. #howmatters.” The company has apologized, but some scientists say the controversy suggests something bigger about anti-science sentiment in America.

headline: Ukrainians Find Jobs and a Slice of Russia in Arctic Norway
text: BARENTSBURG, Norway — While scientists up here in the high Arctic monitor global warming by studying the movement of polar bears, ice floes and glaciers, Nikolai Mikitenko tracks the meltdown in Ukraine, the land of his birth more than 2,000 miles away, through the migration of desperate coal miners.

headline: Hong Kong Rebel Loses His Trademark Long Hair
text: No matter what he did to the laws — making them as a legislator in the somber wooden chamber of Hong Kong’s Legislative Council, or breaking them when he burst into a room to disrupt a public forum — Leung Kwok-hung’s long unkempt hair had been a constant in his decade as one of the city’s most animated legislators. That was, until his hair was cut short on Monday.

headline: In Store | At Rachel Comey’s New SoHo Flagship, Form Follows Fashion
text: It is fitting that Rachel Comey, who hosts intimate dinner parties rather than runway shows during fashion week, has chosen to open her first brick-and-mortar outpost just downstairs from her own SoHo apartment next door. The downtown designer with a cult following has a knack for keeping things personal — and for not taking fashion too seriously. “It’s important for the store to be a tad funny,” she says. Indeed, the buzz surrounding the shop — which her most ardent followers have been hoping and wishing for for the past 13 years — has been on overdrive since Comey released a photo of a cheeky flag, painted with the help of her good friend Leanne Shapton, hanging outside the then-raw space on Crosby Street. It poked fun at the storefront’s mainstream-Manhattan neighbors: SoulCycle, Jamba Juice and Duane Reade.

headline: Rangers Create Bounces; L.A. Kings’ Jonathan Quick Swats Them Away
text: As the puck bounced tantalizingly near what seemed like an open net and a sure chance at a goal in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Monday, Rangers forward Mats Zuccarello’s stick took an extra microsecond to make contact with it. He was in perfect position, poised to make all the overwrought pregame buildup seem valid, primed to make Madison Square Garden erupt, ready to determine both teams’ fortunes.

headline: Trial of South Korean Ferry Crew Begins
text: GWANGJU, South Korea — The captain and 14 other crew members of the South Korean ferry that sank in April, leaving 304 people dead or missing, went on trial here on Tuesday. The defendants faced the anger of victims’ relatives at the courthouse, where senior crew members denied the homicide charges against them.

headline: Appreciating the Flavors of West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Michael Ratney, the United States consul general here, is a fan of the television show “Chopped,” in which cooks must whip up an appetizer, entrée and dessert from baskets of disparate, often unpalatable, ingredients. So for a dinner party last week, Mr. Ratney gave the consulate’s Swiss-born chef, Ursula Imran al Sous, a challenge: Make a menu out of items from West Bank purveyors that Washington underwrites.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Palestinian Feast
text: To celebrate the diversity of Palestinian products grown on the West Bank, America’s top diplomat to the region prepared a feast inspired by the “Chopped” television Series.

headline: ‘Baby Got Back’ Story: Sir Mix-a-Lot Was an Early Interactive Success
text: Before Sir Mix-a-Lot broke through to the pop charts in 1992, he’d found some success on the rap charts with his first two albums, “Swass” and “Seminar.” But his label, Def American, struggled to get widespread airplay in promoting his third album, “Mack Daddy.” The first single they released, “One Time’s Got No Case,” went nowhere. Increasing their efforts for the second single, “Baby Got Back,” the label reached out to the Box, a cable network that played music videos based on viewer requests on the telephone. As Sheila Rule wrote in The New York Times:

headline: Children at the Border
text: More than a few online commenters were annoyed, angered or exasperated by an editorial last week, “Children on the Run,” which told of the recent surge of tens of thousands young migrants being caught at the southern border. These children, many of them traveling alone, are straining the Border Patrol’s resources and prompting the Obama administration to take urgent steps to ease what looks to us  like a refugee crisis, but to others like an invasion.

headline: Recording the Polar Bear’s View of its Changing Arctic Environment
text: I first encountered the wildlife filmmaker Adam Ravetch in 2007 when writing about “Arctic Tale,” a film on polar bears and walruses that he co-directed for National Geographic in 2007 and which meshed fictional storytelling and astonishing imagery.

headline: Incentives and Technology
text: The invaluable Mark Thoma leads me to this post attacking what I thought was a totally obvious takedown of Roger Pielke Jr.. In general, reading attacks on oneself should be done in very limited doses, but in this case I learned something — namely, that what I assumed was obvious apparently isn’t to everyone.

headline: Voter Fraud Is Rare, but Myth Is Widespread
text: Is vote fraud common in American politics? Not according to United States District Judge Lynn Adelman, who examined the evidence from Wisconsin and ruled in late April that “virtually no voter impersonation occurs” in the state and that “no evidence suggests that voter-impersonation fraud will become a problem at any time in the foreseeable future.”

headline: Image of the Day: June 10
text: A woman at a protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, seeking the whereabouts of her family member who went missing since a separatist rebellion broke out in the state in 1989.

headline: Czech Pawns In a System That Stifled
text: On Aug. 20, 1968, Warsaw Pact troops led by the Soviet Union invaded Czechoslovakia, putting a violent end to the reformist socialist experiment known as the Prague Spring. The following winter, a student named Jan Palach set himself on fire in Wenceslas Square, an act of protest that is the starting point of “Burning Bush,” Agnieszka Holland’s thoughtful, gripping, crisply acted new film.

headline: Today in Small Business: Managing People Who Hate Each Other
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Bergdahl Briefing Fails to Allay Senators’ Doubts
text: WASHINGTON — Senators emerged Tuesday from a classified, closed-door briefing on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl seemingly less convinced than ever about the wisdom of swapping five high-level Taliban prisoners for the Army soldier after he spent years in captivity.

headline: Sex in Assisted Living: Intimacy Without Privacy
text: Trulah Goin Mills had developed dementia and couldn’t be left alone in the house, but when she and her husband, Lewis, moved into an assisted living facility in Boise, Idaho, in 2012, one lifelong quality remained intact.

headline: Euronext’s I.P.O. Will Be a Tough Sell
text: Euronext’s initial public offering looks like a tough sell. The firm is seeking a valuation of 1.3 billion euros to 1.8 billion euros when it floats later this month. Anchor investors have a vested interest in backing the issue. But for other buyers, it is a leap of faith.

headline: Gail Collins Responds to Readers: Congress Versus Hobbit
text: Gail Collins, Op-Ed columnist, answered a few questions posed by commenters about her latest column, Congress Versus Hobbit.

headline: You Can Skip the Fitting, Mom
text: IN THE DECADE-PLUS since the psychologist Barry Schwartz published his oft-cited book “The Paradox of Choice: Why More is Less,” the options available to the American bride have increased beyond measure. She can legally marry another woman in many states. She can skip the whole wedding racket entirely, in protest or preoccupation or boredom, and suffer no social stigma whatsoever. Or — and this is a hedge I have observed among many urban millennials — she can sort of back up slowly, shruggingly, consciously down the aisle: save the blood-diamond money for a down payment on a Clinton Hill condominium; hire friends to do the organic catering; and buy her frock, perhaps in electric-blue, from Etsy or similar.

headline: Commodities Regulator Names New Enforcement Chief
text: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | Wall Street’s smallest regulator has hired a big-name enforcement director.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Just Jim Dale’
text: A scene from the actor’s one-man show, at the Laura Pels Theater, about his varied career in show business.

headline: ‘Disgraced’ Will Reach Broadway, Though Without Aasif Mandvi
text: Ayad Akhtar’s blistering play “Disgraced,” which had a critically acclaimed Off Broadway run in 2012 and won the Pulitzer Prize for drama the next year, will open on Broadway this fall at the Lyceum Theater, one of the lead producers, Matthew Rego, confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The Average Age Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Fans Wait Hours to See Hillary Clinton at Book Signing
text: Andre Morales, a 36-year-old from Brooklyn, arrived before 3 a.m. Tuesday and planned to ask Hillary Rodham Clinton how it felt to work for President Obama after he had defeated her in the 2008 Democratic primary.

headline: Arms Windfall for Insurgents as Iraq City Falls
text: The insurgent fighters who routed the Iraqi army out of Mosul on Tuesday did not just capture much of Iraq’s second-largest city. They also gained a windfall of arms, munitions and equipment abandoned by the soldiers as they fled — arms that were supplied by the United States and intended to give the troops an edge over the insurgents.

headline: European Antitrust Authorities Contend That ICAP Colluded to Rig Rates
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission is accusing the British financial firm ICAP of collusion, saying it tried to fix a benchmark interest rate tied to the yen.

headline: Health Officials Call for More Fish in Diets of Children and Pregnant Women
text: Federal officials on Tuesday announced that they would recommend for the first time that women who are pregnant or breast-feeding and young children eat a minimum of two servings of low-mercury seafood every week for their health.

headline: City Settles Occupy Protesters’ False-Arrest Lawsuit
text: The City of New York has agreed to pay nearly $600,000 to resolve a lawsuit accusing police officers of falsely arresting Occupy Wall Street participants who were walking on a sidewalk in the East Village on New Year’s Day 2012.

headline: Tracy Morgan’s New Series Is Still a Go Whenever He Recovers, FX Says
text: The FX cable networks affirmed their commitment on Tuesday to the injured comedian Tracy Morgan, saying that a new series announced earlier in the spring to star Mr. Morgan would still be “waiting for him” when he recovers from his injuries.

headline: Markets Are Less Volatile. Should We Worry?
text: If the stock market was a person, right now it would be a supremely easygoing retiree on the beach in Key West drinking a piña colada. Mr. Market is very, very relaxed.

headline: Judge Rejects Teacher Tenure for California
text: LOS ANGELES — A California judge ruled Tuesday that teacher tenure laws deprived students of their right to an education under the State Constitution and violated their civil rights. The decision hands teachers’ unions a major defeat in a landmark case, one that could radically alter how California teachers are hired and fired and prompt challenges to tenure laws in other states.

headline: Cherche Midi Opens
text: Headliner

headline: Turning to National Front, but Keeping a Distance
text: BOHAIN-EN-VERMANDOIS, France — Armand Pollet, the representative of the far-right National Front in this struggling, largely rural town in the north, sat back in his leather easy chair recently and smiled with satisfaction, declaring that his party was now locked in place as France’s third mainstream party.

headline: A Bouillabaisse Dinner, Halvah Spreads and More
text: To Share: A Bouillabaisse Dinner Is Quite a Catch

headline: Knicks, in Selecting Fisher, Take a Different Approach
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Derek Fisher conceded Tuesday, as he was introduced as the new coach of the Knicks, that he had no experience as a coach at any level. He did not dismiss the empty lines on his résumé, but then again it hardly seemed to matter to the man who hired him, the Knicks’ new president, Phil Jackson, who won 11 N.B.A. titles as a coach.

headline: Google to Buy Skybox Imaging for $500 Million
text: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | Google agreed on Tuesday to buy Skybox Imaging, a provider of high-quality satellite images, for $500 million, as the technology giant continues to work on fulfilling its lofty ambitions for its Internet offerings.

headline: A Legislative Assault on the Financial Stability Oversight Council
text: Two new bills are pending in the House that relate to the Financial Stability Oversight Council and its ability to designate which parts of the financial system are “too big to fail” and thus in need of greater regulatory scrutiny. Both show how political the entire issue has become.

headline: Ireland Investigating Complaints Against Unwed Mother Homes
text: DUBLIN — The Irish government said Tuesday it would begin an investigation into allegations of neglect and criminality at so-called mother-and-baby homes over several decades.

headline: Disapproval of Obama Doesn’t Mean Long-Term Trouble for Democrats
text: The Democratic coalition is thought to have an advantage in national elections, but President Obama’s approval ratings have sagged into the low-to-mid 40s. It’s possible that his weak approval ratings are a sign of weakness in the Democratic coalition, as Ross Douthat, a New York Times columnist, argued on Sunday. Low presidential approval ratings can presage the collapse of a political coalition, like the fall of the Republican coalition in the last years of the George W. Bush administration.

headline: 1956: Elvis Is Introduced to the Nation
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 2
text: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times have counted down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Oregon Shooting Draws Obama’s Outrage on Gun Laws
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, speaking hours after a gunman killed a student and wounded a teacher at an Oregon high school, said Tuesday that his failure to push through stricter gun laws was the greatest frustration of his presidency, declaring, “We’re the only developed country on earth where this happens.”

headline: From the I.R.S., a Taxpayer Bill of Rights
text: The Internal Revenue Service has been accused of a lot of things, but being user-friendly is not usually one of them.

headline: E.U. Official Criticizes U.S. Move Against Norwegian Air
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top transport official expressed deep disappointment on Tuesday with an attempt by American lawmakers to block plans by Norwegian Air Shuttle to offer new cut-rate flights across the Atlantic, and hinted at possible legal action if Washington failed to grant an operating license to the budget carrier’s long-distance subsidiary.

headline: Alabama and Mississippi Voted Last Week. No Official Results Yet.
text: A week after primary elections in eight states, two of them — Alabama and Mississippi — have not posted any results on an official state government website. The two stand alone among states that held primaries on June 3 in not publishing any results in a central location. California, Iowa, Montana, South Dakota, New Mexico and New Jersey had unofficial election-night results sites, in many cases updated live on election night.

headline: Trickle-Down Fragrances
text: Perfume lovers can now buy a deeply scented bottle of a new eau de toilette, blended with natural oils of sandalwood and jasmine absolute sambac, both imported from India, formulated by the French-trained perfumer who has worked on scents from luxurious niche brands like Atelier Cologne, which last year introduced a pair of fragrances in sleek glass bottles infused with either gold or silver, retailing at $195.

headline: Chris Christie Spares No Legal Expense
text: Anyone who slogged through the 344-page report on Bridgegate from New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie’s lawyers in March understood that this old fashioned whitewash would be extremely expensive.The governor hired one of the nation’s  big time law firms, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, which dutifully declared that Gov. Christie was not to blame for the massive traffic jams last year. Those problems were the work of others, the report insisted. The governor’s hands were clean.

headline: A Glimpse (and a Taste) of Celebrity
text: Gato galloped into town in March, pursued by the food media and Bobby Flay fans in a thundering cloud of hoofbeats. The first new restaurant Mr. Flay and his business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, have opened in New York City in nearly a decade, Gato is nominally Mediterranean, but the chef rides herd on pastas and pizzas and romesco sauces with a go-for-broke intensity that’s 100 percent American. Mr. Flay brushes flavor on his ingredients in thick impasto strokes, making each plate a three-dimensional aggregation of char, smoke, capsicum, sugar, acid and fat. The cooking at Gato is many things, often all at the same time, but it is rarely shy.

headline: 2014: Clinton Fans at a Book Signing
text: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton waited in line at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square for Mrs. Clinton’s first book signing on a nationwide tour to promote her new memoir.

headline: Unexpected Love Stories
text: Like his hero, Johnny Cash, he’s a man in black: weathered Levi’s, motorcycle boots, a T-shirt with a box of cigarettes straining the chest pocket. A long-ago rock star who toured the world but never managed to get rich, Dale arrives to crash at his son’s Morningside Heights apartment like a leftover from a more analog time. Broke and unemployed, he has no idea how to navigate a world ruled by technology.

headline: Tony Awards Face Criticism Over ‘In Memoriam’ Segment
text: What happened to the In Memoriam segment of the Tony Awards?

headline: Delay Urged on Actions Tied to Tests by Schools
text: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, one of the country’s largest donors to educational causes and a strong backer of the academic guidelines known as the Common Core, has called for a two-year moratorium on states or school districts making any high-stakes decisions based on tests aligned with the new standards.

headline: Q. and A. | Banks on Tapping Into Her Inner Goddess
text: Early press on Jillian Banks, the 25-year-old songstress who goes simply by Banks, focused largely on how little was actually known about her. The Los Angeles native seemed to appear out of nowhere, dropping a song, “Before I Ever Met You,” on Soundcloud in early 2013 to huge acclaim, and appearing in only a handful of photos in which her dark, searching eyes and model-like cheekbones were hidden in shadow or behind her long brown hair. At a time when many of her peers were blasting out songs about their famous exes and tipping off TMZ to their whereabouts, Banks was — quite literally — shrouded in obscurity. (Appropriately, the singer showed up for her interview with T clad in head-to-toe black, hair hanging over her face.)

headline: Beach Volleyball for All at a California Hotel
text: Fairmont Miramar Hotel & Bungalows, a 302-room property in Santa Monica, Calif., is holding its third annual Vilebrequin Beach Volleyball Games.

headline: To Aid the Blind, an Assist From Cameras
text: In two labs some 50 miles apart in Israel, computer scientists and engineers are refining devices that employ tiny cameras as translators of sorts. For both teams, the goal is to give blind people a form of sight — or at least an experience analogous to sight.

headline: Obama’s Moments of Freedom Send His Aides Scrambling
text: WASHINGTON — The bear was loose again on Tuesday.

headline: Egypt’s Inaction on Sexual Attacks Stirs Fury
text: CAIRO — Rape victims and women’s rights advocates lashed out on Tuesday at the escalating attempts by the Egyptian government and news media to dismiss a plague of sexual assaults more than three years after the Arab Spring uprising began to expose the scale of the problem.

headline: Families Flee Mosul Amid Gunfire
text: Thousands of residents fled Mosul in northern Iraq after the city was seized by militants belonging to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, an extremist group.

headline: A.I.G. Names Successor to Benmosche, Who Nursed It Through Fiscal Crisis
text: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | The American International Group on Tuesday named a successor to Robert H. Benmosche, the insurer’s chief executive and the voluble leader who oversaw its recovery from the financial crisis.

headline: Keep Your Government Hands Off My Cheese
text: Cheese, or at least all good cheese, arises out of the mysterious mating of milk, enzymes and bacteria, and federal bureaucrats do not take kindly to either mysteries or germs. This week, a few of those bureaucrats horrified cheese-eaters across the country by banning cheese that is ripened or aged on wooden boards, apparently unaware that they are upsetting the natural rhythms of the universe.

headline: The ‘Grandfather’ Gets Busted
text: The D.E.A. spent months investigating the Sinaloa cartel’s operation in the Detroit area and tracking their most prolific drug mule: Leo Sharp, a World War II veteran with no criminal record.

headline: A Health Insurer Calls, With Questions
text: Not long after she signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, Judy Shoemaker received a phone call that puzzled her.

headline: Do You Speak Tech?
text: The tech industry’s influence on where people can live and how they spend their time is well documented. Now it may be influencing the way we talk as well.

headline: Marketing Domino’s in the Lunchroom
text: Companies like Domino’s are making more healthful versions of their food to sell in schools, prompting concerns about the use of brands in the school lunch line.

headline: Appeals Court Rules Bloomberg Plan for ‘Taxi of Tomorrow’ Is Legal
text: A state appeals court on Tuesday ruled that a plan for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow taxis in New York City was legal, reversing a lower-court ruling and resuscitating a program initially enacted under the Bloomberg administration but opposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: The Domino’s Smart Slice Goes to School
text: Given the current uproar over new federal rules aimed at getting schoolchildren to eat more healthfully, you might think fast food was an endangered species on the cafeteria line. But Domino’s is delivering a pizza it calls the Smart Slice to more than 3,000 lunchrooms in 38 states, up from 3 states in 2010. And one force driving those sales is the new rules themselves. These pies contain fewer of the worrisome ingredients found in regular pizzas. But they also give the students a hefty dose of marketing for the Domino’s brand, and many other companies are following the same path to the lunchroom.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: G.M. Chief on Ignition Switch Problems
text: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ chief executive, spoke at a news conference ahead of the annual shareholders meeting.

headline: In Ireland, 10 Years of Fresh Air
text: On the morning of March 29, 2004, global television crews gathered outside a Dublin restaurant stocked with celebrating lawmakers to witness what few thought possible in this welcoming land of brilliant but noxious pubs.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Rest in Salt Lake City
text: Along a once humdrum stretch of Main Street in Salt Lake City, tucked behind a storefront called Bodega — a half ramshackle corner store, half taco-peddling beer tavern — is this subterranean speakeasy, the Rest.

headline: Reading List  | The Top 100 Best-Selling Education Books of 2014 (So Far)
text: The book trailer for “The End of Your Life Book Club,” No. 67 on our list.

headline: From Cocktails to Kimchi in Los Angeles’s Koreatown
text: With Koreans making up more than a quarter of the immigrants who live in Los Angeles’s Koreatown, that cultural flavor is palpable in the neighborhood’s remarkable concentration of late-night restaurants, bars and clubs. Thanks to the recent arrival of the Line Hotel in Koreatown — a design-minded homage to all things Korean, and to the street-cool sensibilities of K-town — a whole new audience is getting an introduction to city greats that have long been under the radar: croon-worthy karaoke joints, meticulously frothed cappuccinos, fiery grocery kimchi, some of the best Korean barbecue anywhere. A spate of new businesses (a speakeasy here, a microbrewery there) has only added to the area’s energetic night life.

headline: Hotel Review: Heywood Hotel in Austin, Tex.
text: Rates

headline: At E3, Nintendo Unveils a Mario World Designed by You
text: If you have ever played the first Super Mario Bros., the influential video game from the ’80s, you have probably also ventured into the many subsequent games and levels for Mario created by Nintendo.

headline: Beethoven That’s Not for Bruisers
