text: The fourth of Beethoven’s five piano concertos is the only one that begins with the soloist playing alone. The melody is a statement with the nobility of a Greek temple, a quiet expanse broken only by a playful little burst of a scale, like a giggle atop the Acropolis at sunrise.

headline: Beatles Sing in German, and a Nazi Flag Waves
text: LOS ANGELES — The Nazis, those perpetual video game villains who seemed to have been felled in recent years by a virulent zombie contagion, are back. Nothing that has been announced here this week at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the annual video game trade show better known as E3, has been as surprising or delightful — granted, an odd word to apply to the return of National Socialism — as the recent emergence of a new Wolfenstein game as one of the very best releases of the year.

headline: The Last Gun Report
text: Last Thursday, Jennifer Mascia and I posted our last Gun Report. It was my feeling that although it had been a useful tool — a daily statement about gun violence in America — The Gun Report had run its course. During the year and change that we published it, readers got a close-up look at the many forms gun violence takes — the horrifying incidents involving children shooting other children; the drive-by shootings; the shootings that result from a moment’s rage; and so on. There weren’t just one or two shootings each day; there were 30 or more. On weekends, the carnage was horrific. The Gun Report also became a place where gun proponents and gun opponents could voice their views in the comment section.

headline: O. J. and the White Bronco Ride Again
text: Beginning last fall, we seem to have entered a 12-month period heavy with anniversaries, which allows us to pause and ask: Why observe them? Perhaps to note a traumatic moment in history (the 50th of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination) or a turning point (the 50th of the Civil Rights Act and Freedom Summer). Perhaps to commemorate heroism (the 70th of D-Day). Perhaps to relish a cultural sea change (the 50th of the Beatles on “The Ed Sullivan Show”; the 45th of Woodstock).

headline: A Justice Alone, Even if Surrounded
text: Last fall the pugilistic Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia gave an interview to Jennifer Senior in New York Magazine so playful and revealing that the transcript could nearly be made into a stage play and movie, in the manner of “Frost/Nixon.”

headline: Cold War Spy or Just Wife?
text: In “Ethel Sings: The Unsung Song of Ethel Rosenberg,” the playwright Joan Beber issues a posthumous pardon to Ethel Rosenberg, executed for conspiring to commit espionage in 1953.

headline: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
text: Redhead deposits aren’t wanted at the world’s largest sperm bank, leading a photographer to document gingers in all their blazing, freckled varieties.

headline: A Symphony’s Viral Video
text: The Seattle Symphony commissioned the piece that won this year’s Pulitzer Prize for music, “Become Ocean,” by John Luther Adams. But it is a late-20th-century work that is bringing the orchestra broader fame this week: its performance with Sir Mix-A-Lot of his bawdy song “Baby Got Back,” which by Tuesday had been seen more than 1.5 million times on YouTube.

headline: Colombia Says It Has Begun Peace Talks With Rebels
text: The government of Colombia announced on Tuesday that it had begun exploratory peace talks with a second rebel group, just days ahead of a hotly contested presidential election that could hinge on how voters perceive the efforts of President Juan Manuel Santos to end decades of guerrilla warfare.

headline: Hong Kong Regulators Tense About China Loans
text: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | A surge in business loans to the slowing mainland Chinese economy has prompted Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.

headline: The Heroine’s Retinue as a Magical Force Field
text: Frederick Ashton’s three-act “Cinderella” (1948) is a story of hope fulfilled, a comedy of contrasting characters and a classical ballet dense with sensuous movement. Though New York has been having a Cinderellathon in 2014 — the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical on Broadway, and Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” at the Metropolitan Opera and Massenet’s “Cendrillon” at Juilliard Opera, both in April — this treatment of the old fairy tale takes the prize for dramatic poetry. Still, it looked a pale echo of itself on Monday when it joined American Ballet Theater’s repertory.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Germany, New York, Pakistan and Italy.

headline: A Season for the Blossoming of Hopes and Talents
text: Infectious passion for dancing has been the special thrill of New York City Ballet since the start of this year, and during the spring season that ended on Sunday the level kept rising. The sheer danciness of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Namouna: A Grand Divertissement” on opening night was irresistible. Justin Peck’s new “Everywhere We Go,” the season’s big premiere, had weak aspects, yet just look at how its cast was dancing its heart out! No wonder it won ovations.

headline: Oracle’s Database of Youth
text: Lawrence J. Ellison may have figured out a secret to seeming young: Ignore getting older, and act cutting-edge.

headline: Pentagon on ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike
text: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John Kirby, said five American troops were killed during a security operation in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Power of Style
text: THIS WEEK’S PUBLICATION of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “Hard Choices” has proved a predictably exciting opportunity for Clintonologists, 2016 election obsessives and pundits everywhere to revisit all sorts of issues that otherwise may have been considered, if not resolved, at least over — from the questions surrounding the couple’s marriage to Mrs. Clinton’s relationship with President Obama to the whole hair brouhaha.

headline: A Genre Dabbler Gets His Accolades
text: Donovan Leitch — or just Donovan, as he became known — might have become a painter instead of a musician. As he tells it, he was considering arts school when he decided, instead, to take his guitar and hitchhike to London, where he began performing as a folk singer. By 1965 he had won a following, as well as recording and publishing contracts, with ballads like “Catch the Wind” and “Colors,” guitar-accompanied folk songs similar to one Bob Dylan was writing — not surprisingly since they were both drawing from the large well of English, Irish, Scottish and American folk melodies.

headline: Art Matters | The Second Life of Performance
text: Once left behind by the competitive market, live art is now everywhere — thanks in large part to its staunchest advocate, RoseLee Goldberg.

headline: Why So Many World Cup Fans Dislike Argentina
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina has one of the most successful national soccer teams in the world, and the country has won the World Cup twice, in 1978 and 1986. In this year’s tournament, the team ranks among the most formidable competitors, with Brazil’s coach, Luiz Felipe Scolari, even predicting a final showdown with Argentina.

headline: World Cup’s Most Pessimistic Country: England?
text: The most downcast soccer fans in the world — relative to the quality of their national team — are the citizens of England.

headline: Australia’s Odd World Cup Optimism
text: The Socceroos, as the Australian national soccer team are known, enter the World Cup ranked by FIFA as the 62nd-best team in the world, the lowest standing of any of the 32 teams that earned a slot. They’ve also been dealt the toughest possible draw, facing not only the reigning champions and runners-up in their group, but also highly rated Chile. No wonder oddsmakers give the Aussies less than a 1-in-2,500 chance of winning the tournament.

headline: Morgan Stanley Sees Itself as Two Firms in One
text: The more risk-averse Morgan Stanley that has emerged since the financial crisis may tell a tale of two Wall Streets. But it may also tell a tale of two businesses within the bank.

headline: World Cup Opinions in 19 Countries: Likes, Dislikes, Predictions
text: Argentina, the United States and Iran appear to be the most disliked World Cup teams. Brazilian fans enter the World Cup as the most confident, though Argentines and Spaniards aren’t far behind in their home-country optimism. And fans across many countries agree that the Brazilians play the most attractive form of soccer.

headline: Methodology of World Cup Study
text: The study of public opinion about the World Cup is based on 19,780 interviews conducted by YouGov in 19 countries between May 19 and June 2. YouGov conducted the interviews online, after selecting respondents from opt-in panels recruited by YouGov or its partners.

headline: European Tech Start-Ups Pay Off for Index Ventures
text: LONDON — The European venture capital firm Index Ventures has been on a roll.

headline: Endowment Chief to Exit at Harvard
text: Jane L. Mendillo, the manager of Harvard’s $32.7 billion endowment, plans to step down by the end of the year, the university said on Tuesday.

headline: Detroit Denies Last-Minute Reprieve for Goats
text: The hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel has been denied a last-minute reprieve for his guerrilla urban farming project.

headline: More Lands of Fantasy
text: As “Game of Thrones” obsessives grimace and wait for George R. R. Martin’s next novel, “The Winds of Winter,” he and his publisher, the Bantam imprint of Random House, are tossing fans a couple of dragon bones.

headline: A Lethal Culture of Secrecy at G.M.
Economic Growth and the Failure to Cut Poverty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Glimpses of Mosul in Islamist Hands on YouTube
text: Video uploaded to YouTube on Tuesday appeared to offer glimpses of Iraq’s second-largest city, Mosul, in the hands of Islamist militants after the sudden retreat of Iraqi Army soldiers.

headline: The Use of Child Soldiers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cold Winter and Ukraine Lead to Lower Global Growth Forecast
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank has downgraded its estimate of the world’s economic expansion in a new forecast released Tuesday, with developing economies posting disappointing growth rates and the frigid winter in the United States and the crisis in Ukraine weighing on growth, too.

headline: Change at Housing Agency
Colleges Focus on Alcohol and Drugs as Serious Crime Dips
text: Colleges have become more aggressive about punishing alcohol and drug offenses, even as the rate of serious crime on campuses has dropped, according to a government report released Tuesday.

headline: Knicks Name Derek Fisher as Coach
text: Phil Jackson, the New York Knicks’ president, and Derek Fisher, their new coach, spoke after Mr. Fisher was hired to replace Mike Woodson.

headline: Privately Run Jails
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese Shoppers Change Hong Kong Border Area
text: HONG KONG — Smoking a cigarette outside a mall in the border town of Sheung Shui, a man who gave his name only as Chen stands next to a wheeled cart filled with purchases. He is visiting from the Chinese city of Shantou, 177 miles away, a trip he makes several times a year.

headline: A V.A. Doctor’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Target Hires an Outsider as Its Data Watchdog
text: Target named a seasoned security expert as its new chief information security officer on Tuesday, on the eve of its annual shareholders’ meeting, as the retailer sought to bolster its data defenses and calm investor chagrin after the extensive hacking it experienced last year.

headline: Amazon Stops Taking Advance Orders for ‘Lego’ and Other Warner Videos
text: The Everything Store is shrinking again. Amazon customers who want to order forthcoming Warner Home Video features, including “The Lego Movie,” “300: Rise of an Empire,” “Winter’s Tale” and “Transcendence,” are finding it impossible to do so.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT LEASE

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,311 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: A Bellwether for London Realty
text: LONDON — When the global bank HSBC sold its London headquarters tower to a Spanish buyer in spring 2007, at the height of the credit and property boom, the deal was the single largest real estate transaction in British history.

headline: Holder Criticizes Ban on Gay Boy Scout Leaders
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sharply criticized the Boy Scouts of America’s policy that bans gay scout leaders, calling it “a relic of an age of prejudice and insufficient understanding.” In remarks to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay-rights group, Mr. Holder said, “The continuation of a policy that discriminates against gay adult leaders, by an iconic American institution, only preserves and perpetuates the worst kind of stereotypes.” There is little Mr. Holder can do to oppose the policy. The Supreme Court ruled in 2000 that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to ban gay members.

headline: Sports Should Be Child’s Play
text: THE national furor over concussions misses the primary scourge that is harming kids and damaging youth sports in America.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: What Causes Weight Gain
text: If I ask you what constitutes “bad” eating, the kind that leads to obesity and a variety of connected diseases, you’re likely to answer, “Salt, fat and sugar.” This trilogy of evil has been drilled into us for decades, yet that’s not an adequate answer.

headline: Bloomberg Hires Jacki Kelley, Ad Executive, for Media Business
text: Bloomberg has hired a senior advertising executive, Jacki Kelley, as chief operating officer of its media business, the company announced on Tuesday, its latest hire from outside journalism as it seeks to transform its business under new leadership.

headline: Official Backs Marines’ Move to Classify Photos of Forces With Taliban Bodies
text: WASHINGTON — In an apparent expansion of the government’s secrecy powers, the top official in charge of the classification system has decided that it was legitimate for the Marines to classify photographs that showed American forces posing with corpses of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

headline: Eric Cantor Defeated by David Brat, Tea Party Challenger, in G.O.P. Primary Upset
text: WASHINGTON — In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, was soundly defeated on Tuesday by a Tea Party-backed economics professor who had hammered him for being insufficiently conservative.

headline: Erez Itzhaki
text: Mr. Itzhaki, 44, is a principal of Itzhaki Acquisitions, a real estate development company formerly known as the Keystone Group. His company is involved in boutique condominium projects, including Modern 19 in Chelsea, and is a partner with the developer Michael Shvo and others on a development planned in SoHo.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Plans Action on Wi-Fi in Schools
text: WASHINGTON — Visiting a middle school in Oakland earlier this year, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, got a glimpse of just how badly American schools need better high-speed Internet connections.

headline: Music Industry Officials Agree on Need for Licensing Rule Changes, but Little Else
text: The complex system of music licensing came under attack in a congressional hearing on Tuesday, as entertainment and media executives pleaded for changes to how music rights were acquired and paid for online and by radio and television stations.

headline: One Key to Success: A Belief in a Future
text: CHICAGO — Tim Jackson’s job is to convince young people that they have a stake in the future.

headline: Officials Assigned for World Cup Opener
text: Yuichi Nishimura, 42, of Japan, will be the referee for the World Cup’s opening match on Thursday night, when Brazil plays Croatia in São Paolo. Toru Sagara and Toshiyuki Nagi, also of Japan, will be the linesmen, and Alireza Faghani of Iran was assigned to be the fourth official.

headline: Merkel Cites ‘Threats’ in Warning to Cameron
text: BERLIN — German-British tensions over who should next lead the European Union appeared to heighten on Tuesday as Chancellor Angela Merkel delivered a scarcely veiled rebuke to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, warning that “threats” will not work as the 28 members struggle to mend new fissures in their unity aggravated by European Parliament elections last month.

headline: Getting a Kiehl’s Product Into a Man’s Orbit
text: THE market for men’s personal care products grew 15 percent from 2008 to 2013, according to Mintel, a market research firm. But while a makeup brand introducing a new mascara can seek publicity from countless beauty publications and bloggers, men’s brands face a hurdle: Although men are buying products like face scrub and anti-aging cream, they are not reading extensively about the items or trading grooming tips on the golf course.

headline: After Rough-Hewed Restoration, Experience at Pinehurst Is Devalued
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — The Pinehurst 12, headlined by Phil Mickelson, are those players in this week’s United States Open field who participated in the tournament the last two times it was held here, in 1999 and 2005.

headline: Microsoft Protests Order to Disclose Email Stored Abroad
text: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customer’s email stored in a data center in Ireland.

headline: On Trial’s Tapes, Talk of New York Politics, Secret Cash and Strip Clubs
text: WHITE PLAINS — The picture of New York City politicians emerging from secretly recorded conversations at the bribery trial of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith is not one likely to be found in high-school civics textbooks.

headline: P.F. Chang’s Investigating Possible Data Breach
text: P.F. Chang’s China Bistro said Tuesday that it is investigating a potential security breach that may have led to the theft of information from thousands of customer credit cards.

headline: Martha Hyer, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 89
text: Martha Hyer, an Oscar-nominated movie actress who starred alongside Humphrey Bogart, Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra and Shirley MacLaine in the 1950s and 1960s, died on May 31 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 89.

headline: I.R.S. Publishes Guide It Says Will Help Ensure Taxpayer Rights
text: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday unveiled a Taxpayer Bill of Rights that is intended to ensure the rights to privacy, confidentiality and a fair appeals process in dealings with the agency. “This reinforces for the average taxpayer the fairness of the system,” the agency’s commissioner, John Koskinen, said. He said the timing had nothing to do with the investigations that the I.R.S. is facing after being accused of giving improper scrutiny to conservative groups while reviewing their applications for tax-exempt status. He said that the decision was meant to “help taxpayers’ comfort level with the I.R.S.”

headline: Virginia Governor May Try to Expand Medicaid on His Own
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Gov. Terry McAuliffe has lost his battle with the legislature over Medicaid expansion, an enormous retreat from the high expectations he set for a liberal agenda. However, he is thought to be studying how to press the issue by executive action — a legally and politically uncertain course.

headline: Open Winner Savors Title, and Friendships
text: FLEET, England — Circulars announcing “The Boy Is Back in Town” hung throughout the North Hants clubhouse, where Justin Rose spent an afternoon last month signing autographs, answering questions and posing for photographs with the United States Open trophy he won last June.

headline: F.D.A. Rule May Alter Cheese-Aging Process
text: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has produced a stink that rivals Limburger, prompting an uproar among the artisanal cheese makers and consumers who fear they might lose access to products like obscure blue cheeses from Vermont and imported Parmigiano-Reggiano.

headline: Why Did Cantor Lose? Not Easy to Explain
text: Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost his primary on Tuesday night in one of the most stunning electoral upsets in recent memory. It is not easy to explain his defeat, or the extent to which his campaign apparently underestimated the severity of the threat posed by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed economics professor.

headline: Campaigning for Environment, Seminary to Divest Some Holdings
text: The trustees of Union Theological Seminary, a historic cradle of liberal Protestantism in New York City, voted unanimously on Tuesday to divest the school’s $108.4 million endowment from fossil fuel companies. Union is said to be the first seminary to take up the divestment tactic in a campaign by environmentalists to combat climate change. Last month, Stanford University announced it would divest, but only from coal companies. The president of Union, Serene Jones, said, “Climate change poses a catastrophic threat, and as stewards of God’s creation we simply must act.” The seminary had already divested from tobacco and liquor companies.

headline: Smart Growth on the East Side
text: With the sun setting on his final term, Mayor Michael Bloomberg tried last fall to push through a grand rezoning plan for East Midtown that would have brought many more office towers and a flood of workers to a 73-block area around Grand Central Terminal. He said it met an urgent need to keep the city competitive, with up-to-date buildings and improved transportation above and below ground. The plan died in the City Council, under criticism from community members and elected officials who said it was too drastic and too complicated to wave through.

headline: Student Borrowers and the Economy
text: President Obama took an important step this week when he signed an executive order providing relief to millions of struggling student loan borrowers and urged Congress to pass a student loan refinancing bill that is scheduled for a vote in the Senate on Wednesday. Both the executive order and the refinancing bill speak to a grave problem that has trapped recent college graduates and threatens the long-term health of the economy.

headline: Bank of America Mortgage Settlement Is Said to Be Deadlocked
text: Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement deal, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank’s role at the center of the mortgage crisis.

headline: Wylie Dufresne Says He Is Forced to Close WD-50
text: Updated | June 11, 2014

headline: Clauses That Hurt Workers
text: Many businesses have long required that executives and other important employees agree not to work for a competitor for a year or two after they leave. Now some employers are unfairly imposing that requirement on all kinds of workers, including lower-wage employees like camp counselors, interns and yoga instructors, The Times has found.

headline: The Real War of Ideas
text: The takeover Tuesday of the Iraqi city of Mosul by Sunni extremists who spilled over the Syrian border underscores the clash of world views that is underway in the whole Eastern Mediterranean, which I saw close up during my visit to Kurdistan a few days ago. And it’s not what you think.

headline: In Tough Market, Investment Banks Seek Shelter or Get Out
text: The world of Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and the rest of the investment banks is being remade, squeezed by new regulations and record low volatility in the markets.

headline: Montana: Prosecutors Agree to Improve Sex Assault Response
text: A standoff between the Justice Department and an elected county attorney in western Montana ended on Tuesday with an agreement under which local prosecutors promised to improve their response to sexual assault cases. The agreement came months after a lacerating report by federal authorities accused the Missoula County attorney’s office of gender bias in handling sexual assault cases. The county attorney, Fred Van Valkenburg, sued federal judiciary officials, arguing they had no right to investigate his office. Under the deal, that challenge is being dropped, and the attorney’s office has promised to set up new policies and training for sexual assault cases and to communicate better with victims and the police.

headline: Championship Experience, if Not a Championship Roster
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — From the time I left home Tuesday morning and walked down Edgecombe Avenue in the Sugar Hill neighborhood of Harlem, Knicks fans up and down the block were torn between buzzing and fretting over the news that Derek Fisher would be the Knicks’ new coach.

headline: Rangel’s Top Rival Stirs Up Deportation Debate
text: Signs that a congressional race has entered its final two weeks: dueling statements, accusations of outrageous behavior and liberal use of the words “desperate” and “unconscionable.”

headline: When Companies Close Doors to the Future
text: Should businesses be allowed to have new employees agree to sign noncompete deals? Is it unfair to workers or good for business?

headline: Order for Microsoft to Disclose Data Stored Outside of U.S.
text: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force it to hand over a customer’s e-mail stored in one of its overseas data centers.

headline: Another Voice Joins Chorus for Fair Pay
text: The rent is $1,187 for the walk-up apartment on East 117th Street in Manhattan where Solomon Perez, 30, lives with his wife and their 2-year-old daughter. He delivers food for Indus Valley, an Indian restaurant on the Upper West Side, making $5.25 an hour plus tips. Mr. Perez said the restaurant takes a cut of about 10 percent of the tips in online orders, like ones that come through Seamless, the Internet food-delivery hub.

headline: A Fight as U.S. Girls Face Genital Cutting Abroad
text: ATLANTA — Last summer, an American-born teenager of Somali descent fled her parents’ home in a suburb here after she discovered that a coming vacation to Somalia would include a sacred rite of passage: the cutting of her genitalia. In Guinea, a New Yorker escaped to the American Embassy after an aunt told her that her family trip would involve genital cutting. And in Seattle, at least one physician said parents had sent girls back to Somalia to undergo cutting.

headline: New York City Hotel Workers’ Contract May Grow More Lucrative
text: Workers may be protesting against low wages all around the country, but unionized hotel employees in New York City are not sharing the pain. They have just been offered an additional series of raises that would lift a maid’s annual pay to nearly $70,000 in 10 years.

headline: 3-0 Hole Rangers Inhabit? Only 5 of 320 Teams Have Overcome It
text: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault was subdued and downcast Tuesday, like most of his players, standing on the brink of elimination, peering grimly into the abyss.

headline: L.I.R.R. Popularity Led to Crush After the Belmont
text: A little over three weeks ago, the Long Island Rail Road had a lot of money riding on a horse race in Baltimore.

headline: Exhausted and Bereft, Iraqi Soldiers Quit Fight
text: BAGHDAD — The infantryman and his colleagues were already worn down after six months of fighting militants in western Iraq, men flush with weapons and zeal. Army commanders had no answer for the daily deadly ambushes and no broader strategy for prevailing in the longer war.

headline: Help for Referees, in a Can
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Even casual soccer fans may already be familiar with the sport’s infamous “magic spray,” the ubiquitous mist that team trainers use on seemingly every type of injury to help stricken — or, as they are occasionally known, faking — players recover from grave maladies without missing a single kick.

headline: Eric Cantor Aside, Immigration Is Unlikely to Dominate Politics
text: Eric Cantor’s defeat will most likely lead to a round of speculation about the dominant role that immigration may play in the midterm elections and the 2016 presidential campaign. But you should view that speculation with a somewhat skeptical eye, because immigration has rarely determined the outcome of national elections.

headline: Netflix Orders New Children’s Show Based on ‘Magic School Bus’
text: Continuing the expansion of its original content for children, Netflix has ordered a new series based on Scholastic Media’s “Magic School Bus,” the long-running television series that encouraged young people to pursue science.

headline: A Troubled Son (or Is He Wicked?) Is Just the Start of a Family’s Trouble
text: Your sympathies are constantly shifting as you watch “Our New Girl,” a drama by the Irish-born writer Nancy Harris that cross-pollinates two very different genres. On the one hand, Ms. Harris’s London-set play, which opened at the Atlantic Theater Company’s smaller stage on Tuesday night, is a serious study of a well-heeled but harassed contemporary woman trying to keep her marriage and family from fraying. At the same time, Ms. Harris stocks her play with the classic elements of a thriller: a sullen child who may harbor violent impulses, a comely nanny who may not be as innocent as she appears.

headline: Athena’s Counterpart
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There is absolutely nothing wrong with this puzzle. It is a light-hearted and amusing tribute to June 14’s Flag Day holiday, and Ian Livengood’s puzzle offers us a chance to identify the prominent features of the flags of four countries. So far, so good.

headline: Former Ambassador to Syria Urges Increasing Arms Supply to Moderate Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Ford’s misgivings about the Obama administration’s policy toward Syria became so great last summer that he sought to leave his post as the senior United States envoy for Syria.

headline: Careening Into a Bottomless Vortex
text: Greta Gerwig turns out to be the perfect person to ride right over the edge of a cliff with. Now don’t say you haven’t been warned. Because over the cliff is where this surprising actress will have taken you by the end of “The Village Bike,” the genuinely daring new play by Penelope Skinner that opened on Tuesday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: Eric Cantor’s Voting Record: Angering Allies Is Part of the Job
text: As majority leader, Eric Cantor was charged with running the House and electing his Republican colleagues. The tension between the two caused him to schedule, and to vote for, some legislation that angered the conservative base.

headline: No Body Is Found, but a Man Is Charged With Murder
text: Ramona Moore chatted with a neighbor outside their Bronx homes one July day in 2012. As the story goes, she was eating a mango, and when she saw that her neighbor wanted one, too, she went inside to get one. The neighbor never saw her again.

headline: Coast Cleared by Others, W.N.B.A. Finally Finds Its Gay Pride
text: When Brittney Griner, the No. 1 pick in the 2013 W.N.B.A. draft, heard about her league’s new campaign to market games to people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender, she said, “What are we going to have, T-shirts, shoes?”

headline: Emergency Housing Unit Is Unveiled in Brooklyn
text: In the months after Hurricane Sandy, thousands of New Yorkers faced a daunting search for temporary housing. The supply of vacant apartments ran dry. Cramped hotel rooms prolonged a sense of limbo. Many people just stayed put in dank, waterlogged houses.

headline: Elodie Lauten, Who Wove Opera From Allen Ginsberg’s Poetry, Dies at 63
text: Elodie Lauten, an American composer known for her operatic setting of the work of Allen Ginsberg, died on June 3 in Manhattan. She was 63.

headline: Success Academy Seeks 14 More Charter Schools in New York City
text: A charter school network that recently clashed with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the use of public school space is seeking to vastly expand its footprint in New York City, announcing on Tuesday that it wants to open 14 more schools over the next two years.

headline: Kidd and Fisher Carve New Niche for Veterans: Coach’s Office
text: MIAMI — In the middle of a championship series that has featured several senior N.B.A. citizens, including San Antonio’s 38-year-old spiritual and strategic centerpiece, Tim Duncan, the hiring on Tuesday of Derek Fisher, 39, to coach the Knicks did not go unnoticed.

headline: Bob Welch, Pitching Ace and Prototype for Today’s Power Arms, Dies at 57
text: Bob Welch, a flame-throwing right-hander for the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Oakland A’s who overcame alcoholism to win 211 games, including 27 in 1990, a single-season total no other pitcher has reached in the past 40 years, died on Monday in Seal Beach, Calif. He was 57.

headline: The Circus That Doesn’t Leave Town
text: The circus is in town, but this big tent has nothing to do with Ringling Brothers or trained lions and elephants. Instead it is the carnival theme popping up across New York City in unexpected ways and in unexpected places: acrobats twirling over patrons in downtown nightclubs, men in leotards juggling mud at $475 dinner theater shows in Midtown, gyms offering “circus yoga,” school children learning about clowning in different cultures, and fire breathers spitting flames onto tin ceilings at bars in Brooklyn.

headline: Michael Schmidt, 68, Maker of Photographic Narratives, Dies
text: The German photographer Michael Schmidt was known for presenting stark black-and-white images in dramatic sequence, to powerful emotional effect. A recent project was a penetrating tour of the global food industry that included arresting images of factory farms, a cow’s bulging udder, supermarkets and a single apple. It won an international award just days before Mr. Schmidt’s death on May 24 in Berlin. He was 68.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 10, 2014
Overlooked in Mets’ Focus on the Future, a Nice Victory
text: A certain inevitability hangs over the Mets. Once the season begins to crumble, the future rapidly becomes the present. When the Mets arrived home Sunday after an 11-game trip, in the middle of a six-game losing streak, they appeared to have reached that point more quickly than they had expected.

headline: Bank of America and the Financial Crisis
text: Bank of America, including Countrywide, issued about $640 billion in mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.

headline: ISIS: Behind the Group Overrunning Iraq
text: Background on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Islamist group that gained control of the second-largest city in Iraq.

headline: Cantor’s Loss a Bad Omen for Moderates
text: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership, so solid in its opposition to President Obama, was torn apart Tuesday by the defeat of its most influential conservative voice, Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader. His demise will reverberate all the way to the speaker’s chair, pull the top echelons of the House even further to the right and most likely doom any ambitious legislation, possibly through the next presidential election.

headline: Tanaka Follows Iwakuma, Then Sets Himself Apart
text: SEATTLE — When Masahiro Tanaka went from high school into the Japanese professional leagues with the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles in 2007, his mentor was the team’s ace and best player, Hisashi Iwakuma.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: It’s a Turducken
text: Season 1, Episode 9: Gasp. Lester Nygaard’s transformation is stunningly complete.

headline: The Downward Ramp
text: With the bursting of the tech bubble at the start of the 21st century, two decades of growth at the high end of the job market — once the province of college graduates with strong cognitive abilities — came to an abrupt halt, according to detailed studies of employment and investment patterns by three Canadian economists. We are still feeling the ramifications.

headline: The Franchising of Architecture
text: As leading architects race to put their visual signatures on every nook and cranny of the world, one critic wonders whether globalization is really such a good thing.

headline: Overestimating How Hard We Exercise
text: Most of us know that moderate exercise is good for us. But surprisingly few of us know what moderate exercise means, research shows. An instructive new study found that many of us underestimate how hard we should exercise to achieve maximum health benefits, and overestimate how vigorously we are actually working out.

headline: New York Comic Con Branching Out From Javits Center
text: Its name may emphasize comic books, but New York Comic Con at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in October also celebrates film, television and video games. ReedPop, which organizes the show, is making that appreciation of all things pop culture more official by declaring Oct. 3-12 “New York Super Week,” a citywide festival that will include gaming events, lectures, concerts, comedy shows and more.

headline: Word of the Day | transition
text: transition •\tran(t)-ˈsi-shən, tran-ˈzi-\• noun and verb

headline: The Old Is New Again at E3 for Sony and Microsoft
text: LOS ANGELES – Many music and movie fans of a certain age are accustomed to buying the same works again and again as technologies change.

headline: Spurs Set Blazing Pace and Hang On Late
text: MIAMI — Within minutes of taking the court at American Airlines Arena on Tuesday night, the San Antonio Spurs demolished a 23-year-old record for offensive efficiency.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (Spike TV) GUYS CHOICE 2014 This awards ceremony, taped on Saturday at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, Calif., honors the things men like most, as voted by viewers. Sandra Bullock (above left) is celebrated for a Decade of Hotness; Matthew McConaughey (above right) is Guy of the Year; Kevin Hart is King of Comedy; and Rihanna is the Most Desirable Woman.

headline: Members of Congress React to Cantor’s Defeat Via Twitter
text: Representative Eric Cantor’s defeat in Tuesday night’s primary election in Virginia was a major jolt to congressional politics. Among those reacting on Twitter to the defeat of the House majority leader were a number of his colleagues in the House of Representatives and Senate.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 11, 2014
text: “The results tonight will move the party further to the right, which will marginalize us further as a national party.”

headline: Gabriel Kolko, Left-Leaning Historian of U.S. Policy, Dies at 81
text: Gabriel Kolko, an influential left-leaning historian who argued that American domestic and international policies have long been driven more by the interests of big business than by the interests of the people, died on May 19 at his home in Amsterdam. He was 81.

headline: Jeter Starts Two Rallies and Ellsbury Caps a Victory
text: SEATTLE — Derek Jeter played his first major league game just a few hundred yards outside the walls of Safeco Field, in the long since demolished Kingdome.

headline: Fall of an Apparatchik
text: Wow — Eric Cantor lost his primary, by a large margin. Amazing.

headline: Morning Views
text: Noncompete clauses are harmful to both employees and “the economy as a whole,” writes The New York Times editorial board. While the board recognizes these policies have reasonable utility in deterring upper management from defecting to competitors, the restrictions can be needlessly hampering to lower-wage employees who statistically earn more money over the years the more professional freedom they enjoy. More broadly, The Times points to studies showing that gratuitously stringent noncompete policies stifle entrepreneurship.

headline: Beijing Police Detain Student Over Tiananmen Tweet
text: The Beijing authorities have detained a woman linked with a Twitter posting suggesting that a method for sending spam text messages might also be used to rally public awareness of the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement.

headline: Paul Takes On Clinton Over Her ‘Dead Broke’ Comments
text: WASHINGTON – Senator Rand Paul dismissed comments from Hillary Rodham Clinton that she and her husband were struggling to make ends meet after they left the White House, saying they were “disconnected.”

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
text: LONDON — Europe’s taxi drivers on Wednesday picked a fight with Uber, an increasingly popular smartphone car-paging service, and dared consumers to choose sides.

headline: Where Eric Cantor Won and Lost
text: Map of the results and charts of his margins in previous elections.

headline: In American Journalist’s Photographs, Rare Glimpse of India’s First Prime Minister
text: In January 1952, Margaret Lee Weil, a 30-year-old journalist and photographer, arrived in India to pursue her dream of catching a glimpse of the man whom she had “hero-worshipped from 10,000 miles away all these years,” according to a particularly effusive diary entry.

headline: Emirates Cancels Major Order From Airbus
text: PARIS — Airbus suffered a major blow on Wednesday to its latest commercial jet program after one of its largest customers, Emirates Airline, said it had decided to cancel a multibillion-dollar order for 70 long-range planes.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 11, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
text: In “Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul,” Suadad Al-Salhy, Kareem Fahim and Rick Gladstone report on how Iraq’s second-biggest city was seized in a rapid assault by insurgents.

headline: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
text: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants consolidated and extended their control over northern Iraq on Wednesday, seizing Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein, threatening the strategic oil refining town of Baiji and pushing south toward Baghdad, their ultimate target, Iraqi sources said.

headline: Mac and Cheese for Fancy People
text: An old hardcover copy of “The Escoffier Cook Book” sits in the library of The New York Times, battered and dog-eared, classified on its front endpaper by someone with exquisite penmanship as a book to be shelved amid titles dedicated to “Foreign Foods.”

headline: There’s a True Story Behind ‘The Mule’: The Sinaloa Cartel’s 90-Year-Old Drug Mule
text: The Lincoln pickup truck with Iowa plates was hurtling down Interstate 94, headed for Detroit. A dozen D.E.A. officers in unmarked cars were scattered along a 70-mile stretch, from Kalamazoo to Jackson, Mich. From on-ramps and overpasses, they watched traffic flash by as they tried to spot the truck. They believed it was carrying a major shipment of cocaine.

headline: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
text: When I was young, and my little sister a bit younger, we went on a trip to China. We were visiting its famous Great Wall when, to our puzzlement, Chinese tourists began queuing up — ignoring the thousands-miles-long wonder of the world to photograph two arguably lesser wonders of the world: my sister and me.

headline: Does the Way Your Classroom Is Decorated Affect Your Learning?
text: A new study tries to determine whether there might be a correlation between how a room is decorated and kindergartners’ learning. The researchers wanted to know if too many decorations could actually be distracting or overstimulating for young minds. But similar questions could be asked about how classroom environment might influence older students’ academic performance as well.

headline: Where ISIS Is Gaining Control in Iraq and Syria
text: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria — an organization once part of Al Qaeda — has effectively gained control of large swaths of Iraq and Syria over the past year.

headline: Lufthansa Trims Profit Forecast for 2 Years
text: PARIS — Lufthansa on Wednesday sharply reduced its profit forecasts for the next two years, citing slower than expected recovery in demand for its passenger and cargo services, as well as the fallout from widespread strikes earlier this year.

headline: Hagel Defends Bergdahl Trade as a Part of Waging War
text: WASHINGTON — A defiant Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday defended the prisoner exchange that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl after years of captivity with the Taliban, telling skeptical lawmakers that the decision had been kept secret from Congress because leaks could have scuttled the deal or increased risks to the soldier before the swap.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Not on My Home Ice
text: Good morning to you on this dreary Wednesday.

headline: Beijing’s ‘White Paper’ Sets Off a Firestorm in Hong Kong
text: In December 1984, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China signed a document in Beijing pledging to restore Hong Kong to Chinese control. One of the basic policies laid out in the declaration was that while Hong Kong would be “directly under the authority of” Beijing, it would “enjoy a high degree of autonomy except in foreign and defense affairs.”

headline: Beacon, N.Y.: Quaint City Rediscovered
text: Hats, carpets, baby carriages, shower doors, cookie cartons: These are among the many products made, at one point or another, in Beacon, a small city hugging the Hudson in southwestern Dutchess County. Because of them, said Clara Lou Gould, who was the mayor from 1990 to 2007, “people with expertise in different categories would come to do different jobs” and stay on, resulting in a population representing as many as 50 nationalities.

headline: Campaign to Crack Down on Fringe Sects in China Worries Mainstream Churches
text: BEIJING — Last month, as she waited for her husband and 7-year-old son at a McDonald’s in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong, Wu Shuoyan was approached by members of a Christian sect who were on an aggressive recruitment drive.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Challenges Federal Warrant for Data Stored Overseas
text: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customer’s email stored in a data center in Ireland, Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Tax Breaks for Apple and Starbucks Investigated by E.U.
text: BRUSSELS — European Union officials have been pushing some countries to plug corporate tax loopholes for years to help bolster government coffers in an era of shrinking public budgets and weak economic growth.

headline: An Artist Fills Galleries With Emptiness
text: LONDON — “You look suspicious,” Marina Abramovic said to an older couple standing to the side of a room in the Serpentine Gallery here on Thursday. The couple looked, well, suspicious, as around them people contemplated panels of bright primary colors, or lay on the floor, eyes closed. Ms. Abramovic took them by the hand, gently asked them to close their eyes, and led them away, walking with a slow, measured tread.

headline: Banks Fear Missing Collateral in China
text: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Large banks and trading firms are frantically trying to determine whether they have fallen victim to a suspected commodities fraud emanating from the giant Qingdao Port in northeast China.

headline: The Father’s Day Audit
text: At the end of each year, I get my financial statements so I can assess how my business did. And each Father’s Day I take a moment to think about how I did over the previous year as a father.

headline: Your Personality Type, Defined by the Internet
text: In some ways, the Internet has become a game of “type and be typed.” Now you can play it at home, too.

headline: Report Links Wen Family to Cambridge Professorship
text: A foundation that endowed a professorship at the University of Cambridge is linked to the family of the former Chinese prime minister Wen Jiabao, according to a report in The Daily Telegraph.

headline: HSBC Sells British Pension Business to Swiss Re Unit
text: LONDON – The British bank HSBC said on Wednesday that one of its subsidiaries had sold its pension business in Britain to a unit of the insurer Swiss Re.

headline: 1964: East Bloc Working to Win Bigger Share of Tourism
text: LONDON — All the Communist powers, apart from Albania and East Germany, are making a concerted drive to win a bigger share of the riches of the international tourist industry. Since the start of 1964 newspapers in Britain and Western Europe have been carrying a regular and impressive display of Communist tourist advertisements.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Cantor’s Stunning Loss
text: Good Wednesday morning from a Washington that awoke stunned by a primary election upset for the ages.

headline: Hong Kong Media Worries Over China’s Reach as Ads Disappear
text: HONG KONG — In what may be a major escalation of pressure by mainland China on Hong Kong’s independent-minded news media, two major British banks have stopped advertising with one of the city’s biggest newspapers, a top media executive said.

headline: Japan Protests Chinese Flybys Over East China Sea
text: TOKYO — Japan protested to Beijing on Wednesday after Chinese fighter jets flew within 100 feet of Japanese military planes in airspace claimed by both nations. Similar flybys in the same area took place several weeks ago.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton: By the Book
text: The former secretary of state and author of “Hard Choices” keeps copies of Republican memoirs like “Faith of My Fathers” and “Decision Points” on her shelves.

headline: George R. R. Martin Wants More ‘Game of Thrones,’ Too
text: The culture has a crush on George R. R. Martin’s writing these days, specifically his best-selling “A Song of Ice and Fire” series, the inspiration behind the hit HBO show “Game of Thrones,” whose fourth season ends Sunday night.

headline: OPEC to Hold Oil Output Steady as Turmoil Rocks Some Member States
text: LONDON — OPEC agreed on Wednesday to keep its petroleum production target at 30 million barrels a day for the rest of the year, a decision intended to calm global concerns about the supply and price of oil, despite increasing geopolitical tensions in some of the main supplier countries.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Rangers Win the Cup
text: The Times’s Bill Pennington reflects on the Rangers winning Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals against the Vancouver Canucks.

headline: 1994 in Sports: The Baseball Strike
text: Times staff reflect on the baseball strike of 1994.

headline: Groggy Mornings Ahead for China’s World Cup Fans
text: Despite not having a home team to cheer on, record numbers of Chinese soccer fans are expected to tune in to the 2014 FIFA World Cup early Friday local time — with some finding rather creative ways to get their football fix.

headline: App Smart | Mobile Blogging
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you keep your blog up to date from your phone or tablet.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Legacy of World Cup
text: The Times’s George Vecsey reflects on the impact the 1994 World Cup had on the United States.

headline: Mobile Blogging Options Simplify Storytelling on the Go
text: AS I write this column, I’m sitting in my favorite coffee shop. And instead of using my traditional computer setup, I’m writing on an Internet-connected iPad with blogging apps.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Yankees in First
text: The Times’s Bill Pennington reflects on the 1994 Yankees.

headline: 1994 in Sports: World Cup in America
text: The Times’s Bill Pennington and George Vecsey reflect on the 1994 World Cup.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Knicks Come Up Short
text: The Times’s William C. Rhoden and Bill Pennington reflect on the Knicks losing to the Houston Rockets in the N.B.A. Finals.

headline: Australia’s Graphic Cigarette Pack Warnings Appear to Work
text: SYDNEY — Australia’s landmark cigarette legislation banning logos and putting dire health warnings and graphic images of sick or dying smokers on packs seems to be working, data shows, even as tobacco companies argue business is better than ever.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Reflections on Simpson
text: The Times’s William C. Rhoden speaks about O.J. Simpson and the lessons learned from a tragic story.

headline: 1994 in Sports: World Cup in New York
text: The Times’s Jay Schreiber reflects on attending a World Cup match at Giants Stadium.

headline: 1994 in Sports: O.J. and the Bronco
text: The Times’s William C. Rhoden and Bill Pennington reflect on the O.J. Simpson Bronco chase from the summer of 1994.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Reggie vs. Spike
text: The Times’s George Vecsey and Jay Schreiber reflect on Reggie Miller’s performance against the Knicks during the playoffs.

headline: 1994 in Sports: Messier’s Guarantee
text: Mark Messier guaranteed a victory as the Rangers faced elimination in the Eastern Conference finals. The Times’s Bill Pennington, George Vecsey and Jay Schreiber reflect.

headline: Spanish Lawmakers Clear Way for King’s Abdication
text: MADRID — Lawmakers in Spain overwhelmingly approved on Wednesday an abdication law that paves the way for Crown Prince Felipe to ascend to the throne being vacated by his father, King Juan Carlos.

headline: Film to Fashion Is About to Get a Whole New Meaning
text: Why should “Frozen” and “The Little Mermaid” be the only films with sartorial merchandising potential? And why should fashion companies such as Prada, Brooks Brothers or Brioni be the brands that benefit from a film’s costume impact — see “The Great Gatsby” and all the Pierce Brosnan Bond films — instead of the filmmakers themselves?

headline: Manhattan Transfer
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Happenings | In Big Sur, Sunday Night Storytelling Under the Redwoods
text: “OK, you have an hour at your disposal,” says Magnus Toren, on the phone from Big Sur, Calif. “You’re in the dark. You’re steps from the Pacific Ocean, lying in the grass under a grove of redwoods, and all you can see are the stars overhead. What do you want to hear?”

headline: Uber-Inspired Handybook Raises $30 Million in Round Led by Revolution Growth
text: On the heels of a $1.2 billion investment in Uber last week, one of the start-ups that has taken inspiration from the car-ride company has raised a new round of capital as well.

headline: J. K. Rowling Donates £1 Million to Oppose Scottish Breakaway
text: LONDON — Likening hard-line Scottish separatists to some of her sinister fictional villains, the author J. K. Rowling has donated 1 million pounds to the campaign to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom.

headline: Evercore Hires Senior Banker for Energy Deals
text: The investment bank Evercore Partners has hired a senior banker to advise oil and gas companies on deals.

headline: Weighing the Risks of Investing in Energy Companies
text: LONDON — Norway’s economy is highly dependent on oil and gas production, yet the Nordic country’s largest private pension fund manager, Storebrand, worries about the risks of investing in companies that extract fossil fuels. Figuring that tighter regulations on carbon emissions will emerge in the coming years in an effort to combat climate change, Storebrand has decided not to invest in businesses that it believes will be hurt most by those new rules: coal companies and large producers of oil from tar sands.

headline: Once Snubbed, David Brat Turns the Tables
text: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, David Brat, a conservative economics professor, decided to have a go at politics, making a run for a seat in the Virginia House of Delegates. But the back-room deal makers of his Republican Party snubbed him for someone chosen by allies of Representative Eric Cantor, the majority leader.

headline: Cantor and Brat’s Election Speeches
text: Excerpts from the concession speech by Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia and the victory address by David Brat, the Tea Party candidate who won Virginia’s Republican primary.

headline: Lobbyists Connected to Eric Cantor Are About to Take a Pay Hit
text: House Majority Leader Eric Cantor’s stunning primary loss Tuesday night will reshape the landscape not only within the Republican caucus but on K Street as well. As Dave Brat, his primary challenger, highlighted in his campaign, Mr. Cantor had a close relationship with business lobbying groups like the Chamber of Commerce and the Business Roundtable.

headline: Cantor Resigns Leadership Post in Effort to Smooth House Transition
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, resigned as majority leader Wednesday, completing a precipitous fall after his stunning loss in a primary and setting off an internal battle to remake the upper ranks of House leadership.

headline: Leader in Austerity Push Appointed Head of Greek Central Bank
text: ATHENS — The next governor of Greece’s central bank will be Yannis Stournaras, a Greek economist and former finance minister who led a two-year austerity drive that stabilized the economy but fueled a social crisis.

headline: To Counter G.E., Japanese Company Mitsubishi May Join Siemens in Alstom Bid
text: PARIS — The German engineering conglomerate Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan said on Wednesday that they might bid jointly for Alstom, the French maker of power turbines and high-speed trains, as they seek to trump a rival $13.5 billion offer from General Electric.

headline: Is America’s Economy Stuck in the Doldrums? The Case for Optimism
text: One of the most important economic debates of our time is whether America’s economic machine is fundamentally broken. What should it tell us that growth has been considerably slower since 2000 than it was in the decades before? Or that in recent years the economy has felt healthy only during an unsustainable credit and housing bubble?

headline: Morning Agenda: An Impasse in Bank of America Settlement
text: BANK OF AMERICA SETTLEMENT DEADLOCKED  |  Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank’s role at the center of the mortgage crisis, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. The talks stalled on Monday after the bank’s latest offer, at more than $12 billion, was said to be far short of prosecutors’ demands. The Justice Department has sought a settlement worth roughly $17 billion, which would be the largest payout by any bank to date.

headline: In George V Show, Benson Meets the Beatles
text: The Four Seasons Hotel George V in Paris will showcase an iconic moment in music history with an exclusive exhibition of photographs of the Beatles.

headline: Some Rare Handel, and ‘Dracula,’ on Tap for Morgan Season

headline: D-Day Wasn’t the First Time Eisenhower Felt as if He Had Lost a Son
text: During this week between the 70th anniversary of D-Day and Father’s Day 2014 — next Sunday — here is one more observation about the supreme commander of Operation Overlord, Dwight Eisenhower.

text: This poem, by Emily Rigby, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest.

headline: A Tug-of-War of Tax Breaks Tightens Across the Hudson
text: Late last fall, bankers from BNY Mellon went to state officials in New York and New Jersey with a proposition: The bank was planning to sell its headquarters on Wall Street and was looking for office space on either side of the Hudson River for more than 1,100 employees.

headline: Recalling 1994 in Sports
text: The sports year of 1994 included two New York teams chasing a title, a World Cup, the O.J. Simpson scandal and a baseball strike. Times reporters and editors reflect on these events from 20 years ago.

headline: The Sports Summer of 1994
text: Twenty years after turning the sports world on its head, The New York Times revisits the most memorable moments from the summer of 1994. Our interactive timeline includes archival photography and video recollections from The Times’s George Vecsey, William C. Rhoden, Bill Pennington and Jay Schreiber.

headline: Broadway ‘Raisin’ Recoups
text: The Broadway revival of “A Raisin in the Sun,” the biggest box-office hit play of the spring theater season, has recouped its entire $4.25 million capitalization. The producers made the announcement on Tuesday, two days after Lorraine Hansberry’s classic reaped success at the 2014 Tony Awards. “Raisin” won for best play revival, best director of a play (Kenny Leon), and best featured actress in a play (Sophie Okonedo); its three Tonys were the most for any play in the 2013-14 season. The critically acclaimed production, which stars Denzel Washington and LaTanya Richardson Jackson, is scheduled to end its run on Sunday.

headline: Dave Chappelle Makes the Case for High Marginal Tax Rates
text: Dave Chappelle, the comedian who walked away from a wildly successful TV show named for him a decade ago, made his first talk show appearance in ages Tuesday night. He probably wasn’t intending to make an argument about maximizing the efficiency of the tax system in his appearance on the “Late Show With David Letterman,” but that’s what he ended up doing.

headline: Toyota Orders Big Recall Tied to an Air Bag Part
text: In a widening safety problem at one of the world’s largest auto suppliers, 2.3 million Toyota vehicles are being recalled worldwide because a defective air bag component made by Takata Corporation could injure passengers.

headline: What You Get for ... $2.5 Million
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: The Power to Cure, Multiplied
text: Ten years ago Dr. Sanjeev Arora, a hepatologist at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, realized that he would need to change the way he practiced medicine if he was going to prevent his patients from dying.

headline: Francesco Vezzoli’s Right You Are
text: Francesco’s first-ever performance for Performa was a remake of the famous play by Luigi Pirandello that took place at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Score!
text: Five new picture books to help get ready for the World Cup.

headline: “Bliss” by Ragnar Kjartansson
text: Kjartansson had his cast sing Mozart’s final aria from “The Marriage of Figaro” over and over for hours.

headline: In Chinatown, Remembering the Origins of a 126-Year-Old Synagogue
text: When visitors ask why a great synagogue was built in the middle of Manhattan’s Chinatown, it is clearly time for a history lesson.

headline: Jesper Just’s “True Love Is Yet to Come”
text: The Norwegian actor Baard Owe performed alongside a hologram-like projection of the actor Johannes Lileore.

headline: Mike Kelley at Performa, 2009
text: “Extracurricular Activity Projective Reconstruction #32, Plus” brought to life the figures that appeared in his 2005-6 video installation, “Day is Done” — vampires, dancing Goths and bodybuilders.

headline: Elmgreen & Dragset at Performa, 2011
text: Two English actors, Joseph Fiennes and Charles Edwards, played the artist duo in a performance.

headline: Jennifer Rubell at Performa, 2009
text: Jennifer’s Creation-themed dinner opened Performa 09 which took place on three floors of a building in Chelsea.

headline: “I Feel Your Pain” by Liz Magic Laser
text: Liz borrowed text from television and other media, showing how the news sounds in the mouths of young couples in a movie theater.

headline: House Hunting in ... Bermuda
text: A VILLA DESIGNED FOR ENTERTAINING

headline: Another School Day, Another School Shooting
text: In an all-too-familiar chain of events on Tuesday, a gunman armed with a rifle walked into Reynolds High School in Troutdale, Oregon, killed a 14-year-old student, Emilio Hoffman, and wounded a teacher, Todd Rispler. Later he was found dead by police, an apparent suicide.

headline: Egyptian Dissident Sentenced for Challenging Ban on Protest
text: One of Egypt’s most prominent dissidents, the blogger Alaa Abd El Fattah, was among three men arrested on Wednesday while waiting outside a court in Cairo to stand trial for violating the government’s ban on unsanctioned protests.

headline: Bringing Women to the Table to Address Sexual Violence
text: In war zones, rape is a weapon. We cannot claim to be serious about stopping war crimes if we do nothing to prevent and punish these heinous acts – and if women are not part of the solution every step of the way.

headline: In G.O.P., Far Right Is Too Moderate
text: The forces of political nihilism not only remain alive and well within the Republican Party, but they are on the rise. Witness the way they shook Washington on Tuesday by removing from power Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, who had been one of the most implacable opponents to the reform of immigration, health care and taxation. His crime (in addition to complacent campaigning)? He was occasionally obliged, as a leader, to take a few minimalist steps toward governing, like raising the debt ceiling and ending a ruinous shutdown.

headline: Dad’s Going to Hate Her New Novel
text: “The Who and the What,” opening Monday at the Claire Tow Theater as part of Lincoln Center Theater’s LCT3 program, is the new play from Ayad Akhtar, who won the Pulitzer Prize last year for “Disgraced.” That play, a tense dinner-party drama about the combustible combination of Islam and American culture, had also made its New York premiere under the LCT3 auspices.

headline: The Forgotten Generation
text: Amid America’s obsession with millennials (and their narcissism or lack thereof), the generation directly above them has been a bit left out. But by some measures, the economic uncertainty of the last few years may be hitting Generation X harder than anyone.

headline: Treasury Secretary Points to Lackluster Economy and a Need for Action
text: WASHINGTON — Has Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew just become the most prominent member of the secular stagnation club?

headline: On Beauty | A Dramatic Absence
text: As Ziggy Stardust and Queen Elizabeth knew, a bare brow — bleached, stripped or powdered to invisibility — can transform the face and everything it conveys to the world.

headline: Apollo Global Hesitant to Pursue Smaller Investors
text: Don’t expect to see Apollo Global Management, a major private equity firm, rushing to raise cash from Main Street investors.

headline: The Spurs Speak Out, in Different Languages
text: MIAMI — Tom James, senior director of communications for the multinational blend of united talent known as the San Antonio Spurs, was directing postgame news media traffic in the crowded intersection of a pitifully undersize visitors’ locker room at American Airlines Arena.

headline: European Union Investigates Tax Rulings
text: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Joaquín Almunia, announced the opening of three in-depth investigations into tax breaks affecting Apple, Starbucks and Fiat Finance and Trade.

headline: After Eric Cantor
text: During the government shutdown last year, I wrote a series of posts trying to explain why anyone interested in a healthy conservatism, a viable and serious Republican Party, should be somewhat ambivalent about the fight between the party’s insurgents and its congressional leadership. The insurgents pushed for the shutdown and the establishment resisted it, which meant that on the major question of the moment that establishment was right and the insurgents were not only wrong but utterly disconnected from reality. But in the bigger picture, the insurgents’ critique of the establishment’s lazy, K Street-oriented, “repeal the Medical device tax!” approach to policymaking was quite frequently correct, and it was noteworthy that some of the most prominent figures supporting the shutdown (Mike Lee, most notably, but also Marco Rubio and Rand Paul) were also sources of much of the party’s post-2012 policy innovation. So the post-shutdown scenario favored by many centrist observers in the media, in which John Boehner and Mitch McConnell just found a way to crush the grassroots and bring their base to heel, was not really a long-term solution to the G.O.P.’s lack of vision and seriousness. Instead — somehow, somewhere — the party would need to find leadership that could channel grassroots populism into a constructive agenda, without being captured by that populism’s follies and excesses.

headline: 5 Accused of Luring Men to Strip Clubs for a Night They Wouldn’t Remember
text: It seemed, at the time, to be an unlikely story.

headline: An Honest Answer From David Brat
text: When an MSNBC interviewer asked David Brat, the economics professor at Randolph-Macon College who toppled Eric Cantor in a primary challenge Tuesday, whether he opposed the minimum wage, he responded on Wednesday, “Um, I don’t have a well-crafted response on that one.”

headline: So, Who, Exactly, Is David Brat, the Guy Who Beat Eric Cantor?
text: I’m not the only one asking that question this morning after David Brat, an economics professor from Randolph-Macon College, defeated the House Majority Leader, Eric Cantor, in the primary in the 7th District of Virginia — with a tiny campaign budget and an unlimited willingness to represent Mr. Cantor’s record as too moderate for the Republican Party.

headline: In Kyoto, Tradition Meets Today
text: Accommodations rarely get more atmospheric than this: a 100-plus-year-old Kyoto townhouse that once housed maiko, or apprentice geisha, now thoroughly renovated to 21st-century standards trimmed in 1,000-year-old temple beams, antique art and tatami mats. On the banks of the Kamogawa River, the two-bedroom named  Kamogawa-tei (Kiyamachi Street; 81-75-354-7770) is one of six traditional townhouses known as machiya renovated by Aoi Kyoto Stay.

headline: Peter Mayle's Marseille
text: Provence, that languid, lavender-covered stretch of France along the Mediterranean, is the region most fans associate with Peter Mayle. His 1989 memoir, “A Year in Provence,” about restoring an 18th-century farmhouse in the Luberon, became such a blockbuster it spawned a veritable franchise of Provençal travelogues, food guides and novels. Indeed, Mr. Mayle said he and his wife had to leave the region for several years just to take a break from eager fans turning up at his doorstep (and from his detractors grumbling about those tourists disturbing the area’s tranquillity).

headline: Britain at the 2014 Venice Architecture Biennale
text: Organizers of the exhibition “A Clockwork Jerusalem” discuss the historic influences that shaped their presentation of modern British architecture. The Biennale opened on June 7 and will run until November 23.

headline: Lasagna with Red Chard Satisfies a Meat-Loving Family
text: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived — and to take advantage of a C.S.A. — a community-supported agriculture program — basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, the family was traveling, so they took their new plan with them.

headline: The World’s Game
text: A collection of images of fans and amateur players from around the world illustrates how everyday people embrace the spirit of soccer.

headline: Chappelle Clears Up the Mystery — Sort Of
text: Corporate bullying. Drugs. The illuminati. They have all played roles in the multitude of wild theories to explain why Dave Chappelle left his hit sketch show on Comedy Central in 2005. But on “Late Show With David Letterman” on Tuesday night, Mr. Chappelle offered grist for a new take on the controversy. “Technically, I never quit,” he joked. “I am seven years late for work.”

headline: Hagel on Bergdahl Trade at House Hearing
text: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl before the House Armed Services Committee.

headline: Egyptian Leader Apologizes to Victim of Sexual Assault in Tahrir Square
text: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt apologized on Wednesday to the victim of a mass sexual assault that took place in a crowd celebrating his election, declaring in a televised visit to her hospital bed that he urged every soldier, police officer and “chivalrous man” to eradicate such abuse.

headline: Google Streamlines Its Tools for Small Businesses
text: On Wednesday, Google announced the introduction of Google My Business, a streamlined platform for small businesses to use its tools. The platform allows businesses to update their information, add photos, share news and see reviews, all in one place.

headline: Alibaba Buys Rest of the Mobile Browser UCWeb
text: The Alibaba Group’s coming initial public offering has done little to dent its appetite for acquisitions. The Chinese e-commerce giant announced yet another takeover on Wednesday.

text: Parupalli Kashyap, an Indian badminton player, hitting a return shot while playing against Riichi Takeshita of Japan during a first round match in Tokyo, Japan.

headline: Potent Voices of Conservative Media Propelled Cantor Opponent
text: If Eric Cantor needed evidence that his political career was in real trouble, all he had to do was look outside his living room window one night last week. At a stately country club about half a mile from his home in the affluent Richmond suburb of Glen Allen, so many people had come to see the radio talk show host Laura Ingraham stump for Mr. Cantor’s opponent in the Republican primary, David Brat, that the overflow parking nearly reached his driveway.

text: The Pretenders’ frontwoman talks to Dave Itzkoff about inadvertently going solo for her new album, “Stockholm,” John McEnroe’s chops on guitar and her disgust with award shows.

text: Landscape architect Louis Benech and artist Jean-Michel Othoniel discuss the inspiration for their redesign of the Water Theater at Versailles and how trees have memories.

text: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A trio which smuggled goods between Belgium and France is caught in 1939; Mandela is arrested in 1964.

text: Metaspriggina swam the oceans more than 500 million years ago. Now its fossils are helping scientists understand how our own biology developed.

headline: In Bid for Botox Maker, Valeant Defends Its Record on Research
text: As it pursues a hostile takeover of Allergan, Valeant has reiterated time and again its belief that most pharmaceutical research and development doesn’t pay off.

headline: Goldman’s Blankfein Talks Energy and Politics
text: In a round of interviews this week, Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was eager to talk about natural gas drilling in advance of the bank’s energy summit, which began on Wednesday. But he was hesitant to throw his weight behind one of the most politically divisive issues in energy independence: the Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: Militants Storm Turkish Consulate in Iraqi City, Taking 49 People as Hostages
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government reacted with alarm on Wednesday to the seizure of the country’s consul general and his staff by militants in Mosul, Iraq, vowing to retaliate if any of its citizens are wounded.

headline: The Cantor Upset | The Upshot Countdown
text: The Upshot’s Nate Cohn explains just why Eric Cantor’s primary defeat was such a surprise, and why Republicans can expect to hold on to that district in November.

headline: Creating for Children, Without the Cutesy
text: The first show the Scottish theater artist Andy Manley brought to the New Victory Theater in Manhattan was “My House,” a mostly wordless solo piece co-starring a cardboard box and a wayward melon, designed for children 18 months to 3 years old. Next, he brought “White,” a beguiling, still largely nonverbal show about color and disorder, created for 2- to 4-year-olds.

headline: In Nature | The Gardener of Versailles
text: André Le Nôtre’s 17th-century masterpiece for Louis XIV has not been altered for centuries — until now. The renowned yet humble French landscape designer Louis Benech is reimagining the four-acre Water Theater, the Sun King’s favorite grove.

headline: ‘My Previous Bosses Are Now My Customers’
text: In 2002, Sherry Stewart Deutschmann quit her six-figure sales job at a Nashville company, cashed in her 401(k) and started a competing business.

headline: Before Army, P.O.W. Failed at Coast Guard Training
text: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl spent four weeks in basic training with the United States Coast Guard in early 2006 before he was given an administrative discharge, military officials said Wednesday. The disclosure raised new questions about whether Sergeant Bergdahl should have been allowed to enlist in the Army two years later, and whether he had to be given a waiver to join either because he had previously washed out of boot camp or because of concerns about his emotional fitness.

headline: How Eric Cantor’s Defeat Could Hurt Republican Fund-Raising
text: Eric Cantor’s primary defeat against David Brat on Tuesday means that House Republicans will lose one of their best fund-raisers, and a crucial link to some major donors the party is otherwise not close to.
