headline: Ukraine and Russia Still Far Apart on Gas Deal
text: BRUSSELS — Russia and Ukraine failed on Wednesday to end an acrimonious standoff over the price of natural gas supplied by the Russian energy giant Gazprom, dashing hopes that the election of a new Ukrainian president might ease a dispute that has long poisoned relations between Moscow and Kiev. The failure to reach a deal also raised concern in Europe that its own supplies of energy from Russia could be interrupted.

headline: Amazon Music Streaming Service Is Expected Soon
text: Amazon plans to introduce a limited music streaming feature as early as Thursday, according to several people briefed on its plans.

headline: For Father and Son, a Creative Tug of War
text: R.O. Blechman, an author and illustrator, has drawn for The Times for more than four decades. Today, he often works closely with his son Nicholas Blechman, the art director for the Book Review and an illustrator and designer himself, who came to The Times in 1997 as art director of the Op-Ed pages. Father’s Day is this weekend, so we asked the Blechmans to talk about their collaboration. Nicholas calls his father Bob. The R in his initials stands for Robert.

headline: Did Democratic Voters Defeat Eric Cantor? Probably Not
text: House Majority Leader Eric Cantor’s unexpected defeat has left many looking for equally unexpected answers. One suggestion is that his opponent, David Brat, was bolstered by Democratic crossover voters, who might have contributed to an increase in turnout from 2012. Mr. Cantor’s pollster, John McLaughlin, said the race was decided by Democratic voters.

headline: Blind Soccer in Brazil
text: Brazil’s visually disabled defy the odds by taking part in their country’s favorite pastime, soccer.

headline: Senate Race in Mississippi Exposes a Cultural Rift
text: JACKSON, Miss. — It is still not entirely clear what three supporters of the Tea Party favorite Chris McDaniel were doing locked in at 3 a.m. in a darkened courthouse where votes had been tabulated on the night of the state’s contentious primary election last week.

headline: Stabbing Suspect Indicted on Murder Charges
text: The man accused of the elevator stabbings that left a 6-year-boy dead and a 7-year-old girl critically wounded in Brooklyn was formally indicted on Wednesday on charges of murder, attempted murder, assault and weapons possession.

headline: The Democrats Still Have a Problem
text: So … I am aware that having the Republican House Majority Leader defeated by a no-name insurgent tends to cut against my ongoing argument, hotly contested by Jonathan Chait and others on the left, that the Democrats should be worried about their coalition holding together in the next presidential cycle. But because I’m stubborn, I’m going to celebrate Cantorgeddon by going one more round on the subject of whether President Obama’s approval ratings should be a cause of concern for his party, by responding to my colleague Nate Cohn’s contention that for now, at least, they shouldn’t be.

headline: Why Didn’t the Data-Driven Media See Eric Cantor’s Defeat Coming?
text: Was the coverage – or lack thereof – of Eric Cantor’s doomed campaign an epic fail by the media? Or was Mr. Cantor’s defeat just one of those inevitable surprises that keeps political junkies coming back for more?

headline: Would These Strategies Work With Your Employees?
text: In 2002, when Sherry Stewart Deutschmann quit her six-figure sales job at a Nashville company to start a competing business, she was convinced that her company would thrive if she could keep her employees engaged and committed. Today, that business, LetterLogic, which specializes in printing and mailing statements, invoices and letters, has $30 million in annual revenue and no debt.

headline: Disability Does Little to Impair Passion for Soccer
text: Visually disabled soccer players compete on regional squads with the hope of qualifying for Brazil’s paralympic team.

headline: Live Photos From the World Cup

headline: Italian Bank Hits Market Turbulence With Share Sale
text: PARIS – Shares of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the troubled Italian bank, plunged on Wednesday after going essentially untraded for two days as it undertook a stock sale that seeks to raise nearly $7 billion in new capital.

headline: Classical Playlist: Handel, George Benjamin, David Lang and Others
text: HANDEL: ‘Orlando’Bejun Mehta and other singers; René Jacobs, conductor; B’Rock Orchestra Ghent(Archiv Produktion; two CDs)For me, “Orlando” is Handel’s most innovative and psychologically astute opera, and one of his richest scores. The evocative story tells of Orlando, a renowned knight and crusader, who, weary of finding glory through combat, seeks meaning through love. He comes afoul of a magician who, determined to lead Orlando back to a life of valor, entices him into an enchanted forest where romantic involvements drive Orlando mad. Handel even gives us a mad scene in this opera. René Jacobs, the countertenor turned brilliant conductor, leads a crisp, stylish and immediate performance with the B’Rock Orchestra Ghent and an appealing cast, starring the countertenor Bejun Mehta in the title role, Sophie Karthäuser as his love interest Angelica, and Konstantin Wolff as the magician Zoroastro. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: World Cup Schedule and Results
text: The schedule, results and standings for the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Feeling For | Sustainable Surfboards Made in Maine, or in Your Own Garage
text: Before the advent of mass-produced polyurethane foam and fiberglass surfboards in the 1950s, the industry’s material of choice was durable, hand-hewn wood. Now, a pair of Maine-based craftsmen are seeking to bring the sport back to its roots. Armed with traditional wooden boat-building and fine cabinetry backgrounds, the Grain Surfboards founder Mike LaVecchia and his partner Brad Anderson have created an aesthetically pleasing range of boards that blend old-school materials and craftsmanship with modern shapes and techniques.

headline: Old Industry, Eclectic Styles in Eastern Market, Detroit
text: Sporting a vintage jumpsuit and her dad’s throwback frames, Lauren Stovall was channeling an era when Motown music ruled Detroit. Ms. Stovall was recently passing time in the city’s Eastern Market neighborhood, a diverse area with rich history that she finds inspirational. She is a self-proclaimed ’70s girl, a hippie at heart, and says comfort is her main approach to style. “Heels, I mean, yeah, they’re cool, but I just love like some unique flats,” Ms. Stovall said.

headline: How We Left Iraq
text: As a backgrounder on today’s grim news from Iraq — the most important news of the day, with apologies to David Brat — I’m just going to quote, without comment, from Dexter Filkins’ New Yorker piece today on the reasons the country has slid back into chaos and civil war:

headline: Roger Cohen: When to Read What I’ve Read
text: In a recent column, Roger Cohen wrote about re-reading Saul Bellow’s “Herzog,” 50 years after the book’s initial publication. He mentioned the idea that some books may be read too soon or too late in life. We asked him to elaborate:

headline: What Went Wrong for Eric Cantor
text: Jonathan Martin on the reasons behind Eric Cantor’s surprise defeat in Virginia. Was he just a weak candidate?

headline: Loeb Backs Management of Auction House Sotheby’s After Bruising Fight
text: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb gained three seats on the board of Sotheby’s only after one of the bitterest fights in recent corporate governance history.

headline: A Chicago Homecoming for Hillary Clinton on Her Book Tour
text: CHICAGO — Hillary Rodham Clinton chose her hometown for the first public forum during a nationwide tour to promote her new book. And she shared the stage with an old friend, Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

headline: Immigration: What Americans Think
text: Eric Cantor’s defeat has resulted in great speculation about the future of immigration politics.

headline: Intelligence Too Big for a Single Machine
text: Ever since the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in 1955, the field has gone through cycles of boundless optimism and sobering disillusion. Yet until recently, the supercomputer was the go-to operator of machine intelligence — both in science fiction (HAL, in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey”) and in reality (Watson, IBM’s “Jeopardy!” champ).

headline: European Firms Turn Privacy Into Sales Pitch
text: LONDON — Timo Laaksonen wants to look after your online data.

headline: Wheelies: The Porsche Martini Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: In Modern Marketing, a Big Dose of Data in the Creative Juices
text: On “Mad Men” this spring, the plot hinged on whether the creative types like Don Draper could adjust to the newfangled device in the office — a gigantic computer.

headline: Two Activists in Mormon Church Threatened With Excommunication
text: Two Mormons who have gained national attention for pushing their church to ordain women to the priesthood and to accept openly gay members have been notified this week that they face excommunication for apostasy.

headline: Cloud Computing: A Special Section
text: An inside look at how technology is remaking an industry, lowering costs for some and handing even more influence to a handful of powerful companies.

headline: Campaign-Finance Challenge in Alaska Senate Race
text: Dan Sullivan, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Alaska, says he will disavow all support from outside special interests if his opponent, Senator Mark Begich, a Democrat, agrees to do the same.

headline: Resort Trends
text: From Derek Lam’s ’60s/’70s-inspired dresses to minimally white Balenciaga shirtdresses, here are a few of the trends that emerged for resort season.

headline: Managing ‘Play-Doh’
text: John von Schmid, sculpture manager of the Jeff Koons studio, demonstrates how a part of the sculpture “Play-Doh” (1994–2014) will get through the front door of the Whitney for its Koons retrospective.

headline: De Blasio’s Approval Rating Improves, Poll Finds
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, freed from the torments of a harsh winter and working to put early stumbles behind him, has improved his reputation among New Yorkers, with a slim majority now saying they approve of his performance in City Hall, according to a poll released on Wednesday.

headline: Carolina Herrera Resort 2015
text: Ms. Herrera showed a collection of organza ball gowns and long silk dresses.

headline: Ralph Lauren Resort 2015
text: Mr. Lauren showed a collection of navy-and-white polka-dot and striped classics with eye-poppingly unabashed accents of gold.

headline: Michael Kors Resort 2015
text: Mr. Kors showed sweet white eyelet dresses, sable-lined anoraks and tie-dyed suede flares.

headline: Lanvin Resort 2015
text: The collection included a studded suede tank and not-quite-matching leather skirt.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg Resort 2015
text: The collection included a multitude of flared trousers.

headline: Louis Vuitton Resort 2015
text: Louis Vuitton’s inaugural resort presentation of neat silhouettes with look-at-me prints.

headline: Think Big. Build Big. Sell Big.
text: On a spring afternoon with his first major retrospective in New York looming, the artist Jeff Koons, nattily dressed in navy blue from head to toe, calmly boarded a helicopter heading for a foundry in upstate New York. His mission was to check up on his “Play-Doh,” a monumental sculpture depicting the squidgy material ubiquitous in American playrooms.

headline: Zeppelin Hits the Top 10; Miranda Lambert at No. 1
text: Miranda Lambert’s acclaimed new album, “Platinum” (RCA Nashville), opened at No. 1 this week with 180,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Gucci Resort 2015
text: The collection included pastel cashmeres and oversize sailor bottoms.

headline: Chanel Resort 2015
text: The collection included bouquets of bouclés and florals.

headline: The Weight of the World Rests on Brazil
text: BUENOS AIRES — For all its ability to excite and surprise, the World Cup has a tendency to be a conservative affair. The early group matches usually fulfill the heightened expectation — allowing the minnows of the tournament to have access to a world stage usually denied them — but the knockout phases are where a certain soccer order is restored.

headline: Does Marriage Protect Women Against Violence?
text: W. Bradford Wilcox and Robin Fretwell Wilson started a social-media firestorm Tuesday when they offered a prescription for lessening violence against women: marriage.

headline: Let the Soccer Drama Begin
text: The top players are here (mostly), the stadiums are ready (sort of) and preparation time is up: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday. After Brazil takes center stage in São Paulo (yes, Croatia will be there, too, but all eyes will be on the host), the two biggest heavyweight fights of the first round arrive in short order: Spain versus the Netherlands on Friday and England versus Italy on Saturday. So settle in for the next month and enjoy.

headline: Truck Driver Pleads Not Guilty in Tracy Morgan Car Crash
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The Walmart truck driver whose tractor-trailer slammed into a van carrying the comedian Tracy Morgan, critically injuring Mr. Morgan and killing another passenger, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a New Jersey courtroom.

headline: RoseLee Goldberg Shares Her Favorite Moments From Performa
text: The article “The Second Life of Performance,” from T’s culture issue, explores the increasing ubiquity of live art and the role of RoseLee Goldberg in its growing popularity. Ten years ago, the curator and art historian founded Performa, the New York biennial dedicated to the practice, which has influenced museums around the world. Here, Goldberg shares her favorite moments from Performa’s decade-long history.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Fly by Night’
text: Michael McCormick and Adam Chanler-Berat in a scene from the new musical at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: San Jose Repertory Theater Closes Down
text: The San Jose Repertory Theater, one of the biggest theaters in Silicon Valley, announced on Wednesday that it had shut down.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen
text: Jody Adams is sole owner of Rialto, a 20-year fixture on Harvard Square in Boston’s Charles Hotel.

headline: An Astute Waif Hopscotching Through Time
text: Tom Rachman’s ingenious second novel, “The Rise and Fall of Great Powers,” is harder to describe than “The Imperfectionists,” his sensational first. So here is some sample dialogue, by way of introduction. Humphrey, an older man with a heavy Russian accent, is explaining Russian history to Tooly, an eager 10-year-old girl who will grow up to become the book’s tough, quick-witted main character and the most important person in Humphrey’s life.

headline: Investors Wary of Putting Money Where the Cloud Is
text: Box, the Silicon Valley cloud storage company run by 29-year-old Aaron Levie, was on the cusp of going public earlier this year. Until it wasn’t.

headline: Work Sheds Mythic Aura as It Dons New Clothes
text: SEATTLE — Peter Boal, artistic director of Pacific Northwest Ballet, staged a revelatory “Giselle” for that company here in 2011. Yet “Giselle” is danced everywhere. So what needed to be revealed?  In truth, the basic text of this central work is in a terrible state all ’round the world. (The same is true for most 19th-century ballet classics, alas. No classic play, opera or concert work is presented today laden with anachronistic and showy changes that are standard for the 19th-century ballets.)

headline: A Season That Defies Its Own Description
text: So we come to the end of that interminable, puzzling, ill-defined women’s wear season that is known as pre-spring — or almost the end, to be absolutely accurate; there are a few more shows dribbling out after the men’s wear spring 2015 collections begin in London this weekend. But you have to draw a line somewhere. And having drawn it, we are left with ... what exactly?

headline: A Mesh of Sounds
text: An alluring array of sounds filled St. Paul’s German Lutheran Church in Manhattan on Tuesday evening during a performance of the Brazilian-born composer Felipe Lara’s “Voz de Ventos” (“Voices of the Winds”), part of the imaginative Chelsea Music Festival. Mr. Lara advised the audience not to turn around and watch the clarinetist Danny Goldman, the flutist Caitlyn Phillips and the bassoonist Brad Balliett as they played in a balcony at the back of the church, but to focus instead on how the music traveled in space.

headline: Sutter, Given Plenty of Reasons to Boast by Kings, Deflects Praise Instead
text: News conferences featuring Los Angeles Kings Coach Darryl Sutter are works of art.

headline: Experts Say a Matisse in a Munich Art Trove Should Go to Its Owner’s Heirs
text: BERLIN — A 1921 portrait by Matisse found in the private collection of the reclusive Cornelius Gurlitt was looted by the Nazis from a prominent French art collector and should be returned to his heirs, a team of international experts said on Wednesday.

headline: G.E. May Still Hold Upper Hand in Alstom Bid
text: Siemens is smart to team up with its Japanese engineering peer Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in a potential bid for Alstom’s power assets. But this probably won’t be enough for Siemens to overcome rival interest from General Electric.

headline: Hotels Get in the World Cup Spirit
text: A number of United States hotels are offering themed packages to coincide with the FIFA World Cup, held in Brazil from June 12 to July 13 this year.

headline: Even Early Adopters See Major Flaws in the Cloud
text: The C.I.A. isn’t afraid of the cloud.

headline: New Yorkers Chosen for Grand National Teams
text: Each district of the American Contract Bridge League qualifies one team to play in the final stage of the Grand National Teams. This is held at the beginning of the Summer North American Championships, taking place this year in Las Vegas next month..

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: 1 Day
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. This is the final installment of the World Cup countdown.

headline: In Fela’s Spirit, His Son Keeps Afrobeat Bristling
text: When Seun Kuti had his shirt off, dancing through the end of a sweaty, magnificently funky set at the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night, the tattoo across his muscular shoulders was visible: “Fela Lives.”

headline: A World of Hurt, and Films Still Able to Share Its Pain
text: Images of the horrors of war are so ubiquitous in the age of the camera phone that they threaten to overwhelm and desensitize us. For movie critics who are exposed more than many people to this barrage of carnage, the impulse after a while is to withdraw into a protective shell of world-weary cynicism.

headline: A Colonial Inn Adds a Piece of Victoriana
text: Last month, Patrick O’Connell, the chef and proprietor of the Inn at Little Washington, a clutch of historic buildings in Washington, Va., added the Parsonage to his complex. He did not restore this two-story house, with its six guest rooms, to its original 1850 décor. Instead, he recreated “the feeling of a grand old family home so that a guest room doesn’t feel like a hotel room,” he said. Built in the Colonial style, the building (across the street from the inn) later was “Victorianized,” to borrow Mr. O’Connell’s verb. And its décor has remained that way, though the palette was lighter than one usually finds in Victorians. The exterior and the porch facing a courtyard are painted green with cream accents. Interior walls are pale or papered in light colors, including the walls flanking a window seat in a second-floor guest room. Rooms start at $575 a night. Information: 540-675-3800 or theinnatlittlewashington.com.

headline: Is a Steam Shower Worth the Expense When It’s Time to Sell?
text: Q. Is a steam shower worth the expense when it’s time to sell?

headline: Note to Forgers: Don’t Forget the Spell Check
text: When angry collectors started suing Knoedler & Company for selling dozens of multimillion-dollar forgeries, the gallery’s former president, Ann Freedman, insisted that she and her colleagues had had no reason to think that any of the paintings were counterfeit.

headline: And the Rhubarb Is Easy
text: When it comes to decorating, entertaining and parenting, David Duplantis and Christopher Nordquist make everything look so effortless and appealing, it’s hard not to feel inadequate in comparison.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Company C and OLighting
text: Broadway Panhandler is discounting some knives, cookware and kitchen tools by up to 70 percent, through Sunday (a Cuisinart Vintage 3-quart copper mixing bowl, originally $100, is about $30; a Wüsthof Classic forged fork-tip serrated tomato knife, originally $100, is about $40; a Le Creuset 4.25-quart cast-iron soup pot in select colors, originally $360, is about $140); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway); 212-966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Sky’s the Limit on Game Videos Online
text: Thanks to cloud computing, your local youth soccer league may someday play a 12-and-under version of “Moneyball.”

headline: Feeling For | The Adorable Daughter of Hugo Guinness, and Her Bunnies
text: Most know Hugo Guinness as the British artist whose whimsical drawings, paintings and linocut prints — of everything from inky florals to a playful pair of men’s undies — line the walls of John Derian’s dreamland-like shops in downtown Manhattan, not to mention some of the city’s best-appointed homes. But to his 12-year-old daughter Violet, he is simply dad. And though he doesn’t enjoy the company of his younger daughter’s two pet rabbits, Blackie and Odette, as much as she does — he laments that one bites, while both “pee everywhere and poop everywhere and they never stop eating, and we’ve got them for another 12 years” — he adores Violet’s fondness for them.

headline: ‘Bridesmaids’ Writers Team Up for New Comedy
text: LOS ANGELES — Since 2011, when “Bridesmaids” became a global hit and expanded the range of female-driven comedy, Hollywood has been desperate for its screenwriters, Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, to team again on another big movie.

headline: The Great Digital-Friendly Outdoors
text: Time was when people took to the forest for the weekend with dreams of solitude.

headline: Glass Accessories: Showing Their Strength
text: Sebastian Herkner uses lots of different materials in the furnishings he makes for companies like ClassiCon, Moroso and Rosenthal. But glass has always held a special appeal for him.

headline: With a Bit of Planning, Keep the Cloud With You Always — Even Offline
text: Cloud computing may seem incompatible with being offline, but there are ways to live in the cloud even when you don’t have an Internet connection. The most common situation occurs when you are actually in the clouds — stuck on a plane with no Wi-Fi, or, more likely, Wi-Fi so slow it might as well be nonexistent.

headline: Cynics Need Love, Too
text: Sarcasm is the weapon of choice for the singer and comedian Emily Bergl, who opened at 54 Below on Tuesday evening. And oh, how bracing it feels! Just listen to this supersmart, platinum-haired spitfire sing tainted renditions of the Rodgers and Hammerstein standards “People Will Say We’re in Love” and “I Have Confidence.” Inflected with notes of doubt, cynicism and contempt, they curdle from happy, life-affirming ditties into objects of suspicion.

headline: A Detective Who Is More Softy Than Hard-Boiled
text: The closing credits of “Breakthrough Weekend” list a technical crew of five. That figure doesn’t count the producing team, which consists of two of the actors and the director, or the composer, whose personal website is advertised below his name. This New York shaggy-dog story from Sujewa Ekanayake is an example of extreme-makeshift filmmaking — but not, unfortunately, a successful one.

headline: Moving Beyond Clothing With Collections for the Home
text: Club Monaco’s shop in Southampton, N.Y., which opened Memorial Day weekend, has the expected clothing and accessories. But it also has home furnishings, and mostly vintage ones at that. Crossing the threshold, one comes upon a table full of hotel silver to the right and old-fashioned mirrors. Other collections throughout the 3,000-square-foot space include vintage glass bottles, silver cocktail shakers and ironstone dishes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
text: Photos from London, Portugal, Israel and Washington.

headline: Where the Cool Things Are
text: When his lease was set to expire and his rent to triple, Patrick Parrish considered closing his TriBeCa design gallery, Mondo Cane, after almost 15 years and going online only. But in addition to selling vintage furniture and lighting, Mr. Parrish also holds contemporary art and design exhibits several times a year. “I like having openings, interacting with people,” he said.

headline: Modernist Birds Can Roost Here
text: This artisanal birdhouse looks like a homage to Herzog & de Meuron’s “bird’s nest” Olympic Stadium in Beijing. But the resemblance “probably was subconscious,” said Joe Mansfield, a founder, with Ken Tomita, of Grovemade, a five-year-old woodworking company in Portland, Ore., that produces it. Mr. Mansfield said he started with an Adobe Illustrator plug-in, and then realized, “Oh, that’s like a bunch of branches in a tree.” Made of walnut and what Mr. Mansfield described as “responsibly harvested, domestic Eastern hard-rock maple,” the small birdhouse comes with a solid brass perch and costs $200. Grovemade’s wood iPhone case has already appeared in the cult TV series “Portlandia.” If that show were to do a full-bore Grovemade parody, what product would be required? “I guess they’d have us make a high-end bike-polo stick,” Mr. Mansfield said. “It’s all the rage in Portland.” Information: grovemade.com.

headline: Italian Décor Rooted in Pottery
text: Joseph Sciorra, 59, has spent three decades studying how Italian-Americans adapt traditions from their ancestral homelands. The folklorist has looked at, among other topics, the Americanized versions of Italian embroidery, Neapolitan music, ephemeral architecture built for street processions and lawn shrines with saint statues in grottoes. A director of the John D. Calandra Italian American Institute at Queens College, he has been roaming Brooklyn streets lately, documenting 1950s planters covered in beach pebbles and blogging about his finds at i-italy.org.

headline: Losing the Key
text: In this age of rapid transformation, the house key has been surprisingly resistant to change. Cars have mostly switched to key fobs. Hotels and office buildings favor the pass card. And yet the little metal keys we carry around — part security device, part domestic totem — aren’t that different from the ones carried by our parents, their parents or their parents, going back to the Civil War, when Linus Yale Jr. invented the cylinder lock, modifying an ancient Egyptian design.

headline: What Ferris Bueller Hath Wrought
text: The premise of “Where We Started” seems torn from an indie-script textbook: Will (Matthew Brumlow) and Nora (Cora Vander Broek), two lonely strangers locked in unhappy marriages, happen to run into each other on a night that might change their lives.

headline: Seattle, the New Center of a Tech Boom
text: SEATTLE — From his ninth-floor office in downtown Seattle, Hewlett-Packard’s cloud computing outpost, Bill Hilf can see the Space Needle, the Pike Street Market and the future of computing.

headline: Summer Fashion: Small Canvases for Big Prints
text: Given the season’s giddy profusion of prints — the tribal patterns, the splashy botanicals, the retro blooms — it follows that they would feel right for swimwear as well. Gabby Sabharwal, the designer of the swimwear label Giejo, a collection made with vintage fabrics, worked with a brush-stroke print after seeing the painterly inspirations on the spring runways. Yodit Eklund, who designs the African surf and beach label Bantu, developed the prints for her collaboration with J. Crew from traditional West African wax cloth patterns. Her color palette was based on 1970s funk and high-life album covers from Africa. Kenzo swimsuits echo the popular fish motifs in its spring collection. And as Ms. Eklund points out, a swimsuit is an easy way to pull off ... well, loud prints. “The surface area of a swimsuit is naturally small, so swimwear is a great opportunity to play with print without a head-to-toe look that might be overwhelming.”

headline: The V.A.’s Problems, by the Numbers
text: Facts and figures behind the troubled Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Tools for Troubleshooting
text: What you need to inspect your home.

headline: Hillshire Stuck Between the Terms of 2 Deal Offers
text: Hillshire Brands is in deal limbo.

headline: At the Tonys, a D.I.Y. Fashion Aesthetic Prevails
text: Just before midnight last Sunday, Mark Rylance, a Tony winner for “Twelfth Night,” was standing in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel, clutching his award and discussing his black top hat.

headline: Processing Power, Delivered by the Truckload
text: HOUSTON — Hidden off an unmarked, winding road near the George Bush Intercontinental Airport here is a 40,000-square-foot warehouse filled with boxes, most about the size of a tall chest of drawers. As soon as handlers load one truck, it seems as if they are unloading another.

headline: Costuming Imelda Marcos in ‘Here Lies Love’
text: Clint Ramos was a boy of 13 when he first encountered Imelda Marcos. She alighted fairylike at his high school in Cebu in the Philippines, a beacon of munificence pinning medals on deserving lads.

headline: Lady Gaga Becomes a Live Nation Client
text: Nearly a year after a public split with her former manager, Lady Gaga has become a client of Live Nation Entertainment’s management division.

headline: Looking for Trouble at Home Can Pay Off
text: I know that preventive home maintenance is the grown-up way to save money in the long term and keep rats out of my pantry in the short term. All my friends from Shangri-La tell me so. And let’s face it, they’re the only people on the planet who practice preventive home maintenance.

headline: Bending the Rules to Offer Yoga With a Beer Chaser
text: A chef, 24 yogis and a dog walk into an Art Deco bar. It’s 10:30 a.m. on a recent Sunday, and most of the yogis have just completed a 2.3-mile run through downtown Los Angeles, led by a chef, Rob Rice, who is a certified yoga instructor.

headline: Tony Awards Committee Eases Limits on Promotional Swag
text: Get ready, Tony Award insiders – a whole lot of swag could be coming your way next spring.

headline: A Breakdown of Six Sneakers and Their Wearers
text: What do your sneakers say about you? Here’s a cultural breakdown.

headline: U.S. Said to Rebuff Iraqi Request to Strike Militants
text: WASHINGTON — As the threat from Sunni militants in western Iraq escalated last month, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki secretly asked the Obama administration to consider carrying out airstrikes against extremist staging areas, according to Iraqi and American officials.

headline: A Rubber-Soled Revolution
text: The once ungentlemanly sneaker has undergone a fashion baptism, showing up in offices as well as cafe society.

headline: Tips From Fashion Insiders on How to Wear Sneakers With a Suit
text: Sneakers with a suit? Of course. Men’s wear experts offer their fashion tips for getting it right.

headline: Security Needs Evolve as Computing Leaves the Office
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, people still spoke of cloud adoption as if they had a choice.

headline: The Sneaker Comes of Age
text: When Christopher Tennant, the editor of the magazine Man of the World, met up with his future in-laws a few months ago at JoJo, an Upper East Side restaurant, he wore a navy blazer from Barneys New York, olive slacks and — what else? — a pair of sneakers by Common Projects.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,312 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Goldman and Bain Settle Suit on Collusion
text: Goldman Sachs and Bain Capital have agreed to pay a combined $121 million to settle a lawsuit that accused them and other firms of colluding to drive down the prices of takeovers before the financial crisis, according to a court filing on Wednesday.

headline: Danish Composer Wins $200,000 Prize From Philharmonic
text: Per Norgard, a Danish composer known for kaleidoscopic works with shimmering, seamlessly evolving textures, has been awarded the Marie-Josée Kravis Prize for New Music, presented every two years by the New York Philharmonic. The award carries a $200,000 cash prize as well as a commission to compose a work for the orchestra.

headline: The Not-So-Smart Home
text: Molly Wood explores what it takes to connect lights, garage doors, door locks, speakers and other home electronics on a network. It’s possible, she finds, but not so easy yet.

headline: Morocco’s King Slow to Deliver on Pro-Democracy Vows
text: RABAT, Morocco — A few weeks shy of his 15th anniversary as Morocco’s ruler, King Mohammed VI was spotted on the streets of Tunisia in jeans and a T-shirt while on an official visit, living up to the King of Cool nickname given to him by the foreign news media.

headline: Cloud Technology, in Translation
text: A Glossary of Terms

headline: Controlling Your Smart Home With One Hub
text: THE smart home is full of promise: Coffee makers that turn on when you wake up, garage doors that open when you come home, relaxing music that is controlled remotely and air-conditioners and thermostats that perfectly regulate the home and save you money, too.

headline: Browsing Boutiques Without Taking the Trip
text: Browsing the boutiques and bazaars of a foreign city is one of the many pleasures of travel. It’s also becoming easier to do from your couch.

headline: On the Road to a Photo of America
text: A road trip from Laredo, Tex., to Duluth, Minn., in search of how immigration has changed America in real lives demands a balance between plotted paths and serendipity.

headline: The Era of Cloud Computing
text: SynapDx searches hundreds of thousands of genetic markers, looking for clues about autism in 880 children across 20 states. A few years ago, this would be the task of a major company or research institution. Thanks to cloud computing, the start-up in Lexington, Mass., does it with 22 people, a few laptops and an Internet connection.

headline: Prisoners at Guantánamo: A Tally of 149 Cases
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Cap and a Gown, but Where Is the Job?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Mystery of the Buried Babies in Ireland

headline: Democracy’s Prospects
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aid Groups Allege Abuses of Young Border Crossers
text: Five legal assistance groups asserted in a complaint filed on Wednesday that unaccompanied children detained after crossing the southwest border illegally are held in cold, overcrowded, filthy cells and face mistreatment by border officers, including physical abuse and food deprivation.

headline: A Lesson in Injustice
text: When I was 6, I saw my uncle slap, punch and kick the young boy who lived in his house. This wasn’t unusual in the India of the early ’90s, and it isn’t unusual even now. Parents routinely beat up kids, convinced that it is the best way to discipline them. A friend of mine in Gangtok, my hometown, came to school with stick marks tattooed on his arms every other week. This, though, was the first time that I had actually seen my uncle beating up a child.

headline: Mimicking the S.&P. With an Index for Ad Prices at 500 Publishers
text: A LEADING advertising trade publisher, MediaPost Communications, is seeking to be a kind of Dow Jones or Standard & Poor’s for Madison Avenue, introducing an index that intends to track in real time the movements in price for ads bought and sold on the websites of 500 publishers.

headline: Undecided
text: With the end of the Supreme Court’s term in view, the focus is naturally on the cases to be decided. So it’s worth pausing, before the final onslaught, over a case the court won’t be deciding, one that the justices turned away earlier this week although it cried out for their attention, and ours.

headline: G.M.’s Flawed Culture
text: For me, portions of the report of the investigation into General Motors’ safety problems with certain cars were a journey down memory lane:

headline: Shock Waves From Cantor’s Defeat
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Case David Brat Made to Voters
text: David Brat made a simple case against Eric Cantor, and it seemed to resonate with voters as a convincing argument for getting rid of him. Here, culled from interviews and speeches, are some of his arguments.

headline: The Cantor Omen
text: While the beltway chatter grows over the political death of Eric Cantor, the first House leader to be unseated in a primary, it would be easy to lose sight of just how unsettling his demise is for our politics in general.

headline: In Most States, Unemployment Rates Haven’t Bounced Back
text: Five years since the end of the recession, many states still haven’t returned to, or neared, their previous levels of unemployment.

headline: Missile Strike by C.I.A. Drone Kills at Least 4, Pakistan Reports
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Ending a five-month hiatus, the Central Intelligence Agency resumed its drone campaign in Pakistan on Wednesday with a missile strike that killed at least four people at a compound in the tribal district of North Waziristan, Pakistani officials said.

headline: U.S. Economic Recovery Looks Distant as Growth Stalls
text: WASHINGTON — Recessions are always painful, but the Great Recession that ran from late 2007 to the middle of 2009 may have inflicted a new kind of pain: an era of slower growth.

headline: The Carnival Spectacle at a Bushwick Bar
text: The Folk Circus, a monthly event at a bar in Bushwick, is just one example of circus popping up across the city in unexpected ways and places.

headline: A Digital Orchestra for Opera? Purists Take (and Play) Offense
text: Nothing about Wagner’s epic “Ring” cycle is small in scale, but when a would-be impresario came up with the idea of staging it in West Hartford, Conn., he envisioned replacing its massive orchestral forces with the digital sounds of sampled instruments.

headline: Top Militant Leader Is Arrested in Philippines
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — The Philippines captured a top leader of a militant group on Wednesday who the United States says funneled money from Al Qaeda to Filipino rebels blamed for more than a decade of bombings, beheadings and kidnappings in the southern part of the country.

headline: Texas Lawmaker Investigated Over Campaign Donations
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee is investigating accusations that a Republican lawmaker from Texas — who lost a recent bid for a United States Senate seat — took illegal contributions from two of his staff members and may have made false statements in an effort to cover it up.

headline: Sterling to Face Trial on Mental Capacity
text: LOS ANGELES — He did not know what season it was. He could not remember two objects after three minutes. He had difficulty drawing a clock.

headline: Opponent Resonated With Christian Conservatives in a Way Cantor Could Not
text: WASHINGTON — As the lone Jewish Republican in Congress, representing a deeply conservative, overwhelmingly Christian district in Virginia while dreaming of becoming the first Jewish speaker of the House, Representative Eric Cantor always had a delicate task.

headline: Seizing on Cantor Defeat, Obama Faults G.O.P. at Donor Speech
text: WESTON, Mass. — President Obama, addressing a small group of donors here on Wednesday night, could not help but weigh in on the dominant political issue of the day: the primary defeat of Eric Cantor, the No. 2 House Republican.

headline: Plan Will Change on Young Migrants
text: The border authorities will no longer send female migrants with children to a makeshift detention center in Nogales, Ariz., and then release them in the state, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said Wednesday at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing.  As of June 1, Mr. Johnson said, unaccompanied children caught crossing the border illegally are being sent to the Nogales center for initial immigration processing, and they will not be released in the state. Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona had said that she was “disturbed and outraged” when hundreds of women and children were sent by immigration officials on buses to Phoenix and released with no assistance.

headline: Target Seeks to Reassure Its Investors at Meeting
text: DALLAS — At Target’s annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday, the questions were few and the attendance sparse, in stark contrast to the company’s exceptionally tumultuous year.

headline: CNN Covers Cantor, Shifts to Simpson
text: Did CNN abdicate its commitment to breaking news Tuesday night when it broke away from live coverage of the primary election upset of Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, in favor of a special about the anniversary of the O. J. Simpson trial?

headline: Pinehurst’s Challenges at U.S. Open Will Include Footprints
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Everyday golfers know about footprints in the sand. The scourge of recreational golf is that many players neglect to rake bunkers after hitting out of them. As a result, many weekend duffers are left playing shots from the imprints of shoes.

headline: Golfer Mickelson’s Role Said to Be Overstated in Insider Inquiry
text: Phil Mickelson, the famed golfer, did not trade in the shares of Clorox just as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn was mounting an unsolicited takeover bid for the company in 2011, say four people briefed on the matter.

headline: A Family That Plays Together Reconvenes at Pinehurst
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — On the first week of his summer break, Maverick McNealy was on a resort golf course with his mother, his father and two of his three siblings. Standing off the 10th hole at Pinehurst No. 2 on Wednesday, McNealy smiled and said, “It feels like a typical McNealy family golf vacation.”

headline: Putting a Cap on Cantor
text: Pardon me. I’m having trouble getting my thoughts together today. I’m so upset about Eric Cantor.

headline: Weapons Stockpile Seen in Oregon School Attack
text: TROUTDALE, Ore. — The police on Wednesday identified the assailant who killed a student and wounded a teacher here as a 15-year-old student who had planned to hurt more people when he arrived at his high school in this Portland suburb with two family guns and hundreds of rounds of ammunition.

headline: Spurs Set Records, and Their Shooting Guru Offers Only a Shrug
text: MIAMI — The San Antonio Spurs were well on their way to obliterating all kinds of records for shooting proficiency, and the one man who might have allowed himself to delight in what was happening Tuesday night at American Airlines Arena instead seemed completely unaffected by it all.

headline: The Army Alone Can’t Save Iraq
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE Obama administration must help the Iraqi government retake the city of Mosul from Islamists and stem their march toward Baghdad. But military aid will not be enough. For lasting success, the United States must compel Iraq’s divisive leadership to pursue government by reconciliation just as vigorously as it pursues battlefield victory.

headline: With Marijuana Legalized, a City in Washington State Says, ‘Not So Fast’
text: SEATTLE — The first retail shops selling legal recreational marijuana in Washington State are preparing to open next month. Cash registers are standing by, and the first crops are almost ready for harvesting. But not every part of the state is joining the party.

headline: Why Polling Fails
text: ERIC CANTOR wasn’t the only person at a loss for words on Tuesday night.

headline: Technocrat to Afghan Populist, Ashraf Ghani Is Transformed
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When dealing with Western officials, Ashraf Ghani presents himself as the rare technocrat who possesses both the cultural savvy and practical expertise needed to put Afghanistan back on track if he is elected president in the runoff vote on Saturday.

headline: Security and Enthusiasm Clash in Theater of the Absurd
text: She is a theater lifer, all but born to this Atlantis in the West 40s.

headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Defeats Croatia, 3-1
text: In the end, it’s the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.

headline: Iran’s World Cup Zeal Wanes as Match Draws Near
text: TEHRAN — In a city where few people are allowed to organize large gatherings, and fun is enjoyed in private, the public celebrations of a year ago are legendary.

headline: Cantor’s Lesson: Hedging on Immigration Is Perilous
text: The lesson that immigration advocates say they gleaned from Tuesday’s election results is, simply put, that hedging on such an intensely charged issue can be politically fatal.

headline: She Gets No Respect
text: Here’s a riddle: Why would a Hurricane Alexandra be deadlier than an identical Hurricane Alexander?

headline: A New Battle for Equal Education
text: When states are sued for providing inferior education to poor and minority children, the issue is usually money — disproportionately more money for white students, less for others. A California judge has now brought another deep-rooted inequity to light: poor teaching.

headline: Does Tenure Protect Bad Teachers or Good Schools?
text: Do job protections prevent bad faculty from being removed or do they provide for greater stability in a demanding, low-paid profession?

headline: The Scourge of Sexual Violence
text: The failure of the Egyptian government, now led by Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, to respond aggressively to sexual assaults has justifiably outraged rape victims and women’s rights advocates. A video posted on the Internet of a horrifying mass sexual assault on a woman on Sunday in Cairo’s Tahrir Square now poses a serious test for Mr. Sisi.

headline: Luiz Felipe Scolari, Brazil’s Manager, Shoulders Grief and Expectation
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As the manager of Brazil’s national team, Luiz Felipe Scolari was already facing incredible pressure to win the World Cup. But just days before Thursday’s opening match, his emotions were suddenly clouded with grief.

headline: Cantor Forgot Virginia Roots, Voters Contend
text: GLEN ALLEN, Va. — This once rural community that is now a suburb of Richmond has no downtown, only a patchwork of shopping centers and colonial-style housing developments carved out of forests of white pine and oak.

headline: FIFA Chief Indicates He Will Seek Fifth Term
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Sepp Blatter on Wednesday all but declared his intention to run for a fifth term as FIFA’s president, declaring that “my mission is not finished” in a speech to a congress of soccer’s top officials.

headline: World Cup 2014: Mexico Defeats Cameroon, 1-0
text: Mexico needed to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot, and it did, 1-0.

headline: After Primary Upset, G.O.P. Fears Infighting Will Take a Toll
text: WASHINGTON — The sudden and decisive fall of the House majority leader, Eric Cantor of Virginia, at the hands of a conservative primary opponent tore open divisions among Republicans on Wednesday, setting off a new wave of fear that the internecine feuding would stymie policy-making and imperil Republican presidential prospects in 2016.

headline: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Spain, 5-1
text: The defending champions limped off in defeat as the Dutch triumphed in the remake of the 2010 final as Spanish-language horror film.

headline: World Cup 2014: Chile Defeats Australia, 3-1
text: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams’ opening Group B match.

headline: Randolph-Macon College a Political Hotbed in Hiding
text: Randolph-Macon College, with its neo-Georgian buildings and oak-shaded walkways tucked away in the hamlet of Ashland, Va., fits no one’s image of a political hotbed. Yet the Republican who defeated Eric Cantor in a congressional primary this week is a professor there — and so is the Democrat he will run against in November.

headline: Teacher Tenure Ruling in California Is Expected to Intensify Debate
text: LOS ANGELES — The landmark court decision on Tuesday finding California’s teacher tenure laws unconstitutional is likely to lead to a flood of copycat lawsuits in other states, shifting the battleground on the issue from the legislatures to the courts.

headline: The Deli Guy, the Waitress, the Actress and the Blackout
text: Harold McClam, a guitar-strumming sandwich maker in New York City in the mid-1960s, has a lot in common with the new musical “Fly by Night,” which is more or less centered on him. Both man and musical have a dopey appeal that is irresistible in small doses and an unfortunate way of sabotaging themselves by getting stuck in a groove.

headline: Goldman Sachs Misses Out on Big Alibaba Payoff
text: Goldman Sachs has a reputation for consistently holding the winning lottery ticket numbers. But it got rid of the ticket that is poised to be one of this year’s biggest payoffs.

headline: One Hundred Percent
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — What phrase do you use to convey “100%” of something?

headline: At Senator’s Trial, Video Shows Discussion of Paying G.O.P. Leaders for Support
text: WHITE PLAINS — The three men sat around a coffee table in a gold-wallpapered suite of the Essex House on Central Park South and talked about an improbable plot: enticing New York City’s five Republican county leaders to help State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, a Democrat, run for mayor as a Republican.

headline: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Strip Kills Palestinian
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli airstrike late Wednesday killed a Palestinian, who was believed to be a militant, as he rode a motorcycle in the northern Gaza Strip and seriously wounded a man accompanying him and a 7-year-old boy who was passing by, according to health officials in Gaza.

headline: Legal Confusion Follows Federal Judge’s Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage in Wisconsin
text: In her ruling last Friday that struck down Wisconsin’s amendment limiting marriage to a man and a woman, Judge Barbara B. Crabb spoke plainly on the basic question.

headline: Lenders Enlisted in Effort to Preserve Stuyvesant Town for the Middle Class
text: One month after word circulated that Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village was for sale, the battle is fully engaged to preserve this increasingly rare oasis for middle-class families in Manhattan.

headline: Mayor Criticizes Cab Plan After a Court’s Reversal
text: One day after an appeals court revived a Bloomberg administration proposal for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow cabs, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday denounced the plan, calling its adoption “a broken process on many levels.”

headline: 3 Sought in Series of Laundry Robberies
text: Their plan seemed simple enough. One man stood outside Express Laundry in Brooklyn on Saturday. It was around midnight, and the coast was clear. He gave a partner a cue.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 11, 2014
Cuomo Adds 100 Officers to Units Fighting Heroin
text: A hundred State Police investigators are being added to drug units around New York with a mandate to tackle a growing heroin problem, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday.

headline: When the Trophy Is the Biggest Star
text: While hockey may have struggled to keep its footing among the most popular sports in the United States in recent years, it has held tight to the status of having the coolest championship trophy. The Stanley Cup is the most singular of trophies, a 35-pound hunk of silver recognizable instantly even by those who do not watch a second of the playoffs.

headline: Michigan: Another Retiree Group Agrees to Pension Cuts
text: The board of Detroit’s general retirement system voted Wednesday to endorse the city’s bankruptcy plan, becoming the latest retiree group to support a so-called grand bargain that includes outside funding and base pension cuts of 4.5 percent for former municipal workers. Pensioners must vote on the proposal by July 11 and could face steeper reductions if they reject the debt-slimming plan, which is subject to a federal judge’s approval. As part of the bargain, which would also keep a city-owned art collection off the auction block, two national foundations committed a combined $13 million to the Detroit Institute of Arts, the museum announced Wednesday. This week, automakers made a $26 million pledge. The artwork has been targeted by some creditors as a source of cash.

headline: Court Requires Warrants for Tracking Locations by Cellphone
text: In a groundbreaking case, a federal appeals court in Atlanta on Wednesday ruled that the Fourth Amendment protects information about people’s locations based on the cell towers their mobile phones are using. The ruling means investigators must get judicial warrants to obtain cell site data about someone. It builds on a ruling by the Supreme Court in 2012 finding that the police needed a warrant to attach a GPS device to a suspect’s car. While the court held that investigators should have obtained a warrant to get his locational data, it declined to overturn his conviction because the legal principle was not yet clear at the time of the investigation.

headline: White House Outlines Steps to Protect Covert Identities
text: The White House on Wednesday outlined the steps it would take to prevent the disclosure of covert officials’ identities when the president is traveling abroad. The moves are in reaction to the accidental revelation last month of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top spy in Afghanistan.

headline: Massachusetts: Venue Change Is Sought in Marathon Case
text: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused in last year’s marathon bombings, filed court documents on Wednesday saying that they want their client’s trial moved out of Boston. The lawyers did not say why they were seeking a new location, but indicated that they were trying to spare Mr. Tsarnaev the death penalty. In early court filings, Mr. Tsarnaev’s lawyers have referred to Boston’s news media coverage of the bombings, suggesting that the pretrial publicity there would prevent Mr. Tsarnaev from receiving a fair trial. If the court grants the move, the trial could still be held in Massachusetts, avoiding the intense feelings in Boston while benefiting from the state’s general anti-death-penalty tilt.

headline: Familiar Course to Defeat for deGrom
text: Last season, when Matt Harvey pitched a brilliant game and was ultimately let down by his offense, he often recited the same message. He said that his job was to pitch as well as he could, to give his offense a chance, and that he could do nothing more than that.

headline: For Rangel and Challengers, a Subdued Debate
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel discarded his props and toned down the racial language during the first live televised debate that pitted him against State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat and the Rev. Michael A. Walrond as he seeks a 23rd term to represent the 13th Congressional District.

headline: Ugandan Official to Be Next General Assembly Chief
text: The United Nations General Assembly chose Sam Kutesa, Uganda’s foreign minister, as its next president on Wednesday, bypassing concerns of rights advocates and Western officials over Uganda’s  law criminalizing homosexuality, which took effect four months ago. Mr. Kutesa was selected by acclamation, without a vote. The one-year post is largely ceremonial but carries significance because the president leads General Assembly meetings. Mr. Kutesa said nothing about gay rights in his acceptance speech but vowed to promote gender equality and women’s rights. Asked by reporters afterward about his views on gays, he said, “As long as they respect privacy, I have no problem with it at all.” Philippe Bolopion, the United Nations director at Human Rights Watch, said the Uganda law “makes him a questionable choice.” Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, supported Mr. Kutesa’s presidency but has expressed concern about the law, urging its repeal.

headline: Pakistan: Brothers Sentenced Again for Cannibalism
text: An antiterrorism court in Punjab Province on Wednesday sentenced two brothers accused of cannibalism each to 11 years and four months in prison. The brothers, Muhammad Arif and Farman Ali, were arrested in April after the police found a baby’s head at their home in remote Bhakkar. They were convicted after a similar discovery in 2011 but were released after 18 months because, lawyers said, Pakistani law has no specific provisions against cannibalism. This time they were convicted of terrorism, desecrating a corpse and concealing evidence, said Mian Muhammad Rizwan, the public prosecutor in the case. Mr. Arif said that his older brother had disinterred a baby’s body and that the two had cooked and eaten the remains.

headline: Brazil: With World Cup Near, Airport Staff Plans Strike
text: The workers at Rio de Janeiro’s airports said they would go on a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the opening day of the World Cup soccer tournament. Other strikes have recently affected Brazilian cities as unions exert leverage at a time when the government is trying to avert major problems. The workers at Rio’s international airport and two domestic airports said they were seeking better conditions and a new collective bargaining agreement. It was not clear how the strike would affect the thousands of visitors flowing into Rio, which will host several games, including the World Cup final. Union officials said that as much as 80 percent of the airport work force would keep working during the strike, Brazilian news organizations reported. In São Paulo, subway workers voted not to resume their strike.

headline: Mets Reach Intersection of Expectation and Patience
text: The Mets’ most dependable starting pitcher was a seventh-round draft choice from an Ohio high school who was not considered a top prospect as he clawed through the minor leagues. That pitcher, Jon Niese, cannot relate to the expectations that stalk so many others in the organization.

headline: Phyllis Patterson, Who Revived 16th Century, Dies at 82
text: Phyllis Patterson, who brought 16th-century Europe to Southern California in the 1960s when she helped found the first contemporary Renaissance fair, died on May 18 in a hospital in San Rafael, Calif. She was 82 and lived in a log cabin nearby, in Novato.

headline: Glenn Britt, Cable Chief Who Saw Broadband’s Future, Dies at 65
text: Glenn A. Britt, the longtime chief executive of Time Warner Cable, whose career encompassed the shift from televisions with rabbit ears to streaming video, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: Yankees’ Ellsbury Has Reputation as ‘Dirt Rat’ (It’s Praise)
text: SEATTLE — Jacoby Ellsbury has earned some earthy nicknames over the years, mostly stemming from his six seasons with the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Security of Sites Storing Small Radioactive Material Is Found to Be Lacking
text: Radioactive chunks of industrial metal that could be used in terrorist attacks are sometimes secured at sites around the country with no more than ordinary padlocks, according to congressional auditors. Also, auditors called ineffective the procedures for doing background checks of employers handling the materials.

headline: The Eloquence of Silence
text: In her final interview, the intensely private heiress Rachel ‘Bunny’ Mellon opened the doors to her legendary Virginia estate and the unparalleled treasures of her lifetime.

headline: A Series of Indecisive Moments
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Selected Poems by Charles Wright
text: Poems by Charles Wright, the newly named poet laureate.

headline: Charles Wright Named America’s Poet Laureate
text: The Library of Congress is to announce on Thursday that the next poet laureate will be Charles Wright, the author of nearly two dozen collections of verse that fuse the legacy of European modernism with mystical evocations of the landscape of the American South.

headline: Should Runners Get Pedicures?
text: Jackie Cartier of Boulder, Colo., has been running for 10 years. That has left her feet beaten up and bruised, with thick calluses and the occasional missing toenail. But she won’t step foot in a salon to have a pedicure.

headline: Anchor of Rangers Buoys Them Just in Time
text: After practice one afternoon, Henrik Lundqvist discussed his hockey mortality. “You don’t know how many chances you get in the playoffs,” Lundqvist said. “Before you know it, it might be over.”

headline: Word of the Day | conveyance
text: conveyance •\kən-ˈva-ən(t)s\• noun

headline: Lundqvist’s 40 Saves Give Rangers a Shot
text: Madison Square Garden once again served as the Rangers’ fortress Wednesday night. They held off the Los Angeles Kings, 2-1, refusing to allow the indignation of seeing them lift the Stanley Cup on home ice.

headline: Rafael Frühbeck, 80, Dies; Conductor Made the World a Podium
text: Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, a Spanish conductor known for his frequent guest appearances with the world’s foremost symphony orchestras, died on Wednesday in Pamplona, Spain. He was 80.

headline: Polarization Is Dividing American Society, Not Just Politics
text: It is common for Americans to lament the polarization and dysfunction of Washington, but Congress might be doing a better job of representing the public than voters care to admit.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 12, 2014
text: “The days of just going to Washington and things happening in a vacuum are over.”

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (FX) WANDERLUST (2012) Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd star as Linda and George, out-of-work Manhattanites unable to sell their “microloft” in the West Village. Then they stumble onto Elysium, an “intentional community” in rural Georgia, where good vibrations — and not a little smoke — fill the air, and the only blackberries grow on trees. Established decades earlier by Carvin (Alan Alda), now in a wheelchair and battling memory loss, and his hippie friends, the commune is home to a touchy-feely guitar-strumming collage led by Seth (Justin Theroux), a creepy Lothario; and a novelist and nudist (Joe Lo Truglio) who wears the occasional sanitary pouch (like a hairnet, but lower) when he’s crushing grapes for homemade wine. “Part of what gives this movie unexpected resonance is that Linda and George have joined only somewhat voluntarily,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “mostly funny comedy” from David Wain. “Like other Americans seeking simplicity and maybe a chicken coop out back, they want off the road, at least for a while. There’s something touching about this desire, though Mr. Wain doesn’t let Linda and George fly their freak flags for long.”

headline: Rookie Jets Cornerback Gets the Green Light to Bump and Run
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Dexter McDougle, a rookie cornerback, was ecstatic when the Jets’ training staff allowed him to trade the red jersey he had worn since he joined the team as a third-round draft choice for a green one that signified he was free to engage in contact drills.

headline: Stout Performance Extends the Finals
text: A stellar game by goaltender Henrik Lundqvist and goals from Martin St. Louis and Benoit Pouliot helped the Rangers cut the Kings’ lead in the Stanley Cup finals to 3-1.

headline: Corrections: June 12, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Kings Head Home Empty-Handed but Hoping for Redemption
text: The Los Angeles Kings entered Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night needing one victory to clinch their second Stanley Cup in three years.

headline: Xi of Two Minds: Be a Good Neighbor, or Assert China’s Power?
text: If you’re sometimes discombobulated by China’s foreign policy gyrations, there may be some consolation in knowing that so, apparently, is President Xi Jinping. A new report argues that China’s external strategy under him remains an unstable compound of impulses: swelling ambitions that China will use its growing economic and military power to subdue rivals versus a longstanding desire for a stable, benign regional setting so that the ruling Communist Party can tend to domestic priorities.

headline: Synthesis Lost
text: Brad DeLong has some notes on the evident trouble we’ve been having maintaining the “neoclassical synthesis” — the doctrine, made famous by Paul Samuelson but actually there in Keynes too, that macroeconomic policy is needed for full employment but once you have that a relatively free-market policy works.

headline: In Testimony Against N.C.A.A., Economics Professor Suggests Players Should Be Paid
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Three days into a federal antitrust trial involving the N.C.A.A., the key witness has been Roger Noll, a 74-year-old economics professor emeritus at Stanford. His studies and theories form much of the basis for the allegation that the N.C.A.A. has engaged in price fixing by systematically depriving players a piece of lucrative broadcast and video-game contracts.

headline: Tanaka Earns Win No. 10 as Yankees Beat Mariners
text: SEATTLE — Masahiro Tanaka is putting together the type of rookie season that even longtime baseball fans cannot remember seeing.

headline: Greenpeace and Other Advocates Fear Clampdown After Leaked Report
text: NEW DELHI — A confidential intelligence report submitted to the prime minister’s office and leaked to the local media criticizing foreign-funded nongovernmental organizations, including Greenpeace India, for their detrimental effect on the Indian economy has caused many social activists to worry about the security of their operations.

headline: European Court Upholds $1.44 Billion Fine Against Intel
text: BRUSSELS — An appeals court on Thursday upheld an antitrust fine of 1.06 billion euros against the computer chip giant Intel, giving more teeth to the European Union’s power to hold multinational technology giants accountable — even if the case is years old and Intel no longer wields the sort of power over consumers that got it into trouble in the first place.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 12, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Killing a Patient to Save His Life
text: In “Killing a Patient to Save His Life,” Kate Murphy reports on an experimental medical procedure.

headline: BNP Paribas Executive Leaves as Trade Investigation Grows
text: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | A senior BNP Paribas executive is stepping down in the face of an investigation into whether the bank did business with countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: An Interview With Xi, Long Before He Was China’s Leader
text: China’s president, Xi Jinping, belongs to the “sent-down” generation of urban youths assigned to labor in the countryside during the radical fervor of the Cultural Revolution, and while many of his peers rue that era as a lost decade, in a newly unearthed interview, Mr. Xi describes his seven rural years as a life-transforming immersion in poverty, hard work, spartan eating and bed fleas.

headline: British Discount Retailer B&M Raises $1.81 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – B&M European Value Retail, the British discount retailer, said on Thursday that it had raised 1.08 billion pounds, or about $1.81 billion, in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Prison Sentence Feared for Detained Rights Lawyer
text: A lawyer who met with Pu Zhiqiang, a crusading human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, has expressed pessimism about the prospect of his speedy release.

headline: On the Road to a Photo of America
text: Last month, the New York Times staff photographer Todd Heisler and a reporter, Damien Cave, set off on an ambitious journey to travel up Interstate 35, chronicling how the middle of America is being changed by immigration. With two weeks left on their assignment, Mr. Heisler took a moment to record a brief yet personal account for Lens regarding his experiences on the road.

headline: Will You Be Watching the World Cup?
text: The World Cup, which is held every four years, begins on Thursday in Brazil and will last until mid-July. Thirty-two countries are contending for the title of world champion. The last time around, Spain won — but who will win this year? And will you be watching?

headline: U.S. Drone Hits Pakistan for 2nd Time in 12 Hours
text: LONDON — An American drone struck a militant compound in Pakistan’s tribal belt for the second time in 12 hours on Thursday, killing at least 10 suspected members of the Haqqani network in a suddenly intense resurgence of the C.I.A. offensive in Pakistan.

headline: Kurdish Fighters Take a Key Oil City as Militants Advance on Baghdad
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Kurdish forces exploited the mayhem convulsing Iraq on Thursday to seize complete control of the strategic northern oil city of Kirkuk as government troops fled in the face of advancing Sunni militants. The insurgents pressed their advance southward toward Baghdad, warned officials of occupied Mosul to renounce allegiance to the central government and threatened to destroy religious shrines sacred to Shiites.

headline: New York Today: Brazil vs. Croatia, in Queens
text: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: First Year May Be Critical for Lowering Asthma and Allergy Risk
text: Childhood exposure to allergens and germs is generally believed to protect against the development of asthma and allergy, but a new study suggests that this effect happens only with exposure in the first year of life.

headline: Facebook to Let Users Alter Their Ad Profiles
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that advertisement for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out.

headline: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Beijing’s Pressure Tactics in Hong Kong
text: Anson Chan served as the No. 2 official in Hong Kong in the last years of the British colonial administration as well as in the first four years of the government following the territory’s return to China in 1997. During her time in office she was often referred to as Hong Kong’s “Iron Lady” and regarded as one of Asia’s most powerful women.

headline: Oil Rig Operator Shelf Drilling to List in London
text: LONDON – Shelf Drilling, a Dubai-based operator of oil rigs, is looking to become the latest company to cash in on a buoyant market for London stock offerings.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook to Give Users More Control Over Marketing Data
text: If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that ad for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The forces of political nihilism not only remain alive and well within the Republican Party, but they are on the rise,” writes The New York Times editorial board. The Times finds the defeat of Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, by David Brat, an upstart “of the distant extremes,” to be both regrettable and disconcerting. For the Republicans of Virginia’s Seventh Congressional District, even Mr. Cantor, “who had been one of the most implacable opponents to the reform of immigration, health care and taxation,” was apparently too moderate. “His crime (in addition to complacent campaigning)? He was occasionally obliged, as a leader, to take a few minimalist steps toward governing, like raising the debt ceiling and ending a ruinous shutdown.”

headline: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen: Jody Adams
text: Jody Adams remembers her first job as a 25-year-old cook, working directly on the hot line. “I cut myself. I burned myself. I was a mess; I cried,” she said. “But I survived.”

headline: The Economic Damage of Recession News
text: Real gross domestic product (G.D.P.) in the United States shrank by 1 percent in the first quarter of the year. What made this announcement seem so significant?

headline: Freshdesk Raises $31 Million for Customer Support Software

headline: Morning Agenda: Mickelson Not Linked to Clorox
text: MICKELSON’S ROLE OVERSTATED IN INSIDER INQUIRY  |  The golfer Phil Mickelson did not trade in the shares of Clorox as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn was mounting a takeover bid for the company in 2011, according to people briefed on the matter, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Recent news reports said that Clorox was among the stocks that federal authorities were examining as part of a two-year investigation into well-timed trades made by Mr. Mickelson and the gambler William T. Walters.

headline: Russian Absurdism, With Floating Furniture
text: PARIS — Robert Wilson was sketching. Circles within circles, horizontal lines punctuating them, numbers and words alongside. The diagram was a visual rendition of the structure of one of his early works, “The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin,” but he could doubtless do exactly the same thing for any of the numerous theater and opera pieces he has created and directed in the course of a 45-year career.

headline: Finding Her Future Looking to the Past
text: LOS ANGELES — In October, before starting an international theater tour, the songwriter Lana Del Rey consulted a clairvoyant. She was instructed to write down four questions in advance and sleep on them. The first question on the list, Ms. Del Rey said in an interview in May at her house here, was “Am I meant for this world?”

headline: Sex, Violence and Power, With a Feminist Slant
text: A few years ago, the British playwright Penelope Skinner found herself in an editing suite, staring at a woman’s breasts. She had written an episode of “Fresh Meat,” a sitcom about college students, which contained a sex scene. The woman in it had just a few lines, and Ms. Skinner didn’t want her to serve as merely a source of titillation. So in the script she’d stated, “She does not take her top off.”

Fitbay aims to be the “Facebook of social shopping” according to Christian Wylonis, its founder and chief executive.

headline: Nathan Fielder’s Ingenious Dumb Humor
text: The new cafe at 1802 Hillhurst Avenue looked familiar, but something was off. It was nestled into a strip mall in Los Feliz, on the east side of Los Angeles, and its logo was a double-tailed mermaid, rendered in black and green, wearing a crown and a smile. Its name, spelled out in blocky white letters, was recognizable, too, except for a blunt détournement up top: DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE. The store was the creation of Nathan Fielder, a Canadian-born comedian, and he designed it to look exactly like an outpost of the ubiquitous coffee chain — that is, until you realized that the word “dumb” was everywhere. The menu listed 27 beverages with names like Dumb Iced Caramel Macchiato and Dumb Chai Tea Latte. Cups came in sizes from Dumb Tall to Dumb Venti. Two baristas manned the counter, with DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE emblazoned on their green aprons. “I hired them on Craigslist,” Fielder told me recently. “The ad actually asked for people who worked at Starbucks before, so we wouldn’t have to train them.” A rack of easy-listening CDs kept to the theme: “Dumb Jazz Standards,” “Dumb Norah Jones Duets.” The cafe quietly opened for business on a Friday last February. “I didn’t expect things to get as crazy as they did,” Fielder said.

headline: Parental Collusion on Spending and Rules: Harder Than It Sounds

No birthday parties with elaborate presents, or at least a declaration of a goody-bag truce. Some restraint on giving fancy new vehicles to teenagers.

These may be too much heavy baggage to attach to a corporate product like “How to Train Your Dragon 2.” But such matters are there for you to ponder in this sequel to the 2010 blockbuster that recertified DreamWorks Animation, after a fallow period, as a major player in Hollywood’s cartoon sweepstakes. And pop mythology nowadays has a way of seeping into the culture and sending far-reaching undercurrents.

He also said he would not take any professional engagements during the 2014-15 season.

headline: Now Booking | A Techno-Utopian Bar in San Francisco for Those Who Like to Think While They Drink
text: Since merriment sometimes just isn’t enough, the Interval, a Mensa-courting bar that opens this month in the Fort Mason Center, also offers a library stacked with 1,000 literary masterworks and reference books, an ambient soundtrack created by Brian Eno and, later this year, two robots: One will make drinks, while the other will write predictions about the future on the space’s massive chalkboard. Conceived by the San Francisco-based collective the Long Now Foundation — whose board of directors includes Eno and the Whole Earth Catalog creator Stewart Brand — the Interval will also host regular salons for cerebral scenesters.

headline: Efforts by Colleges to Curb Assaults Focus on Fraternities
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — At the University of Tennessee this year, some fraternity pledges had hot sauce poured on their genitals. At Emory in Atlanta, pledges were required to consume items “not typical for eating” and to engage in fistfights. And at Wesleyan in Connecticut, a few months after the university reached a settlement with a woman who said she was raped at a fraternity house, another woman said that she was raped at a different fraternity house.

headline: Missing Collateral a Sign of Weakness in China’s Financing Chains
text: Faith in metal-backed lending in China is corroding – and so is confidence in the country’s giant credit system. Authorities and banks, including Standard Chartered and Citic, are investigating whether traders at Qingdao port used the same lot of copper and aluminum to back multiple loans. Vanishing collateral isn’t a new problem, but could prove to be China’s weakest link.

headline: In Her Words | Elizabeth Hawes on Fashion and Style
text: For T’s culture issue, out this Sunday, Alice Gregory wrote about “The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer”: Elizabeth Hawes, the writer, designer and feminist who passed away in 1971. Throughout her career, Hawes offered an honest, often funny appraisal of the fashion world as it was and as she thought it should be. She was a proponent of using style to get what you want (and, essentially, to become who you want to be), and a wicked critic. While researching the piece, Gregory amassed a collection of Hawes’s wittiest one-liners from her nine books. Here, she lists her 10 favorite quips from the most important woman in fashion you’ve never heard of.

headline: The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer
text: Introducing Elizabeth Hawes: genius writer, wry cultural commentator, perverse humorist, gifted artist and truly modern thinker. You’ve never heard of her.
