headline: Just Like the Last One, Only Different
text: More is more and is, at times, just right in “22 Jump Street,” an exploding piñata of gags, pratfalls, winking asides, throwaway one-liners and self-reflexive waggery. This is, of course, the sequel to “21 Jump Street,” the 2012 hit that borrowed its title and undercover brother shtick from the old television show best known for its hair-gel hottie, Johnny Depp. For a second time, Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum play lovable undercover cops who — in between dodging danger and jokes that fly almost as fast as they do on “The Simpsons” — insinuate themselves into a juvenile population, whose resistance to these charmers has been rendered completely futile, much like that of the movie’s audience.

text: President Obama could change the tax treatment of carried interest with a phone call to the Treasury Department. But the White House will need a precise understanding of the regulatory landscape to make a change that is fair, easy to administer, and will hold up in court.

headline: Kids and Parents: Happy to Move Up, Sad to Say Goodbye
text: This morning was the “step-up” ceremony at my children’s school. It’s the fifth time I’ve attended this same event (it’s a K-8 school) and it always follows the same leisurely pattern: acknowledging the teachers; various presentations; songs from each of the different music classes; speeches from the fifth graders who are moving on to middle school; and a class gift from the graduating eighth grade (that had a separate graduation ceremony the day before). There is no pomp and circumstance, there are no flat hats. It’s a pleasant, charming way of acknowledging the passing of another year and the inevitable forward movement of children. And the first time I attended, I felt like chewing my own arm off to escape.

headline: Brazil vs. Croatia: Live Blog
text: In the end, it’s the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.

headline: Life in the Fast Lane
text: My widowed father is 80 and has begun dating a woman close to his age. She has tremendous joie de vivre, but my siblings and I worry that she is wearing our father out, scheduling social events nearly every night of the week. We want our father to enjoy his life, but not at the expense of his health, which seems to be failing. We have raised our concerns with our father, who has not taken them to heart. But we disagree about whether to speak with his new partner. Should we?

headline: We Didn’t Have a Plan, but the Baby Did
text: About a year into our marriage, my wife and I decided we were ready for the adventure of having a child. Despite our best efforts, it wasn’t happening. We didn’t know why. One night as we were watching television, my wife turned to me and said, “I think you’re the problem.”

text: Caesars Entertainment, the owner of several casinos, is taking a page from the Dynegy playbook. That is not meant as a compliment.

headline: Haitian Art and Dance in Brooklyn

headline: Q. and A. | Wild Belle Spreads Its Island Vibes
text: Reggae-based pop music has unlikely torchbearers in Elliot and Natalie Bergman, a.k.a. Wild Belle. The brother-sister duo grew up around Chicago, a city that’s more Buddy Guy than Bob Marley, and spent much of their childhood like modern-day Von Trapps, singing songs around the piano with their parents and two other siblings. Elliot, who plays keyboard and saxophone and, at 32, is seven years Natalie’s senior, would go on to study jazz and play in an Afrobeat band, Nomo, at the University of Michigan. And the siblings’ travels, both literal and sonic, helped expand their musical purview. The resulting mix of sounds — indie pop tinged with reggae and ’70s soul — can be heard throughout Wild Belle’s debut album, “Isles,” released last year. And though they insist the title is more about the album’s structure than its influences (“each song is its own island,” Natalie has said), it might just as easily be a nod to Chris Blackwell’s Island Records, whose catalogue of ska and reggae hits surely left an impression.

headline: ‘A Logo for America’
text: A video of the work by Alfredo Jaar.

headline: Anatomy | ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’
text: Dean DeBlois narrates a sequence from “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”

headline: Drug Merger Discussion Leaves Out a Key Risk
text: As shareholders of the global pharmaceutical giant Mallinckrodt consider approving its $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals, a small but fast-growing California company, they must try to assess the risks associated with the deal.

headline: Mallinckrodt, Questcor and Questions About Acthar
text: Mallinckrodt announced in April that it intended to merge with Questcor Pharmaceuticals, which makes the immune system drug Acthar. But a key filing last month did not disclose adverse effects from the drug that were reported to regulators.

headline: Clip: ‘The Rover’
text: A scene from “The Rover,” directed by David Michod and featuring Guy Pearce and Robert Pattinson.

headline: Jump-Start Your Workday With an 8 A.M. Rave
text: THREE tall, glowing jellyfish puppets swept around the club floor, illuminating the broad grins and sweat-soaked brows of the wildly hopping dancers. Thumping house remixes of Tears for Fears’ “Everybody Wants to Rule the World” and Missy Elliott’s “Work It” rattled the balcony railings. Two D.J.s pumped their fists as a small pack of brass players appeared on the balcony, bleating along to the electronic soundtrack under stark strobe lights.

headline: European Film Directors Issue Appeal for Imprisoned Ukrainian Colleague
text: Top European film directors, including Pedro Almodóvar, Mike Leigh, Andrzej Wajda and Wim Wenders, have appealed to President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russian officials about the fate of Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was arrested in Crimea last month on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts.

headline: Dean DeBlois Narrates a Scene From ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’
text: In this video, the director Dean DeBlois discusses a sequence from “How to Train Your Dragon 2,” a sequel to the 2010 blockbuster. This scene features the lead character Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) flying through the clouds with his dragon companion, Toothless.

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to Premature Death
text: People with low blood levels of vitamin D are more likely to die prematurely than those with normal levels, a new analysis has found.

headline: ‘Homeless Lamp, the Juice Sucker’
text: Excerpt from a video of a performance by the artist Iván Navarro and his flourescent light bulb sculpture on the streets of Chelsea.

headline: In World Cup, Mexico Believes Anything Can Happen After Rough Road to Brazil
text: NATAL, Brazil — In the eyes of the Mexican writer Juan Villoro, a frequent commentator on soccer and, thus, a person with a keen sense of narrative structure, the Mexico national team’s undulant path to this city unfolded much like the plot of a telenovela.

headline: Training at the Top of the World
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Clip: ‘Witching & Bitching’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Alex de la Iglesia.

headline: Clip: ‘Lullaby’
text: A scene from the film directed by Andrew Levitas.

headline: Three Confirmations to Fed Board May Strengthen Yellen’s Hand
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday brought the Federal Reserve Board a little closer to full strength, confirming Lael Brainard, a former Treasury Department official, to one of the three open seats by a vote of 61 to 31.

headline: New Flights to Colombia
text: Two airlines have announced plans to add flights to Cartagena this year, reflecting the growth in American tourism demand in Colombia.

headline: Police Tactics Under Increased Scrutiny at World Cup
text: Protesters in Brazil accused the police of using excessive force to prevent a small group of demonstrators opposed to what they call lavish spending on the World Cup from reaching the stadium in São Paulo where the tournament began on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Defending ‘Guilty Pleasures’
text: Should we feel bad about reading for fun? A Slate critique of young-adult fiction last week had readers answering mostly in the negative. But beyond any specific genre, there may be a larger conversation to be had about which books are good, which books are fun, and whether there needs to be a difference.

headline: In Store | Everlane Pops Up in SoHo
text: Since 2011, the online-only basics brand Everlane has, with its motto of “radical transparency,” encouraged consumers to ask where and how their clothes are made — and how much they are marked up (which in Everlane’s case is a fraction of the usual amount). Starting tomorrow, shoppers will have the chance to sample the brand’s understated (and, compared to similar offerings, underpriced) staples in person at a SoHo pop-up. And though it’s not Everlane’s first appearance in New York, it’s by far its largest and most social outing. Called “Open House,” the space, which operates through June 28, will host catered events with other transparency-minded organizations from the food world, such as Gather Journal and Edible Schoolyard NYC. Every garment and accessory sold in the store — whose perforated-plywood interiors come courtesy of the Isa restauranteur Taavo Somer’s creative agency, Friends and Family — will be sold alongside an infographic detailing its origin story.

headline: Getting to the Heart of Suriname
text: Nelson Tiapoe pointed out two mature trees just a few feet apart amid the dense jungle vegetation. “When you see a mango tree and a cacao tree together, you know people used to live here,” he said. He was leading me and a 62-year-old Dutch man named Ton through the dense Amazonian rain forest of central Suriname just across the Upper Suriname River from his eco-resort, Knini Paati.

headline: Friulano, an Italian White Wine That Makes Friends Easily
text: CIVIDALE DEL FRIULI, Italy — You may have sipped a pleasant pinot grigio from Friuli, a region in the far northeast of Italy known for its white wines and more properly called Friuli-Venezia Giulia. But you are less likely to have had a glass of friulano, a more distinguished wine that is worth discovering.

headline: Built on Historic Foundations
text: Sometimes there’s too much theory. Sometimes too little. There’s not enough animating “Exposed: A History of Lingerie,” an otherwise nicely produced exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Organized by Colleen Hill, the museum’s associate curator of accessories, it presents 80 examples of European and American undergarments and accessories dating from the 18th century to the present, all from the museum’s permanent collection.

headline: Woman Is Found Hanged in Indian State
text: NEW DELHI — The body of a 19-year-old woman was found hanging by her scarf from a eucalyptus tree in a village in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh on Thursday morning, the police said. It was the third similar gruesome discovery in the state in two weeks.

headline: Living With Cancer: ‘The Fault in Our Stars’
text: “Cancer books suck,” says 16-year-old Hazel Grace Lancaster. But she has a favorite and so do I. Mine is the novel John Green wrote about her.

headline: Harris’s Run in ‘Angry Inch’ Won’t Get Any Longer
text: Neil Patrick Harris, who won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical for  “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” will not extend his run in the show beyond his scheduled departure date of Aug. 17 in spite of strong ticket demand, the show’s lead producer said on Thursday. Taking over for Mr. Harris will be Andrew Rannells, a Tony nominee as Elder Price in “The Book of Mormon” and a cast member of the HBO series “Girls,” according to the producer, David Binder.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Remember the Problems With Mortgage Defaults? They’re Coming Back With Student Loans
text: Student loans, along with mortgages and car loans, have become one of the three largest sources of credit, exceeding credit-card debt. This growth in student debt appears to have caught regulators unprepared. Compared with mortgages, auto loans and credit cards, student loans are loosely regulated, and that regulatory weakness is particularly threatening to consumers because they can’t discharge their debts through bankruptcy and escape lenders who are causing them harm.

headline: James Jebusa Shannon’s Portraits Rescued From Obscurity
text: ONCE FORGOTTEN PAST, NOW RECALLED IN PAINTING

headline: Marijuana’s Journey to Legitimacy
text: “Great social policy changes are not an easy sell,” says Jonathan Martin, a reporter for The Seattle Times, in Riley Morton’s assured documentary “Evergreen.” He’s not kidding: This record of Washington State’s battle over Initiative 502, which legalized possession of small amounts of recreational marijuana in 2012, is predictably loaded with rancor. The battle isn’t over whether pot should be legalized, but to what extent.

headline: Questioning the Unimaginable: A Fifth FIFA Term for Sepp Blatter
text: RIO dE JANEIRO — There was that face again.

headline: Iraqi Army Retakes Government Complex in Central Ramadi
text: Efforts to stem the rise of the Islamic State.

headline: A History of Awesome in One Room
text: THE MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM does not usually put trash on the wall, but there are exceptions. Among the nearly 60 rare books, manuscripts and objects on exhibit in “Marks of Genius: Treasures From the Bodleian Library” is a constellation of khaki-colored papyrus scraps retrieved about a century ago from an ancient dump outside the vanished Egyptian city of Oxyrhynchus. Over the years, excavations at the site have yielded census forms, invoices, bureaucratic correspondence and the occasional literary find — in this instance, a fragment of verse by Sappho, inscribed in Greek in the second century A.D., from the first of the nine books of poems she is known to have written.

headline: A German Rebel in South Africa
text: Jürgen Schadeberg left Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.

headline: A Photographer Recalls Her Life Within a Demimonde
text: A long time ago, a doctor told the photographer Nan Goldin that she had the genes of an Olympic athlete. Just as well: Even while eliding the details of her colorful, adventurous past, “Nan Goldin: I Remember Your Face” contains enough throwaway references to bodily harm to make her and her admirers grateful for the gifts of biology.

headline: Movies Listings for June 13-19
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Arriving Late to the Party, but Dancing on All the Clichés
text: Our big museums were built by businessmen, and significant changes are usually about making money. In these days of international markets and a cosmopolitan tourist flow, it pays for Western Modernist strongholds to look culturally embracing. This helps explain the Guggenheim’s UBS MAP Global Art Initiative, a three-phase collecting venture that finds the museum buying and showing the kinds of work it has paid little attention to in the past.

headline: Letters: Summer Reading Issue
text: Summer Reading Issue

headline: Navigating Persistence and Despair
text: A line Ben Watt sang at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday night — “Who am I fooling when I say I have no regrets?” — could encapsulate his songwriting. It’s modest, pensive, backhanded, self-questioning, emotional yet elegantly restrained.

headline: Antics Pierced by Angst
text: Emily Dickinson, a very American poet, may have called hope “the thing with feathers.” But for the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn, hope is largely a flightless creature. It flaps its wings from time to time, but it seldom gets far off the ground.

headline: The Battle Money Couldn’t Win
text: The dowdy loft building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street is about as blank as a building can get, just limestone and windows. But it sent the Vanderbilt family over the edge, the symbol of their defeat after years of attempts to preserve the residential sanctity of this stretch of New York’s most famous address.

headline: Schomburg to Create Center to Study Slave Trade
text: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is establishing a major new center for the analysis of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, the only such center based in a public research library, Schomburg officials said on Thursday.

headline: Jayson Musson: ‘Exhibit of Abstract Art’
text: Salon 94 Bowery

headline: Ken Price: ‘Specimen Rocks’
text: Matthew Marks Gallery

headline: A Car Is Stolen, Setting Off an Angry Pursuit
text: “The Rover,” David Michôd’s new film, takes place in Australia 10 years after an unspecified event called the Collapse, which has left everyone in a bad mood and catastrophically short of shaving supplies. This is not quite the apocalyptic ground zero of “The Road” or “The Road Warrior” (speaking of Down Under dystopias). Roving bands of armed men drive around shooting, but some of them wear uniforms and fill out government paperwork when they catch someone. Money still works (American dollars are preferred over Australian), and there seems to be enough food, gasoline and ammunition to keep everybody alert, mobile and angry.

headline: ‘A Painter and His Poets’: ‘The Art of George Schneeman’
text: Poets House

headline: Barely Moving, but Communicating Volumes
text: The Canadian performance artist Dana Michel is a real original, peculiar to the nth degree and remarkably compelling onstage. She scarcely dances; she scarcely speaks; her manner is oblique. It would be easy to make what she does sound ridiculous. Yet no sooner does she take the stage than she creates a complex world. She’s doing a singular form of acting, and we’re caught up by the strangeness of both her outward behavior and her character’s private thoughts. For me and others, she was the one important discovery of the American Realness Festival at the Abrons Arts Center in January.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 15-21, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Show That Really Gets Into Your Head
text: PHILADELPHIA — Clambering upward in dim violet light, stepping from one glass platform to another, you trigger flashes of light and polyps of sound. You climb through protective tubes of metallic mesh as you make your way through a maze of pathways. You are an electrical signal coursing through a neural network. You are immersed in the human brain.

headline: Mark Rothko: ‘The Watercolors 1941-47’
text: Pace Gallery

headline: The Antidote to Sweet
text: PHILADELPHIA — With her site-specific sphinx-goddess on view at the former Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn, Kara Walker is making a bold leap from two dimensions into three. And she has many more thoughts brewing on the subjects of sculpture and architecture, to judge from “Ruffneck Constructivists,” a smart, gripping and confrontational show she organized for the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

headline: Conversation Served With Cocktails
text: IT was at some point between mixing caipirinhas and doing a little dance to Ann-Margret’s rendition of “Thirteen Men” (“Last night I was dreaming/I dreamed about the H-bomb”) that Bryan Richgruber, a bartender at Big Bar in the East Village, quietly said, “Isn’t this a great bar?”

headline: Sycamore Takes 10% Stake in Express and Seeks a Deal
text: The investment firm Sycamore Partners disclosed on Thursday that it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in Express Inc., the fashionable retailer that has hit a slump of late, and is interested in buying the rest of the company.

headline: Missed Connections
text: Is there room in American fiction for another brilliant young émigré writer? There had better be, because here he is. Boris Fishman’s first novel, “A Replacement Life,” is bold, ambitious and wickedly smart.

headline: A Difficult Woman, With a Past Worth Writing About
text: In “Violette,” Emmanuelle Devos plays one of those impossible women who can’t give anyone, most of all herself, a break. For Violette Leduc, a black marketeer turned celebrated writer, life is a series of crushing disappointments, from the mother who never took her hand to the friends who never stay. Early in the film when a friend leaves the home they share, he sneaks out like a thief. He knows her too well. She doesn’t let him go; rather, she chases him down a road, frantically pulling at him and howling. This is a woman who doesn’t feed on misery: She gorges on it.

headline: Man Without a Country
text: The last full-length book Stefan Zweig wrote was a memoir called “The World of Yesterday,” an elegy for the Viennese culture that had nurtured his literary talent and was, in 1941, in the process of being wiped out by fascism and world war. The book was completed in Brazil, where Zweig and his second wife, Lotte, had settled after years of expatriate hopscotching and where they would commit suicide on Feb. 22, 1942.

headline: Out of Berlin, the Heart of an Artist
text: BERLIN — Before Jasper Johns or Jackson Pollock, there was Marsden Hartley, America’s first great modern painter of the 20th century. He achieved this distinction in Paris and most of all in Berlin between early 1912 and late 1915. There he produced a stream of paintings that synthesized Cubism and other European modernisms, mixed in non-Western motifs and mysterious symbols and culminated in his lusty, elegiac German Officer paintings.

headline: In Serious Pursuit, Even in Clown Shoes
text: In a musician’s work, you often hear a position or an effect or a big idea: humor, revision, argument, discipline, cynicism, romance. It’s just something extra to engage, a filter or transformer between the creative force inside him and the expectations of his listeners. Not so much, though, in the work of Charles Gayle, who played through opening night of this year’s Vision Festival on Wednesday night at Roulette, as bandleader and duet partner and conductor; playing saxophone, piano and bass; and in and out of clown clothes. He seems almost transparent: Your hearing cuts right through to what animates him.

headline: Hellfighters, High Finance and an Heiress
text: Before the 15th New York National Guard Regiment was formed, black Americans who wanted to enlist against the Germans in World War I had to join the French or Canadian Army. By the end of the war, this all-black regiment was famous on both sides of the Atlantic for never losing an inch of ground to the enemy, or a single man to capture.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Clarification, but Cheese Makers Are Wary
text: The panic over what appeared to be a change in the federal rules that govern the craft of artisan cheese making seems to be dying down, but cheese makers remain suspicious, even after the Food and Drug Administration said late Wednesday that it had erred.

headline: Agnes Varda in Chris Marker’s Studio
text: The French filmmaker Agnès Varda visits with Chris Marker at his home.

headline: An Extended Family Puts on a Big Recital
text: Alvin Ailey died almost 25 years ago at the too-young age of 58, yet his company, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, remains undeniably robust, unlike many that have lost their founders. So much so that it’s no longer just a company. The institution has tiers, as showcased Wednesday during the inaugural Ailey Spirit Gala at the David H. Koch Theater, where the main company shared the stage with members of Ailey II, the Ailey School and AileyCamp.

headline: Orpheus Descending and Arising
text: The indomitable Yefim Bronfman stars in the New York Philharmonic’s minifestival of Beethoven’s piano concertos unveiled on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall with glowing performances of the first and fourth concertos.

headline: Who Was Gyp the Blood?
text: Q.My father used to tell me that when he was a little boy, he was scared to death at hearing stories about a gangster known as Gyp the Blood. Can you tell me something about this person?

headline: Clip: ‘Hellion’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Kat Candler.

headline: Mosul Residents Flee as Unrest Spreads
text: Thousands of Mosul residents continued to flee the violence in Iraq’s second-largest city after Al Qaeda-inspired militants seized the area.

headline: Protests Spread Across Brazil
text: Demonstrators clashed with the police in São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro a few hours before the opening game of the World Cup.

headline: Player Tumbles; Opposition Falls
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It was Dia dos Namorados on Thursday, the Brazilian equivalent of Valentine’s Day, which meant there were chocolates and flowers and couples holding hands tucked among the sea of yellow jerseys that stretched from the Itaquera neighborhood over to Jardins. From sunrise all the way until the shimmering moon peeked above the skyline, Brazilians showed their passion for one another, and for soccer, as the World Cup began.

headline: Brides Gather Outside Court to Jeer Restaurateur Who Dashed Wedding Plans
text: The balding man dressed in black knew plenty of the people in the Brooklyn courtroom, watching on Thursday morning as he pleaded guilty to charges of tax fraud. But as he hurried out of the courthouse and into a waiting car, he did not lift his eyes to acknowledge a single one of them.

headline: Celebrating a Salsa Legacy
text: FROM the beginning, the kinetically danceable Latin music style known as salsa had deep New York roots. It was created by musicians who, though mostly of Caribbean origins, lived here, played in clubs here for audiences trying to find their footing here and recorded in studios here for a label that was also born here: Fania Records.

headline: When Teenage Anger Spirals Like a Texas Tornado
text: Going nowhere slowly and with great deliberation, “Hellion” presents a fractured family locked in a closed loop of adolescent misbehavior and adult retaliation. The instigator is Jacob (Josh Wiggins), a troubled 13-year-old whose father, Hollis (Aaron Paul), has withdrawn into boozy depression after the death of his wife. Now a distant parent and indifferent housekeeper, Hollis provides little for Jacob and his younger brother (Deke Garner), aside from junk food and remonstrations.

headline: Oy Gevalt! Untranslated Yiddish Recordings Stall State Senator’s Trial
text: WHITE PLAINS — In an odd twist in a courtroom saga dense with allegations of political corruption, the fate of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants may be put on hold because, of all things, Yiddish.

headline: Two Bands of True Believers Hurtling Toward a Collision
text: There are moments in “Policeman” when it feels as if the director Nadav Lapid is drawing one very large noose around his characters. That’s especially true early in this hypnotic, slow-building shocker from Israel, before the narrative pieces have slid into place, revealing Mr. Lapid’s intentions. Certainly, nothing looks out of the ordinary in the opening images of five men bicycling up a steep country road. That is until one, Yaron (Yiftach Klein), breaks away and begins riding so hard and fast toward the camera that he looks as if he might break through the screen.

headline: Abandon the Two-State Solution?
Now Screening | Travels With Agnès Varda
text: In her new five-part travel series “From Here to There” (available through SundanceNOW’s subscription program, Doc Club), the French filmmaker Agnès Varda, now 86, sometimes referred to as “The Grandmother of New Wave,” attends art and film festivals, visits old friends, interviews favorite artists and makes new acquaintances. Most of the time, a camera is in her hand. Occasionally, someone else is filming and she enters the scene. Whether in front of the lens or behind it, her curiosity is boundless and rooted in a desire to share her friendships and pleasures. “The main subject is ‘the other,'” she says. “I’m present in my films, I’m among the others.”

headline: Keeping Troubled Youths Out of Solitary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Restaurant Workers
From the Friedman Forum: ‘What Is a Job Today, and Who Is Getting Hired?’
text: From the Editor: Below are the prepared remarks Thomas L. Friedman delivered today at the start of his second annual Next New World forum. This year’s conference, held in San Francisco, focused on the question, “What is a job today, and who is getting hired?” Speakers included Andrew McAfee, co-founder of the M.I.T. Initiative on the Digital Economy; Sebastian Thrun, chief executive of Udacity; Laszlo Bock, head of human resources at Google; David Coleman, president and chief executive of the College Board; and Jeff Weiner, chief executive of LinkedIn.

headline: The Cathedral and the Towers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Students Succeed
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brokers Fight Rule to Favor Best Interests of Customers
text: David O’Brien, a certified financial planner, has tried to repair the retirement portfolios of several victims over the years. There was the high school science teacher who didn’t realize she had been sold a variable annuity, where layers of incomprehensible fees devoured nearly 2.5 percent of her retirement savings each year. Then there was the woman fighting cancer, who was also sold a high-cost annuity, but whose underlying investments were tied up in a money-market type fund — one that cost 1.5 percent annually.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 13-19
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 13, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “22 Jump Street,” “How to Train Your Dragon 2” and “The Rover.”

headline: Tenure Decision Draws Sharp Debate
text: Timothy R. Williams is a community moderator, monitoring comments submitted to the website.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 15-21, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Greece, Ukraine and France.

headline: Clip: ‘Test’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Chris Mason Johnson.

headline: 36 Hours in Venice
text: As frustrating as it is fascinating, Venice is not an easy city to get to know. Getting lost is a given. The crowds can be beastly. And yes, the whole place is sinking — literally under rising sea levels, and figuratively beneath the weight of day-tripping tourists. But these obstacles have not hindered this beguiling city from establishing itself over the past decade as the pre-eminent place in Italy for contemporary art. More recently, a wave of high-end hotels has opened along the Grand Canal, and back alleys have been set abuzz with new nightspots and a revived restaurant scene. So leave the famous sights to the crowds and instead drink up the less overt charms of this watery wonderland.

headline: Grimly Staring in the Mirror, a Dancer in ’85
text: “Test,” set in San Francisco in 1985, captures with extraordinary precision and sensitivity the moment when an H.I.V. test became available, and the city’s gay men faced the daunting prospect of finding out their status. In those scary days, there was no pharmaceutical regimen that could arrest the disease. And as one man, looking ahead to a future of sexual self-discipline, puts it, “Monogamy seems so unnatural.” In the golden era of promiscuity and unprotected sex, the notion of suddenly having to use condoms seemed almost an affront, not to mention inconvenient.

headline: Events on Long Island for June 15-21, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut for June 15-21, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Ford Lowers Gas Mileage on 6 Models, All 2013-14s
text: For the second time in less than a year, the Ford Motor Company is lowering the fuel-economy ratings for some of its vehicles.

headline: Kentile Floors Sign, a Stalwart Remnant of a Grittier Brooklyn, Will Get a New Home
text: It is confirmed: The Kentile Floors sign in Brooklyn is coming down.

headline: An Insurer and an Ad Agency Join Forces, Again
text: A WALK down memory lane for a major marketer and one of its former advertising agencies, inspired by “Mad Men,” is ending with a reunion.

headline: When Chaos Trumps Civility
text: The opening scenes of Amat Escalante’s “Heli” establish the terrible contradiction that ensnares its main character, a young Mexican factory worker. First, we see a brazen but also unnervingly businesslike act of brutality, in which a group of men drag two bound-and-battered hostages from the bed of a pickup truck and hang one of them, stripped to his underwear, from a highway overpass. Then we meet Heli (Armando Espitia) as he answers a knock on the door and chats with a friendly census worker in a bright yellow polo shirt. Her questions sound reasonable enough at first: How many people in the household? What is your profession? Later they will seem grotesquely irrelevant to the facts of Heli’s life.

headline: Global Rules for Auditors? Don’t Hold Your Breath
text: Chris Cox, who as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to bring international accounting rules to the United States, has now done an about-face.

headline: One Generation Passes; Another One Grumbles
text: Am I a hardhearted meanie because I watched “Lullaby,” a solemn, triple-hankie sobfest about assisted suicide, in a state of dry-eyed impatience? Maybe so. But “Lullaby,” the directorial debut of Andrew Levitas, a jack of all artistic trades, is the kind of manipulative, cliché-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears. Its subliminal message — “I’m more sensitive than you could possibly be” — is exclusionary, and much of its stilted dialogue (“It’s hard to love someone who’s got an expiration date stamped on their forehead”) is cringe worthy.

headline: The Fix Isn’t In
text: How big a deal is the surprise primary defeat of Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader? Very. Movement conservatism, which dominated American politics from the election of Ronald Reagan to the election of Barack Obama — and which many pundits thought could make a comeback this year — is unraveling before our eyes.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Jesus, You’ll Be the Stick-Up Guy. SpongeBob, You’re a Lookout.
text: Not counting a prologue right out of “Macbeth,” the Spanish comedy “Witching & Bitching” begins as a madcap heist picture. In Madrid, a group of hapless would-be criminals — dressed as a silver Christ, a soldier, Minnie Mouse, the Invisible Man and SpongeBob SquarePants — steals gold from a pawnshop.

headline: Taking On Teacher Tenure Backfires
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — IN his decision on Tuesday to strike down California’s teacher-tenure system, Judge Rolf M. Treu of Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that laws protecting teachers from dismissal violated the state’s constitutional commitment to provide “a basically equal opportunity to achieve a quality education” and drew parallels with prior cases concerning school desegregation and funding levels.

headline: Cy Twombly Works Donated to Tate Modern
text: Since 2010, the Tate Modern in London has devoted a gallery to Cy Twombly, the postwar American painter who died in 2011. In it are three large paintings from his “Bacchus” series — enormous abstract canvases of drippy red spirals dating from 2006-8 — along with five bronze sculptures and assemblages of found objects, such as the top of an olive barrel, that were made between 1979 and 1991.

headline: Secrets of the Ordinary Dad
text: His gut was a jellyroll or two over the belt line and he smoked these discount cigarettes he bought by the carton, but that didn’t keep him from showing me one of his more nimble tricks. We’d wait till just after kickoff at the football game, the Cougars of Washington State. Then he’d lead me around the side where we could sneak in by crawling under a small opening in a big chain-link fence. I was 6 or 7.

headline: Private Toll Road Considered to Counter Population Boom
text: Facing traffic congestion that is only expected to get worse, officials in North Texas are weighing a proposal to build a toll road for commuters into Dallas. The Texas Turnpike Corporation of Dallas has proposed a private toll road, the only of its kind in the state, connecting Greenville and Wylie, and local transportation officials say they are keeping an open mind.

headline: Truth as a Tinderbox That Must Disappear
text: Depicting his combustible material with a cool head and a steady hand, the Iranian filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof — defying a 20-year government ban on his work — makes “Manuscripts Don’t Burn” a slow-motion explosion of anti-authoritarian rage.

headline: Save the Frick Collection
text: AMERICA has few mansions built by a family with an art collection they meant to share with the public. So when word came this week that the Frick Collection, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was planning to expand and build a six-story addition where there is now a discreet garden and a splashing fountain with lily pads — one of those few places in the cityscape where we are allowed to stop and breathe — I felt blunt disappointment, as well as betrayal.

headline: Under the Skin
text: CHICAGO — TRANSGENDER Americans scored a major victory for equality last month, when the Department of Health and Human Services overturned a decades-old ban on Medicare coverage for gender-confirming surgeries.

headline: A Young Man’s Dark-Roasted Day
text: A day-in-the-life story, “A Coffee in Berlin” follows the downward-sloping fortunes of Niko, a scruffily poetic slacker who loses his girlfriend, his driver’s license and his financial support from Daddy. And that’s before night falls.

headline: New York Attorney General Supports a Bill Regulating Payroll Cards
text: After firing a warning shot last July, New York’s attorney general has stepped up his battle against the A.T.M.-style cards that some of the state’s largest employers use to pay their workers.

headline: Democrats Hope for Shift in Their Favor
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Those Offensive Linemen Make a Filling Meal
text: One witch and four cheerleaders enact savage revenge on the stars of a high school football team in “All Cheerleaders Die,” a trashy horror caper oozing blood and pheromones.

headline: Hostile Takeover Bids for Big Firms Across Industries Make a Comeback
text: Endurance Specialty Holdings’ offer for Aspen Insurance Holdings in April did not get much attention from the broader business world.

headline: A Move to Get Youths to Take Tuition Aid After Foster Care
text: By the time Corey Vollette decided to go to college — after years spent adrift after dropping out of high school — it was too late to take advantage of an exemption from tuition and fees at a public college or university in Texas.

headline: In Emerging Markets, What Scares Most Investors Entices Oppenheimer
text: The day has been long for Justin M. Leverenz, who runs America’s largest emerging markets mutual fund at Oppenheimer Funds.

headline: Westchester Adopts a New Plan to Save Rye Playland
text: How to save Rye Playland, the old-timey amusement park in Rye, N.Y., owned by Westchester County, has been a conundrum, and a source of local tension, for years.

headline: Winding Journeys to the N.B.A.’s Summit
text: MIAMI — Fortune is not often discriminatory when it chooses those it will ultimately smile upon. Eleven years ago, before he became the ink-swathed and enigmatic Birdman, Chris Andersen was merely a very tall tag-along, uncomfortably folded into the way back of my Volvo station wagon.

headline: From Invalid to Nanny, in a Twinkling of an Eye
text: The Mexican director Claudia Sainte-Luce orchestrates the beginning of “The Amazing Catfish” to show her sluggish main character — a young supermarket clerk, also named Claudia — finally waking up, in a manner of speaking. First she literally awakens, in an ineffably eerie, dimly lighted scene. But it’s during a sudden hospital visit, in a room with an older woman named Martha (Lisa Owen), that she feels the unfamiliar tug of family.

headline: Clothes Make the Player
text: The Great Neck Weekend Softball league — with its modest slogan: “The Greatest Pickup Game on Earth” — does not take itself too seriously.

headline: Methodists to Sell Shares as a Protest Over Israel
text: The pension board of the nation’s largest mainline Protestant denomination, the United Methodist Church, has decided to divest its shares in a British company that supplies security equipment to Israel for use in prisons and in the occupied West Bank.

headline: U.S. Bishops Seek to Match Vatican in Shifting Tone
text: NEW ORLEANS — They are rethinking what kinds of houses they live in, and what kinds of cars they drive. They are wondering whether, in anticipation of the 2016 presidential election, they need to rewrite their advice to parishioners to make sure that poverty, and not just abortion, is discussed as a high-priority issue. And they are trying to get better about returning phone calls, reaching out to the disenchanted and the disenfranchised, and showing up at events.

headline: U.S. Denies Talk on 2022 World Cup
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The president of the United States Soccer Federation, Sunil Gulati, denied a report that FIFA had asked it to form an organizing committee that could take over preparations for the 2022 World Cup if it is taken away from Qatar.

headline: A Good Ruling on Privacy
text: The capacity of cellphones to track people’s movements and provide a vivid picture of their private lives poses a substantial and growing threat to privacy.

headline: The Port Authority Is Fooled Again
text: The purchase of 131 acres along the waterfront of Bayonne, N.J., in 2010 was a fabulous bargain for the seller, the struggling city of Bayonne, and a windfall for New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie. It was not such a good deal for the buyer — the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Iraq in Peril
text: What’s happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.

headline: ‘A Lot of Oops Moments,’ but the Scores at the U.S. Open Aren’t Too Shabby
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Matt Kuchar’s second shot at the 18th hole rolled through the green, sped down an embankment and did not stop until it was in the clubhouse. A Brandt Snedeker bunker shot ricocheted behind him and settled in the woods. Justin Rose came within an inch of a hole in one, but after his ball flirted with the cup, it ended up so far from the hole Rose chose a wood to play his next shot. In a flash, a near ace became a bogey.

headline: A Woman Is Courted, but the Suitor Is Her Father
text: To the mini-trend in films about aging parents in decline (“Amour,” “Away From Her,” the recent “Grand Départ”), add “I Am I,” a wispy vanity project for the writer-director-actress Jocelyn Towne. Rachael (Ms. Towne) is at her mother’s funeral when she encounters Gene (Kevin Tighe), her father, who left shortly after Rachael was born. Gene, his memory dimming, has been in a retirement home. When he meets Rachael, he falls under the delusion that she is her mother, for whom he still carries a torch. Rachael, to know him better, eventually decides to play along.

headline: Obama’s Odds With Congress: Bad to Worse
text: WASHINGTON — One day in April, President Obama called Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, to wish him a happy Passover. However the call started, it went downhill from there. By day’s end, both sides were arguing about what was said and taking shots at the other for not getting along.

headline: The Big Burn
text: When the United States invaded Iraq in 2003, it effectively destroyed the Iraqi government. Slowly learning from that mistake, the U.S. spent the next eight years in a costly round of state-building. As Dexter Filkins, who covered the war for The Times, wrote in a blog post this week for The New Yorker, “By 2011, by any reasonable measure, the Americans had made a lot of headway but were not finished with the job.”

headline: Stewart Tributes Fill Day 1 of U.S. Open as Mickelson Feels the Crowd’s Support
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — The United States Open course and the fans who lined it showed their softer side on Thursday. How could a mushy sentimentality not prevail given that wherever you looked on Pinehurst No. 2 on a leaden morning, the ghost of Payne Stewart lurked?

headline: Reaction to Brazil’s First Goal
text: From across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup.

headline: The Iraqi Army Was Crumbling Long Before Its Collapse, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The stunning collapse of Iraq’s army in a string of cities across the north reflects poor leadership, declining troop morale, broken equipment and a sharp decline in training since the last American advisers left the country in 2011, American military and intelligence officials said Thursday.

headline: Brazil’s First Goal
text: Across the country, Brazilian fans react to their team’s first goal of the 2014 World Cup, in what would be a 3-1 victory against Croatia.

headline: In Weapons Case, Prosecutors Press 2 Brothers to Urge 3rd to Come to U.S. to Plead Guilty
text: It was an unusual example of family pressure, exerted by federal prosecutors against two brothers.

headline: After Florida State Rape Case, Police Will Revise Procedures
text: The police department in Tallahassee, Fla., the target of stinging criticism and national attention for its handling of a rape accusation against Florida State University’s Heisman Trophy winner, Jameis Winston, has begun working with a respected women’s advocacy group to rewrite its sexual assault complaint policy.

headline: Spain Enters as a Favorite That’s Forgotten
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — For the first time in more than 60 years, the World Cup is back in the spiritual home of soccer, and it is only natural that the pretournament spotlight has been overwhelmingly focused on the hosts and their enormously popular players.

headline: Job Losses in Need of Interpreting
text: New York is the city of tongues, a metropolis where language has about 800 separate tributaries, the babbling global capital of human speech.

headline: Iraqis Who Fled Mosul Say They Prefer Militants to Government
text: ERBIL, Iraq — After Islamic extremists swarmed his city this week, Saad Hussein fled here with his wife and six children. But after one night, he was on his way back home to Mosul, hearing that things were quiet there.

headline: Clip: ‘The Signal’
text: A scene from William Eubank’s film featuring Brenton Thwaites and Laurence Fishburne.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 12, 2014
The Tip of the Iceberg: Rethinking Life After High School
text: “Ivory Tower,” a documentary about soaring costs and other problems confronting higher education, can’t seem to decide what points it wants to make and ends up making none. Parts of it seem like free advertising for the institutions it visits, which include Harvard, Arizona State University and experimental institutions like Deep Springs College. Other parts sound the already familiar lament that students come out of college with crushing debts and no prospects for the kinds of jobs that would enable them to pay off those debts. There are suggestions that colleges do a poor job of actually educating students, and that the cost issue is a result of bloated administrative salaries and a rush to build showpiece campuses.

headline: The World’s Ball
text: An evolution, from 1930 to today.

headline: Hackers Take a Road Trip, With a Sci-Fi Detour
text: William Eubank’s “The Signal” demonstrates the fine line between paranoid science-fiction fantasy and demo reel. Both involve impressive visions of reality reimagined, and both defy logic extravagantly and yet somehow casually, too. Mr. Eubank’s diverting but disconnected film might fairly be described as a little bit of each.

headline: Vermont G.O.P. Finds Candidates in Short Supply
text: MONTPELIER, Vt. — The Vermont Republican Party website makes a plain-spoken appeal: “CANDIDATES WANTED.”

headline: Family Guy
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a big day coming up this weekend, and if you are a dad or have ever been important in the life of a child, Wordplay wishes you a happy Father’s Day.

headline: Take a Dive, Have a Drink
text: A game you can play while the footballers are playing theirs.

headline: With Data and Resolve, Tacoma Fights Pollution
text: TACOMA, Wash. — Last year, environmental engineers working for this city had an unnerving worry. After a decade and tens of millions of dollars devoted to a fastidious cleanup of its corner of Puget Sound, Tacoma’s shore front was in danger of being contaminated with a highly toxic chemical.

headline: Former BP Engineer Wins New Trial in Case on Gulf Spill
text: A federal judge in New Orleans has ordered a new trial for a former BP engineer convicted of deleting text messages relevant to an investigation of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, concluding that outside information influenced the jury’s verdict.

headline: A Dominatrix Who Hates Heels
text: Emmanuelle Seigner hates high heels and avoids wearing them at all costs. When the designer Tom Ford asked her to walk in a fashion show, she successfully pleaded with him to put her in flats. But there was no avoiding them in her latest film, “Venus in Fur,” directed by her husband, Roman Polanski, in which she plays a dominatrix of sorts whose sartorial centerpiece is a pair of thigh-high kinky boots.

headline: Tanks, of Unknown Origin, Roll Into Ukraine
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Ukraine’s interior minister claimed on Thursday that an armored column from Russia had crossed the border into eastern Ukraine overnight and had fought with Ukrainian troops during the day.

headline: As Sunni Militants Threaten Its Allies in Baghdad, Iran Weighs Options
text: TEHRAN — In years past, Iranian officials would smirk when recalling how the United States had done the dirty work for them by removing the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein, a Sunni who led an eight-year war against Shiite Iran.

headline: Officials to Investigate Reports of Mistreatment of Minors Caught Crossing Border
text: Border officials opened an investigation on Thursday into claims by legal aid groups that border agents were mistreating unaccompanied minors caught crossing the Southwest border illegally.

headline: The Goal Heard Round Brazil
text: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazil’s first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.

headline: Dino? Ol’ Blue Eyes? All the Above, by Jerry
text: The movie widely regarded as Jerry Lewis’s masterpiece, “The Nutty Professor” (1963), arrives with a swagger on the occasion of its 51st anniversary in a deluxe “50th Anniversary Collectors Edition,” from Warner Bros. Home Entertainment.

headline: Building Nuclear Weapon Would Take Years, Not Months, Iran Says in Report
text: WASHINGTON — The Iranian government this week published its first detailed study of how long it estimates it would take its scientists and engineers to assemble a nuclear weapon, saying that with its current infrastructure, “the required time span is in years.”

headline: Giant Seeks Return to Pre-Injury Success
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants safety Stevie Brown intercepted a pass against the Jets in a preseason game on Aug. 24 and was racing down the left side when he spotted an opening toward the middle of the field. He pushed off on his left leg — and it buckled.

headline: Chicago Winces After a Jewel Is Stamped ‘Trump’
text: CHICAGO — There was a collective sigh of relief when Donald Trump opened his 92-story hotel and condominium tower here six years ago.

headline: In Bitterly Contested House Primary, a State Legislator Defends His Record
text: In 2007, Hispanic lawmakers saw a crisis brewing on eastern Long Island: Under the direction of the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, the police were raiding rooming houses full of immigrants and arresting drivers, many of them Hispanic, who lacked licenses or identification. The county jail was running checks to catch inmates in the country illegally.

headline: Campus Colleagues, Basketball Teammates, and Now, Political Rivals
text: ASHLAND, Va. — Before the two professors became overnight political rivals in one of the most improbable, high-profile races in memory, they knew each other best as basketball teammates.

headline: Concerns on Mad Cow Lead to Recall
text: Dozens of Whole Foods stores in the Northeast and a restaurant in New York received beef over an eight-month period that may not have been properly slaughtered to reduce the threat of mad cow disease, federal officials said on Thursday.

headline: Greece Wars With Courts Over Ways to Slash Budget
text: ATHENS — The Greek government has made a range of painful cuts to salaries, pensions and jobs for public workers over the last four years, saying they were needed to satisfy the demands of the international creditors that bailed the country out. But the Greeks hurt by those steps, and the nation’s courts, have a different idea.

headline: Cantor Loss May Temper House Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — For all the talk of a lurch to the right after the primary election defeat this week of the House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the race to remake the Republican leadership may actually leave its top ranks more moderate.

headline: Obama’s Checkup: Healthy, but Ouch, That Right Foot
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is often on his feet, and it is starting to hurt.

headline: Hot Off the Press
text: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, print’s age-old medium is a material of modern design.

headline: Despite Upheavals, NBC Extends Lauer’s Contract
text: NBC’s “Today” show issued a new endorsement of its longtime anchor Matt Lauer on Thursday, signing the veteran newsman to a contract extension that will keep him in place on the morning show for what NBC described as multiple more years.

headline: Heat’s Crash Course Can’t Prevent Another Wreck Against the Spurs
text: MIAMI — It was no fun. Before meeting the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, the Heat spent a substantial portion of Wednesday huddled in a darkened room watching film of their well-publicized debacle in Game 3.

headline: A Dance-Off With Fallon. Next Up, Clinton?
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s appearance on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” on Thursday resembled a spurned suitor’s return to the site of his humiliation.

headline: Tanaka’s Early Performance Eliciting Praise From Nearly Everyone but Him
text: SEATTLE — Masahiro Tanaka is neither impressed nor surprised that a little more than two months into his first major league season, he is one of only two pitchers with 10 victories.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Showtime) DAVID BECKHAM INTO THE UNKNOWN Just in time for the World Cup, the director Anthony Mandler follows Mr. Beckham, above, the retired soccer superstar, and his friends Derek White and Dave Gardner into the heart of the Amazon in Brazil, where they travel by motorcycle and boat from Manaus to Angelin, across the Negro and Cuieras Rivers, and deep into the rain forest to mingle with the remote Yanomami tribe.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 13, 2014
text: “We have to have a home, have to have a car that’s not going to fall apart in the middle of the desert, but within reason we have to live simply.”

headline: In Trying to Halt the Mets’ Slide, Wright Is Enduring His Own Struggles
text: Often this season, when the Mets have started to slide, David Wright has stressed the importance of stopping it before it gets worse. He has sounded urgent and a tad desperate, perhaps because in each of the previous five seasons, he felt a sense of inevitability set in, like a man standing atop a leaky dam staring down a flood.

headline: At Rangers’ Practice, Mood Is Light but Focused
text: LOS ANGELES — The Rangers have reached the point of the Stanley Cup finals where mileage in the air and wear on their bodies provide yet another test of mettle for them and their opponents, the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: Cameroon Players Say Protest and Late Arrival Have Not Affected Morale
text: NATAL, Brazil — Four days after Cameroon players refused to board a flight to Brazil in a dispute over World Cup pay, Coach Volker Finke attributed the disagreement to cultural norms in Africa and played down its significance to the team’s preparations.

text: LONDON – The Italian lender Unicredit has received approval from regulators for an initial public offering of its online banking arm that could value the unit at up to $3.62 billion.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms
text: BAGHDAD — The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew on Friday as the country’s top Shiite cleric implored his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni extremist militants who have captured broad stretches of northern territory this week in a sweep toward Baghdad.

headline: A German Rebel in South Africa
text: When Jürgen Schadeberg was forced to join the Hitler Youth, he knew wearing brown shirts, marching in step and singing the glories of the Führer and the Fatherland were not for him. Even before his teens, he abhorred what they stood for.

headline: More Protein in Diet May Lower Stroke Risk
text: Getting more protein in your diet, though not red meat, may reduce your risk for stroke, a review of studies found.

headline: Debate Rages After Death Sentences Overturned in Child Prostitution Case
text: Should a person be executed for raping or prostituting a child? That question — which lay behind an explosion of comments as Chinese responded on Friday to a Supreme People’s Court decision overturning the death sentences of two men for crimes committed against an 11-year-old girl — seemed hardly the point.

headline: Wrongness, OK and Not
text: USA! USA! NYC! Back from Oxford, but still — as you can see from the posting time — jet-lagged. I have a steakhouse dinner tonight in honor of Eric Cantor with some business economists; we’ll see if I end up face down in my tenderloin.

headline: Daily Report: Scrutinizing Silicon Valley’s Response to Obama’s Climate Goals
text: If the United States is going to achieve President Obama’s new climate change goals, an X factor is how Silicon Valley will respond, Claire Cain Miller reports. Success will depend, many analysts think, on whether the policy will spur entrepreneurs to come up with new technologies and create a clean energy economy.

headline: Company Backed by Robert Diamond Likely to Miss Fund-Raising Goal
text: LONDON – The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., is likely to fall short of the $400 million it was seeking in a second round of fund-raising to back investments in the African financial sector, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: A Better Way to Rank Soccer Teams in a Fairer World Cup
text: The World Cup draw needs to be fairer, as I proposed last week in a system that includes the seeding of teams from 1 to 32.

headline: China and Japan Face Off Over Documentation of Wartime Atrocities
text: China and Japan, whose festering relationship has seen their rival military aircraft buzz each other over the East China Sea, have found yet another forum in which to duel: Unesco’s Memory of the World Register.

headline: No Ceremony for Bowe Bergdahl Upon Return to U.S. Soil
text: SAN ANTONIO — Exactly 1,809 days after he was captured by Taliban fighters who kept him in a metal cage for weeks and possibly months during nearly five years in captivity, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to the United States early Friday to a homecoming void of any of his relatives and dampened by a swirling controversy over his capture and release.

headline: Tableau Software Helping Data Become More Visual

headline: States Choose to Defer Employee Choice for Health Plans
text: When it set the final rules implementing small-business health insurance exchanges for next year, the federal government gave states the option of taking a one-year pass on one of the exchanges’ most attractive features: the opportunity for small-business employees to choose among a variety of health plans. This week, the Department of Health and Human Services announced that 18 states would in fact defer employee choice until 2016.

headline: Eric Cantor Is Not a Reform Conservative
text: One thing we’re hearing about Eric Cantor’s primary defeat is that it’s bad for “reform conservatism.” That’s a term that means different things to different people, but for these purposes I’m talking about a different domestic agenda from the one the Republican Party has been pursuing in recent years and one that centers on middle-class economic concerns.

headline: Morning Views
text: “What’s happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.” The New York Times editorial board comments on the sudden capture of Mosul by Sunni militants, and the greater threat to Iraq and the Middle East region, noting there are few good options in resolving the crisis with ease or speed.

headline: Fears About Iraq Continue to Push Up Oil Prices
text: LONDON — The oil markets are likely to remain on edge, as escalating tensions in Iraq prompt concerns over supplies in the major oil-producing country.

headline: Islamic Insurgents Advance on Baghdad

headline: Morning Agenda: Univision’s Sale Talks
text: UNIVISION OWNERS SAID TO WEIGH A SALE  |  The owners of Univision Communications, the biggest Spanish-language broadcaster in the United States, are said to have held preliminary talks about a potential sale with media companies in recent weeks, including CBS, Time Warner and Viacom, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The talks were at a very early stage and no sales process is underway at the moment. Should Univision’s owners ‒ a consortium led by the billionaire Haim Saban ‒ pursue a sale, they will probably expect bids to top at least $20 billion.

headline: Swedish Auteur Takes On a Brave Loner
text: From “High Noon” to “Silkwood” and “The Insider,” the courageous loner who stands up to evil at great personal risk is a familiar film figure. Now the Swedish master Jan Troell has added to that gallery with “The Last Sentence,” his portrait of Torgny Segerstedt, a Swedish newspaper editor who was an early, ferocious and persistent critic of Hitler, defying both Nazi threats and his own government’s pleas not to undermine its neutral stance.

headline: What to Consider When Looking for the Right Place to Retire
text: Models of pre-retirement planning, Don and Reina Weiner bought an acre of land almost a decade ago in the Woodlands of Chapel Hill, a mixed-age community in North Carolina.

headline: The Lack of Major Wars May Be Hurting Economic Growth
text: The continuing slowness of economic growth in high-income economies has prompted soul-searching among economists. They have looked to weak demand, rising inequality, Chinese competition, over-regulation, inadequate infrastructure and an exhaustion of new technological ideas as possible culprits.

headline: Ackman’s Hedge Fund Sues Botox Maker Allergan Over Poison Pill Trigger
text: Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by the activist investor William A. Ackman, has sued Allergan, the target of a hostile bid from Pershing Square and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

text: Updated, 4:12 p.m. |  Not content with a commanding presence in online travel booking, Priceline is now taking aim at the world of dinner reservations.
