text: Dear Diary:

headline: Indications of Growth in U.S. Job Market
text: FOR more than 60 years, unemployment in the United States was largely a short-term problem. The level of unemployment went up and down, but most of the unemployed found work relatively quickly. Few remained out of work for as long as 15 weeks. Long-term unemployment was always a lesser problem.

headline: British Regulator Osborne Takes a Step Forward for Foreign Exchange Oversight
text: Michael O’Brien and Bill Nosal are senior executives with Nasdaq OMX’s SMARTS market surveillance.

headline: And a Choir Shall Heal Them
text: The Scottish playwright David Greig was hard to pin down while traveling in the highlands of his homeland recently, so it turned out to be eerily coincidental that we finally spoke the day after Elliot O. Rodger went on a murderous rampage in Isla Vista, Calif. Efforts to understand what motivated the young man were popping up all over the Internet as Mr. Greig discussed “The Events,” his 2013 play about the anguished aftermath of a deadly shooting.

headline: Keep Fighting For Sane Gun Restrictions. Only Harder.
text: Like many Americans — most, actually, I venture — I feel the same sense of frustration and anger over Congress’s failure to approve stricter gun laws that President Obama expressed following this week’s fatal school shooting in Oregon.

headline: Upset Fueling Tea Party Hope in Senate Race
text: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — Moments after a little-known economics professor in Virginia became a conservative sensation by toppling Eric Cantor, the House Republican leader, Chris McDaniel, the Tea Party’s best hope for a Senate seat this year, got a text message from his best friend in Mississippi’s capital.

headline: Selling TOMS: The Questions, and a Few Answers
text: The fashion/philanthropy world was surprised by the news in The Financial Times this week that TOMS — the shoe brand started by Blake Mycoskie in 2006 and based on the One-to-One model (for every pair sold, a pair is given away) — was up for sale.

headline: U.N. Warns of Rights Abuses and Hundreds Dead in Iraq Fighting
text: GENEVA — As Sunni insurgents pursued an offensive toward Baghdad on Friday, Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, expressed “extreme alarm” over what she termed summary executions, rape, reprisal killings and shelling of civilians, putting the first estimate of casualties in the hundreds.

headline: Comcast Seeking to Replace G.E.’s Initials Atop 30 Rock
text: Comcast is known for its low-key corporate culture. At its 58-story headquarters, the tallest building in Philadelphia, a boxy glass crown gleams conspicuously but anonymously.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘22 Jump Street,’ ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’ and ‘The Rover’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics look at “22 Jump Street,” “The Rover” and “How to Train Your Dragon 2.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: In Fashion | The Return of Alice Roi
text: For girls-about-downtown in the late ’90s and early aughts, Alice Roi was a patron saint. The lower-Manhattan-born-and-bred designer with the cool-kid persona created clothes that tempered a girlish sensibility with a subtle sense of humor. There were the “La Caricature” dresses, covered in an Honoré Daumier print of two snobs turning their noses at each other. There were the Yeti-like mohair jackets and the bare-shouldered tops with cutouts meant to resemble crewneck openings. The line was a cult hit until 2008, when Roi became a mom and not only shuttered her business but withdrew completely from the fashion world.

headline: A Lost Father, and a Daughter Who’s Not Ready to Let Him Go
text: While preparing my daughter for her preschool graduation ceremony last year, a text message buzzed my phone from my brother: “Dad has been missing for two hours.”

headline: 2 Private Equity Settlements Followed Failure of Broader Talks on Collusion Lawsuit
text: For six years, the biggest private equity firms fought a lawsuit that accused them of illegal collusion during the buyout boom. Their strategy, through rounds of difficult settlement talks, was to stick together.

headline: Former Goldman Director Gupta’s Last Days of Freedom
text: On Tuesday, Rajat K. Gupta, the former managing director of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company who was convicted of insider trading, is scheduled to report to a minimum-security prison camp in Massachusetts, spending the next two years not far from his onetime friend and partner in crime, Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: For Cantor, Loss of Leadership Role Means Far Fewer Perks
text: WASHINGTON — As House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia has enjoyed a bump in salary, a large political staff, an elegant office suite on the second floor of the Capitol and a security detail that drove him to and from his suburban Richmond home.

headline: Critique of Narendra Modi in College Magazine Leads to Arrest of Seven
text: A college magazine that published an implied, strident critique of Narendra Modi, the newly elected prime minister, incited enough ill will that six students on the magazine’s editorial staff were arrested Wednesday and accused of printing defamatory material and of provocation with the intent of causing riots, among other crimes.

headline: If a Teenager Lands a Summer Job, the Value Is Lasting
text: HUNTER-JOHN HURST, 16, of Raleigh, N.C., is a living example of a modern-day conundrum. Like many others his age, he needs to earn money this summer. But finding a job is tougher than ever, with the number of teenagers employed nationwide at a near-historical low.

headline: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The State Department said Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine, supporting accusations Thursday by the Ukrainian government.

headline: Who Made That Inflatable Noisemaker?
text: As soccer fans arrived at Portland’s Civic Stadium on Sept. 7, 1997, they were handed an unfamiliar implement: a pair of long balloons, sponsored by Nike, designed to make their cheering louder. “That was the first time I saw those inflatable things that people bang together,” says Tab Ramos, a starting player on that U.S. men’s soccer team and now an assistant coach. The sellout crowd for the World Cup qualifier, among the noisiest that Ramos had ever heard, reached maximum cacophony when he scored the winning goal. “The stadium sounded like it was going to fall down,” he says.

headline: Reply All: The 6.1.14 Issue
text: LIFE IN THE VALLEY OF DEATH

headline: Highly, Highly Recommended
text: As part of a typical hiring process, I asked a job applicant for a reference. It turned out that I already knew the reference, who was very supportive of the candidate. The man got the job. After I extended the offer, I heard through the grapevine that the applicant and the reference were romantically linked. The hire has performed very well, but I felt that they both should have been more forthright about their relationship. Should they have been? JEFF H., SAN DIEGO

headline: Before Learning to Crawl, You Must Learn to Swim
text: Rachael Ubiera, a 25-year-old in Kissimmee, Fla., considers herself “one of the relaxed moms.” But the first time she saw her 5-month-old daughter, Zoe, carefully dropped underwater in a pool for infant survival swim training, it was nerve-racking. “She looked surprised,” Ubiera says. “Like, ‘What are you doing to me?’ ” Zoe was being introduced to “self-rescue,” in which babies are taught to hold their breath underwater, kick their feet, turn over to float on their backs and rest until help arrives. The technique, photographed here by Seth Casteel, who is working on a related book that will come out next spring, was pioneered in the late ’60s by Harvey Barnett, who at 18 became determined to teach infants to swim after the drowning of a neighbor’s child. His methods have spread around the world — taught in clinics and imitated widely. “It gives the baby the best possible chance,” he says. Julie Bosman

headline: The Breakup List
text: It was summertime in Brooklyn, so hot that the trees were shedding leaves and the Realtors were sweating through their starched shirts and stopping on street corners to wipe down their Bluetooth earpieces. My girlfriend — we’d been together, more or less, since our first date in February — was staying with me for a couple of weeks while she sublet her apartment. She was between trips abroad. She was always traveling for work. I’d set her up at my kitchen table with the wireless password. I got her a partner membership at my gym. We cranked up the air-conditioner in the bedroom at night and lay across the comforter to let our sweat dry. In the mornings, the tired air-conditioner wheezed out a spray of mist.

headline: Love, Kuwaiti Style
text: Way out of Eden: Adam and Eve, with fangs; pneumonia in Arizona.

headline: Can General Linder’s Special Operations Forces Stop the Next Terrorist Threat?
text: On a searing morning this spring, Brig. Gen. James B. Linder leaned against the red-webbing seats of a C-130 as it flew over the Sahara. On his camouflaged knee, he balanced two dog-eared Moleskine notebooks and a map of Africa. Linder, who is in his early 50s, commands the United States Special Operations forces in Africa. He was on his way to visit a detachment of 12 Army Green Berets training with African troops to fight Al Qaeda and its affiliates in Niger. Through the plane’s scratched plexiglass portholes, dunes crested like waves in an ocean of sand, and hot blasts of wind buffeted the fuselage. An hour’s flight to the south, his team of Special Forces was deployed along the Nigerian border, where the militant group Boko Haram was targeting children in its bid to establish an Islamic state.

headline: World Cup Is Huge on Twitter … in Japan
text: The World Cup buzz is building on social media – in Brazil, in England and, most of all, in Japan.

headline: Washington’s Gyms Want a Tax Break. That’s a Problem.
text: When I went to the gym in Washington on Thursday, I was urged to get on Twitter and tell local leaders members “#donttaxfitness.” That’s because next Tuesday, the Council of the District of Columbia will vote on expanding the sales tax to include gym memberships and related services, like yoga and personal training; currently, those kinds of services aren’t taxed.

headline: Charity Golf Events Have Courses Filling Up
text: HOURS before the start of the Jonas Center Golf Classic, rain was pouring down. The skies were thick with clouds, and puddles were forming in the fairways of the Stanwich Club, a private country club in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: The Killer Assessment
text: Nothing inflicts fear and loathing on the heart of a co-op resident like the specter of a major assessment. The A-word has to be the most unpopular notification a co-op board ever drops on shareholders, the verbal equivalent of a stink bomb. Trouble, anxiety and intramural back-stabbing inevitably ensue.

headline: Arachnid Phobia
text: What looks like a spider bite and acts like a spider bite but isn’t a spider bite?

headline: Should We Learn to Live With Debt?
text: The country’s $1.1 trillion of student loan debt continues to inspire plans for relief. But as these are debated, some borrowers are dealing with a more personal issue: what to do, and how to live, while they pay.

headline: DiMaggio and Sinatra: The Feud Between Two Italian-American Pathbreakers
text: In March 1949, Joe DiMaggio posed in Yankee Stadium, smiling, with another famous Italian-American of his era — each in his professional uniform — but their friendship would not endure.

headline: Using Artists to Sell Condos in Miami and New York
text: With cities like New York and Miami in the midst of another luxury condominium boom, developers seem to be tripping over one another in the scramble to announce their latest projects, and to stand out from the pack, they are locked in an escalating game of one-upmanship.

headline: In Store | A New Multibrand Concept Boutique in Detroit
text: Perhaps the most visible new success story in the ongoing effort to revitalize Detroit’s economy is Shinola — the three-year-old leather goods and lifestyle brand which employs more than 130 people at its bicycle and watch manufacturing facilities there (and some 130 more in its offices and retail operations). Now, a couple of doors down from its store in the city’s emerging Midtown district, the company is spawning what might be Detroit’s first multibrand concept boutique. Willys, which opens to the public on Saturday, takes its name from the Willys Overland Motor Company, which invented the first jeep in 1941 and was for a time during the 1910s the second-largest car manufacturer in the U.S.; the 2,900-square-foot space is housed in the former service bay of the company’s old headquarters.

headline: Discovering What Defeat Looks Like
text: MIAMI — Toward the end of the third quarter of Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals Thursday, an intensely generic D.J. began exhorting the crowd in the Miami Heat’s arena to get loud. In the stands, a few women with bare midriffs stood up and randomly started shaking.

headline: A Literary Expert on Driving in the Dark
text: Stirring his pot of nightmares, legends, fairy tales and human folly into stories, the British-born fantasy writer Neil Gaiman has produced more than 20 books for children and adults, most of them scary and strange. The multitasking Mr. Gaiman is the author of the best-selling adult fairy tale “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” and the children’s books “Coraline” and “Stardust,” which have been made into films. He has written episodes for the sci-fi TV show “Dr. Who,” and is the author of the popular “Sandman”  series of graphic novels. And then there are his 1.9 million Twitter followers.

headline: Nathan Fielder, In Short
text: For this week’s magazine I profiled Nathan Fielder, whose excellent Comedy Central series, “Nathan for You,” begins its second season on July 1. The starting premise of his series is that Fielder — who is Canadian and studied marketing and entrepreneurship at college before turning in earnest to his comedy career — presents himself to actual business owners as a reality-TV business consultant, pitching them preposterously elaborate, compellingly off-kilter marketing schemes and then documenting the unpredictable results. (The entire first season of “Nathan for You” is currently available to watch free.)

headline: Today in Small Business: House Approves Small-Business Tax Break
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Behold the Fall Harvest
text: When BookExpo America, the annual trade convention, took place in Manhattan two weeks ago, the publishing industry turned its gaze to the traditionally heavy-hitting fall season.

headline: Motherhood
text: DRUNK MOM  A Memoir  By Jowita Bydlowska  Penguin, paper, $16.

headline: Flying Start
text: Perhaps the last of the great rugged individualists were the early pilots. Their dangerous solo missions made heroes of them all as they paved the way for modern aviation. None was more beloved than “Lucky Lindy” himself, Charles A. Lindbergh, who completed the first lone nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean on May 21, 1927. In a way reminiscent of Robert Lawson’s 1939 children’s book “Ben and Me,” which suggested that Benjamin Franklin’s brilliant ideas came from a Philadelphia mouse named Amos, the young German artist Torben Kuhlmann has reimagined the Lindbergh legend through the character of an inventive rodent.

headline: Cameroon vs. Mexico: Live Blog
text: Live coverage and analysis of the Mexico-Cameroon match. Mexico needs to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot. (Brazil will very likely get the first.) For Cameroon, this game is probably the best chance for a point in group play.

headline: Dragon Seed
text: Certain fairy tales are so ingrained in our consciousness that we have no memory of when we first heard them; there’s a sense we always knew them. I had that feeling when reading Rebecca Hahn’s debut novel, “A Creature of Moonlight.” Though Hahn’s story is new and wholly original, I immediately felt I had fallen into a dark and beautiful fairy tale, one that resonated like something important but long forgotten.

headline: Drawn to the Shore
text: In the first frames of “This One Summer,” a graphic novel written by Mariko Tamaki and illustrated by her cousin Jillian Tamaki, a father carries his sleeping daughter down a driveway to a cottage in the dark. This is Awago Beach, where Rose Wallace’s family has been coming “since . . . like . . . forever.” Or, more precisely, since Rose, who is now either an old tween or a young teenager (we don’t learn her exact age), was 5.

headline: Global Repositioning
text: The publishers of S. E. Grove’s novel, an ambitious and quixotic high fantasy called “The Glass Sentence,” smartly slapped upon the dust jacket an assessment by Megan Whalen Turner: “Not since Philip Pullman’s ‘The Golden Compass’ have I seen such an original and compelling world built inside a book.” A sensible precaution; it’s easy to suppose that “The Glass Sentence” was written in reaction to Pullman’s magisterial “His Dark Materials.” I am hardly one to lodge a complaint about that. Great works create their own gravitational field; Pullman wrote under the influence of Milton. The question ­remains: Does this admirer pull off something worthwhile of her own?

headline: Inside the List
text: Notorious: After spending two and a half months on the hardcover fiction list last year, Neil Gaiman’s fantasy novel “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” slips onto the trade paperback list this week at No. 8. The paperback follows on the heels of another book that should appeal to Gaiman’s fans — Hayley Campbell’s winningly scrapbookish tribute, “The Art of Neil Gaiman,” which Audrey Niffenegger describes in the foreword as “a sort of midcareer retrospective.” The book recounts Gaiman’s early days as a hungry arts journalist and his rise to cult success as a writer of comic books, notably the “Sandman” series, before he turned his hand to novels. It also reminds readers that Neil himself (as he’s known on Twitter) once wrote a scrapbookish tribute of his own: His first published book — “written solely for the money,” he says — was “Duran Duran: The First Four Years of the Fab Five” (1984). “I got a phone call from a lady,” Gaiman explains in an interview cited in the book, “and she said would you like to write a rock ’n’ roll book for us? A rock ’n’ roll biography? And I thought, ‘Oh God, yes! I’m in!’ ” Gaiman suggested a handful of subjects, including the Velvet Underground, David Bowie and Elvis Costello, before the editor interrupted: “Do you want to write the Duran Duran book, the Barry Manilow book or the Def Leppard book?” Pragmatism led him to choose the relative newcomers Duran Duran. “With Barry Manilow,” he said, “I figured I was going to have to listen to, you know, 40 Barry Manilow albums.”

headline: Office Max
text: How you work depends in large part on the spaces in which you work. This big theme is taken up by Nikil Saval in “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace.” There is in fact nothing “secret” about this history; from the Civil War on, as the white-collar world grew, managers and designers thought out loud about where workers should sit, the furniture they should use, the walls and windows that should surround them. Instead of a secret history, Saval, an editor of n+1, has written something more interesting. He has infused a straightforward factual account with all sorts of literary, cultural and political insights; these make the story he tells more dark than dry.

headline: Isolation Unit
text: Evie Wyld’s second novel opens with its narrator, a woman named Jake Whyte, discovering one of her sheep killed and gutted. Carrion birds are feasting: “Crows, their beaks shining, strutting and rasping, and when I waved my stick they flew to the trees and watched, flaring out their wings, singing, if you could call it that.” Jake shouts, “What are you laughing at?” and throws a rock at them.

headline: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night
text: Val McDermid’s “Northanger Abbey” is the second book to emerge from the Austen Project, in which Jane Austen’s published oeuvre is reimagined by 21st-­century authors. But early on her heroine, Cat Morland, encounters, via audiobook, the Gothic work of another 19th-century novelist — Bram Stoker’s “Dracula.” “For Cat,” we are told, “schooled only in contemporary vampire romance, it was a curious and unsettling experience. It reminded her of the first time she’d tasted an olive. It was unlike everything that had crossed her palate before; strange and not quite pleasant, yet gilded with the promise of sophistication.”

headline: Puritans’ Progress
text: Concord, Mass., is a sacred spot in the mythology of New England Protestants, once the Brahmins of American society, now fast becoming just another ethnic group. With this change comes new material for our venerable tradition of ethnic comedy. The territory is not altogether virgin, of course, but Sarah Payne Stuart comes to it with freshness and flair in this memoir.

headline: Abdullah Abdullah Moves Toward Center of Afghan Power
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — AFTER decades roaming the margins of power — as a close aide to the revered resistance leader Ahmed Shah Massoud, as a foreign minister and later as Afghanistan’s perennial opposition leader — Abdullah Abdullah may finally be arriving at the center of it all.

headline: Southern Living
text: Throughout Frances Mayes’s idylls about “the sweet life in Italy” — the subtitle of one of her best-selling memoirs — there are glimpses of a childhood, far less blissful, in the American South. In “Bella Tuscany,” she mentions her “tyrant” grandfather, Daddy Jack. In “Under the Tuscan Sun,” she touches on her “resigned disappointed ancestors” back home. Even as she enjoys a “pure surge of pleasure” while restoring Bramasole, a villa near Cortona, Italy, and discovering what it means to “surprise your own life,” she must keep the shadows cast by the town of Fitzgerald, Ga., at bay. “To put it mildly,” she remarks in passing of her father, Garbert, “he was a difficult man and to complicate that, he died at 47.”

headline: Nothing to Hide
text: Paula Bomer writes the kind of women’s fiction that critics like to call “raw.” Her stark portrayals of biological womanhood have been described as raw and angry, raw and darkly funny, brutally raw and urgent. The word is meant literally, to a degree: Her earlier books, “Nine Months” and “Baby,” feature birth scenes that spare no anatomical detail. But “raw” has also come to mean something specific in blurb-speak about quasi-confessional writing by women, and it’s not always fitting or fair. Half praise, half dis, it commends the struggle to embrace female ugliness while finding the work unsatisfactory. “Raw” work is visceral but also hard to digest — a kind term, in other words, for something half-baked.

headline: Late Bloomer
text: In 2012, at the age of 82, the indomitable stage and screen actor Christopher Plummer won his first Academy Award for his energetic portrayal of Hal Fields, a 75-year-old who comes out of the closet shortly after his wife’s death, in Mike Mills’s structurally complex romantic comedy “Beginners.” In the film, Hal’s full-throttled, last-call embrace of life inspires his son, Oliver, to fully embrace his own, while asking what exactly it takes to start life anew, and when, if ever, it’s too late.

headline: European Pastoral
text: Michel Déon’s 1975 novel “The Foundling Boy” (in French “Le Jeune Homme Vert,” or “The Green Young Man”) is a bildungsroman, an account of a naïve young person’s education and the formation of his character, in this case inspired by Henry Fielding’s 18th-century novel “Tom Jones,” about a similarly clueless but likable character making his way on the road of life. As witty as its English forebear but with French savoir-faire, “The Foundling Boy” may win new readers for books translated from French, of which too few are published. English PEN and Arts Council England have supported Julian Evans’s translation, evidently in hopes of broadening our reading of these classics.

headline: G.M. Recalls Camaros to Replace Faulty Keys
text: General Motors is recalling more than half a million Chevrolet Camaros because of the danger that a bump to the keys could suddenly turn off the ignition — a problem similar to the defect that led the automaker to recall millions of small cars this year.

headline: Here’s How
text: It is entirely possible, if you sit down on a comfy couch with a plump pillow, a good reading light and a crack pipe, that you can read a bunch of parenting books and not feel terrible.

headline: All in the Famiglia
text: In “Blood Brotherhoods,” the British scholar John Dickie sets himself the wildly ambitious task of writing the histories of Italy’s three major criminal organizations from their origins in the mid-19th century to the present. The result is a book that is alternately impressive and infuriating. Dickie has amassed and digested an astonishing mass of material (tens of thousands of pages of trial documents, newspaper accounts and secondary literature) and followed scores of different characters (bandits, crime bosses, policemen, judges, politicians) in disparate places across a 150-year span. And yet he has managed, despite the girth and diversity, to sustain an argument and a story. He entertains the reader with dozens of fascinating figures — both noble and blood-chilling — while making frequently shrewd judgments that place this story in context, as a central feature of Italian life.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BELIEVING IS SEEING: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography,  by Errol Morris. (Penguin, $25.) Morris brings his great talent as a filmmaker to this investigation of the contested reality behind an eclectic range of documentary photographs — from the Crimean War, the Depression, Abu Ghraib and elsewhere. Intercutting his essays with maps, letters, timelines and interview excerpts, Morris “refines our most basic way of understanding the world,” Kathryn Schulz wrote here.

headline: A Second Chance to Help Families Save Their Homes
text: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” was published in May by Yale University Press.

headline: Obama Says He Will Decide on Military Support for Iraq in ‘Days Ahead’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would make a decision “in the days ahead” about whether to use American military power to help the besieged Iraqi government stave off collapse at the hands of Islamist insurgents, but he ruled out using ground forces.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHAT IS VISIBLE,  by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $25.) While contemplating the bare requisites of being human, this historical novel about the Helen Keller-like Laura Bridgman also dishes dirt on a pantheon of 19th-century heroes of civil reform.

headline: Heavy Lifting From the Vaults: Lots of Allmans and Elvis on the Way
text: Classic albums by the Allman Brothers Band and Elvis Presley are to be given expanded reissues that, depending on your level of fascination with these musicians, are either textbook examples of bloated archival sprawl or something like perfection.

headline: A Reagan or a Blair?
text: I wrote a little on Wednesday about what I described as the uncertain implications of David Brat’s primary victory for the future of a more reform-minded conservatism. For a less uncertain take on the matter, here is David Frum, arguing that the only way to reform the Republican Party is for figures like Eric Cantor – or, I suppose, his successors in the leadership — to take the fight more ruthlessly to the party’s insurgents:

headline: Thad Cochran’s Unlikely Donor Lineup
text: The adage that politics makes for strange bedfellows may have few better examples than the Senate race in Mississippi, where Senator Thad Cochran faces Chris McDaniel, a state senator, in a June 24 runoff.

headline: A Trip That Will Assist the Rhino
text: Extraordinary Journeys, the New York City-based safari outfitter, recently announced a new 10-day safari to Botswana and Zambia that is intended to benefit the Great Plains Foundation’s Zeros for Rhinos initiative.

headline: Portraits From Kiev
text: Photos of the protesters and the mourners at Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, in February.

headline: Strike a Pose
text: The actress imitates the poses from fashion catalogs and magazines for Leanne Shapton’s forthcoming book, “Women In Clothes.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
text: This week, Nikil Saval talks about “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Lenore Skenazy discusses two new books about parenting; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Five Things to Do This Weekend
text: There are a lot of cultural options out there. Too many to choose from? Perhaps. So below we’ve winnowed them all down to a few, for brows of all kinds.

headline: Document | Act Natural
text: Soon after the Canadian-born artist Leanne Shapton ordered a nightgown from the Vermont Country Store last year, she began to receive mail-order catalogs from National (their tagline: “Living the comfortable life since 1952″) and Woman Within. Struck by the models’ demure stances, she cut out certain images, before turning to her own fashion magazines and other periodicals. Last September, she asked Zosia Mamet to imitate the poses she had collected; the photographer Gus Powell shot. “Posturing” — inspired by the grids of the German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann, illustrated workouts and 1970s yoga manuals (hence the unitard) — is one of the many projects in “Women in Clothes,” out this fall. Edited by Sheila Heti, Heidi Julavits and Shapton, the book explores the issues women face when they get dressed. According to Shapton, the photo series evokes the energetic, experimental spirit of the publication, which features over 600 contributors. “We wanted the reader to do exercises,” Shapton said. “Exercises for the critical eye.”

headline: Kevin McCarthy Won’t Enjoy Being Majority Leader
text: Kevin McCarthy of California, the House Republican Whip, is running hard to win Eric Cantor’s post as Majority Leader, and claims he has the votes locked up. But except for the big office — and the security detail, and the power and the glory — it’s hard to know why he really wants the job.

headline: Winning a Real Estate Bidding War
text: The low supply of homes for sale in many markets means buyers must be prepared for bidding wars. Buyers should be strategic in how they present their offers, and avoid paying too high a premium for their “perfect” property.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
text: This week, Nikil Saval and Lenore Skenazy.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: After a severe winter that sent the economy into negative territory at the start of the year, have things turned around? Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar review their predictions on economic growth for the year ahead. Are the stock market’s recent record highs trickling down to everyone? Plus, whatever happened to Bitcoin?

headline: Back From the Brink, Minnesota Orchestra Announces New Season
text: For anyone still waiting for assurances that the Minnesota Orchestra is settling back into its routine after a 16-month lockout and subsequent administrative drama, the orchestra has announced its 2014-15 season. And if that alone is not a clear enough sign, the orchestra and Osmo Vanska, its highly regarded music director – newly restored to his post after resigning during the dispute – plan to open its subscription season on Sept. 26 with Mahler’s “Resurrection” Symphony. (An opening gala with Renée Fleming, and a pair of performances outside the orchestra’s hall precede the Mahler, but surely Mr. Vanska and company want the symbolism to be clear.)

headline: Movie Review: ‘22 Jump Street’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “22 Jump Street.”

headline: On Our Walls
text: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Son of David Rockefeller Dies in Small-Plane Crash
text: Dr. Richard Rockefeller, son of the billionaire and prominent philanthropist David Rockefeller, was killed Friday morning when the small plane he was piloting crashed shortly after takeoff, according to a spokesman for the family.

headline: Driven | 2015 Audi A3 2.0T quattro
text: Don’t confuse small with inexpensive.

headline: Israeli Teenagers Said to Be Kidnapped in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli teenagers were missing in the West Bank and were presumed to have been kidnapped, Israeli military officials said on Friday. The episode tested Israel’s already strained ties with the Palestinians and prompted the involvement of the State Department amid reports that one of the youngsters held United States citizenship.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Nikil Saval’s ‘Cubed’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Richard Sennett reviews Nikil Saval’s “Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace.” Mr. Sennett writes:

headline: Video: The Audi A3 Is a Small Car With a Big Price
text: There are a few key things to know about the new Audi A3 compact car, which for 2015 is being offered in the United States for the first time as a sedan, not a hatchback.

headline: A ‘Money Pit’ No More
text: The Long Island mansion used for “The Money Pit,” the 1986 comedy starring Tom Hanks and Shelley Long about the ultimate fixer-upper fiasco, is poised to go on the market for $12.5 million. The annual property taxes on the home are $65,992.

headline: Bookshelf: Baby Talk
text: New picture books include Sara Gillingham’s “Snuggle the Baby” and Lori Nichols’s “Maple.”

headline: John Kerry on Obama’s Iraq Thinking
text: At the Global Summit to End Sexual Violence in Conflict, Secretary of State John Kerry spoke about the “timely decisions” on the violence in Iraq that he expects from President Obama.

headline: Image of the Day: June 13
text: People at the Gateway of India in Mumbai, Maharashtra, during a high tide.

headline: Tactician Will Try to Take a Title From a Brawler
text: Backgrounds often help shape boxing styles, and contrasting styles are said to make fights.

headline: Fathers' Rights and Women's Equality
text: Is the father's rights movement a legitimate claim for equality, or a backlash against feminism?

headline: Assessing the Benefits of Becoming a Benefit Corporation
text: When business owners incorporate, they typically do so for one of two reasons: Their accountant told them it’s a good idea, or they want to be taxed in a particular manner. Now there’s a third reason to consider.

headline: Can Uber Live Up to Its $40 Billion Valuation?
text: Dec. 4, 2014: Uber, the mobile-phone-based car service, is getting bigger. The company said today that it had raised another $1.2 billion in funding in a round that values the firm at a remarkable $40 billion (thus post-funding the firm is worth $41.2 billion). At 5 years old, the company now has a valuation on par with that of giants like Time Warner Cable and Prudential Insurance.

headline: The End of Cuisine
text: Nathan Myhrvold, the Mad Hatter of modernist cooking, invited the movement’s leading chef, Ferran Adrià, over for a 50-course, lab-prepared meal. It was a lot to digest, sure, but what does a feast like this mean for the future of eating?

headline: F.C.C. Begins Investigation Into Quality of Internet Download Speeds
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission has opened an investigation into recent deals where entertainment companies like Netflix have agreed to pay Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon for faster video delivery, a practice that critics contend will divide Internet service into fast and slow lanes.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Dragon 2’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “How to Train Your Dragon 2.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: fish during pregnancy, tools to combat blindness and sex after 60. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: An Intense Chef, and His Commandments
text: The first thing you should know about Tomonori Tanaka, the owner, chef and one-man band calling the tunes at Tomo’s Cuisine in East Hanover, is that he’s not as stern as he looks.

headline: The Rebirth of the Wedding
text: A few years ago, it seemed like America might reject the wedding. Feminist criticisms of various wedding traditions gained steam; a New Yorker writer released a book on the ceremonies’ ballooning costs; the recession made couples scale back. The phrase “wedding-industrial complex” entered common parlance.

headline: John Seymour: Home for Tuck-In Time
text: When the restaurateur John Seymour moved 12 years ago from Manhattan to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he was drawn by the raw lofts with low rents. “The first place I lived was on Kent Avenue, with a revolving door of roommates and 20-foot ceilings,” he said. “We could throw a football inside.”

headline: The Halal Guys: Cashing In on Street Cred
text: Some empires are managed from a distance: in corner offices, from cellphones on beaches, under palm fronds while being fanned by servants.

headline: The Times Critics’ Guide to the ‘Friday the 13th’ Movies
text: There’s only one actual Friday the 13th in 2014 — good news for paraskevidekatriaphobics. But if you wanted to complete a marathon viewing of all eleven movies in the “Friday the 13th” franchise on the actual date, you’ve probably missed your chance for this year. (If you want to go ahead anyway, note that most of the films are available for digital rental.)

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season Finale: 6 Questions That Need Answers
text: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Kerry Joins Envoys to Deplore Sexual Violence in War
text: LONDON — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that sexual violence in conflict zones should be banished “to the dark ages and the history books,” as he joined dozens of ministers and the actress Angelina Jolie to promote efforts to bring perpetrators of such crimes to justice.

headline: Stayin’ Alive
text: Meryl Meisler couldn’t believe the sight that greeted her when she emerged from the subway in Bushwick, Brooklyn, for the first time, in 1981. “It looked like the photographs that I had seen of Beirut,” she recalled of the cityscape of bombed-out buildings.

headline: It Never Happened, but It’s Still True
text: At the conclusion of a 2011 New Yorker article on the Church of Scientology, the writer-director Paul Haggis made a prediction regarding his very public break with that institution.

headline: King’s College in New York to Accept Bitcoin
text: Bitcoin can already be used to purchase a plane ticket, donate to a political campaign and pay a satellite TV bill. Beginning this fall, it can also be used to pay for a college education.

headline: Enter the World Cup
text: The world will now pause for a month. It’s the World Cup. Coups and annexations, meltdowns and earthquakes will have to take a back seat to the beautiful game. No other global obsession even comes close. I have been at the last two in South Africa and Germany and came away with glorious memories. Love of the game usually wins out in the end whatever the pretournament grumbling and ugly moments (like Zinedine Zidane’s head butt in the 2006 final).

headline: Whom to Watch in the G.O.P. Shuffle
text: As Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, exits the scene, several candidates are vying for leadership positions, which may force a change in Republican party politics.

headline: Art Matters | A Biennial in, and About, Los Angeles
text: In his infamous Artforum review of the first “Made in L.A.” biennial in 2012, the critic and curator Michael Ned Holte used some choice language: the survey of nascent L.A. artists at the Hammer Museum had a “boosterish tone,” he wrote. He even name-checked every Angeleno’s favorite “Saturday Night Live” sketch, “The Californians,” with its memorable recurring finale in which all the characters crowd in front of a single mirror.

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Iraq
text: President Obama announced that he would not be sending United States troops back into combat in Iraq, but said he had asked his national security team to prepare a range of options.

headline: Hillary Clinton Talks Same-Sex Marriage on ‘Fresh Air’
text: Hillary Clinton has been getting some heat in the media for being evasive about her views on gay marriage during an interview with Terry Gross, host of NPR’s Fresh Air program, and for snapping at Ms. Gross when she pressed her on the subject.

headline: A Train to Nowhere in a New Ice Age
text: In the sci-fi thriller “Snowpiercer,” class warfare goes express.

headline: Reassessing Reversal of Adversary to S.E.C.
text: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan sent shock waves through the legal and financial establishments in November 2011 when he rejected a proposed $285 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup. Judge Rakoff said it was impossible for him to say whether it was “fair and reasonable,” let alone in the public interest, after the bank “neither admitted nor denied” the S.E.C.’s accusations nor otherwise revealed any of the facts in a complex mortgage fraud case.

headline: Evidence Is Still Thin That Democratic Voters Ousted Eric Cantor
text: The theory that Democrats cost Eric Cantor his re-election continues to fester. It’s not impossible; it’s just highly unlikely. Mr. Cantor lost by 11 points, which is a significant margin in what was a congressional primary with fairly high turnout. I’ve not seen any evidence that there was a surge of 15,000 Democratic votes.

headline: Skillet Chicken With Rhubarb
text: Rhubarb is just as good in savory dishes as it is in dessert. Here, Melissa Clark uses it in a bright, fresh and seasonal dish with chicken and green garlic.

headline: Drinks and Food, in That Order
text: A place that bills itself as a cantina, as this nearly year-old spot does, calls to mind a few assumptions. First, that a good time will be had there. Second, that drinking — of the lively, boisterous variety — will factor heavily into that good time. And third, that food can be enjoyed there, even if it is not quite the main point.

headline: Rhubarb Flaunts Its Savory Side
text: Are you ready for the rhubarb revolution?

headline: This Weekend: The Northside Festival
text: The sixth annual Northside Festival in Brooklyn kicks off Thursday and will run through the weekend. There will be hundreds of bands showcasing their latest music. Here are three to check out.

headline: Early Gershwin Musical to Open City Center’s Encores Season
text: The Gershwin brothers’ first full musical, “Lady, Be Good” – which yielded, apart from the title song, “Fascinating Rhythm” and “So Am I” (and from which “The Man I Love” was unaccountably dropped during an out-of-town run) – will open City Center’s Encores! season on Feb. 4. The musical, which has a book by Guy Bolton and Fred Thompson as well as Ira Gershwin’s lyrics and George Gershwin’s music, ran for 330 performances on Broadway in 1924 and 1925.

headline: Love, Fear and Anxiety in Suite 719
text: For most of his career, Neil Simon explored family relationships in plays that were either comedies or bittersweet dramas tinged with humor. Even his funniest work, though, was often built on pain. Where would “The Odd Couple” be without the marital difficulties that brought Oscar and Felix together as mismatched roommates?

headline: Iraq May Turn to Iran for Help, Maliki Aide Says
text: BAGHDAD — A senior Iraqi official on Friday warned that his country might be forced to turn to Iran for military help if none were forthcoming from the United States, but he insisted he was unaware of any Iranian military units in his country so far.

headline: The Snakes May Not Bite, but the Humidity Devours
text: MANAUS, Brazil — It is the one place all 32 teams probably wanted to avoid in the World Cup, this Amazon city where the heat and humidity feel like a dryer full of damp clothes.

headline: Spain vs. Netherlands: Live Blog
text: Welcome to our live coverage of Friday’s Group B clash between Spain and the Netherlands, a rematch of the 2010 World Cup final.

headline: High Cost to Focusing on Student Loans Over Saving
text: This week, President Obama ordered changes to the federal student loan program that could help millions of borrowers make their payments more affordable starting in December 2015.

headline: Malfunction Seen in Jet Crash That Killed Co-owner of Philadelphia Inquirer
text: The wreckage of an executive jet that crashed on takeoff at an airport north of Boston on May 31 shows signs of a mechanical malfunction, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Friday in a preliminary report.

headline: A First Great Love Plots the Course for the Second
text: The night before she died, Diane Gamble helped plan her husband’s life without her.

headline: Training at the Top of the World
text: To train for the largest descent of his life, Jeremy Jones partnered with the legendary climber Conrad Anker for an ascent of Denali.

headline: Unraveling in Iraq, and Beyond
China to Prosecute Pu Zhiqiang for Activism
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities on Friday announced the formal arrest of a well-known rights defender who last month took part in a private seminar where participants discussed the army’s violent suppression of the student-led protests of 1989 in Tiananmen Square.

headline: Iraq’s Uncertain Future
text: As President Obama weighs whether to help defend the Iraqi government against insurgents, analysts around the world are offering their prescriptions (and their sometimes-dire predictions) for a country in the throes of worsening conflict.

headline: Talking Talent | Jenny Mollen’s New Book of Laughs
text: Honest and often painfully embarrassing, Jenny Mollen’s debut book, “I Like You Just The Way I Am: Stories About Me and Some Other People” (St. Martin’s Press), hits bookstores on Tuesday and is poised to be one of the season’s funniest reads. The 35-year-old wife of the actor Jason Biggs and mother to their newborn son, Sid, spent over a decade appearing in barely-there parts on film and television, but found her true calling when she decided to put pen to paper to chronicle her every phobia, sexual encounter and misadventure while stalking her future husband’s exes. With over 125,000 Twitter followers who hang on her acerbic pearls of wisdom — “It’s 10:40, He’s not calling to make plans!” — Mollen, who looks more like a Maxim pinup than a raunchy comedienne, is amassing a devoted legion of fans, one selfie at a time.

headline: 30-Year-Old Decision Could Serve as Template for N.C.A.A. Antitrust Case
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — William Isaacson has only a few items in his trial binder at federal court here every day. There are both sides’ pretrial briefs filed in the antitrust suit brought against the N.C.A.A. by his client, the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed O’Bannon. There are the major decisions by the presiding judge, Claudia Wilken. And there is the full text of a 30-year-old Supreme Court case.

headline: A Better Ranch Dressing
text: Ranch dressing for dipping makes almost any vegetable more appealing to children, but commercially prepared ranch dressings have nutritional drawbacks. So here’s a salad dressing base made with yogurt and white beans that can be the foundation of a healthful ranch dressing as well as a few variants.

headline: A Little Assistance on the Path to ‘I Do’
text: It takes a village, the saying goes, to raise a child. And in today’s world, it may take an army of consultants, and the cash to pay for them, to bring two lonely souls from bar stools through bended knee and into a glittering wedding celebration. Here is just a partial rundown of the consultants, or concierges, if you will, that the lovelorn may encounter on their road to wedded bliss, and beyond.

headline: Big Ticket | At $70 Million, a Manhattan Co-op Sales Record
text: A palatial Fifth Avenue penthouse embraced to the west and south by a wraparound terrace with 100 feet of panoramic Central Park frontage sold for $70 million and, along with breaking a sales record for Manhattan co-ops, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Iraq Reportedly Blocks Social Networks
text: As officials in Baghdad searched for ways to blunt the momentum of Islamist militants who have seized large stretches of Iraq in recent days, the government blocked access to social media sites including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, bloggers and journalists inside the country reported on Friday.

headline: New York City vs. Street Peddlers, a Brief History
text: A selection of articles from The New York Times’s archives chronicling the battle.

headline: The Beautiful Data Set
text: THE World Cup is finally underway. At long last, soccer fans can don their team colors, head down to the local pub — and begin collecting data to test economic theories.

headline: Weekend Autos Calendar: Henry Ford Museum’s Motor Muster Celebrates the Mustang
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Cara Delevingne’s Acting Debut, Karlie Kloss’s Designs and Jeff Koons’s Storefront Show
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: In China, Negotiating Peaks and Police
text: The black sport-utility vehicle stopped about 300 feet behind us at a bend in the road. Its occupants were hidden behind its tinted windows. Inside, we assumed, were police officers assigned to follow our group of five foreign men and a local driver up the narrow mountain road. A metal bar across the road had brought us to a halt. It was a police checkpoint, and a man posted at a booth said no outsiders were allowed farther.

headline: Finding Mexico City, and Luis Barragán, Again
text: Memory, in its random way, erased the reasons I stopped going to Mexico City.

headline: The Sister of Second Chances
text: Venita Pinckney grew up around Catholic schools and churches, and she thought she knew about nuns. Then a small, gray-haired sister named Teresa Fitzgerald came to fish her out of a Harlem crack house. Ms. Pinckney had been a drug addict for 23 years, a dealer and a prostitute, and had lost both of her children to foster care. She was high at the time.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Giants’ Beason Sustains Foot Injury
text: Jon Beason, the Giants’ middle linebacker and one of their defensive leaders, sustained a foot injury that may jeopardize his availability for the season opener against the Lions in Detroit on Sept. 8.

headline: Priceline Will Need to Expand OpenTable Overseas to Justify the Splurge
text: The Priceline Group picked an expensive option in its search for expansion.

headline: Giving a Semi-Hearty Cheer for Semi-Staged Opera
text: When the vengeful husband enters his wife’s bedroom to kill her in the final act of Verdi’s “Otello,” he is accompanied by the muted snarl of a sepulchral E natural in the double basses. For several measures, the violins have been sustaining a heaven-high A flat, and the low tone suddenly replaces it, as if a candle had been snuffed out.

headline: Selling Baubles on the Street: License Required
text: On March 14, Chun Yin took the subway from her apartment in East Harlem to get a good spot on Canal Street to sell jade bracelets, pearl earrings and carved figurines on red silky thread she braids by hand.

headline: Weekend Reading: London Bankers May Be Slow to Return Your Calls
text: Who has time to advise a deal or underwrite an initial public offering when important events are taking place in one of the BRIC countries?

headline: Taking a Spin: Republicans Have It Their Way
text: Just about everything broke right for Republicans today in my spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of how much uncertainty remains in this year’s elections.

headline: Avoiding Another Iraq Quagmire
text: Given that he built a political career on opposition to the Iraq war, it was a relief but no surprise when President Obama on Friday ruled out sending American ground troops back into the country.

headline: At Bonnie Slotnick Cookbooks, Recipes to Feed Your Mind and Body
text: There’s always a slight sense of dread as you approach West 10th Street, just off Seventh Avenue, that you might find Bonnie Slotnick’s vintage cookbook shop closed that day. But if the chipped wooden “Open” sign (she painted it herself) peeks out from the brownstone’s stoop, you’re in luck. Shove open the rickety door and a string of bells will herald your arrival.

headline: Mick Jones: A Quiet Day, for a Juke Box Hero
text: It is an amusement of New York life that rock stars live among us, picking up dry cleaning or going to the dentist just like everybody else. And it is a quirk of contemporary rock stardom that its constituents now come in all vintages, with hairstyles and heydays stretching back for decades. So it is that Mick Jones, 69, original lead guitarist of the band Foreigner, has been living near Central Park since the ’70s, long enough that he can say, in the accent of Somerset, England, “I’m really a native New Yorker.” These days he is sometimes eclipsed by his stepchildren and children, who include: the D.J., singer and producer Mark Ronson, 38; the fashion designer Charlotte Ronson, 36; the singer and D.J. Samantha Ronson, 36; and the actress Annabelle Dexter-Jones, 27. Foreigner will perform with Styx and Don Felder at Jones Beach on Long Island on June 28.

headline: The Mediterranean Seafood Salad of Your Dreams
text: Summer appetites are different, and so is summer cooking. In the morning one craves fresh fruit and little more, but by midday a voracious hunger is upon us. We want garlic and lemon and olive oil, and olives, and tomatoes with salt. Maybe a little pizza to tide us over until lunch.

headline: A Ride Across America | Greenmarkets and Off-the-Grid Living in the Heart of Kentucky Coal Country
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Senegal to the Caribbean, With a Stop at the Church of Funk and Soul
text: Dexter Johnson

headline: Have You Shopped for a ’70 Ford Lately?
text: EL MIRAGE, ARIZ. — To step into Kevin Marti’s garage here is to travel back in time, to reset the dial on the WABAC Machine for 1970 and the destination for the Ford dealership in Anytown, America.

headline: A Full-Service Time Machine
text: Kevin Marti’s garage and museum in El Mirage, Ariz., is a reproduction of a circa-1970 Ford dealership.

headline: 24-Hour Race Could Lure Huge Crowd at Le Mans
text: LE MANS, France — Authorities here are expecting a potential record crowd — possibly approaching 300,000 people — for the start Saturday of the 82nd running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race.

headline: Mayor of Venice Resigns Amid Corruption Scandal
text: ROME — Venice’s mayor, Giorgio Orsoni, resigned on Friday amid a mounting corruption scandal connected with the construction of a colossal flood-barrier system designed to save the lagoon city from flooding.

headline: Finding Cracks in a Perfect Life
text: Wendy Wasserstein is best remembered for writing thoughtful, witty plays about smart women of her baby boom generation.

headline: Tradition Will Play On at Clearwater Festival
text: The Clearwater Festival, which has grown from a counterculture-era folk picnic into a sprawling event featuring nearly 100 acts on seven stages, remains at heart a modest affair, free of corporate logos and nurtured by a handful of artist-activists who shared a smaller-is-better ethos with the festival’s founder, Pete Seeger.

headline: On the Market in Hilton Head, S.C.
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: At E3, Virtual Reality Goggles Don’t  Fit Into Reality
text: It’s tough to stand out at E3, the annual gaming conference. People wander around dressed as orks, gangsters, prehistoric humans, and no one really bats an eye. As one person put it to me, “E3 is nerdier than the cantina scene in Star Wars.”

headline: Futebol para Cegos no Brasil
text: Os deficientes visuais brasileiros desafiam o destino ao jogarem o esporte favorito do seu país, o futebol.

headline: Where the Z/28 Legacy Began
text: Carmakers often resurrect popular model names, but only rarely do they reinstate the character that made the original so memorable. It does happen — the 2014 Corvette Stingray seems to have it — and early reports say that Chevrolet’s Camaro Z/28 revival is faithful to its take-no-prisoners ancestor.

headline: Inside the Frog, a Prince Awaits
text: If a building contractor arrived on time, performed heroically and charged a fair price — this is a New York fantasy, stay with me — would you complain that he wasn’t good-looking? Would you refuse to hire him if he didn’t come with a fashionable tool belt?

headline: A Legend Revived, Its Spirit Intact
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y. — For the Chevrolet Camaro, burning rubber in a straight line has rarely been a problem. Turning and stopping? Not always a top priority.

headline: Taliban Run Into Trouble on Battlefield, but Money Flows Just the Same
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite years of efforts by Western officials to cut off the Taliban’s financial lifelines, the militants are as rich as ever, bringing in so much cash from opium trafficking, illegal mining, extortion rackets and other ventures that the money itself appears to be a reason for many insurgents to keep fighting, Afghan and Western officials say.

headline: World Cup 2014: Switzerland Stuns Ecuador, 2-1, in Added Time
text: Haris Seferovic’s goal with 20 seconds left in added time capped a wild finish and gave Switzerland a stunning 2-1 victory over Ecuador in a first-round match.

headline: A Vieques Hotel With Contemporary Design–and Cuisine
text: The small island of Vieques, just off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico, will soon harbor one of the most architecturally significant hotels in the Caribbean.

headline: World Cup 2014: France Easily Beats Honduras, 3-0
text: France rolled past Honduras in its opening match, helped by a red card to Honduran midfielder Wilson Palacios and two goals from forward Karim Benzema.

headline: 2015 Camaro Z/28
text: A look at the latest Camaro Z/28.

headline: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department confirmed on Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine.

headline: World Cup 2014: Italy Defeats England, 2-1
text: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus to win the first match in the Amazon rainforest.

headline: In Baghdad, Where ‘Hello’ Means Goodbye, Hellos Abound at Travel Agencies
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqis say “hello” when they mean goodbye. This can get a little confusing to visitors who do not speak the local dialect of Arabic and think they are hearing English, instead of a borrowed word that has been inverted in meaning.

headline: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Greece, 3-0
text: Colombia more than made up for the absence of Radamel Falcao, its star striker, in its victory against Greece on Saturday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica Defeats Uruguay, 3-1
text: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scored three goals in the second half to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.

headline: The 2015 Honda Fit: More Than Skin Deep
text: Honda’s well-mannered hatchback gets an update, proving that beauty is as beauty does.

headline: Settlement Talks Stall for Citigroup and Justice Department
text: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | Talks between the Justice Department and Citigroup to settle a civil investigation into its sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated in recent days, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.

headline: World Cup 2014: Ivory Coast Defeats Japan, 2-1
text: The Ivory Coast recovered from an early setback, scoring two second-half goals in the space of 100 seconds Saturday night to earn a 2-1 win over Japan in Group C.

headline: Revealing Art, Bursting at the Seams of Control
text: The soprano Ariadne Greif stepped out of her gown and ripped off the strips of silver duct tape that crisscrossed her torso like a girdle until she stood naked at the front of the stage, flushed and defiant. “Under my skin gruesome fire smolders,” she sang in a German translation of verses by Sappho. “A high roaring buzzes in my ears, and from every pore seep pearls of sweat.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Bosnia-Herzegovina, 2-1
text: Lionel Messi scored a goal to the delight of his fans, and Argentina received the gift of an own goal in scoring a 2-1 victory over Bosnia-Herzegovina.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Portugal, 4-0
text: Thomas Müller scored three goals to power Germany to a commanding 4-0 victory and solidified his country’s place at the top of the list of teams that will challenge for the title.

headline: Electricity Reporting for Duty
text: TESTED 2014 Zero SR

headline: Bumpy Road to Bright New Days
text: “Time has left us older/but wiser, I know I am.” “Come in From the Rain,” the welcoming hymn to a solid longtime friendship from which those lyrics come, was written in the 1970s by Melissa Manchester and Carole Bayer Sager. Although Ms. Manchester’s original recording was not a big hit, the song nevertheless became a nightclub staple until it slowly faded out of fashion.

headline: Are You a ‘Fun Dad’?
text: This week, President Obama described himself as a “fun dad” who “teeters on the edge of being embarrassing sometimes.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Iran and Nigeria Play to 0-0 Draw
text: Iran and Nigeria tied, 0-0, in a match that was low on goalscoring opportunities and became the first draw of the 2014 World Cup.

headline: London’s Legacy in the Slave Trade
text: It was a bright Saturday morning, and the City of London, the financial district of the British capital, was empty. I was wandering its narrow side lanes seeking a sculpture. I kept getting lost, and found myself going forward and then backtracking. Finally, in a courtyard between office buildings I came upon it: “The Gilt of Cain,” by Michael Visocchi and Lemn Sissay.

headline: U.S.O.C. Narrows Bids to Four Cities
text: The United States Olympic Committee announced Friday that it had narrowed its list of potential American cities to host the 2024 Summer Games to four finalists — Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington.

headline: The Z/28 Generations
text: The Camaro Z/28 through the years.

headline: A Balanced Flavor for the Modern Father
text: Fatherhood used to be so simple. Wake up, grab your briefcase, kiss your wife and kids goodbye, work all day and come home to find a clean house, kids tucked into bed and a cocktail awaiting your arrival.

headline: Under an Unblinking Gaze, a Farewell to Privacy
text: Who’s watching whom and to what purpose? “Surveillance” — a new 60-minute piece by ZviDance at New York Live Arts this week — is a shrewd collage, both appealing and disconcerting, of the Orwellian Big Brother society, aspects of sexuality and dancing to rock music. It’s the urban world we know, deconstructed and reassembled. In a society in which people need to film or photograph everything, what intimacy is left? Zvi Gotheiner’s choreography suggests that he is as much sociologist as dance-maker.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Mexico.

headline: The Duet Between the Right Brain and the Left
text: In 2003, when the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, it sounded like a whim. Yet, over time, the troupe earned respect by filling a hole in the market, commissioning work by rising European choreographers gaining buzz abroad but little seen here. This is a valuable service, even if the effect so far has been to make New York dance audiences feel that they haven’t been missing much.

headline: The Barrister Has 2 Faces
text: In one area, at least, America has a severe trade imbalance with the British. They keep sending us their brainy, urbane leading men — Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Kenneth Branagh, Daniel Day-Lewis — and receive very little in return.

headline: The World Wide Bridge Contest Results
text: The World Wide Bridge Contests were held in clubs around the world on June 6 and 7. They were organized by Ecats Bridge, which is run by Anna Gudge and Mark Newton (ecatsbridge.com).

headline: Stephane Cremieux of the French Brand Cremieux Shares Father’s Day Gift Ideas Any Dad Will Love (Including His)
text: Last month, the venerable French brand Cremieux, a purveyor of preppy tailored sportswear since 1976, opened its first American store in SoHo. These days, Cremieux is a family business, jointly operated by its founder, Daniel Cremieux, and his son, Stephane. Here, Stephane offers his list of 10 great Father’s Day treats (many of which can be picked up at locations around New York City for you last-minute shoppers) that his dad and any other would appreciate.

headline: Under Cover: Photographing Frontline Operations in Africa
text: The June 15 cover story about confronting terrorism in Africa is accompanied by photographs from Michael Christopher Brown. For the past several years, Brown has primarily covered North and Central Africa, particularly Libya and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Here, he discusses his recent assignment for the magazine.

headline: Chile vs. Australia: Live Blog
text: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams’ opening Group B match.

headline: Publishing a Novel to Preserve a Legacy
text: Elise Jordan curled her petite frame into the sofa in her sunny apartment in TriBeCa and kept her voice steady as she explained why she pushed to publish the unfinished novel of her husband, Michael Hastings, on the first anniversary of his death.

headline: Judge to Consider Retrial or Dismissal in Malcolm Smith Case
text: WHITE PLAINS — As prosecutors hurriedly assembled a team of translators to transcribe 28 hours of Yiddish conversation, a federal judge said on Friday that he would entertain written arguments to help him determine whether the untranslated material might warrant a mistrial or a dismissal of the bribery indictments against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants.

headline: Scoring Onslaught Does In Defending Champions
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — Sitting on the bench, worrying that history might be repeated at his team’s expense, Dirk Kuyt, the Dutch reserve forward, had a perfect view of a goal that energized a nation and a tournament with its daring and flair.

headline: High-End Hermès Handbags at Center of Suit Against Christie’s
text: Locked behind glass, illuminated like a jewel, lies an Hermès Birkin — totem of wealth, bestower of status, and one seriously expensive handbag.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Tunes From the Great Shakespearean Songbook
text: In the olden days (2011 or so), if you wanted to see and hear Karen Akers doing the exquisite songs of masters like Cole Porter and Stephen Sondheim, you had to make reservations at one of Manhattan’s chic cabarets. But here she is in all her splendor, onstage at the Westport Country Playhouse, in “Sing for Your Shakespeare,” both standing out from and blending in with an ensemble cast.

headline: The Honoree Wanted to Play, Too
text: The evening’s honoree on Thursday at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn was Ornette Coleman, and the first to pay respects was Sonny Rollins, wearing a stylish black raincoat.

headline: Nostalgia’s Blurring Glow
text: In “Mythologies,” Roland Barthes’s classic collection of essays on the roots and consequences of interpretation, the theorist examines the ways in which consensus understanding evolves around cultural phenomena, typically — or, perhaps almost always — at the expense of layered or contested meaning.

headline: After Four Decades, a School Program Still Shows Youth and Energy
text: As Eliot Feld has said, ballet is not for a class of people, but for everyone with talent. Discovering dancers through auditions at New York City public schools is his mission. On Thursday night, that talent was on display at the Joyce Theater when Mr. Feld’s Kids Dance revealed exactly what a student showcase should be: fresh and unpretentious, with just enough rigor to make it easy on the eye.

headline: Obama Finds He Can’t Put Iraq War Behind Him
text: WASHINGTON — In a high-profile speech to Army cadets last month, President Obama tried to move beyond America’s tumultuous adventures in Iraq and Afghanistan with a new doctrine all but forswearing the use of military power except in the most dire of circumstances.

headline: Reactions to the Turmoil in Iraq From Those Who Served
text: Many of the American servicemen and women who served in Iraq had strong reactions this week when Sunni extremist militants seized broad stretches of the country. The New York Times asked some of the contributors to At War to share their feelings about events there.

headline: Alitalia’s Board Agrees to Cash Infusion From Etihad of Abu Dhabi
text: Facing the prospect of bankruptcy for the second time in five years, the board of Italy’s troubled flagship airline, Alitalia, agreed on Friday to a strategic partnership that would give a stake of up to 49 percent to the state-owned Abu Dhabi carrier Etihad Airways.

headline: Eastern Tent Caterpillar: Warm, Fuzzy and Icky
text: The eastern tent caterpillar (Malacosoma americanum) ranks high on the “ick” scale for many New Yorkers. Vilified by gardeners, and frequently mistaken for other more destructive caterpillars like those of the nonnative gypsy moth, it is unfairly cast as a woodlands plague. Children seem to instinctively want to squish them. But beauty can sometimes be found in unlikely places. A close examination of the eastern tent caterpillar reveals a handsome native, well adapted to life in the northeast.

headline: Kevin McCarthy’s New Challenge
text: Kevin McCarthy, the House majority whip, faces a new challenge in the wake of Eric Cantor’s primary defeat.

headline: Natasha Lyonne Is the Character Who Came for Dinner
text: Natasha Lyonne had come from taping NBC’s “Late Night With Seth Meyers” on Wednesday, and was waiting for the cable guy in her lofty SoHo apartment.

headline: With Pop-Up Salons, Art Is Demystified
text: On a Saturday afternoon in Chelsea, a group of a few dozen people milled around the International Print Center New York, drinking Champagne and making small talk about the show New Prints 2014/Winter. But this wasn’t a gallery opening, nor was it an artist’s talk. Rather it was a salon by Gertrude, a new company organizing events to discuss art.

headline: At the Tone, Leave a What?
text: In a memorable scene from the 1996 comedy “Swingers,” Jon Favreau’s romantically inept protagonist, Mike, deluges the answering machine of a woman he’s just met at a bar with a spate of excruciatingly self-sabotaging messages.

headline: Ayahuasca: A Strong Cup of Tea
text: On a recent Friday night, a dozen seekers in loosefitting attire, most in their 20s and 30s, climbed a flight of steps of a mixed-used community space in Bushwick, Brooklyn. After arranging yoga mats and blankets on the floor, they each paid $150, listened to a Colombian shaman and his assistant welcome them in Spanish and English, signed a disclaimer, and accepted large plastic takeout-style containers for vomiting.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 13
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the Puerto Rican Day Parade, fire breathers, and a soccer game that helps unite a community.

headline: Defense Reports Puncture Led to Botched Execution
text: Oklahoma executioners failed to place an injection line properly in a vein in the groin of Clayton D. Lockett, according to an independent autopsy commissioned by Mr. Lockett’s defense lawyers after his bungled execution drew wide attention to the problems of lethal injection.

headline: George Takei Is Still Guiding the Ship
text: George Takei sat in a V.I.P. room at the Waldorf-Astoria as a young makeup artist named Eryk Datura dabbed foundation on his brow.

headline: Orchestrated Conflict
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — IN the lush green fields here in Ukraine’s troubled east, I attended a funeral and a wedding over two days earlier this month. They presented vivid tableaux of contrasting emotions — one of fury, the other of fatalism — but each contained clues to the direction of things in this country on the edge of Europe whose eastern flank has risen up in open rebellion against the central government.

headline: Proving Their Chops in the ‘Real World’
text: If you’ve ever taken a chance on a haircut at a beauty academy or let high school football players wash your car, you might be a candidate for eating at the hands of culinary students. At the newly refurbished Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, and at the year-old Dining Lab at Monroe College, in New Rochelle, diners who aren’t risk-averse can open themselves up to an enormously fun — and rewarding — experience.

headline: Evening Hours | So Happy Together
text: With summer approaching, many celebrated outdoors.

headline: First Briefing on Bergdahl’s Condition
text: Maj. Gen. Joseph DiSalvo of the Army said the freed Taliban prisoner Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was in stable condition.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Strutting
text: Signs of a new peacock men’s wear revolution are in evidence.

headline: In the Air | Paper Revolution
text: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, print’s age-old medium is a material of modern design.

headline: For Early Birds and Late Risers Alike
text: After years of catering to night owls with pub offerings like the Good Life in Massapequa Park and the Phoenix in Seaford, Peter Mangouranes, 38, and Paul Oliva, 35, decided to introduce themselves to customers who like to socialize before the sun sets with an all-day breakfast spot called Jam. The cheerful, eight-month-old country cafe, just down the block from the Good Life, has been serving breakfast standards with a twist since October.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Men’s Wear Revolution
text: Signs of a new peacock revolution are in evidence. It features keen attention to detail, including the lapel flower, real or fake. Further evidence are the spectacular windows at Saks Fifth Avenue. A star of the movement, Domenico Spano, known to the world of custom tailoring and fastidious style as Mimmo, outside the Bowery atelier Against Nature. His style has drawn the focus of a group of young men. Also, a gentleman carries the same bright briefcase but pairs it with a different jacket each day.

headline: Among the Rediscovered: Jimmy Giuffre and Eric Dolphy
text: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss two underappreciated jazz artists.

headline: Beinecke Library Gets Sackville-West Papers
text: The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale has acquired the papers of the writer and gardener Vita Sackville-West and her husband, Harold Nicolson, a diplomat, novelist and historian. The couple featured prominently in Britain’s literary and political life in the first half of the 20th century and provided their son, Nigel Nicolson, with the subject of his best-selling 1973 biography, “Portrait of a Marriage.” The archives include drafts of lectures, broadcasts and articles (including a manuscript of her 1942 novel, “Grand Canyon”); letters from her parents; letters from close friends and lovers, including Rosamund Grosvenor, Pat Dansey, Geoffrey Scott, Hilda Matheson, Christopher St. John and Gwen St. Aubyn; and diaries and garden journals dating from 1930 to 1962.

headline: Ruth Simmons at Smith College
text: Ruth Simmons, former president of Smith College and Brown University, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Smith College.

headline: Bob Garfield at Albright College
text: Bob Garfield, journalist, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Albright College.

headline: Oil Industry in Iraq Faces Setback to Revival
text: After a long history of wars and sanctions, Iraq re-emerged as a critical source of oil in recent years. Mounting Iraqi production helped to ease world oil prices despite the tightening restrictions on Iran and tanking exports from Libya. And Western and Chinese oil companies rushed back, revitalizing long-neglected oil fields in the north and south.

headline: No Money, No Time
text: THE absurdity of having had to ask for an extension to write this article isn’t lost on me: It is, after all, a piece on time and poverty, or, rather, time poverty — about what happens when we find ourselves working against the clock to finish something. In the case of someone who isn’t otherwise poor, poverty of time is an unpleasant inconvenience. But for someone whose lack of time is just one of many pressing concerns, the effects compound quickly.

headline: Alexis Ohanian at Carthage College
text: Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Carthage College.

headline: Atul Gawande at U.N.C.-Chapel Hill
text: Atul Gawande, doctor and writer, addresses the 2014 graduating class of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

headline: In ‘Two Gentlemen,’ Shakespeare’s One Dog
text: You don’t see a lot of dogs in Shakespeare’s plays. Actually, you don’t see any — except Crab.

headline: Echoes of Africa Along the Carolina Coast
text: Pete Marovich has been documenting the Gullah communities in South Carolina, which maintain traditions despite the challenges of encroaching development.

headline: Making Sense
