text: I like to think that T is a magazine about all the things in life that you don’t really need, but that make every day seem that much more beautiful and interesting. It’s why, in every issue, we try to bring you a mix of the most compelling cultural ideas percolating in fashion, art, design, food, travel. This month, we decided to focus on the deeper meanings behind some of the most influential people (living and dead) and ideas shaping how we live right now.

headline: Jimmy Scott, Singer Whose Star Rose Late, Dies at 88
text: Jimmy Scott, a jazz singer whose distinctively plaintive delivery and unusually high-pitched voice earned him a loyal following and, late in life, a taste of bona fide stardom, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 88.

headline: Massachusetts Democrat Wins Over Voters; Her Party Is a Different Story
text: BOSTON — It was a cringe-worthy moment for Massachusetts Democrats.

headline: Botox: A Drug With Many (Potential) Uses
text: Botox is currently approved for nearly 30 uses worldwide, including 10 in the United States. But Allergan, the manufacturer, has applied for or received patents on many more uses for the drug, a move made partly to discourage competitors while it pursues further research.

headline: Martha Coakley on Lessons Learned
text: Martha Coakley, the attorney general of Massachusetts, is running as a Democrat for governor, after a failed run for Senate in 2010.

headline: John A. Hamilton, Host of Public Affairs TV Programs, Dies at 84
text: John A. Hamilton, a host and producer of public affairs television programs beginning in the 1970s, died on June 7 in Fairfax, Va. He was 84 and lived in nearby McLean.

headline: Prenatal Testing, Along With the Worries
text: To the Editor:

headline: T Culture Issue
text: The latest issue of T peels back the layers on some of the most influential figures in our culture, past and present. In our cover story, Jody Rosen explores the meaning of music’s biggest superstar, Beyoncé – from her teenage days with Destiny’s Child to her current standing as pop’s most glorified (and scrutinized) V.I.P. In the Seattle laboratory of Nathan Myhrvold, Dwight Garner ponders the future of food over a 50-course meal the Mad Hatter-like culinarian cooked for his hero, Ferran Adrià. And in suburban Chicago, Emily Witt catches up with the teen blogger turned budding media mogul Tavi Gevinson, whose greatest act — after she takes on Broadway, that is — may be yet to come. Elsewhere, the outspoken critic and forward-thinking American fashion designer Elizabeth Hawes finally gets her due, more than four decades after her death; lit’s reigning bad boy and memoirist of the moment Karl Ove Knausgaard grapples with fame in a soul-searching essay; Charlotte Moss looks back on an interview with the late heiress and horticulturist Bunny Mellon, whose fabled Virginia estate is testament to her extraordinary life; BuzzFeed’s click-bait empire gets the “By the Numbers” treatment; and the director Richard Linklater, whose 1970s-set stoner dramedy “Dazed and Confused” helped define a generation (albeit almost two decades after the fact), tackles time once again in his most ambitious project to date. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Iraq’s Factions and Their Goals
text: The goals of of the three main groups in Iraq — Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish — as the country threatens to split apart along sectarian lines.

headline: Easy to Vote in Ohio
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blocking Any Medicaid Expansion, Virginia Legislature Passes Budget Bill
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Empowered by their new majority in the State Senate, Republicans have moved to checkmate Gov. Terry McAuliffe in a monthslong contest over Medicaid, passing a budget that does not include the Medicaid expansion the governor sought and forbidding him from unilaterally expanding the health care program for the poor.

headline: The Psychic Wounds of Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eric Hill, 86, Dies; Created Spot, a Pup Beloved by Toddlers
text: Eric Hill, an illustrator and writer whose picture books featuring a puppy named Spot enchanted toddlers and sold tens of millions of copies, died on June 6 at his home in Templeton, Calif. He was 86.

headline: The Battle Over Dress Codes
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — IN the Bay Area, the last week of school is a time to dig out cozy jackets and socks, but this year our natural air-conditioning (that’s “fog” to you) failed, giving us a few sweltering June days.

headline: World Cup 2014: USA Defeats Ghana, 2-1, on John Brooks Goal
text: An early goal by Clint Dempsey and an improbable late score by John Brooks helped the United States stave off Ghana and avoid a third straight World Cup loss to the small African nation.

headline: The Father’s Example
text: RECENTLY, my 14-year-old son, Carlos, accompanied me on a trip to give a speech alongside a group of politicians. In the large holding room backstage, the speakers milled about, making small talk before our speeches. Working as my assistant, Carlos handed me a bottle of root beer, which, unbeknown to me, he had been shaking. (Behold the mysteries of the 14-year-old mind.) Upon opening it, I sprayed a copious amount onto a distinguished member of Congress.

headline: Bringing Back Europe’s Bison
text: A German prince is leading an effort to bring back the European bison, Europe’s largest land mammal, in Bad Berleburg. The animal almost went extinct in the early 20th century.

headline: Obama Visits Sioux Lands on a Trip Shadowed by Iraq
text: CANNON BALL, N.D. — Hours after adjourning a tense Oval Office meeting about the Iraq crisis, President Obama found himself on the ancestral lands of Chief Sitting Bull, taking part in a powwow to honor American Indians who have served in America’s foreign wars.

headline: New Chairman of Board at N.Y.U. Is Announced
text: New York University has announced a new leader for its board of trustees, one of the largest and most powerful in American academia: William R. Berkley, an insurance industry executive currently serving as a board vice chairman.

headline: In Iraq Crisis, a Tangle of Alliances and Enmities
text: The major players in the Iraq and Syria crisis are often both allies and antagonists, working together on one front on one day and at cross-purposes the next.

headline: Eyesore and Landmark in One
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Rotting, crumbling, covered in graffiti, overrun by weeds, the hulking wreck of a building known as the Aldeia Maracanã would make an unsightly addition to any neighborhood.

headline: A Muslim Entrepreneur Follows a Kosher Model to Mainstream Success
text: During the early months of 2010, Adnan A. Durrani found himself frequently thinking of kosher hot dogs. To be more precise, he was thinking of an ad campaign for them created decades earlier by the Hebrew National company. Its well-known slogan went, “We answer to a higher authority.”

headline: S.E.C. Conducting Investigation of Port Authority Projects
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said this week that it is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, adding to the series of inquiries that have been ordered since the lane-closing scandal at the George Washington Bridge last year.

headline: Chicago Competes Against Itself for Site of Obama Presidential Library
text: CHICAGO — The tussle over the location of President Obama’s future presidential library seems to have come down to a debate over various places he has lived, including this city, New York City and Hawaii. Leaders from all three have been boasting lately of their relative assets as they lobby for the site, which they see as an honor, not to mention an economic driver.

headline: Beleaguered Iraqis Court Iranian Mastermind of the Shiites Who Fought the U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the shadowy commander of Iran’s paramilitary Quds Force, flew to Iraq this week with dozens of his officers to advise the country’s beleaguered leadership about how to blunt the advance of militant forces on Baghdad, American officials said Friday.

headline: A Better Approach to School Discipline
text: The “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies that swept through the country’s schools beginning in the 1990s have led to millions of children each year being suspended, expelled and even arrested, mainly for minor misbehavior that would once have been dealt with at the principal’s office. Federal civil rights officials warned this year that these tactics are often used in a discriminatory fashion against black and Latino children, who are at greater risk of being thrown out of school and denied an education.

headline: Obama, McCain and Maliki
text: THE debacle in Iraq isn’t President Obama’s fault. It’s not the Republicans’ fault. Both bear some responsibility, but, overwhelmingly, it’s the fault of the Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: With Attention Elsewhere, Kaymer Is in Midst of Run of Distinction at U.S. Open
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — With a second straight round of 65, Martin Kaymer set the United States Open record for the lowest score at the halfway mark and became the first player in any of the four major golf championships to open with back-to-back 65s.

headline: Getting a Good Table by Flicking an App, Not Greasing a Palm
text: Who owns a restaurant reservation?

headline: Veterans Watch as Gains Their Friends Died for Are Erased by Insurgents
text: A few weeks before their battalion was to get new mine-resistant vehicles, Capt. Adam P. Snyder, Pvt. Dewayne L. White and Sgt. Eric J. Hernandez were speeding toward a mission in Baiji, Iraq, when a roadside bomb engulfed their Humvee in flames, killing the two enlisted men. Captain Snyder, 26, died the next day, Dec. 5, 2007.

headline: Seeing Their Gains at Risk, Shiites Flock to Join Militias
text: BAGHDAD — When he heard on Tuesday that Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, had fallen to Sunni militants, Abu Ali Alakabaie knew what he had to do.

headline: With No Body, Police Sought Murder Clues Elsewhere
text: Detectives entered a basement in the Bronx and recoiled at the stench and the scene.

headline: Next Steps in Iraq
text: As a bit of an experiment we’re publishing my Sunday column on line tonight, Friday, because it’s newsy and based on today’s events. My deadline for the Sunday column is Friday afternoon, because of early printings for the Sunday Review section, and the Sunday columns normally go on line roughly when the Sunday paper comes out. But we’re all trying not to hamper our digital product with our print constraints, so we decided to put this column up early. Let me know what you think of the idea. And don’t be confused if you read it now on line and then encounter it Sunday in print.

headline: Decorating and Design Meet Taxation and Politics Where Cuomo Lives
text: NEW CASTLE, N.Y. — The white clapboard colonial-style house at 4 Bittersweet Lane in this exclusive town is special for two reasons.

headline: Pastor New to Harlem Takes Rangel On
text: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr. knows he is the outsider. In the Democratic primary for the congressional seat carved out of Harlem that now stretches into parts of the Bronx, Mr. Walrond trails far behind the longtime incumbent, Representative Charles B. Rangel, and State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in the polls.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 13, 2014
In a Downpour, Mexico Keeps Calm to Edge Cameroon
text: NATAL, Brazil — The rain was relentless, descending in thick sheets to turn this city’s glistening new soccer stadium into an overstuffed water park. The officiating was contentious, as two apparent goals were canceled within a 20-minute span in the first half.

headline: The Koch Cycle of Endless Cash
text: It’s not enough, apparently, that some of the wealthiest Americans spend millions to elect their candidates to Congress. Now they are using their fortunes to lobby Congress against any limits on their ability to buy elections.

headline: Sign at the End of a Freeway
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re going to attempt to solve the Saturday New York Times Crossword — and why wouldn’t you? — it helps to try one that has lots of white space in which to roam, plenty of fun, crunchy entries, some tricky cluing to keep you interested and some high-scoring Scrabble letters in the mix. Alex Vratsanos’s puzzle pretty much achieves all of these. He’s also hit for the cycle — published a puzzle for each day of the week — with this one, so congratulations are in order.

headline: Spain Was Asking for Trouble Against the Netherlands
text: Spain played a high defensive line, positioning themselves well forward, near midfield. It left them vulnerable, giving the Netherlands multiple opportunities for long passes to streaking forwards, resulting in many high-quality chances — and many goals.

headline: Recreating Wilderness in Spain
text: A reserve in the country’s west seeks to transform unused farmland into the type of wild area that disappeared from Europe centuries ago.

headline: From Untended Farmland, Reserve Tries to Recreate Wilderness From Long Ago
text: LA ALAMEDILLA, Spain — The forces of nature were getting more than a little prodding recently on the grassy 1,200-acre reserve outside this village near Spain’s border with Portugal.

headline: So Triple Crown Is Tough? Try Sweeping Golf’s Majors
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Thirteen horses have won the first two legs of the Triple Crown since 1978, when Affirmed completed the feat with a victory in the Belmont. In the same span, only one man, Tiger Woods, has won the first two legs of golf’s holy grail.

headline: Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity
text: Despite major gains in fighting hepatitis C and other chronic liver conditions, public health officials are now faced with a growing epidemic of liver disease that is tightly linked to the obesity crisis.

headline: A Game of Groans
text: Today let’s find fun ways to talk about the Highway Trust Fund.

headline: Walking in a Graduation Procession, 50 Years Late
text: Richard Zirpolo’s heart pumped. His hands sweated. It was his high school graduation ceremony in 1964, and he was ready to receive his diploma.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteers Deserve Fairness
text: Women make up more than 60 percent of the Peace Corps, volunteers who are often put in situations where safe and reliable medical care is difficult to find and where they face the risk of sexual assault. Yet federal law does not allow abortion coverage in the volunteers’ health care program, even in cases of rape or incest, or when a pregnancy endangers a woman’s life. Next week, subcommittees in both the House and the Senate will begin work on a Peace Corps budget for the next fiscal year. The lawmakers should repeal this unfair prohibition.

headline: Reprisal Killings Reported in Iraq’s Militant-Held Areas
text: ERBIL, Iraq — While still largely refraining from terrorizing the population inside Mosul, militants, working from a list they have obtained, have begun seeking out citizens who worked for the government, offering some a chance to repent and live under their authority, and in other cases executing them on the spot, according to accounts of residents and a top United Nations official.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso
text: My wife, who hates you all, suggested this as today’s music selection:

headline: Immigration Is Key, Not Top, Issue in South Carolina County
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Dripping with sweat while working in his front yard here, Kevin Bailey had sharp words about President Obama’s health law and what he sees as runaway spending on Capitol Hill. Those issues, he said, were those that mattered most.

headline: After Heat’s Humbling Loss, Future Is Uncertain
text: MIAMI — His numbers were solid, nothing out of the ordinary for LeBron James. He finished Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals with 28 points and 8 rebounds, plying his trade against a convoy of defenders that included the San Antonio Spurs’ Kawhi Leonard, who, at a precocious 22, somehow plays with both energy and polish.

headline: Franz Beckenbauer Barred by FIFA for 90 Days
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — FIFA’s ethics committee on Friday suspended Franz Beckenbauer from all soccer activity for 90 days, saying he had refused requests to cooperate with an investigation into the bidding for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups.

headline: Spurs Have Made N.B.A. Finals Anything but Close
text: The N.B.A. finals were billed as a repeat of one of the most competitive series in history. The defending champion Miami Heat may have won their 2012-13 series against the Spurs, but you had to really squint to see the difference between the two teams. At the end of seven intense games, the San Antonio Spurs had actually outscored the Miami Heat by five points.

headline: Drowsy Drivers, Dangerous Highways
text: Days before an accident in which an allegedly drowsy truck driver crashed into a van carrying the actor Tracy Morgan, critically injuring him and killing another passenger, a Senate committee voted to roll back regulations meant to keep fatigued truckers off the nation’s highways.

headline: Try a Little Common Sense
text: Last month, around the same time the European High Court ruled that Europeans had a “right to be forgotten” by the search engine Google, a man named Tim Barefield approached me with the following story:

headline: Idaho Republican, Appealing to Right, Enters Race to Replace Cantor
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Raúl R. Labrador, a Republican of Idaho who has barely served two terms in Congress, jumped into the race for House majority leader on Friday, offering himself as the more conservative alternative who could pull the House rightward in the wake of Representative Eric Cantor’s loss in a primary.

headline: Jeter’s Return to Oakland Recalls a Defensive Gem
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Unless the Yankees and the Oakland Athletics meet in the playoffs, shortstop Derek Jeter will make his final stop this weekend at the O.co Coliseum, the site of perhaps the most memorable defensive play in his 20-year major league career.

headline: Strategies in the Political and Athletic Arenas
text: The opening game of the World Cup had everything the advance hype promised — battles between the police and protesters outside the São Paulo stadium; boos for the leaders of Brazil and FIFA, the governing body of world soccer; dodgy refereeing; and a beautiful game between Brazil and Croatia.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Could Help in Reversing Insurgent Offensive, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — American air power could play an important role in reversing the Sunni insurgent offensive in Iraq, current and former American military officials said on Friday, but it would be most effective with improved intelligence about insurgent targets and if the United States were willing to deploy small teams of advisers to call in airstrikes.

headline: Kings Beat Rangers for Cup, Ending Short Series of Long Games
text: LOS ANGELES — Bad omens stared at Henrik Lundqvist at the start of Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals. It was the 666th game of his Rangers career. A full moon — the first on Friday the 13th since 2000 — hung over Staples Center.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE CONJURING (2013) Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga, above, play Ed and Lorraine Warren, the real-life paranormal investigators who declared an infamous Dutch colonial-style house on Long Island haunted, leading to more than a dozen “Amityville” movies. Their target this time is a Rhode Island farmhouse, where the blissful dreams of Carolyn and Roger Perron (Lili Tayor and Ron Livingston) and their five daughters become a moaning, creaking nightmare when they find themselves playing cat-and-mouse with an evil force. The director, James Wan, “smartly keeps enough distance from the Warrens that you can see that these true believers are also hovering at the edge of dangerous fanaticism,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “That gives the movie a shiver of political currency, even if a greater, more sustaining pleasure of this particular haunted-house fantasy is how it works as a metaphor for moviegoing itself. When the Perrons first settle into their house, they’re facing the future with bright, anxious smiles that aren’t much different from those of the horror-film faithful who are waiting nervously, hopefully, to be jolted by the next great shocker. It’s here.”

headline: Kings Capture Cup at Home
text: The Kings rallied in the third period to force overtime and scored in the second extra period to beat the Rangers in Game 5 and win the Stanley Cup.

headline: Talk of Puck Luck Bounces Both Ways for Both Teams
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s called puck luck, and it would seem to be an appropriate phrase for some of the bounces, deflections and goal-line theatrics that threaded their way through the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Chuck Noll, Coach of Steelers’ 1970s Dynasty, Dies at 82
text: Chuck Noll, who built the “Steel Curtain” Pittsburgh Steelers of the 1970s into one of the most dominant teams in pro football history, becoming the only N.F.L. coach to win four Super Bowl championships, died on Friday at his home in Sewickley, Pa., outside Pittsburgh. He was 82.

headline: Mets Choosing Sides in World Cup
text: Mets reliever Carlos Torres was sitting at his locker Wednesday, speaking into his phone in a hushed tone and a hurried manner. Torres sounded desperate, almost as if he were begging.

headline: Republicans at Romney Retreat Search for Focus
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The official topic of the conference, emblazoned on materials handed out to guests gathered here at a luxury Norwegian-inspired resort, was “The Future of American Leadership.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 14, 2014
text: “The equivalent of this is foie gras. You have to force feed ducks to get fatty liver, but people seem to be able to develop it on their own.”

headline: Phelps Shuts Down Athletics as He Gets Support From Yankees’ Offense
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — No one saw this coming Friday night from Yankees right-hander David Phelps against the Oakland Athletics.

headline: Corrections: June 14, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Afghans, Looking Ahead to U.S. Withdrawal, Vote With Guarded Optimism
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghans lined up on Saturday to vote in the second and final round of the country’s presidential election, choosing a new leader to steer Afghanistan through the coming withdrawal of American-led military forces. Despite reports of numerous attacks in rural parts of the country, the Taliban appear to have failed to disrupt the voting.

headline: Separatists Down Military Transport Jet, Killing 49 in Eastern Ukraine
text: LUHANSK, Ukraine — Separatists in Ukraine used a shoulder-fired missile to shoot down a large Ukrainian military transport jet as it was trying to land at an airport in this eastern city on Saturday, killing all 49 people on board, the military said. The attack was the deadliest episode for the Ukrainian military since the unrest began in the country’s east.

headline: Analytics: Poem by Committee
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the June 15 issue of the magazine.

headline: Iraq Rebels Stall North of Baghdad as Residents Brace for a Siege
text: BAGHDAD — A rebel juggernaut that captured Iraq’s second-largest city and raced nearly 200 miles south in three days, raising fears of an imminent assault on Baghdad, stalled for a second day on Saturday about 60 miles north of the capital, leaving residents bracing for a siege that so far has not happened.

headline: Why That Phone Charger Took Two Years to Arrive
text: I first heard about the JuiceTank, a slim iPhone case that doubles as a wall charger, when my friends started raving about it two years ago on Twitter. There was one catch, though it didn’t bother them: The JuiceTank didn’t yet exist.

headline: We Will Be Welcomed As Liberators
text: I’ve often noted that to a first approximation, nobody ever admits having been wrong about anything. My usual prime example is all the people who issued dire warnings five years ago that runaway inflation was imminent — and are issuing identical warnings to this day. But all of that is nothing as compared with the way the same people who assured us that the invasion of Iraq would be a splendid little war — remember “Everyone wants to go to Baghdad, real mean want to go to Tehran”? — are now insisting that we should go all in on behalf of a corrupt, incompetent regime that is basically Iran’s ally, not ours.

headline: At De Beers, Collecting Images and Inspiration
text: Above the buzz

headline: On the Steamboat, and Striking Up the Calliope
You Can’t Have A Wage-Price Spiral Without Wages
text: There was a fairly characteristic argument over dinner last night about when the Fed should tighten. I’m in the camp that says it should wait until we see wages rising at least at pre-crisis rates. The other side says that wages are a lagging indicator, and if it waits that long the Fed will be behind the curve.

headline: Bernard Schwartz, on the Philosophy of ‘Just Say Yes’
text: This interview with  Bernard L. Schwartz, an investor who is the former chairman and C.E.O. of the Loral Corporation, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Finding Shock Absorbers for Student Debt
text: President Obama last week signed an executive order aimed at easing the debt burden on millions of people who borrowed money for college. Soaring loan costs, he said, have put “too big a debt load on too many people,” and it’s time to do something about it.

headline: Pension Funds, Dancing a Two-Step With Ratings Firms
text: Pension fund investors lost billions of dollars trusting the rosy credit ratings stamped on troubled mortgage securities before the 2008 crisis. In its aftermath, they have spent years and many dollars suing Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, the main purveyors of those dubious grades.

headline: Allergan, Defending Its Fort Botox
text: David E. I. Pyott spent a couple of hectic days in Manhattan last week, paying calls on institutional investors and Wall Street analysts, trying to persuade them that his company is worth much more than $54 billion.

headline: The Nation’s Economy, This Side of the Recession
text: In the five years since the United States began its slow climb out of the deepest recession since the 1930s, the job market has undergone a substantial makeover.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 15
text: “Noncompetes are a dampener on innovation and economic development.”

headline: Troubled by Lengthy Elevator Repairs
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Colombia vs. Greece: Live Blog
text: Live coverage and analysis of the match between Colombia and Greece. Colombia, the seeded team and a sleeper pick by many to make a deep run, lost its star striker Radamel Falcao to a knee injury, but the team still has plenty of talent.

headline: Room Service, I’ll Have a Massage
text: In-room massages are a standard amenity at most upscale hotels, but luxury properties are increasingly giving their guests a chance to enjoy more elaborate spa treatments en-suite. The Chatwal in New York City, for example, has a package through its Elizabeth Arden spa that includes reflexology, a warm cream manicure and a blow dry and style for women and hair trim and neck cleanup for men ($534).

headline: Carrying Fragile Hopes, England Stumbles in Opener
text: MANAUS, Brazil — England had just counterattacked and counterpunched, quickly responding to a goal by Italy with one of its own. But this is the World Cup, and England never seems to escape the bizarre.

headline: Variety: A Somewhat Hostile Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Samuel Butler had a complicated relationship with his parents, but particularly his father, which could explain the underlying hostility in today’s acrostic quote. In the 1932 book “Samuel Butler: A Mid-Victorian Modern,” he wrote: “He never liked me, nor I him; from my earliest recollections I can call to mind no time when I did not fear him and dislike him … I have never passed a day without thinking of him many times over as the man who was sure to be against me.”

headline: E3 Still Dazzles, Even as Video Game Sales Go Digital
text: LOS ANGELES — The Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, the video game industry’s annual convention, is very good at a certain ritual: building hype for big-budget games — more often than not for consoles — just before summer starts, so publishers can maximize their sales when games land on store shelves for the holidays.

headline: The End of Iraq
text: EVERY so often, in the post-9/11 era, an enterprising observer circulates a map of what the Middle East might look like, well, after: after America’s wars in the region, after the various revolutions and counterrevolutions, after the Arab Spring and the subsequent springtime for jihadists, after the Sunni-Shiite struggle for mastery. At some point, these cartographers suggest, the wave of post-9/11 conflict will necessarily redraw borders, reshape nation-states, and rub out some of the lines drawn by Sir Mark Sykes and François Georges-Picot in a secret Anglo-French treaty almost 100 years ago.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Latest Updates on the Insurgency in Iraq
text: Open Source is collecting reports from bloggers and journalists in Iraq on Saturday, as the government in Baghdad attempts to regroup following a string of victories by Islamist militants.

headline: 21 Flat-Screen TVs, 18 Holes, One Pair of Eyes
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — It was the first round of his 20th United States Open telecast, and the Golf Channel and NBC producer Tommy Roy had a meaty morsel of information for the on-air host Dan Hicks, who could not decipher what Roy was shouting into his earpiece.

headline: ‘After Midnight’ to Close After 8 Months
text: The Broadway musical “After Midnight,” a revue of song-and-dance numbers from the Cotton Club era of the 1920s, will close on June 29 after more than eight months of performances, a spokesman for the show confirmed on Saturday. The producers of “After Midnight” were hoping to boost their modest ticket sales by winning the Tony Award for best musical last Sunday, but another nominee, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” took the prize. “After Midnight,” which was capitalized at about $7 million, will close at a financial loss. Investors may recoup some money if a national tour of the show – now in discussions – comes together and proves successful.

headline: Medical Device Maker Medtronic Is Said to Be Near a Deal for Covidien
text: Medtronic Medtronic is nearing a deal to buy a competitor, Covidien, for more than $45 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, in a deal that would combine two major medical device makers.

headline: Ukrainian Military Plane Shot Down
text: A Ukrainian military plane was shot down by Pro-Russia separatists in Novohannivka, Ukraine. All 49 people aboard were killed.

headline: Flying 3 Flags and Seeking One Banner
text: SAN ANTONIO — Benny Mills, it appears, is the type of man who is incapable of speaking without a smile, one that instantly gives his cherubic face an impish glint. His wife, Yvonne, is a more serious study, a woman who chooses her words carefully, as if they are irrevocable, and speaks them with a quiet force.

headline: A Cantor Effect for Businesses and the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — The day after Representative Eric Cantor became the first congressional leader in modern times to lose his seat in a primary, one of the biggest aftershocks occurred not on Capitol Hill or in the sprawling Richmond suburbs he has represented for more than a decade but on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Kings’ Second Stanley Cup in Three Seasons Defies Cap Logic
text: LOS ANGELES — One team winning two Stanley Cups in three seasons during this salary-capped era of parity in the N.H.L. defies logic. But the Los Angeles Kings have never paid mind to the expectations of others.

headline: New Position for Angels: Contention
text: In his first two seasons as general manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Jerry Dipoto watched his team all but disappear from contention in the early-season quicksand. In 2012, the Angels doomed themselves with a 6-14 start. Last year, they lost 22 of their first 33.

headline: Minority Gun Owners Face Balancing Act, Weighing Isolation and Stigma of Violence
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Standing in a small booth surrounded by displays for rifles, pistols, holsters and other firearm accouterments, the Rev. Kenn Blanchard signed copies of his book “Black Man With a Gun: Reloaded.” Amid the sea of thousands of white faces that descended on this city for the National Rifle Association convention in late April, Mr. Blanchard, an N.R.A. member since 1991, offered his reasoning for why he was one of the few black visitors.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: The Big City Book Club’s hot-summer reading selection is Richard Price’s best-selling 2008 novel, “Lush Life.” The book is both an evocation of decades of life on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and the tale of a violent crime whose effects ripple. One of the witnesses of the murder is initially considered a suspect, and even when he is exonerated, the trauma of the event stays long with him. Join us for the live discussion of the book on Tuesday, July 15, at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Uruguay vs. Costa Rica: Live Blog
text: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scores three goals to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.

headline: A Conflict on Campus
text: Readers discuss whether college groups should be allowed to exclude students.

headline: Notes From the Plasticene Epoch
text: Like diamonds, plastics are forever. The tons dumped into the ocean float around, swirling on currents, breaking into smaller bits, never going away. Scientists have identified huge gyres of plastic in the Pacific. There is an Eastern Garbage Patch, between Hawaii and California; a Western Garbage Patch, off Japan, and a patch between them called the Subtropical Convergence Zone, north of Hawaii.

headline: Highways Need Help, but Not This Way
text: It should surprise no one that the federal Highway Trust Fund is on the brink of insolvency. The 18.4 cents a gallon federal gas tax that is the fund’s main source of revenue has not been raised since 1993. Since then, the population has grown by 55 million people. Roads, bridges, tunnels and public transit have not been maintained or upgraded to meet the increased demand.

headline: Peggy Smith
text: Peggy Smith was a chef at Chez Panisse in Berkeley for 17 years before co-founding Cowgirl Creamery, which makes award-winning artisan cheeses. The company, in Point Reyes Station, Calif., was among the first American cheesemakers inducted into France’s prestigious Guilde Internationale des Fromagers.

headline: 5 Principles for Iraq
text: THE disintegration of Iraq and Syria is upending an order that has defined the Middle East for a century. It is a huge event, and we as a country need to think very carefully about how to respond. Having just returned from Iraq two weeks ago, my own thinking is guided by five principles, and the first is that, in Iraq today, my enemy’s enemy is my enemy. Other than the Kurds, we have no friends in this fight. Neither Sunni nor Shiite leaders spearheading the war in Iraq today share our values.

headline: My Father, Body and Soul
text: IT’S been eight years since I last saw my father, lying in his reclining chair in his living room, as perfectly still as the half-filled coffee cups on the side table.

headline: A Paper Boat Navigating a Digital Sea
text: IT’S Wednesday morning and 39 editors have filed in to the 10 a.m. meeting in The Times’s third-floor conference room, some carrying laptops and smartphones, others with pens and notepads.

headline: Naked Confessions of the College-Bound
text: THE Yale applicant had terrific test scores. She had fantastic grades. As one of Yale’s admissions officers, Michael Motto, leafed through her application, he found himself more and more impressed.

headline: When Will Hillary Let It Go?
text: WASHINGTON — NO one wrote about blondes like Raymond Chandler.

headline: The Fog Machine of War
text: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan. — WHEN I chose to disclose classified information in 2010, I did so out of a love for my country and a sense of duty to others. I’m now serving a sentence of 35 years in prison for these unauthorized disclosures. I understand that my actions violated the law.

headline: Abortion and Birth, Together
text: SOME of the pregnant women who arrive at Buffalo Womenservices in upstate New York are there for checkups or tours of the birth center, with its pool and homey delivery room. Others arrive to talk to a doctor, nurse or counselor. But they are not waiting for prenatal tests. They are there to get abortions.

headline: Poetry: Who Needs It?
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — WE live in the age of grace and the age of futility, the age of speed and the age of dullness. The way we live now is not poetic. We live prose, we breathe prose, and we drink, alas, prose. There is prose that does us no great harm, and that may even, in small doses, prove medicinal, the way snake oil cured everything by curing nothing. But to live continually in the natter of ill-written and ill-spoken prose is to become deaf to what language can do.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 15
text: A primary race in Virginia rocked the political world when Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost to his Tea Party-backed opponent David Brat, an economics professor. By the following day, Mr. Cantor announced that he would resign his leadership position by July 31. Mr. Cantor will appear on both ABC’s “This Week and CNN’s “State of the Union,” to give his opinion on why he lost his congressional seat and what went wrong with his campaign.

headline: The Milk Carton Guy
text: In early 2003, military investigators traveled to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to interview one of the prison camp’s most valuable detainees, a Qaeda loyalist from Morocco named Abdullah Tabarak. According to multiple reports, Mr. Tabarak had been Osama bin Laden’s chief bodyguard and longtime confidant, and he gave himself up to help bin Laden elude capture shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: The Ultimate Underdog
text: TOKYO — Itaru Kobayashi remembers what his baseball coach at the University of Tokyo used to tell the team before games, and he remembers what the coach said after the team inevitably lost.

headline: A Stigma of Black Gun Ownership
text: In recent decades, gun ownership has been taboo among many African-Americans, but that may be changing.

headline: Teams Win N.B.A. Titles, but Superstars Sell the Sizzle, and Themselves
text: I get nervous whenever people begin pining for “the good old days.” There has been a lot of this over the last few days as the San Antonio Spurs have mopped the floor with the Miami Heat during the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Extremist Video Appears to Show American
text: Intelligence analysts believe that a video released by a Syrian rebel group last month shows Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the American who blew himself up in the conflict recently.

headline: Syria Suicide Bombing Puts U.S. Face on Jihad Video
text: WASHINGTON — Like a trailer for a summer blockbuster, the video begins with loud music and the words “Coming Soon.”

headline: Rift Bared as Palestinians Aid Israel in Search for Teenagers Missing in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — As the search continued on Saturday for three Israeli teenagers who were missing in the West Bank and were presumed to have been abducted by Palestinian militants, the crisis underscored the complexity of Israel’s relations with the Palestinian Authority and the authority’s deep differences with Hamas despite a recent reconciliation pact.

headline: A Piece of the Game Beyond the Walls
text: CONTAGEM, Brazil — Hugo Alves used to play professional soccer for a living. He remains connected to the sport, but not in the way he intended. Now his uniform consists of a red T-shirt and pants, and he makes soccer balls at a factory in prison.

headline: A Baseball Binge Woven From Dreams
text: This would be a week from my dreams: five major league baseball games in five cities in five days.

headline: Palace of Squatters Is a Symbol of Refugee Crisis
text: ROME — On a recent evening, two volunteer doctors and a handful of medical students moved gingerly around a dimly lit room, examining dozens of newly arrived migrants from the Horn of Africa. The medics treated blotchy arms, legs and feet — symptoms of scabies — lighting the infected areas with a smartphone app. Nearby, a pediatrician listened to the chests of newborns and toddlers.

headline: Obama Moves to End Rail Workers Strike in Philadelphia
text: A transit strike in Philadelphia ended late Saturday after President Obama signed an executive order creating a presidential emergency board to help resolve the labor dispute.

headline: Graduates Cautioned: Don’t Shut Out Opposing Views
text: Commencement speakers made news this year mostly by their absence. Protesters on the left assailed speakers who had been invited by colleges and universities, and in some cases, they got their wish, driving away the intended guests.

headline: The Fight Over New Standards
text: Backlash reigns in schools nationwide after the introduction of Common Core standards. Critics say they are overly difficult, but others say they challenge students to become better thinkers.

headline: Tears of Joy and Heartbreak After an Enthralling Series
text: LOS ANGELES — Long passages of breathless excitement and almost unbearable anxiety, and then, in an instant, utter joy and utter despair. Alec Martinez leaps once, his arms aloft in joy; a second time, and tosses away his stick; a third time, and throws off his gloves. He turns to embrace his teammates — he has just scored to win the Stanley Cup for the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: Common Core, in 9-Year-Old Eyes
text: He could have written about the green toy truck he kept hidden in his room, a reminder of Haiti, a place he did not yet fully understand.

headline: England vs. Italy: Live Blog
text: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus in the first match in the Amazon rainforest.

headline: At Commencement, Obama Mocks Lawmakers Who Deny Climate Change
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — President Obama, appearing emboldened after his recent move to cut carbon emissions from coal-fired power plants, on Saturday ridiculed members of Congress who deny climate change or plead scientific ignorance as an alibi for avoiding an uncomfortable truth.

headline: Enrich
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., so it’s not really a Father’s Day puzzle, unless, of course, you really like the letter ‘N,’ in which case, surprise! Happy Father’s Day!

headline: Korea’s Fish Special: A Delicate Mix of Outhouse and Ammonia
text: HEUKSAN ISLAND, South Korea — South Korea has a generous list of foods some find hard to swallow, among them boiled silkworm pupae and live baby octopuses, which have been known to attach their suction cups to the roofs of diners’ mouths in what appear to be desperate bids to escape.

headline: Cambodia’s Scam Orphanages
text: In Cambodia, less than a quarter of children in orphanages are actual orphans.

headline: Property Taxes and the Urge to Tinker
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Cambodian Activist’s Fall Exposes Broad Deception
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The fall from grace of one of Cambodia’s most prominent social activists and the unraveling of her sad tale of being an orphan sold into sex slavery has highlighted what aid workers here say is widespread embellishment and in some cases outright deception in fund-raising, especially among the country’s orphanages.

headline: Trying to Limit Outside Influence in Prescribing Drugs
text: As sales representatives for pharmaceutical companies brought doughnuts and lunch over the years to physicians at the 20 Kelsey-Seybold medical clinics in the Houston area, Patrick Carter worked to limit the representatives’ presence.

headline: Lee Hyla, 61, Who Mixed Rock and Jazz Into Classical Works, Dies
text: Lee Hyla, an American composer whose work married the formal rigor of classical music with the driving energy of rock and the improvisational abandon of jazz, died on June 6 in Chicago. He was 61.

headline: Recognizing a Hurdle and Finding Her Voice
text: Kat Candler, the writer and director, fell in with an ambitious group of filmmakers when she first moved to Austin from Florida in 1997.

headline: Alan Douglas, Who Mined Hendrix Archive, Dies at 82
text: Alan Douglas, a music producer and packager who worked with jazz greats like Duke Ellington, recorded the prerap stylings of the Last Poets and published a book of monologues by Lenny Bruce — but who is best known as a controversial steward of the legacy of Jimi Hendrix — died on June 7 at his home in Paris. He was 82.

headline: In Democratic Stronghold, a Republican Fights Back
text: EL PASO — A San Antonio native and former C.I.A. agent is trying to break through in the only region in this Republican state where congressional Democrats hold a steady grip: Texas’ border with Mexico.

headline: Frank Schirrmacher, German Newspaper Publisher, Dies at 54
text: BERLIN — Frank Schirrmacher, a co-publisher of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung and one of Germany’s most prominent and forceful intellectuals, died on Thursday after a heart attack. He was 54.

headline: After Annexing Crimea, Euphoric Russia Turns Thoughts to Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — The event in Moscow last week was billed as an expert discussion, not a political one, on Ukraine’s future. But Sergei Y. Glazyev, an economic adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin with a distinctive Stalinist bent, unleashed some rather overtly political remarks.

headline: University of Tokyo’s Favorite Disappointment
text: The university, locally known as Todai, churns out success in almost every field, except baseball. The team has lost 76 straight games.

headline: As the Demand for Court Interpreters Climbs, State Budget Conflicts Grow as Well
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Judge David Segura of Santa Fe County Magistrate Court called his first housing case of the day, a disagreement between Gabriela Herrera and her landlord over a rental payment. In Spanish, Ms. Herrera — born in California, raised in Mexico and a resident of this city for six years — recounted her side of the story, fixing her eyes on the judge, whose eyes, in turn, kept shifting to the interpreter translating her words into English in a booming baritone.

headline: Ivory Coast vs. Japan: Live Blog
text: This is Ivory Coast’s moment after two cycles of bad luck and bad draws at the World Cup. While Japan is looking to atone for some spotty pre-World Cup performances.

headline: With Spurs’ Minds on a Title, the Heat Give Theirs a Break
text: SAN ANTONIO — After the San Antonio Spurs dealt his team two straight losses in Miami, Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra took an unconventional approach, advising his players to avoid even thinking about basketball. That was his prescription for Friday: no practice, no second-guessing themselves, no stress.

headline: Massachusetts Democrats Hand Coakley a Setback
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Massachusetts Democrats on Saturday endorsed for governor Steve Grossman, the state treasurer, passing over Martha Coakley, the attorney general, and setting up an intense fight for the party nomination in the September primary.

headline: Calling Back a Zombie Ship From the Graveyard of Space
text: For 17 years, it has been drifting on a lonely course through space. Launched during the disco era and shuttered by NASA in 1997, the spacecraft is now returning to the civilization that abandoned it.

headline: A Nation Teased by a Stale Promise of Supremacy
text: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — Few in Uruguay will have heard of the English man of letters Cyril Connolly. Yet his most famous phrase — “Whom the gods wish to destroy they first call promising” — would not be lost on a country used to auspicious starts.

headline: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
text: ERBIL, Iraq — When Islamic militants rampaged through the Iraqi city of Mosul last week, robbing banks of hundreds of millions of dollars, opening the gates of prisons and burning army vehicles, some residents greeted them as if they were liberators and threw rocks at retreating Iraqi soldiers.

headline: Despite Five Bogeys, Kaymer Calmly Holds On to a Five-Shot Lead
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — No one plays the United States Open without hitting a shot that ends up somewhere unforeseen or, worse, somewhere unbelievably unlucky. What happens after that often defines the golfer’s competitive journey.

headline: In Second Career Start, Harvey’s Former Teammate Blanks the Mets
text: After the finest pitching performance of his young career, in front of about two dozen friends and family members at Citi Field, Jesse Hahn returned to his locker in the visiting clubhouse and checked his phone. He found a simple text message: “Good job.” It was from Matt Harvey.

headline: Yankees Aren’t Exactly Bombers, but Their Bats Are Showing Signs of Life
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees went 12 straight games without scoring more than four runs before beating the Seattle Mariners, 6-3, on Thursday night to sweep their three-game series.

headline: High School Stars Mix With Pros at Grand Prix
text: After the women’s 1,500 meters Saturday at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island in New York, Alexa Efraimson had to put her hands on her knees, with beads of sweat dripping down her forehead as she tried to catch her breath. She had finished the race in 4 minutes 7.05 seconds, the second-fastest time in the event by a high school runner in the United States.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 14, 2014
Worry Under the Big Top as Mexico City Moves to Ban Circus Animals
text: MEXICO CITY — It is a weekday evening under the circus tent, and Bebeto Fuentes does it all effortlessly. He soars on the trapeze, vaults on and off a cantering horse, keeps an eye on the tigers, spins off the trampoline and takes a turn as a melancholy clown.

headline: Pinehurst Scary? Not After Heart Surgery
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — While Erik Compton rested for his Saturday afternoon round at the United States Open, his mother, Eli, monitored the morning wave of players at Pinehurst No. 2. It was like watching a man-made disaster unfold. The first 33 golfers to tee off averaged 75.06 strokes, and four did not break 80.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Alison and Donnie Team Up
text: Season 2, Episode 9:

headline: Czech Star Loses Again in His Own Showcase

headline: Young, Former Titans Quarterback, Retires
text: Quarterback Vince Young, who has not played in the N.F.L. since 2011, told NFL.com that he had retired. Young, the No. 3 overall pick in 2006 by the Tennessee Titans, was released in 2011 after a falling-out with Jeff Fisher, then the Titans’ coach. Young participated in the Cleveland Browns’ minicamp before signing with the team May 1, but the team cut him four days after drafting Johnny Manziel.

headline: Fearing a Junta Crackdown, Cambodian Workers Stream Out of Thailand
text: Tens of thousands of Cambodians working in Thailand have fled the country in a chaotic exodus that appears to be driven by fears of a crackdown on illegal foreign laborers by the military junta that seized power in Thailand last month.

headline: Massacre Claim Shakes Iraq

headline: The World’s Best Father Gets a Close Shave
text: Today is Father’s Day! Whether it’s cooking breakfast in bed or playing superheroes together, my daughter Alice Bee always has something fun planned for the two of us. And it’s sounding like today is going to be no exception: She just informed me that she has scheduled my first-ever straight razor shave down at the local barbershop.

headline: Morning Views
text: “Republicans continue to rail against President Obama’s trade of five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl on May 31,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “But prisoner releases in wartime are never simple or clean.” The board cites President George W. Bush’s release of a Moroccan Al Qaeda operative by the name of Abdullah Tabarak, chief bodyguard to Osama bin Laden, in 2004 as precedent for President Obama’s decision. The Times believes opposition to the swap derives not from concerns for national security but for partisanship: “Perhaps Republicans were not troubled by such releases — and the more than 500 others that occurred during the Bush administration — because they were not then blinded by hatred of the White House occupant.”

headline: The Corporates and the Crazies
text: Jeremy Peters and Shaila Dewan write about corporate shock over the sudden fall of Eric Cantor; it’s further confirmation of the story I told in my last column. Corporations and plutocrats had a good deal going: they bankrolled politicians who talked cultural populism during campaigns, but more or less ignored all that and focused on tax cuts and deregulation after the polls closed. And Cantor fit that profile perfectly.

headline: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Soccer Falls Short
text: NATAL, Brazil — The list of improvements that the United States men’s soccer team needs to make is considerable. Coach Jurgen Klinsmann would like to see a more consistent back line, better touch from his midfielders and plenty more production from the attackers.

headline: Bombings Kill Up to 21 People in Baghdad
text: Insurgents set off two bombs in separate incidents in central Baghdad on Sunday, killing as many as 21 people, witnesses said, and breaking a recent although brief lull in attacks in Iraq’s capital city.

headline: Disciplined Democrats

text: Anne-Marie Slaughter has noted that while everybody asks expectant moms how they’re going to balance work and family, few think to ask the same of dads. But now that may be changing — and dads’ answers reveal a lot about American culture at home and at the office.

headline: Netanyahu Says Three Were Taken by Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday that Israel knew “for a fact” that the kidnapping of three Israeli teenagers was the work of the militant Islamic movement Hamas but held the Palestinian Authority responsible, arguing that the abduction proved that the world was wrong to accept the Palestinian government formed this month with Hamas’s consent.

headline: Casey Kasem, Wholesome Voice of Pop Radio, Dies at 82

headline: Casey Kasem, an American Voice
text: At the height of his career, Casey Kasem was among the best-known D.J.’s in the country. His weekly four-hour show, “American Top 40” defined middle-of-the-road radio taste in America at the time.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (Smithsonian) SHARK GIRL “My family and morals have made me the person I am today,” Madison Stewart, above, says, before adding what might give some viewers pause: “When I speak of family, I speak of sharks.” The 20-year-old Ms. Stewart, who was 2 when she began crisscrossing the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia on a boat with her parents, goes where few others dare. Since the age of 12, she has been diving with sharks, without the protection of a cage but armed with the video camera she uses as a media weapon to fight the misconceptions circling these creatures. This documentary follows Ms. Stewart as she travels from Australia to Mexico, Palau and the Bahamas to commune with tiger sharks, Caribbean reef sharks and silky sharks — and in the process debunks myths and alleviates fears by demonstrating how these predators help keep the entire ocean ecosystem in balance.

headline: Six Are Killed in a House Fire in Newark
text: NEWARK — An 11-year-old boy and five of his relatives died on Sunday in an early morning fire that swept through the family’s house here, killing everyone inside and leaving a neighborhood in mourning.

headline: Making Balls Behind Bars

headline: Dancing for the Knicks Is a Coveted Opportunity, but the Salary Is a Secret
text: There were no rabble-rousers among the aspiring Knicks City Dancers who poured into a dance studio in Midtown last week. There was no rebellion amid the shoulder shimmies and high kicks as dozens of young women prepared for an upcoming audition for a coveted spot on the squad.

headline: Casey Kasem Remembered on Twitter
text: Kerri Kasem used her Facebook page on Sunday to announce the death of her father, Casey Kasem. She described the family as “heartbroken.”

headline: Host in a Big-Tent Era of Pop Music
text: The music didn’t matter that much on “American Top 40,” the syndicated radio countdown show devised by Casey Kasem and a handful of Los Angeles radio colleagues. Individual songs might advance steadily toward No. 1, stall out along the way, suddenly leapfrog into the Top 10 or peak early and plummet. They would come and go: rock or pop, soul or country, hip-hop or synth-pop. The format would hold them all.

headline: Pakistan Military Wages Assault Against Militants
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Ending years of hesitation, Pakistan’s military on Sunday said it was launching a major military operation against the Pakistani Taliban and allied foreign militants at their main base in the tribal belt along the Afghan border.

headline: Obama Discusses Climate Change
text: At a commencement ceremony at the University of California, Irvine, President Obama called for action on climate change.

headline: For Your Birthday, We Got You the Sun
text: With permanent works installed on the High Line and at the newly opened National September 11 Memorial & Museum, Spencer Finch is now pursing his interest in the passage of light and time across the all-but-transparent atrium of the Morgan Library & Museum.

headline: Up at a Villa, Down in a Temple
text: The annual summer festivities at Caramoor, a genteel estate and pleasant getaway from the city, kick off on Saturday with an opening-night gala featuring Joshua Bell playing Sibelius’s soulful Violin Concerto with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s.

headline: Side by Side by Riverside
text: The River to River Festival, presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, gets better every year, and this summer, two female choreographers — both integral to postmodern dance in New York — make the lineup even brighter. Eiko, the extraordinary Japanese dancer revered for her haunting collaborations with Koma, her usual male counterpart, shakes up her creative process in “Two Women,” a new duet featuring the young Japanese dancer Tomoe Aihara.

headline: Senior-Year Blues in 1950s Texas
text: It is 1951 at the start of Peter Bogdanovich’s “The Last Picture Show” (1971), and a bleak winter wind whips through the dusty small town of Anarene, Tex., as high school students (played by Cybill Shepherd, in her screen debut; Jeff Bridges; and Timothy Bottoms) prepare for graduation and the rigors of adulthood. From what they encounter — marital infidelity, class struggle, economic and cultural decline — the future doesn’t look promising.

headline: Peace, Love and Mayhem
text: Hardcore can be a closed circle, with dogmas attacking from every side, which is why it’s refreshing to see the nonlinear path Trash Talk has taken to its career.

headline: When Barristers Do Battle
text: “If you’re chained up in a safe at the bottom of a shark tank,” a colleague advises early in “The Escape Artist,” what you do is “call for Houdini.” The Houdini he means is Will Burton (David Tennant, expressive as ever), London’s top-ranked junior criminal defense barrister, according to a recent poll, and well up the ladder toward queen’s counsel because of his ability to win any case. But his invincible legal acrobatics backfire when a handshake denied sends his latest client, the reclusive bird lover, sadist and psychopath Liam Foyle (Toby Kebbell), into a rage — leaving Will, his wife (Ashley Jensen) and their son (Gus Barry) targets of his revenge. Enter Will’s professional nemesis, Maggie Gardner (Sophie Okonedo, fresh off a Tony victory for best supporting actress in a play for “A Raisin in the Sun”), frothing to overtake her rival. David Wolstencroft, the mastermind behind the BBC spy series “MI-5,” wrote this two-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” thriller, beginning Sunday night on PBS, which plumbs Will’s justification for his job in all its ramifications. “Everyone deserves a defense,” he maintains. Even he.

headline: Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Nearing an Offer for Alstom
text: Updated, 2:41 p.m. | FRANKFURT – Competition to acquire the French energy equipment maker Alstom was expected to intensify on Monday, as Siemens of Germany and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan were said to be preparing to make a joint offer that could pressure General Electric to improve its $13.5 billion bid.

headline: Moving Together, if Not in Unison

At one point, Mr. Miller recalled, “Matthew leaned over to me and said, ‘Man, if we wanted to, we could go out tonight and turn New York out, if we all got together.’ ”

headline: James Franco to Direct Play
text: James Franco, below, will soon add another occupation to his extensive cultural résumé when he makes his theatrical directorial debut for the premiere of “The Long Shrift” by the author Robert Boswell, presented as part of the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater’s coming 20th anniversary season. The play tells the story of a convict just released from jail who was accused of rape as a teenager. Performances at the Rattlestick are scheduled from July 7 to Aug. 23. Other world premieres in the 2014-15 season are “Pitbulls” by Keith Josef Adkins (“The Last Saint on Sugar Hill”), which is to run from Nov. 6 to Dec. 13, and “Shesh Yak” by Laith Nakli, scheduled for Jan. 15 to Feb. 19. The Rattlestick also announced that “Juárez: A Mythology Documentary” by Rubén Polendo, would be part of the second annual Theater: Village festival, in which a number of new works at West Village locations share a playwright or theme.

headline: Batting Leadoff, Granderson Helps Mets Beat Padres
text: During Saturday’s game, Mets Manager Terry Collins approached Curtis Granderson on the bench in the dugout and began asking him questions, like “Have you hit well out the leadoff spot before?” and “How have you felt up there?”

headline: Tony for Best Musical Is Nice, but a Profitable Hit Is Better
text: All winter and spring, the Broadway producer Joey Parnes wore his game face to the advertising meetings at 11:30 a.m. Wednesdays for his $7.5 million musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder.” The show was losing money most weeks, and his big bet — that the June 8 Tony Awards could be a game changer — was a ways off and hardly a sure thing.

headline: Subs
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a revealer here in Bruce Haight’s grid, but you might have to look for it. It’s at 11 Down, not a place where you might normally expect to find the punchline of the puzzle.

headline: Out of Desert Dust, a Miracle on a Shoestring
text: MECCA, Calif. — About an hour east of Palm Springs, past the Tesla and Maserati dealers and the poodle and labradoodle walkers, lies St. Anthony’s Trailer Park, in the eastern Coachella Valley. It is a vast psychic and economic distance from the annual spring hipster music festival. This Coachella is a place where farmworkers live in dilapidated mobile home parks improbably named after saints. These are communities where clean drinking water and reliable electricity are never givens, and where, during the rainy season, children wrap plastic bags around their sneakers to stay dry while parched desert turns to mud.

headline: Some New Games to Sink Your Claws Into
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the hardest things to do at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the annual video game trade show here, is actually to play video games. Even if you possess a media badge that lets you skip the long lines at the Los Angeles Convention Center, you’re often allowed only to watch a developer play a forthcoming game — or worse, watch a video pitch that highlights the concepts that the makers will try to execute over the next year or two. At times, it can feel like a book expo where you read only proposals or a film festival for screenplay treatments.

headline: The Other Veterans Scandal
text: WASHINGTON — THE Department of Veterans Affairs is mired in scandal. More than 57,000 veterans have been waiting at least three months for a doctor’s appointment. Another 64,000 never even made it onto a waiting list. There are allegations that waits for care either caused or contributed to veterans’ deaths.

headline: Among a Troupe’s New Works, a Battle ...
text: In the three years since Robert Battle became artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he has shown remarkable poise in balancing between boldness and cool calculation as he revamps a repertory long in need of renovation.

headline: ... And an Ostrich That Spreads Its Wings
text: One of the newest additions to Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s repertory is, in another sense, the oldest. Asadata Dafora choreographed “Awassa Astrige/Ostrich” in 1932, soon after moving to New York from his native Sierra Leone. On Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, Ailey became one of a handful of troupes to present this three-and-a-half-minute gem, with Antonio Douthit-Boyd as its majestic interpreter: part prowling warrior, part resplendent bird.

headline: Museum Power Squabble Borders on the Surreal
text: NORTH MIAMI, Fla. — In a somewhat bizarre arrangement, scholars gathered at the Museum of Contemporary Art here this weekend for a symposium led by a man whom city officials view as the museum’s director and who museum officials regard as an impostor. It was scheduled despite objections from the museum’s board, which ultimately gave up its effort to cancel the event inside the museum’s city-owned building.

headline: Racing by Snowmobile for Economic Survival in Michigan
text: Cool in tone and temperature, Nick Bentgen’s “Northern Light” turns white vistas and blue language into a sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

headline: France Leaves Scoring Struggles Behind in Its Opener
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — It was a rocky start to the World Cup in Porto Alegre.

headline: For Katie Couric, Shift to Web From TV Is Complete
text: After three decades of continuous work in television, Katie Couric has now officially moved on to what she is calling “my new chapter.”

headline: A Theme Park for Thomas Trains
text: A theme park based on the adventures of the popular children’s character Thomas the Tank Engine is to begin construction at Edaville USA Railroad in Carver, Mass., The Associated Press reported. The park, called Thomas Land, will have 14 rides inspired by characters in the British television show “Thomas & Friends,” which is broadcast on PBS in the United States. A 20-minute train ride on a life-size Thomas the Tank Engine is to be the park’s centerpiece when it opens in the summer of 2015.

headline: How We Play the Game
text: Every team plays in distinct ways. To understand their style, one must learn a bit about each country’s history.

headline: A Long Day’s Bach Journey, by Train, Foot and Ferry, With Cello
text: When two festivals combine to produce an event, you might expect it to be a big deal. And “A Suite Ride Through NYC,” which was presented on Friday by the Five Boroughs Music Festival but was also the opening program in the new Early Music Festival: NYC, was indeed big in many ways.

headline: London Welcomes the Tech Set and Its Money
text: LONDON – From hipster hangouts in East London to corporate headquarters in West London, the British capital will roll out the red carpet this week for many of the world’s leading tech entrepreneurs and investors.

headline: The True Cost of Hidden Money
text: GABRIEL ZUCMAN is a 27-year-old French economist who decided to solve a puzzle: Why do international balance sheets each year show more liabilities than assets, as if the world is in debt to itself?

headline: High-Scoring A’s Punish Yankees in a Matchup of Fill-In Starters
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees and the Oakland Athletics have both lost multiple starting pitchers to injury this season. In a matchup of replacements at the Coliseum on Sunday, the A’s gave another reason they have the best record in the American League.

headline: Kaymer, Leading All the Way, Wins by 8 for His First U.S. Open Title
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Martin Kaymer arrived at the first tee Sunday dressed appropriately for a methodical man with a modest, logical plan for the day.

headline: Device Maker Medtronic Agrees to Merger and Will Move to Ireland
text: Updated, 10:13 p.m. | Medtronic agreed on Sunday to buy Covidien for $42.9 billion, combining two of the world’s biggest medical device makers and helping Medtronic lower some taxes by gaining access to cash held overseas.

headline: Starbucks to Provide Free College Education to Thousands of Workers
text: Starbucks will provide a free online college education to thousands of its workers, without requiring that they remain with the company, through an unusual arrangement with Arizona State University, the company and the university will announce on Monday.

headline: Out of Power Almost 7 Years, Blair Is Still Haunted by a Legacy of War
text: LONDON — Twiggy Garcia, a part-time bartender, had talked with friends about making a citizen’s arrest if he ever got near Tony Blair, the former prime minister who led Britain into war in Iraq. But he never seriously imagined it happening.

headline: It’s Privacy vs. the People in the Battle for Martin’s Beach
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — The Pacific Ocean glistens in the distance, past the rolling bluffs that rise beyond the electric gate that blocks off Martin’s Beach Road. The road leads to Martin’s Beach, once a revered hideaway for surfers, fishers and beachgoers drawn by its isolation, dramatic cliffs and sweep of soft sand.

headline: Modern Cosmology Versus God’s Creation
text: This is the seventh in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Tim Maudlin, a professor of philosophy at New York University and the author of “Philosophy of Physics: Space and Time.”

headline: Eric Cantor’s Defeat Exposed a Beltway Journalism Blind Spot
text: It’s now clear why the primary defeat of the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, came so completely out of the blue last week: Beltway blindness that put a focus on fund-raising, power-brokering and partisan back-and-forth created a reality distortion field that obscured the will of the people.

headline: A Curious List of People Who Donated to the Central Park Zoo
text: Almost from the time Central Park opened in the late 1850s, prominent citizens pushed for the inclusion of an animal menagerie like those in London and Paris. Unsolicited donations quickly followed, from powerful men like the secretary of state for Abraham Lincoln and a 10-year-old boy with no ties to power or fame. Each animal and donor was listed in the park’s annual reports, including the report from 1866:

headline: Egyptian Police Confiscate Newsletter, Arrest Sign Holders and Close Grocery Stores
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian police over the weekend confiscated a human rights group’s newsletter, arrested two activists for a paper sign criticizing the police and shut down two Cairo grocery store chains that the police said had ties to the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Giving Life to Central Park Zoo, One Donation at a Time
text: The year was 1864, and a Manhattan hatter named Nicholas Espenscheid had come into possession of a spare nutria — the beaver-size water rat whose fur was used for hats.

headline: Thousands to Be Questioned on Eligibility for Health Insurance Subsidies
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is contacting hundreds of thousands of people with subsidized health insurance to resolve questions about their eligibility, as consumer advocates express concern that many will be required to repay some or all of the subsidies.

headline: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do for the Rangers
text: The N.H.L. playoffs are grueling, but the truly hard part for the Rangers comes now, as General Manager Glen Sather decides who will be back for another try at the Stanley Cup and who will be gone.

headline: With an Amazon Smartphone, the Retailer Seeks a Tether to Consumers
text: Hold the phone: Amazon wants to burrow even deeper into your life.

headline: Events in Iraq Open Door for Interventionist Revival, Historian Says
text: McLEAN, Va. — In a much-discussed essay, the historian Robert Kagan recently depicted President Obama as presiding over an inward turn by the United States that threatened the global order and broke with more than 70 years of American presidents and precedence. He called for Mr. Obama to resist a popular pull toward making the United States a nation without larger responsibilities, and to reassume the more muscular approach to the world out of vogue in Washington since the war in Iraq drained the country of its appetite for intervention.

headline: William M. Roth, Shipping Heir Who Became Lifelong Public Servant, Dies at 97
text: As the scion of a shipping empire, William Matson Roth grew up in a 43-room home with 16 acres of formal gardens. When his twin sisters made their debut at a ball there in 1939, The San Francisco Chronicle said they were “launched like luxury liners.”

headline: Yes He Could
text: Several times in recent weeks I’ve found myself in conversations with liberals who shake their heads sadly and express their disappointment with President Obama. Why? I suspect that they’re being influenced, often without realizing it, by the prevailing media narrative.

headline: Evacuating Children Along a Dangerous Ukraine Route
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — It was a trip no mother would wish to take. But faced with few options, a group of women and children piled into a blue minivan on a recent day to take to the dangerous road out of town on the way to a safer place.

headline: Dangerous Divisiveness
text: For an increasing number of Americans, the tenor of politics has reached a near-religious pitch, in which people on opposing ends of the ideological scale take on theological properties: good or evil, angels or demons, here to either save our way of life or destroy it.

headline: Worries Over Access to Free Public TV
text: Public television officials are raising the concern that the Federal Communications Commission’s planned spectrum incentive auction, intended to free airwaves for use by wireless broadband companies, could leave parts of the country without over-the-air public television access.

headline: Bank Tool Is Expanding Unbanked Households, Regulators Say
text: In her early college years, when Charlette Williams started routinely mismanaging her finances and pushing her checking account balance into the red, she never thought the mistakes would haunt her five years later, she said. Now, she is paying a steep price.

headline: Corporate Confidence Likely to Bring Pricier Deals
text: As companies feel bolder in making acquisitions this year, the price they are willing to pay seems likely to rise as well.

headline: A Cramped View of Antitrust Laws
text: American antitrust laws have protected consumers against monopolies and cartels for more than a century. But a recent appeals court decision could severely limit the enforcement of those laws against foreign cartels that supply critical components used in cellphones, computers and other products Americans buy.

headline: Ultra Violet, Warhol Superstar, Dies at 78
text: Isabelle Collin Dufresne, the French-born artist, actress and author known as Ultra Violet, the beauty among the superstars of Andy Warhol’s glory days at his studio, the Factory, died on Saturday at a Manhattan hospital. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan and in Nice, France.

headline: Despite a Shadow, Messi Shimmers in Argentina’s Cup Opener
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Lionel Messi can never be the man Argentina wants him to be, since that man is Diego Maradona, and in their eyes not even Messi — no matter what genius he conjures — will ever measure up to Maradona.

headline: How to Stabilize Iraq and Stop the March of ISIS
text: What can be done to stabilize Iraq and stop the gains from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria?

headline: Fighting Terrorism With More Money
text: If all goes according to President Obama’s plan, the United States will soon be making a major new investment of $5 billion so that other countries can help in the fight against extremists. Regardless of how sensible such a proposal might sound, many things can go wrong, and the new program already seems too heavily dependent on military responses.

headline: Agency Aims to Regulate Map Aids in Vehicles
text: Getting directions on the road from Google Maps and other smartphone apps is a popular alternative to the expensive navigation aids included in some cars. The apps are also a gray area when it comes to laws banning the use of cellphones or texting while driving.

headline: Why Hispanics Don’t Have a Larger Political Voice
text: Hispanic-Americans are growing in number, coveted by the nation’s political parties and deeply in favor of an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws. Given this combination, why does such an overhaul still seem to be such a long shot in Washington?

headline: In History-Making Event, Men and Women Share the Stage
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — On the Pinehurst No. 2 driving range Sunday, a teenage girl shyly approached Sergio García, who greeted her with a warm embrace. She walked away as if there were clouds beneath her feet.

headline: An Explosion in Washington
text: The timing could not have been more eerily ironic. On June 17, 1864, an official read a letter thanking the girls and women who worked at Washington’s federal arsenal for a donation to a monument for the 78 victims of a deadly 1862 arsenal blast in Pittsburgh. Then, just hours later, an explosion – like “a sudden flash of lightning,” in the words of one survivor – went off inside the arsenal’s 100-foot-long wooden laboratory.

headline: Never Boring, Always Beautiful
text: Some people party too soon. I was in Brazil in spring 2006, and Brazil was in a festive mood. The World Cup in Germany was on the way, and Brazilians, rightly convinced they had the best team, were already celebrating their triumph. At one public event, I said: “Just calm down, please. Italy is going to win this one.” The audience chortled, saying: “Come on. Italian soccer is in the midst of its biggest scandal ever. Two championship titles have been revoked. The players are in shock, and the clubs are in disgrace!” That’s why, I said.

headline: Where Prose Turned to Poetry
text: In Brazil, soccer was initially played among elite clubs behind closed doors. Blacks were excluded.
