Outside the confines of formal championships, however, the sport was quickly taken up as a game played in abandoned lots, meadows and urban gaps. Balls were improvised, fields were improvised, and the game was fertile ground for the spirit of improvisation.

headline: Life Sentences for 2 Sex Traffickers Who Preyed on Mexican Immigrants
text: It was a sprawling family business, employing drivers, dispatchers and doormen. There were “steerers” who passed out “chica” cards on the street to solicit customers. There was even a mechanic who swept vehicles for tracking devices that might have been surreptitiously placed by federal agents, prosecutors said.

headline: How We Play the Game
text: Every team is simply trying to score goals while preventing its opponent from doing the same. But they all seem to go about it in distinct ways. To understand what is happening on the fields in Brazil at the World Cup, one must learn a bit about each country’s history, and literature, and music, and regionalism, and economy — not to mention bicycles and pottery.

headline: A Boy’s Execution, 70 Years Later
text: On the first page of the official sentencing report for George Stinney Jr., the outline of a boy is visible in a short string of numbers. Age: 14. Height: 5-1. Weight: 95. His complexion is listed as Black, his religion as Baptist, his occupation as None. Next to Build one word is typed: Small.

headline: A Smartphone Keyboard App That Anticipates What You Want to Type
text: LONDON — Typing on the glass of a smartphone can be a headache. The keyboards are tiny. Errors are easy to make, even on the simplest of words. And autocorrect, the function meant to fix typing mistakes, often introduces errors, switching words that have little to do with what people actually mean.

headline: V.A. Punished Critics on Staff, Doctors Assert
text: WASHINGTON — Staff members at dozens of Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals across the country have objected for years to falsified patient appointment schedules and other improper practices, only to be rebuffed, disciplined or even fired after speaking up, according to interviews with current and former staff members and internal documents.

headline: Artificial Pancreas Shows Promise in Diabetes Test
text: A portable artificial pancreas built with a modified iPhone successfully regulated blood sugar levels in a trial with people who have Type 1 diabetes, researchers reported Sunday.

headline: A Nemesis in the Black Stars
text: NATAL, Brazil — For more than two days straight here in this beach town in northeastern Brazil, the rain came down with the strength of an open fire hose. It shook the cashew trees and bent the palm trees so that their fronds nearly kissed the ground. It turned roads into rivers, caused mudslides and turned some neighborhood soccer fields into ponds.

headline: Senate Panel Examines Stock Market, and Fed Moves Closer to End of Stimulus Program
text: SENATE HEARING TO EXAMINE STRUCTURE OF STOCK MARKET

headline: Colombian President Re-elected After a Race Challenging His Peace Negotiations
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Voters elected President Juan Manuel Santos to a second term on Sunday, giving him a chance to complete peace negotiations with rebel groups that could end decades of guerrilla war.

headline: Population Shifts Turning All Politics National
text: SOUTHAVEN, Miss. — When William E. Davis was growing up here in DeSoto County, just across the state line from Memphis, there were more than 300 dairy farms, and he was raised on one of them.

headline: 2 Deals Focus on Big Data and Youth
text: A COUPLE of deals are shining a spotlight on just how big of a deal big data is becoming on Madison Avenue.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 16
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: New York Adoptees Fight for Access to Birth Certificates
text: Maureen Sheridan’s search for her biological mother began in the late 1990s, after she had a precancerous mole removed and her doctor suggested she look into her medical history. That research led her to the New York Public Library, where in 2001, sifting through a vast trove of vital records, Ms. Sheridan discovered the name she had been given at birth: Beth Lyons.

headline: Louisville Brings the Heat and the Funk
text: OMAHA — The entrance lacked drama and everything else Nick Burdi imagined.

headline: Methodist Church Pension Board Links Divestment to Firm’s Role in Israeli Prisons
text: A decision by the pension board of the United Methodist Church to sell its stock in a company that provides security equipment to Israel has set off a backlash from supporters of Israel, who are gearing up for another fight over divestment this week at the convention of another mainline Protestant denomination, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.).

headline: The United Nations of the Hardwood
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Spurs played seamlessly through all five games of the N.B.A. finals, moving the ball from player to player, from corner to corner, all their effortless teamwork earning them their fifth N.B.A. championship in 16 seasons.

headline: Her Heart Didn’t Belong to Daddy (or the Prince)
text: Despite the teeth-baring title, the tone is mostly cool and considered in “Pat Kirkwood Is Angry,” a spellbinding cabaret show at the 59E59 Theaters written by and starring the gifted singer Jessica Walker. The titular actress, portrayed by Ms. Walker, was a British star probably unknown to most Americans. Her up-and-down career included glittery stints in the West End, steep plunges into the panto circuit when things got tough, a brief stay in Hollywood that sent her to a sanitarium and, most spectacularly, a festive night with a royal that made her a figure of scandal for decades.

headline: New York City Street Treasure
text: Dear Diary:

headline: With Offensive Bonanza, Spurs Force the Heat to Consider Taking Fewer Gambles
text: SAN ANTONIO — Lost in the sweatbox of the N.B.A. finals opener, amid cramps and complaints about the failed air-conditioning system at AT&T Center, was a road map for how the rest of this series would turn.

headline: Popular Demand
text: “Frozen,” released last November, is the second-highest-grossing 2013 film after adjusting for inflation, surpassed only by “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” — and it is still in theaters. “Despicable Me 2,” even without a hit song, was No. 4, and “Monsters University” ranked sixth.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale: Sibel Kekilli Takes Home an Odd Souvenir
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s season finale of “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Success Academy’s Expansion Plans Put de Blasio in a Tough Spot
text: A charter school network’s plan   to double in size over the next few years could reignite a war over classroom space in New York City, only this time with the ground rules already tilted against the mayor.

headline: Dispute Over Judges Leaves Family Courts in Limbo
text: In a drab waiting area on the fifth floor of Manhattan Family Court, a 6-year-old boy danced among the wooden benches and two strangers wrangled over custody schedules as Natasha, 39, stared plaintively at a closed courtroom door.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 15, 2014
Spurs Win Fifth Title, Cementing Dynasty Across Decades
text: SAN ANTONIO — The arena rumbled. It was only the first half on Sunday night, but there was already a growing sense of inevitability with each passing possession. Having withstood the best that LeBron James could offer, the Spurs were closing in on another championship.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: Please, Hurry Up and Kill the Bird
text: Season 1, Episode 3: This show has lost the plot. In the span of a single episode, “Halt And Catch Fire” has descended from a fairly enjoyable melodrama about the dawn of the personal computing industry into a writhing mess. This third episode was a tossed-salad of seeming arbitrary stabs at character development; everyone does something a little weird, shocking, or apparently deep, but little of it adds to a sense of who these people are or what on earth they’re trying to do.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: It’s a Bloody Father’s Day
text: Season 1, Episode 6: Happy bloody Father’s Day here on “Penny Dreadful.” The episode picks up with Vanessa and Sir Malcolm surveying the carnage left by their demonic visitor in Episode 4. But it’s impossible not to view what happens in “What Death Can Join Together” – and what led up to it – through the prism of the full-length flashback that made up the previous episode. (As with previous weeks, spoilers are sprinkled throughout.)

headline: Unexpected, Unplanned and Unwanted
text: When her second son was born, six weeks premature, Emily Guillermo recalled thinking, “You’re not supposed to be mine. You were not supposed to be made.”

headline: ‘Thinking of Ways to Harm Her’
text: Postpartum depression isn’t always postpartum. It isn’t even always depression. A fast-growing body of research is changing the very definition of maternal mental illness, showing that it is more common and varied than previously thought.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 16, 2014
text: “I don’t know if you call it a problem or a weakness, but it’s clear that the American nature is to try and make everything fair, to try and be fair to the game.”

headline: In Fez, a Restaurant Starring the Finest Chefs in the World
text: Deep in the hive-like medina (old city) of Fez, Morocco, one of the world’s most beautiful restaurants has just reopened as a venue for an intriguing new visiting-chef-in-residence project that casts the kitchen as an incubator for both cultural exchange and culinary innovation.

headline: Steering Clear of Poison Ivy
text: I was once among those who claim, “I could walk through a field of poison ivy and not get it.” One day I learned otherwise: On a hike, I needed to relieve myself in the great outdoors and ended up with an impossibly itchy, blistering rash on a most delicate body part.

headline: Word of the Day | irretrievable
text: irretrievable •\ˌir-i-ˈtre-və-bəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 8 P.M. (FXX) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier. Rooney Mara, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery in this adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by David Fincher. “She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Lisbeth, first played by Noomi Rapace in the 2010 Swedish adaptation. “It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories.” And “despite the slick intensity of Mr. Fincher’s style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism,” Mr. Scott said. Still, he added, “Mr. Fincher’s impressive skill is evident.”

headline: First True Test, and a Noticeable Gaffe, for Goal-Line Technology
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — Goal-line technology was put to its first serious use at the World Cup on Sunday in the 48th minute of France’s match with Honduras.

headline: Outrage After Pencil-Chewing Is Blamed for Lead Poisoning
text: The dangerous levels of pollution in a village in Hunan Province have been well known for some time, but after a Chinese state television investigation and a particularly callous remark by one local official, the authorities have begun taking action.

headline: James, Even at His Best, Can’t Carry the Heat to the Finish
text: SAN ANTONIO — Miami’s LeBron James sat on a trainer’s table an hour before tipoff, his eyes closed, his headphones on as he sang to himself, his back rested squarely against a wall.

headline: Corrections: June 16, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Three Sentenced to Death Over Tiananmen Attack
text: A Chinese court sentenced three men to death on Monday for their roles in carrying out an attack near the entrance to Beijing’s Forbidden City in October that left six people dead and 39 injured, in what the police said was a terrorist act carried out by Islamic jihadists belonging to the Uighur ethnic minority.

headline: China Surpasses U.S. as Largest Corporate Debt Issuer
text: HONG KONG — China has overtaken the United States as the world’s biggest issuer of corporate debt, despite worsening cash flow at Chinese companies since the financial crisis, according to a report released Monday by Standard & Poor’s.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Wind and dust, not flame and steel’
text: This poem, by Ibante S., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest.

headline: Father’s Day Plea to Educate China’s ‘Illegal’ Children
text: Father’s Day is an imported concept that not all Chinese are comfortable with, but the news media celebrated on Sunday with photographs of new fathers and, in a display of filial piety, children thanking dads by scrubbing their feet.

headline: Mota-Engil Africa Plans I.P.O. Amid Flurry of London Offerings
text: LONDON — Mota-Engil Africa, a subsidiary of the Portuguese conglomerate Mota-Engil, said on Monday that it planned to list an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange, the latest in what has been a rush of offerings in London.

headline: Coast Town Is Attacked in Kenya; Dozens Die
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least 48 people were killed when dozens of militants attacked a Kenyan coastal town overnight, targeting a police station and two hotels, officials said Monday.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Unrest in Iraq
text: In “Obama Pushes Iraqis to Mend Sectarian Rifts,” Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon write about the U.S. reaction to recent events in Iraq and the unrest there.

headline: Student Crossword | Ancient Egypt
text: Test your knowledge of ancient Egypt by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Echoes of Africa Along the Carolina Coast
text: Africa endures in the language and customs of the Gullah people, descendants of slaves who have lived along the Carolina coast for generations, sustaining themselves through the land and water.  Pete Marovich, who grew up in South Carolina aware of this distinctive culture, wanted to photograph these communities, so about a decade ago he pitched the idea to a magazine editor.

headline: Atos of France to Spin Off Its Payments Unit in I.P.O.
text: LONDON — The French computer services provider Atos announced on Monday that it was spinning off its electronic payments unit in an initial public offering that could value the business at up to 2.4 billion euros, or $3.2 billion.

headline: Gazprom Cuts Russia’s Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Further aggravating already tense relations between Russia and Ukraine, the Russian energy giant Gazprom cut off natural gas supplies to its neighbor on Monday, warning that the reduction could diminish the amount of gas flowing to Europe.

headline: Britain’s Mitchells & Butlers to Acquire 173 Pubs
text: LONDON – Mitchells & Butlers, Britain’s largest operator of managed pubs and restaurants, said on Monday that it would acquire the bulk of Orchid Group, including 173 pubs, for about $451 million.

headline: Israel Demands Palestinian Leader’s Help After Abductions
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Monday that he expected his help in finding three kidnapped Israeli teenagers and capturing their abductors. The telephone conversation, initiated by Mr. Abbas, came after Israeli troops killed a Palestinian man overnight as they continued an aggressive campaign across the West Bank, arresting a total of 150 people, most of them leaders of the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Test Time
text: Good sunny Monday morning to you.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Unrest Boils Over in Sri Lanka
text: ALUTHGAMA, Sri Lanka — In some of the worst religious violence in Sri Lanka in decades, three people have been killed and 78 injured in riots between Buddhists and Muslims in this southwestern coastal town after months of rising tensions, officials said Monday.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: Season 4 Finale
text: Here be spoilers, and the end of our watch … for now.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon Seeks Tighter Hold on Shoppers Through a Phone
text: Amazon is expected to introduce a smartphone on Wednesday at an event in Seattle, a long-rumored project that aims to close any remaining gap between the impulse to buy and the completed act, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: In London, the Men’s Wear Revels Begin
text: That green juice, the sip choice in New York, has reached London was only one of the takeaways of a late lunch on Saturday, held in honor of the London men’s wear designer Craig Green. A fruit-and-veg concoction was passed around at Hoi Polloi, the restaurant at the Ace Hotel in the designer-heavy Shoreditch, but it was only one green offering of many: The theme of the lunch (and its official hashtag) was “Eat Your Craig Greens,” and each course — soup, salad and supper — was a rhapsody in that color.

headline: Alibaba Clarifies Leadership Structure as I.P.O. Approaches
text: Updated, 9:00 p.m. | The Alibaba Group, China’s biggest e-commerce company, is continuing to slowly reveal more about its operations.

headline: The Trouble With Apple’s Health App
text: Earlier this month, Apple made news with the introduction of Health, an iPhone app that will allow users to collect biometric information like heart rate and blood pressure and send it automatically to doctors or hospitals. The company also announced a partnership with Epic Systems, one of the largest suppliers of electronic medical record systems in the United States. This has led many to speculate that a new age is upon us, with patients having much greater access to health information, as well as the ability to share it with their doctors.

headline: Definition of ‘Rich’ Changes With Income
text: “Congratulations, Joe! You’re rich!” John McCain said to Joe Wurzelbacher in the 2008 presidential campaign. Joe was thinking of buying a small plumbing business. He was dismayed to learn from Barack Obama that the candidate’s plan to raise marginal tax rates on individuals earning more than $200,000 a year was described as “taxing the rich.”

headline: J.W. Anderson: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: London

headline: UGL of Australia to Sell Property Management Arm for $1.15 Billion
text: LONDON – The Australian engineering services company UGL said on Monday that it had agreed to sell the property management business DTZ to a consortium of investors, including the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and the private equity firms TPG Capital and PAG Asia Capital, in a deal that values the business at 1.22 billion Australian dollars, or about $1.15 billion.

headline: What Makes a Great Editor? Part I.
text: “I am not the editor of a newspaper and shall always try to do right and be good so that God will not make me one.”

headline: Grocery Delivery Service Instacart Raises $44 Million
text: Companies like Uber and Airbnb have prospered by allowing people to sell their services to strangers on a smartphone-powered network.

headline: Morning Views
text: “If all goes according to President Obama’s plan, the United States will soon be making a major new investment of $5 billion so that other countries can help in the fight against extremists,” writes The New York Times editorial board. The goal is to scale back American involvement in combatting terrorism by funding and equipping foreign counterterrorism operations. The Times is skeptical: “As Iraq demonstrates, just training troops to shoot and providing generals with expensive weapons will not address the threat.”

headline: Start-Up WeLab Raises $14 Million From Sequoia Capital and Hong Kong Tycoon
text: HONG KONG – WeLab Holdings, an Internet finance start-up in Hong Kong, said on Monday that it had raised $14 million from Li Ka-shing, Asia’s richest man, and Sequoia Capital, a stalwart of Silicon Valley.

headline: In Our Pages: June 17
text: 1889: Improving Africa

headline: Summer 2014 on The Learning Network
text: As we do every year, we’ll be scaling back our offerings a bit this summer in order to make time for planning and experimentation.

headline: PAI Partners Plans Joint Venture to Control Labeyrie Fine Foods
text: LONDON — The European private equity firm PAI Partners said on Monday that it was moving forward in its effort to acquire a stake in the gourmet food producer Labeyrie Fine Foods.

headline: Hillshire Lays Out Path to End Its Deal With Pinnacle Foods
text: Hillshire Brands said on Monday that its board would no longer back its planned $4.3 billion takeover of Pinnacle Foods, paving the way for the company to sell itself to Tyson Foods for $7.7 billion.

headline: My Biggest Failure? Failing to Recognize Failure
text: Anyone who has picked up a business book, attended a panel discussion or read an entrepreneurship blog in the past several years has probably learned about the virtues of “failing fast.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba’s Inner Circle Revealed
text: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group on Monday publicly disclosed the names of all 27 individuals who will make up the company’s select inner circle in an amended initial public offering prospectus, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The individuals, led by a company founder, Jack Ma, will essentially control the online market operator through their ability to nominate a majority of directors.

headline: Level 3 to Buy TW Telecom for $5.7 Billion
text: Level 3 Communications said on Monday that it had agreed to buy TW Telecom, a provider of business Internet connections, for about $5.68 billion, as consolidation continues in the telecommunications industry.

headline: Airbus and Safran Plan to Merge Satellite Launch Activity
text: PARIS — The Airbus Group and Safran of France plan to merge their satellite launching activities into a new company that aims to better compete against lower-cost rivals from Russia and the United States.

headline: SanDisk to Buy Fusion-io for $1.1 Billion in Cash
text: The SanDisk Corporation said on Monday that it would buy the data storage provider Fusion-io for $1.1 billion.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Agi & Sam Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Executive Editor of The New York Times Is Treated for Cancer
text: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The New York Times, had a malignant tumor removed from his kidney on Saturday and will spend about a week away from the office while recovering, he said in an email to the newspaper’s staff on Monday morning.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Situation in Iraq Worsens
text: Good Monday morning. President Obama is returning from Southern California today to a Washington heat wave and a Middle East crisis.

headline: Modi Underscores Ties to Bhutan in First Foreign Visit
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian prime minister Narendra Modi concluded a two-day visit to Bhutan on Monday afternoon, making the tiny landlocked country nestled toward the eastern end of the Himalayas his first stop on his foreign policy tour.

headline: Insurgents in North Ambush Militia Volunteers and Seize Another City
text: BAGHDAD — The Sunni extremist militants threatening Iraq seized another northern city on Monday in a battle with the Iraqi Army after having ambushed a convoy of untrained Shiite volunteers in the first lethal encounter between Sunni and Shiite combatants since the government began mobilizing thousands of Shiites.

headline: In Battle Over Allergan, Morgan Stanley Gets in the Crossfire
text: In its quest to defend against a $53 billion hostile takeover, Allergan pulled back the veil on the usually secretive world of mergers and acquisitions banking on Monday.

headline: Should Modeling Be Treated Like Driving, or Drinking?
text: There’s a very good piece on the Terry Richardson is-he-a-sexual-predator-or-not scandal in this week’s New York magazine. I think it’s worth reading not simply because it lays out a very hot-button issue fairly dispassionately, but because it also highlights one of the problems with modeling that is related to the recent skinny-models controversy, yet may actually be more essential than both: namely, the young-models problem.

headline: Argentina’s Debt Appeal Is Rejected by Supreme Court
text: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | The Supreme Court handed Argentina two major defeats on Monday in cases brought by bondholders who refused to accept reduced payments after the country’s 2001 default.

headline: Opening Ceremony Collaborates with Fashion’s Favorite Florist
text: The Brussels-based florist Thierry Boutemy has decorated the runways of Lanvin and Dries Van Noten and the halls of Versailles for Sofia Coppola’s “Marie Antoinette.” Now he’s lending his darkly romantic aesthetic to Opening Ceremony for a range of capsule collections — including Opening Ceremony clothing, Manolo Blahnik shoes and a fragrance made in conjunction with Le Labo — which go on sale today at the brand’s stores and online. Working with the Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, Boutemy created still lifes — from artfully smashed petals to lavish arrangements of blue roses, dahlias and delphiniums — which were then photographed and translated into a vibrant series of digital prints. The scent, meanwhile, was formulated to capture what Boutemy calls “the permanent feeling of walking in a perfectly arranged mad and wild garden.”

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Eliza Griswold on the Roots of Extremism, Boko Haram and the Weight of Public Opinion
text: Eliza Griswold wrote the June 15 cover story about U.S. Special Operations forces in Africa. She is the author of “The Tenth Parallel: Dispatches From the Fault Line Between Christianity and Islam” and a book of poetry.

headline: 21st-Century Concentration Camps
text: Nicholas Kristof travels to Myanmar, where Muslims are confined to camps or within their own villages, deprived of jobs, schools and doctors. Why is the world silent?

headline: Myanmar’s Persecuted Minority
text: A collection of stories from a recent trip focusing on a Muslim minority who are confined to camps and villages. UPDATED June 20: Nicholas Kristof responds to readers’ questions.

headline: Another Factor Said to Sway Judges to Rule for Women’s Rights: A Daughter
text: WASHINGTON — It was, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg later said, “such a delightful surprise.”

headline: In Drive Against Militants, Pakistani Airstrikes Hit Strongholds
text: LONDON — As a full Pakistani military offensive in the tribal district of North Waziristan took shape on Monday, commanders promised a crushing blow to the jihadi groups that have flourished there in the past decade, spreading chaos in the region and posing a security threat to the West.

headline: Pop Music to Get Its Due on BBC Awards Show
text: Evidently in the belief that the entertainment industry does not have sufficient opportunity to pat itself on the back, the BBC announced on Monday that it would present the inaugural BBC Music Awards at a live ceremony at Earl’s Court, in London, on Dec. 11.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Lou Dalton Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: Food Curated | Zucker Bakery’s Cookies
text: Inside Zucker Bakery in the East Village, where Zohar Zohar, the owner and head baker, creates cookies and pastries that incorporate the flavors of Israel and other countries.

headline: Video: Zucker Bakery’s Cookies
text: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: Cruises With Unesco Sites as Destinations
text: The small-ship cruise line Seabourn has tied virtual mooring lines to Unesco in a new program that offers increased access to the organization’s diverse World Heritage sites such as Avignon, France, the Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland and Peterhof Palace in St. Petersburg.

headline: A Long Way From Wonder Bread
text: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. — Pam Ross showed up at Ponsford’s Place Bakery & Innovation Center at 5 p.m. sharp, just minutes after the owner, Craig Ponsford, put out the sidewalk “bread man” sculpture that alerts customers: Pizza night is on.

headline: Germany vs. Portugal: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Loaded with talent, Germany is a contender to win it all, as it is at almost every World Cup. Portugal is increasingly regarded as a one-man team. But that man is Cristiano Ronaldo, who is the reigning world player of the year. Expect Germany to swarm him with defenders.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Dunhill Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Measuring Recovery? Count the Employed, Not the Unemployed
text: South Carolina’s unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent in April, lower than in December 2007, when it stood at 5.5 percent on the eve of the Great Recession.

headline: Rise of the Internet Hate Machine
text: Welcome to the age of Internet hate, when “it’s never been easier to send an anonymous death threat,” writes Jack Shafer for Reuters. “As with so many of life’s labors, advanced technology has removed most of the work and hazard from sending cowardly messages to people to frighten them.”

headline: Stir-fried Broccoli Stalks and Flowers, Red Peppers, Peanuts and Tofu
text: Probably most of you have used broccoli time and again in stir-fries. In this version I cut the stalks into 2-inch julienne, which is almost like adding a separate vegetable to the mix of broccoli flowers and red pepper (also cut in julienne). There’s a lot of texture at play here – crisp-tender vegetables, crunchy peanuts and soft tofu. You can add a little spice if you want, but I’ve made the chili flakes optional.

headline: Pan-Fried Broccoli Stems
text: This was an experiment and now it is a keeper. Peel broccoli stems, slice them thin, and pan-fry in hot oil just until the slices are charred on the edges, then flip over and brown for just a little bit of time on the other side. If you do this just right, the medallions will have edges that are slightly crispy with that wonderful fried flavor, and tender interiors. With a little salt (or even without) they are irresistible. One stem’s worth of medallions will disappear quickly, so count on 1 per person (at least!). Although you will use a fair amount of oil for frying, it doesn’t all get absorbed by the broccoli stems.

headline: Pre-Summer Greek Salad With Shaved Broccoli and Peppers or Beets
text: Classic Greek salad is a summer dish in my house; impossible to make if tomatoes are not in season and wonderful. But other vegetables take to the same treatment – a simple dressing with a high ratio of acid (in this case a combination of lemon juice and vinegar with olive oil), feta cheese and lots of mint and parsley.

headline: Pasta With Mushrooms and Broccoli
text: Broccoli stems and flowers can be prepared and cooked separately, like two different vegetables. For this pasta I used a vegetable peeler to shred the broccoli stems into thin ribbons, which I cooked briefly with the mushrooms. I sliced the crowns very thin and blanched them briefly with the pasta. The result is a dish with different textures and shades of green: the stems should be crisp-tender, their color faded. The crowns will be bright green, and 2 to 2 1/2 minutes cooking will render them tender but not mushy.

headline: ScienceTake | Secrets of the Bat Wing
text: The spectacular flight of bats may be aided by long, thin muscles in the skin of their wings.

headline: Spring Rolls With Shredded Broccoli Stems, Vermicelli and Red Pepper
text: Lately I’ve been finding bags of shredded broccoli stems or broccoli stem slaw in supermarkets. I used just such a bag for this. You can grate the stems that come with your bunch broccoli for these, or you can save a bit of time and effort by buying the bagged product.

headline: New Insight Into How Bats Conquer the Air
text: Bats are an extraordinary evolutionary success, the only mammals to conquer the air. Their flying ability has long attracted the attention of engineers and biologists, and it comes through soft, flexible wings unlike those of birds or insects.

headline: Medtronic-Covidien Deal Is a Marriage of Convenience
text: The marriage of Medtronic and Covidien looks to be one of convenience. The $42.9 billion deal includes a premium that exceeds the estimated cost savings. Stents and sutures are not an obvious fit. And moving Medtronic’s headquarters from Minneapolis to Covidien’s Dublin base will not obviously cut the American company’s tax bill. Freeing up overseas cash is too shallow a reason to tie the knot.

headline: Tony Gwynn, Hall of Fame Batting Champion, Dies at 54 of Cancer
text: Tony Gwynn, who won a record eight National League batting championships, amassed 3,141 hits and gained acclaim as one of baseball’s most passionate students of the art of hitting, died on Monday in Poway, Calif. He was 54.

headline: Aftermath of a Militant Attack in Kenya
text: Scenes from Mpeketoni, where militants attacked a police station and two hotels, according to officials.

headline: Microsoft Unveils Machine Learning for the Masses
text: Microsoft has a new strategy to win cloud business: A supposedly comprehensive predictive analysis service — and all you have to do is store your data in Azure, the Microsoft cloud.

headline: Col. George Sicherman’s Dice
text: Our challenge this week is a classic by recreational mathematician Col. George Sicherman, who hit upon the insight in 1977. The resulting Sicherman Dice are a curiosity known to pretty much anyone who’s spent some time with recreational math. I reached Col. Sicherman by phone and asked him — How did he even think to look for something no one else had even considered?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Webrooming’ Versus ‘Showrooming’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Former Medtronic C.E.O. Defends Inversion Deal
text: Bill George, a former chief executive of the medical device maker Medtronic, came out last month against Pfizer’s proposed inversion – a deal to acquire an overseas competitor and reincorporate abroad, lowering tax rates and freeing up overseas cash.

headline: Alibaba Drops In to Say Hi to Institutional Investors in U.S.
text: The Alibaba Group is not expected to begin a formal road show with prospective investors in its upcoming initial public offering for at least a month.

headline: True Appreciation of These Spurs Will Come
text: Suffering is good. It reinforces character, resolve and commitment. Experienced in public, it exposes vulnerability. Handled with class, it heightens likability.

headline: Schumacher, Out of Coma, Leaves French Hospital
text: Michael Schumacher, the former Formula One champion, has left the hospital in Grenoble, France, where he was admitted with brain injuries nearly six months ago, to “continue his long phase of rehabilitation.” He is “no longer in a coma,” his family announced in a statement Monday.

headline: China Executes 13 in Xinjiang Region After Attacks
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government executed 13 people in the Xinjiang region on Monday, part of an intensifying response to growing violence in the region that is spreading to other parts of the country.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Penalties for Gay Themes
text: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina upheld a budget item requiring two universities to spend $70,000 to teach United States founding documents — as punishment for having assigned gay-themed books to freshmen last year.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: Image of the Day: June 16
text: A scene from a paddy field on the outskirts of Amritsar, Punjab.

headline: Justice Dept. Takes Hard Look at G.M.’s Handling of Issues
text: The Justice Department is taking a hard look at who should be held accountable when it comes to the General Motors debacle.

headline: Crafts Retailer Michaels Stores Aims to Raise $500 Million in I.P.O.
text: The crafts retailer Michaels Stores may be nearing the end of its long journey to the public markets.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Audi Works Hard for 13th Le Mans Win
text: Audi won the 24 Hours of Le Mans on Sunday for the 13th time in the last 15 years, with its diesel-electric hybrid R18 e-tron quattros finishing one-two ahead of a field of exhausted rivals. The winning Audi entry, for the third time in four years, was shared by Benoît Tréluyer of France, André Lotterer of Germany and Marcel Fässler of Switzerland.

headline: A Faster Way to Find the Origin of Malaria
text: By using a DNA “bar code” of 23 short snips from the genes of parasites that cause malaria, scientists can now often quickly determine where they originated, British researchers report.

headline: Siemens and Mitsubishi Counteroffer for Alstom Is Less Than G.E.’s Bid
text: Updated, 5:12 p.m. | PARIS — Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries formally presented a counteroffer for Alstom on Monday in an attempt to assuage French fears about losing one of its most important companies, even as their combined bid was less than what General Electric had proposed.

headline: A Merger in a Race With Congress
text: Why does Medtronic want Covidien?

headline: At the London Men’s Wear Shows, Exuberance Reigns
text: LONDON — As the men’s wear shows here finish up their second day, it’s hard not to be struck by three things that almost every show so far has shared in common: the size of the crowds, the energy in the rooms and the youthfulness of the attendees who jam into their seats or line the back walls, craning for a look at the fashion on exuberant display.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: London

headline: Bitcoin Security Firm BitGo Raises $12 Million
text: The Bitcoin security platform BitGo announced on Monday that it had raised $12 million, the latest example of how investors see opportunity in a growing industry aimed at making virtual currency easier and safer to use.

headline: U.S. Is Exploring Talks With Iran on Crisis in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — A senior American diplomat met with his Iranian counterpart in Vienna on Monday to explore whether the United States and Iran could work together to create a more stable Iraqi government and ease the threat from Sunni militants.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Daniel Ahiakpor joined the New York office of Vdopia in a new post, vice president for business development. He had been senior director and head of publisher platform sales at Adap.tv, New York, part of AOL.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: S.E.C. Fines Hedge Fund in Demotion of Whistle-Blowing Employee
text: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Securities and Exchange Commission has sounded a warning to Wall Street and corporate America, taking aim at a hedge fund not only for improper trading but for punishing the employee who blew the whistle on the wrongdoing.

headline: The Wisdom of Breaking Away
text: In February 2012, a group of experienced skiers headed into the backcountry near the Stevens Pass resort in Washington State to look for untracked powder. It was a beautiful day, and everyone expected to have a great time skiing the popular Tunnel Creek section.

headline: For the ‘Fargo’ Finale, Many Unanswered Questions
text: Two weeks ago, a very pregnant Molly Solverson and her sleepy postman husband, Gus Grimly, cozied up in bed, a sublime scene of domestic tranquillity amid all the violence and trouble that has coursed through the episodes of FX’s “Fargo.”

headline: A Mother’s Anguish, a History of Violent Crime and Rocks That Ring
text: A woman’s suicide sheds light on maternal mental illness; a vast database of trial transcripts from the Old Bailey Courthouse in London helps historians figure out when British justice shifted from brutal to civilized; researchers discover the hidden musical qualities of Stonehenge.

headline: ‘Frida Kahlo’s Garden’ to Sprout in New York City
text: “I paint flowers so they will not die,” Frida Kahlo once said, and in her paintings as well as her life, flora of many varieties – flowers, trees, roots, tendrils, watermelon, cactus fruit – took on an almost supernatural presence. Next year the New York Botanical Garden will explore her obsession with the vegetable world in “Frida Kahlo’s Garden,” an exhibition that will include not only rarely seen paintings by Kahlo but also a re-creation of her studio and garden at Casa Azul in the Coyoacán neighborhood of Mexico City, where she lived for many years and where she died in 1954.

headline: Thanks to Ad Agency, You’re in the Picture at Museum Exhibition
text: An agency known for its creativity has developed an interactive installation for an exhibition at a museum that is devoted to an artist known for his creativity.

headline: Gazprom Cuts Gas to Ukraine
text: A Gazprom spokesman, Sergei Kupriyanov, explained the Russian gas giant’s action to stop supplying natural gas to Ukraine.

headline: Blast From the Past: No Digital Technology for Beatles LPs in Mono
text: Many fans of the Beatles, including the group’s producer, George Martin, and the band members themselves, have long argued that the most authentic way to hear the group’s music is in the original mono mixes. Those were the band’s principal focus during recording and mixing sessions, and they sometimes differ strikingly from the now more familiar stereo versions.

headline: Sex, Drugs and G.D.P.
text: Help me out here.

headline: James Long: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: London

headline: I.R.S. Commissioner to Testify on Ex-Official’s Lost Emails
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service commissioner will testify before two House committees next week about the agency’s disclosure that it lost thousands of emails sought by investigators looking into accusations of politically motivated misconduct by the agency, the committees said Monday.

headline: Met Opera Tax Filing Reveals Pay For Gelb
text: The Metropolitan Opera, which is seeking concessions from its workers amid tough labor talks, reported in a tax filing on Monday that its general manager, Peter Gelb, had earned a total of $1.8 million in pay and benefits in 2012 — but said that he had since taken a pay cut.

headline: MyCopter Simulator
text: This video from the University of Liverpool demonstrates the myCopter, a personal helicopter being developed in the United Kingdom.

headline: Popcast: Jimmy Giuffre and Eric Dolphy, Rediscovered Jazz Innovators
text: The saxophonist Jimmy Giuffre, who died in 2008 at the age of 86, was often out of step with jazz, even after he wrote the swing anthem “Four Brothers” for Woody Herman’s band in 1947 and led the Jimmy Giuffre 3, a late-’50s, drummer-less group that created cultural weight out of light-toned music. He started new groups that got away from swing rhythm and other conventions of jazz; his searches made him fall out of favor with audiences, and after the 1962 album “Free Fall,” he released no new records for 10 years.

headline: Whose Dress Code Is It, and Why?
text: The dress code — for girls, at least — has become a complicated issue. Is it intended to protect the girls against unwanted advances, or the boys against temptation? If the intent is to foster an atmosphere conducive to learning, why would spaghetti straps interfere with an understanding of algebraic equations? Does demanding that young women disregard the siren song of advertising and the media and leave the midriff-baring tops on the racks teach them that they are worth more than their appearance, or that their appearance is the measure of who they are? Is sexy strong, or is sexy dangerous?

headline: A Helicopter of One’s Own
text: LIVERPOOL, England — You know what would be cool?

headline: Exploring Academia’s Role in Charting Paths to a ‘Good’ Anthropocene
text: I spent the tail end of last week at the annual conference of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences, a young network of scholars and students aiming to foster collaborations among disciplines — from ecology to ethics — in studying, and improving, the human relationship to the environment.

headline: Gluten-Free Eating Appears to Be Here to Stay
text: In the luxe dining room of Del Posto, one of New York’s most heralded and expensive Italian restaurants, one-third of the tables on any given night will have at least one gluten-free diner.

headline: Iran vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Nigeria won the African Nations Cup last year, but it lacks a star striker. Iran is solid defensively, so goals could be hard to come by.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against ‘Straw’ Purchases of Guns
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday allowed a challenge to an Ohio law banning lies in political campaigns to move forward, turned back a challenge to a law concerning gun purchases and refused to hear a case about holding high school graduations in churches.

headline: Afghan Candidate Alleges Voting Fraud by Karzai and Aides
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Less than 48 hours after a runoff election to choose the next president of Afghanistan, the first signs of a looming political crisis emerged on Monday, with the campaign of Abdullah Abdullah claiming there had been widespread ballot stuffing and suggesting he was being set up for a defeat he would not accept.

headline: Asparagus, Revisited
text: Q. Why does eating asparagus make one’s urine smell funny?

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Margaret Howell Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Syrian Government Making Aid Delivery More Difficult, U.N. Official Says
text: GENEVA — The government of President Bashar al-Assad is making it harder to deliver humanitarian aid to millions of war-battered civilians in Syria, the United Nations chief aid coordinator, Valerie Amos, said on Monday.

headline: Producers Aim to Bring ‘Love Letters’ to Broadway This Fall
text: A Broadway revival is in the works for A.R. Gurney’s “Love Letters,” a two-character epistolary play that has long been a favorite of famous actors, with producers aiming to mount the show at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in the fall. The director would be the Tony nominee Gregory Mosher (Broadway’s “A View from the Bridge” in 2009-10) and the lead producers include Nelle Nugent (“The Trip to Bountiful” in 2013), Barbara Broccoli (the James Bond movie series) and Fred Zollo (“Once”), according to two Broadway producers who are not involved with the show but are familiar with the plans.

headline: Two Kids Still Hopelessly Devoted to Each Other
text: There’s certainly some heart in the serviceable production of “Grease” at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. But the show’s pulse can be overwhelmed by percussion. Here, the big tunes are belted out, then underscored in fear you might miss a beat. That leaves only the modest, quiet numbers to give those peppy characters some much-needed depth.

headline: Festival Style: Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival
text: Music fans gather in Manchester, Tenn., for the music and to don their favorite festival-style interpretations.

headline: Pterosaurs, Flying Reptiles, Were a Social Lot
text: Scientists have discovered the first intact eggs from pterosaurs, the flying reptiles that lived alongside the dinosaurs. The eggs, along with dozens of pterosaur fossils, are from a site discovered in 2005 in northwestern China. In a new study in the journal Current Biology, the scientists report that the pterosaurs belong to a new genus and species, Hamipterus tianshanensis, dating to the Early Cretaceous, 145 million to 100 million years ago. They had wingspans of five to 11 feet.

headline: Sounds of Frog Lust, Made Even Sexier
text: Tiny frogs in Taiwan are making the most of urban development by using storm drains to amplify their mating calls and impress females, researchers say. Open concrete drains are common in Taiwan, and male  Mientien tree frogs (above, one in its more usual setting) like to perch inside when courting. Writing in The Journal of Zoology, researchers reported that the drains enhanced the volume and duration of calls.

headline: The Mother Who Jumped
text: A few months after Cindy Wachenheim gave birth to the child she had long dreamed of, she became convinced that she had caused her son irrevocable brain damage. It was a certainty she couldn’t shake.

headline: In Defeat, Portugal Shows Its Ugly Side
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — The goals came in volume for Cristiano Ronaldo this year, as he stretched nets in towns across Europe at a stunning rate. While playing for Real Madrid, Ronaldo scored 51 times in 47 games, earning him the Ballon d’Or for best player in the world.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 10-16, 2014
text: How well did you follow the news this week? How well can you do against others taking our 10-question quiz?

headline: Green Space So Exclusive It’s Off Limits Even to Residents
text: Deborah Nevins is one of the most sought-after landscape designers in the world. She has seeded and sodded estates for the likes of the entertainment mogul David Geffen, the Greek shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos and the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, and her haute habitats dot townhouse backyards and prewar rooftops from Greenwich Village to Park Avenue.

headline: After Baby, an Unraveling
text: Cindy Wachenheim was someone people didn’t think they had to worry about. She was a levelheaded lawyer working for the State Supreme Court, a favorite aunt who got down on the floor to play with her nieces and nephews, and, finally, in her 40s, the mother she had long dreamed of becoming.

headline: Spurs’ Title Is a Testament to Persistence
text: SAN ANTONIO — In a corner of the San Antonio Spurs’ locker room, there is a framed quotation from the muckraking social reformer Jacob Riis.

headline: A Chain Reaction of Change Behind Dams
text: When settlers in 18th-century New England dammed their lakes, they unwittingly set off evolutionary changes in the herring species called the alewife. Now researchers have discovered that those changes rippled across the food web.

headline: Ticketless Fans Breach Security Gate at World Cup
text: FIFA and World Cup officials faced questions about security Monday after two incidents Sunday kept ticketed fans out of one match until after it had begun and nearly allowed fans without tickets to force their way into another.

headline: Voice by Eternal Lips
text: A premiere of the band’s latest music video features the dancer Alex Sotomayor as Michael Jackson.

headline: Creating a Supply Chain of Work by Female Playwrights
text: All but daring American theaters to put on more new plays by women, an advocacy group of female writers and producers released a list of 46 such works on Monday that have been recommended for production by dozens of other playwrights, dramaturges and artistic directors.

headline: Middle School Never Ends
text: Do “cool kids” suffer for their status later in life? A new study suggests they may — and its reception shows how much power childhood hierarchies seem to have over us, even decades later.

headline: Computing Crime and Punishment
text: In 1765, John Ward was hanged for stealing a watch and a hat.

headline: Bill de Blasio Loves L.A. (We Love It!)
text: Sports wagers by politicians are boring and not worth your time. But this one could have been interesting.

headline: United States vs. Ghana: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: The pressure to mount an attack for the Americans will be on Clint Dempsey, Jozy Altidore and Michael Bradley. Ghana will look to the stalwart captain, Asamoah Gyan, and the young Jordan Ayew, starting instead of Kevin-Prince Boateng.

headline: Merrill Lynch to Pay More than $32 Million for Overcharging Clients
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has ordered Merrill Lynch to pay more than $32 million over sales fees it charged on certain mutual funds.

headline: Diplomacy and Soccer for Biden in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Seeking an opening during the World Cup soccer tournament to thaw relations with Brazil, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Latin America’s largest country on Monday, expressing a desire to “rebuild trust” after the souring of ties over revelations of the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices.

headline: Jonathan Ive on Apple’s Design Process and Product Philosophy
text: When Steven P. Jobs led Apple, he created a core principle for the company’s designers and engineers: stay fully focused on making great products.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Octopus Press
text: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by editors at Octopus Books, Hajara Quinn, Zachary Schomburg, Mathias Svalina and Alisa Heinzman, and book designer Drew Swenhaugen.

headline: Casely-Hayford: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: London

headline: Moschino: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: London

headline: The Earth’s Hidden Ocean
text: An analysis of seismic waves passing through the deep earth appears to confirm what laboratory experiments have suggested was possible: that an ocean of water is tied up in the mantle, 400 miles below the surface.

headline: The Making of a Male Model
text: During Men’s Fashion Week, hundreds of young men head to Europe, hoping it will be the start of their modeling careers. “I think that most people think that when you become a model, you don’t have to worry anymore about money,” said Tomas Gajdos, a 17-year-old high school student from Slovakia who was discovered by a modeling agent while riding the London Tube. “But, it isn’t so easy as it maybe looks.”

headline: American Tower Expands Cellphone Tower Holdings in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The American Tower Corporation has agreed to acquire a Brazilian cellphone tower company, BR Towers, backed by the private equity firm GP Investments, for about $978 million, the companies said in regulatory filings on Sunday.

headline: Listen Up | A Brooklyn Experimental Musician Gets in Touch With His Inner Michael Jackson
text: “I avoided pop music for a long time,” says Grey Gersten, a veteran of the Brooklyn indie music scene, of his new pop-minded solo project Eternal Lips. “I thought pop was all about consumerism. Then I realized pop was about dreams and fantasy.”

headline: Father, Doctor, Role Model
text: In a career that spanned more than five decades, from the 1950s into the 21st century, Dr. Phillip I. Lerner witnessed vast transformations in medicine. But as his son, Dr. Barron H. Lerner, writes in this exquisitely insightful new memoir, none of the changes was more profound than the evolution of the doctor-patient relationship.

headline: In Another Blow, G.M. Recalls 3 Million More Defective Cars
text: General Motors said on Monday that it would recall 3.36 million defective cars worldwide, another low point in the seemingly endless safety crisis that has engulfed the nation’s largest automaker.

headline: Dense Breasts May Obscure Mammogram Results
text: The doctors were pleased to inform me, the letter said, that the results of the mammogram were normal. Early detection of cancer is important, a report was sent to my referring physician, I should report any lumps, see my health provider, have a physical.

headline: Ask Well: Feeding Heavy and Thin Kids Together
text: Question:

headline: Delay in Translating Recordings May Affect Jury Availability at State Senator’s Trial
text: WHITE PLAINS — A mistrial in the federal government’s bribery case against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants seemed highly possible on Monday after the judge said he would ask jurors whether they could serve into mid-July so defense lawyers could digest dozens of hours of conversation in Yiddish and English.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Senate Hearing on Fairness of High-Speed Stock Trading Could Get Heated
text: Updated, 7:14 p.m. To the average investor with a brokerage account, the process of buying and selling shares of stock seems straightforward. But the back end of these systems, governing how billions of shares are traded, remains opaque to many customers.

headline: Best Week Yet for ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ After Tony Win
text: Last week was the best yet at the box office for the Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” following the show winning the Tony Award for best musical on June 8. “Gentleman’s Guide,” one of the most modest-selling musicals of the 2013-14 season until it became a front-runner for the Tony last month, grossed $851,262 for eight performances last week; its previous high was $816,932 for nine performances during Christmas week last year. The average paid ticket price was $121.89, up nearly $22 from the week before – a big jump that reflects theatergoers’ buying more premium-price tickets, a goal of the show’s producers as they try to leverage the Tony into making the show a commercial hit.

headline: Despite a Wayward Journey, Márquez Is a Rock for Mexico
text: NATAL, Brazil — With one arm folded across his chest, Rafael Márquez of Mexico stood in the pouring rain and belted out his country’s national anthem. Moments later, he was cruising around the drenched field, influencing play in his typical subtle ways, helping lead his team to a  1-0 victory over Cameroon.

headline: A Superspy Races to Halt Armaggedon
text: Neither its plot nor its provenance do much to recommend Terry Hayes’s “I Am Pilgrim.” So it’s all the more surprising that this first novel by a screenwriter of films not renowned for their dialogue turns out to be the most exciting desert island read of the season.

headline: With His Best Finish in a Major, Fowler Displays Substance and Style
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — As befits the perfect pitchman, Rickie Fowler met with the news media Sunday wearing a cap with “Puma” spelled in large writing and a shirt bearing a Puma logo so large the eye was reflexively drawn to it.

headline: Rocks With Resonance
text: The sounds of ringing rocks at Preseli Hills in West Wales, the source area of some of the Stonehenge bluestones.

headline: Older Than the Rolling Stones
text: Before dawn Saturday, thousands of revelers will again gather among the monoliths at Stonehenge to sing, bang drums and frolic beneath a solstice sunrise.

headline: Relatives of Missing Teenager Speak Out
text: Relatives of Naftali Fraenkel, an Israeli-American teenager who is believed to have been kidnapped by Palestinian militants, expressed hope that he would be found soon.

headline: As Robotics Advances, Worries of Killer Robots Rise
text: From driverless cars to delivery drones, a new generation of robots is about to revolutionize the way people work, drive and shop. But there is one area where robots are already entrenched and spreading fast: the industrial sector, especially manufacturing and storage.

headline: A Hublot Timepiece Specially Designed for World Cup Fans
text: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Hublot.

headline: A Delay at La Guardia Becomes ‘The French Connection’
text: I HAVE been flying for most of my 35-year career. As the chairman and chief investment officer at Saguenay Strathmore Capital, I’m constantly traveling for business. I was on a plane two and a half weeks after rotator cuff surgery. The doctor thought I was nuts.

headline: Hoping the Tale of a Glass Slipper Fits Into a Troupe’s Repertory
text: The stylistic versatility offered by American Ballet Theater at its best is a marvel. During this spring season, it has been dancing choreography by four thoroughly unalike 20th-century masters — Leonide Massine, George Balanchine, Kenneth MacMillan and Frederick Ashton — and, often enough, the standards it has set in each have been world class.

headline: Squeezing the Life Out of Airline Travel
text: SUMMER is coming, airplanes are fuller than ever, and the airlines are squeezing every penny they can from passengers. Even stalwart fliers like my friend Heather Poole, a flight attendant and author of a humorous memoir about her career (“Cruising Altitude: Tales of Crash Pads, Crew Drama and Crazy Passengers at 35,000 Feet”), are taking a deep breath.

headline: Efforts to Inspire Students Have Borne Little Fruit
text: An occasional column on developments in what educators call STEM — for science, technology, engineering and math.

headline: Keeping Health in Stock at New York City’s Bodegas
text: At Sandy Ortiz’s bodega in the Bronx, no platanos means no business.

headline: Did George W. Bush Foresee What’s Happening in Iraq?
text: In their rush to blame the escalating violence in Iraq on President Obama, Republican critics brush off any suggestion that his predecessor may also be to blame, offering up some version of “Oh yeah, Democrats always want to blame Bush, but Obama has been in office for more than five years.”

headline: A Newsroom Tradition Comes to an End, Sort Of
text: A Times tradition ended on Monday: the coffee cart, which had been wheeled into the third-floor newsroom to provide a free caffeine fix every weekday afternoon around 4:30 for more than 20 years. The company told newsroom employees in an email that it would be replaced by an offering of “fruits and other healthy snacks.”

headline: Transforming Phone Video Into Publicity and a Film
text: Chicago was blowing up. There were explosions at the convention center, cars cartwheeling down South Wacker Drive, pandemonium in Millennium Park and helicopters swooping down the river, ducking under drawbridges.

headline: What Olivier Theyskens’s Departure From Theory May Really Mean
text: On Monday, Theory announced that its artistic director, Olivier Theyskens, was leaving the brand to “pursue other design projects.” The recent pre-spring 2015 collection was his last.

headline: ‘Ring’ Cycle With Digital Orchestra Is Postponed
text: The effort to bring Wagner’s “Ring” cycle to Connecticut with digital samples instead of a traditional orchestra has been postponed. Organizers announced Monday that they were canceling their first offering, a production of “Das Rheingold” planned for August, saying that several artists had withdrawn, citing threats to their careers.

headline: Bonnaroo 2014
text: Scenes from the Bonnaroo 2014 photo diary of Tamara Reynolds.

headline: Tell Us What You Love About Your Bodega
text: Bodegas, the trusty neighborhood shops that carry the bare essentials and are never far away when you need them, have long been a point of pride for New Yorkers.

headline: Sending Patients Home, Décor and Distraction, Priceless Nature
text: Health Care

headline: In Performance | ‘The Village Bike’
text: Greta Gerwig and Scott Shepherd in a scene from Penelope Skinner’s dark comedy at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: The Redesign of a Design Museum
text: Andrew Carnegie used the third floor of his Fifth Avenue mansion as a gymnasium where he practiced his putting. The current owner, the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, plans to put a small mini-golf green there on Tuesday when the news media gets a preview of the mansion’s nearly completed $91 million renovation.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Iraq, Palestine and Spain.

headline: Willie Nelson, Mali Music and Keith Jarrett and Charlie Haden
text: WILLIE NELSON

headline: As Brazil Cheers, Protesters Struggle to Be Heard
text: Twelve months after hundreds of thousands of protesters took to Brazil’s streets to complain of lavish public spending on stadiums for the World Cup, the tournament organizers have been relieved to see just hundreds attend scattered demonstrations as the first round of games got underway.

headline: Creative Destruction Yada Yada
text: Jill Lepore has a great article in the New Yorker debunking the hyping of “disruptive innovation” as the key to success in business and everything else. It’s not a bah-humbug piece; it is instead a careful takedown, in which she goes back to the case studies supposedly showing the overwhelming importance of upstart innovators, and shows that what actually happened didn’t fit the script. Specifically, many of the “upstarts” were actually long-established firms, and more often than not the big payoffs went not to disruptive innovators but to firms that focused on incremental change and ordinary forms of efficiency and quality.

headline: Spanish-Language ‘Vagina Monologues’ Closes After Short Run
text: Spanish-speaking audiences didn’t turn out for “Los Monólogos de la Vagina,” forcing the quick closure of Eve Ensler’s play after 15 previews and 33 regular performances.

headline: At Home, a Dramatic Organist
text: A well-remembered highlight of the Boston Early Music Festival a year ago was a Bach organ recital by John Scott. Mr. Scott, the organist and director of music at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue in New York, is better known here for his work with the splendid St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys than as an organist.

headline: Drifters Look for Work; One of Them Finds Love
text: For all of the dearly departed New York City Opera’s contributions to American culture, the 30 or so new operas it presented were never really among them. Seen Gian Carlo Menotti’s “The Most Important Man” or Thea Musgrave’s “The Voice of Ariadne” lately? Neither have I.

headline: A Red Carpet for Young Guests
text: Travis Evans could meet his friends in just about any bar around Washington, but he is drawn to the Dignitary Bar at the Marriott Marquis, where he takes time to enjoy his favorite drink, an Old-Fashioned.

headline: Questions and Answers About the Crisis in Iraq
text: The conflict in Syria has escalated into a wider regional crisis, edging neighboring Iraq closer to all-out sectarian warfare, as Sunni militants led by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, have  declared a caliphate that stretches across eastern Syria and much of northern and western Iraq.

headline: Mariano Rivera and JPMorgan’s James Lee Honored by Sports Charity
text: It isn’t quite a merger of pinstripes, but one of Wall Street’s top deal makers is taking the stage with a New York Yankees legend to raise money for a sports-focused children’s nonprofit.

headline: Reclaim the Firefox Search Box
text: Q. How do I restore the Google search box and its search engines list to Firefox version 29.0.1?

headline: Excerpt: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
text: Lily Rabe and members of the cast of the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Moelis Creates Private Equity Fund-Raising Team by Hiring From a Rival
text: Moelis & Company said on Monday that it has hired four executives from a rival boutique investment bank, Greenhill & Company, to start up a group specializing in raising money for private equity firms.

headline: Iraq’s Current Conflict Foretold
text: As rebel forces capture Iraqi cities, veteran photojournalists look at the lessons learned and the obstacles that lie ahead for independent coverage in the region.

headline: Who Will Win in Iraq?
text: WASHINGTON — TO go by much of the commentary about Iraq in recent days, the country is already past the breaking point under the lightning campaign by Sunni insurgents. Reinforced by hardened fighters from Syria and sympathetic communities in northern and western Iraq, the insurgents control much of Mosul, the most important city in northern Iraq, and Tikrit, the home of Saddam Hussein’s clan, and they have laid siege to Samarra, the site of one of Shiism’s most storied shrines. It would be no surprise if the next few weeks brought them to the gates of Baghdad.

headline: With ‘SmartBinge,’ WNYC Wants Listeners to Load Up on Its Podcasts
text: DURING pledge drives, public radio hosts often highlight what they call driveway moments, those instances when, upon arriving home, motorists are so captivated by a radio segment that they remain behind the wheel until it concludes. Now a new campaign from WNYC promotes the notion that in the era of smartphones and podcasts, far from being confined to their cars, listeners can tune in wherever and whenever they want.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,317 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A Judge’s Attack on Teacher Tenure
The Culture at G.M.: A Call for Congressional Action
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fiber Networks for Phones
What’s in a Brooklyn Sign?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spain’s Mosque-Cathedral
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Video of Modern-Day Concentration Camps
text: On my recent trip to Myanmar, I was accompanied by a Times video journalist, Adam Ellick, who just published a searing video of the modern-day concentration camps for Rohingya in that country. I must say that sometimes as a scribbler, I find it a hassle to make videos on trips. There’s more equipment, and we’re always fussing over microphones and capturing sunsets, and the cameras make us more obvious to the authorities. I like nimble, and videos aren’t nimble. But then I see the finished results, and I’m so impressed.

headline: Egypt to Free Ill Journalist Who Staged Hunger Strike
text: CAIRO — Prosecutors will release a hunger-striking journalist, Abdullah Elshamy, because of his deteriorating health, the Egyptian state news media said on Monday, offering a concession on the treatment of one of more than 16,000 prisoners detained since the military takeover last summer.

headline: Suze Orman’s Approved Prepaid Debit Cards Are Quietly Discontinued
text: Suze Orman is quietly getting out of the payments business.

headline: A Church-PAC Link Raises Questions in Mississippi
text: The full-page advertisement in Mississippi Link, a weekly newspaper aimed at black residents of Jackson, the state’s capital, urged readers to vote for Senator Thad Cochran in the June 3 Republican primary.

headline: General to Lead Bergdahl Inquiry
text: The Army has appointed a two-star general on Monday to conduct an investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from his outpost in Afghanistan in 2009. The officer, Maj. Gen. Kenneth R. Dahl, who has combat experience in Afghanistan, will conduct the inquiry into Sergeant Bergdahl, who returned to the United States from an Army hospital in Germany last Friday, two weeks after being released in exchange for five senior Taliban detainees. Sergeant Bergdahl is undergoing therapy and counseling at an Army hospital in San Antonio.

headline: Marriage by Force Is Addressed in Britain
text: LONDON — England and Wales made it a criminal offense as of Monday to force anyone into marriage, an effort to persuade victims to come forward and to emphasize secular legal values.

headline: Can the Port Authority Save the Planet?
text: THIS has been a bad year for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, with scandals over a bridge closure and, most recently, a shady real estate deal. But the authority has a chance at redemption, if it is willing to move beyond its traditional mandate. Its model of interstate cooperation could do much more than prevent traffic jams; it could also play the leading role in managing the ecological health of the Hudson River estuary, and serve as an example for other coastal cities around the world facing complex environmental problems in a time of climate change.

headline: Writing in the Here and Now
text: There may be no literary genre that, at its best, evokes sense of place more than travel writing. The whole point is to make the reader feel there, not here, to transport proverbial armchair travelers from their dull, quiet living rooms to a cacophony of scarlet macaws clearing their throats deep in a tropical rain forest in Costa Rica.

headline: Obama to Send Armed Support to U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
text: In a letter to the speaker of the House, the president explained that United States soldiers will be sent to Baghdad to protect American citizens.

headline: World Cup 2014: Belgium Defeats Algeria, 2-1
text: Two second-half goals enabled Belgium to rally for a 2-1 victory against Algeria and keep alive its hopes of winning the group.

headline: British Spy Agencies Assert Power to Intercept Web Traffic
text: LONDON — In a broad legal rationale for collecting information from Internet use by its citizens, the British government has asserted the right to intercept communications that go through services like Facebook, Google and Twitter that are based in the United States or other foreign nations, even if they are between people in Britain.

headline: In Medtronic’s Deal for Covidien, an Emphasis on Tax Savings
text: To invest in the United States, Medtronic says it needs to move to Ireland.

headline: Ruling on Argentina’s Debt May Give Creditors More Power
text: For decades, a country in deep financial trouble could, as a last resort, cut a deal with its creditors to slash its debt load, perhaps gaining relief for its economy and its people.

headline: In Two Michigan Villages, a Higher Calling Is Often Heard
text: FOWLER, Mich. — Aside for the mole grazing his right eyebrow, it is difficult to distinguish Gary Koenigsknecht from his identical twin, Todd, four minutes the elder.

headline: Climbing Out of the Darkness of Maternal Mental Illness
text: Two articles in the Health section, “Thinking of Ways to Harm Her” and “After Baby, an Unraveling,” shed new light on the timing and range of maternal mental Illness. New studies and research suggest that maternal mental illness can appear during pregnancy, or can appear not only in the first few weeks after birth but in later months. In the year after giving birth, studies suggest, as many as one in five and at least one in eight women develop symptoms of mental illness, including not just depression, but anxiety, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder or a combination as well.

headline: A Dream Start
text: NATAL, Brazil — It began with the magical. It ended with the miraculous.

headline: Court Rulings on Voter Restrictions Create Limbo as Midterms Near
text: MIAMI — With the midterm elections only months away, efforts to carry out some of the country’s strictest photo ID requirements and shorten early voting in several politically pivotal states have been thrown into limbo by a series of court decisions concluding that the measures infringe on the right to vote.

headline: The Structures of Growth
text: Most of us are trying to get better at something. And when we think about our future progress, we tend to imagine we will improve linearly. We’ll work hard at mastering some skill; we’ll steadily get better and better.

headline: Frances Foster, Children’s Book Editor With an Imprint, Dies at 83
text: Frances Foster, a children’s book editor who published authors like Roald Dahl, Peter Sís and Philip Pullman, and who had her own imprint, died on June 8 in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Truckers Resist Rules on Sleep, Despite Risks of Drowsy Driving
text: The tractor-trailer set off at 2:30 a.m. from Springfield, Mo., the usual time and place. Nearly 11 hours later, along the Will Rogers Turnpike in Oklahoma, fatigue caught up.

headline: Ruling Against J.C. Penney in Dispute With Macy’s Over Martha Stewart Products
text: A New York judge on Monday ruled that J. C. Penney unlawfully interfered with an exclusive merchandising agreement between Macy’s and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

headline: Study Asserts Startling Numbers of Insider Trading Rogues
text: There is often a tip.

headline: How Health Care Systems Stack Up
text: Britain and Switzerland were top scorers in a study examining the quality and efficiency of health care systems in 11 advanced nations by a leading American research organization. As usual, the United States finished last over all and last on several important measures of cost and health outcomes, despite having the most costly system in the world.

headline: Legislating Ignorance About Guns
text: Eighteen months and dozens of school shootings after the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., public-health experts still lack basic information on the roots of gun violence and how best to prevent it.

headline: Innocents at the Border
text: The surge of desperate young migrants across the southwest border has the Obama administration scrambling to respond. It was clearly ill-prepared for a problem that grew steadily for years before exploding this year, with more than 47,000 unaccompanied children caught at the border since October.

headline: In a .338 Lifetime Average, Every Day Counted
text: Tony Gwynn may have embodied the game of baseball better than anyone else who has played. It was not because Gwynn, who died of cancer on Monday at age 54, was among its greatest hitters. It was because of the wonder he found in the game and the joy he took in applying his daily discoveries.

headline: Sunnis and Kurds on Sidelines of Iraqi Leader’s Military Plans
text: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has presented himself as the man who could bring Iraqis together, but with the collapse of his army before a Sunni militant assault, he has taken on only one role — that of commander in chief of Iraq.

headline: A New College Model
text: On Monday, Howard Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, unveiled his company’s newest — and possibly most important — perquisite for its employees: a free college education. He announced this new program on a stage in The Times Center in Midtown Manhattan, alongside his partner in the new venture, Michael Crow of Arizona State University.

headline: Sharpton’s Coolness to Rangel Marks Waning of a Political Generation
text: When the Rev. Al Sharpton abruptly summoned the candidates in the Democratic primary for Representative Charles B. Rangel’s seat to the headquarters of Mr. Sharpton’s organization, the National Action Network, this month, the incumbent showed up an hour late.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees’ Lawyers Seek Further Delays
