text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Defense lawyers on Monday sought further delays in the war crimes case against five Guantánamo Bay detainees accused of aiding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, telling a military judge that there had been greater scrutiny of defense teams by the F.B.I. than had previously come to light.

headline: U.S. Judge Denies Stay of Execution in Georgia
text: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Monday rejected a Georgia inmate’s argument that his execution, scheduled for Tuesday evening, should be stayed because the state had refused to disclose details about the drug to be used in his lethal injection.

headline: To Bolster Its Claims, China Plants Islands in Disputed Waters
text: BEIJING — The islands have all that one could ask of a tropical resort destination: white sand, turquoise waters and sea winds.

headline: Chicago Is Freed From Oversight on Graft
text: CHICAGO — The city that was once known as the patronage capital of the world may no longer live up to the title.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 16, 2014
Tensions Mount as Troops Scour Hebron in Search for Missing Youths
text: HEBRON, West Bank — Kayed and Hassan Jaber, brothers who drive trucks loaded with marble from this city’s quarries into Israel each day, stood in the doorway of their Star of the South company here Monday afternoon watching pretty much nothing happen on the street.

headline: Abduction of Young Israeli Hitchhikers Spurs Debate on Conduct
text: NOF AYALON, Israel — The three Israeli teenagers kidnapped by Palestinian militants while hitching a ride in the West Bank last week have provoked an outpouring of sympathy in Israel’s ordinarily fractious society, with nonstop news coverage and gatherings of thousands who have recited psalms for the safe return of the hostages, all students at yeshivas in West Bank settlements.

headline: Bratton Still Sees Challenges in a New York He Made Safer
text: In his office on the 14th floor of Police Headquarters, William J. Bratton displays copies of his memoir, “Turnaround,” his account of taming New York’s crime-filled streets and subways in the 1990s. On a mostly empty wall hangs a framed Time magazine cover from 1996, declaring over a steely photo of Mr. Bratton: “Finally, We’re Winning the War Against Crime. Here’s Why.”

headline: Big Retailers Agree to List Unit Prices on Websites
text: Is that television-size box of graham crackers at Costco really a better deal than a standard box at Walmart? Soon, online customers won’t have to do the math to figure it out.

headline: The Shadow of the Patriarch
text: Matters of faith and family, gender and culture are stirred together into a fiery-flavored stew in “The Who & the What,” the probing new play by Ayad Akhtar that opened on Monday at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center. Like Mr. Akhtar’s “Disgraced,” which won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize and will be seen on Broadway this fall, this new work considers the itchy frictions that emerge when religious belief and contemporary life rub up against each other, as they do for the family at the center of the play, a Pakistani immigrant and his two grown daughters.

headline: Dancing Between Battles
text: Fair weather never lasts forever, not even in the Eden-like patch of Sicily that has popped up in Central Park. That’s the setting for Jack O’Brien’s pleasure-filled production of “Much Ado About Nothing,” which opened on Monday night at the Delacorte Theater. Though skies and temperaments are sunny when the show begins, you’re always conscious of brooding storms waiting to make their angry entrances.

headline: Pop the Question
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — It took me a long time to figure out what the theme was for Zhouqin Burnikel’s puzzle. That’s not a bad thing, mind you; There’s a revealer at 69 Across that explains everything, albeit in a very quiet way (pun intended).

headline: Migrants Flow in South Texas, as Do Rumors
text: McALLEN, Tex. — Exhausted and dazed, hundreds of Central American migrants, mainly women with small children, come to the bus station of this border city every day now, spilling into a church next door that has opened its doors. Having crossed into the United States illegally, the new arrivals are often grimy and famished. In the church, they eat, bathe and sleep, changing into donated shoes and clothes.

headline: How the United States Scored Against Ghana

text: Within hours on Monday of unveiling, with much fanfare, a program to pay employees’ college tuition, Starbucks faced criticism for drawbacks in the fine print — notably that students could have to pay thousands of dollars out of pocket, and wait months or years before being reimbursed.

headline: Spanish Police Target Cells Recruiting War Volunteers
text: MELILLA, Spain — Starting in this tiny North African enclave, the Spanish police have cracked down in recent weeks on a network of Islamic militants with footholds in Spain and Morocco that they say has recruited and dispatched young volunteers to join insurgencies from Mali to Libya to Syria.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) HELLO I MUST BE GOING (2012) A divorced 30-something (Melanie Lynskey) finds a haven from her adult problems in the suburban Connecticut home of her critical mother (Blythe Danner) and indulgent father (John Rubinstein) in this comedy written by Sarah Koskoff and directed by Todd Louiso. There, she finds sex and romance with the 19-year-old stepson (Christopher Abbott, above with Ms. Lynskey) of a potential client her father is desperate to impress, who has allowed his doting mother (Julie White) to believe he is gay. “Needless to say, there are complications, some farcical, some belonging more to the realm of therapeutic melodrama,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “This is ultimately a tale of affirmation, self-acceptance and second chances, and its lessons, while not unwelcome, are a bit too forced and neatly packaged to make it fully satisfying. But when Ms. Lynskey and Mr. Abbott are together, there are inklings of a wilder, riskier, less predictable movie — one you may wish the characters could escape into, even though you know they never will.”

headline: Rick Perry’s ‘Groundhog Day’
text: “Boys, I am going to bless this meal,” Rick Perry said, ducking his head and folding his hands under his chin. We were sitting at Nate ’n Al, the Jewish Deli in Beverly Hills, and the governor of Texas was looking every bit the regular customer in a tight black polo shirt and designer glasses. His face was nicely tanned; his hair, as ever, was coifed and TV-ready. He had just ordered a corned-beef Reuben (“I worked out this morning”) and a Diet Dr Pepper (“you got those critters?” he asked the waiter). But before diving in, Perry took a moment to appreciate his surroundings. “I’m more Jewish than you think I am,” he told me. “I read the part of the Bible that said the Jews are God’s chosen people.” He boasted that he has been going to Israel since 1992. Then Perry got down to business, thanking the Lord for His many blessings, and asking Him to be with “our men and women who defend our freedom, bring ’em home safe, be with the president, give him wisdom.”

headline: Iraq’s Current Conflict Foretold
text: With Sunni rebel extremists increasing their attacks on Iraqi government forces, the conflict has drawn in Shiite civilians who had been mobilized in defense. The rebels of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, who claim to have executed hundreds of Iraqi troops, have overtaken cities in the northern and western parts of the country.

So it was all the more a surprise to see, at his debut men’s show for Moschino here Monday, a famous friend perched quietly — and punctually — front row.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times reports dozens of school shootings have occurred in the 18 months since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and the public-health community still lacks necessary information on how to prevent gun violence. “And if pro-gun members of Congress have their way, it will stay that way,” the editorial board writes. Representative Jack Kingston, Republican of Georgia and head of the House subcommittee that sets the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention budget, has labeled efforts to understand the socio-psychological causes of gun violence as “propaganda” for “gun-grabbing initiatives.” The price of ignorance “is measured in tens of thousands of preventable deaths and avoidable injuries from guns, year in and year out,” the board notes. “Compared with that, $10 million for the C.D.C. to study the problem and propose solutions would be a small price to pay.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Argentina’s Court Loss Buoys Creditors
text: The Supreme Court on Monday handed two major defeats to the government of Argentina, which has been fighting with New York hedge funds over bonds that the country defaulted on in 2001. Along with putting Argentina at risk of another default, the setbacks could also make it harder in the future for a financially troubled country to cut a deal with its creditors to reduce its debt load, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Argentina had asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court’s ruling that had required the country to pay back defaulted bonds held by the litigating hedge funds, known as holdouts.

text: This week’s video features the actors Greta Gerwig and Scott Shepherd in a scene from Penelope Skinner’s dark comedy “The Village Bike.”  The play centers on Becky (Ms. Gerwig), a pregnant young woman who moves to a small English town with her husband, only to embark on an adventurous but troubled affair with a local lothario, Oliver (Mr. Shepherd). In this scene, Becky and Oliver get acquainted, and there’s some awkward flirtation. The show, directed by Sam Gold for MCC Theater, continues through July 13 at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: Feeling For | Illesteva Shades You Design Yourself
text: In the four years of its existence, the New York-based eyewear and accessories brand Illesteva has made some noise with its collaborations, including House of Waris, the Webster boutique and Lou Reed. Lou Reed! How to follow up a partnership with the man who helped invent punk? Perhaps the only thing more punk than punk is the ethos of D.I.Y., and so today, the line — whose colorful, unisex shades have been sported by Beyoncé, Lady Gaga and Cara Delevingne — is unveiling a new custom sunglasses service. Using Illesteva’s website, users can select one of three frame styles, then choose from up to eight colors for the fronts and sides and match them up with one of up to nine lens varieties, including a polarized option. Like all of the brand’s offerings, the shades will be made in Italy or France. “I’ve never seen this offered in sunglasses before. I’m interested to see what color ways people will come up with,” says Daniel Silberman, the brand’s co-owner and designer. His decision to hand control over to his customers comes down to one of punk’s main tenets: self-expression. “Everyone wants to feel like they have something unique,” he says, “something that someone else doesn’t have.”

headline: Bowe Bergdahl the Subject of Rival Films
text: LOS ANGELES – To the competing films in development about Edward Snowden add another pair of projects on a hot-button political subject: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the recently freed Taliban prisoner of war.

headline: Car Owners Criticize Pace of G.M. Recall Repairs
text: Four months after Melissa Miller’s car was recalled by General Motors for a deadly defect, she is still waiting for it to be fixed — and still driving it.

headline: He Can Fly, in a Flash, Right Before Your Eyes
text: In 1982, David Parsons made his greatest choreographic discovery: He invented a way for a dancer to fly.

headline: Bathhouse ‘Dutchman’ Heads to Chicago
text: The artist Rashid Johnson’s production of “Dutchman,” which was staged last year as part of the Performa 13 Biennial in a true hothouse environment – the Russian and Turkish Baths on 10th Street in the East Village – is heading out on the road to another storied urban bathhouse.

headline: Vans and Ace Hotel Team Up for a Sleek Take on the Skateboarding Shoe
text: At the Ace Hotel Downtown Los Angeles, which opened earlier this year in what was once the United Artists building, the doormen and front-desk team have been outfitted with a fresh new set of kicks: a leather-and-canvas men’s lace-up designed in collaboration with Vans, the skate-shoe company which has previously teamed up with everyone from Hello Kitty to Kenzo. The black-on-black version of the classic Era model is the ultimate grown-up sneaker, equally at home in the hipster-chic, movie-set-like hotel or on the SoCal streets. Starting this weekend, the shoes are also available in limited quantities in the gift shop; next Monday, they’ll be sold online.

headline: Knicks Changing, With or Without Anthony
text: Phil Jackson is not one to deal in absolutism. He is pragmatic but whimsical. Basketball is his honored career, not his spiritual calling.

headline: At the Fragrance Foundation Awards, the Sweet Smell of Success
text: Wtih Coco Rocha and Carine Roitfeld as co-chairwomen for the evening, there was glamour in the air.

headline: Live Video from State Department Briefing on Suspect Arrested in Attack on Benghazi Compound
text: State Department officials answer questions about the arrest of a suspect in the attack on the compound in Benghazi on Sept. 11, 2012.

headline: How to Choose a Hospice
text: The American Hospice Foundation, an advocacy group that has worked to improve care for the dying and bereaved since 1995, will close its doors at the end of this month. The foundation has lost too much funding to continue, its founding president and chief executive Naomi Naierman told me in an interview. As a parting gift, however, Ms. Naierman — a hospice executive for more than 30 years — has passed along some consumer advice.

headline: Hearing Indicates Easy Path for Obama’s Housing Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee for housing secretary, Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio, fielded a series of mostly friendly questions on Tuesday from members of the Senate Banking Committee, signaling a smooth path to confirmation in the coming weeks.

headline: A World Premiere From Patti Smith and Her Daughter at Crossing the Line Festival
text: “Killer Road,” a work by the rock iconoclast Patti Smith, her daughter Jesse Smith and the ambient composer-performers of Soundwalk Collective, is one of three productions that will have their world premieres as part of Crossing the Line, the multidisciplinary festival presented by the French Institute Alliance Française (FIAF).

headline: Finally, an Executive Order on LGBT Workplace Discrimination
text: Workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity “needs to stop,” President Obama said last November, “because in the United States of America, who you are and who you love should never be a fireable offense.” But November came and went, as did 2013, and the first quarter of 2014, without the president heeding the rising calls for executive action.

headline: U.S. Calls on Europe to Ease Limits on Gene-Altered Food
text: BRUSSELS — The top American agriculture official on Tuesday called on the European Union to do more to ease restrictions on gene-altered food and feed crops if it hoped to reach a trans-Atlantic trade pact.

headline: Obama Plans Protected Marine Area in Pacific Ocean
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to protect diverse habitats of coral reefs, whales, dolphins, sharks, sea turtles and numerous fish species from commercial fishing and other activities, President Obama announced Tuesday that he intended to use his executive authority to create the world’s largest marine protected area in the south-central Pacific Ocean.

headline: Scoop: A Glimpse Into the NYTimes CMS
text: You know the importance of technology to the future of journalism has become a widely accepted fact when a prominent editor decides to join a new company because of its content management system. That’s what Ezra Klein told The New York Times about his decision to leave The Washington Post for Vox Media, a digital publisher with a fancy, custom-built CMS. Klein couldn’t quite describe what made the Vox system so special, but the fact that a journalist said he loved, let alone even tolerated, his CMS was all you needed to know that the world has changed.

headline: Defensive Shift Finds Some Believers in College Baseball
text: OMAHA — It is not that big a deal, Texas Tech Coach Tim Tadlock said. Sometimes he overshifts his infield against left-handed pull hitters, putting three players on the right side of second base like major league teams do for David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox. Sometimes he moves defenders a few feet, subtly, all in the hope of getting an out.

headline: Brazil vs. Mexico: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Both teams won their first games, so a win is not vital. Brazil will expect one nonetheless, while Mexico would be ecstatic with a draw.

headline: Stepping Into the Role of the Ringmaster
text: When a restaurant is founded by a chef whose kitchen acrobatics make us sit up and notice, it can be confusing for everybody when that chef moves on. Will the replacement be a caretaker cook mimicking the style that made the place exciting? Or will the successor be a creative whiz who can make the menu jump through a new set of hoops?

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Street Style
text: Looks range from dapper to experimental.

headline: An ’80s Warhol Brings $30 Million at Art Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland — An Andy Warhol self-portrait priced at more than $30 million led the rush of early sales at the V.I.P. preview of Art Basel, the world’s pre-eminent fair devoted to modern and contemporary art. The 45th edition of this event, held at a time when auction prices of contemporary art are booming, features hundreds of international galleries.

headline: Spy Photographers Capture Camouflaged Mini F-150
text: It’s not unusual for automotive spy photographers to pop up with images of heavily camouflaged prototype vehicles, typically taken from the other side of a fence. This week, though, the photographers shot something a bit smaller: a tot-size F-150 pickup.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
text: Statement pieces and staples from the men’s collections in London.

headline: Roma Boy, 16, Is Comatose After Beating Outside Paris
text: PARIS — A teenage Roma boy lay in a coma in a hospital here on Tuesday after being abducted from a shantytown and beaten last week, apparently in retaliation for what his assailants thought were thefts he committed in a nearby housing project, the French authorities said.

headline: The 9th Annual Jazz Age Lawn Party
text: Scenes from the photo diary of Christina Paige.

headline: In Competing Offers for Alstom, France’s Government Holds Sway

headline: Met Opera Cancels Simulcast of ‘Klinghoffer’
text: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Tuesday that it was canceling plans to simulcast John Adams’s “The Death of Klinghoffer” this fall to cinemas around the world, drawing praise from some Jewish groups who object to the opera, but laments from the work’s fans and a warning from its composer that the decision promotes “intolerance.”

headline: Koch Group Forms ‘Super PAC’ as 2014 Races Near
text: A political nonprofit group at the center of the philanthropic and political network overseen by Charles and David Koch has formed a new “super PAC,” according to documents filed earlier this month with the Federal Election Commission, providing a new outlet for the hundreds of millions of dollars the Kochs and their fellow donors are preparing to funnel into the 2014 election.

headline: Brazen Figure May Hold Key to Mysteries
text: CAIRO — Ahmed Abu Khattala was always open about his animosity toward the United States, and even about his conviction that Muslims and Christians were locked in an intractable religious war. “There is always hostility between the religions,” he said in an interview. “That is the nature of religions.”

headline: AnonyWatch: When Unnamed Sources Are Flat Wrong
text: In a blistering column this week, the Reuters media critic Jack Shafer takes The Times to task for using a particular kind of anonymous source — the kind who turn out to be wrong.

headline: How to Help Myanmar’s Muslim Minority
text: It’s a question I’ve heard over and over again from readers who learn about the persecuted Rohingya Muslim minority in Myanmar. For a couple of weeks now, I’ve been asking myself the same thing: “What can we do to help?”

headline: The Wonking Dead
text: The Commonwealth Fund is out with a new report comparing advanced-country health care systems, and the (mostly pre-Obamacare) US system looks very bad indeed: vastly higher spending per capita than anyone else, with worse results.

headline: A Scrapped Aphex Twin Album Finds New Life on YouTube
text: Fans of the electronic music composer Richard D. James, who releases his music under the name Aphex Twin, have come up with an elaborate plan to get some of his unreleased music out there. When members of We Are the Music Makers, an online electronica forum, learned that a collector was selling one of five known acetate test pressings of “Caustic Window” – an Aphex Twin album that Mr. James produced in 1994 but scrapped – they sprang into action.

headline: Doublethink in Punditry
text: A belated reaction to Mark Thoma’s comments on Barry Ritholtz and the issue of pundit accountability. Mark writes:

text: A panoramic view of Monday’s game at Estádio das Dunas in Natal, Brazil where the United States scored two goals to win.

text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: SolarCity Is Acquiring a Start-Up, Silevo, to Build Panels
text: SolarCity, the fast-growing provider of rooftop solar electricity systems, is moving into the panel manufacturing business, acquiring a start-up and planning to build one of the world’s largest module factories in Buffalo, executives said on Tuesday.

headline: David Henry Hwang and Lynn Nottage Joining Columbia Playwriting Faculty
text: The playwrights David Henry Hwang and Lynn Nottage will join the faculty of Columbia University’s School of the Arts, the school’s dean, Carol Becker, has announced, thus raising the profile of an M.F.A. program in playwriting that has existed since 1965 but in recent years has had only two professional playwrights, Charles L. Mee and Kelly Stuart, on its full-time faculty.

headline: Ramen: A Quick Fix for the Soul
text: It tells you something about the philosophy of Roy Choi that one of the recipes in his 2013 book, “L.A. Son,” doesn’t seem at first glance like a recipe at all. You make some instant ramen. Slide an egg into the hot broth, then some butter.

headline: Putting Fun in Fatherhood
text: As every dad knows, fatherhood isn’t all fun and games. But our recent Father’s Day question, “Are you a fun dad?” did prompt a number of amusing stories. We heard about dads who moonwalk, sing ZZ Top songs, play “name that potato,” dress up as the Grim Reaper on holidays and find various other ways to connect with their sons and daughters.

headline: Does TV Ignore Female Sexuality?
text: Much criticism of “Game of Thrones” — and, indeed, of cable TV in general — has focused around its depictions of violence against women. But at Salon, Lili Loofbourow points to another problem: Much of television may offer not just too many scenes of brutality toward women but also too few designed to make them feel good.

headline: Israelis Start #BringBackOurBoys Campaign
text: Updated, Wednesday, 5:44 p.m. | Inspired by the success of Nigerian activists who used a simple hashtag to trigger a global outpouring of sympathy for schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamist militants, a group of Israelis trained to promote their country online started a #BringBackOurBoys campaign last week after three teenagers disappeared on their way home from religious schools in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Roy Choi, King of L.A. Food Trucks, Moves On to a Hotel
text: LOS ANGELES — Roy Choi stood on the roof of the Line, a new hotel in the same Koreatown neighborhood he used to roam around as a child, and surveyed the surrounding blocks like a ship’s captain scanning the ocean waves.

headline: A Smart Way to Skip College in Pursuit of a Job
text: Could an online degree earned in six to 12 months bring a revolution to higher education?

headline: Russia vs. South Korea: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: With Belgium as the favorite to win this group and Algeria a longshot to advance, the winner of this match should be in good position to qualify for the knockout round.

headline: On View | Lee Ufan’s Contemplative Sculptural Installations at Versailles
text: For the past several years, the Chateau de Versailles has invited different contemporary artists to exhibit works on its grounds, including Takashi Murakami and, controversially, Jeff Koons. Starting today, the palace will be hosting 10 new pieces by the South Korean-born, Japan-based artist Lee Ufan, nine of which have been installed outdoors in the vast gardens designed by André Le Nôtre for Louis XIV.

headline: Torn Between Competing Perspectives on Iraq
text: Is this what 1975 felt like?

headline: With Business Initiative, Obama Aims to Show He Can Act Without Congress
text: PITTSBURGH — President Obama acted as a pitchman for entrepreneurs on Tuesday afternoon, fielding questions from small-business owners in an attempt to highlight creative ways to bolster manufacturing.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: At the World Cup, Doomsday Predictions Give Way to Smaller Hiccups in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — One stadium would not be ready on time. Another would not be ready at all. Violent street protests would threaten fans and upstage everything. Airport and subway strikes would strand tens of thousands of visitors.

headline: Kids’ Activities, Sonoma Style (New Museum Included)
text: With more than 400 wineries, Sonoma County, Calif., might be known as an oenophile destination, but the region is making a big push to also draw in families with several attractions and events.The Children’s Museum of Sonoma County, for example, opened in March and has an outdoor nature education area that’s representative of the local landscape with a redwood grove, a mini version of the Russian River, and wetlands.

headline: War’s Hell, Especially for Editors
text: What was meant to be Michael Hastings’s first novel, “The Last Magazine,” is his final and only one. This talented young journalist and war correspondent died last year in a car crash at 33. This book, which he’d apparently told few people about, was rescued from his laptop.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Cambodia, India and France.

headline: Appeals Court Affirms Sherlock Holmes Is in Public Domain
text: A federal judge has rejected a copyright appeal brought by the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, opening the way for writers, filmmakers and other creators to make free use of Sherlock Holmes, his sidekick Watson and any elements of their story that appeared in Conan Doyle works published prior to Jan. 1, 1923.

headline: Giants’ Beason Avoids Surgery, but Status for Opener Is in Doubt
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants middle linebacker Jon Beason will not need surgery to correct the ligament tear and small fracture in his right foot sustained last week in an off-season practice, the team announced Tuesday. But Beason’s foot will be immobilized for six weeks, which will precede an additional, undetermined period of recovery. His availability for the season opener Sept. 8 in Detroit remains in doubt.

headline: Put Language Aside, Then Let the Music Take Time to Speak
text: Nina Garenetska makes an unlikely rapper. Along with the two other women in the Ukrainian band DakhaBrakha, which performed on Monday night at Brookfield Place’s Winter Garden, she was wearing a white lace wedding dress, a tall black lamb-fur hat and half a dozen beaded necklaces. Ms. Garenetska was also holding her cello, painted with bright geometric designs.

headline: Lawmakers Introduce Bill to Ban Paid Prioritization
text: WASHINGTON – Democratic members of both houses of Congress introduced legislation Tuesday that would ban Internet service providers from charging content companies for faster or more direct connections to Internet service subscribers.

headline: Putting Duct Tape to Yet Another Use: Opera
text: The Kitchen in Chelsea is not a big performance space. So when Ariadne Greif, the soprano starring in Opera Cabal’s production of Georg Friedrich Haas’s “Atthis,” came to the front of the stage on Thursday evening, stepped out of her dress and began to tear off the metallic-looking strips of duct tape that girded her naked torso, even the last row of audience members got a close-up of what must be one of the most searingly painful and revealing operatic performances in recent times.

headline: Extremist Gains in Iraq Confirm Fears in Middle East
text: The recent capture of Iraqi cities by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni militant group known as ISIS, has added credence to widespread fears in the Middle East of extremists taking control of Syria and of violence spilling beyond its borders.

headline: Walter White, Meet Walter Blanco: It’s the Same Story, With a Different Desert
text: A scrubby landscape. A pair of white pants floating through the air. A large vehicle driven by an overexcited man in a pair of tighty whities and a gas mask.

headline: Elephant Tusks and Rhino Horns in New York City
text: The stories are horrifying: ruthless criminals slaughtering thousands of African elephants for their ivory tusks and wantonly killing rhinoceroses for their horns. Besides the terrible suffering inflicted on these animals, there is a growing fear that they could soon become extinct.  The best way to stop this killing is to stop the market.

text: London

headline: Ukraine Suspects Terrorism in Pipeline Explosion
text: MOSCOW — A major natural gas pipeline exploded in central Ukraine on Tuesday, a day after the Russian energy behemoth Gazprom said that it was cutting off supplies to Ukraine in a dispute over pricing, and officials immediately labeled it a possible act of sabotage.

headline: PBS Plans to Add a Shorter Version of ‘Sesame Street’
text: Viewers of “Sesame Street”‘ are about to get a big lesson in how to divide in half and multiply by 150 percent.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: As China’s Leader Fights Graft, His Relatives Shed Assets
text: HONG KONG — As President Xi Jinping of China prepares to tackle what may be the biggest cases of official corruption in more than six decades of Communist Party rule, new evidence suggests that he has been pushing his own family to sell hundreds of millions of dollars in investments, reducing his own political vulnerability.

headline: Sharing Cultural Jewels via Instagram
text: On a recent spring morning, some 90 minutes before the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened, Dave Krugman, a 26-year-old photo retoucher from Bushwick, Brooklyn, ushered six friends into its cavernous halls through a side door near East 81st Street.

headline: Stressed Out
text: My NYRB review of Tim Geithner is up.

headline: Mexico Sings Praises of Its Goalie
text: FORTALEZA, Brazil — It is a hard thing to have your voices heard over tens of thousands of people who are screaming at the same time, hoping to drown you out, but that did not stop the fans of Mexico here Tuesday from trying and trying and trying.

headline: A Crown Spurs Fashion in Spain
text: The coronation of Crown Prince Felipe de Borbón as the new Spanish king and his wife, Letizia, as queen consort on Thursday is generally being greeted, anti-monarchists aside, as a new start for Spain; a smart move on the part of Felipe’s father, King Juan Carlos; and the introduction of a new royal “fashion icon” — this last even though the event itself is billed as an austere affair, without the usual pomp and elaborate gowns a coronation implies.

headline: Saving, and Splurging, in Guyana
text: Where I come from, we don’t put ice in our Guinness. Or Red Bull. But in the gold-mining frontier town of Bartica, Guyana, I became a (temporary) convert.

headline: New Energy Rouses Boston’s Downtown Crossing
text: BOSTON — Ever since the postwar demise of the venerable department stores that once distinguished Downtown Crossing as a shopping hub, the central section of this city has struggled to survive as a retail destination.

headline: A Gleam of Renewal in Struggling Detroit
text: Corktown, once a desolate strip just west of downtown Detroit, is a serious hotbed of new restaurants, bars, hotels and more, all sitting in the shadow of one of the most glaring icons of Detroit’s demise, the skeleton of the old train depot, Michigan Central Station. In this ailing city, people look at Corktown as a bright example of what rebuilding can do. The resurgence of Corktown, originally an Irish enclave, began with the 2005 opening of Slows Bar B Q. These days, thanks to low rents and a consumer base hungry for things to do, the area is now a vibrant community of passionate restaurateurs, stylish shopkeepers, meticulous coffee connoisseurs and craft cocktailers.

headline: Restaurant Report: Opposite Mess Hall in Bangkok
text: If you spot a Bangkok chef or two dining at Opposite Mess Hall, don’t be surprised. With its signature cocktails and small inventive plates inspired by cuisine from all over Asia and beyond, this ingredient-focused restaurant and bar has become a popular post-service spot, a kind of stylish mess hall for those looking for an unpretentious but excellent meal.

headline: Fragrance Foundation Awards: Glory and Aromatherapy
text: The fashion editor Carine Roitfeld scanned the lobby at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. She was there for the annual Fragrance Foundation Awards (formerly nicknamed the FiFi awards), and it was cocktail hour, before the ceremony. Ms. Roitfeld was mostly left to herself.

text: Rates

headline: Despite Protests, Canada Approves Northern Gateway Oil Pipeline
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian government’s approval of a major pipeline running from the Alberta oil sands to a new port on the coast of British Columbia has intensified opposition from aboriginal groups, environmentalists and community advocates.

headline: She Wasn’t Called ‘Sleepless Beauty’
text: Dr. Amy Wechsler, a New York dermatologist, recently had a patient walk into her office and point to a wrinkle that had not been there a week before.

headline: Makeup for the Sleep-Deprived
text: A full night’s sleep may be the ideal way to a bright, refreshed face, but for the many days we are short on shut-eye, there are products to help you fake that slept-for-eight-hours look. Here are four.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: World Cup 2014: Chile Eliminates Defending Champion Spain
text: The defending champion Spain failed in its attempt to win a second successive World Cup after a 2-0 defeat to Chile on Wednesday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Outlasts Australia, 3-2
text: The Netherlands beat Australia, 3-2, in a back-and-forth game that gave the Dutch an excellent chance of qualifying for the knockout stages, and all but assured that Australia would exit the World Cup after the first round.

headline: World Cup 2014: Croatia Defeats Cameroon, 4-0
text: Croatia is still alive and Cameroon is out of the World Cup after a very one-sided encounter in Manaus.

headline: Jewish Groups United by Prayers for 3 Missing Youths
text: On the windswept shore of Atlantic Beach, on Long Island, merriment was postponed as a bride and groom said a prayer on Sunday for three teenagers kidnapped late last week in the West Bank.

headline: Don’t Fight in Iraq and Ignore Syria
text: WASHINGTON — FOR the last two years, many people in the foreign policy community, myself included, have argued repeatedly for the use of force in Syria — to no avail. We have been pilloried as warmongers and targeted, by none other than President Obama, as people who do not understand that force is not the solution to every question. A wiser course, he argued at West Point, is to use force only in defense of America’s vital interests.

headline: Assessing Fukushima Damage Without Eyes on the Inside
text: A particle that barely ranks as a footnote in a physics text may be about to lift the cleanup of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex in Japan over a crucial obstacle.

headline: Kampgrounds of America Sets First National TV Campaign
text: THE recreational vehicle industry was riding high in 2006, with the number of motor homes and towable trailers shipped to dealers reaching a 30-year high of 390,500, according to the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association. Then came the blow of the economic downturn and rising gas prices, with units plummeting 58 percent over the next three years, to 165,700 in 2009.

headline: Paying for the Forest Fire Next Time
text: WE’RE just midway through June and have already witnessed major fires in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Alaska. Many of these wildfires have grown in heat, intensity and size in recent years, consuming millions of acres with disastrous consequences and costs. They have become the new reality in the Western United States.

headline: Social Security Agency Cuts Services as Demand Grows, Senate Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Social Security Administration is closing field offices and reducing services to the public even as demand for those services surges with the aging of the baby boom generation, according to a bipartisan Senate committee report.

headline: Parasites, Killing Their Host
text: You can buy food from farmers — directly, through markets, any way you can find — and I hope you do. But unless you’re radically different from most of us, much of what you eat comes from corporations that process, market, deliver and sell “food,” a majority of which is processed beyond recognition.

headline: College Essays: Going All-Out to Get In
For U.S., Win Over Ghana May Be Enough to Advance
text: The United States earned 3 points by winning its World Cup opener against Ghana on Monday night. Ordinarily, the team would expect to need at least another point and maybe more from its last two games to advance.

text: On the eve of the financial crisis, the hedge fund manager Bruce M. Rose did a surprising deal that took his firm into the business of collecting mortgage payments from people with tainted credit.

headline: Always Iconic, Empire State Building Now Goes for Hip
text: Workers inside the Empire State Building may soon be able to imagine testing their weight-lifting prowess or other muscle-building regimens against the mythical feats of King Kong who once scaled this building’s facade.

headline: Governors Unite to Fight Heroin in New England
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — Facing a heroin crisis that they say has reached epidemic proportions, the governors of five New England states met here on Tuesday to devise a regional strategy to combat the rise in overdoses and deaths from opioid abuse.

headline: Inquiry Widens Into Hynes’s Spending as Prosecutor
text: Federal prosecutors have joined a state investigation into possible fraud by Charles J. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, signaling that he could now be facing federal charges with longer prison terms.

headline: Argentina Defiant Against Supreme Court on Bond Payments
text: Argentina said on Tuesday that it had started to take steps to circumvent a United States court order to avoid a technical default.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes Rules for Listing Risks on Social Media
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed new rules that would require drug and medical device makers to disclose risks, along with benefits, of products on social media platforms, even when the allowable length of messages is very limited as on Twitter. Until now, many medical product makers have refrained from using Facebook and Twitter to talk about their products because they were unsure of the rules or whether the F.D.A. would censure them, said Lori Leskin, a lawyer at Kaye Scholer. The rules would also permit, but not require, companies to correct misleading information posted by third parties about their products.

headline: A Rally for Missing Israeli Teenagers
text: The mother of one of three Jewish seminary students kidnapped in the West Bank last week appealed for their return as hundreds rallied outside the Israeli embassy in New York on Monday.

headline: Obama Discusses Innovation and Economy
text: The president delivered remarks on how to “remain the most innovative economy in the world” at TechShop in Pittsburgh.

headline: Inside a LED Factory
text: Workers manufacture LEDs at the GuoLi Optoelectronics Technology factory in Foshan, China, contributing to the country’s rapid gains in global market share in the LED industry.

headline: As LED Industry Evolves, China Elbows Ahead
text: GUANGZHOU, China — A year ago, China’s light-emitting diode industry seemed like a case study of industrial policy gone awry. Hundreds of factories built all over eastern China, often with lavish clean energy subsidies from state-owned banks and local governments, were operating at half capacity. The share prices of LED manufacturers were plunging.

headline: Julian Koenig, Who Sold Americans on Beetles and Earth Day, Dies at 93
text: Julian Koenig, who is widely regarded as one of the 20th century’s most innovative advertising writers — a creative force behind an array of memorable campaigns, including for the original Volkswagen Beetle and the enduring environmental brand Earth Day — died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Is a Pill Enough to Fight H.I.V.?
text: Is promoting the use of the antiviral drug Truvada a good public health strategy, or will it encourage more to have unprotected sex?

headline: The Non-Disappearing Web Reacts to Facebook’s Slingshot
text: When Facebook unveiled Poke last year, a service that enabled people to send photos, messages and videos with a built-in shelf life, the tech world thought it was trouble for Snapchat, a competing vanishing messaging service.

headline: SunTrust Settles With Justice Dept. Over Mortgages; Talks Continue for Citigroup and Bank of America
text: Just as the federal government reached an agreement on Tuesday with SunTrust Banks over questionable mortgage practices, the government’s talks to resolve Citigroup’s mortgage issues grew increasingly tense and veered toward a lawsuit.

headline: Arizona Cities Could Face Cutbacks in Water From Colorado River, Officials Say
text: Arizona could be forced to cut water deliveries to its two largest cities unless states that tap the dwindling Colorado River find ways to reduce water consumption and deal with a crippling drought, officials of the state’s canal network said Tuesday.

headline: Forbidden Afghan Couple Are Reunited After Arrests
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Zakia and Mohammad Ali, an Afghan couple who married for love despite death threats from her family and criminal charges by the authorities, were reunited on Tuesday after they were both freed from custody.

headline: The Fed Appears to Have Been Wrong About Growth. Again.
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials, who have persistently overestimated the strength of the economic recovery, predicted last June that the economy in 2014 would finally grow more than 3 percent for the first time since the recession.

headline: 11 Years Old, in the Open, and Carefree
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Hannah Pietila’s father was walking the fairways on Monday with his daughter during her first practice round at Pinehurst No. 2. He was supposed to be marking off yardage in anticipation of his caddying duties for the 69th United States Women’s Open, which will get underway on Thursday.

headline: Daniel Keyes, Author of ‘Flowers for Algernon,’ Dies at 86
text: Daniel Keyes, the author of “Flowers for Algernon,” the story of a man with an I.Q. of 68 who temporarily becomes a genius after surgery — a book that inspired the film “Charly,” starring Cliff Robertson — died on Sunday at his home in South Florida.  He was 86.

headline: In G.M. Hearing, Lawmakers May Focus on Contradictions
text: Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, is expected to tell a House panel on Wednesday that the auto giant is determined to change its culture and prevent another safety crisis similar to its deadly delay in recalling millions of small cars with a defective switch.

headline: Nature, Opaque and Mysterious, in All Its Seasons
text: Four of the five sections of “From a Firefly’s Eye,” a suite of dances presented by Zendora Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space over the weekend, took their titles from the seasons. But the show was no pastoral, no pretty nature calendar, and the music was definitely not Vivaldi.

headline: City’s Love Affair With the Summer Sprinkler Bursts Forth
text: Just after 2 p.m. Tuesday, with the temperature bursting 90 degrees, Sariya Rodriguez, age 20 months, stepped into the sprinkler section of Printer’s Park in the Longwood section of the Bronx. The water jets — set in the ground in a circle — were resting at the moment, but there were ample puddles for her to stamp with her pink plastic sandals. Suddenly, the water sprung from the jets. Sariya, who had never been in that part of the playground before, now was encircled with dancing streams of water. Her eyes and mouth opened in surprise. She looked up at her mother, Yajaira Rodriguez. Then they both laughed.

headline: U.S. on Protecting Pacific Ocean Areas
text: President Obama, Secretary of State John Kerry and the actor Leonardo DiCaprio expressed their support in protecting areas of the Pacific Ocean from overfishing and environmental damage.

headline: With Altidore in Doubt, Americans Look to Portugal
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As Jozy Altidore was lifted onto a stretcher just 20 minutes into Monday night’s victory over Ghana in Natal, Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national team, leaned over and cradled his striker’s head in his hands.

headline: Yahoo Reveals Work Force Data, Joining Tech’s Small Diversity Parade
text: Defining the scope of a problem is the first step toward solving it.

headline: Schools Chief Vows to Preserve Number of Gifted Programs and Their Exams
text: Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña plans to preserve the hallmarks of New York City’s gifted programs, the immensely popular classes and schools that draw high achievers but have been criticized as shutting out low-income children.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Ocean Monument
text: They are seven sand-and-coral dots in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, far west and south of Hawaii. They are known best, if they are known at all, for guano mining in the 19th century and nuclear tests in the 20th.

headline: In Mississippi, Largess Helped a Senator, Until It Hurt Him
text: HERNANDO, Miss. — Senator Thad Cochran’s critics may disparage him as the “King of Pork.” But to the local politicians in the booming suburbs here in northwest Mississippi, just south of Memphis, it is good to be in the realm of the king.

headline: Accused of Unheroic Acts, a Spider-Man Claims Self-Defense
text: By Times Square standards, the act was nothing extraordinary: A man in a Spider-Man costume was accused of throwing a punch at the mother of two young children after an ugly argument over a tip.

headline: Soccer Fans’ Dream Job Has a Catch: No Peeking
text: FORTALEZA, Brazil — At first blush, it probably sounded like the best job in Brazil.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 17, 2014
A Balancing Act on Iraq
text: President Obama has, so far, struck the right note on Iraq, where Sunni extremist militants are seizing territory and threatening the existence of the state. He has been cautious — emphasizing the need for political reform in Iraq and reaching out to other countries that could have an impact on its fate.

headline: Lawmakers Skeptical on Emails and I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Six additional Internal Revenue Service workers lost emails sought by congressional investigators when their computers crashed, investigators announced Tuesday, escalating Republican suspicions that the employees may have been trying to cover up political targeting of Tea Party organizations.

headline: Bill to Reduce Speed Limit to 25 M.P.H. Gains Favor
text: A proposal to lower the New York City speed limit to 25 miles per hour cleared a critical hurdle on Tuesday, as a bill in the State Senate won the support of the de Blasio administration and some, though not all, traffic safety advocates.

headline: The Limits of the Fed
text: The Federal Reserve is expected to conclude its two-day meeting on Wednesday afternoon with another $10 billion scale-back of its monthly bond purchases. At that pace, the bond-buying program — an effort to stimulate the economy by lowering long-term interest rates — will be over by December at the latest.

headline: Following in a Writer’s Rhythms
text: In “Everybody’s Autobiography,” Gertrude Stein explained why she preferred saints to martyrs. “A really good saint does nothing,” she wrote. “Anybody is more interesting doing nothing than doing something.”

headline: A Woman’s Place at a Pivotal Moment
text: The year is 1972, and a new age of feminism is dawning as women grope to find voices to match their evolving identities. Well, some of them are groping. The female characters in “When We Were Young and Unafraid,” Sarah Treem’s debate-driven new play at City Center Stage 1, appear to have little difficulty articulating their viewpoints or making sure that we know exactly where to place them on a shifting scale of political consciousness.

headline: What You’d Need To Play
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — In 1938, an architect named Alfred Mosher Butts created a word game that evolved from an earlier one he called “Lexiko.” The new game, which criss-crossed letter tiles to form words, used a distribution and points system that he developed after doing a letter-frequency analysis of various sources, including The New York Times.

headline: Talks on Medical Marijuana Bill as Time Starts to Run Out in Albany
text: ALBANY — For a drug known for tranquillity, marijuana has become a very tense issue here.

headline: Woman Sentenced to 41 Months for Fake Water Park Plan
text: An Orange County, N.Y., woman who duped investors out of more than $1 million through a fictional proposal to build a water park for foster children was sentenced on Tuesday to 41 months in prison.

headline: What to Do With the Twins?
text: There is much talk right now about America teaming up with Iran to push back the coalition of Sunni militias that has taken over Mosul and other Sunni towns in western Iraq and Syria. For now, I’d say stay out of this fight — not because it’s the best option, but because it’s the least bad.

headline: With War at Doorstep, Iran Sees Its Revolutionary Guards in a Kinder Light
text: TEHRAN — They came to celebrate the short life of Ali Reza Moshajjari, a local boy from a south Tehran neighborhood and apparently the latest Iranian victim of the escalating sectarian conflict in neighboring Iraq and in Syria.

headline: Stamp Sells for a Record $9.5 Million
text: A tiny square of very old red paper with cut corners — a one-cent postage stamp from the 19th century — sold for $9.5 million on Tuesday, the most ever paid for a stamp at auction, but $500,000 short of the auction house’s $10 million to $20 million presale estimate.

headline: Obama Is Said to Consider Selective Airstrikes on Sunni Militants
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering a targeted, highly selective campaign of airstrikes against Sunni militants in Iraq similar to counterterrorism operations in Yemen, rather than the widespread bombardment of an air war, a senior administration official said on Tuesday.

headline: Obama on Captured Benghazi Suspect
text: President Obama said that Ahmed Abu Khattala, suspected of being the ringleader in the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, was being transported to the United States.

headline: Aftermath of Sadr City Bombing
text: A car bomb was detonated at a crowded outdoor market in the Shiite district of Sadr City in eastern Baghdad.

headline: U.S. Suggests Getting Tougher With Syria on Chemical Weapons Deadline
text: The United States suggested on Tuesday that the global organization responsible for overseeing the ban on chemical weapons would have to take more assertive action than a simple condemnation concerning Syria, which will miss a June 30 deadline for the destruction of its chemical munitions and has been accused of using chlorine-gas bombs in its civil war.

headline: Tanaka’s Bold Brushstrokes Paint Blue Jays Into Corner
text: Masahiro Tanaka’s latest gem, on Tuesday against the Toronto Blue Jays, materialized a little differently from most of his other performances. It seemed to develop slowly, like a mosaic. It was not until the later innings that the full form of his mastery took shape.

headline: Cutting the Poor Out of Welfare
text: Over the past three decades, Congress has conducted a major experiment in anti-poverty policy. Legislators have restructured benefits and tax breaks intended for the poor so that they penalize unmarried, unemployed parents — the modern-day version of the “undeserving poor.” At the same time, working parents, the aged and the disabled are getting larger benefits.

headline: Bringing Turkish Flavors to Boston
text: Ana Sortun built a restaurant group inspired by the subtleties of Eastern Mediterranean cuisine.

headline: Lawyer Not Entitled to See Classified Surveillance Material, Court Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Reversing a potentially groundbreaking ruling, a federal appeals court this week said the government need not show a defense lawyer classified materials related to the national-security surveillance of his client.

headline: Obama, in a First, Attends a ‘Super PAC’ Fund-Raiser
text: President Obama once criticized the flow of money to political action committees, calling it a threat to democracy.

headline: U.S. Defends Prosecuting Benghazi Suspect in Civilian Rather Than Military Court
text: WASHINGTON — Conservative lawmakers on Tuesday sharply criticized the Obama administration’s decision to prosecute the suspected leader of the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, in the civilian criminal justice system, arguing that he should be questioned and tried by the military.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Finale Recap: Morton’s Fork: They’ve Come Undone
text: In the criminal wilderness, invading “Fargo,” people align themselves with good or evil, as protector or predator. Few fall in between.

headline: Sudan: Attack Ravages Hospital
text: A hospital run by the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders was heavily damaged by the Sudanese Air Force in an attack on the village of Farandalla in the South Kordofan region, the group said Tuesday. The group’s head of mission, Brian Moller, expressed shock, “especially since it was clearly identified with a flag and a cross on the roof.” One hospital staff member was hurt, as were five villagers, the group said. Rebels in the region have been fighting the government in Khartoum since 2011.  In recent weeks, the Sudanese government has stepped up its offensive in the region. The Sudanese Army’s press officer could not be reached for comment.

headline: Exercise and the ‘Good’ Bugs in Our Gut
text: Being physically active may encourage beneficial germs to thrive in your gut, while inactivity could do the reverse, according to an innovative new study. The findings suggest that, in addition to its other health benefits, frequent exercise may influence our weight and overall health by altering the kinds of organisms that live inside of us.

headline: Word of the Day | penury
text: penury •\ˈpen-yə-re\• noun

headline: Brazil: Biden and Rousseff Meet
text: President Dilma Rousseff met Tuesday with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as Brazil and the United States moved to improve relations. Ties were strained last year by revelations of surveillance of Ms. Rousseff and other Brazilian officials by the National Security Agency. Mr. Biden told reporters in Brasília that their conversation about the spying was “candid,” while emphasizing the potential for improving ties. He also handed over to Ms. Rousseff declassified documents related to Brazil’s military dictatorship, which seized power in a 1964 coup supported by the United States. Ms. Rousseff is a former Marxist guerrilla who was tortured by agents of the dictatorship. She said this month in an interview that she was prepared for a thaw in ties with Washington.

headline: Canada: Carbon Monoxide Affects Scores at Day Care
text: About 70 children and 10 adults were overcome by carbon monoxide at a day care northwest of Montreal on Tuesday and were rushed to the hospital by ambulances and school buses. Health and fire officials said at a news conference that no one had lost consciousness during the episode in St.-Eustache, Quebec. But the five children with the most severe symptoms were transferred to a larger hospital for further examination. The source of the gas was unclear, but fire officials are investigating the cleaning machinery used in the day care center the previous night.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 18, 2014
text: “There really isn’t much better dietary advice than eating your veggies, exercising and limiting calories. People just seem to like making eating difficult for themselves.”

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 3:05 P.M. (Cinemax) SAVAGES (2012) Two Southern California marijuana dealers — Chon (Taylor Kitsch), a cynical combat veteran, and Ben (Aaron Johnson, above right, with Mr. Kitsch and Blake Lively), a soulful Berkeley graduate — and their gorgeous significant other, O (Ms. Lively), take on Mexican traffickers in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called “Oliver Stone’s feverish, fully baked, half-great adaptation of Don Winslow’s ferocious and funny drug-war novel of the same name.” The film, he added, “is a daylight noir, a western, a stoner buddy movie and a love story, which is to say that it is a bit of a mess. But also a lot of fun, especially as its pulp elements rub up against some gritty geopolitical and economic themes.”

headline: N.C.A.A. Begins Its Turn in Antitrust Case Brought by Athletes
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Christine Plonsky, the director of women’s athletics at the University of Texas, took the stand Tuesday morning in federal court here in an effort to persuade a judge that the N.C.A.A. and its biggest athletics programs are not the commercialized profit centers they have been accused of being by a string of witnesses during the past week and a half.

headline: Georgia Inmate Is Put to Death in First U.S. Execution Since Botched Procedure
text: JACKSON, Ga. — Marcus A. Wellons, who was convicted in the 1989 rape and murder of a teenage girl, was executed at a Georgia prison on Tuesday, becoming the first inmate put to death in the United States since a botched execution in Oklahoma seven weeks ago prompted renewed questions about capital punishment.

headline: Mets, Stifled by Cardinals, Waste Solid Start by Niese
text: ST. LOUIS — The way he pitches, Jon Niese is often overlooked. He is not imposing. He does not throw particularly hard. His strikeout rate is not high. And pitching for the Mets, because of their low-octane offense, he is often deprived of wins.

headline: Citic’s Missing Alumina Prompts Concern Over China Commodities Fraud
text: HONG KONG — Citic Resources, a Chinese state-owned commodities trader, said on Wednesday that it had been unable to locate more than 100,000 tons of alumina at a port in northeast China that is the focus of a commodities fraud investigation.

text: NEW YORK

headline: Rebels Reject Ukrainian Leader’s Cease-Fire Idea
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — After Ukraine’s new president, Petro O. Poroshenko, told reporters in Kiev on Wednesday that he might soon order a temporary, unilateral cease-fire as part of a broader 14-point peace plan, it took all of several seconds for pro-Russian militants to rule it out.

headline: Malaysia Searches for Survivors After Boat Sinks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Five people died when an overloaded wooden passenger ship carrying 97 Indonesians back to their home country sank off the west coast of Malaysia early Wednesday, Malaysian officials said, and search-and-rescue teams were working into the night looking for 32 others who remained missing.

text: In “U.S. Captures Top Suspect in Benghazi Siege, Pentagon Says,” David D. Kirkpatrick and Eric Schmitt report on the capture of a suspect in the 2012 attack on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya.

text: “Weidmann Goes to Guillotine With Firm Step But Eyes Shut”

headline: Betrayal in Charlie Rangel’s Harlem?
text: St. John’s Baptist Church, in the Sugar Hill section of Harlem, is a modest redbrick building, discernible from the buildings on its block by two white Corinthian columns and a large, illuminated plastic cross hanging from the second story. Back in the civil rights era, the church housed a thriving congregation, many of them African-Americans who had fled the South. Its rolls have since dwindled to about 250, but Harlem is a neighborhood eternally preoccupied with its past, and St. John’s remains a place where local power brokers — and former power brokers and aspiring ones, too — gather to debate issues and anoint leaders.

headline: Taking Care of People and Pictures in Hong Kong
text: A stream of images from Hong Kong caught Rick Rocamora’s attention on Facebook: black and white street scenes, with dramatic light and compositions that ranged from kinetic to serene. The fact that the photographer, Xyza Cruz Bacani, was from the Philippines — like Mr. Rocamora — intrigued him, though he was reluctant to contact her.

headline: British Property Website Zoopla Valued at $1.5 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Zoopla Property Group, a British real estate listings website, was valued at more than $1.5 billion in its initial public offering in London on Wednesday.

headline: Setting Sour Words Aside, Li Keqiang Begins Visit to Britain
text: After an exchange of unflattering comments between the Chinese and British sides threatened to overshadow Prime Minister Li Keqiang’s trip to Britain, sunny skies greeted him on Tuesday, the first full day of his visit. Following a meeting with Queen Elizabeth II in the morning, the second-ranking Chinese leader met with Prime Minister David Cameron at 10 Downing Street for talks and lunch with business leaders.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: A Scorcher, for Real
text: A sticky Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Dutch Coach Keeps Expectations in Check
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — The excellent news for Louis van Gaal is that the Netherlands beat Spain, 5-1. The bad news for Louis van Gaal is that the Netherlands beat Spain, 5-1.

headline: Japan Outlaws Possession of Child Pornography, but Comic Book Depictions Survive
text: TOKYO — Yielding to years of pressure to fall in line with the rest of the developed world, Japan’s Parliament outlawed the possession of child pornography on Wednesday. But the new law left untouched the nation’s popular and sometimes sexually explicit manga comics as well as other portrayals of young girls as objects of sexual desire.

headline: Insurgency in Iraq Widens Rivals’ Rift
text: Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, Islamic rivals of the Middle East, appeared to escalate on Wednesday over the Sunni extremist insurgency convulsing Iraq, as President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared readiness to defend Iraq’s Shiite holy sites with force and Saudi leaders issued a barely veiled admonishment not to intervene.

headline: Daily Report: AT&T and Udacity Create Online ‘NanoDegree’ Program
text: This week, AT&T and Udacity, an online education company founded by the Stanford professor and former Google engineering whiz Sebastian Thrun, announced something meant to be very small, Eduardo Porter reports: the “NanoDegree.”

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times welcomes the news that President Obama will double the area of protected waters in the Pacific Ocean. “The United States does not have an Amazon basin,” the editorial board writes, “but it has the watery equivalent, a paradise of turtles and sharks, seals and dolphins, coral reefs and giant clams, frigate birds and boobies.” Mr. Obama is expanding on the legacy of his predecessor, George W. Bush — a fact The Times finds heartening: “Environmental conservation has a long bipartisan history in this country. These remote waters are a part of America most citizens may never see, but they should be thankful that presidents, of both parties, had the foresight to protect them.”

headline: Extremists Attack Iraq’s Biggest Oil Refinery
text: BAGHDAD — Refinery workers, witnesses and an Iraqi Army officer reported the seizure of Iraq’s biggest oil refinery by Sunni extremists on Wednesday after army helicopter gunships failed to repel their attack. But other Iraqi officials, including the commander of the garrison defending the refinery in Baiji, asserted that fighting was still going on inside the extensive facility, shut down by the violence.

headline: Ackman’s S.E.C. Filing on Bid for Botox Maker Allergan Contains an Error
text: William A. Ackman has made billions on a reputation for being the smartest guy in the room. Sometimes, it turns out, even the smartest guy can be wrong.

headline: What Makes a Great Editor? Part 2.
text: “Only Southerners have taken horsewhips and pistols to editors about the treatment or maltreatment of their manuscript. This — the actual pistols — was in the old days, of course, we no longer succumb to the impulse. But it is still there, still within us.”

headline: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen: Ana Sortun
text: This is part 2 of a two-part series on entrepreneurial female chefs. Last week, we spoke with Jody Adams.

headline: G.A.O. Tech Chief Says Washington Should Start Small on Big Projects
text: When it comes to technology, Washington needs to learn how to fail smaller.

headline: Push Polls, Defined
text: “Push polls” — which are not really polls at all — are often criticized as a particularly sleazy form of negative political campaigning. Voters pick up the phone to hear what sounds like a research poll. But there is no effort to collect information, which is what a legitimate poll does.

headline: U.N. Report Details Casualties in Eastern Ukraine
text: GENEVA — Hundreds of people have been killed and thousands have fled their homes amid rising violence, insecurity and crime in areas of eastern Ukraine that are under the control of pro-Russia armed groups, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

headline: Bain Capital Ventures Raises $935 Million to Back Growth Firms
text: In a sign of continued investor enthusiasm for venture capital deals, Bain Capital Ventures has raised $935 million to back young companies, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Wrestling With Heartache in a Birthplace of Soul
text: At this point, the Apollo Theater exists largely in totemic form, a repository of credibility available for loan to those seeking to cloak themselves in its legacy, whether out of homage or insecurity. Its meaning is fungible, whatever its occupant for the night needs it to be.

headline: Morning Agenda: SunTrust in Mortgage Settlement
text: The Federal government reached a $968 million settlement on Tuesday with SunTrust Banks over questionable mortgage practices, underscoring how state and federal authorities have been targeting banks beyond Wall Street, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. But even as the government reached one settlement, its talks to resolve mortgage issues with one of the nation’s largest banks, Citigroup, grew increasingly tense and veered toward a lawsuit.

headline: PEN Announces Shortlists for 2014 Book Prizes
text: The PEN American Center today announced the shortlists of finalists for its 2014 PEN Literary Awards. Taken together, the awards, fellowships and grants from the literary and human rights organization total nearly $150,000 for writers, editors and translators.

headline: The Hillary Clinton-Fashion Love Affair Continues
text: If anyone is wondering which potential presidential candidate the fashion world may support in 2016, I think the question is fast being put to rest.
