text: Dear Diary:

headline: Palestinian Leader Pledges to Hold Abductors of Israeli Teenagers to Account
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Wednesday strongly denounced the kidnappers of three Israeli teenagers who went missing in the West Bank six days ago and said he would hold the perpetrators accountable.

headline: Soft Money’s Squishy Political Influence
text: To congressional campaign workers, the groups that can raise and spend unlimited donations can seem like unpredictable wedding guests: You don’t know when they’ll show up, what they’ll bring or whether their presence will prove a welcome distraction or a disaster.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 London Men’s Shows
text: A peek at what some of the peacocks in London were wearing.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Situation in Iraq Worsening
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington.

headline: Obama and Lawmakers Meet to Discuss Iraq Action
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and congressional leaders on Wednesday privately confronted the politically delicate question of whether Mr. Obama would be required to ask Congress for permission to take military action against Sunni fighters in Iraq, but emerged from an hourlong Oval Office meeting with different views of what was said.

headline: Europe May Be in a Recession (Still)
text: Is the European economy expanding, or is it in recession? Turns out, even the people whose job it is to decide aren’t sure. And their reasoning shows why the economic situation seems so perilous in Europe, even though its economy isn’t clearly shrinking. In fact, part of their hesitation to call the end of the recession stems from their fear that policy makers may not be sufficiently concerned about the state of the economy.

headline: It’s So Immersive, You Even Get Wet
text: Theater doesn’t really have an equivalent of the summer blockbuster. If anything, the home of the biggest, showiest spectacles — Broadway — is usually quiet during the hot months, with few new openings. But if you’re looking for high-energy fun and empty-headed action accessible to anyone, head to Union Square, where the high-flying acrobats from “Fuerza Bruta: Wayra” will splash around in giant pools over your head. From the makers of “De la Guarda,” this show, which opens at the Daryl Roth Theater on Friday, is an expanded version of a production that ran in New York from 2007 until January, with 20 new minutes added.

headline: Boston Bombing Suspect Seeking Change of Trial Venue
text: BOSTON — Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in last year’s marathon bombings, said Wednesday that their client could not receive a fair trial in Boston or elsewhere in the state, and asked for the trial to be moved to Washington.

headline: Spain’s Incoming King Takes Over a Throne Heavy With Political Tension
text: MADRID — This year, while visiting a telecom conference in Barcelona, Crown Prince Felipe worked the room as the heir apparent to the Spanish throne, smiling and glad-handing the crowd, until he ran into a Catalan businessman who refused to shake his hand because of the Spanish monarchy’s opposition to a planned independence referendum in Catalonia this fall.

headline: In the Euro Zone, Recession Is Not Quite Over, Economists Say
text: FRANKFURT — Many people probably thought the euro zone recession ended about a year ago when output began growing again. Not so, a group of leading economists argued this week.

headline: The Democrats United?
text: Vox’s Matthew Yglesias, seconded by my colleague Paul Krugman, has written a seven-point response to my argument that the Democratic coalition is more fragile, and more dependent on Hillary Clinton’s unique strengths, than many people (mostly liberals) tend to think. Yglesias’s rebuttal focuses on the Democratic Party’s apparent lack of deep policy divisions, which he regards as the main reason why there’s so little opposition to Clinton at the moment. “It is impossible,” he writes, “to mount a coherent anti-Clinton campaign because there is no issue that divides the mass of Democrats.” There’s no equivalent of the intra-Democrat war over the Iraq War that gave us Dean v. Kerry and than Obama v. Clinton; the neoliberal/populist debate over Wall Street is muddled and complicated; there’s unanimity on the need to tackle inequality; the education reform debate is real but doesn’t matter enough at the federal level to shape presidential politics; and the party’s demographic diversity coexists with increasing ideological conformity. Then as his parting point, he notes that polarization and partisan rancor make it hard to imagine either political coalition truly dissolving any time soon: The collapses of the past, “where one party’s candidate gets utterly blown away … simply can’t happen under modern conditions.”

headline: Pro-Democracy Media Company’s Websites Attacked
text: Next Media, which publishes Apple Daily, an independent Hong Kong newspaper often critical of the Chinese government, saw the largest attack ever against the company’s websites on Wednesday, taking the group’s websites offline for hours.

headline: What’s on Your New York City Reverse Bucket List?
text: Future comments on this post have been closed. We have published a selection of our favorite reverse bucket list items from readers here.

headline: A Darker View of the Age of Us – the Anthropocene
text: I alerted a batch of scholars and scientists focused on climate change and sustainable development to my taped talk on “Paths to a ‘Good’ Anthropocene” at the annual meeting of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences.

headline: Barra Faces Scrutiny in House Over G.M. Recalls
text: WASHINGTON — Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, walked into a crowded House hearing on Wednesday with her high-powered lawyer at her side, confident that his exhaustive internal investigation about a deadly defect would convince lawmakers that G.M. is taking safety seriously.

headline: Just How Were Those Underwater Babies Photographed?
text: What better way to welcome summer’s arrival than with pictures of happy babies underwater? The June 15 Look features children from 4 months to 22 months during infant survival swim training in Kissimmee, Fla. They were photographed by Seth Casteel, who specializes in animal photography and is publishing a book called “Underwater Puppies” in September. Here, Casteel talks about what babies and dogs have in common when they’re all wet.

headline: Valeant Takes New Step to Pressure Botox Maker Into Sale
text: Updated, 12:07 p.m. |

headline: A Glimpse of Syrian Lives Ravaged by War in Homs
text: Anne Barnard, the Beirut bureau chief for The New York Times, traveled to Syria recently and reported her experiences in Damascus and Homs via Twitter. Her social media dispatches provided a rare view into the dire circumstances in Syria where the three-year conflict has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians and left millions displaced. And she shared some poignant reactions to the devastation there.

headline: Right Out of Hollywood, a Witness to History
text: In the summer of 1964, Richard Beymer — the actor who a few years earlier had made a splash playing Tony in the film of “West Side Story” — furiously drove his Austin-Healy from Los Angeles to rural Mississippi. He was going to join the hundreds of young people heading there, mostly white students from the North, who would become part of the audacious civil-rights campaign known as Freedom Summer.

headline: St. George, S.I.: Framed by the Harbor
text: In praise of St. George, a historic neighborhood on Staten Island that gazes on New York Harbor, residents invariably mention the free ferry to Manhattan. They often cite the affordability of a place where one-bedroom apartments can cost less than half of what they go for in pricier parts of the city. And they might even point out the wondrously out-of-place look of some blocks, with fanciful Victorians on steep hills that can feel cut-and-pasted from San Francisco.

headline: Jay Leno to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
text: Have you heard about this? Have you seen this? Jay Leno, the doggedly populist comedy monologist and former host of the “Tonight” show, will be the next recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, the prize’s organizers said Wednesday.

headline: Daring Deeds
text: In Nick Bertozzi’s graphic novel “Shackleton,” the great man who between 1901 and 1921 embarked on four attempts to reach the South Pole is first depicted in a moment of total failure. So sick with scurvy that he can scarcely lift his head from his pillow — let alone pull a loaded sledge — Shackleton is ordered back to England, forced to abandon Robert Falcon Scott’s Discovery expedition. But he is determined to return to the Antarctic, despite his wife’s entreaties (“The children are growing so quickly”!) and the claims of common sense. Though it’s easy to miss in Bertozzi’s telling, Shackleton went back about 5 years later, leading the Nimrod expedition, which came within 97 miles of reaching the South Pole. He managed to secure funding for a third attempt in August 1914, on the eve of the First World War. It is this famed adventure that is the focus of “Shackleton.”

headline: Charges Against Simon and Brickell Are Dropped
text: The disorderly conduct charges that were brought against Paul Simon and Edie Brickell after a domestic dispute in late April were dropped by prosecutors in a Norwalk, Conn., courtroom on Tuesday. Mr. Simon and Ms. Brickell, who had made a court appearance when the charges were brought, did not appear to hear them dismissed, The Associated Press reported.

headline: HelloFresh, a Meal Delivery Start-Up, Raises $50 Million
text: The race for dominance in the dinner-kit delivery business — where companies ship out packages of fresh ingredients for specific recipes, ready for customers to turn into home-cooked meals — is intensifying.

headline: Latinos Onscreen, Conspicuously Few
text: If you went to the movies in 1946, when Latinos constituted barely 3 percent of the American population, you might have caught Carmen Miranda, reportedly the highest-paid woman in the world at the time, dancing with her improbably tall fruit hat. By the 1950s, Desi Arnaz graced network TV as a star of “I Love Lucy.”

headline: Redskins Lose Ruling on Trademarks, but Fight Isn’t Over
text: For years, the N.F.L. and the Washington Redskins have defended the team’s name by claiming that it is a sign of honor and bravery, not a slur. When critics disagreed, the team pointed to a survey showing that a majority of Native Americans supported the name.

headline: Cherries Go Savory, Sweet and Boozy
text: They can be in every part of a meal, including a cocktail.

headline: Australia vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: The Netherlands is virtually assured to make the knockout stage, although that would change should Australia somehow pull off a shocker here. For the Socceroos, a point in any of their matches would be a triumph.

headline: In Our Pages: June 19
text: 1939: Million-Ton Rocket Needed

headline: WETA to Take Ownership of ‘PBS NewsHour’
text: WETA, the Washington, D.C., public broadcaster, is expected to take over ownership and control of “PBS NewsHour” on July 1 from the program’s longtime owner, MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, the station announced Wednesday. Approval for the transfer came late Tuesday at a meeting of the WETA board of trustees.

headline: U.S. Opens Safety Review of Chryslers
text: Concern over the safety of ignition switches is spreading beyond General Motors cars.

headline: Wheelies: The Black Plate Special Edition
text: ■ California has received the 7,500 preorders required to begin reproducing its classic yellow-on-black license, says a report from Hemmings Daily. The plates, which were originally issued from 1963-69, will be made with a reflective finish that complies with state laws. The plates will be available in nine to 12 months. (Hemmings Daily)

headline: A Conversation With Health Minister Harsh Vardhan
text: Dr. Harsh Vardhan was sworn in as the new union minister of health on May 26, taking over a ministry with substantial challenges.

headline: Character Study: Corey Kilgannon
text: Corey Kilgannon writes the Character Study column weekly for the Metropolitan section. In a video shot by two journalism students, Mr. Kilgannon becomes the subject of their character study.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,300,000
text: WASHINGTON, D.C.

headline: How to Build a Better Neighborhood
text: A great public place gives residents of a neighborhood a sense of belonging, pride, connection and beauty. But too many neighborhoods have no such place. Some have been destroyed by recession, with shuttered businesses and boarded-up buildings. Others are simply soulless, built for cars, not people, featuring strip malls that require driving instead of places for residents to walk, bike, play or gather.

headline: A Retailer and Vintner Recalls Her Bohemian Hamptons Upbringing
text: Joey Wölffer, 32, the founder of the mobile shopping truck the Styleliner and co-owner of Wölffer Estate Vineyard, recalls the Hamptons of her childhood as a very different place: “miles and miles of potato fields” and “a low-key vibe inspired by artists, poets and writers.”

headline: Is This the Beginning of the End of the Redskins’ Team Name?
text: We can only guess the exact volume and color of the steam coming out of Daniel Snyder’s ears right about now. Wednesday morning, the United States Patent and Trademark Office canceled the trademark for the Washington Redskins, the pro football team that Mr. Snyder owns — and that he has steadfastly refused to rename, amid accusations that its mascot is racist.

headline: Candidate’s Protest Clouds Afghan Vote-Counting for President
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s presidential election was cast into crisis on Wednesday as the candidate Abdullah Abdullah announced a boycott of the electoral process, accusing his opponent and President Hamid Karzai of engineering huge fraud in the runoff vote on Saturday.

headline: A Retiree, 89, Is Held in Deaths at Auschwitz
text: WASHINGTON — The 89-year-old Johann Breyer shuffled unsteadily into a federal courtroom in Philadelphia on Wednesday morning, using a cane for support as he sank slowly into a chair at the defense table.

headline: The ISIS Advance Provokes the West and Arab States
text: As the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, or ISIS, advances in Iraq, many eyes are trained on Washington and on the governments of Mesopotamia. Two questions are being hotly debated: First, will the United States take military action to prop up a fragile government it left in place after a decade of battle and more than 4,000 casualties? And, at a higher level, what does ISIS’s rise say about the prospects of an effective governance ever being established in the region?

headline: House Hunting in ... Sweden
text: A MODERN FOUR-BEDROOM WATERFRONT VILLA OUTSIDE STOCKHOLM

headline: Police Bullying on Tape
text: “Because I want you to go away and not stand here and argue with me. Otherwise you’re about to get locked up.”

headline: Ask Martha Rose Shulman
text: Have a question for Martha? With the Ruder family traveling next week, she’ll be taking questions from readers instead. Have a vegetable you don’t know what to do with? A recipe that never works? Tired of your go-to spinach? Ask Martha here, and look for answers to the most common or interesting dilemmas next Wednesday, June 25.

headline: Detroit Rolls Out New Model: A Hybrid Pension Plan
text: In the face of Detroit’s tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, in which multiple parties are quarreling to protect their interests, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments.

headline: Arguing About the Truth of Disruption
text: “Most big ideas have loud critics,” writes Jill Lepore in The New Yorker. “Not disruption.”

headline: Abdullah Halts Work on Afghan Vote Count
text: Abdullah Abdullah, a candidate for Afghanistan’s presidency, said he suspended work with the country’s electoral bodies and asked officials to stop counting votes because of widespread fraud.

headline: A Gilded Monument Is Mysteriously Shedding Its Brand-New Gold
text: Crazing. You know what it is if you’ve ever looked at your grandparents’ chinaware and discerned a web of hairline cracks fracturing the glaze.

headline: App Smart | Going Green
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

headline: For Ideas on How to Live Greener, Think Mobile
text: SMARTPHONES and tablets may not seem to be designed with the environment in mind, being made of complex layers of plastics, metals and electronics, with chemical batteries. But apps may help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

headline: BBC Anchor Who Delighted in Blistering Politicians Steps Down
text: LONDON — Famed for his combative questions, disdainful delivery and lack of deference, Jeremy Paxman, one of Britain’s best-known broadcasters, on Wednesday made his last appearance on the TV program he has dominated for a quarter of a century.

headline: MoMA to Host Bjork Retrospective Next Year
text: The Museum of Modern Art will present what it is calling a full-scale retrospective of the Icelandic rock composer, singer and otherworldly fashion-plate Bjork next year. The exhibition, which the museum announced on Wednesday, is being organized by Klaus Biesenbach, the museum’s chief curator at large. The retrospective will run from March 7 to June 7, 2015.

headline: France Sees Double Standard in U.S. Prosecution of BNP, but Justice Is Weak
text: Events in the Middle East and Ukraine demonstrate that the United States can’t always be the world’s policeman. But there is one arena where it is still the top cop on the block: corporate law enforcement.

headline: Amid the Tombstones, a Look Back at Life
text: Given Thornton Wilder’s specification that “Our Town” be presented in minimalist fashion, you wonder what he would have made of Brooklyn’s majestic Green-Wood Cemetery as a theatrical setting. There is no curtain, of course, in this presentation by the Green-Wood Historic Fund of Wilder’s drama, only the wind rushing through the tall trees and the jets streaking overhead and the glittering spires of Manhattan in the distance. It doesn’t get more urban Americana than this.

headline: YouTube to Block Videos From Some Indie Labels
text: Soon to disappear from YouTube: videos by Vampire Weekend, the Arctic Monkeys and perhaps hundreds of other independent musicians.

headline: Report on New York City’s Underground Infrastructure
text: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio issued a report on the city’s underground infrastructure on Wednesday.

headline: Fire Dept. Is Now Responding to All Gas-Odor Calls
text: New York City’s Fire Department has started responding to all reports of gas odors that the city receives, a significant change in policy put into effect in the wake of an explosion in East Harlem in March that killed eight people.

headline: Google Ready to Comply With ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Rules in Europe
text: LONDON — Your right to be forgotten on the Internet is almost here.

headline: Bachfest Celebrates Monteverdi Choir’s 50th Anniversary
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — If ever there was a composer to be celebrated on Father’s Day, it is Bach. Of his 20 children, 10 died in infancy or early childhood, but that still left his hands full. And though inhumanly busy with composition, performance and teaching, he took an active hand in the children’s upbringing and education.

headline: Can’t Fake the Funk
text: In its small confines between the Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Clinton Hill is home to multimillion-dollar historic brownstones and towering housing projects. The area is a mix of young professionals, Pratt Institute art students and locals whose families have lived in the area for generations.

headline: Porsche Tops J.D. Power Initial Quality Study for Second Consecutive Year
text: The 2014 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study found that new vehicle owners experienced more problems with their vehicles than the previous year’s respondents, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Image of the Day: June 18
text: Dmitry Rogozin, deputy prime minister of Russia, is on a two-day official visit to India.

headline: Today in Small Business: Banking on Belts
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Iraq Under a Colder Eye
text: Let me be clear, as the president would say: Like many better-informed people, I have no definite idea what our current strategy should be in Iraq, and unlike some of them I’m willing to admit it. In the same lukewarm/conflicted way that I supported the 2007 surge, I’m semi-persuaded by the Dexter Filkins argument (amplified here by Reihan Salam) that a residual American force might have made a difference in the current mess — constraining the Maliki government’s sectarian impulses, stiffening up the Iraqi Army’s backbone, giving us better intelligence about ISIS’s development. But that’s pure hindsight, and looking forward most of the strategic options being discussed look somewhat fantastical, from the invasion 2.0 favored by the editors of The Weekly Standard (in which “special operators, and perhaps regular U.S. military units” would rout ISIS, and then somehow re-join together what Maliki has very deliberately put asunder) to the ally-with-Tehran option advanced as the thinking internationalist’s alternative (which even its advocates acknowledge requires lending U.S. resources to the cause of a “strengthened expansionary Iran”), to the “targeted” air strikes reportedly being contemplated by the administration (which, as a certain general with some in-theater experience just pointed out, would risk turning the U.S. military into “the air force for Shia militias”).

headline: In Israel, Masks With a Past
text: It is a tiny yet haunting exhibit: just 12 stone masks, primitive faces with only holes for eyes, small gaping mouths without lips and uneven, spiky teeth.

headline: With Blood Pressure, Lower Is Not Always Better
text: In treating people with high blood pressure, most experts believe that the lower the better. But a new study suggests that that there are limits beyond which there is no benefit.

headline: Vegetarian Meals Are a Success, But the Real Win Is Learning to Plan Ahead
text: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, they tried a Big Bowl with Black Beans, Greens, Avocado and Salsa Fresca.

headline: Select Home Care Weighs New Wage and Labor Regulations
text: SELECT HOME CARE, based in Westlake Village, Calif., offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. It has nine offices, 500 employees and more than $10 million in annual revenue.

headline: Listen Up | A Danish Duo Gets Moody With Ukuleles
text: In their early 20s, Rasmus Bak and Bjarke Niemann bonded over a shared love of ambient music. Nearly 10 years later, on a whim, the Danish pals embarked on a journey from Copenhagen to upstate New York, where they spent seven days with 20 bottles of wine and two ukuleles in the Rubber House, a desolate black building covered with neoprene sheeting once owned by the actor Willem Dafoe. There, isolated from the outside world and surrounded by woods, their new musical project, Death Has No Dominion, was born.

headline: Delaware Museum Faces Sanctions From Directors’ Group
text: The Delaware Art Museum, which recently began to sell works of art to help dig its way out of debt incurred by a 2005 expansion and renovation, has been sanctioned by the Association of Art Museum Directors, which said the museum’s actions “violated one of the most basic and important” principles of a collecting institution.

headline: Britain’s Thaw With Iran, Coming at a Crucial Juncture, Could Be Useful to Allies
text: LONDON — With the election of a relatively moderate president in Iran and the rise of radical Sunni fighters in Syria and Iraq, Britain is pressing ahead to improve relations with Iran and reopen its embassy in Tehran.

headline: How Should Select Home Care Adjust to New Wage and Labor Regulations?
text: We’ve just published a case study about Select Home Care, based in Westlake Village, Calif., which offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. As the article explains, Select is confronting an array of regulatory changes that will necessitate shorter shifts, more employees and higher wages.

headline: BlackBerry to Add Amazon App Store to Phones
text: OTTAWA — In a side story to Amazon’s expected move into the smartphone business, the ailing handset maker BlackBerry said on Wednesday that it would include Amazon’s app store on its phones.

headline: Thirteen in Years, but 10 or 15 in Thoughts and Action
text: Gather together a random assortment of 13-year-olds, and you’ll likely find yourself looking at a group of people who have only their age in common. Some will be way into teenage culture, into hanging out and hooking up, even into alcohol and drugs; others will be little changed from the children they were at 12, 11, even 10 years of age, still singing the songs and playing the games of children.

headline: For Vietnam and China, No Easing of Tensions
text: HONG KONG — China and Vietnam exchanged sharp views Wednesday in their dispute over a Chinese oil rig deployed in contested waters in the South China Sea near Vietnam’s coast and appear to have made little headway in cooling tensions, according to accounts by both governments summarizing a top-level meeting in Hanoi.

headline: Street Style at Florence’s Pitti Uomo
text: Fashion from outside the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo.

headline: Federal Reserve Sees Slower Growth, but Maintains Plans to Trim Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday sharply cut its economic forecast for 2014 even as it said the economy had bounced back after a nasty winter, allowing the central bank, in its view, to continue to retreat from its stimulus campaign.

headline: Ban on Gun ‘Straw Purchases’ Survives, But Only Just
text: The Supreme Court came alarmingly close this week to eviscerating one of the most important gun safety rules on the books — the federal ban on “straw purchases.”

headline: Spain vs. Chile: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Spain must win or their title defense will be over. Chile can probably afford a loss, but would much rather get a point or three to make their final game less crucial.

headline: Messaging App Gets People Talking With One Word: Yo
text: Some technology start-ups want to cure the world’s ills. Others want to disrupt major industries. One app has a strategy that amounts to a single word.

headline: Fire Phone Immerses Users in Amazon’s World
text: SEATTLE — Amazon on Wednesday announced a device that tries to fulfill the retailer’s dream of being integrated into consumers’ lives at every possible waking moment — whether they are deciding where to eat, realizing they need more toilet paper or intrigued by a snatch of overheard music.

headline: G.E. to Propose Sweeteners to Its Alstom Offer
text: PARIS — Jeffrey R. Immelt, the General Electric chairman and chief executive, is heading back to France with sweeteners for his $13.5 billion bid for Alstom, hoping to lure the government away from a rival offer from Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries.

headline: Readers Mourn the Loss of ‘The Gun Report’
text: Gun violence has rarely been more relevant in America than it is right now, so a recent decision to discontinue “The Gun Report” on Joe Nocera’s blog struck many readers as a simply terrible idea. My office has received more than 100 complaints or laments that it has been discontinued; they don’t seem to be a part of a writing campaign but an outpouring from individuals with strong feelings.

headline: Elon Musk’s Halo Effect
text: Elon Musk is applying his magic touch to mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Rail Strike Strands French and Tests Their President
text: PARIS — Now entering its second week, the national railway strike here has stranded thousands and exasperated millions more. It has brought on even more stress for high school students trying to reach their nationwide graduation test sites; upended business trips, hospital visits, vacations and daily commutes; and cost the state rail system upward of $250 million (about 184.2 million euros).

headline: Mother Charged With Fatal Poisoning of 5-Year-Old Boy
text: Lacey Spears’s struggle seemed like every mother’s worst nightmare. From the moment her son was born, she said, he was afflicted with never-ending illnesses.

headline: ‘Soul Doctor’ Will Return, Off Broadway
text: “Soul Doctor,” the musical about the guitar-strumming, folksong-composing rabbi Shlomo Carlebach that had a brief Broadway run at Circle in the Square in 2013, will return in an off-Broadway production at the Actors Temple Theater. Previews begin on Nov. 25; the show opens on Dec. 13. Jeremy Chess is producing. Casting details for the production have not been announced.

headline: Indictment of Lacey Spears
text: Ms. Spears, 26, was arrested and charged with murder in the death of her 5-year-old son on Tuesday.

headline: Redskins Trademark: A Primer on the Cancellation
text: The United States Patent and Trademark Office’s decision Wednesday to cancel the Washington Redskins’ trademark registration will probably increase calls for the N.F.L. team to change its name.

headline: The Scene at Pitti Uomo
text: At the international men’s trade show at Pitti Uomo in Florence, a thousand or more exhibitors set up in a chaotic cluster of pavilions scattered throughout fairgrounds inside the 16th century Fortezza da Basso.

headline: Intel Introduces Custom Cloud Chip
text: Intel is solving a tough business problem, using a little technical innovation.

headline: G.M.’s Chief on Staff and Restructuring
text: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, returned before a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee and said the implementation of new safety reviews and procedures are underway.

headline: A Retro-Flavored Playlist from the Spring/Summer 2015 London Men’s Shows
text: During a typical show season, there is usually one genre-crossing Top 40 track that gets played ad nauseam — on the runways, during presentations, at parties — until it has been beaten into the brains of showgoers. Thankfully, the spring/summer 2015 London men’s shows offered a diverse and unexpected soundtrack. There was late ’90s and early ’00s R&B and hip-hop at Astrid Andersen, which used “Affirmative Action” by the short-lived super group the Firm, and at MAN, where the finale, “Freak Me” by Silk, was like bedroom music for the collection of duvet-worthy linens and pillowcase-shaped bags. At the Agi & Sam after-party, Black Rob’s 2000 track “Whoa” got everyone (including fellow designer Matthew Miller) onto the dance floor. At the other end of the sonic spectrum, Topman presented a trio of nostalgic songs by contemporary bands — Temples, Saint Etienne and Tame Impala — that fit the retro-inspired collection without making it feel dated.

headline: The Next-Generation Fitness Bands
text: Molly Wood reviews the LG Lifeband Touch and the Samsung Gear Fit, two wearable devices that marry fitness bands with smartwatches.

headline: Fitness Devices That Do (Just) a Bit More
text: WEARABLE technology is having an identity crisis.

headline: Jack White Hits No. 1, With Strong Vinyl Sales
text: When it comes to the music charts, a victory for Jack White is a victory for vinyl.

headline: When Mysterious Symptoms Strike a Small Town
text: Megan Abbott is a seasoned, Edgar Award-winning author with exceptional gifts for making nerves jangle and skin crawl. She is also skilled at turning teenage sexuality into cause for squirming, “like watching a movie with her dad and suddenly there’s a scene you don’t want to watch with your dad,” as Deenie, the heroine of her latest, “The Fever,” nicely puts it.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': John Lithgow’s Shakespeare in the Park Diary
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park. His first report follows.

headline: Shift Emerges in Europe on Focus on Austerity
text: BRUSSELS — France and Italy, still struggling to meet the euro zone’s tough budget targets, may be gaining support for an effort to relax the rules.

headline: Ivory Coast’s Cornerstone Becomes a Catalyst
text: BRASÍLIA — Perhaps it was the moment when Didier Drogba rose from the bench to warm up, drawing the attention of almost everyone at Arena Pernambuco in Recife, Brazil. Or maybe it was when he stood poised to enter the game, inspiring his teammates with just his nearing presence.

headline: Times Square Spider-Man Found Not Guilty of Assault
text: Extra! Extra! Read all about it: Spider-Man Is Not Guilty!

headline: What Janet Yellen Is Trying to Tell Us
text: One huge question was hanging over the Federal Reserve before Wednesday’s Fed-a-palooza. And in the course of a statement after the central bank’s policy meeting; new forecasts for the economy and interest rates; and a Q. and A. from Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, it got at least a semblance of an answer.

headline: City Ballet to Add a Week to Its Saratoga Residency
text: The Saratoga Performing Arts Center has found a way to stop the New York City Ballet’s slow disappearing act. Having seen the company’s residency dwindle from four weeks to three in 1978, then from three weeks to two in 2009 and then to a single week in 2013 and this year, mainly because the cost of presenting the company was outstripping the center’s ability to raise money to pay for it, the center’s board of directors announced on Tuesday that it would reverse that trend: when the City Ballet returns to Saratoga in 2015, it will be for a two-week season.

headline: An Evening of Sonic Exploration on Keyboards, Electronic and Otherwise
text: All composers are interested in sound, but Anthony Cheung more than most. His orchestral work “Fog Mobiles” (2010) has its horn soloist create tones that suggest foghorns heard from various distances. “Lyra,” first performed last week by the New York Philharmonic, calls for shimmering transitions between a live ensemble and taped music.

headline: In House G.O.P.’s Leadership Fight, the Main Event Is Still to Come
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans will vote on their leadership on Thursday, but the outcome will essentially keep them in a holding pattern, with the real contest months if not years away.

headline: Pop-Up Restaurants on the Rails
text: Stars of London’s restaurant scene will be periodically hopping aboard the vintage Art Deco cars of the British Pullman, one of several luxury trains operated by Belmond, the former Orient Express Hotels Group, to serve as one-night-only pop-up chefs.

headline: Watch for Low-Flying Angels
text: “Dominion,” beginning Thursday night on Syfy, is a television series spun off from a movie. But we’re not talking about something like “The Avengers” or even, say, “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” The source in this case is the little-noticed 2010 film “Legion,” in which a motley crew of humans, holed up in a desert diner, fight off a crew of malevolent angels with the help of the archangel Michael, who takes our side for one reason or another. Maybe pity? Hey, it’s been a while.

headline: Families of G.M. Victims Speak Out
text: Relatives at a news conference provided accounts of accidents that they say involved General Motors’ ignition defect.

headline: Summer Fashion for the Sandal Averse
text: Summertime footwear can be extreme: too-high strappy sandals that are simply painful; or, on the trendier front, all of those Birkenstocks and Teva styles. And maybe you’re just not a woman who is crazy about showing off her feet. In the face of all that, demure closed-toe pumps are now looking right, and nicely refined, for the office and for evening hours. At the recent CFDA awards, Marion Cotillard, left, glorious as always, wore a Dior pair with her haute couture dress. Few of us will be wearing couture, but we can pull off the elegant statement with any of these closed-toe options and, perhaps, a pencil skirt and mannish button-down or a smart cocktail dress.

headline: A School Is a Jungle Where Teeth Are Bared
text: Funny thing about the Neanderthals. Although scientists tell us that these cave men cousins of ours became extinct about 30,000 years ago, they have a way of reappearing in contemporary society, especially classrooms.

headline: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Says He Is Healthy
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul knows he had an unproductive season last year as he recovered from back surgery. But he feels some people around the N.F.L. have been too quick to declare that his days as a Pro Bowl-caliber player are over.

headline: Amazon’s Phone: It’s Not About the Phone, Really
text: You’ve probably heard that Amazon introduced a phone today, called the Fire. But are phones already so yesterday?

headline: A Rare Double, Even by the Mets’ Standards, Helps Prevent a Sweep
text: ST. LOUIS — There is an old baseball saying that goes something like this: Every day at the ballpark, you might see something new.

headline: ‘No Body Talk’ Summer Camps
text: Last August, on a clear summer day, Tom and Maura Gould were driving their 12-year-old daughter from Eden Village, an organic farming camp in Putnam Valley, N.Y., to their home in Cambridge, Mass., when they started talking about family members who were particularly hairy.

headline: Farewells, and Some More Questions, for Press Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — At the top of his last briefing as White House press secretary on Wednesday, Jay Carney acknowledged to his adversaries in the news media “how hard it can get in here, how hot it can sometimes be.”

headline: Curating the Décor
text: AGE 29

headline: Amazon’s Fire and the Real Cost of Switching Phones
text: Amazon’s new phone has loads of features: the ability to recognize thousands of products in stores, supposedly tangle-free earbud cords and a screen that gives images the illusion of depth.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Going Past the Grave to Gain His Love
text: Playing the character of Giselle, a great ballerina can put herself through astonishing changes: A village girl falls in love with a count (named Albrecht) who is pretending to be a peasant, and when she learns he is betrothed to someone else, she goes mad, dies of shock and returns as an ethereal spirit. But a great ballerina often has to play Giselle again and again; and over time, a radiant performance can settle into habit.

headline: In Single Gene, a Path to Fight Heart Attacks
text: Two major studies by leading research groups published on Wednesday independently identified mutations in a single gene that protect against heart attacks by keeping levels of triglycerides — a kind of fat in the blood — very low for a lifetime.

headline: Pulling Back the Veil, or Keeping It On
text: A Yemeni photographer worked both sides of the camera as she and her daughter – and a doll – posed for a visual mediation on the increasing covering of women.

headline: No ‘Fat Talk’ and No Skinny Talk, Either, at Some Camps
text: Many children figure out young that one road to conversation with peers, older children and even parents is to talk appearance — theirs, or someone else’s. “She really shouldn’t wear those pants,” or even just “Did you notice his beard?” spark conversations (not always kind), and can lead, eventually, to the dubious bonding ritual that is negative self-talk: “No cookies for me! Not with these thighs!” “Oh, I know, my jeans are getting so tight!” Ninety-three percent of college women told one researcher they had engaged in such “fat talk,” and such talk comes with a cost, putting the focus on weight and appearance, and not in a positive way.

headline: Rappers’ Lyrics and Lifestyles Scrutinized in Murder Case
text: Studio time until 5 a.m., $400 bottles at nightclubs, taking a bullet to the head: Such is the life of a modern-day rapper.

headline: Croatia vs. Cameroon: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Losing a World Cup opener as these teams both did, is bad, but not fatal. Losing Game 2 as well is the end of the line. Both teams must win to have a shot at the second berth behind Brazil.

headline: Exploiting Circus Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Albania, Kenya and England.

headline: A Charter Leader’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: There’s Pride in Embracing the Past
text: The Orchestra of the League of Composers gave its final concert of the season on Monday at Miller Theater at Columbia University, under the baton of Louis Karchin.

headline: Pull Over, It’s John Waters
text: The film director and author hitchhiked across the United States and lived to tell the tale.

headline: The Controversy Over ‘The Death of Klinghoffer’
The Value of a ‘NanoDegree’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Flight of Top-Shelf Books About Drinking
text: This season a number of excellent books about spirits come to market, covering every corner of drinking culture. Pick one up if you’re thinking about new ways of serving drinks this summer.

headline: John Waters on Hitchhiking Across America
text: John Waters was safely ensconced in his Greenwich Village apartment, which is unexpectedly tasteful — Oriental rugs, carefully arranged books — for the filmmaker known as the “Pope of Trash,” thanks to movies like “Hairspray” and “Pink Flamingos” that traffic in camp, gore and, ahem, bodily functions.

headline: Boy, 14, Fatally Stabs Schoolmate in Bronx, Police Say
text: A 14-year-old Bronx boy who may have been teased and robbed by a 14-year-old schoolmate stabbed him to death on Wednesday afternoon outside the school they attended, the police said.

headline: With Wind Calm, Serenity in Slovenia
text: The subject was the Bora — the ferocious northern wind that wreaks seasonal havoc on the western Slovenian region known as the Vipava Valley, where we had just arrived — and my friend expressed disappointment that we had just missed out on the chance to experience it. “It sounds so impressive,” she said.

headline: At London Men’s Fashion Week, Designers Fly the Flag for Individuality
text: LONDON — One of the standout shows of London Collections: Men, the city’s three-day men’s fashion “week,” was by a 27-year-old novice named Craig Green. It was all the more astonishing because it was, technically, his first.

headline: Cupid Flitted About Briskly, While the TV Stars Just Stood There
text: Julia Roberts couldn’t stop smiling during Tuesday’s On Site Opera performance of Rameau’s “Pygmalion.” Kim Kardashian maintained a more skeptical pose, hands on peplum-frilled hips, a hint of a pout on her closed lips. Of course, neither of them was a reliable measure of the show’s success. Their facial expressions, like everything else about them, were perpetually frozen in wax.

headline: Yellen Delivers Remarks on Fed Policy
text: The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said the Fed would maintain its plan to trim its stimulus campaign by reducing its monthly bond purchases to $35 billion beginning in July.

headline: When Time Isn’t Free
text: How much free time do you have? On a basic level, you could answer that question by tallying up the hours you spend working, sleeping and doing chores, and figuring out what’s left over. But some argue that the real answer is a lot more complicated — and that the way you experience time might have a lot to do with money.

headline: Facebook Makes Its Own Computer Networking Switch
text: In pretty short order, Facebook is out to shake up big parts of what makes the Internet go.

headline: Openings and Sales for the Week of June 19
text: Openings

headline: Careful Defense in a World Wide Bridge Contest Heat
text: In the World Wide Bridge Contest held on June 7, Corey Krantz and Bruce Lang came in second, playing at the Bridge Club of Center City in Philadelphia. They had a 73.14 percent game, finishing 1.48 percent behind George Criparacos and John Vergitsakis from Greece.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’ Composer Responds to Met’s Decision
text: John Adams said he learned that the Metropolitan Opera was scrapping plans to transmit his opera “The Death of Klinghoffer” to movie theaters around the world when the Met’s general manager, Peter Gelb, told him on Sunday by telephone that he had gotten “unimaginable pressure” from some Jewish groups that oppose the work.

headline: New York’s Film Czar Preserves Indie Spirit
text: When Cynthia López was 9 years old, her mother told her, “Make sure you hold the door for those who come behind you.”

headline: Protection Sought for Vast and Ancient Incan Road
text: It is an engineering marvel of antiquity, comparable, experts say, to the Roman road system, but more remarkable for the rugged terrain it has traversed for more than 3,000 years.

headline: At Beijing School, Some Parents Take a Sex Education Class
text: If life were a movie, the meeting of 50 mothers and a doctor would have been called ‘‘Sex Ed 2: The Parents.’’

headline: Gyms Add More Obstacles to Fitness Training
text: Steven Beckwith was desperate. A friend had convinced him to sign up for a Spartan Beast, a notoriously tough obstacle course race stretching more than 12 miles, and he knew lifting weights and running on a treadmill at his regular gym wouldn’t prepare him to, say, spider-man across the flat face of a wall or climb a 20-foot rope.

headline: Twitter Restores Access to ‘Blasphemous’ Tweets in Pakistan
text: Pakistanis disappointed by Twitter’s decision last month to block content deemed “blasphemous” or “unethical” by their government expressed satisfaction when the company restored access to the blocked text and images early Wednesday.

headline: Do Children’s Backyard Play Areas Turn Off Buyers?
text: Q. Will children’s outdoor play structures make the yard look junky to buyers?

headline: William Maclay’s Road Map to Get Off the Grid
text: Books by architectural firms are often vainglorious marketing efforts that keep the content glossy and light. But an ambitious new book from William Maclay, an architect in Waitsfield, Vt., and his associates, challenges the genre.

headline: Sales at Kikkerland, ABC Carpet & Home and MoMA Design Store
text: Some items are up to 65 percent off at Kikkerland, from Saturday through June 25 (a Mona Lisa wall clock by Constantin Boym, originally $35, will be $25; a Gator grater, $3.50, down from $10); 493 Sixth Avenue (West 12th Street), 212-262-5000, kikkerlandnyc.com.

headline: Furnishing an Outdoor Room
text: After a longer and more-brutal winter than usual, many outdoor spaces are in need of a little sprucing up.

headline: From Ma Bell to Design Central
text: Ameico, an importer of contemporary design, has turned an abandoned telephone exchange building in New Milford, Conn., into an unlikely showcase. The 1917 structure, which had been boarded up for two decades, has been renovated and filled with a retail shop, called 29 Church. It sells clocks and watches from Braun, flatware by Konstantin Grcic for Serafino Zani, and classic posters by Bruno Munari and Enzo Mari for Danese. Upstairs, shoppers will find furniture and lighting from &Tradition, Santa & Cole, Max Bill and the Josef Albers Foundation. The 6,000-square-foot complex includes a library stocked with books on industrial design and will be open to the public for research. Plans are afoot to host industrial design conferences and exhibitions. “We have always felt that one of our missions is to educate consumers about what is good design,” said Peter Kahane, Ameico’s founder. Information: 888-350-8765 or ameico.com.

headline: Breaking Free of Boundaries
text: Design Miami/Basel, a part of the semiannual Art Basel fair, opened on Tuesday in Switzerland with a new feature called “Design at Large.” Curated by Dennis Freedman, the creative director of Barneys New York, the program displays six large-scale installations stationed under an oculus. The works, a few of which have interactive or performance-based elements, aren’t intended to be commercial, Mr. Freedman said, adding, “None of these pieces could ever have been shown in a booth.” The group includes a tiny biomorphic plastic house, designed in 1965 by the French architect Jean Maneval, and Sheila Hicks’s interactive color lab, “Séance,” which consists of colorful fiber bundles that look like boulders Information: designmiami.com.

headline: He Found His Corner of the Sky
text: As a boy growing up in Brooklyn Heights, Peter Heller was fascinated by the mythic West, in particular the cowboy novels of Louis L’Amour. “I remember the cover of this one L’Amour book showed a guy on horseback, leading a pack horse across a creek in the snow,” Mr. Heller, 55, said. “Something about that cover — all I wanted to do was drift the high lonesome on horseback.”

headline: Mastering a Collision Course Called Home
text: By the time my son was 9 months old, I had fully baby-proofed our tiny Brooklyn walk-up. Cabinets containing toxic chemicals were locked. Doorknobs and stove dials had been disabled. All four corners of the coffee table were padded. Easy. Effective. The process of blind-proofing the apartment, for myself, was far more complicated.

headline: Bringing Rio a Bit Closer
text: Cristiane Peixoto, a floral designer, and her husband, Marcus Silberman, an investment banker, are from Rio de Janeiro, and as Ms. Peixoto said, “Life in Rio is all about being on the beach and outdoors.” So when the couple bought an apartment for their family in Manhattan, they chose one with as much space outdoors as there is indoors.

headline: Descend Into Giddiness
text: “I think it would change our lives if we could slide more,” said the Belgian artist Carsten Höller, who has been building slides on and off since 1998. The structures not only carry you efficiently from place to place, he believes, but they also create a special state of mind that, borrowing a phrase from the French sociologist Roger Caillois, he likes to describe as “voluptuous panic.” On Wednesday, Mr. Holler unveiled his first free-standing slide on the campus of the furniture company Vitra in Weil am Rhein, Germany. It is a steel spiral descending from a 100-foot-high tower with a platform that offers a rare elevated view of the architectural masterworks around it. (Among the neighbors are buildings by Álvaro Siza, Tadao Ando and Zaha Hadid.) Topping the structure is a large, numberless clock that is positioned askew so that viewers must tilt their heads and guess the correct time. Mr. Holler prefers that idea to consulting a cellphone, a gesture that can be construed as rude. “People think you could be checking your email,” he said. Information: vitra.com.

headline: What Good Taste Smells Like
text: Meredith Melling’s duplex loft in NoHo features the polished decorating of Ariel Ashe — lots of neutrals with some standout pieces like a tufted royal-blue velvet sofa and a burl-wood-and-chrome dining table — set against its bleached wood floors and gutsy exposed beams and columns. Tying it all together is an invisible, but palpable, element: a sandalwood, vanilla and pepper fragrance, designed especially for Ms. Melling and her apartment, wafting from a sleek metal machine the size of a tablet hidden behind the blue sofa.

headline: Another Blow to the ‘Redskins’ Name
text: When it canceled the trademark on the Washington Redskins name on Wednesday, the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board ruled that the word was “disparaging.” But many came to that conclusion — and stopped using the name — a long time ago.

headline: Assembly Is Not Required
text: Instead of trying to make sense of the dizzying array of boxes and shelving options at the Container Store, you can now hire somebody to figure it out for you. After successful runs in Texas, the company just started At Home in its two Manhattan locations. Twelve orderly professionals are ready to lend a hand, said Eva Gordon, vice president for stores. “They’ll come to your home, look at your space to understand your style, assess your needs and come back with an organizational plan.” The cost to get started is $50, which covers the visit and creation of the plan. The organizer recommends Container Store products to carry it out, and returns — at $50 an hour — to oversee the installation of shelving systems and the like, help with staging and styling, and even paint the space. Information: 855-827-4663 or containerstore.com/athome.

headline: Aston Martin Racing to Explore Solar Technology
text: Aston Martin Racing announced last week that it would join with the Hong Kong-based Hanergy Global Solar Power & Applications Group to find ways to apply solar energy to racecars.

headline: List of Potential Bitcoin Bidders Is Accidentally Released
text: A musician, a college professor and the head of public policy for Yelp could all bid on 30,000 Bitcoins being auctioned by United States Marshals Service this month, according to a list that was accidentally leaked by the office on Wednesday.

headline: Bits of Brooklyn, Everywhere
text: For decades, the Brooklyn Academy of Music flourished comfortably at the edge of New York’s cultural life. Residents of the borough found it a well-tended and accessible garden of sometimes exotic delights, while Manhattanites could congratulate themselves for their adventurousness, and for finding a taxi willing to take them across the East River.

headline: SAC Capital’s Deal With S.E.C. Gets Final Court Approval
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission‘s insider trading lawsuit against Steven A. Cohen’s former hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is finally over.

headline: Markit, a Big Financial Data Provider, Raises Nearly $1.3 Billion in I.P.O.
text: One of the most important names in the world of debt trading, Markit, is poised to join the public stock markets — and generate a payday for the banks that are both owners and customers of the financial data firm.

headline: As the U.S. Ponders What to Do in Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Amazon Measures Phone Success
text: Amazon’s new Fire phone might be less about the phone and more about what its computing power can do in a few years, when it is built into futuristic devices like Internet-connected contact lenses, as I wrote today on the Upshot.

headline: Abdullah Elshamy Released From Prison
text: Abdullah Elshamy, an Al Jazeera correspondent who had been on a hunger strike for more than 100 days, was released late Tuesday from an Egyptian prison.

headline: New York City’s Emergency Management Chief Resigns
text: Joseph F. Bruno, the commissioner of New York City’s Office of Emergency Management for a decade, has resigned, after remaining in office for several months at the request of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s aides.

headline: The Gall of Dick Cheney
text: The situation in Iraq is truly worrisome, as militants threaten to tear the country asunder and disrupt the fragile, short-lived period absent all-out war there.

headline: Popular at Easter, Peeps Candy Extends to the Quirky Holidays
text: PEEPS, the 61-year-old brand of marshmallow candies, is wildly popular for Easter, but the brand has struggled to expand beyond the holiday.

headline: Battle Between Argentina and Hedge Funds Continues in New York
text: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | A fierce legal battle between Argentina and New York hedge funds took a new twist on Wednesday when the country offered to negotiate with the funds just hours after announcing measures that would help it avoid a settlement.

headline: College to No Longer Consider Test Scores in Its Decisions
text: Hampshire College, in Amherst, Mass., said on Wednesday that it would no longer consider SAT or ACT scores in admissions or financial aid decisions. Meredith Twombly, the dean of admissions, said Hampshire had been “test optional” since it opened in 1970 but would become “test blind,” both for greater fairness and because Hampshire favors assessment through written work, projects and discussions, not test scores. Robert Schaeffer, public education director of FairTest, said Hampshire would be the only test-blind college: Sarah Lawrence College was test-blind for several years, but it reverted to test-optional two years ago after U.S. News and World Report stopped ranking it because of the lack of test scores.

headline: 2 Million Tune In to See Hillary Rodham Clinton on Fox News
text: Apparently the Fox News audience was intensely interested in what Hillary Rodham Clinton had to say about her latest book.

headline: J.K. Rowling’s ‘The Silkworm’ a Boon for Other Booksellers as Hachette and Amazon Brawl
text: Like any mystery novel expected to be a summer blockbuster, Robert Galbraith’s “The Silkworm,” set for release on Thursday, features shadowy subtext and crafty machinations — but in this book’s case the maneuverings are both on and off the page.

headline: What to Call Iraq Fighters? Experts Vary on S’s and L’s
text: Everyone seems to agree that the Sunni extremists who are striving to carve out a caliphate in Syria and Iraq have upended the region, but there is no consensus on what to call the militant group, in English at least.

headline: An Answer on a Postcard
text: WASHINGTON — THIS year, more than 20 million college students will complete the dreaded 108-question Free Application for Federal Student Aid, commonly known as the Fafsa. Most do it again every year they’re in school. Some pay someone to help them. Colleges hire thousands of staff members to assist. Too many students are so intimidated by the form that they don’t bother to apply.

headline: The Not-So-Beautiful Game
text: IT’S wonderful that America has fallen in love with World Cup soccer, as it plays out across the greenswards of Brazilian host cities like Natal, Manaus and Curitiba. To walk through New York City on Monday night and hear the restaurant crowds’ whooping at John Brooks’s late-game goal, which propelled the United States over Ghana, was to experience soccer as it is experienced in the rest of the world: collective, noisy and cathartic.

headline: Leader’s Words About Women Jolt Morocco
text: Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane of Morocco told Parliament this week that women would be better off at home than in the workplace, setting off alarm in a country that has seen slow but steady gains in women’s rights.

headline: Drones Kill 5 as Pakistan and U.S. Target Tribal Belt
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An American drone strike killed at least five people in North Waziristan on Wednesday, Pakistani officials said, as the Pakistani military continued its offensive against militants in that tribal district.

headline: Jeff Bezos Shows Off Amazon Fire Phone
text: Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, demonstrated the company’s new phone at a presentation on Wednesday.

headline: Parity Could Be a Plus for the So-So Yankees
text: The Toronto Blue Jays hold first place in the American League East, but their grip on it is slipping. They have lost 8 of 11 games and, as usual, fell again to the Yankees in the Bronx on Wednesday. It was their 15th loss in a row at the new Yankee Stadium.

headline: After 10 Months in Jail, Freed Egyptian Journalist Says, ‘I Have Won’
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo on Monday, prosecutors decided to release a hunger-striking journalist, Abdullah Elshamy, because of his deteriorating health.

headline: Pressure Grows in Hunt for Kidnapped Israelis
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Wednesday denounced the abduction of three Israeli teenagers and vowed to help catch the kidnappers, as pressure mounted on him and threatened to collapse his fraying reconciliation pact with the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Arraigned in Case That Could Help Decide Fate of Tribunals
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — An Iraqi detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was arraigned Wednesday on war-crimes charges before a military commission, setting in motion a case that could help determine whether the tribunals system will be used extensively in the future or wither away after the handful of cases before it are completed.

headline: Thomas B. Morgan, Writer, Editor and Lindsay Press Aide, Dies at 87
text: Thomas B. Morgan, who combined a knack for writing and passion for public affairs to shape a heterogeneous career that included being press secretary to Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York, editor of The Village Voice and chief of the city’s broadcasting operations, died on Tuesday in Westmoreland, N.H. He was 87.

headline: Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The gimmicks to attract attention and passengers — a $1 million raffle, a chance to win a Porsche 911, or a monthlong shopping festival — are still there but are hardly needed anymore. Travelers from around the world no longer need to be lured to this parched former trading post on the edge of the Persian Gulf.

headline: TCI Hedge Fund in Britain Ends Ties to Charitable Arm
text: When Christopher Hohn, the founder of one of Britain’s largest and most successful hedge funds, chose to structure his fund to automatically donate a portion of its fees to charity — specifically his wife’s charity — people took notice.

headline: Governor Plans to Cut Ties to Common Core in Louisiana
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Wednesday that he would seek to end his state’s enactment of the Common Core educational guidelines and plans to administer a test tied to them, but other officials immediately said that the governor had overstepped his authority and vowed to resist his moves.

headline: Was This Student Dangerous?
text: The undergraduate who had been writing poems about killing people showed up for his appointment in my office carrying a black canvas backpack. He was slim and dark-haired, his mouth torqued into an uneasy smile. I had spoken several times about his violent ramblings to the campus police and to the university’s office of mental health, and this was what they came up with: I should invite the student to my office and calmly begin a conversation with the following question: “Do you have a plan to harm yourself or anyone else?”

headline: John Devens, Valdez Mayor During Exxon Spill, Dies at 74
text: John Devens, whose tenure as the mayor of an obscure coastal town in Alaska was rocked by a stunning disaster on its shores — the wreck of the Exxon Valdez oil tanker in Prince William Sound — died last week at his home in Copper Center, Alaska. He was 74.

headline: Up in Arms Over ‘Soccer’ vs. ‘Football’
text: The letter writer was incensed, as so many people so often are, by America’s insistence on using its own special word to describe the game that almost everyone else calls football.

headline: Should Restaurant Reservations Be for Sale?
text: Do reservation apps usefully provide a way for people to  get into popular restaurants, or are they just another way to sell what was once free?

headline: Espaillat for Congress
text: After a humiliating censure by Congress four years ago for failing to pay taxes and other ethical lapses, Representative Charles Rangel has steadily lost power in Washington. After nearly 44 years in office, it is now time for him to yield to the next generation. In Tuesday’s Democratic primary for New York’s 13th Congressional District, we recommend Adriano Espaillat, a New York State senator, who will be a better representative of this district stretching from Upper Manhattan into parts of the Bronx.

headline: Guns at the Airport
text: On June 4, a 32-year-old woman tried to get through security at San Antonio International Airport with a loaded .380 caliber Diamondback in her carry-on bag. This wasn’t a freak occurrence. Transportation Security Administration officials intercepted 18 guns on that day alone — a single-day record in what looks to be a record-setting year. The T.S.A. found 1,320 guns in 2011, 1,556 in 2012, 1,813 in 2013 — and has found roughly 900 so far in 2014.

headline: Mighty Spain Goes Out of the World Cup Meekly
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The chants at the game between Spain and Chile began slowly, first from one side of Estádio do Maracanã, then from the other. By the time the final minutes had ticked off the clock Wednesday, tens of thousands of fans had joined in.

headline: Maine Court Fight Pits Farmers Against State and One Another
text: BLUE HILL, Me. — When Dan Brown quit his job driving trucks and began to work on his wife’s family homestead here about a decade ago, he was looking forward to a quiet life of farming. He began raising chickens and growing vegetables, and watched happily as a calf named Sprocket thrived. The Browns built a farm stand and began selling unpasteurized milk and eventually other products, like jam and salsa.

headline: Amazon Fire Phone’s Missed Opportunities
text: SEATTLE — When Amazon invited the media and hundreds of its most loyal customers to witness the unveiling of a new device on Wednesday, everyone thought the company would introduce a smartphone made in the mold of its line of tablet computers: pretty good and really cheap.

headline: ‘This Isn’t About Farmer Brown Anymore’
text: Dan Brown is a Maine farmer who was sued by the state for selling milk without a license. On Tuesday, Mr. Brown lost an appeal he had made to the state’s highest court.

headline: Courting Swing Vote in Harlem District: Whites
text: There was never a question that race would play a key role in Representative Charles B. Rangel’s re-election fight, a battle for a seat held by two black men since the 1940s, in a district where Hispanics recently became the majority.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 18, 2014
Ko Adds Another Weapon to Her Bag
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Keeping up with the 17-year-old Lydia Ko has been a chore for the sexagenarian caddie Mike Cowan. After a nine-hole practice round on Wednesday in extreme heat, Cowan fell a few paces behind when he stopped to pose with another caddie who requested to have a photo taken with him.

headline: Former Envoy Pipes Up in Conservative Chorus of ‘Told You So’ on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — The only thing that John R. Bolton has tamed is his mustache.

headline: A King Refuses to Abdicate His Throne
text: It is a shirt-sticking-to-your-back 88 degrees along Gun Hill Road in the Bronx, and a few dozen union workers at Montefiore Medical Center have waited through their lunch hour and they are wilting.

headline: Uneasy Alliance Gives Insurgents an Edge in Iraq
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Meeting with the American ambassador some years ago in Baghdad, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki detailed what he believed was the latest threat of a coup orchestrated by former officers of Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party.

headline: General Motors Receives Welcome News in Automotive Survey
text: DETROIT — While General Motors was under fire in Washington at a House hearing over its failure to recall defective cars, the automaker received some welcome news at home on Wednesday with a strong showing in the annual J.D. Power quality survey of new vehicles.

headline: State Pressing Lopez to Pay Ethics Fine
text: The office of Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman said on Wednesday that it would seek payment of $330,000 from former State Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez after he failed to pay a fine from a sexual harassment scandal that doomed his political career.

headline: N.C.A.A. President Will Get His Say at Antitrust Trial
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Sonny Vaccaro was here early on June 9, the opening morning of the Ed O’Bannon trial. A long line snaked out of the federal courthouse, but Vaccaro, 74, had flown in from Palm Springs, Calif., with his wife the night before. He was at the front.

headline: Border Centers Struggle to Handle Onslaught of Young Migrants
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — In a 120,000-square-foot warehouse on the edge of this desert city, Border Patrol agents line up hundreds of children who may have never seen a doctor for basic vaccinations and other medical care, hand out snacks or join them for a game of basketball under a circuslike tent that doubles as a recreation room.

headline: Mitt! Again! What?
text: Mitt Romney is back.

headline: Decades Later, 17 Service Members Who Perished in Crash Will Be Laid to Rest
text: For more than six decades, a tombstone at the Sunnyside Cemetery in Caney, Kan., has marked Pvt. Leonard Kittle’s final resting place. On Saturday, he will at last be buried there as his family looks on.

headline: Conflict in Iraq Adds New Angle to U.S.-Iran Nuclear Talks
text: VIENNA — The Iranian leadership had a message for Washington on Wednesday: If President Obama really wants some cooperation on stabilizing Iraq, he might first think about speeding forward with a permanent deal over Iran’s nuclear capability.

headline: An Unusual Media Start-Up: A Local Newspaper
text: Kevin Boyle has done two stints as editor of The Wave, a 120-year-old weekly newspaper in the Rockaways that has long been a source of local news in its seaside Queens neighborhood.

headline: On Iraq, Echoes of 2003
text: Is this 2014 or 2003?

headline: New York Legislature Reaches Deal on More Laws to Fight Heroin Problem
text: For the second time in two weeks, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gathered reporters on Wednesday to make an announcement about the state’s heroin problem, which has dominated discussions at the close of the legislative session in Albany. Last week, flanked by law enforcement officers, the governor was behind a lectern emblazoned with the words “Heroin Epidemic.”

headline: Mormons Say Critical Online Comments Draw Threats From Church
text: Rock Waterman, a retired innkeeper in California, writes a blog called Pure Mormonism, which attracts Mormons so orthodox that they believe their church is not sufficiently adhering to its own doctrines.

headline: Mentally Pooped
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m not sure if I’ve ever seen a 15 x 16 crossword puzzle with 20-plus theme entries, but we have one today, and you really have to admire the sneaky way Timothy Polin got them in there. Instead of a set of a few long entries, he and Will Shortz have clued many of the shorter entries as trivia questions.

headline: As Moderate Islamists Retreat, Extremists Surge Unchecked
text: TUNIS — Islamist politicians swept elections across the region in the aftermath of the Arab Spring, stepping close to power in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and Morocco and undermining the thesis of Qaeda-style militants that violence offered the only hope for change.

headline: T-Mobile Offers iPhone Tests and Unlimited Music Streaming
text: T-Mobile US, the fourth-largest American phone carrier, has spent the last year and a half introducing aggressive new offerings to lure customers. Late Wednesday, the company said it would add to those offerings with unlimited streaming music and the ability to test-drive an iPhone.

headline: Family of Framed Man Sues City and Police
text: The family of a man wrongfully convicted in Brooklyn has sued the city and police officers, asking for $15 million — even though the man, David Ranta, had already reached a settlement with the city.

headline: The Cost to Change the Redskins’ Name
text: With the Washington Redskins’ trademark now canceled, a look at the costs in both keeping and changing the team’s name.

headline: Hats Off
text: Enddi Harris, 19, tried to keep cool while eating lunch on Wednesday at the stand where he works in Manhattan. “I just pray for the shade to move,” he said.

headline: Horace Silver, 85, Master of Earthy Jazz, Is Dead
text: Horace Silver, a pianist, composer and bandleader who was one of the most popular and influential jazz musicians of the 1950s and ’60s, died on Wednesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: Slurs Don’t Deserve Trademark Protection
text: There is no question that the term “redskin” has been used as a racial slur for American Indians for hundreds of years and is on par with offensive terms used to denigrate blacks and Hispanics. And it is also clear that federal law prohibits the Patent and Trademark Office from registering trademarks that disparage people or bring them “into contempt, or disrepute.”

headline: Roaring on the Seas
text: Few aspects of China’s dynamic emergence as a global power have generated as much insecurity and danger in its neighborhood as its mounting campaign to control the South China Sea, a vital waterway for international commerce. On Wednesday, at a high-level meeting in Hanoi, China’s top diplomat scolded his Vietnamese hosts for complaining about an oil rig that Beijing planted in early May in waters that Vietnam claims, as its own.

headline: Mexico: Governor of Michoacán Resigns
text: The governor of Michoacán, one of the country’s most violent states, where people have taken up arms to fight drug and organized crime gangs, has resigned because of poor health. The resignation on Wednesday of the governor, Fausto Vallejo, 65, injects political uncertainty in a state where officials’ failure to quell surging violence, giving rise to vigilante groups, led the federal government to take over security this year. Mr. Vallejo, whose four-year term expires in 2016, did not disclose his health problem, but he underwent a liver transplant last year. He returned Tuesday night from a checkup in the United States and informed President Enrique Peña Nieto of his decision Wednesday morning. The State Legislature will choose a successor to serve the remainder of the term.

headline: Stuart Vaughan, Director and Shakespeare Expert, Dies at 88
text: Stuart Vaughan, who directed the first productions of the New York Shakespeare Festival and later seeded several regions of the country with classic works, starting repertory theaters in Seattle and New Orleans and another that toured community centers and colleges, died on June 10 at his home in High Bridge, N.J. He was 88.

headline: A Struggling McCann Shows Some of the Pop He Was Signed to Provide
text: Much of the Yankees’ attention this season has been on their injury-ravaged rotation, their aging lineup and Derek Jeter’s retirement tour. There has hardly been time to worry about catcher Brian McCann, stuck in a slump after signing a five-year, $85 million contract in the off-season.

headline: Battle Cries
text: The world’s best soccer players bring their own unique style to the game. So it is only fitting that the commentators react in kind — calling a goal with passion and personality.

headline: U.S. Asserts Self-Defense in Benghazi Suspect Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has told the United Nations that Ahmed Abu Khattala, the suspected ringleader of the 2012 attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, was plotting additional attacks on Americans and that the United States conducted the weekend raid that seized him under its right to self-defense.

headline: Olivia Bee’s Personal Images of Her Teenage Years

headline: Who Can Speak for the Patient?
text: Our patient was never going to wake up. He had an unrecoverable brain injury. The prognosis had become clear over time. As the patient’s attending physician in the intensive care unit, I arranged a meeting with his sister, the only visitor we’d seen for days, and explained. She was resolute. “He’ll wake up,” she said. “He’s a fighter. Do everything you can to keep him alive.”

headline: Smartphones Embracing ‘Kill Switches’ as Theft Defense
text: By next summer, most new smartphones may no longer be quite so attractive to thieves.

headline: Tibetan Security Official Gunned Down in Sichuan
text: A Tibetan security official was shot and killed last week in western Sichuan Province as he was returning from policing the lucrative harvest of caterpillar fungus used in Chinese medicine, the state news media reported Thursday.

headline: China Sentences Three Activists
text: BEIJING — Three activists in China who had demanded that public officials disclose their assets were sentenced on Thursday to prison, according to one of their lawyers and a daughter of one of the defendants.

headline: The Slumdog Millionaire Architect
text: The offices of Hafeez Contractor, India’s most commercially successful architect, are on Bank Street, just around the corner from the Mumbai Stock Exchange. The prestige of the address, however, is undermined by the beleaguered state of the Raj-era building. In the reception area, a flat-screen displaying a loop of Contractor’s futuristic projects is mounted on a cracked, stained plaster wall. Upstairs, hundreds of designers sit shoulder to shoulder at long rows of computer monitors, packed in almost as mercilessly as on the commuter trains that ferry them to work each day. The office has struggled to keep up with the firm’s expanding work force and is perpetually under construction. Staff members were known to walk 15 minutes to the five-star Taj Mahal Palace Hotel rather than brave the employee-restroom line. Contractor has vastly increased his square footage by building a loft, but a day at the office now entails ducking through archways, dodging stray wires and ignoring the wail of power saws.
