headline: A Chorus of ‘Goooooool,’ the Siren Song of Soccer
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Having caught his first big break on radio 50 years ago, José Carlos Araújo, who had honed his sportscasting skills by calling button soccer games in a neighbor’s backyard, figured he would have to tame his changing voice to avoid losing his pitch halfway through the effusively long cries of “goooooool” that are the hallmark and necessity of a Brazilian play-by-play announcer’s routine.

headline: Morning Views
text: “On June 4, a 32-year-old woman tried to get through security at San Antonio International Airport with a loaded .380 caliber Diamondback in her carry-on bag,” The New York Times reports. “This wasn’t a freak occurrence. Transportation Security Administration officials intercepted 18 guns on that day alone — a single-day record in what looks to be a record-setting year.” The editorial calls on state governments to introduce measures that would make any attempt to bring a firearm into an airport a felony. “Unless states decide to classify bringing a gun into security as a felony, though, forgetful people will almost certainly continue to have the right to own, carry and misplace firearms because basic responsibility hasn’t been made a prerequisite for gun ownership.”

headline: In New York, on the Hunt for Characters
text: Sara Ashley O’Brien and Kimberly Ammiano, students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, followed Metropolitan reporter Corey Kilgannon as he interviewed people for his weekly Character Study column.

headline: Keeping a Cash-Starved Start-Up on Track
text: In a start-up, there’s always too much to do and not enough time or money to do it. There are never enough people to fix what’s broken and never enough resources to develop the next strategic phase. For the first 12 months of Posse, I felt as if I was swimming as hard as I could, trying to avoid drowning. But I knew that if we were going to succeed I had to develop a rhythm to our development.

headline: Opponents of Hong Kong’s Occupy Central Envision Chaos

headline: Iraqi Officials Claim Control of Major Refinery in Baiji

headline: Why We’re All Crony Capitalists, Like It or Not
text: If there’s one thing that populists on the left and right can agree upon, it is disdain for crony capitalism. It is a distaste for the cesspool of Washington influence, in which big-business lobbyists canoodle with lawmakers to get their way. It is anger at corporate welfare enriching America’s biggest companies at the expense of the little guy.

headline: In Germany, Ordeal Ends for Physicist Hurt in Cave
text: BERCHTESGADEN, Germany — Johann Westhauser, a 52-year-old physicist who was struck in the head by a rock 3,766 feet below the surface in Germany’s deepest cavern on June 8, had only one wish as he was finally hoisted to the surface on Thursday — to personally thank all 728 people responsible for his rescue.

headline: Polish Premier Says Scandal May Prompt Early Vote
text: Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland warned Thursday that he might be forced to call early elections if a scandal over secretly taped conversations of senior government officials continued to escalate.

headline: Can Amazon’s New Phone Make It as a Fashion Accessory?
text: In all the hoo-ha around Amazon’s entry into the smartphone market Wednesday with its Fire phone, complete with 3D screen and the ability to drive users to the Amazon marketplace, one pretty important issue has been overlooked: Will it work as a fashion accessory?

headline: Morning Agenda: Detroit’s New Pension Plan
text: In the face of Detroit’s tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments, Mary Williams Walsh writes in DealBook. One of the most closely watched issues of the case is whether government pensions can be legally cut in bankruptcy. Now, Detroit has introduced a new plan with the cooperation of its unions, which have been among the most vocal opponents of cutbacks.

headline: BlackBerry’s Earnings Point to Signs of Stabilizing
text: OTTAWA — For BlackBerry, the smartphone company recently known for producing relentlessly grim financial results, the announcement on Thursday of a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss counts as good news. Although BlackBerry’s management stopped well short of declaring a turnaround, the results suggested that severe cost-cutting and efforts to refocus the company might be at least stabilizing it.

headline: Daily Report: Missed Opportunities With Amazon’s Fire Phone
text: When Amazon invited the media and hundreds of its most loyal customers to Seattle to witness the unveiling of a new device on Wednesday, everyone thought the company would introduce a smartphone made in the mold of its line of tablet computers: pretty good and really cheap.

headline: First Data to Raise $3.5 Billion to Reduce Debt
text: The First Data Corporation, a payment processing company owned by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, said on Thursday that it would raise $3.5 billion in a private sale of its stock.

headline: As Military and Rebels Clash in Ukraine, Doubt Falls on Cease-Fire Prospects
text: SEVERSK, Ukraine — Fierce fighting raged here on Thursday between the Ukrainian military and pro-Russian separatist rebels, with hours of intense shelling casting grave doubts on the prospects of a unilateral cease-fire that was promised just a day earlier by the new Ukrainian president, Petro O. Poroshenko.

headline: Mozilla to Develop Comments Platform With New York Times and Washington Post

headline: Q. and A. | Max Silvestri, Funnyman and Foodie
text: Is Brooklyn the epicenter of new comedy? To make such a claim would be to bait Internet controversy. But it’s safe to say that in 2008 a very good and very influential weekly comedy show, Big Terrific — hosted by Jenny Slate, Gabe Liedman and Max Silvestri — began on Wednesday nights in Williamsburg, eventually settling at Cameo gallery. Since then, it’s become a destination for pros to work out new material (famous names like Aziz Ansari, Zach Galifianakis, John Mulaney and Sarah Silverman have been known to drop by) and for up-and-comers to earn their stripes.

headline: Analysts Say China May Try to Use Manmade Islands to Bolster Bid for Economic Development
text: China has been moving sand onto some reefs and rocks in the Spratly archipelago of the South China Sea to create islands that can support buildings, equipment and human habitation. The construction is stirring anxiety in the Philippines and Vietnam, which compete with China over territorial claims in the Spratly Islands, and raising alarms in the United States, which sees China’s actions in the South China Sea as destabilizing.

headline: How Do You Take the Measure of a School Year?
text: As the school year draws to a close, teachers and parents are left wondering how to take its measure, to identify their successes, failures and lessons learned. For those who follow education news, 2013-14 has been The Year of Big Data, and conclusions from recently published studies and surveys have been released in the media like so many rubber balls from a dump truck. The resulting bouncy chaos has been difficult to subdue, let alone organize and interpret.

headline: A Holy Space in More Ways Than One
text: Since 1964, a former Sunday school classroom on the second floor of St. Mark’s Church in the East Village has housed a theater. To find it, walk through a rusty gate, past a graveyard, up a narrow flight of stairs, across a cramped lobby and into new worlds.

headline: Ed Sheeran, Lighter and Wiser, Releases ‘x’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Seven hours before Ed Sheeran was scheduled to perform at a taping of the show “Austin City Limits” here this month, three young women were sitting on a red blanket on the sidewalk outside the studio, braving 97-degree heat in hope of getting a ticket. Usual pop idol stuff.

headline: Richard Linklater’s Leading Boy
text: In his new film, “Boyhood,” the director Richard Linklater takes a novel approach to the classic coming-of-age story — one that’s both strikingly radical and entirely logical. Filmed in short installments over a period of 12 years, “Boyhood” details the journey from boyhood to adolescence of one Mason Jr., played by Ellar Coltrane, above, who blossoms on screen before our eyes from a pensive, tentative 6-year-old to a sensitive, freethinking young man of 18.

headline: Challengers Emerge to Replace Divisive Maliki

headline: Three’s a Trend | Striped Knits on the London Runways
text: Instead of the now ubiquitous nautical stripes, designers at the spring/summer 2015 London men’s shows presented variegated striped knits in retro colorways, with a ’70s-by-way-of-the-’90s feeling. They’re the kind of sweaters that the Blur frontman Damon Albarn might have worn circa “Parklife,” or Harmony Korine might have slipped into while he was writing “Kids.” At Topman, a mockneck was paired with bell bottoms (and alternately layered under a short-sleeve daisy-printed shirt). Pringle of Scotland offered a tailored version of the retro golf sweater, worn with suit pants. Meanwhile, continuing his exploration of gender boundaries, J.W. Anderson presented the throwback striped look in the form of a knotted boatneck.

headline: When Getting Laughs Annoys the Neighbors
text: “THIS is the kind of show you’re really going to appreciate if comedy is ever illegal,” the comedian Sam Morril said, looking around a small basement in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It was a rainy night, and about three dozen people were gathered in the downstairs of a duplex for “Live @ the Apt,” a regular stand-up show held in the home of its producers. “It’s a very Prohibition-era vibe,” Mr. Morril added.

headline: 40 Indian Workers Kidnapped in Iraq Are Said to Have Been  Located
text: NEW DELHI – After an hours-long journey in a private bus from villages near the city of Amritsar, in Punjab State, the families of 13 of the 40 construction workers whom the Indian government announced had been kidnapped in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul arrived at the Gurdwara Rakab Ganj, a centuries-old Sikh shrine, on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Astronomers Hedge on Big Bang Detection Claim

headline: The Unsettled Politics of Foreign Policy
text: The conventional wisdom, such as it is, on the political impact of events in Iraq, Ukraine and elsewhere seems to be that they will empower the Republican Party’s hawkish establishment at the expense of the party’s libertarian/anti-interventionist wing — strengthening the hawks’ critique of the Obama White House, bringing Bush-era voices back to the fore, and throwing new obstacles in Rand Paul’s already-difficult path to the nomination. And when you combine this scenario with Hillary Clinton’s none-too-subtle positioning of herself as a more interventionist figure than the current president, you have the possibility of the return of a kind of 2004-style hawkish center in American presidential politics, in which both Clinton and her eventual G.O.P. rival (be it a Cruz, a Rubio, a Bush, a Christie, whomever) would compete to out-tough the other on terrorism, Syria, Iran, ISIS, Putin, and so forth.

headline: Chelsea Handler Will Host a Late-Night Talk Show on Netflix

headline: Raise Minimum Wage Past $10? Been Here Before

headline: Drawing a Line Between Art and Abuse
text: “Is Terry Richardson an Artist or a Predator?” asks the headline of a recent New York Magazine profile of the fashion photographer. That question is getting nearly as much discussion as the article itself. Many argue that Mr. Richardson is able to get away with predatory behavior precisely because he’s a male artist in a society that valorizes them.

headline: You’re Just Too Good to Be True
text: At the end of “Jersey Boys,” Clint Eastwood’s likable, resolutely laid-back adaptation of the Broadway musical, the actors all freeze. They’ve just performed their last song on a set that looks so artificial that you half-expect the Sharks and the Jets to leap into the frame. Instead, that Jersey music man Frankie Valli and the other Seasons, along with a crowd of central-casting types, gather one last time and together warble and fancy-foot down a back-lot street. They finish big and then they all stop, staring straight ahead as sweat pops and bodies tremble under the now harsh lighting. That’s entertainment, baby, and it is hard work.

headline: Image of the Day: June 19
text: India receives annual rainfall from June to September.

headline: Listen Up | A New Indie Label With an Old Soul
text: Few record label bosses have the distinction of also being their own first signee. But that’s the case with the British soul artist Christian Gregory, who started Movement Records in London last year as a platform for emerging soul artists in the U.K. “There were a few labels doing kind of throwback stuff,” he says, “but none that really cater to soul as an art form in itself.” The child of classical musicians, Gregory started looking for his own musical direction at an early age. “My parents’ record collection is mostly orchestral stuff, so I would hunt through and look for anything that was different,” he says. “The closest thing I could usually find was either jazz or swing.” By his teens, his love for soul had taken hold.

headline: Nick Wooster, One-Man Brand
text: FLORENCE, Italy — He is an Instagram idol, an object of veneration across social media platforms, the sole focus of blogs consecrated to charting his individual style. That style, which the fashion retailer and savant Nickelson Wooster spent decades retooling, has lately become influential enough in the age of image obsession that a cadre of street photographers tracks him wherever he goes.

headline: Nick Wooster’s List of Five

headline: Book of Comedy Interviews Coming From Judd Apatow
text: The producer, director and screenwriter Judd Apatow’s expansive ideas about comedy and how it works are evident in his films and television series, which include “The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” “Knocked Up,” “Freaks and Geeks” and “Girls.” But Mr. Apatow has always liked talking about comedy with others who practice it, and now Random House has signed him to produce “Sick in the Head,” a compilation of interviews he has conducted with many of his comedy heroes and colleagues over the last three decades. The book is due in 2015. Proceeds will go to 826LA, a nonprofit organization that teaches creative writing to students between 6 and 18.

headline: Uruguay vs. England: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Luis Suarez scored twice for Uruguay, including the game-winning goal in the 84th minute, in a 2-1 victory against England, who is all but mathematically eliminated now.

headline: How to Give ‘Skipping Town’ a Whole New Meaning
text: OF all the things from childhood I left behind, I never saw myself revisiting skipping. Not skipping rope, just the plain old “Skip to My Lou” variety. But that’s what I did when I joined what may well be the city’s only skipping club for the first “skip” of the 2014 season.

headline: Angie Martinez Joins New York’s Power 105.1
text: In a shake-up of the hip-hop radio world in New York, Angie Martinez, one of the longest-running and most popular D.J.'s on Hot 97, has left that station to join its biggest rival, Power 105.1.

headline: An Over-Engineered Alstom Bid
text: Paris has forced General Electric into an over-engineered bid for Alstom’s power businesses.

headline: The Fed Faces Reality, Lowers Growth Forecast
text: The Federal Reserve faced reality on Wednesday, lowering it forecast for economic growth this year to 2.1 percent to 2.3 percent, down from a March projection of 2.8 percent to 3.0 percent.

headline: Text of Obama’s Remarks on Iraq
text: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s press conference on the conflict in Iraq in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

headline: Excerpt: ‘Holler if Ya Hear Me’
text: An excerpt from the number “California Love” from the new Broadway musical based on the lyrics of the rapper Tupac Shakur,

headline: Dining Without Borders
text: Here come the devils on horseback, that relic of dinner parties past: prunes and dates cowled in bacon and thrust onto skewers, chewy, crunchy, sweet and salty at once. Except that these devils are in Japanese garb, adorned with nitsume, the dark, sticky sauce that traditionally accompanies eel; squiggles of extra-tangy Kewpie mayonnaise; and translucent bonito flakes like blanched confetti.

headline: ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’
text: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Karen Olivo rehearse the number “Therapy” from the Encores! Off-Center production of the Jonathan Larson musical.

headline: Colombia and Its Coach Bring Joy to Fans by Advancing
text: BRASÍLIA — After their first World Cup victory in 16 years last Saturday, Colombia fans expressed their appreciation by giving Coach José Pékerman more than 400,000 write-in votes in Sunday’s presidential election.

headline: Redskins Isn’t the Only Name the Patent Office Has Blocked
text: The United States Patent and Trademark Office blocked the trademark registration for the Washington Redskins on Wednesday on grounds that it disparaged an ethnic group, American Indians. While such cases are not common, they do pop up, reflecting the turbulent mixing bowl of American ethnicity.

headline: Obama on New Military Advisers to Iraq
text: The president said the United States would send up to 300 military advisers to Iraq to train that country’s security forces, but he emphasized that America would not be returning to combat.

headline: Wheelies: The Price of Fuel Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Command Performance
text: Before the Chitlin’ Circuit, before the Cotton Club and eons before “Soul Train” or Black Entertainment Television (BET) put black talent on display, there was Congo Square in New Orleans. During Louisiana’s 18th-century French and Spanish colonial era, slaves were allowed to convene near the square on their Sundays off from work to sing, dance and play music — a practice that continued beyond the Louisiana Purchase. Word spread of the spectacle, and soon the slaves began to draw crowds of whites. Later the attempted suppression of “savage” African music by the Protestants helped transform Congo Square into a phenomenon sought by visitors from far and wide. You could argue that in that square, located in what is now Louis Armstrong Park, the American black as an entertainer was born.

headline: Italian Businessman Paolo Scaroni to Join Rothschild
text: LONDON — The British financial advisory firm Rothschild Group has hired Paolo Scaroni, an influential Italian businessman who was pushed out as chief executive of the oil company Eni this year by Italy’s prime minister, Matteo Renzi.

headline: Food Networks
text: To start a food trend from agriculture is “one of the riskiest” things an entrepreneur can do, David Sax writes in “The Tastemakers,” his entertaining new excursion into, as his subtitle has it, “Why We’re Crazy for Cupcakes but Fed Up With Fondue.” “Yet every day,” he adds, “there are countless farmers, scientists and gardening dreamers with a trowel in their hand, digging in the dirt and planting the seed that they hope will one day change the way we eat.”

headline: New York Leaders Reach Deal on Medical Marijuana
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced an agreement on Thursday for a pilot program to provide access to marijuana to sick New Yorkers, making the state one of the largest to embrace the drug’s use as medicine.

headline: Arms and the Men
text: “The right of the people to keep and bear arms” has been enshrined in the Second Amendment to the Constitution since 1792. In our day, the National Rifle Association and batteries of conservative jurists have fought so successfully to persuade people that the amendment guarantees Americans an individual right of self-­defense that in 2008 the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional an outright ban on handguns for residents of the District of Columbia. Two years later, the court ruled that Chicago could not ban handguns, either — the right to own handguns applied all over the United States.

headline: House Republicans Name McCarthy as Cantor’s Replacement
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans reached for continuity and stability on Thursday in electing a new leadership team, promoting a Californian of moderate temperament to No. 2 and a more conservative Louisianian who has the loyalty of the Tea Party as No. 3 in an effort to quell dissent in their restive ranks.

headline: A Deal-Making Touch Honed in the Minority
text: WASHINGTON — When he was the leader of Republicans in the California State Assembly — an ideologically diverse group of lawmakers often choleric toward both Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and the Democrats who controlled the Legislature — Kevin Owen McCarthy was known as the guy who could help bring a bill across the finish line. Gently, almost as if no one could see it.

headline: Obama on What Iraq’s Leadership Must Do
text: President Obama said the fate of Iraq hangs in the balance and discussed whether Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki could unify his country given the sectarian divisions.

headline: Disenchantment in France With Fickle National Team
text: Four years ago, Les Bleus, the French national soccer team, went on strike in South Africa. The incident capped the team’s self-destruction in the 2010 World Cup. In the aftermath, the players were called undereducated “PlayStation junkies” who were too individualistic to serve the nation.

headline: Domino Sugar, Brooklyn’s Sweet Story, Makes History
text: Almost 20 years ago, the Miser stood on the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg, wondering how long it would take the city’s savvier real estate developers to salvage the considerable stock of forsaken lots and warehouses, perched perfectly between a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood and sweeping river views.

headline: Five Plead Guilty to Beating a Motorist in Detroit
text: Five people involved in the severe beating of a Detroit motorist after his truck hit a 10-year-old boy pleaded guilty this week to reduced charges, ending a case that had raised concerns about racial tension and vigilantism in the bankrupt city.

headline: Obama on Engaging Iran in Iraq Crisis
text: The president discussed Iran’s declaration to intervene in Iraq.

headline: Neruda Poems Found
text: Twenty previously unknown poems by Pablo Neruda have been discovered by the Pablo Neruda Foundation in Santiago, Chile. Seix Barral, Neruda’s Barcelona-based publisher, announced the news on Wednesday. Elena Ramirez, the company’s editorial director, called it “”the biggest find in Spanish literature in recent years,” and emphasized “the extremely high quality” of several of the poems.

headline: Video of Man Rescued From German Cave
text: Rescuers from Bavaria’s Mountain Rescue Service carefully extracted an injured explorer through a series of shafts and tunnels after he was trapped for more than 11 days.

headline: Wisconsin Governor at Center of a Vast Fund-Raising Case
text: CHICAGO — Prosecutors in Wisconsin assert that Gov. Scott Walker was part of an elaborate effort to illegally coordinate fund-raising and spending between his campaign and conservative groups during efforts to recall him and several state senators two years ago, according to court filings unsealed Thursday.

headline: Baptism by Fire
text: Coming soon, by N.R. Kleinfield: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.

headline: At Art Basel, Works With a Museum Presence
text: BASEL, Switzerland — In an old market hall adjacent to the cavernous center where Art Basel, the gold standard of contemporary art fairs, is taking place, there is a happening unlike anything ever staged here. Called “14 Rooms,” it consists of 14 mini-performances created by artists including Marina Abramovic, Damien Hirst and Yoko Ono, each secreted in a small space behind mirrored doors. Open one door, and there’s a Marina Abramovic look-alike naked and astride a bicycle seat, arms outstretched. In another, identical twins sit in front of identical spot paintings by Mr. Hirst.

headline: Public Worker Testimony Is Protected, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The First Amendment protects government employees from retaliation for giving truthful testimony that was not part of their job responsibilities, a unanimous Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

headline: A German Voice, Hans-Olaf Henkel, Calls for Euro’s Abolition
text: BRUSSELS — He was once one of Germany’s most prominent business leaders, head of a major industry lobby and IBM’s top executive in Europe. But recently Hans-Olaf Henkel has embarked on a new career, one that puts him radically at odds with most of his European business peers.

headline: As Demand for Education Rises in Brazil, For-Profit Colleges Fill the Gap
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Higher education in Brazil is increasingly in the hands of profit-seeking entrepreneurs.

headline: Ask Well | Game On, Weekend Warrior
text: A reader asked Well if occasional cardiovascular exercise is better or worse than regular workouts.

headline: Money Remains Crime-Fighting Tool for New York Police
text: Amid advances in data-driven policing and forensic science, one traditional crime-solving tool has remained a constant for the New York Police Department: money.

headline: Sunday Night Dinner | At Il Buco, Platefuls of Pasta Seem Made to be Lingered Over
text: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: What’s a Tiara Like You Doing on Reality TV?
text: A first lady’s diamond tiara will head “home” to Ohio soon.

headline: Ask Well: Weekend Warriors
text: Question:

headline: Support From the Left Helps Keep a Right-Wing President in Power in Colombia
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Going into Sunday’s presidential election here, many people expected that the right-wing former president, Álvaro Uribe, would be the one whose outsize influence might tip the balance in favor of his preferred candidate, Óscar Iván Zuluaga.

headline: Iraqi Youth Orchestra Cancels American Trip
text: For the 43 teenage musicians of the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq, it was a dream about to come true: the ensemble, formed by the Iraqi pianist Zuhal Sultan in 2008, was planning to visit the United States this summer to work a similarly constituted American group, the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra, of Elgin, Ill., and then to perform in Elgin, Washington, D.C., Chicago and possibly New York (a concert was in the planning stages).

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
text: In the five years since Spain’s economy took a nose-dive, madrileños never stopped going out, but they did become more judicious in their spending. While not easy on businesses, this has ultimately been good for consumers, as retailers and restaurateurs dug deep in the treasure chest of Spanish talents and traditions — not to mention agricultural bounty — to weather the economic storm. Before that storm, Madrid seemed frantic to become a copy of any other European metropolis, but now the city feels more Spanish again. Resourcefulness, creativity and reinvention are bubbling up in art galleries, designer ateliers and restaurants. The city’s symbol may be a bear, but for style, culture, history and sybaritic delights, there are plenty of reasons to be bullish on Madrid.

headline: Valencia’s Newest Sounds of Music
text: Music is at the heart of Valencia, Spain’s third largest city. For hundreds of years, people in and around the city have formed symphonic brass bands. Children grow up learning to dance the jota and boleros and to play works by Mozart and Stravinsky, with flamenco coursing through their veins as well. Bordering the Mediterranean on Spain’s east coast, Valencia has long been the nexus of Western, African, Hispanic and South American cultures, the various musical traditions blending with the local.

headline: A Mother-Daughter Test: London, Together
text: Traveling with children seems to operate on a continuum that begins with plane discomfort for the gravely pregnant and ends with teenagers taking ski trips without you. It’s the various in-between stages that currently occupy me: the necessary Children-as-Extra-Luggage travel, as I once did on a book tour with a 5-month-old, coordinating feeds between readings; followed by attempts at Traveling Despite the Child, which my husband and I once did in Japan, hoisting our 10-month-old in a backpack and dining in our hotel bathroom while she slept. And then there is the interminable Where Else Could We Possibly Go? stage, a yearslong stretch of visits to the in-laws, house rentals in places where you won’t bother other people, forays into Disneyland. Into this category fall the whiling away of two-week breaks, babysitter vacations and four-day weekends that constitute the academic calendar.

headline: Moments in Iraq Reporters Will Never Forget
text: Over the course of the United States’ long entanglement in Iraq, many reporters from The New York Times have cycled through the bureau in Baghdad. As the country once again teeters toward sectarian warfare, we asked these reporters — now on other beats, in other parts of the world — which stories from their time in Iraq have been resurfacing in their minds. Several recalled ominous hints of what was to come, while others described the moment that pushed them to see just how deep-seated Iraq’s problems are.

headline: Unplugging in the Unofficial Capital of Yoga
text: It was a hot and dusty afternoon, about 30 hours into my Indian journey, when the bus driver dropped me off in a small town that he said was near my destination: Rishikesh, regarded as the unofficial world capital of yoga. Only a short rickshaw ride, it seemed, separated my fatigued self from inner Zen. Nearly two weeks of life with monks at an ashram awaited.

headline: Congressional Panel Subpoenaed in Insider Trading Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors and financial regulators have subpoenaed Congress in an investigation that could test the limits of federal insider trading laws.

headline: Picnic Tables for Dancing, Bookcases for Naps
text: FROM a distance, the yellow clapboard house on Governors Island looks normal, with its pretty pink flowers, white gingerbread porch railing and wide side yard. But move a little closer, and you start to wonder.

headline: Our Robot Nightmares
text: As robotics technology grows ever more surprising, its developers and users face a difficult problem: Robots are kind of scary.

headline: Congress and Us: A Hate-Love Relationship
text: Dear Congress: Our relationship has soured. I no longer have confidence in you. I’ve asked my friends, and they all agree. Only 7 percent of my fellow Americans now tell Gallup they have either a “great deal” or “quite of lot” of confidence in you. A mere 15 percent approve of the way you’re handling your job. They never really liked your friends — big business, organized labor and the banks — but now they tell me they have more confidence in each of them than they have in you.

text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: postpartum depression, celiac disease and mammograms. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: A Reporter Unplugs and Still Finds Connection
text: After spending three weeks in Russia covering the Olympics in Sochi, sports reporter Mary Pilon took a vacation in Rishikesh, India. This weekend, the Travel section will publish a story that she wrote about her time there. Here she shares how the trip, inspired by her desire to unplug, and the travel piece came to be.

text: Japan worked hard against Ivory Coast and might have won in slightly different circumstances. Greece was simply woeful; a complete offensive rethink is necessary, and it’s unlikely one was made in the past few days.

headline: With Pine and Ambrose Out, Rockwell and Arianda Step Into ‘Fool for Love’
text: Tony winner Nina Arianda and film and stage actor Sam Rockwell will play a battling couple in “Fool For Love” at the Williamstown Theater Festival this summer, replacing Lauren Ambrose and Chris Pine, who dropped out citing “scheduling difficulties.”

headline: A New Guide to the Grand Canyon by Wheelchair
text: Wheelchair users might not think of the Grand Canyon as a place to visit comfortably, but the accessible-travel writer Candy Harrington says it can be done in “Barrier-Free Travel: The Grand Canyon for Wheelers and Slow Walkers.”

headline: Icahn Urges Family Dollar to Sell Itself
text: Updated, 6:38 p.m. | The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has turned up the heat on Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake.

headline: Auditor Moore Stephens Said Not at Fault; Puda Coal Investor Suit Is Dismissed
text: In 2010, Puda Coal, a Chinese company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, raised $116 million from American investors in two public offerings. It presented audited financial statements showing that it had assets of $111 million and a net worth of $84 million at the end of 2009.

headline: C.D.C. Details Anthrax Scare for Scientists at Facilities
text: As many as 75 scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention may have been exposed to live anthrax bacteria after potentially infectious samples were sent to laboratories unequipped to handle dangerous pathogens, a spokesman for the federal health agency said Thursday.

headline: Praise to Make a Californian Blush
text: Not so long ago, the stereotype of California rosés included all the characteristics you would never want in a pink wine: heaviness, sweetness, high alcohol.

headline: A Summer Dinner With Echoes of Paella
text: Do not lose any sleep over what to serve with a rosé, be it from California or elsewhere. Mia Van de Water, one of our panelists, said that people tend to order rosé the way they do Champagne, because that’s what they want to drink, and it has nothing to do with the food. Jerusha Frost, the other guest panelist, agreed. “It’s rare when you get an opportunity to pair food with a rosé,” she said.

headline: Unsealed Court Order and Exhibits From ‘John Doe’ Investigation
text: These court documents detail a secret investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker and his campaign illegally coordinated fund-raising with 12 conservative groups during efforts to recall him in 2012.

headline: Cybercriminals Zero In on a Lucrative New Target: Hedge Funds
text: They say crime follows opportunity.

headline: F.C.C. Plans to Fine C.T.S. Technology of China for Selling Signal Jammers
text: WASHINGTON – The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday proposed a $34.9 million fine, its largest ever, against a Chinese electronics company for illegally marketing cellphone and radio jamming equipment online in the United States.

headline: Promoting Mortgage Preapprovals in Competitive Markets
text: Smaller lenders are using preapprovals to attract borrowers in markets where competition for homes is fierce.

headline: Turkish Officers Convicted in 2012 Coup Case Are Released
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s highest criminal court on Thursday ordered the release and retrial of 230 military officers who were convicted in 2012 of trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The decision came one day after the country’s constitutional court delivered a landmark ruling saying that the defendants’ rights had been violated.

headline: Torn by Three Loves and Styles of Jousting
text: Eric Rohmer, the French New Wave master, was in his mid-70s when “A Summer’s Tale,” the third installment of his “Tales of the Four Seasons” cycle, was released abroad in 1996. The only one of the cycle’s four films not distributed in the United States, it is finally having an American release, and it was worth the wait.

headline: Eye of the Beholder
text: My friend’s wife is an amateur painter. She gave me a painting as a housewarming gift a few years ago. I don’t like her work, so I stashed it in my office. Recently, she borrowed it for a charity exhibition, and later told me proudly that the painting sold for $10,000. She offered me another as replacement. I think selling the picture without asking was tacky. I also think I should receive the tax deduction for the donation because the painting belonged to me. Do you agree? And may I tell her I don’t want a replacement?

headline: Indie Rock Reflections on a Place and Time
text: Frank Zappa made a hobby out of tilting at rock journalists. He called the lot of them, in a tidy summary, “people who can’t write interviewing people who can’t talk for people who can’t read.”

headline: Globe Wiped Out? Tips From the Vault
text: You know the feeling. You emerge from a nap in your wine cellar or from a month in a submarine to find that during your absence, civilization has been destroyed, and only you, and perhaps a few other people, are left alive. You’re panicky. Grief stricken. Bummed. Full of impotent rage. Perhaps even a little gleeful.

text: 103 Norfolk Street,

headline: A Family Man (Daddy’s a Dictator)
text: This boy toy’s all grown up. To play Bassam Al Fayeed, a Middle Eastern dictator’s son living incognito as a Beverly Hills pediatrician named Barry on FX’s new “Tyrant,” Adam Rayner traded the callow sexual maneuverings he optimized in British series like “Mistresses” and “At Home With the Braithwaites” for the gravitas befitting a family man.

text: 523 West 24th Street

headline: A Calligraphic Answer to ‘I Like This’
text: Chinese calligraphy can seem daunting to viewers who are unfamiliar with the characters of this ancient art form. Some, stymied by the language barrier, tend to think about the physical act of the brushwork in the more familiar terms of dance or choreography, or to see the characters as abstract shapes (which, of course, they are not, although they have inspired abstract painters like Brice Marden and Franz Kline).

headline: Leaping Away From Success
text: In the last nine years, the contemporary ballet company Trey McIntyre Project became something almost unheard-of in the often beleaguered cultural landscape: a small, independent dance troupe that was a familiar name both at home in Boise, Idaho, and nationwide. A darling of festivals, the company traveled to up to 40 cities a year, finished each season in the black, gave its dancers full health insurance and offered them over 30 weeks of work each year.

headline: One Century’s Breathing Room Is Another’s Hiccup
text: The old network of easements and rights of way beside and behind the mansions on Fifth Avenue between East 78th and 79th Streets made life more comfortable for millionaires, but in 2014 is creating a headache for New York University.

headline: A Sadist and a Masochist Walk Into a Theater
text: “Venus in Fur,” Roman Polanski’s nimble film adaptation of the play by David Ives, might provoke a lively post-viewing argument. Is it about sex or power? Art or life? The nature of theater or the logic of desire?

headline: Presbyterians Vote to Allow Same-Sex Marriages
text: DETROIT — The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted at its General Assembly on Thursday to change its constitution’s definition of marriage from “a man and a woman” to “two people,” and to allow its ministers to perform same-sex marriages where it is legal.

headline: An Empty Heart Is One That Can Be Filled
text: I was 31 before I got my heart broken.

headline: The Man in the Gold Lamé Suit
text: James Lee Byars (1932-97) was one of the more intriguing characters to stir international art waters during the 20th century’s second half. An American playing the role of artist-as-shaman, he was lionized in Europe but not so well known in the United States. “James Lee Byars: ½ an Autobiography,” a retrospective at MoMA PS1, offers a valuable opportunity to assess his career. Was he the real deal, a true mystic sage? Or was he a canny, charismatic showman who knew how to exploit a modern hunger for timeless wisdom? The question hangs in the air throughout the exhibition, which was organized by Peter Eleey, the museum’s curator and associate director of exhibitions and programs, and Magalí Arriola, curator at Fundación Jumex Arte Contemporáneo in Mexico City, where it had its debut last November.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Third Person’
text: Paul Haggis narrates a sequence from “Third Person,” with Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

headline: ‘The Birth of a Theatrical Comet’
text: The musical “Rent” was featured on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section of The New York Times on Sunday, March 17, 1996.

headline: Steve Scalise, Obstructionist, Joins the House Leadership
text: Interest groups love keeping scorecards measuring the fidelity of lawmakers, but to judge the new leaders that House Republicans elected today all you really need to know is how they’d answer the question: Do you believe in governing by consensus or by destruction? Republicans today elected one of each type, which will probably lead to more tension, more obstruction, and less progress.

headline: If Seeing Is Believing, a Panorama of Truth
text: The Queens Museum has a big advantage when it comes to the familiar curatorial tactic of using older works from its permanent collection to inspire an exhibition of contemporary art. At the museum’s figurative and actual heart lies one of the great visual wonders of New York: “The Panorama of the City of New York,” a nearly 10,000-square-foot miniaturization of every building, street, park and bridge in the five boroughs, complete with day-night lighting cycles and tiny planes zipping in and out of La Guardia and Kennedy along almost-invisible wires.

headline: Events That Ponder a Grim Anniversary
text: PARIS — A century ago this month, the great powers of an earlier order began to unravel. World War I redrew the world map, ending the Hapsburg Empire and the Ottoman Empire and shifting the tectonic plates beneath Europe and the Middle East in ways that still resonate. From June 28, the date in 1914 when a young radical assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo, setting off a chain of events that started the war, to Nov. 11, the date that the Allies and Germany signed a first armistice ending the war in 1918, hundreds of cultural events are planned across Europe and the United States to observe the war’s 100th anniversary. Here are a few of them.

headline: I.R.S. Eases Some Rules for Taxpayers Overseas
text: WASHINGTON — Facing criticism that its crackdown on overseas tax cheats had disproportionately hurt small taxpayers guilty of innocent oversights, the Internal Revenue Service said it would revise its rules, lowering or eliminating some fines while tightening other requirements.

headline: The Sadness of Bugles as Soldiers Head Home
text: Ralph Vaughan Williams, the British composer long pigeonholed as a purveyor of bucolic calm, knew war, though he didn’t have to. When World War I began, he was 41, old enough to have avoided military service.

headline: In an Ironic Lens, a Latin Myth Evaporates
text: A Latin American spring is about to turn into a Latin American summer in New York City art museums. Purely, it seems, by chance, a record number of institutions have recently opened significant shows of work from South America and the Caribbean. The International Center of Photography, as usual one step ahead of the curve, has two.

headline: Dissimilar Figures, Revolted by Carnage
text: World War I made for strange bedfellows. One such pair, who never met, haunt me.

headline: Paul Haggis Narrates a Scene From ‘Third Person’
text: In this video, the writer and director Paul Haggis discusses a sequence from his drama “Third Person” featuring Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

headline: Visceral Reality vs. the Big Picture
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In the century since the First World War began, there have been bloodier conflicts and more barbaric ones. There have been wars that seem more pointless and wars that seem less conclusive. But the First World War remains distinctively stupefying.

headline: Future Shock: Whispering Harleys
text: Sales of electric motorcycles are just a tiny slice of a market that totals about 370,000 road-legal motorcycles a year in the United States, but Harley-Davidson, the proudly American maker of rumbling, brawny heavyweights, is hinting that it would like to change that.

headline: A Test for the Early Detection of Alzheimer’s Disease
text: Liz Arledge is all too familiar with the ravages of dementia. Her mother died of Alzheimer’s, and one of her brothers has been found to have the progressive brain disease as well.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael C. Davis on the Battle Over Hong Kong’s Future
text: Hong Kong is undergoing deepening tensions over its political future as a self-governed territory under Chinese sovereignty. Democratic activists have demanded that residents win the right to elect Hong Kong’s top leader, called the chief executive, without procedures that would ensure that only candidates approved by Beijing appear on the ballot. Many of the activists have endorsed Occupy Central with Love and Peace, a movement whose members have said they will stage civil disobedience protests in the city’s financial heart if electoral reform plans proposed by the Hong Kong government and Beijing, possibly later this year, do not meet their criteria for universal suffrage.

headline: A Venn Diagram of Love and Its Mutations
text: In Paul Haggis’s film “Third Person,” Liam Neeson plays Michael, a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist who has lost his creative mojo and is holed up in a Paris hotel, completing his latest opus. Accompanying him but staying in a separate suite is his girlfriend, Anna (Olivia Wilde), a wacko celebrity journalist who has literary pretensions that Michael is quick to shoot down. They go at each other with the merciless cruelty of two egotists whose only harmonious moments are bouts of frantic sex.

headline: Pitti Uomo: Z Zegna Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Adam Katz Sinding.

headline: Simple Fare, Bursting With Flavors
text: In recent weeks, when I told friends I was reviewing Crabtree’s Kittle House, I received a consistent response along the lines of: “That used to be my favorite place. I haven’t been in quite a while.” It wasn’t a terrible experience that had turned them off; there was just a general feeling that the longtime Chappaqua star had lost its zing.

headline: Good Feelings About McCarthy and Scalise Elections on Twitter
text: Republicans elected two members of their caucus to the No. 2 and No. 3 leadership positions in the House of Representatives today.

headline: Waiting in Existential Ennui
text: Many and contradictory are the claims that have been made for “Journey’s End,” the British playwright R. C. Sherriff’s 1928 portrait of life in the trenches and probably still the greatest of 20th-century English-language war dramas. It has been extolled and reviled as an impassioned plea for pacifism, a jingoistic celebration of homegrown heroes and an indictment of shortsighted military blundering.

headline: Suárez Staggers England With Finesse and Ferocity
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Luis Suárez’s first goal on Thursday was a delicate touch of class, a deft header nodded in with precision and purpose and placement. Suárez’s second goal, however — the one that was a death blow for England — was something closer to a savage blast.

headline: A ‘Rent’ Duo, Now Reunited
text: Scene Unseen is a new occasional series in which Sara Krulwich, a staff photographer for The New York Times, digs into her archives to talk about a theater photo that has never before been published. In this first installment, Ms. Krulwich takes a look at an image, taken in March 1996, of the original production of the musical “Rent” that features the actors Idina Menzel and Anthony Rapp. The two are now starring together in the new Broadway musical “If/Then.”

headline: A Chef Takes Time to Work the Crowd
text: “The hamburger or the pulled pork sandwich?” I wondered aloud one lunchtime at 55 Main, failing to notice that a wide-mouth bottle of ketchup on each table pointed the way. Jonas Gold, 43, the owner and chef, stopped by my table with the answer. That he is a “burger man,” as he told my party, shows in the quality of the hamburgers here — strip steak and filet mignon trimmings ground in-house, char-grilled as rare as you like, served with a brioche bun and crisp, fresh lettuce, onion and ripe tomato. French fries on the side are hand-cut in the kitchen. The only thing better would be a burger and a beer, Mr. Gold joked. It was true, though with liquor licenses so few and far between, good times take planning in New Jersey. Bring your own cold one, and follow the ketchup to this burger.

headline: The Clerk at Checkout Has Reasons to Be Happy
text: In Neil LaBute’s “I Dare You,” part of Theater Breaking Through Barriers’ “Power Plays,” a woman in a wheelchair dismisses another woman’s romantic overtures. “I’m not. ...” she says, gesturing reluctantly toward her legs, unable to complete the sentence. “I don’t care what you’re not,” the other woman answers. “I want you to find out what you are. Who you are.”

headline: Clip: ‘Venus in Fur’
text: A scene from the film directed by Roman Polanski.

headline: A Familiar Taste of the Mediterranean
text: On a recent Tuesday night at Yevma Authentic Greek Cuisine in East Meadow, a young man approached the takeout counter and complained that the gyro he had just purchased lacked lettuce and was studded with French fries. Peter Messaris, 48, the owner and chef, offered to add lettuce but also explained to the customer that gyros in Greece sometimes have French fries — not lettuce — tucked into the pita. The patron left with a smile on his face and we (seated nearby) learned why “authentic” is part of the restaurant’s name.

headline: Theater Listings for June 20-26
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 20-26
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: For Your Alfresco Friends
text: Gift ideas for an easy day trip based on lightweight, portable equipment for transporting food, cooking and lounging.

headline: Canadian Judge Says Google Must Remove Links Worldwide
text: OTTAWA — Google will appeal a decision by a court in British Columbia that requires the company to remove specific search results worldwide. While the case stems from an intellectual property dispute between two small industrial equipment companies, some legal experts say that if the decision is upheld it could have far-reaching consequences for the Internet.

headline: Staying Afloat in End Times
text: Premium cable hasn’t just influenced television, it has mated with it and spawned hybrids. “The Last Ship,” a maritime drama that begins on Sunday on TNT, is one of the better results of crossbreeding.

headline: Movie Listings for June 20-26
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: A Familiar Name Looks for Consistency on a Women’s Tour
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Walking along the fairways of Pinehurst No. 2 at the United States Women’s Open, Cheyenne Woods could not help but smile when fans yelled “Go Deacs!” as she passed by.

headline: For Clam and Lobster Lovers, They’re Palaces
text: Cruising the coast, a summertime tradition, has more purpose when one of Connecticut’s many clam and lobster shacks is the destination. Picnic-table views of the water are the rule, plastic-cutlery casual is the norm, and a sense of urgency is imposed because these spots are open only for the season. The three seafood shacks listed below deliver quality food in unsurpassed waterside settings.

headline: Kevin McCarthy’s Tea Party Bona Fides
text: How the moderate Republican from California got elected House majority leader with overwhelming Tea Party support.

headline: Carla Laemmle, Actress Since the 1920s, Dies at 104
text: Carla Laemmle, a dancer and actress whose screen career began in the silent era and ended with newfound celebrity in the Internet age, died on June 12 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 104.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for June 20-26
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
