text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for June 20-26
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: McCarthy on House Majority Leader Role
text: The newly elected House majority leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy, spoke after he was chosen to replace Eric Cantor who unexpectedly lost a primary election last week.

headline: Dance Listings for June 20-26
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Garbage In, Art Out
text: Plastic spoons, bullet shells, tennis balls.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 20-26
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Questions on Treatment of Mentally Ill by State
text: The sheriff of the state’s largest county is peeved with the Texas Department of State Health Services, the agency that runs the state’s mental health hospitals.

headline: Women of Congress and the Press Battle Breast Cancer, and for Bragging Rights
text: WASHINGTON — There are two foes capable of bringing together members of Congress: breast cancer and the press.

headline: McDaniel Drawn Into a Shouting Match at Campaign Event
text: JACKSON, Miss. — State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is in a runoff with Senator Thad Cochran for the Republican nomination in Mississippi, was drawn into a shouting match with a critic on Thursday as he met with a dozen retirees over cranberry and carrot cakes at a grocery store.

headline: Witness to Fatal Shooting of Palestinians Reports Threats From Israeli Soldiers
text: A Palestinian carpenter whose security cameras recorded the fatal shooting of two Palestinian teenagers at a protest in the West Bank last month told Human Rights Watch that he was threatened by Israeli soldiers this week during an hourlong interrogation.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 20, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Venus in Fur,” “Norte, the End of History” and “Jersey Boys.”

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 20-26
text: ‘Sharks’

headline: Tally of Cyber Extortion Attacks on Tech Companies Grows
text: Tech start-ups continue to get hit by extortion attempts from cybercriminals who aim to shut down their systems until companies pay their ransom.

headline: Carley Roney: Picnics in the Park, and Selfies With Brides
text: Carley Roney nearly wore black at her wedding in 1993, but decided at the last minute to wear her mother’s wedding dress. She planned the reception in three weeks; it turned out to be on a sweltering July evening. “I was the anti-bride and now I’m the queen of weddings,” she said. Ms. Roney, 46, and her husband, David Liu, 48, were among the founders of the wedding resource company The Knot in 1996. It has since become the XO Group, a media company that includes sites for new and pregnant couples. Ms. Roney and Mr. Liu and their children, Havana, 16, Cairo, 10, and Dublin, 6, live in Dumbo, which Ms. Roney calls “wedding central,” especially in June. Every bride in the city, she said, seems to take pictures beneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Spare Times for June 20-26
text: Adventures NYC (Saturday and Sunday) A bit of the great outdoors can be experienced in the city during this free, two-day celebration of rock climbing, kayaking, fly casting, slacklining and other activities in Central Park (on Saturday) and Marine Park, Brooklyn (on Sunday).

headline: I Was a Digital Best Seller!
text: WEST TISBURY, Mass. — FIVE months ago I published a short book called “Boom.” Commercially it was a bust. No news in that: Most books lose money and are quickly forgotten by all but their wounded authors.

headline: Gerry Goffin, Hitmaking Songwriter With Carole King, Dies at 75
text: Gerry Goffin, who collaborated with Carole King to write some of the biggest hits of the 1960s, songs that endured through generations and became classics, including “Will You Love Me Tomorrow?,” “Up on the Roof,” “One Fine Day” and “The Loco-Motion,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: Lucy Li, 11, Tops a 78 With Ice Cream at the U.S. Women’s Open
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Lucy Li’s historic United States Women’s Open debut was marred by two double bogeys and a triple bogey, which she handled with equanimity. The most disappointment Li showed all day was after her round of eight-over-par 78, when she had to hand over her pink ice-cream bar to her aunt to answer a videographer’s interview questions.

headline: The Hard Choices in Iraq and Syria
Live Music or Digital? The Drama Is Operatic
Congress and Guns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Events on Long Island for June 22-28, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Caring for Circus Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suit by Protest Groups on Spying Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge in Washington State has dismissed a lawsuit that accused a civilian intelligence analyst working for the military of breaking the law by using a fake name to infiltrate antiwar groups and trying to thwart protests by sharing information he collected with the Army, law enforcement agencies and private security firms.

headline: Clip: ‘Coherence’
text: A scene from the film directed by James Ward Byrkit.

headline: The Frick’s Expansion Plan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Female Playwrights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Just Another Little Dysfunctional Dinner Party
text: It’s a commonplace that speculative fiction speaks to the anxieties percolating in its age. Such seems the case with the likes of “Edge of Tomorrow,” which kinks up its narrative by repeatedly cycling back to the past, suggesting that complex theories about space-time are now so mainstream that they’re the stuff of mass entertainment. The same might be said of the far more modest “Coherence,” although it’s also true that digital tools, which allow directors to shoot fast, cheap and sometimes sloppily, are also helping pry loose linear narrative’s hold on movies.

headline: The Maze of Homelessness
text: To the Editor:

headline: After a Fire, a Dusty Town Hopes Not to Evaporate
text: FRITCH, Tex. — A month after a fire roared through this Panhandle town, all that remains of Sam Jones’s house is its concrete foundation, a row of charred pine trees and the underground storm shelter where he now lives.

headline: A Push for New Look into Tainted Water’s Source
text: WEATHERFORD, Tex. — Steve Lipsky has nearly everything he needs on his 14-acre estate along the Brazos River, west of Fort Worth. The estate includes a guesthouse, a resort-style swimming pool and a seven-bathroom, 15,000-square-foot home where he lives with his wife and three children.

headline: Luxury Apartments? Later. For Now, They Burn Sage.
text: The increasingly glassy Williamsburg waterfront seems an unlikely place for a sacred site. Yet among mirrored high-rises and a manicured shoreline, near the decaying remains of the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn, there sits on a shaggy patch of grass a 30-foot-tall white tepee, the smoke flap open to the sky, the door positioned east (toward the rising sun) and the poles lashed together, stretching out to infinity.

headline: Portrait of a Marriage, With a Star Turn for a Townhouse
text: The real star of “Exhibition,” the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London. Within its chilly spaces, the principal characters have lived and worked for 20 years. Married, childless artists in their 50s, the couple — identified only as D (Viv Albertine, an alumna of the rock group the Slits) and H (Liam Gillick, a well-regarded Conceptual artist) — work on separate floors connected by an elevator and a spiral staircase, and communicate via intercom.

headline: Chinese Government Tightens Constraints on Press Freedom
text: HONG KONG — China introduced new restrictions on what the government has called “critical” news articles and barred Chinese journalists from doing work outside their beats or regions, putting further restraints on reporters in one of the world’s most controlled news media environments.

headline: Tablet Geared Toward Children Underscores Power of Imagination
text: TO introduce the Nabi DreamTab, a computer tablet for children from a partnership between DreamWorks Animation and Fuhu, the companies are not initially focusing much on the device’s technical specifications, like its operating system and parental control features. Instead, advertising, marketing and promotional events are going out on a limb, in every sense, and prominently featuring treehouses.

headline: No to Guantánamo for Ahmed Abu Khattala
text: NEARLY eight years ago, 14 men arrived at Guantánamo after years in Central Intelligence Agency custody. Since then, only one has been tried and convicted with the case upheld on appeal. That was Ahmed Ghailani, a Tanzanian national who received a life sentence for his role in the 1998 bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed 223 people. Mr. Ghailani was tried in federal court in New York, and he is serving his sentence in a federal prison in the United States. His 13 comrades from the C.I.A. detention and interrogation program are still in limbo at Guantánamo, where justice for them and the families of their victims remains elusive.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Clip: ‘The Last Sentence’
text: A scene from Jan Troell’s film.

headline: International Monetary Fund Says Europe Should Weigh Bond-Buying
text: LUXEMBOURG — The International Monetary Fund on Thursday said that if inflation continued to drag, the euro zone’s central bank could do more to invigorate the economy by buying government bonds and other financial assets.

headline: Gay G.O.P. Candidates Feature Partners in Ads
text: WASHINGTON — Richard Tisei’s new campaign ad offers a scene of domestic bliss.

headline: After Challenging Hitler, It All Goes to the Dogs
text: It’s plausible that Torgny Segerstedt, a crusading Swedish journalist, was every bit as heroic, freethinking and sexually irresistible to women as he is portrayed in “The Last Sentence.” But you will need to take it on faith even after seeing this stultifying movie, a fictionalization of how Segerstedt (1876-1945) positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared “Herr Hitler is an insult.” Hermann Göring sent a telegram objecting to this boldly tossed gauntlet, one of many such complaints that challenged Segerstedt’s lonely fight.

headline: Health Exchange Enrollees Had Mostly Been Uninsured
text: WASHINGTON — Four in 10 people enrolling in health plans through the new insurance exchanges already had insurance, but six in 10 were previously uninsured, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey released Thursday.

headline: ‘We Should Be Further,’ Dominicans Say
text: The manager of Best Barbers in the Bronx offers free political advice to his fellow Dominicans sitting for $12 haircuts: Vote for Adriano D. Espaillat.

headline: The Corporate Daddy
text: For some time now, Republicans in Congress have given up the pretense of doing anything to improve the lot of most Americans. Raising the minimum wage? They won’t even allow a vote to happen. Cleaner air for all? They may partially shut down the government in a coming fight on behalf of major polluters. Add to that the continuing obstruction of student loan relief efforts, and numerous attempts to defund health care, and you have a party actively working to make life miserable for millions.

headline: Rays of Humanity in a Vile World
text: More than four hours long, filmed in expansive takes with almost no close-ups and very few camera movements, Lav Diaz’s “Norte, the End of History” is a tour de force of slow cinema. The movie, something of a sensation at Cannes last year, is not difficult or obscure — there is a clear, dramatic story involving characters who solicit both empathy and curiosity — but it does require an adjustment of the usual viewing metabolism.

headline: Looking After New Mothers
text: Should screening for postpartum depression be mandatory? How can those suffering be assured of treatment?

headline: What Happens in Vegas ...
text: Well, you can’t fault “Think Like a Man Too” for being a sequel too much like the original. The first film, inspired by Steve Harvey’s how-to-get-your-guy best seller, “Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man,” was a blatant product promotion, complete with bookstore signings and author appearances.

headline: Federal Reserve’s Bond-Buying Fades, but Stimulus Doesn’t End There
text: WASHINGTON — THE Federal Reserve is poised to keep purchasing large volumes of mortgage bonds, and potentially Treasury securities too, even after the likely conclusion of its prominent bond-buying program later this year.

headline: Those Who Took the Veil vs. Neighbors Who Take It All Off
text: STONE PARK, Ill. — It was a muggy afternoon, but the Sisters of St. Charles were wearing turtlenecks, long-sleeved habits and stockings as they gathered next to a microphone and an unsavory stretch of four-lane highway. They stood on the sidewalk below a billboard picturing a blonde who appeared to be wearing only eyeliner and a come-hither look: a jumbo-size invitation to Club Allure, a 20,000-square-foot strip club that is a newcomer to the neighborhood.

headline: Candidate Says He Can’t Trust Officials’ Tally of Afghan Vote
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah intensified his political brinkmanship on Thursday, insisting that he would not accept any result put forth by the country’s election commission as his supporters appeared to be gearing up for street protests.

headline: Even Among No-Hitters, Clayton Kershaw’s Was a Standout
text: Years from now, Charley Steiner said, when he recalls one of the greatest pitching performances in major league history, he will first remember Clayton Kershaw the hitter. In the bottom of the eighth inning Wednesday night, when he came to bat with an eight-run lead, Kershaw, the ace of the Los Angeles Dodgers, competed with everything he had.

headline: When Packing Up Unfurls a Hidden Past
text: “A Picture of You,” the feature debut from J. P. Chan, who wrote and directed, looks at one of the less cinematic aspects of grieving: packing up a house after a parent has died. A brother and sister, Kyle (Andrew Pang) and Jen (Jo Mei), spend the weekend at their mother’s Pennsylvania home. Purging her computer, they discover evidence of a romantic life neither wishes to ponder.

headline: Lessons for Dethroned Spain From Italy, a Rival Who’s Been There
text: RECIFE, Brazil — It was a shocking about-face: Four years after lifting the World Cup trophy and charming fans around the world with its attractive brand of soccer, Spain fizzled unceremoniously out of the tournament’s opening round, losing its first two games. It was cast as the sudden end of an era.

headline: Clip: ‘A Picture of You’
text: A scene from the film, directed by J. P. Chan.

headline: Buying Into Solar Power, No Roof Access Needed
text: Like many consumers, David Polstein had already done much to reduce energy use in his large Victorian home in Newton, Mass. He replaced his appliances with energy-efficient models, installed better heating and put in new insulation. But he was unable to get a solar system to reduce his utility bill, he said, because his roof is too small and shady to make it worthwhile.

headline: Obama Awards Medal of Honor
text: The president presented the Medal of Honor to Lance Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, who took the brunt of a grenade blast to save a fellow Marine while serving in Afghanistan.

headline: Marine Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter Receives Medal of Honor
text: WASHINGTON — Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, an automatic rifleman who shielded a fellow Marine from a grenade thrown at them during a firefight in Afghanistan in 2010, received the Medal of Honor from President Obama on Thursday.

headline: Turning It on, After a Long Drought
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — The opportunities and the goals came in rapid succession for Karim Benzema in his first World Cup match.

headline: Every Dish Is a Plat du Jour
text: Like the culinary geniuses of “Le Chef,” French cinema may need a new seasonal menu. This light, disposable soufflé from Daniel Cohen at times suggests “Ratatouille” with humans. For a film about mouthwatering cuisine, it offers only fleeting delectable sensations.

headline: 5 Exonerated in Central Park Jogger Case Agree to Settle Suit for $40 Million
text: The five men whose convictions in the brutal 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned have agreed to a settlement of about $40 million from New York City to resolve a bitterly fought civil rights lawsuit over their arrests and imprisonment in the sensational crime.

headline: In Chaos, Iraq’s Kurds See a Chance to Gain Ground
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — The chair Col. Imad Muhammad sat in belonged to a commander in the Iraqi Army. So did the tiny cup from which he was drinking his tea, the ashtray where he snuffed out his cigarettes and the Ping-Pong table and treadmill outside his office.

headline: World Cup 2014: How Teams Can Advance to the Next Round
text: Analysis and graphics show what needs to happen for teams in the 2014 World Cup to advance to the Round of 16.

headline: A Hit Man Repents, With Barrels Blazing
text: In “No Tears for the Dead,” the writer and director Lee Jeong-beom’s convoluted and stylish new action film, a South Korean-born, American-raised hit man with abandonment issues is assigned to assassinate the mother of a little girl he accidentally killed during an earlier hit. (We see this incident in a prologue, scored to a jazz club rendition of “Smooth Operator.”)

headline: Keeping Track: A Patent Decision, Overtime Pay
text: A Good Patent Decision

headline: Gay G.O.P. Candidate Begins Ad Campaign
text: Dan Innis, a gay Republican from New Hampshire, announced his candidacy for the House of Representatives in an advertisement.

headline: After Years of Solitude, Spanish Literary Champion Takes Partner
text: BARCELONA — Carmen Balcells was never just a literary agent. Nicknamed La Mamá Grande, after a story by Gabriel García Márquez, she served as a confidante and coach, someone who paid her writers’ dentist bills and deftly resolved their domestic problems while promoting the greatest Latin American and Spanish authors across the globe, including Mr. García Márquez, Mario Vargas Llosa and many more.

headline: Mark Emmert Plays Down Claims of Hypocrisy by N.C.A.A.
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the months before he took over as N.C.A.A. president in 2010, Mark Emmert received two important documents. One was a briefing email from his senior aide Wallace Renfro that referred to the “great hypocrisy of college athletics.” Renfro described it as a growing public perception that unpaid athletes were driving a multibillion-dollar industry.

headline: If Health Care Is a War, Here’s the Front Line
text: Idealism and reality collide in “Code Black,” Dr. Ryan McGarry’s impassioned record of his training in the embattled emergency room of the Los Angeles County General Hospital.

headline: Trial Secondary as U.S. Questions a Libyan Suspect
text: WASHINGTON — The Libyan suspected of playing a key role in the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi is talking freely with American interrogators aboard a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, according to senior American officials.

headline: Suárez Sends Rooney and England to the Brink
text: Luis Suárez gave Uruguay the lead with a header in the 39th minute. Wayne Rooney kept England's hopes alive with a goal in the second half, but Suárez struck again in the 85th minute to give Uruguay the victory.

headline: The Ugly Side of Bollywood
text: In “Miss Lovely,” Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade. It’s the flip side, or backside, of Bollywood’s sparkle, a place of intimidation, titillation and cash-for-reels deals, with only glimpses of cut-rate glamour.

headline: Signs of Trouble Preceded Fatal Stabbing at Bronx School
text: When Noel Estevez and Timothy Crump were friends, they did the things that 14-year-old boys everywhere like to do. They played video games, shared dirty jokes on Facebook and had at least one sleepover.

headline: Colombia: U.S. Ends Cali Gang Blacklist
text: The United States Treasury on Thursday removed 308 names from a sanctions blacklist that helped cripple the Cali drug gang in Colombia, once considered the most powerful drug trafficking organization in the world. The delisting, the largest in the history of the Treasury’s economic sanctions operations, lifted penalties against 78 individuals and 230 entities, mostly based in Colombia. The move left only the two leaders of the organization, which has collapsed financially, on the list. The leaders — the brothers Miguel and Gilberto Rodríguez Orejuela — were sentenced to 30-year prison terms in the United States after their capture and extradition in 2006. The brothers also agreed to forfeit $2.1 billion in assets worldwide, which the Colombian authorities are in the process of collecting.

headline: Yours, Mine and All That Other Mine
text: Diego Costa (José Garcia) is a feckless if amiable 42-year-old who regularly donated his sperm for research purposes 20 years ago, using the name Fonzy (no relation to Fonzie, Henry Winkler’s “Happy Days” character). A pothead with a vintage pinball machine at home, he is a variation on the movies’ overfamiliar man-child template. Now Diego learns he has sired 533 children, 142 of whom are looking for him. Oh, and his no-nonsense girlfriend (Audrey Fleurot) is pregnant by him, too. But by customary means.

headline: With Canoes of Concrete, Engineers at City College Paddle Merrily Onward
text: It might sound like an idea that would go over like the proverbial lead balloon, but in September, a group of engineering students at City College of New York began meeting and devising a way to build a concrete canoe.

headline: Gaza: Tunnel Blast Kills 5 Militants
text: Five militants affiliated with the Hamas movement were killed Thursday in what appeared to be an accident when an explosion ripped through a tunnel they had dug on the east side of Gaza City. An emergency worker also died, of smoke inhalation, while responding to the blast. Hamas, the militant faction that has ruled Gaza from 2007 until the formation of a Palestinian unity government this month, has long stored weapons in tunnels. Israel has carried out airstrikes in Gaza over the past week in response to rockets fired from Gaza into Israel, but Hamas did not blame it for Thursday’s explosion. Instead, the party’s armed wing said that the men were killed “while carrying out their jihadist duty in one of the resistance tunnels.”

headline: To Be Young, Besieged and Black
text: The beats are sweet, and the words often have an electric charge in “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” a new Broadway musical inspired by the lyrics of the popular but troubled rapper Tupac Shakur, who was shot and killed at 25 in Las Vegas in 1996. Unfortunately, much else about this ambitious show, which opened on Thursday at the Palace Theater, feels heartfelt but heavy-handed, as it punches home its message with a relentlessness that may soon leave you numb to the tragic story it’s trying to tell.

headline: In the Land of Mass Graves
text: Just over two decades ago, Rwanda was swept up in a murderous wave of ethnic violence that was as bad or worse as anything happening today in Iraq and Syria. The conflict was between a historically dominant ethnic minority and a historically oppressed majority, as in Iraq. Yet, today, Rwanda is a relatively successful country.

headline: Veterans and Zombies
text: You’ve surely heard about the scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs. A number of veterans found themselves waiting a long time for care, some of them died before they were seen, and some of the agency’s employees falsified records to cover up the extent of the problem. It’s a real scandal; some heads have already rolled, but there’s surely more to clean up.

headline: Egypt: Court Calls for Death Sentences for Top Muslim Brotherhood Members
text: An Egyptian court on Thursday began the process of imposing death sentences on the top leader and other members of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist political movement swept from power by the military nearly a year ago, in the latest sign of judicial support for the government’s crackdown on the Brotherhood. In the past few months, Egyptian courts have drawn international condemnation by issuing hundreds of death sentences against Brotherhood members and supporters after rushed trials that have relied on questionable evidence. On Thursday, the court referred the cases of Mohamed Badie, above, the Brotherhood’s spiritual leader, and 13 other people to Egypt’s highest religious authority, in what is seen as the first step in confirming the death sentences. Mr. Badie was also sentenced to death in April, in an unrelated case, but he is entitled to a retrial because the sentence was passed in absentia. In the latest trial, Mr. Badie and other senior leaders, including Essam el-Erian and Mohamed el-Beltagy, faced charges that included inciting murder during violence in Cairo last August.

headline: The Klinghoffer Tragedy
text: The Metropolitan Opera, which has scheduled “The Death of Klinghoffer” in the next season, has canceled plans to broadcast the opera live in movie theaters around the world. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, defended the decision this week, saying that the broadcasts “would be inappropriate at this time of rising anti-Semitism, particularly in Europe.”

headline: Good Progress on Affordable Health Care
text: Americans are finding very affordable health insurance and a wide choice of plans on the exchanges operated by the federal government, according to a report issued Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services. The report was based on data from the 36 states in which the federal government is operating health insurance exchanges this year. Comparable data from states operating their own exchanges is not yet available.

headline: Playing With Fire in Afghanistan
text: At this pivotal moment for Afghanistan, one of the two candidates for president, Abdullah Abdullah, is creating a political crisis by trying to interrupt the vote-counting in Saturday’s runoff. On Wednesday, he demanded that the election commission stop counting ballots and withdrew his election observers from the process.

headline: Uganda: Anti-Gay Law Draws Sanctions
text: The Obama administration announced additional punitive steps against Uganda on Thursday in response to the country’s new law criminalizing homosexuality. Certain Ugandan officials will be barred from entering the United States, and some aid money for Ugandan police and health agencies will be cut off or redirected, the administration said. In addition, the Obama administration canceled plans to hold a military aviation exercise in Uganda. But administration officials said the moves would not diminish the American partnership with Uganda against the Lord’s Resistance Army, a rebel force known for its brutality. And the new travel ban is not expected to prevent Uganda’s foreign minister, Sam Kutesa, from traveling to New York, where he has just been elected president of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Weathering the Deluge of 1927
text: “The Great Flood” and “Visitors,” two monochromatic, wordless, nonnarrative features that opened theatrically this year and are now available for home viewing, aren’t so much avant-garde as anachronistic — although it is that anachronism, the notion of a silent cinematic symphony, that makes them seem avant-garde.

headline: Puts Somebody Out
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — UPDATE: Sorry for the delay. Back to your regularly scheduled blog.

headline: A Freelance Career, Found in Translation
text: The opening of “Monty Python and the Holy Grail” memorably features credits translated by an overzealous subtitler. Tired of listing the cast, the unseen translator abruptly goes rogue with a tourism pitch: “Wi not trei a holiday in Sweden this yer?”

headline: U.S. Authorities Step In to Charge 2 After Deaths From Extra-Lethal Heroin
text: The first death came in late December. A 20-year-old man and his girlfriend bought $100 worth of heroin from a man named Dennis at an apartment complex in Hopewell Junction, N.Y. It was a new brand for them: The glassine envelopes were labeled “Breaking Bad” and bore the distinctive logo of the television show of that name.

headline: Owner of Revel Casino in Atlantic City Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: The $2.4 billion Revel Casino Hotel, whose opening two years ago on the Atlantic City boardwalk was hailed as a revival of the city’s gambling industry, filed for protection from creditors in federal bankruptcy court on Thursday as the owner formally put the property on the auction block.

headline: New Contract for Teachers Is Altering Schools’ Hours
text: For New York City public school students and their parents, the trek to school can often seem like a race to the finish line, with the constant fear of stalled subways or unexpected squalls disrupting a carefully orchestrated routine.

headline: Rapper Denies Murder, but Testifies About a Life Studded With Criminal Acts
text: Ronald Herron’s youth unfolded in Apartment 4E at 423 Baltic Street in Brooklyn. That was where, he testified on Thursday, he saw his mother using cocaine and heroin; where his sisters, who were “professional shoplifters,” also lived; and where he resided when he was arrested for his first crime at age 13.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 19, 2014
Rebukes Aside, Rangel Heads Into Primary With Large Lead, Poll Shows
text: Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem congressman fighting to secure a 23rd term in office, has retained a significant lead over his nearest rival, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, with only days to go in a hotly contested Democratic primary, a poll released on Thursday found.

headline: New York Legislature Closing Session With a Flurry of Activity
text: ALBANY — New York State’s lawmakers were wrapping up their annual six-month sojourn here with a flurry of deals and decisions on Thursday, closing an election-year legislative session with little conflict or high drama.

headline: Avraham Shalom, 86, Israeli Spy Chief Who Hunted Eichmann, Dies
text: JERUSALEM — Avraham Shalom, who helped track down Adolf Eichmann and led Israel’s internal security agency in a long spying career for his country before resigning under a cloud over the killing of two Palestinian hijackers, died Thursday in Tel Aviv. He was 86.

headline: Wheeler and Wright Give Mets Everything They Need
text: MIAMI — Last month, before a Dodgers-Mets game at Citi Field, Clayton Kershaw happened upon Mets Manager Terry Collins in center field. They had known each other since 2006, when Collins was the Dodgers’ director of player development and Kershaw was drafted in the first round, seventh over all.

headline: Chemical Company’s Shares Rise in Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — Shares in the Tianhe Chemicals Group rose on Friday in their trading debut in Hong Kong after the company raised about $650 million last week in an initial public offering.

headline: King Juan Carlos’ Reign Over Spain
text: A slide show of the king through the years and the transition of power to his son Felipe.

headline: Jets’ Geno Smith, Dedicated to Improving, Will Work Through the Summer
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — With the close of N.F.L. minicamps, many players will travel far and wide, eager to refresh their bodies and minds in preparation for the sweltering days of training camp leading to a 16-game regular season that inevitably leaves them battered, if not broken.

headline: Dr. Lorna Wing, Who Broadened Views of Autism, Dies at 85
text: Dr. Lorna Wing, a British psychiatrist who was instrumental in identifying autism as a mental disorder of many gradations, affecting people across the spectrum of intelligence — and who gave autism in its mildest form the name Asperger’s syndrome — died on June 6 in Kent, England. She was 85.

headline: Moroccan Flair in Late-Season Summer Finds
text: Though summer doesn’t officially begin until tomorrow, stores have already begun to stock autumn/winter 2014 collections. But beneath the onslaught of warm outerwear and cozy sweaters, you can still find some seasonally appropriate spring/summer pieces. There are separates and accessories inspired by both the fashion and architecture of Morocco. The exotic prints embraced by designers like Isabel Marant, Tod’s and Emamò are as colorful as the country’s inhabitants, evoking the graphic tiles that line the riads and the vivid shades that pop throughout the spicy perfumed souks of Marrakesh. Whether worn together in some far off corner of the world or as part of an otherwise minimalist outfit, these bohemian accents are worth the hunt. (And soon, they could end up on sale!)

headline: Obama Extends Marriage Benefits to Gay Couples
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Friday announced regulatory changes to extend a wide range of marriage benefits to same-sex couples, making good on a promise by President Obama after the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act last year.

headline: Word of the Day | conformity
text: conformity •\kən-ˈfȯr-mə-te\• noun

headline: Yankees Cap Sweep With Speed, Not Slugging
text: There are nights when the Yankees, long known for their power hitting, look meek at the plate and must find ways other than the long ball to score runs. The off-season additions of Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian Roberts to complement Brett Gardner have made these Yankees, uncharacteristically, more runners than bombers.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) TANAQUIL LE CLERCQ: AFTERNOON OF A FAUN In 1944, as a 15-year-old dancer at the School of American Ballet, Ms. Le Clercq (above, with Edward Bigalow) appeared in “Resurgence,” a short piece created by George Balanchine for a March of Dimes benefit. Portraying the evil Polio, Balanchine enveloped Ms. Le Clercq in a black cape, rendering her character paralyzed. After children tossed dimes at her character, she arose. In 1956, by then the wife of Balanchine and a muse to Jerome Robbins, Ms. Le Clercq, 27, contracted polio while touring with the New York City Ballet in Copenhagen. Paralyzed from the waist down, she never danced again. Through interviews with her colleagues Jacques d’Amboise and Arthur Mitchell and others, this “American Masters” documentary, directed by Nancy Buirski, chronicles the life of Ms. Le Clercq (1929-2000), the inspiration behind Balanchine’s “Symphonie Concertante,” “Symphony in C,” “Bourrée Fantasque” and “La Valse” and Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 20, 2014
text: “We will be helping Iraqis as they take the fight to terrorists who threaten the Iraqi people, the region, and American interests as well.”

headline: Corrections: June 20, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Man Takes His Cabbage for a Walk
text: The Chinese performance artist Han Bing drags a cabbage through city centers as a social commentary on people’s relationships with objects in their lives.

headline: Family, Corruption and Sage Words From a News Agency
text: The Chinese language is revealingly rich in mordant sayings about the nexus of family, officialdom and corruption. When a man becomes an official, one saying goes, even his “chickens and dogs become immortals.” And a commentary by the state news agency Xinhua that appeared Friday, laced with similar phrases, was likely to be worrisome reading for Ling Jihua, once the powerful gatekeeper to the Communist Party’s leadership.

headline: In Last-Ditch Effort for Alstom, Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Raise Offer
text: PARIS — The top executives of Siemens and General Electric on Friday made what were likely to be their final pitches to the French government in their battle for Alstom, the French industrial company at the center of a high-stakes political battle.

headline: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Refugees as Civil Wars Cripple Nations
text: In Central African Republic, they ran from home and slept under the trees. In Colombia, they dared not return to their villages. From Syria, they fled by the hundreds of thousands, escaping barrel bombs and summary executions.

headline: Beijing From on High, Just Steer Clear of the Halls of Power
text: On all-too-rare clear days, Beijing can be a remarkably beautiful city, with elegant imperial buildings, ramshackle courtyard homes, shimmering skyscrapers and jagged hills rising in the distance.

headline: Student Crossword | Cooking
text: Test your knowledge of cooking by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: I.P.O. Values Euronext Exchange Operator at $1.9 Billion
text: LONDON – IntercontinentalExchange, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said late Thursday that an initial public offering of its Euronext unit valued the business at 1.4 billion euros, or $1.9 billion.

headline: Lloyds Sells More Shares Than Expected in I.P.O. of TSB Unit
text: Updated, 3:07 p.m. |

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
text: In “Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe,” Jad Mouawad writes about the rise of the Persian Gulf city of Dubai.

headline: It’s Official: The Boomerang Kids Won’t Leave
text: Annie Kasinecz has two different ways of explaining why, at age 27, she still lives with her mom. In the first version — the optimistic one — she says that she is doing the sensible thing by living rent-free as she plans her next career move. After graduating from Loyola University Chicago, Kasinecz struggled to support herself in the midst of the recession, working a series of unsatisfying jobs — selling ads at the soon-to-be bankrupt Sun-Times, bagging groceries at Whole Foods, bartending — in order to pay down her student loans. But she inevitably grew frustrated with each job and found herself stuck in one financial mess after another. Now that she’s back in her high-school bedroom, perhaps she can finally focus on her long-term goals.

headline: French Summer Castles in the Sand
text: At Piémanson, a Mediterranean beach in southern France, summer starts early. On April 30, families wait for the clock to strike midnight, ready to build makeshift beach houses on the same shoreline spot from previous years.

headline: G.O.P. Senator Courts Blacks in Mississippi Primary Race
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Inside an abandoned grocery store-turned-church here, a dozen black pastors gathered to discuss a seemingly impossible task: persuading their congregations to vote Republican next week.

headline: Drug Maker AbbVie Joins a Stampede to Go Abroad
text: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | At first it was a trickle. A few relatively unknown pharmaceutical companies acquired international competitors, and moved their headquarters abroad.

headline: New York Today: The Longest Day
text: Good morning to you on this brightening Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Shirley and the Bodybuilder
text: When a former champion bodybuilder from Ghana opened a small gym in an affordable housing development in lower Manhattan, 90-year-old Shirley Friedman became a dedicated client.

headline: A Chiseled Bodybuilder, Frail Clients and a Fitness Story for the Ages
text: With his enormous muscles bulging beneath a small T-shirt, Martin Luther King Addo guided one of his most dedicated clients through a squat exercise inside his tiny Manhattan gym. “You can do it, Shirley,” he said.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches
text: What to watch for in Friday’s Group D and E matches of Italy vs. Costa Rica, Switzerland vs. France and Ecuador vs. Honduras.

headline: Lebanon Detains 17 Said to Be Islamist Militants
text: BEIRUT — Lebanese security forces arrested 17 men in two Beirut hotels on Friday on suspicion that they were plotting to assassinate a prominent Lebanese Shiite leader, a government official said, describing an attack that could inflame sectarian conflict across the Middle East.

headline: As Ukraine Announces Cease-Fire, White House Points Finger at Russia
text: WASHINGTON — On a day that the Ukrainian government announced a unilateral cease-fire in its battle with separatists in the country’s east, the Obama administration raised the stakes with Russia on Friday, accusing the Kremlin of continuing to covertly arm the rebels.

headline: In Hong Kong, an Unofficial Election Draws Beijing’s Ire
text: HONG KONG — More than 350,000 residents of Hong Kong did something on Friday that no one in mainland China can do: They participated in a free vote over their political future. The Chinese government promptly responded by denouncing the entire exercise in bottom-up democracy as “illegal and invalid.”

headline: Morning Views
text: “Americans are finding very affordable health insurance and a wide choice of plans on the exchanges operated by the federal government, according to a report issued Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services,” writes The New York Times. The editorial board believes this indicate progress toward an America where all citizens have coverage: “Though the system is still new, millions of Americans are already being helped, and every success makes it that much harder for its political enemies to repeal or disable it.”

headline: The Unexpected Ceasefire in Washington’s Tax Wars
text: “I grew up castrating hogs,” Joni Ernst tells voters in Iowa in her signature TV ad, vowing to “make ′em squeal” in Washington. But she’s not talking about cutting income tax rates.

headline: What Makes a Great Editor? Part 3.
text: An editor is one who separates the wheat from the chaff and prints the chaff.

headline: On Our Walls
text: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: More Thoughts on How Small Businesses Can Deal With Big Businesses
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about strategies for handling late-paying clients and continued to discuss the challenges of negotiating with larger companies.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In the news this week: the crisis in Iraq. What did you read in The Times that interested you most?

headline: A College Major Matters Even More in a Recession
text: Graduating into a recession is unlucky. The bad luck haunts young people for years, studies have shown, affecting their salaries, employment prospects and even their health and happiness.

headline: Morning Agenda: Icahn Takes Aim at Family Dollar
text: ICAHN TAKES AIM AT FAMILY DOLLAR  |  The activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who has a long record of aggressively lobbying corporate boards and management, has turned his attention to Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake, DealBook’s William Alden writes. In a letter to Howard R. Levine, Family Dollar’s chief executive, Mr. Icahn urged the company to self itself “immediately.” He also demanded that three of his representatives be added to Family Dollar’s board. If the company does not cooperate, Mr. Icahn said he plans to go directly to shareholders with an effort to throw out the entire board.

headline: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian Teenager Protesting Arrests in the West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli troops killed a Palestinian youth before dawn Friday and seriously wounded several adults as their sweeping West Bank arrest campaign following last week’s disappearance of three Israeli teenagers both slowed and encountered more resistance.

headline: A Second Career, Happily in the Weeds
text: MARBLETOWN, N.Y. — STANDING at the edge of an overgrown field, Charles Noble, 65, cups his hands around his mouth and yells, “Mooowaaaahhh.” He hopes his bovine impression will motivate 68 cattle to follow him to a nearby creek. His herd is apparently not thirsty, preferring to munch on tall grass.

headline: U.S. Will Send 300 Advisers to Iraq
text: Iraq is facing an uprising of Sunni militants.

headline: Egypt Has a Sexual Violence Problem
text: CAIRO — There is a fierce battle raging in Egypt, and it’s not the one between Islamists and military rulers — the two factions that dominate most coverage of my country these days. The real battle, the one that will determine whether Egypt frees itself of authoritarianism, is between the patriarchy — established and upheld by the state, the street and at home — and women, who will no longer accept this status quo.

headline: In a Comedic Grab Bag, Many Welcome Surprises
text: Jane Lynch signaled in the opening moments of her smart, witty show at 54 Below on Wednesday evening that this was not going to be your typical cabaret evening of songs built around a theme, with a carefully plotted narrative arc. It was the opposite. In its free-form goofiness, it was what you might call “anti-cabaret.” That’s my term, not hers.

headline: Facing Cuts, Musicians Criticize Met’s Leadership
text: The bitter labor talks at the Metropolitan Opera took a new turn this week with a blast from the pit: Musicians in the orchestra, who are being asked to accept pay and benefit cuts, sent letters to the company’s board questioning the Met’s artistic and financial stewardship.

headline: Beethoven, Bronfman and Soaring Sparks
text: Twice now, in the course of a week, a New York Philharmonic concert has begun, uninspiringly, with a Beethoven piano concerto and has ended, powerfully, with a Beethoven piano concerto.

headline: After Accolades, Trio Injects a Little Folk Melody and Switches Gears Often
text: Before playing a note in its sold-out first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday night, the trio known as Children of the Light paused to receive some accolades. Together, its members — the pianist Danilo Pérez, the bassist John Patitucci and the drummer Brian Blade — make up the rhythm section in the Wayne Shorter Quartet. As such, they were presented with awards from the Jazz Journalists Association: midsize ensemble of the year and record of the year, for Mr. Shorter’s most recent album, “Without a Net.”

headline: Some Playful Touches in a Serious Approach
text: It takes grit to run a modern-dance company for 20 years, and Pascal Rioult has succeeded, driven partly by a desire to churn out works meant to pack an emotional wallop. Like his mentor Martha Graham, in whose troupe he danced, he creates efficiently structured choreography that is meant to stir and even unsettle the soul. Yet while Mr. Rioult’s passion for pairing dance and music is obvious, passion isn’t everything, and a missing ingredient blurs his efforts: a choreographic voice of his own.

headline: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica Defeats Italy, 1-0
text: With a gritty performance and a clear strategy, Costa Rica guaranteed themselves a spot in the knock-out rounds with a 1-0 victory over Italy.

headline: World Cup 2014: France Defeats Switzerland, 5-2
text: The last time France won its first two opening-round games was in 1998 — when they went on to win the World Cup.

headline: ‘The Goldfinch’ Alights in a Repolished Jewel Box
text: THE HAGUE — Since it opened to the public in 1822, the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis has been one of those quiet gems, set in a 17th-century classical townhouse in the center of this patrician city and frequented by lovers of Dutch Golden Age painting. But when it closed for a renovation and expansion two years ago, and a selection from its collection went on tour, Mauritshuis gained an instant celebrity it had never had before.

headline: World Cup 2014: Ecuador Defeats Honduras, 2-1
text: Ecuador is still alive for one of the top two spots in Group E after Friday’s victory over Honduras.

headline: A Glass Window Imperils a Baby Bird
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Republicans, at Hearing on Lost Emails, Accuse I.R.S. Chief of Lying
text: WASHINGTON — A congressional hearing examining how the Internal Revenue Service lost thousands of emails sought by investigators turned confrontational on Friday, with Republicans on the panel accusing the I.R.S. commissioner of lying.

headline: Does Sex No Longer Sell T-Shirts? The Lessons of American Apparel and Abercrombie & Fitch
text: O.K., I know that is a big question. But I’ve been thinking about it ever since the ouster on Wednesday of the American Apparel founder and chief executive Dov Charney.

headline: Listen Up | Andrea Balency Takes the Long Road to Electronica
text: The singer and producer Andrea Balency takes an unconventional tact when it comes to making electronic music. Rather than adding to what has become the echo chamber of EDM (electronic dance music), Balency’s ethereal voice and soft structures instead aim to mimic the movements of contemporary dance. “I’ve always loved dancing,” she says. “Those movements are something I try to translate with music.”

headline: U.S. Gives Thailand and Malaysia Lowest Grade on Human Trafficking
text: HONG KONG — Thailand and Malaysia are among the two dozen countries doing the least to fight human trafficking, according to a State Department report released Friday, a finding that could lead to economic and diplomatic penalties.

headline: Telling Folk Heroes From Monsters
text: Woe to the once-hallowed trickster. In ancient mythologies, the riddler-thief and agent of change held a position of prestige. Now, we don’t know what to do with him. In our two Americas, we do black and white, either/or, with us or against us. The trickster is in between, both and neither, a character on the fringes.

headline: America As A Lousy Exporter
text: Sorry about two-day silence — busy with real life and various obligations.

headline: New York City Leaders Reach Accord on $75 Billion Budget
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, have announced an agreement on a $75 billion budget that Mr. de Blasio said signaled a more compassionate era for New York City, with investments in public housing, expanded prekindergarten programs and summer jobs for youths, but with no tax increases or major cuts.

headline: Chinese Workers in Iraq Staying Put, for the Moment
text: As sectarian fighting continues to roil Iraq, Chinese companies say they are preparing contingency plans to evacuate their workers from the country. But Chinese citizens based in the country’s south, which is less affected by the violence and where Chinese investment is concentrated, said in interviews that they felt safe for now and had no immediate plans to leave.

headline: In Our Pages: June 21
text: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Baron Henri de Rothschild is shot in Paris in 1914; Nationalist Spain says it will be neutral in the event of a European war in 1939.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be American?
text: Throughout our journey up Interstate 35 — we’re at 3,500 miles, and counting — Todd Heisler and I have chronicled the process of cultural transformation in Middle America. Once-homogeneous towns and cities from Texas to Minnesota are now heavily influenced by the world; by immigrants with different customs, languages and ideas.

headline: Austerity and Hysteresis
text: Larry Ball has an important paper documenting, on a consistent basis, a very disturbing point: if you believe official estimates of potential output, the Great Recession and its aftermath have done incredible damage, not just to short-run output and employment, but to long-run prospects.

headline: 6 New Ways to Measure Your Financial Goals
text: Most of us want goals to shoot for, but all too often we pick the wrong ones.

headline: As Child Migrants Flood to Border, U.S. Presses Latin America to Act
text: MEXICO CITY — Faced with an unprecedented surge of child migrants from Central America that is overwhelming shelters and jails in Texas and Arizona, the United States has begun pushing for stronger regional cooperation to arrest the flow and enable the children’s safe return.

headline: The Unwanted Rites of Summer Phone Service
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Of Shower Scenes and Santeria
text: Season 2, Episode 5 Strap in. Just as the last four episodes were starting to feel a bit too linear, this one moves fast in a lot of different directions — both in the past and present stories. (Spoilers below.)

headline: U.S. Moves to Stop Surge in Illegal Immigration
text: McALLEN, Tex. — White House officials, saying that misinformation about administration policies helped drive a surge of illegal migrants from Central America across the South Texas border, on Friday announced plans to detain more of them and to accelerate their court cases so as to deport them more quickly.

headline: Letters: ‘No Place to Hide’
text: ‘No Place to Hide’

headline: The Great Y.A. Debate of 2014
text: When the journalist Ruth Graham finished reading John Green’s tear-jerker of a best seller “The Fault in Our Stars,” her eyes were dry, and she wondered: “Does this make me heartless? Or does it make me a grown-up?”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A REPLACEMENT LIFE,  by Boris Fishman. (Harper, $25.99.) In Fishman’s bold, ambitious and wickedly smart first novel, a Soviet émigré writer in New York becomes disturbingly adept at forging applications for Holocaust reparations.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WE NEED NEW NAMES,  by NoViolet Bulawayo. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.) Ten-year-old Darling, the narrator of Bulawayo’s striking first novel, a Man Booker Prize finalist, ekes out a bare-bones existence in a Zimbabwe shantytown. When she’s sent to live with relatives in Detroit, Darling discovers that, far from the comforts of her childhood community, much of America’s abundance is out of reach, and she is forced to reckon with the sacrifices and mixed rewards of assimilating.

headline: The Living and the Undead
text: Reading the blurbs on the dust jacket of Lauren Owen’s first novel — from such luminaries as Kate Atkinson, Hilary Mantel and Tana French — readers might think they’re about to embark on a highhanded version of the Gothic novel, full of metafictions and literary allusions. These do appear, along with some beautiful language, but by Page 100, when the first neck is about to be bitten, “The Quick” drops its cloak and becomes a good old-fashioned vampire novel.

headline: The Descent
text: How, in this age of surveillance, can we lose a 210-foot airplane? With its known initial flight path and fuel load, investigators can restrict the last possible position of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to a sliver of the globe. Trouble is, most of that sliver — like 71 percent of Earth’s surface — is covered by water.

headline: Down Under
text: Our planet’s coral reefs offer nourishment and sanctuary to as many as nine million species, running the gamut of life, from single-cell organisms to whales. The Great Barrier Reef, shimmering beneath the turquoise shallows of Australia’s east coast, surpasses all other coral ecosystems in scale and fame. This colossal spine of life stretches for 1,400 miles, roughly the distance from Boston to Havana. Today the Great Barrier Reef seems obviously spectacular: a World Heritage Site visible to astronauts in outer space and acclaimed as one of the earth’s greatest natural wonders. Yet as Iain ­McCalman reveals in his enthralling book, “The Reef,” little more than 200 years ago no human had any inkling of its dimensions, far less any inkling of the complex science of its precarious vitality.

headline: Secret Lives
text: ’TIL THE WELL RUNS DRY  By Lauren Francis-Sharma  Holt, $27.

headline: For Whom the Bell Tolled
text: While many ran in terror from the mounting monstrosities of Spain’s civil war in the late 1930s, three couples — the bright young photographers Robert Capa and Gerda Taro, the writers Ernest Hemingway and Martha Gellhorn, and the devoted press officers Arturo Barea and Ilsa Kulcsar — jumped into the fray. As Amanda Vaill writes in “Hotel Florida,” they risked their lives to shape public opinion and sharpen political will, daring their way toward a new destiny.

headline: Late Reinforcements
text: Of the many challenges confronting the contemporary writer of fiction, among the most vexing is the problem of goodness. How does one convincingly portray goodness in an age when the twin presiding deities are irony and violence, when the most feared transgression is the sin of sentimentality? Can there be a place for a character who seems genuinely selfless, motivated by benevolence, decency, the desire to be of help?

headline: Who Made That Pacifier?
text: By the time Christian W. Meinecke applied for a patent for “a new and original Design for a Baby Comforter” in 1901, people had been giving babies soothing objects to suck on for centuries: knotted rags dipped in water or honey, wooden beads or “gum sticks” made of stone, bone or coral. But nothing would ever be quite as popular as the pacifier.

headline: So You Think You Can Steal?
text: I witnessed an odd incident: Two cars stopped, and the drivers began arguing. After a few moments of yelling, one driver got into the other’s car, and they drove off, leaving the second car unlocked with the engine running. I saw this very situation on a reality TV show called “Bait Car”: a vehicle is left for someone to steal while the police and cameramen wait. I yelled: “Bait car! Bait car!” as a warning for people nearby. When I told this story later, I was criticized for helping would-be thieves. But I am not comfortable with the show’s premise. Should I have said nothing? STEVEN FONG, SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Kevin Hart: ‘I Don’t Need Therapy’
text: The comedian talks to Jessica Gross about his first night onstage, growing up in North Philadelphia and learning about the existence of tall people.

headline: How to Give an Outdoor Cocktail Party
text: Advice from an event planner, plus the dangers of the Dow, sunscreen brands by S.P.F. and more.

headline: What I Didn’t Understand That Summer in Mexico
text: I had never been to Mexico before. It was the summer after eighth grade, and my best friend’s parents invited me to their condo in the Yucatán Peninsula, about an hour by car from Cancun. My mother dropped me at Newark Airport. She told me to behave.

headline: Moving Forward
text: On the cusp of turning 50, the artist Tracey Emin told the BBC: “I always thought that love was about desire, being with someone, holding someone, feeling someone. But it isn’t necessarily. Love can be different and come in lots of different ways and lots of different guises.” Her interviewer was suitably intrigued. England’s notorious “bad girl” no longer cared about shagging.

headline: Early Frost
text: In the early fall of 1912, a blandly handsome, tousle-headed American schoolteacher arrived in London. Nearing 40, coming without introduction or much of a plan — except, as he later confessed, “to write and be poor” — he was making a last attempt to write himself into poetry. It would have taken mad willfulness to drag his wife and four children out of their ­settled New Hampshire life in a quixotic assault on the London literary scene. Still, he was soon spending a candlelit evening with Yeats in the poet’s curtained rooms, having come to the attention of that “stormy petrel” Ezra Pound, who lauded him in reviews back home. Little more than two years later, the schoolteacher sailed back, having published his first two books, “A Boy’s Will” (1913) and “North of Boston” (1914). He had become Robert Frost.

headline: The Wordy Shipmate
text: When Geoff Dyer came aboard the U.S.S. George H. W. Bush for his 14-day stay, he had his Ping-Pong paddle securely stowed but had misplaced his notebook. Too tall, spindly, self-described as “a leftover from a novel Graham Greene had decided not to write,” he had managed through a stubbornness born of sheer neurotic panic to wheedle his way, despite considerable and justified resistance from the United States Navy, into private quarters on the giant but very crowded vessel: the Vice-Presidential Room, no less. His report of his first day on board is a nonstop string of complaints: The noise is unbearable, he keeps knocking his head on the low ceilings and hatches, the spaghetti is cold and the lettuce inedible, the oil fumes are overwhelming, the temperature is like a blast furnace, the air is toxic, the ocean glitters but is spoiled by a sky greased with jet fuel. Dyer admits he is constitutionally incapable of adjusting to new environments; in fact, the only thing he’s grown accustomed to, over the years, is that he never gets used to things. This is the same man who, when asked by a friend (Alain de Botton) if he would like to spend some time writing in an interesting and relaxing environment, immediately replied: Put me on an American aircraft carrier.

headline: Exile’s End
text: In September 1939, more than 350,000 Jews lived in Warsaw. Six years later, only 11,500 were left. Most of Warsaw itself had been wiped from the face of the earth.

headline: Inside the List
text: Turkey Stuffing: Diana Gabaldon’s hefty new novel, “Written in My Own Heart’s Blood” — the eighth entry in her Outlander series of time-traveling romances — enters the hardcover fiction list right at No. 1. These books describe the escapades of an 18th-century Scotsman and the World War II-era English nurse who fell into his world courtesy of a witches’ coven; writing in Salon in 1999, the critic Gavin McNett called it “the smartest historical sci-fi adventure-romance story ever written by a science Ph.D. with a background in scripting ‘Scrooge McDuck’ comics.” It’s been five years since the last Outlander title hit stores, and with a new Starz TV show based on the series coming in August, fans are primed for the latest installment. Gabaldon answered their questions recently on the website Goodreads. “People often say to me, ‘You write such strong female characters,’ ” she told one reader who praised the depiction of her heroine, “and I say, ‘Well, I don’t like stupid women.’ ” Gabaldon also cited her belief that fiction has three kinds of characters: mushrooms, hard nuts and onions. It’s a theory she’s expanded on at her official website. Onions, she explains, “develop slowly through the addition of multiple layers of personality, rather than popping up full-fledged as the ‘mushrooms’ do.” Hard nuts, meanwhile, play a merely functional role, making them difficult to animate. “Onions, mushrooms and nuts,” Gabaldon writes; “this is beginning to sound like an exotic recipe for turkey stuffing.”

headline: This Is Your Brain on Writing
text: A novelist scrawling away in a notebook in seclusion may not seem to have much in common with an NBA player doing a reverse layup on a basketball court before a screaming crowd. But if you could peer inside their heads, you might see some striking similarities in how their brains were churning.

headline: House Votes to Curb N.S.A. Scrutiny of Americans’ Communications
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives late on Thursday voted to bar the National Security Agency from looking for Americans’ communications without a warrant within a database of emails and phone calls it gathers while targeting foreigners, a technique critics have labeled a “backdoor search loophole.”

headline: For Incarcerated Japanese-Americans, Baseball Was ‘Wearing the American Flag’
text: After the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor in December 1941, some Americans expected Major League Baseball to be suspended until World War II was won. Many of the players would want to enlist, they argued, and letting baseball go on as usual might be frivolously disrespectful of the nation’s war effort.

headline: My Lower East Side
text: The way we heard it, the rabbi’s wife died on a Tuesday. That left just enough time for seven days of sitting shiva, and after that, a speedy white paint job and a Sunday open house that ended with our successful offer for a spacious and sunny two-bedroom co-op apartment.

headline: Dispatches From the Culture Front
text: Modernism in the arts can be traced to the late 19th century, but it was the years during and after World War I when the movement matured and produced some of its most startling work. Here are excerpts from The New York Times that show how it covered a few key figures and developments.

headline: Costa Rica vs. Italy: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: When Costa Rica headed to halftime down by 1-0 to Uruguay, few expected what came next: three unanswered goals and a team-defining win. But will this long shot be simply a one-hit wonder? Italy will be better organized and more professional than Uruguay.

headline: Sky Diving as a Birthday Gift? Maybe a Nice Sweater Instead
text: Everyone was so excited about George H. W. Bush’s jumping out of a plane for his 90th birthday last week, it has inspired me to publicly make a vow: I will not be jumping out of a plane when I turn 90. I won’t do it when I turn 80, either.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Barber’s ‘The Third Plate’
text: This week, Dan Barber talks about “The Third Plate”; John Williams on the week’s literary news; James Nestor discusses “Deep”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Court Allows Coca-Cola Plant to Reopen in Uttar Pradesh
text: The National Green Tribunal, an environmental court, on Friday ruled to allow a Coca-Cola production facility in the state of Uttar Pradesh to reopen after it had been closed in early June because of concerns over waste disposal and water usage.

headline: In Los Angeles, Old-Fashioned Glamour or Hip Mixology
text: Los Angeles is not what you would call a bar town, and for all the obvious reasons. The region covers almost 5,000 square miles. While public transit does exist there — and taxis and Uber are thriving — it is not New York: If you stumble out of a bar on the way home, there’s not a subway on the corner.

headline: A Guide Who Knows the Turf
text: Tama Robertson, a real estate broker, was warming up to a landlord on the Lower East Side of Manhattan recently when he casually asked for her help in breaking the law. Ms. Robertson had heard landlords make crude requests before, but this one stopped her cold.

headline: Eight Hours of Free Music at Sunday’s Bang on a Can Marathon
text: The Bang on a Can Marathon has been one of the central events of the new-music calendar since 1987, when the composers who founded the organization – Michael Gordon, Julia Wolfe and David Lang – invited composers and performers to present the first of them at a SoHo gallery. In recent years, the marathon has been part of the River to River Festival, and has been held in the vast Winter Garden at Brookfield Place (formerly the World Financial Center), where listeners can take it in with varying degrees of casualness, coming and going as they see fit.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Return of Wide-Legged Jeans
text: Tight-fitting denim will always have its place on the runway, thanks to designers like Hedi Slimane for Saint Laurent. But in the spring/summer 2015 collections so far, looser, longer jeans silhouettes are on the rise. Unlike the baggy low-riders of the hip-hop ’90’s, the new crop of wide-legged jeans is surprisingly understated. At the E.Tautz show in London, the designer Patrick Grant offered a version that was dark-washed, cuffed and slightly high waisted. (He sported a pair for his bow.) Worn monochromatically with a tucked shirt and long mac coat, the runway look was put-together but relaxed. Margaret Howell, who continues to show strong collections of covetable basics, also introduced a loose-fitting pair of jeans, which was topped with a simple shirt and coat. And Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, the duo behind Marques’Almeida, took a more youthful approach, fraying the pants’ hems and pairing them with an equally frayed top and coat that evoked a similarly laid-back minimalism, but with an edge.

headline: Surprisingly Good at Talking About Sex
text: “I hate the word ‘moist.’”

headline: Michael Shannon Finds Balance on the Waterfront
text: Throughout history men have made quixotic and impressive sacrifices for the women they loved — started wars, committed murder, swallowed poison, abdicated.

headline: Broccoli, Stems and All
text: Once upon a time, when you bought broccoli you bought the whole vegetable, stems and crowns. Then it became customary for grocery store produce departments to separate the crowns from the stems and to sell the crowns at a premium.

headline: TV’s Messy Women
text: “Trainwreck.” “Burnout.” “Poster child for IDGAF.” Whatever you call her, a new female archetype has made its way to film and TV, and some viewers are more excited than others.

text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: R.I.P. Gerry Goffin, a Master Songwriter
text: I used to give a class for New York Times interns on writing and editing. I would start by playing the Gerry Goffin and Carole King song “Will You Love Me Tomorrow?” (I used Ms. King’s version.) I wanted to make a point about brevity and beauty: to show how it’s possible to convey complicated emotions, deep feeling and intricate meanings with the tiniest and plainest of words. You can be short and sweet. You can also be short and heartbreaking.

headline: France vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Switzerland was much buzzed-about coming into the Cup, and after an initial struggle, it rallied to beat Ecuador.

headline: A Survivor, Inspired by Love and Loss
text: HAVERTOWN, Pa. — The visual artist Christopher Cairns’s sprawling studio near Philadelphia is filled with installations that include piles of skulls and forlorn figures slumped despairingly in chairs. Sculptures that evoke the victims of Pompeii are strewn across the floor near the white wall, which is made of crumbling bricks and shards of glass and will be replicated in the sets for “On the Threshold of Winter,” Michael Hersch’s new opera. Mr. Cairns’s eerie art seems an aptly somber pairing for the dark-hued monodrama, which will receive its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, Mr. Hersch’s birthday, with Tito Muñoz conducting the ensemble Nunc.

headline: A War to End All Innocence
text: “I feel like a soldier on the morning after the Somme.” This line of dialogue, from an episode in the second season of the BBC series “Call the Midwife,” caught my ear recently as an especially piquant morsel of period detail. It is uttered by a doctor to a nurse after they have just assisted in a grueling home birth, an experience that is compared to the four-month battle in a muddy stretch of Picardy beginning on July 1, 1916, that was, at the time, the bloodiest episode of combat in human history, generating 60,000 casualties in a single day of fighting on the British side alone. The doctor’s comparison is surely metaphorical overkill, but it also represents a familiar style of wit, a habit of linking the challenges we regularly endure with calamities we can scarcely imagine.

headline: When a Will Divides an Estate, and Also Divides a Family
text: KATE’S father died when she was in college, but she stayed close to his side of the family. Although she moved to North Carolina after graduation, she and her three siblings returned to New Jersey a couple of times a year to visit her grandmother, aunts and cousins. She called her grandmother frequently until dementia made it impossible for them to communicate.

headline: A Soft-Shell Crab to Top Your Toast
text: Of all the things you may put on toast, one of the best has claws. The soft-shell crab isn’t as classic as, say, butter and jam. But when the crabs are in season, there are few better ways to savor them.

text: The Times critic A. O. Scott offers his must-see list of films from BAMcinemafest.

text: In 1996, Gregory Crewdson left New York to spend the summer living alone in his family’s cabin in the Berkshires. Upon his arrival, he devised a plan: He would go outside nightly to photograph fireflies.

text: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants overran one of the last government-held crossings on the Syrian border on Friday after a fierce battle that left at least 34 Iraqi soldiers dead.

text: Students in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, praying for the safety of Indians kidnapped by militants in Iraq.

headline: Afghan Leader Backs U.N. Election Role
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seeking to quell a political crisis surrounding the June 14 election to choose his successor, President Hamid Karzai reversed course on Friday and suggested that the United Nations get involved in helping Afghanistan settle disputes over the voting.

headline: There Is a Simpler Way for Students to Apply for Financial Aid
text: Any college student who wants a federal loan or Pell grant has to file a Free Application for Federal Student Aid. With well over 100 questions about income, assets and expenses, the Fafsa approaches the IRS Form 1040 in length, and is longer and more complicated than the 1040A and 1040EZ, the tax forms filed by a majority of taxpayers.

headline: The Latest Icon in Artistic Rebellion: A Cabbage
text: Every so often, the artist Han Bing likes to play a little prank with a white cabbage — that iconic, rectangular vegetable synonymous in China with full bellies and good fortune. Impaled on a wheeled frame and tied to a length of rope, the cabbage resembles a miniature parade float trailing along behind him through streets around the globe. In Beijing, Los Angeles, New York, Tokyo and other cities, the spectacle has triggered laughter, finger-pointing and questions from bemused passersby. But Mr. Han, 40, gives no answers.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Jersey Boys’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jersey Boys.”

headline: Asked, Maybe Answered
text: Two apps recently introduced in New York illustrate the challenges developers face when trying to make useful question-and-answer platforms. Enquire, which connects users with locals who can answer questions about the city’s neighborhoods, and Pyne, which allows users to create and respond to polls, both rely on groups of people willing to ask — and answer — questions.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Norte’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Norte, the End of History.”

headline: When the Korean Team Plays, Eat Korean
text: Hahm Ji Bach is a robust Korean family-style barbecue on 149th Place in Flushing, Queens, with room for 150 diners and tables with built-in grills. But during the World Cup, especially when South Korea is playing, Ham Ji Bach bustles with people indulging together, as well as single eaters with giant portions at tables for one.

headline: Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, British Pop Imports
