headline: ‘In C,’ and Many Other Keys
text: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of Terry Riley’s “In C,” the seminal Minimalist score that has become virtually a standard repertory work, at least in New York – hardly a season goes by without at least one performance – 11 composers have joined forces to write companion works built around the other notes of the chromatic scale.

headline: Charles Barsotti, Cartoonist With Humor Both Simple and Absurd, Dies at 80
text: Charles Barsotti, a cartoonist for The New Yorker whose jaded canines, outlaw snails and obtuse monarchs made readers laugh for more than 40 years, died on Monday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 80.

headline: S.E.C.’s Mary Jo White Seeks to Shine Light Into Opaque Bond Markets
text: Updated, 6:49 p.m. | The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to shine a light on trades in the relatively opaque markets for corporate and municipal bonds.

headline: The House Actually Did Something About Warrantless Surveillance
text: In an unusual display of unity from the divided, do-nothing House, a bipartisan group of lawmakers pushed through a bill that basically says, yes, the Fourth Amendment applies to electronic communications, too.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: General in Sex Case to Retire With a 2-Rank Demotion
text: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, whose extramarital relationship with a subordinate officer led to charges of sexual assault and a prosecution that ultimately collapsed and embarrassed the military, will retire as a lieutenant colonel, two grades lower than his current rank, the Army said Friday.

headline: Popcast: Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, British Pop Imports
text: Two young English pop singers, Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, both enthusiastically welcomed in the United States, have ambitious new records.

headline: Calculated Risks: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’
text: In 1969, the night before a Wellesley College senior named Hillary Rodham gave a commencement address that would draw national attention, she was introduced to Dean Acheson, the legendary former secretary of state who had come to campus for his granddaughter’s graduation. “I’m looking forward to hearing what you have to say,” Acheson told Rodham. At the time, many in the country were looking forward to hearing what Acheson had to say. He had just put the finishing touches on “Present at the Creation,” his landmark memoir that would come out a few months after his encounter with the young Rodham, providing a seminal portrait of his role in helping Harry S. Truman forge a new national security architecture at the outset of the Cold War.

headline: Number of French Jews Emigrating to Israel Rises
text: PARIS — For Tiffany Taieb Nizard, the decision to abandon France for Israel came this month when a French-born man was accused of gunning down four people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels in an anti-Semitic attack.

headline: Trumping the First Choice
text: The cover review this week wasn’t our original choice — we had an entirely different plan at the ready, a review of something else, already edited with the illustration assigned — and then the review of the novel “Song of the Shank” by Jeffery Renard Allen came in, less than a week before we had to go to press.Mitchell S. Jackson, whose first novel, “The Residue Years,” came out last year, had written a total rave, calling Allen’s book “the kind of imaginative work only a prodigiously gifted risk-taker could produce.” It was an interesting match between reviewer and author because, as the assigning editor Gregory Cowles explained, “Their novels are very different — Jackson’s was contemporary and seemingly autobiographical, while Allen’s is on the face of it neither of those. But both are voice-driven and beautifully written, and both play with contemporary ideas about family, race, class and the long legacy of slavery.”

headline: Hoofbeats and Ocean Views in Brooklyn
text: In a city where dogs are carried around in purses, it seems amazing to find that Susan Gallahue, 64, keeps a horse. Not in her apartment on the Upper West Side, of course, but at the bucolic Jamaica Bay Riding Academy in Bergen Beach, Brooklyn, where she visits Silver Palace, her Thoroughbred-warmblood mix, about four times a week. Ms. Gallahue, a full-time psychiatric nurse, looks forward to every visit with Silver, a retired show-jumping mare she says has “the best personality.”

headline: N.F.L. Collusion Case Reinstated on Appeal
text: A federal appeals court reinstated a case brought by the N.F.L. Players Association, which has accused N.F.L. owners of collusion by creating a secret salary cap in the 2010 season.

headline: Palestinians Hold Funeral for Boy Killed
text: Hundreds attended a funeral procession in the village of Dura for a Palestinian teenager killed by Israeli troops in the West Bank during search operations for three missing Israeli teens.

headline: A Revue of Pop Songs as Catchy as Poison Ivy
text: Creating a Broadway revue around a songwriting duo who specialized in pop music was a novel idea back in 1995, when “Smokey Joe’s Cafe: The Songs of Leiber and Stoller” made its debut. But it worked. The musical, based on the work of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, ran for nearly five years, showcasing such beloved tunes as “Dance With Me,” “Kansas City,” “Hound Dog” and “There Goes My Baby.”

headline: Letting Go of Sykes-Picot
text: Earlier this week I quoted David Frum, usually more hawkish than I, on the theme that American interests in Iraq might be better pursued by looking for solid ground in, say, Kurdistan than by trying to help Iran stabilize the Sunni Triangle or replaying the Diem drama with our new batch of military advisers and Nouri al-Maliki. Now Jeffrey Goldberg, also usually more hawkish than I, has written a follow-up to the 2008 essay I cited in my Sunday column, on the Middle East’s potential post-Iraq War map, which circles around to a similar conclusion:

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.75 Million, With a Tycoon for a Neighbor
text: A full-floor residence at One Madison, the sylphlike bronze-and-glass tower at 23 East 22nd Street that has inspired a defection of high-rollers, including the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, from less avant-garde locales uptown, sold for $11.75 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Polar Exploration Inside an Insurance Office
text: There was Kevin Spacey. There was a weird dream about an out-of-control copy machine. And there was the unraveling of the economy in 2008. All played a part in the creation of “Endurance,” a 90-minute theatrical mash-up in which grumbling insurance workers morph into chantey-singing polar explorers, office furniture subs for a doughty wooden icebreaker, and a light switch conveys audiences at the Long Wharf Theater from a standard-issue Hartford workplace to the shifting ice floes of Antarctica and back again.

headline: Driven | 2014 Buick Regal Turbo
text: The old slogan “Wouldn’t you really rather have a Buick” means something again.

headline: Video: The 2014 Buick Regal Turbo Is Fun for All Ages
text: Baby boomers know Buick as an automotive brand favored by their parents (or grandparents). Jingles that purred “Wouldn’t you really rather have a Buick?” during “The Ed Sullivan Show” didn’t work on the generation raised on Barbie, Hot Wheels and the Beatles. They ended up preferring to have a Lexus. Or an Audi. Or a BMW.

headline: I.R.S. Head Testifies on Tea Party Query
text: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, clashed with lawmakers over missing emails during a heated House hearing on the tax agency’s scrutiny of Tea Party-aligned political groups.

headline: Japanese Report Casts Doubt on Admission of Wartime Sexual Coercion
text: TOKYO — A group of government-appointed Japanese scholars seemed to raise doubts about the accuracy of a landmark 1993 apology to women forced to work in military brothels during World War II, in a finding that could worsen tensions between Japan and South Korea over wartime history.

headline: America, Online: Love for Hopper’s ‘Nighthawks’
text: The plan to fill 50,000 billboards, in all 50 states, with American art works this summer is moving closer to completion. Starting in April, art fans voted for their favorites from among 100 works posted on the ArtEverywhereUS.org website. Voting was closed in early May, and the museums announced the 58 winning works on Friday.

headline: New York Senate Passes Bill on Medical Marijuana
text: ALBANY — The New York Senate passed a bill legalizing access to medical marijuana on Friday, a day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced the agreement on a seven-year pilot program to provide the drug to sick New Yorkers.

headline: A New, Eclectic Tour of Reykjavik
text: Have a layover in Iceland, but not sure what to do? There’s a new walking tour aimed at introducing travelers — particularly those on stopovers in Iceland — to the locals’ side of Reykjavik.

headline: Affordable Island in the Sun
text: Gus Christensen was, until six months ago, a managing director at Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, a position preceded by stints at JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs and an education at Wharton. Some years ago, befitting that profile, he was a Republican; but eventually the religion of the free market lost its hold on him, so much so that his politics migrated aggressively to the left. Last week he posted on Twitter a link to a tabloid piece about a billionaire who was buying a $70 million pied-à-terre for his children at 740 Park Avenue, with the hashtag #Signoftheapocalypse.

headline: Health Insurers Pressing Down on Drug Prices
text: In dealing with health plans, drug companies are facing a new imperative — bargain or be banned.

headline: Wall Street’s Latest Must-Have? A Volcker Helper
text: The next accessory desired by top Wall Street traders may not be swanky cufflinks or a Swiss watch.

headline: Rangers Buy Out Richards’s Contract
text: Brad Richards was admired by everyone on the Rangers, including the man who decided to let him go, General Manager Glen Sather.

headline: Wheelies: The Sonata Eco Edition
text: A roundup of motor news from the web:

headline: Clothes That Made the Man’s Mark
text: The tormented yet indissoluble relationship between Yves Saint Laurent and his life and business partner, Pierre Bergé, is the governing narrative of Jalil Lespert’s “Yves Saint Laurent,” a biopic about that French fashion designer that opens in New York on June 25. But the life of Saint Laurent, who died in 2008, can also be traced through a parallel narrative: that of the clothes he designed. Between his first collection in 1957 and his retirement in 2002, he changed the way modern women dressed, often prefiguring social change by bringing street and exotic influences to conventional wear, and showing women as newly powerful figures in trousers, trench coats and tuxedos.

headline: U.N. Leader Deplores Syria War’s Spread to Iraq
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday drew attention to perhaps the bleakest chapter of his tenure at the United Nations: the three-year-old war in Syria, and now the prospective unraveling of the region along sectarian lines.

headline: Grand Central Food Hall Proposal Nears Approval
text: The cavernous and elegant Vanderbilt Hall, in Grand Central Terminal, has recently been home to many temporary displays, holiday retail shops and private events. Now it is moving one step closer to housing its first permanent installation, a food hall and a fine-dining restaurant that would be run by Claus Meyer, the founder of Noma in Copenhagen, considered one of the world’s best.

headline: After the Storm, 20 Months in Limbo
text: One after another, caseworkers entered the small, stuffy Downtown Brooklyn conference room — the court of last resort.

headline: A Bicoastal Romance That Got a Big Kickstart
text: One would think that someone creative enough to write jokes for television shows would have no trouble finding ways to fill his spare time.

headline: A Grandeur That Eclipses the Grotesque
text: WASHINGTON — The fellow with a third leg really appears to have that extra appendage, the lizard man sports scary scales, and the hermaphrodite seems to be split down the middle in the new production of “Side Show” at the Kennedy Center here. As they lumber, slither or caper forth in the opening number of this 1997 musical, creating a macabre pageant of human oddity, it becomes clear that what we will be seeing is less a revival than a full-scale reimagining of this show, which drew mixed reviews and closed after a few months on Broadway in its first incarnation, while quickly acquiring a cult following among, er, musical-theater freaks.

headline: Drugs Not Covered by Express Scripts and CVS Caremark
text: Express Scripts (E.S.I.) and CVS Caremark, the nation’s two largest pharmacy benefits companies, have gotten drug manufacturers to offer greater discounts and rebates by refusing to pay for certain drugs, forcing companies to bid against one another.

headline: A Central American Mouse Roars
text: RECIFE, Brazil — There was less than 20 minutes left to play here on Friday when a bundle of three balloons — red, white and green, the colors of Italy’s flag — floated down from the stands and onto the field.

headline: Booksellers Score Some Points in Amazon’s Spat With Hachette
text: Robert Sindelar, the bearded, redheaded managing partner at the Seattle independent bookseller Third Place Books — definitely a David to Amazon’s Goliath — got the idea to take on Amazon while attending BookExpo America in New York a few weeks ago.

headline: G.E.’s Pyrrhic Victory
text: There’s a paradox in General Electric’s French triumph. The  conglomerate is finally getting Alstom’s energy businesses, having seen off German nemesis Siemens and reached an accommodation with a hostile French government. Yet some other players won clearer victories.

headline: Fifty Million Displaced People
text: When it comes to Iraq, the international focus is largely on the Islamic militants who have seized a huge swath of the country and are moving toward Baghdad.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 22-28, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Olivier Theyskens Leaves Theory, Gisele Replaces Kate Moss and Kendall Jenner Is Here to Stay
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Whither Yo?
text: It’s hard to talk about Yo. The app is so simple (it lets users send the word “Yo” to each other) that even to mock it feels like taking it too seriously — come on guys, it’s just Yo! Luckily, hackers have made things easier on all of us by making Yo do some new tricks.

headline: Odd and Original, Yes. Appetizing? Maybe Not.
text: A certain barbecued blandness can infest food programs at this time of year. “Frankenfood,” a spunky series that begins on Sunday night on Spike, puts variety back on the plate, with ridiculous, sometimes gag-inducing results.

headline: House Ethics Panel Orders Alaska Republican to Pay Fine
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee on Friday ordered Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, to pay a fine of almost $60,000 for using campaign money for personal purposes and for accepting “impermissible gifts.”

headline: Chinese Company Demands Edits to New ‘Transformers’ Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — The China woes are not over yet for Michael Bay’s latest “Transformers” film, “Age of Extinction.”

headline: Raising a Glass to Chile
text: One of the great pleasures of the World Cup every four years is in the underdogs. When a smaller, poorer country vanquishes a larger, richer one, it is something to cheer, perhaps even when you happen to live in that larger, richer country.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Agricultural Output Climbed in 2013, Recovering From Drought
text: AGRICULTURE is a small part of the United States economy, but last year it was the best part.

headline: Clinton’s Cough Was Really a Gasp
text: Hillary Clinton has apparently gotten over her allergies.

headline: Saying No to Austerity, Spain Unveils Tax Cuts
text: MADRID — Turning its back on fiscal austerity, the Spanish government presented a broad package of income and corporate tax cuts on Friday that are scheduled to begin before next year’s general election.

headline: Harley’s Electric Prototype
text: A look at the Harley-Davidson electric motorcycle prototype.

headline: ‘Hi, Mom, I’m Home!’
text: One in five young adults lives with his or her parents. Is this a recessionary blip or the dawn of a whole new economic age?

headline: Ecuador vs. Honduras: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: After taking a lead on Switzerland, Ecuador was disappointed to lose. Based on its downright bad performance against France, Honduras may be just the cure.

headline: The Case for ISIS, Made in a British Accent
text: Apparently seeking to capitalize on the wave of news coverage that has accompanied their recent gains on the battlefield in Iraq, militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, released a recruitment video online late Thursday aimed at persuading Muslims in the West to abandon their comfortable lives and embrace jihad.

headline: Lullabies by Caruso Ignited a Love of Opera in Brooklyn
text: When Nina DiGregorio was a baby in the 1920s, her mother would wind up the phonograph and play opera records.

headline: Our Moral Tongue
text: ON June 20, 2003, employees of the Union Pacific Railroad faced a difficult decision as a runaway train headed toward downtown Los Angeles: Should they divert the train to a side track, knowing it would derail and hit homes in the less populated city of Commerce, Calif.? Did the moral imperative to minimize overall harm outweigh the moral imperative not to intentionally harm an innocent suburb?

headline: Using Microsoft OneDrive for Photo Backup
text: Q. The Microsoft OneDrive app on my Android phone once asked if I wanted to back up my photos automatically and I said no, but now I’ve reconsidered. How can I get back to that screen again?

headline: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In to the World Cup
text: MANAUS, Brazil — The PP Maués would not set sail for an hour, but its long and narrow decks were already crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

headline: In Colorado, a Brewers’ Festival Toasts an Anniversary
text: The Colorado Brewers’ Festival will celebrate its 25th anniversary this month in Fort Collins, Colo., a place where the thirst for craft beer is alive, kicking and growing. This year’s festival brings 13 new breweries to the tasting tables, offering a total of close to 120 different brews, including its first group of hard ciders.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows in London
text: In a city where anything goes, at least in terms of fashion, the most impressive shows in London Collections: Men were the ones that proposed new silhouettes and ideas, yet were still grounded in reality. These five designers accomplished that delicate balance and introduced wearable spring/summer 2015 collections that would look as at home on the street as on the runway.

headline: Josh Earnest’s First Briefing: A Few Observations
text: WASHINGTON — After striding to the famous lectern for his highly anticipated first briefing as the White House press secretary on Friday, Josh Earnest quickly did what his predecessors have turned into an art form: He lowered expectations.

headline: Packed With Technology, Prepped for Hyperbole
text: Pull up to the 7-Eleven in this car and you feel like Leonard Bernstein arriving at Lincoln Center. Ride in the back and you’re escorting Julie Andrews to the Oscars. The doors are substantial enough to repel anything Occupy Wall Street throws at them, and it’s effortlessly powerful enough to outrun any S.E.C. subpoena. The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550 4Matic sedan is so advanced it should be in geosynchronous orbit over Gstaad.

headline: Hi, I’m a Tablet. I’ll Be Your Waiter Tonight.
text: BRAINTREE, Mass. — An idea came to Ronald M. Shaich, the chief executive of Panera Bread, as he was driving his children to school about four years ago: What if everyone could order lunch the way he did?

headline: Taking a Spin: Republicans Win Despite Some Disappointment
text: The Republicans retake control of the Senate in this week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly illustration of the uncertainty that remains with so much time until November’s elections. But two red-state Democrats defy the Republican sweep.

headline: Next Stop, India: Full Steam Ahead
text: If you are a lover of street food, India is the place to be. Outrageously delicious snacks, of which there are countless thousands, beckon from every corner.

headline: How to Translate Döppelgangers Into Hindi: Just Keep Adding Characters
text: At the beginning of the awful Bollywood comedy “Humshakals,” our handsome billionaire hero pursues his passion: stand-up. He’s awful. His jokes are infantile, his style eager to please but clueless.

headline: Commander in Chief With Idealism Untarnished
text: Ideally, the president should be relatively smart. In the premiere of his new series on the Hub Network, Kid President proves himself smart enough to know that no one can take an unbroken half-hour of the chirpy observations that have brought him Internet fame.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, Iraq, Ukraine and Yemen.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 20
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a memorial in the Bronx and more than one hot day.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Woods Set to Return From Surgery
text: So much for the speculation that Tiger Woods would be sidelined the rest of the year after having back surgery in March. Woods announced Friday on his Facebook page that he would make his first competitive start in nearly four months at next week’s Quicken Loans National, which benefits the foundation that bears his name.

headline: Patrick Huang Introduces a Bridge Deal
text: The Longevity Valley 2nd Asia Cup Bridge Championships in Wuyi Qingshuiwan, China, will end on Sunday.

headline: New York’s Not-So-Perfect Medical Marijuana Law
text: New York is finally joining the ranks of states that allow the use of marijuana for medical purposes, becoming the 23rd in the nation to do so. Too bad Governor Cuomo, who held the upper hand in bargaining because of his veto power, forced legislators to accept so many restrictions that the law will be a lot less useful than it could have been. The legislation has passed both chambers and is awaiting the governor’s signature.

headline: A Ride Across America | Soccer, Bourbon and a Very Special Farm in Missouri
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Reinventing Emily Gould
text: Emily Gould stood posing for a photograph on West 29th Street in front of the building where she works, wearing a stone-colored cardigan, her hair scraped back into a messy ponytail, her only concession to vanity a slash of red lipstick applied with apparent indifference.

headline: A Civil War Skirmish, Fought With Badinage
text: IT’S HARD TO CATEGORIZE “Butler,” a new play being staged by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. It’s part comedy, part historical drama and part biography, often all at once, and sometimes none of those. Yet the show is easy enough to review. Just call it splendid.

headline: Law to Impose Tough Limits on Sales of Ivory Art
text: To the chagrin of New York antiques dealers, lawmakers in Albany have voted to outlaw the sale of virtually all items containing more than small amounts of elephant ivory, mammoth ivory or rhinoceros horn. The legislation, which is backed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, will essentially eliminate New York’s central role in a well-established, nationwide trade with an estimated annual value of $500 million.

headline: A Night Out With Jenny Slate of ‘Obvious Child’
text: The actress Jenny Slate arrived at a panel discussion for her new film, “Obvious Child,” Tuesday night, where the first person she saw was a woman who reminded her of her grandmother.

headline: But Can They Write Fashion Code?
text: On a brisk Thursday afternoon, Peter Semple strode purposefully through Google’s Chelsea offices looking for a quiet place to discuss his latest project. “I haven’t slept in the last four days,” Mr. Semple said, bypassing the cafeteria, which was blasting En Vogue, in favor of a curtained-off conference room with a large lime-green armchair at the head of its table.

headline: Swim in Bronx River Kills Boy, 13; Another Is Hospitalized
text: One 13-year-boy died and another was in critical condition on Friday after they went swimming in the Bronx River and had to be pulled from the water by emergency divers, according to the Police Department.

headline: Amy Alkon’s Crusade Against Rudeness
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Please let me be on time for the maniacal manners lady. I don’t want her to scold me. Please, pretty please, don’t let me be late.

headline: To the Sea in Ships, as Naughty as Ever
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The drag queen Persia, in full bejeweled regalia, went out on one of the first rafts, sloping down the launch ramp in thigh-high red stiletto boots.

headline: Translating English Protocol for a Wider Audience
text: It was a breach of protocol few of the two billion viewers of the royal wedding would have spotted, but the etiquette expert Alexandra Messervy noticed the faux pas immediately.

headline: Four Guys With Swords and Morals
text: Certain stories never get old, and certain people never tire of rewriting them.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Photo Caper in Poland
text: A trove of Marilyn Monroe photos by Milton H. Greene is being auctioned in Poland this week. How the photos got there – and how they will be sold – is worthy of a madcap caper.

headline: Evening Hours | Warming Up
text: Opening doors for celebration and whimsy in gardens.

headline: Flight Prep: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550
text: Mercedes-Benz’s big luxury sedan glides into the future with high ambitions that are seamlessly executed.

headline: For His Second Act, a Hot Rod Builder Turns Back the Clock
text: STAMFORD, CONN. — “So this is it,” Dennis Wuchiski says as he opens the door to what is possibly the cleanest garage this side of the McLaren Formula One racecar operation in Britain.

headline: Hot Rod Hideaway
text: Dennis Wuchiski’s home garage in Stamford, Conn., is both a dream shop and a display case for a lover of Ford hot rods.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Great, Gatsby
text: Nearly 10,000 people attended the Jazz Age Lawn Party on Governors Island, many in costume.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Jazz Age Lawn Party
text: The ninth annual Jazz Age Lawn Party took place last weekend on Governors Island with Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra. Mr. Arenella, founder of the event, paid for it himself at first, and the earliest parties drew a few hundred people. Last weekend, nearly 10,000 attended, many in costume.

headline: Readers Respond: Love and Hate for Guns and Video Games
text: Discussions about the right to own a gun in real life can become quite a debate. It turns out that talking about the right to bear arms in video games can be an equally hot topic.

headline: Not Your Average Garage
text: A peek at Dennis Wuchiski’s custom 1932 Ford, which took him 18 years to build.

headline: Under Cover: A ‘Boomerang Kid’ Documents His Generation
text: The June 22 cover story about “boomerang kids” features photographs taken by Damon Casarez, who graduated from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., with $120,000 in student debt. Eventually, his loan payments became unmanageable, and he moved in with his parents. The discomfort of sleeping on the living-room couch and readjusting to his parents’ house rules inspired Casarez to reach out to others like him. “I did this project because it was something that I knew and something that I thought needed to be talked about,” Casarez says. He recently discussed how his circumstances influenced his portrait-taking.

headline: They Are the World: A Psychedelic Rock Ritual
text: The Swedish band Goat calls its concerts rituals, and that’s how it performed on Wednesday night at Webster Hall: as a psychedelic rock ritual of rhythm, motion, hypnotic repetition and ecstatic drive. The men in the band were masked or hooded, in a mélange of ethnic clothes. The two female singers up front, dancing and shaking assorted percussion instruments, were post-hippie celebrants in colorful dresses, wearing feathered headdresses above their own glittery masks. No one spoke to the audience: The songs arrived on their own, droning and pounding, wailing with guitar solos and churning with funk.

headline: Pickups Wearing Camo, but Not to Blend In
text: Hot competition among pickups has inspired automakers to seek every possible edge, in style as well as technology. So like such disparate trendsetters as downtown club kids and “Duck Dynasty” fans, trucks are now stepping out in camouflage.

headline: ‘All These Darlings and Now Us’
text: A waterborne installation in San Francisco combines performance art, urban resistance and a sex-positive philosophy.

headline: The Clubs That Connect The World Cup
text: The global tournament is mostly a remix of the professional leagues that are in season most of the time. See which professional clubs have the most players on the most World Cup teams.

headline: Why Are We Importing Our Own Fish?
text: IN 1982 a Chinese aquaculture scientist named Fusui Zhang journeyed to Martha’s Vineyard in search of scallops. The New England bay scallop had recently been domesticated, and Dr. Zhang thought the Vineyard-grown shellfish might do well in China. After a visit to Lagoon Pond in Tisbury, he boxed up 120 scallops and spirited them away to his lab in Qingdao. During the journey 94 died. But 26 thrived. Thanks to them, today China now grows millions of dollars of New England bay scallops, a significant portion of which are exported back to the United States.

headline: Toughest Issues Still Unresolved in Iran Nuclear Talks
text: VIENNA — Negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program entered their brinkmanship phase on Friday, with the toughest issues still unresolved a month before the deadline for a final agreement.

headline: Beautiful Game Played With a Gaúcho Flair in Southern Brazil
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — “Tell me how you play, and I will tell you who you are.”

headline: Streaming Eagles
text: THERE was a situation with some bald eagles on the Internet the other day. The drama played out in a large, disheveled nest somewhere in Minnesota, in front of a camera that had been streaming the lives of those birds onto the Internet for the last two years.

headline: You’re Not Really Wearing That to School?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Biden Adviser Leaving Washington, but It May Not Be for Long
text: WASHINGTON — When Jake Sullivan leaves Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s staff in August to teach at Yale Law School this fall, he will join a familiar Washington subculture: the battle-scarred White House alumnus, desperate to sample a normal life before deciding whether to jump back into the maelstrom of the next political cycle.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’: The Opera and the Furor
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Kind of Church, Led by Pope Francis
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Solstice Blues
text: IN mid-June, the twilight seems to go on forever, the sky awash with translucent shades of rose, pearl, gray. These are evenings of enchantment — but also of apprehension. The moment the sun reaches its farthest point north of the Equator today is the moment the light starts to fade, waning more each day for the following six months. If the summer solstice doesn’t signal the arrival of winter, surely it heralds the gradual lessening of light, and with that, often, an incremental decline in disposition.

headline: Candy’s Dandy, but Pot’s Scary
text: WE know that occasionally people react badly to marijuana. Some withdraw into anxious, glassy silence. Some responses are more horrifying. In a recent, much discussed case, a Denver man bought cannabis-infused Karma Kandy and hours later — perhaps after also taking prescription pain medication — began raving about the end of the world and killed his wife.

headline: Cavaliers Are Said to Hire Israeli Coach David Blatt
text: A month after leading Maccabi Tel Aviv to the Euroleague championship, David Blatt agreed to a four-year deal to become the head coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday, according to a person with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Missing Israeli Teenagers Revive a Mother’s Hard-Earned Intimacy With Loss
text: TEKOA, West Bank — Sherri Mandell was toasting her daughter’s engagement with her future in-laws at her home in this Jewish settlement south of Jerusalem last Friday morning when she heard the news. After the first sip of sparkling white wine, the groom-to-be put down his glass. “I’m sorry, but we have to stop the party,” Ms. Mandell recalled him saying. “Something terrible has happened.”

headline: Stephanie L. Kwolek, Inventor of Kevlar, Is Dead at 90
text: Stephanie L. Kwolek, a DuPont chemist who invented the technology behind Kevlar, a virtually bulletproof fiber that has saved thousands of lives, died on Wednesday in Wilmington, Del. She was 90.

headline: The Computer Will Now Take Your Order
text: Restaurants have been late to the tech revolution, and many are now scrambling to incorporate tablets, apps, computerized kitchen equipment and data analysis capabilities.

headline: Collecting Catholics’ Everyday Stories as an Antidote to Scandals in the News
text: The sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church broke into the news around 2000, just as Paul Elie was writing his book “The Life You Save May Be Your Own.” His topic was the intertwining friendships of four great Catholic thinkers and writers, some of the best people in his tradition: Dorothy Day, Walker Percy, Flannery O’Connor and Thomas Merton.

headline: Fighting Off the Coast of France
text: Sunday, June 19, 1864, the C.S.S. Alabama, a swift commerce raider carrying eight guns, steamed out of Cherbourg harbor, prepared to battle the U.S.S. Kearsarge, a sloop of war of similar size and firepower.

headline: Nürburgring 24-Hour Race Draws Huge Entry
text: Nürburg, Germany — An automotive clambake of enormous proportions has assembled here this weekend for the 42nd running of the Nürburgring 24-hour race, an endurance contest whose demanding course includes the fabled section known as Nordschleife.

headline: Royalties and Teaching Help Fill Bank Accounts of Justices, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Financial disclosure reports released by the Supreme Court on Friday showed that book royalties continued to fill the bank accounts of certain justices, while most bolstered their incomes with teaching assignments.

headline: After a Career Peak at Wimbledon, a Long Fall and a Clouded Future
text: ROEHAMPTON, England — A year ago, Steve Darcis, a Belgian who was ranked 135th, stunned Rafael Nadal in the first round of Wimbledon, ending the 22-match winning streak of Nadal, the two-time champion from Spain. Darcis sealed the 7-6 (4), 7-6 (8), 6-4 victory with an ace, bringing the crowd of 11,429 at No. 1 Court to its feet.

headline: Hackers Take Down World Cup Site in Brazil
text: Hackers on Friday made good on their threat to take down the 2014 World Cup site in Brazil.

headline: FIFA Looking Into Possible Use of Gay Slur by Mexican Fans
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — FIFA has opened disciplinary proceedings against the Mexico team for what it has called the “improper conduct of spectators” at the World Cup.

headline: Judge Blocks Evidence in Goldman Code Theft Case
text: The curious case of Sergey Aleynikov — the former Goldman Sachs programmer who was criminally convicted, then acquitted and then charged again — has taken yet another surprising turn.

headline: Presbyterians Vote to Divest Holdings to Pressure Israel
text: DETROIT — After passionate debate over how best to help break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted on Friday at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.

headline: U.N. Chief Served Papers in Suit by Haitian Victims, Lawyers Say
text: The United Nations has been resisting, successfully so far, lawsuits from Haiti cholera victims who assert that United Nations peacekeepers caused the 2010 epidemic still ravaging the country. But on Friday, lawyers for the plaintiffs said, something new happened: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was personally served with court papers ordering him to appear, an assertion that his spokesman denied.

headline: Administration Takes Steps to Aid Bees
text: The White House announced new initiatives on Friday to promote the health of honeybees and other pollinators, which have suffered enormous losses in recent years. The memorandum, signed by President Obama, called for research into the causes of the severe decline and the role of pesticides, and formed a “pollinator health task force” of more than 14 federal agencies, saying, “It is critical to expand federal efforts and take new steps to reverse pollinator losses and help restore populations to healthy levels.” Erich Pica, president of the environmental group Friends of the Earth, said the administration “does not go far enough” to address pesticide issues.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Camaros of the World Unite, in Maryland
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Report Calls for Tracking Data on Stress Disorder
text: The Department of Defense and the Veterans Affairs Department should track their efforts to treat post-traumatic stress more carefully, to see how effective those efforts are, a government-sponsored report released Friday said. The report, from an expert panel assembled by the Institute of Medicine, noted that the agencies spend more than $3.3 billion annually on treatment of the disorder, which affects more than 500,000 veterans, including 8 percent of those who served in Iraq or Afghanistan — who are twice as likely to seek help as veterans of previous wars. It affirms the findings of a report published in 2012 that called for more careful tracking. The V.A. has tracked symptoms in some members given treatment, but it is not clear how many and whether those veterans are in fact improving, experts said. “Given that the D.O.D. and V.A. are responsible for serving millions of service members, families and veterans, we found it surprising that no PTSD outcome measures are used consistently to know if these treatments are working or not,” the chairman of the panel, Sandro Galea of Columbia University, said in a statement.

headline: Rangel and Espaillat Discuss Foreign Affairs as House Primary Nears
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel and his top challenger, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, debated international issues on Friday in one of the final pushes for votes in the Democratic primary for the 13th Congressional District seat.

headline: After Stumbles, Rangel Finds Some Level Ground
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel clambered up two flights of stairs into Public School 132 in Washington Heights to meet with parents on Tuesday, the second of a half-dozen stops on a full day of campaigning.

headline: Google’s Nest to Acquire Dropcam for $555 Million
text: Nest Labs, a maker of digital thermostats, announced Friday evening that it planned to buy another fast-growing producer of home devices, Dropcam, for $555 million in cash.

headline: ‘Lights Went Out,’ but He Kept Playing
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The team doctor stepped away from his patient and motioned to the coaches on the far sideline. He rolled his hands one over the other, the signal that the stumbling player beside him, Uruguay midfielder Álvaro Pereira, would have to be substituted.

headline: In Refugee Statistics, a Stark Tale of Global Strife
text: Statistics are not usually effective at depicting tragedy, which is why United Nations reports rarely generate passion. But the figures released this past week by the United Nations refugee agency offer perhaps the starkest reflection of the strife raking vast stretches of the globe.

headline: Every Senior V.A. Executive Was Rated ‘Fully Successful’ or Better Over 4 Years
text: All of the 470 senior executives at the Department of Veterans Affairs received annual ratings over the last four years indicating that they were “fully successful” in their jobs or even better, according to data released at a congressional hearing on Friday, despite delays in processing disability compensation claims and problems with veterans’ access to the department’s sprawling health care system.

headline: Health Site Is Changing Supervision
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration hired a top executive from the UnitedHealth Group on Friday to bolster management of the federal health insurance marketplace and to prevent a repetition of the chaos that engulfed the program last fall.

headline: Patience and Crib Notes Help as Wie Moves Into Open Lead
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Michelle Wie did her homework this week.

headline: Officials Plan Adjustments as New York City Slows to 25 M.P.H.
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s traffic safety push yielded perhaps its most significant change early on Friday, when the State Legislature approved a plan to reduce the default speed limit in New York City to 25 miles per hour.

headline: Amateurism and the N.C.A.A.
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — It was Thursday of Week 2 at the O’Bannon trial, the day Mark Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A., was going to be on the stand.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: A Settlement in the Central Park Jogger Case
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio acted in the interest of justice when his administration agreed to pay about $40 million to the five black and Hispanic men wrongly convicted in the brutal beating and rape of a white, female jogger in Central Park in 1989. If the settlement is approved by the city comptroller and a federal court, it will bring to a close one of the more shameful and racially divisive episodes in New York City history.

headline: Adventurous Couple Arrive in New York From Africa, Merrily, Merrily
text: Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys, a fun-loving couple from Cape Town, have been together for 14 years, so when Ms. Geldenhuys, 36, suggested a vacation, he was agreeable.

headline: On Immigration, the Hard Lines Start to Blur
text: FARMERS BRANCH, Tex. — Halfway through an evening of campaigning for mayor of this Dallas suburb, David Koch met a Colombian immigrant who had just moved in. “Well, welcome to the town,” he said, adding after friendly chatter: “Why did you pick Farmers Branch?”

headline: Iraq Insurgents Reaping Wealth as They Advance
text: BAGHDAD — When Qaeda-style insurgents overran the northern city of Mosul, among the war booty they seized were what they claimed were five American-made helicopters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 20, 2014
Gov. Scott Walker’s Campaign Violations
text: Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy promised in 2010 that there was nothing to fear from independent spending groups that raised unlimited dollars. Because they could not coordinate with political candidates, he wrote in the Citizens United decision, they “do not give rise to corruption or the appearance of corruption.”

headline: De Blasio’s Vow to Ease Reimbursement for Special Education Halts a Bill in Albany
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has promised to make it easier for some parents of special-needs children to get New York City to pay for private school tuition, holding off an effort by state legislators to make him do so by law.

headline: No Doping at the World Cup? That’s What FIFA Says
text: RIO dE JANEIRO — So far in this World Cup, not a single player has tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

headline: In Tournament Packed With Goals, France Stuffs in Five More
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — It was a gorgeous, ruthless finish from Karim Benzema: a perfectly timed swing of the right leg on the move from the French striker that put the ball into the upper-left corner of the Switzerland goal.

headline: The Heavy Burden of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
text: Post-traumatic stress disorder has reached staggering levels in the American military. An estimated 7 percent to 20 percent of all service members and veterans who have served in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq may have the disorder, and rising percentages of veterans from earlier conflicts are also afflicted.

headline: El Greco, After Age 36
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If there is anything that unnerves me more than realizing that I am about to sit down and solve a Saturday New York Times puzzle, it’s realizing that I am about to sit down and solve a Saturday New York Times puzzle under Brad Wilber’s and Byron Walden’s bylines. A hard puzzle is one thing; a hard puzzle by two of the toughest constructors in crossword puzzledom is wholly another.

headline: Twisty, Grindy and Brightly Hued
text: Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is fond of flattering his audience. During his preshow speech at the David H. Koch Theater on Thursday, he encouraged the spectators to applaud themselves. “Look at you!” he said, before humorously noting the usefulness of the phrase and how it can be directed at people who aren’t actually looking that good.

headline: On Duty, Patrolling the Projects; Off Duty, Exorcising Demons
text: The worried woman described the bizarre goings-on at her home in the Bronx, which she suspected was haunted, to the police officer standing before her. He was off duty, there on his own time. If she was braced for a gentle pat on the shoulder and a brushoff, she was in for a surprise.

headline: Aid Scarce as Pakistanis Flee Conflict
text: BANNU, Pakistan — The man waited for hours in the sweltering heat at a security checkpoint near here as his family struggled to leave Miram Shah, fleeing the military offensive the Pakistani military had announced against militants in North Waziristan.

text: Sorry about late posting — I just heard Lake Street Dive live in Prospect Park, which was wonderful. But instead of music, here’s a great guide to how they pronounce things over there:

headline: For Yankees’ Pineda, Return to Throwing Hinges on Results of M.R.I.
text: The Yankees are awaiting the results of a precautionary magnetic resonance imaging test on starting pitcher Michael Pineda’s injured right shoulder, the final hurdle before he can begin a throwing program.

headline: Matt Harvey and Mets Achieve Détente
text: MIAMI — During batting practice Thursday, Matt Harvey approached Jose Fernandez near the Miami Marlins dugout. Two of the best young pitchers in baseball were relegated to the periphery as they recovered from Tommy John surgery.

headline: Linesman Is Replaced After Two Curious Offside Calls
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — FIFA dropped an official from his crew’s next assignment at the World Cup after he made offside decisions that denied Mexico two potential goals in the team’s opening game, against Cameroon.

headline: Two Plays at Plate Doom Mets’ Rally Against Marlins
text: MIAMI — The Mets had the tying run on third with one out in the top of the ninth when Chris Young lifted a high fly ball to left field. Marcell Ozuna drifted back, about 10 yards behind where he thought the ball would land, as if he were winding himself up, and then ran forward, building momentum.

headline: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Refugees
text: The total number of people displaced by violence reached more than 51 million by the end of 2013, according to the United Nations.

headline: Beltran’s Homer Rescues Yankees After Kuroda Shines, Then Stumbles
text: Carlos Beltran’s career has been full of extraordinary moments, but his first few months as a Yankee had been rather average. He sustained an elbow injury that kept him out of the lineup for 21 games. His batting average had hovered around .200 for most of the season. The three-year, $45 million contract he signed this past off-season was appearing to be another regrettable decision the Yankees had made with an aging player.

headline: Four Contenders to Replace Maliki
text: Iraqi politicians have begun to position themselves as possible replacements for the embattled Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. These are the four contenders.

headline: China: Police Kill 13 in Attack in Xinjiang Region
text: Police officers shot dead 13 attackers on Saturday who rammed a vehicle into the main police station of Yecheng County, in the region of Xinjiang in far western China, according to state news media reports. Three police officers were lightly wounded in the attack, which also involved the detonation of explosive devices, the reports said. Violent episodes in Xinjiang have become more frequent in the last couple years, and attacks on police stations appear to be on the rise. Yecheng County is an area that is heavily populated by Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking ethnic group who in in recent years have often clashed in Xinjiang with ethnic Han, the dominant group in China. Many Uighurs say they face discrimination, and some call for an independent Uighur state to be carved from in Xinjiang and called East Turkestan. In recent months, there have been attacks across China that state news media reports have attributed to Uighur militants.

headline: Seafood, Shipped In
text: The United States imports seafood in increasing numbers, even for salmon, which it has in abundance.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WOLVERINE (2013) This sixth installment in the X-Men film franchise finds Logan (Hugh Jackman) living as a hermit in the great white north and tormented by the memory of being forced to kill Jean Grey (Famke Janssen). Then the warrior pixie Yukio (Rila Fukushima) spirits him back to Tokyo to meet with Yashida (Haruhiko Yamanouchi), who is intent on repaying his life debt to Logan, who saved him during the bombing of Nagasaki — and alleviate Logan of his immortality, which he now considers a curse. “Mr. Jackman, for all his growling, flexing and macho wisecracking, keeps our attention focused on Logan’s feelings,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. So does the director James Mangold, he said, adding, “A modest superhero picture may sound like a contradiction in terms, but really it is a welcome respite.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 21, 2014
text: “We no longer have to imagine a terror state. We have one.”

headline: Conflicting Gestures From Putin to Ukraine Leaders
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia proffered both a carrot and a stick to Ukraine on Saturday, issuing a qualified acceptance of a peace plan proposed by the Ukrainian leadership to quell a separatist uprising in the southeast, but simultaneously putting troops across central Russia on combat alert and mounting surprise military drills.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches
text: Argentina vs. Iran, 12 p.m.: Look for Argentina to iron out the kinks in its game — perhaps Lionel Messi improving his interactions with attackmate Sergio Agüero — because Iran does not figure to offer much in the way of competition. It barely hung on to a 0-0 draw with Nigeria in (so far) the most dreary game of the tournament.

headline: New Offering for Job Seekers: Fewer Embarrassing Social Media Photos
text: Before a college graduate goes job hunting, he or she will probably do a few things: prepare a good résumé, be ready to answer some key questions about his or her skills and qualifications, buy some nice clothes.

text: Iran fought hard and really neutralized some of the world’s finest players. But they couldn’t contain Lionel Messi, who scored in the final minutes to lift Argentina.

headline: Sunnis in Iraq Make Some Gains in Fighting in the North and West
text: BAGHDAD — The violent struggle over Iraq on Saturday consumed cities and towns widely spread over the north and west of the country, with Sunni militants making some gains near a strategic border crossing with Syria..

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 22
text: “Guess what — one of the things people want to do with their phones is buy stuff, from Amazon and in general.”

headline: In Digital Marketing, the Sociology of the Sale
Espousing Equality, but Embracing a Hierarchy
text: People never say they want to grow up to be a middle manager, and some company founders aspire never to hire one.

text: Is inherited wealth making a comeback?

headline: Argentina vs. Iran: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Argentina can wrap up its expected second round berth. An Iran win, or even a draw, would rank at the top of the list of its greatest soccer achievements.

headline: Urban Hurly-Burly of a Bumptious Era
text: The great street photographer Garry Winogrand once said, “I photograph to find out what something will look like photographed.” That curiosity led him to make some of the most indelible photographs of life in the United States during one of its most turbulent decades, the Sixties, with extraordinary avidity. In crowded off-kilter pictures that seemed haphazard and badly composed to critics at the time, he captured urban pedestrian traffic, people and animals at zoos and political demonstrations and altercations.

headline: He’s an Old Soul, In a Young Way
text: In jazz, there are young people who sound old, old people who sound young and, very occasionally, young people who sound like old people who sound young. Pay attention to those people. The tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry has been such a person, with a full tone, slow and songlike phrasing and a totally in-the-present disposition equally indebted to free jazz and, say, Lester Young. He’s unpredictable, open to the ideas of his band members and to creating benign mischief.

headline: Tyrannical Captor of Under-Age Wives
text: Talk about scandalous. In “Outlaw Prophet: Warren Jeffs,” on Saturday night at 8 on Lifetime, Tony Goldwyn channels Mr. Jeffs, the president and prophet, seer and revelator, of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints — who in 2006 joined Osama bin Laden on the F.B.I.’s 10 Most Wanted list for having arranged illegal marriages between his adult male followers and under-age girls. “He’s a far cry worse than playing President Fitz,” Mr. Goldwyn said in a phone interview, alluding to his role in the ABC drama “Scandal.” “You have a guy who was essentially disenfranchised in this very strange community, and who usurped power and became a complete dictator in his world.”

headline: A Verdant Treat, and a Period Viola
text: Fresh air, proud history: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts in Central Park has both. A perfect setting, then, for the Knights, a collective that brings equal doses of meticulous musicianship and fun to its performances. In the opening concert of the series on Tuesday, the conductor Eric Jacobsen leads the Knights in a typically eclectic program, including an arrangement of Boccherini’s Quintet in C (Op. 30), set in nighttime Madrid, alongside two newer works by composers with a strong sense of place: Andrew Norman’s “Light Screens” and Ives’s “Three Places in New England.” The composer-pianist Timo Andres joins in for his own take on Mozart’s “Coronation” Concerto. (7:30 p.m.; naumburgconcerts.org.)

headline: Gently Dissecting a British Milieu
text: With three features under her belt, the British auteur Joanna Hogg has carved out a niche in British cinema, gently anatomizing the habits and humors of the English middle class. (Éric Rohmer is a rough analogue.) Now, New Yorkers will get a chance to see all of her films.

headline: Blending Beauty With Sharp Edges
text: Since its founding 50 years ago by E. Virginia Williams, one of the pioneers of American regional ballet, the Boston Ballet has steadily broadened its outlook. Now, under the direction of Mikko Nissinen, it comes to Lincoln Center with two programs that reflect its diversity.

headline: Cyberattack on Hong Kong Vote Was Among Largest Ever, Security Chief Says
text: The online voting platform for the unofficial referendum now underway on Hong Kong’s political future has been subjected to one of the most severe cyberattacks of its kind ever seen, according to the head of the Internet security company tasked with protecting it.

text: Everybody seems to be following the World Cup. I’m not, and it’s making me feel a little left out at work. What’s all this talk about yellow cards?

headline: Yahoo Wants You to Linger (on the Ads, Too)
text: Four editors were deep in debate at Yahoo Food’s offices in Manhattan: Would Yahoo visitors click on a feature about foods of the ancient Silk Road, or would they prefer a guide to cheese fries and other snacks that go well with ranch dressing for the Final Four basketball games?

headline: Bike Storage Needed
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A Job Seeker’s Desperate Choice
text: On the morning of March 20, Shanesha Taylor had a job interview. It was for a good job, one that could support her three children, unlike the many positions she’d applied for that paid only $10 an hour. The interview, at an insurance agency in Scottsdale, Ariz., went well. “Walking out of the office, you know that little skip thing people do?” she said, clicking her heels together in a corny expression of glee. “I wanted to do that.”

headline: A Leadership Lesson for Goodell, From Goodell
text: In late 2011, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell paid a visit to my barbershop in Harlem, where we enjoyed an informal conversation about a variety of issues centering mainly on player safety and whether the game was becoming too soft.

headline: Variety: A Delicious Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s summer and grilling season is here, as far as Fred Piscop is concerned. Today, we’re not only going to build a puzzle with him, but we’re also going to build the ultimate burger.

headline: A Misguided Departure From the Serve-and-Volley
text: The art of the serve-and-volley, many tennis experts argue, has no place in today’s game. It is a common refrain that the speed of the courts, modern string technology and even the size of the athletes have made that style of play obselete.

headline: Unblinking Eyes Track Employees
text: A digital Big Brother is coming to work, for better or worse.

headline: The Anchor on an Evolving Team
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Tim Howard did not always like what Jurgen Klinsmann was doing to Howard’s closest friends. He actually hated it. One by one, all of the veteran players on the United States national team had their moments with Klinsmann, the coach from Germany, who had made clear since the moment he was hired in 2011 that history and past performance meant nothing to him.

headline: Workplace Surveillance and the ‘Transparency Paradox’
text: Jim Sullivan, general manager of a Dallas restaurant, embraces digital monitoring in the workplace. Software, sensors and data make it increasingly possible, and Mr. Sullivan, as noted in an article I wrote, is a beneficiary of the improved measurement techniques. His data showed he was a highly productive worker, a prime candidate for the promotions he received.

headline: ‘You Can Do It, Shirley’
text: Martin Luther King Addo, a 44-year-old bodybuilder who was twice crowned Mr. Ghana, opened a storefront gym in a N.O.R.C. — a naturally occurring retirement community — in Lower Manhattan. His clients, many of them older women, are glad he did. Read the full story, and watch the video, above.

headline: Juli Inkster Leaves a Legacy as a Master Multitasker
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Take a long look at Juli Inkster, who carded a four-under-par 66, the lowest round of the week, on Saturday. Admire her the way you might the Yankees’ consummate contact hitter, Ichiro Suzuki, or any other favorite relic. She is easy to spot on the driving range, with her short hair and her skirt so long the hem nearly reaches her knees.

headline: South Korea Hunts for Army Shooter
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Army sergeant killed five of his fellow soldiers and wounded five others on Saturday when he opened fire along the border with North Korea, military officials said. A hunt for the soldier was underway late Saturday.

headline: Baptism by Fire: A New York Firefighter Confronts His First Test
text: Jordan Sullivan’s decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.

headline: Are You a Firefighter? Tell Us About Your First Fire
text: “To a firefighter, the first fire is like a police officer’s first collar, a lawyer’s first jury trial, a fisherman’s first tuna. It becomes chiseled into your memory in big block letters, rolled out and dusted off for reminiscence over a lifetime,” N.R. Kleinfield wrote in an article about Jordan Sullivan, a New York City firefighter with Ladder Company 105 in Brooklyn.

headline: Rite of the Sitting Dead: Funeral Poses Mimic Life
text: NEW ORLEANS — All last week, people were calling Louis Charbonnet to find out how they might avoid lying down at their funerals. Funeral directors have called; so have people with their own requests, such as the woman who wanted to be seen for the last time standing over her cooking pot.

text: BAGHDAD — The long lines of Shiite fighters began marching through the capital early Saturday morning. Some wore masks. One group had yellow and green suicide explosives, which they said were live, strapped to their chests.

text: How Germany shut down Ronaldo and what the U.S. needs to do when they face him on Sunday.

text: BRASÍLIA — In 1500, Portuguese explorers arrived on the shores of what is now Brazil seeking, among other things, gold. Today, Portuguese adventurers have come here seeking merely goals.

headline: My Mother, My Writing Student
text: On the first day of a weeklong creative-writing workshop, I sit across from a group of serious-minded first-time novelists, people who have come to me, their teacher, to make their books better. I’ve just been going over the schedule, a series of craft talks, workshops and one-on-one conferences. “Are there any questions?” I ask.

headline: In Shiite Heartland of Iraq, Volunteers Get Set for a ‘Defensive Jihad’
text: NAJAF, Iraq — It had been quite the morning for Jamli Umm Saif, a mother of four. After morning prayers on Saturday, she sent off her husband and eldest son to join a military parade by the Mahdi Army, a Shiite militia run by the populist cleric Moktada al-Sadr.

headline: Immigration Reform’s Open Invitation to Children
text: FOR years now, one side of the immigration debate — the side of billionaires, professional bipartisans, and all the great and good — has argued that an amnesty of some kind for illegal immigrants isn’t just a sensible policy choice but a crushingly obvious one: self-evidently wise, morally farseeing and a win for almost everyone, from corporations to labor unions to Republican politicians to the immigrants themselves.

headline: Postpartum Depression
text: Readers react to articles on the various ways that mental disorders can afflict new moms.

headline: Ed Lu
text: Ed Lu is a physicist and former NASA astronaut who is currently the chief executive of the B612 Foundation, a nonprofit organization on a mission to save the world from a possible asteroid apocalypse. The group is in the process of building an infrared telescope that, once launched into space, will search the solar system for monster asteroids on a collision course with Earth.

headline: So Similar, So Different
text: READERS often ask: Why do I travel to places like Sudan or Myanmar when we Americans have so many challenges at home to worry about?

headline: Inside Firefighter School
text: Jordan Sullivan, a rookie New York City firefighter, recalls his training at the Fire Academy on Randalls Island, known as the Rock, where one of the most challenging exercises is search and rescue.

headline: The Coming Climate Crash
text: THERE is a time for weighing evidence and a time for acting. And if there’s one thing I’ve learned throughout my work in finance, government and conservation, it is to act before problems become too big to manage.

text: Milan

headline: How My Wine Turned to Water
text: TRURO, Mass. — MY email inbox startled me with the subject line: A Voice from the Past. The last email I received with that heading was from Peanuts LoBianco, a deranged former high school classmate who claimed he had learned to walk on water, change water into wine and then walk on the wine. For all that, he still needed money from me.

headline: An Ace Agent Finally Has a Hall of Famer
text: For most of the last three decades, few people have had more influence on baseball, or been more ubiquitous, than the agent Scott Boras. When you flip on a game taking place in Anaheim, Calif., chances are he is looking back at you from his suite behind home plate. When you wonder whether your team will sign, or retain, a prominent star, quite often it is Boras handling the negotiations.

headline: Baltimore Joins Cities Toughening Curfews, Citing Safety but Eliciting Concern
text: BALTIMORE — To beat the summer heat, Isaiah Jackson waits until the sun goes down to play basketball in an alley near his home.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 22
text: As unrest and violence continues in Iraq, President Obama announced Thursday that he would send 300 military advisers to the country to aid struggling security forces to fight off Sunni militants. Insurgents with the Sunni militant group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have swept through northern cities, often seizing money from banks along the way.

headline: Death Threats, Then Red Tape
text: ON June 20, 2011, in Veracruz, Mexico, Miguel Ángel López Solana arrived home to find that his brother, mother and father had been murdered. Both sons were photojournalists at the newspaper where their father was a columnist, writing about crime and political corruption. Within a month, another journalist at the paper was decapitated. A year later, four more journalists were murdered there in a single week. It’s not clear why they were killed, but Mr. López wasn’t going to wait around to find out.

headline: Two-Parent Households Can Be Lethal
text: AFTER spending two years studying services for domestic violence survivors, I was surprised to realize that one of the most common barriers to women’s safety was something I had never considered before: the high value our culture places on two-parent families.

headline: Hacker Tactic: Holding Data Hostage
text: THE perpetual cat-and-mouse game between computer hackers and their targets is getting nastier. Cybercriminals are getting better at circumventing firewalls and antivirus programs. More of them are resorting to ransomware, which encrypts computer data and holds it hostage until a fee is paid. Some hackers plant virus-loaded ads on legitimate websites, enabling them to remotely wipe a hard drive clean or cause it to overheat. Meanwhile, companies are being routinely targeted by attacks sponsored by the governments of Iran and China. Even small start-ups are suffering from denial-of-service extortion attacks, in which hackers threaten to disable their websites unless money is paid.

headline: Superstitious Soccer Fans
text: Some Brazilian soccer fans say their personal rituals have a direct impact on their team’s success.

headline: With Salary Choice, Anthony Will Show How Much Value He Places on Winning
text: Carmelo Anthony will soon be making a choice on how much he is willing to sacrifice, in terms of salary, to be part of a winning team.

headline: Fear Not the Coming of the Robots
text: JUST over 50 years ago, the cover of Life magazine breathlessly declared the “point of no return for everybody.” Above that stark warning, a smaller headline proclaimed, “Automation’s really here; jobs go scarce.”

headline: Atlanta Summons the Past to Showcase the Present
text: ATLANTA — Far from his typical Broadway haunts, the director George C. Wolfe was walking through a construction site here this spring when, amid a cacophony of saws and drills, he stopped and stood before what was to become a replica of a lunch counter that he said would claw visitors back into history.

headline: Gaming the Poor
text: In a referendum in November, voters approved as many as seven new casinos to join New York State’s existing nine gambling facilities. And New York is hardly alone. In recent years, 23 other states have legalized and licensed commercial (as opposed to Native American) gambling facilities. In the casino-dense Northeast and mid-Atlantic regions, where 26 casinos have opened since 2004 and at least a dozen more are under development, most adults now live within a short drive of one.

headline: But I Want to Do Your Homework
text: MY son and I are shouting at each other, and crying. He is holding his essay between his fingertips as if it’s a dead cockroach. “I’m sorry,” I said. “I just made a few corrections...”

headline: Mass Surveillance in Britain
text: European officials have often acted as though excessive government surveillance was solely an American problem. The recent release of a  legal statement from a senior British counterterrorism official, Charles Farr, shows that the United States government is certainly not alone in justifying such practices.

headline: Sentencing Reform Runs Aground
text: Criminal justice reform is one of the rare issues on which there has been bipartisan support in Congress and significant progress toward a legislative solution. Until recently, anyway.

headline: Slavery and the Shrimp on Your Plate
text: Shrimp and other seafood fishing is a big business in Thailand. The industry employs more than 650,000 people and annually produces more than $7 billion in exports that show up on dinner tables all over the world, including in the United States. It also has a horrific dark side. Its reliance on slave labor is so pervasive and ugly that the State Department now lists Thailand as one of the worst violators among 188 countries judged every year on how they deal with human trafficking.

headline: Despite Recent Early Exits, Federer and Williams Like Their Chances
text: WIMBLEDON, England — A couple of 32-year-olds who have each won 17 Grand Slam titles weighed in Saturday on the prospects of reaching No. 18 by the end of the Wimbledon tournament, which begins Monday. While Roger Federer was talkative, Serena Williams was terse.

headline: A Largely Indian Victory in World War II, Mostly Forgotten in India
text: KOHIMA, India — Soldiers died by the dozens, by the hundreds and then by the thousands in a battle here 70 years ago. Two bloody weeks of fighting came down to just a few yards across an asphalt tennis court.

headline: Iraqi-Americans Watch Chaos in Alarm
text: WASHINGTON — Every mile Iraqi militants log on their warpath toward Baghdad is another reason for Majid al-Bahadli to worry.

headline: Versace: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With Job in Peril, Yankees’ Nuno Wobbles Through a Start
text: Vidal Nuno had only a tenuous hold on his spot in the Yankees’ pitching rotation when he took the mound Saturday against the Baltimore Orioles. He hardly strengthened his position in the Yankees’ 6-1 loss, allowing five runs, four of them earned, in six and a third innings while giving up three home runs.

headline: Should America Solve its Own Problems First?
text: Whenever I write about international issues, I always get pushback from readers who say that we should solve our own domestic problems before worrying about the rest of the world. As House Majority Leader Tom DeLay put it years ago, international humanitarianism puts “Ghana over Grandma.” I don’t buy that, and my Sunday column is a response to that way of thinking. But as my column notes, I think there’s sometimes also the opposite tendency, especially among university students–that is to think that it’s glamorous to fight illiteracy in Tanzania, but not to mentor at-risk students on the wrong side of the tracks in one’s own city. As far as I’m concerned, there are important needs both at home and abroad, and we needn’t solve one before beginning to tackle the other. The story I tell in this column is why I think that. So read the column and post your thoughts below.

headline: Big Ten Commissioner Testifies for a Simpler Time
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Mark Emmert, the N.C.A.A. president, drew a crowd to federal court here last week, as journalists and lawyers packed a courtroom and a second overflow room to witness his defense of amateur college sports. When Emmert finished his testimony early Friday, much of the crowd was gone.

headline: American Apparel Ousts Its Founder, Dov Charney, Over Nude Photos
text: The founder and chief executive of American Apparel, Dov Charney, was fired this week because an internal investigation found that he had misused company money and had allowed an employee to post naked photographs of a former female employee who had sued him, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Bosnia-Herzegovina vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Vedad Ibisevic of Bosnia did manage to score against Argentina, but it was largely because of keeper error. Bosnia will be looking to do better, with forward Senad Lulic a key man.

headline: Alstom Board Backs Offer From G.E., Ending Battle
text: PARIS — The board of the French industrial conglomerate Alstom said Saturday that it had unanimously backed General Electric’s offer to acquire most of its energy business for $13.5 billion, essentially ending the battle for the company. A final deal was still awaiting the successful outcome of negotiations between the government and Alstom’s largest shareholder over the sale of a stake to the state.

headline: Dime Store
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, this was just brilliant on a few levels. We saw something like this nearly a year ago, by Daniel Finan, but even so, this is a delicious “Aha!” moment.

headline: Carlton A. Sherwood, Reporter Behind 2004 Kerry Film, Dies at 67
text: Carlton A. Sherwood, an investigative journalist and former Marine who lurched between accolades and controversy, most prominently with a 2004 film about the chagrin of Vietnam War veterans over John Kerry’s turning against the war as a naval officer, died on June 11 in Philadelphia. He was 67.

headline: Vows | When the Beat Works
text: As musicians, Rachel Elmer and Gabriel Hernandez know when they have a song right. That has not always been the case in their relationship. (Correction: An earlier version of a capsule summary with this video misstated the given name of the groom. He is Gabriel Hernandez, not George.)

headline: Seeing Sons’ Violent Potential, but Finding Little Help or Hope
text: GENEVA, Ill. — The 15-year-old was perched on his bed, smoking a cigarette, when his mother came in. She demanded he put it out; he refused; she reached to take it from his mouth.

headline: A Christian Convert, on the Run in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a dank basement on the outskirts of Kabul, Josef read his worn blue Bible by the light of a propane lantern, as he had done for weeks since he fled from his family in Pakistan.

headline: Dr. Arnold Relman, 91, Journal Editor and Health System Critic, Dies
text: Dr. Arnold S. Relman, who abandoned the study of philosophy to rise to the top of the medical profession as a researcher, administrator and longtime editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, which became a platform for his early and influential attacks on the profit-driven health care system, died at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on Tuesday, his 91st birthday.

headline: For Yankees, the Immortalization Process Is Worth Rethinking

After the Wednesday practice round in Augusta, Ga., Martinez got a phone call from Deborah Tymon, the Yankees’ senior vice president for marketing. She told him he would get his own plaque in Monument Park on June 21.

headline: A Young Marlin With a Rocket Arm Works to Grow Into an All-Around Threat
text: MIAMI — Marcell Ozuna paced around left field during batting practice Saturday afternoon. It was the same spot where he had made the decisive play the night before, and he re-enacted it for his Miami Marlins teammates in slow motion. He retreated a few steps, came forward under an imaginary ball, reached out his glove and wound his arm.

headline: Project Tests New Storage for Energy
text: LANCASTER, Tex. — No one at the equipment lot here would blame you for failing to notice the drab green box sitting across from the spare transformers. But the lithium ions inside that refrigerator-size container are part of a wave of energy storage technology that could help Texas revolutionize its electric grid.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches

Two of them, Marouane Fellaini and Dries Merten, provided the goals that lifted Belgium over Algeria. Russia also got its only goal in a draw against South Korea from a sub, Alan Dzagoev. A draw may be enough for these two teams to advance.

headline: Mastering the Art of Three-Dimensional Graffiti

Carlos Mare sweated and huffed as he bent a stainless steel arrow over his knee. He tucked it into a mirror-shiny tangle of curves and lines that hung from a wall, stepped back and waved his arms, as if he were conducting an orchestra.
