headline: ‘Newsies’ to Close in August
text: The hit Broadway musical “Newsies” will close on Aug. 24 after two and a half years of performances, Disney Theatrical Productions announced on Sunday. The profitable run has far exceeded Disney’s expectations and helped the company bounce back on Broadway after two critical and commercial disappointments, “Tarzan” and “The Little Mermaid.”

headline: Understanding the Land Where ‘Kafkaesque’ Was Born
text: One thing worth remembering while reading Mariusz Szczygiel’s mordant “Gottland: Mostly True Stories From Half of Czechoslovakia” is that Franz Kafka was a Czech, and Mr. Szczygiel is not. He’s a Polish writer and journalist, looking with a kind of appalled fascination at his country’s southern neighbor and finding that life there can often be, well, Kafkaesque.

There will be additional auctions of one-year bills and two-year notes on Tuesday, five-year notes and two-year floating rate notes on Wednesday and seven-year notes on Thursday.

headline: Clock Ticking, Anthony Is Set to Test Free Agency
text: Countless possessions for the Knicks last season ended with Carmelo Anthony cradling the basketball as he looked for an angle against a defender. With the shot clock winding down, Anthony would be operating in an isolation set, the crowd at Madison Square Garden awaiting his next move.

headline: The Harmony of Liberty
text: ATLANTA — It isn’t that great a distance from the birthplace of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Auburn Avenue here to the $68 million, 42,000 square-foot National Center for Civil and Human Rights that is opening on Monday near Centennial Olympic Park. The two sites, though, seem as if they’ve emerged not just from different time periods, but from different and incompatible universes.

headline: The Week Ahead: AT&T-DirecTV Hearing, and First-Quarter Growth
text: ANTITRUST HEARING IS SET FOR AT&T AND DIRECTV

headline: A Hybrid Star Expresses the Currents and Crosscurrents in the Europe of Today
text: Stromae dances to a continent’s disquiet. He’s a Belgian songwriter who performed on Friday night for an adoring full house at the Best Buy Theater. He’s also a pop-star embodiment of a contemporary Europe that’s smart, increasingly heterogeneous, historically aware, anxious about the future, sleekly charming and unfailingly stylish.

headline: Digging Deep, a Singer Gives Signature Songs Her Own Stamp
text: Conventional cultural wisdom has it that Billie Holiday, who wrote “God Bless the Child” with Arthur Herzog Jr. in 1939 and first recorded it two years later, is the ultimate interpreter of this devastating reflection on poverty and humiliation. In Holiday’s performances, her voice curled around the song and enfolded it as though she were trying to comfort a wounded stray animal she found on the street and brought home to care for: perhaps her own inner child.

headline: Writhing Upon the Shoulders of Giants
text: Some choreographers seem to know exactly what they want to say before they say it. Why express through movement what you can articulate just as clearly, if not more, in a program note?

headline: Kerry on the Iraq Crisis
text: In a news conference with Egypt’s foreign minister, Secretary of State John Kerry said that Islamist militants seizing control of parts of Iraq were a threat to the entire region.

headline: The Amazing Adventures of Pencil Man
text: “King Kirby,” now at the Brick in Brooklyn as part of the Comic Book Theater Festival, opens with a scene that prompts knowing eye rolls to those familiar with the show’s subject: In 1994, a Sotheby’s auctioneer, hawking work by the comic book artist Jack Kirby, dismissively confuses Spider-Man with Iron Man. Of course she does; after all, this is comic book art, not “fine” art, and the cultural elite, like countless parents, have sneered at comics since time immemorial. Even comic publishers, as this show demonstrates, were once happy to shortchange their own creators.

headline: Croatia Hosts European Championships
text: The European Team Championships have just started in Opatija, Croatia, and will run until July 1. Details are at eurobridge.org.

headline: Leaping From Marvel to DC in a Single Bound
text: On Wednesday, readers of Superman will be introduced to two men new to DC Comics: Ulysses, a strange visitor from another dimension; and the illustrator John Romita Jr., a decades-long veteran of Marvel Comics, making his DC debut.

headline: A Woman’s Leadership May Steel Murray’s Nerve
text: WIMBLEDON, England — England could use an encore.

headline: Goodness Had Nothing to Do With It
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I never learned how to do many YO-YO TRICKS myself, mainly because I wasn’t even very good at the basic up-and-down motion. And for reasons that were never clear to me, the string always wound up with knots in it.

headline: With a Resolve Years in the Making, Wie Wins the U.S. Women’s Open for Her First Major Title
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Michelle Wie’s strategy for the 69th United States Women’s Open was to laugh in the face of disaster. She made it her mantra. When bad shots happen, smile and move on.

headline: European Regulators Seek to Tighten Rules for Airliner Tracking and Safety
text: BRUSSELS — More than three months after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, regulators in Europe are pressing for new ways that would make it impossible to disable safety and communications systems on commercial airliners.

headline: On the Hoof in the City for a Day of Music
text: It was lovely to be out and around in New York on Saturday, the first day of summer, warm, sunny and dry. And if you were out, you may well have tripped on a concert or two.

headline: Cole Porter’s Lost Show Unearthed
text: The bandleader Vince Giordano said that when he dialed the number, he figured it was little more than a Hail Mary pass. But that simple phone call solved the mystery.

headline: The Cold War Brews Anew in Prime Time
text: Vladimir V. Putin is great for television.

headline: A Most Rare Vision: Shakespeare in China
text: BEIJING — On the final night recently of the Actors’ Gang production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” here, theatergoers were treated to an unexpected — and rather meta — performance.

headline: Man Dies in Las Vegas at Electric Daisy Carnival
text: A 24-year-old California man died after attending opening night of the Electric Daisy Carnival in Las Vegas on Friday. The Las Vegas Sun reported that the man, Montgomery Tsang of San Leandro, collapsed in the parking lot of the Las Vegas Motor Speedway, where the festival was being held. He was taken to a hospital, where he died early Saturday morning. No cause of death had been determined as of Sunday afternoon, Jennifer Jacobs, senior coroner investigator at the Clark County Coroner’s Office, said. The festival’s organizers, Insomniac Events, estimate that approximately 134,000 people attended on Friday. About 250 medical calls were made that night, five of which resulted in trips to the hospital, according to the Las Vegas police. A spokeswoman for Insomniac, Jennifer Forkish, said in a statement on Saturday that “one death is one too many,” and asked festivalgoers to help keep one another safe on the remaining two nights. Saturday’s was not the first death tied to an Electric Daisy event. In 2010, a 15-year-old girl died of a drug overdose at the festival in Los Angeles. The next year, a 19-year-old man died at an Electric Daisy event in Dallas, and in 2012 two people died off site after attending the festival in Las Vegas.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13) THE ESCAPE ARTIST “Everyone deserves a defense,” says Will Burton (David Tennant, above), who is London’s top-ranked junior barrister, according to a recent poll, and well up the ladder toward Queen’s Counsel because of his ability to win any case. But his invincible legal acrobatics backfire when a handshake denied sends his latest client, the reclusive bird lover and psychopath Liam Foyle (Toby Kebbell), into a rage — leaving Will, his wife (Ashley Jensen) and their son (Gus Barry) the targets of revenge. Enter Will’s nemesis, Maggie Gardner (Sophie Okonedo), frothing to overtake her rival. David Wolstencroft, the mastermind behind the BBC spy series “MI-5,” wrote this two-part “Masterpiece Mystery!” thriller, shown here in its entirety. (Part 2 will be broadcast on Channel 49 at 9.) “For the Tennant completist, it’s mandatory viewing,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Is Real Inclusiveness Possible?
text: Like many institutions that have become more concerned with equality in the past few decades, academic philosophy today aims to be more inclusive. In general, university departments are now striving to consider the experiences and concerns of a broader range of people than have traditionally played the social and professional role of the philosopher. This makes sense. In an increasingly global intellectual landscape, the removal of barriers to entry for previously excluded groups of people and schools of thought is productive and fair.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Can’t Capitalize on Another Solid Outing from Tanaka
text: Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium began with the traditional Old-Timers’ game. With each hit, each strikeout and each introduction, the former Yankees stars earned thunderous applause.

headline: Mayors Put Focus on How to Raise Wages for Lowest-Paid Workers in Cities
text: DALLAS — About one in five people in Hallandale Beach, Fla., live below the poverty line. Though it is a small city — 37,000 people, a horse track and a greyhound track — its mayor, Joy Cooper, bellied up to the table during a jobs committee discussion on Saturday among the nation’s mayors and fired off a few questions about raising the minimum wage, if not for the whole city, at least for businesses with city contracts.

headline: For Women, a Full Range of Reproductive Services

headline: Our Children and the Common Core
Curlers’ Aim: Sweep to a Win Over the Heat
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — As the temperature dipped to a stultifying 106 degrees one recent evening, members of the Coyotes Curling Club showed up at their clubhouse in a factory district near the airport ready to unwind, work out and cool off.

headline: Late Shock Interrupts U.S. Party
text: MANAUS, Brazil — The ball was barely past United States goalkeeper Tim Howard, and already he had put his hands to his head. On the bench, Jurgen Klinsmann spun away as if he had seen a ghost. Up the field, not far from where he lost the ball, Michael Bradley could only stare.

headline: Quirky to Create a Smart-Home Products Company
text: The repurposed red brick warehouse in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood is a bustling hub of modern industrial activity. Skilled young workers are hunched over pristine machine tools and 3-D printers that churn out prototype products.

headline: Creating Unexpected Opportunities in a Recovering Economy
text: In New York City’s burgeoning tech world, the start-ups and corporate behemoths are all hungry for talented coders and programmers. But Jahmil Eady never envisioned a career in technology. That was for math geeks, science nerds, white guys.

headline: African Teams Band Together in Spoiler Role
text: BRASÍLIA — It is Sunday in Brasília. The nation’s capital has the air of a city that was out of date even as it was being built. This may have been the city of the future, but now it looks as if it belongs to the past. In the afternoon sun, many of the older, concrete high-rises look shabby compared with their new, glass-fronted neighbors.

headline: Bergdahl Begins Outpatient Treatment
text: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the American prisoner of war freed in exchange for five Taliban detainees held at Guantánamo Bay, has been moved from a military medical center in Texas to begin outpatient treatment, the Pentagon said Sunday.

headline: De Blasio Brings Back a Mayoral Tradition: Performing Marriages
text: On Inauguration Day, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised to fulfill a campaign pledge to unite the people of New York City.

headline: 3 Who Escaped Prison by Helicopter Are Caught in Montreal
text: OTTAWA — Three men who made a dramatic escape by helicopter from a Quebec detention center two weeks ago were captured in a tourist section of Montreal by a police tactical squad early Sunday morning.

headline: Honolulu Shores Up Tourism With Crackdown on Homeless
text: HONOLULU — It was just before 7 a.m. and the streets of Waikiki were filled with tourists, surfers, early morning joggers — and Ronnie Cruz, a 34-year-old homeless man getting a ticket from a Honolulu police officer for pushing a shopping cart piled high with his belongings along the sidewalk.

headline: What the U.S. Must Do Now to Advance
text: After a brutally disappointing tie Sunday night, the United States faces a dizzying array of possibilities heading into its final match in the World Cup’s group stage. Here are the basic facts to keep in mind:

headline: Brasília, a Capital City That’s a Place Apart
text: BRASÍLIA — The Brazilian flag reads, “Ordem e Progresso” — “Order and Progress” — which is somewhat curious in this wonderfully jumbled and beautiful country. For an outsider who has visited the samba-infused nightclubs of Rio de Janeiro, the Amazonian jungle or São Paulo, with its ramshackle favelas and snarled traffic, order is not what springs to mind.

headline: Elite, Separate, Unequal
text: WASHINGTON — NEW YORK CITY’S elite public high schools were always meant to provide a quintessentially American blend of academic excellence and democratic accessibility. Unlike the city’s expensive private schools, they would be free and open to all who were academically qualified, irrespective of pedigree.

headline: A Brand Highlights Its Natural Bona Fides, and Taste
text: PARENTS who dread walking down the breakfast cereal aisle because their children will demand sugary brands were given more to worry about by a recent Cornell University study that found characters on cereal boxes tend to direct their gazes downward at youngsters.

headline: McCarthy’s Role Is Debated in His Land of Immigrants
text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The diner on 24th Street serves salsa as well as homemade jam, and cactus-leaf scrambles share a place on the menu with chicken-fried steak and eggs. Over the clatter of coffee cups, it’s difficult to tell which tables are chatting in Spanish and which in English.

headline: At School, Turning Good Food Into Perfectly Good Compost
text: One by one, the children at Public School 30 on Staten Island dumped their uneaten bananas into a bin in the back of their raucous cafeteria, each greenish-yellow missile landing with a thud. Thud. Thud.

headline: Croatia Talks Good Game but Will Have to Play One vs. Mexico to Advance
text: RECIFE, Brazil — Luka Modric heaped superlatives upon the Mexican team. Then he said his Croatian team was better in every way.

headline: Putin Attempts to Straddle a Divide He Helped to Pry Open in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s charged balancing act in its policy toward Ukraine was evident on Sunday, with President Vladimir V. Putin both endorsing a peace plan outlined by the Ukrainian president and rebuking Kiev for the shaky cease-fire.

headline: Nielsen Rewards Innovations of Successful New Products
text: It’s tough being a consumer products company.

headline: Here Lies Progress: Asian Actors Fill the Playbill
text: After decades of inching toward center stage, Asian-American theater actors are facing something that they’ve rarely enjoyed in New York: demand.

headline: Fate of 3 Kidnapped Israelis Raises Tensions on Many Fronts
text: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli teenagers kidnapped from the West Bank have been missing for more than 10 days now, their names — Naftali, Gilad, Eyal — becoming staples of synagogue prayers and cafe chatter across this tiny country. Four Palestinians, one of them 15, have been killed by Israeli troops, their photos hoisted at mass funerals as martyrs in the liberation struggle.

headline: The Frustration Doctrine
text: Americans’ confidence in American leadership is flagging to such a degree that it poses a critical threat to our democracy, particularly as moneyed interests seek to manipulate the malaise and stir policy and politician away from principle and toward profit.

headline: Despite a Hex, Ronaldo Works Magic
text: MANAUS, Brazil — The World Cup arrives every four years, and without fail it brings a good and possibly even true story about a witch doctor.

headline: Conservatives Plan to Use Poll Watchers in Mississippi
text: WASHINGTON — As Senator Thad Cochran, the veteran Republican, fights for his political life in Mississippi by taking the unexpected step of courting black Democrats, conservative organizations working to defeat him are planning to deploy poll watchers to monitor his campaign’s turnout operation in Tuesday’s runoff election.

headline: Yahoo Hires Michael Isikoff as Chief Investigative Correspondent
text: Michael Isikoff, the investigative reporter who recently left NBC News, is joining Yahoo News as its chief investigative correspondent. He will start in August.

headline: The Big Green Test
text: On Sunday Henry Paulson, the former Treasury secretary and a lifelong Republican, had an Op-Ed article about climate policy in The New York Times. In the article, he declared that man-made climate change is “the challenge of our time,” and called for a national tax on carbon emissions to encourage conservation and the adoption of green technologies. Considering the prevalence of climate denial within today’s G.O.P., and the absolute opposition to any kind of tax increase, this was a brave stand to take.

headline: Iraq’s Military Seen as Unlikely to Turn the Tide
text: BAGHDAD — As Iraqi Army forces try to rally on the outskirts of Baghdad after two weeks of retreat, it has become increasingly clear to Western officials that the army will continue to suffer losses in its fight with Sunni militants and will not soon retake the ground it has ceded.

headline: Fouad Ajami, Commentator and Expert in Arab History, Dies at 68
text: Fouad Ajami, an academic, author and broadcast commentator on Middle East affairs who helped rally support for the United States invasion of Iraq in 2003 — partly by personally advising top policy makers — died on Sunday. He was 68.

headline: The Real Drama at the Met
text: Over its 131 years, the Metropolitan Opera has drawn virtually all the major stars onto its massive stage — from the days of Enrico Caruso to the time of Anna Netrebko. The company presents more than 20 operas each season, drawing about 800,000 people to more than 200 performances. Its live broadcasts in movie theaters around the world give 2.5 million people a chance to enjoy opera up close and in real time.

headline: Diapers.com Co-Founder Launches Online Publication
text: Vinit Bharara made his fortune selling Pampers and Huggies. Now he wants to capitalize on a business fast becoming as commodified as diapers: digital content.

headline: Japan’s Historical Blinders
text: At a time when constructive relations between Japan and South Korea are more important than ever to Asian security, the two countries, allies of the United States, have been unable to put a difficult history behind them. Unfortunately, that seems unlikely to change soon given the release on Friday of a Japanese report on World War II sex slaves.

headline: Vanity Fair’s Fall Conference Taps Power of the Rolodex
text: Vanity Fair magazine will host a conference in San Francisco this fall, becoming the latest publication to enter the potentially lucrative — and increasingly crowded — field of live events.

headline: The Hidden Cost of Trading Stocks
text: There’s no escaping the conclusion that the stock market is not a level playing field where all investors, large and small, have an equal shot at a fair deal.

headline: Facing Pressure From Tenant Groups, Board Is Set to Vote on Rent Freeze
text: The board that decides how much landlords can raise rents for New York City’s nearly 1 million regulated apartments is scheduled to vote on Monday whether to forgo increases for the first time in history.

headline: British Prime Minister to Undertake a Calculated Risk in Bucking Brussels
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, recently described by a former adviser to his Conservative Party as “a sphinx without a riddle,” has set himself up for a highly public failure this week, as other European leaders look set to ignore his strident opposition and select an old Brussels hand, Jean-Claude Juncker, as the next head of the powerful European Commission.

headline: Relief Over U.S. Exit From Iraq Fades as Reality Overtakes Hope
text: WASHINGTON — Standing in Al Faw palace in Baghdad, surrounded by an artificial lake and the ragged remnants of eight years of war, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. felt a surge of emotion on that day in December 2011.

headline: Nickelodeon Opens a Talent Search Even Wider
text: Two years ago, Viacom’s Nickelodeon announced an annual competition as it battled a ratings drop. Rookie animators could vie for the chance to create an 11-minute cartoon. With any luck, Nickelodeon would find fresh creativity.

text: Should those with beachfront homes have to open their land to the public?

headline: Judge Upholds Policy Barring Unvaccinated Students During Illnesses
text: In a case weighing the government’s ability to require vaccination against the individual right to refuse it, a federal judge has upheld a New York City policy that bars unimmunized children from public school when another student has a vaccine-preventable disease.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 22, 2014
Vice Has Many Media Giants Salivating, but Its Terms Will Be Rich
text: A black S.U.V. recently rolled through the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and stopped in front of the converted warehouse that is the global headquarters of Vice Media. Out of the vehicle stepped the media mogul Rupert Murdoch.

headline: A Novel Lays Bare Media Ills
text: At first glance, “The Last Magazine: A Novel” by Michael Hastings would appear to lack relevance in the current media age. A fictional account of life inside a failed magazine — Newsweek — in a dying industry — print — written by a now-dead journalist, the book seems very much beside the point. And the march of history aside, does the world need another roman à clef from inside the world of Manhattan media, whose bottomless interest in itself is not generally shared by the public?

headline: Second Teenager Pulled From the Bronx River Dies
text: The second of two 13-year-old cousins pulled from the Bronx River by emergency workers died Sunday, a pastor who has been acting as a family spokesman said.

headline: The Iraq Crisis is Worse Than it Seems for the Kurds
text: It seems that some who support the Kurdish cause see an opportunity in the mayhem in Iraq. Commentators from abroad see the Iraqi army’s meltdown and retreat from the Sunni Arab heartland north of Baghdad as a sign that things might finally fall into place for the Kurds. Here in Erbil, people were positively elated when the Kurdish armed forces, called pesh merga (meaning “those who face death”), consolidated their grip on oil-rich Kirkuk, after the Iraqi army gave up on the region this week.

headline: Candidate Says Recordings Show Afghan Election Was Rigged
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the candidates in Afghanistan’s disputed presidential election released on Sunday what his campaign said were recordings of phone calls in which a top election official, other election officials and aides of a rival candidate speak about stuffing ballot boxes and rigging the vote.

headline: G.M. Prepares to Count Cost of Suffering
text: Mykia Jordan has no memory of the car accident that put her in a coma for three weeks, left a large scar across her jaw and caused the limp that forces her to walk with a cane at 23.

headline: Gerry Conlon, 60, Imprisoned in I.R.A. Attack and Freed After 15 Years, Dies
text: Gerry Conlon, who spent a quarter of his life in prison for Irish Republican Army bombings in which he was later found to have had no involvement — and whose case inspired an Oscar-nominated film — died on Saturday at his home in Belfast, Northern Ireland. He was 60.

headline: An Employee Dies, and the Company Collects the Insurance
text: Employees at The Orange County Register received an unsettling email from corporate headquarters this year. The owner of the newspaper, Freedom Communications, was writing to request workers’ consent to take out life insurance policies on them.

headline: Popular Demand
text: The popularity and rank of mobile games changes daily, as developers battle for the interest and relative loose change of people buying apps for their smartphones and tablets.

headline: As Primary Nears, Candidates Retreat to Their Campaign Comfort Zones

Espaillat, spent hours shaking the hands of black, white and Hispanic residents, seeking broad coalitions in a hotly contested election where accusations of racial and ethnic divisiveness have dominated debates.

headline: Reading, Writing and Allegations: Muslim School at Center of Debate

They looked at the loudspeakers, the ablution rooms and the prayer mats in the gym behind the volleyball net. And, according to accounts by school officials and students, the inspectors asked teenage girls in white hijabs:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 23, 2014
text: “I would like to see a settlement. I was out of work. I missed so much of my son’s developmental growth while I was in the hospital. I had to have my face reconstructed. And my leg just hurts.”

headline: China Manufacturing Hits 7-Month High
text: HONG KONG — China’s manufacturing sector rebounded in June, showing signs of growth for the first time this year, according to a purchasing managers’ index released on Monday.

headline: Early Results Arrive on Weight-Loss Pills That Expand in the Stomach
text: It is a tantalizingly simple idea for losing weight: Before meals, swallow a capsule that temporarily swells up in the stomach, making you feel full.

headline: Too Hot to Handle
text: Hot weather kills more Americans than all other natural disasters combined, and the casualties continue to climb despite decades of warnings about how to recognize the signs of heat stress and take prompt corrective action.

headline: Lewis Rallies at U.S. Open but Falls Short of the Title She Covets Most
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — Stacy Lewis rallied Sunday in the final round of the United States Women’s Open with a red-hot four-under-par 66 in a formidable chase, but the eventual champion, Michelle Wie, proved impossible to catch.

headline: World Cup 2014 Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Portugal (2)
text: The United States appeared headed for a golden 3 points and a secured spot in the World Cup’s Round of 16, but that all changed after Portugal scored an equalizer in the final minute to earn a 2-2 draw Sunday.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 10 P.M. (OWN) OPERATION CHANGE Former President Bill Clinton (above, in Zambia), Richard Branson, Elton John, the Dalai Lama, Harry Connick Jr. and other celebrities join Bill and Tani Austin and their son Steven Sawalich of the Starkey Hearing Foundation as they take on projects intended to improve lives in some of the world’s poorest regions. This 10-part documentary series begins in Haiti, where the fashion designer Donna Karan, the actress Maria Bello and the entrepreneur Bill Rancic work with organizations including World Wide Village, We Advance and Urban Zen to help survivors of the 2010 earthquake. (The Starkey Hearing Foundation distributes free hearing aids to people in need.)

headline: Treaty Is Making Land Mines Weapon of Past, Group Says
text: Despite the conflicts in Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan, the armed uprising in Ukraine and turmoil in other hot spots in the Middle East and Africa, one of war’s most insidious weapons — antipersonnel land mines — have been largely outlawed and drastically reduced, a monitoring group said in a report released Monday.

headline: China State Media Calls Hong Kong Vote ‘Mincing Ludicrousness’
text: “However many people take part in Hong Kong’s illegal public vote, there will never be as many as 1.3 billion,” the headline in the state-run newspaper Global Times declared on Monday.

headline: Corrections: June 23, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Kerry Says ISIS Threat Could Hasten Military Action
text: BAGHDAD — Winding up a day of crisis talks with Iraqi leaders, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Monday that the Sunni militants seizing territory in Iraq had become such a threat that the United States might not wait for Iraqi politicians to form a new government before taking military action.

headline: The Multimillion-Dollar Minds of 5 Mathematical Masters
text: Mathematics has turned into an unusually lucrative profession for Maxim Kontsevich. First, Dr. Kontsevich, 49, who works at the Institute of Advanced Scientific Studies outside Paris, won the 2012 Shaw Prize in Mathematical Sciences, an honor accompanied by a $1 million award. Then a couple of months later, he was among nine people who received a new physics prize — and $3 million each — from Yuri Milner, a Russian who dropped out of graduate studies in physics and became a successful investor in Internet companies like Facebook.

headline: Student Crossword | The 1960’s
text: Test your knowledge of the 1960’s by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Soldier Accused of Killing 5 Is Captured in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Army sergeant accused of fleeing his unit on the border with North Korea after killing five fellow soldiers was caught alive with a self-inflicted wound on Monday, ending a manhunt that involved a shootout and shocked the country over the weekend.

headline: British Roadside Assistance Company AA Raises $2.36 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The AA, the British roadside assistance provider, raised 1.39 billion pounds, or about $2.36 billion, in its initial public offering in London on Monday.

headline: Yulin Dog Meat Festival Proceeds Despite Protesters
text: A dog meat festival in southern China went ahead over the weekend even as the local government tried to lower the profile of the controversial event. Animal rights advocates protested dog meat vendors, including one who demanded that protesters meet his price for a live dog or he would strangle it, according to Chinese news reports.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Photo Caper in Poland
text: In July of 2012, two wooden crates arrived in Warsaw. Nestled inside were smaller boxes: Some were labeled “Pulling off Stockings,” or “Legs Spread — Hat in Lap.” Some simply said “M.M.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Funeral Poses Mimic Life
text: In “Rite of the Sitting Dead: Funeral Poses Mimic Life” Campbell Robertson and Frances Robles write about a small but growing trend in the funeral ritual known as the viewing.

headline: Santander to Buy G.E.’s Nordic Banking Business
text: LONDON – The Spanish lender Banco Santander said on Monday that it would pay about 700 million euros for General Electric’s Scandinavian consumer finance business.

headline: Egypt Convicts 3 Journalists; U.S. Is Critical
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry came to Egypt this weekend to renew its “important partnership” with Washington and to offer its new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, assurance of the swift restoration of military aid.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Adam Davidson on a Changing Job Market, Student Debt and Why ‘Boomerang Kids’ Are Here to Stay
text: Adam Davidson, who writes It’s the Economy for the magazine, is the author of the June 22 cover story about young adults who move back in with their parents. Davidson is a founder of NPR’s “Planet Money,” a podcast and blog.

headline: Jailed Woman’s Daughter Also Accused of ‘Stirring Up Trouble’
text: Just one day after a court sentenced her mother, a rights campaigner, to six and a half years in prison, the police told Liao Minyue to surrender her passport because she was “provoking quarrels and stirring up trouble,” Ms. Liao said by telephone, stirring fears she was being targeted next.

headline: Health Minister Questions Stress on Condoms in AIDS Fight
text: NEW DELHI — India’s new health minister, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, has said that he would like to see a change in the way that the government promotes awareness of AIDS and H.I.V., with more emphasis on “promoting the integrity of the sexual relationship between husband and wife,” which he said was “part of our culture.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Fire in the Dark
text: Good Monday morning to you.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches
text: Australia vs. Spain, noon: With both teams already eliminated, this game will be for pride only. Spain’s older stars, like Iker Casillas, Xavi and Xabi Alonso, will be playing a final game after winning two European championships and a World Cup, so take a good last look at tiki-taka. Expect Australia, which has punched above its weight at this tournament, to give another good performance.

headline: France Puts Drag on Euro Zone Growth, Report Shows
text: PARIS — The euro zone economy expanded in June for a 12th straight month, a private sector report indicated on Monday, but the pace of growth slowed and there were signs that the French economy may again be shrinking.

headline: Daily Report: Quirky to Spin Off Wink, Company for Smart-Home Products
text: The offices of Quirky, in a repurposed red brick warehouse in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood, are a bustling hub of modern industrial activity. The start-up fields 4,000 new product ideas a week, picks three winners and then takes over all aspects of production, from making blueprints to marketing the goods through big-box retailers like Home Depot and retail websites, including Amazon, Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Live Stream | Gucci’s Spring 2015 Collection at Milan Men’s Fashion Week
text: The live stream has ended.

headline: Now the Air Bags Are Faulty, Too
text: One of the most critical safety components in cars, the air bag, is rapidly becoming a central concern of automakers and regulators.

headline: Morning Views
text: “There’s no escaping the conclusion that the stock market is not a level playing field where all investors, large and small, have an equal shot at a fair deal,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations recently held a hearing on “maker-taker” pricing in which stock exchanges pay rebates to brokers for sending them buy-and-sell orders. The practice has been around for years, as a growing number of exchanges — there are now 11 public exchanges in the United States — have battled for business. What is new is the compelling evidence that the rebates are corrupting.” Brokers are technically supposed to find the best stock prices for their clients, but new research shows that they are “routinely sending orders to venues that paid the highest rebates.” The board calls on financial regulators to monitor executions, for the good of the American economy and maintaining fair competition: “Securities regulators clearly need to better enforce the best execution requirements on brokers, combined with better disclosure on brokers’ routing decisions and the rebates they earn. If Congress won’t provide more resources for enforcement, rebates need either to be passed along to the customer or eliminated altogether.”

text: Milan

headline: Obama’s Move to Help Students Is Not as Forgiving as It Seems
text: If you’re a student loan-burdened recent college graduate putting the final touches on a note to President Obama, thanking him for his recent executive order on debt repayment, don’t get too excited.

headline: The New Magazine Editor’s Taste in Reading, and Barbecue
text: Last month, Jake Silverstein, former editor of Texas Monthly, took over as the editor of The Times’s Sunday magazine. He told us a bit about what his influences are, what readers can expect with him at the helm and whether New York City’s barbecue compares to Texas’.

headline: Poll Shows No Consensus in U.S. for Helping in Iraq
text: The American public is divided over whether the United States is obliged to deal with the sectarian violence in Iraq and whether the troubles there are increasing the threat of terrorism domestically. The latest New York Times/CBS News poll also found that while many see President Obama’s actions as appropriate, there are large partisan differences.

headline: My Disturbing Experience With Employee Reviews
text: “Get the right people on the bus,” the business pundits like to say.

headline: Bigger Health Companies: Good for Medicare, Maybe Not for Others
text: Although Obamacare’s health insurance expansion has directly provided coverage to only about 4 percent of Americans, changes embedded in the Affordable Care Act could affect many more people, and not always in good ways.

headline: How Mississippi’s Runoff Defies Conventional Wisdom
text: The political class will keenly watch Tuesday’s runoff in Mississippi to see how the Tea Party will follow its ouster of Eric Cantor this month. The conventional wisdom is that turnout will decline compared with the initial primary, and that lower turnout will benefit Chris McDaniel, the state senator who is challenging Senator Thad Cochran for the Republican Senate nomination.

headline: In Our Pages: June 24
text: 1939: France Signs Turkish Treaties

headline: Sequoia and Greylock Lead $40 Million Round for Skyhigh Networks
text: Skyhigh Networks, which makes security software for cloud computing, has raised an additional $40 million from investors, including Greylock Partners and Sequoia Capital. Salesforce, one of the biggest cloud computing companies in Silicon Valley, also participated in the round.

headline: Education Should Be Beyond Belief
text: LONDON — Last year, the council in Birmingham, Britain’s second largest city, received an anonymous document that supposedly advised militant Muslims on how to take over the governing bodies of state-run schools and impose Islamist values. Since the so-called Trojan Horse plot was reported in March, it has become the center of a national controversy.

headline: Wisconsin Energy to Buy Integrys for $5.7 Billion
text: The Wisconsin Energy Corporation agreed on Monday to buy the Integrys Energy Group for about $5.7 billion in stock and cash, uniting two big Midwestern utilities.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Put It In the Blog!
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Emporio Armani: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Morning Agenda: Path Clear for G.E.’s Alstom Deal
text: The last big obstacle to General Electric’s $13.5 billion acquisition of Alstom’s energy assets fell on Sunday, when the French government agreed to buy a stake in the French industrial conglomerate from the billionaire Bouygues family, David Jolly writes in DealBook. Alstom’s board said on Saturday that it had unanimously backed G.E.’s offer, contingent on the French state buying Alstom shares. On Friday, France’s economy minister, Arnaud Montebourg, blessed G.E.’s bid over a rival offer from Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries.

headline: Gucci: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Bill de Blasio and the Art of Political Image at … the Mermaid Parade
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his family had kind of an interesting fashion moment over the weekend. In case you missed it, I offer the above photo of Mr. de Blasio in pirate kit; his wife, Chirlane McCray, in full Ariel getup and their two children both body-painted blue — all for the annual Coney Island Mermaid Parade. In fact, Dante and Chiara were king and queen of the parade, a kitsch classic that takes place on the first official day of summer (i.e. Saturday).

headline: Director of National Gallery in London Announces Intention to Retire
text: LONDON — Nicholas Penny, the director of the National Gallery in London since 2008, announced on Monday that he intended to retire. Mr. Penny, who turns 65 in December, said in a statement that he would stay in the job until a replacement was found.

headline: It’s Time to Opt Out of Impulse Buying
text: “It’s instant gratification that just looks like a phone.”

headline: Sentencing of Journalists in Egypt Draws Condemnation
text: LONDON — In a chorus of condemnation, rights groups and Western governments on Monday criticized jail terms imposed by an Egyptian court on three journalists from Al Jazeera’s English-language service, while the network itself said the punishment defied “logic, sense, and any semblance of justice.”

headline: Falcone’s Harbinger Group Offers to Buy Central Garden and Pet
text: The Harbinger Group, the publicly traded holding company run by the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone, has offered to buy the Central Garden and Pet Company for $10 a share.

text: Updated, 6:51 p.m. |

headline: Hedge Fund and ValueVision Shopping Network Settle Differences
text: After a seven-month battle, the activist hedge fund Clinton Group and the Internet and shopping network ValueVision Media have settled their differences.

headline: Key Supreme Court Decisions in 2014
text: How the justices have decided major cases this term and the implications of their decisions.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Kerry Visits Iraq
text: Good Monday morning from Washington.

headline: India Promoting Lower-Cost Military Exports
text: HONG KONG — India’s ambitions to increase its domestic military industry may have grown a little more expansive.

headline: Shire Makes Its Case Against a Deal With AbbVie
text: LONDON – The pharmaceutical company Shire  made an impassioned defense on Monday for why it should remain an independent company as the industry continues to consolidate.

headline: 32 Terrorist Groups Smashed in Xinjiang, China Says
text: BEIJING — Officials in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang said Monday that an antiterrorism crackdown that began in late May had resulted in the smashing of 32 terrorist groups and the sentencing of 315 people to prison terms, death row or other punishment, according to state news reports.

headline: Former Top Official in China to Face Graft Trial
text: HONG KONG — The former head of the National Energy Administration of China, whose downfall followed a public denunciation from an investigative journalist, will face trial on charges of taking huge bribes, prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Chile, 2-0, to Win Group B
text: The Netherlands won Group B with a 2-0 victory over Chile, and both teams will move onto the Round of 16.

headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Beats Cameroon, 4-1, Wins Group A
text: Neymar scored a pair of goals to send Brazil to a 4-1 victory over Cameroon and to the Round of 16 as the winner of Group A.

headline: World Cup 2014: Spain Defeats Australia, 3-0
text: Spain makes its early exit from the 2014 World Cup with three beautiful goals in its last match, a 3-0 defeat of Australia.

headline: World Cup 2014: Mexico Defeats Croatia, 3-1, to Advance From Group A
text: Mexico wore down Croatia, scored three goals in a 10-minute span and moved on to the Round of 16 with a 3-1 victory.

headline: Malaysian Jet Was in Controlled Flight After Contact Was Lost, Officials Suspect
text: CANBERRA, Australia — Investigators have concluded that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which veered off course and disappeared on March 8, was probably not seriously damaged in the air and remained in controlled flight for hours after contact with it was lost, until it ran out of fuel over the southern Indian Ocean.

headline: British Lessons on Inflation Hysteria
text: Tim Duy tells us that “inflation hysteria is gripping Wall Street“; that matches my own observations. A modest uptick in core inflation has all the usual suspects declaring that the Fed will/must tighten now now now. Meanwhile, Janet Yellen is looking at wages, which are going nowhere, and sitting tight.

headline: Which Supreme Court Justices Vote Together Most and Least Often
text: Tables and charts showing how frequently Supreme Court Justices agree with one another.

headline: Report Assails Parks Dept. Over Slowness in Finishing Projects
text: David G. Greenfield, a city councilman from Brooklyn, is passionate about parks, having allocated $12.9 million to green spaces in his district since taking office in 2010. “Parks are a great equalizer,” he said. “Whether you’re rich, poor, young, old, you use parks. There really is no better expenditure of government funds than parks.”

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: AdColony, Los Angeles, hired four employees. They are Sally Medina, director for sales, based in Detroit; Brian Mulcahy, director for brand sales, based in the New York office; David Pokress, senior vice president for monetization and publisher relations, in Los Angeles; and Megan Sullivan, vice president for client relations, also in Los Angeles.

headline: Etro: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Iraqi Insurgents Secure Control of Border Posts
text: ERBIL, Iraq — The Sunni militant extremists who have seized a broad area of Iraq extended their control on Monday to the country’s entire western frontier, having secured nearly all official border crossings with Syria and the only one with Jordan, giving them the semblance of the new independent state that they say they intend to create in the region.

headline: Steve Rossi, Singer Who Found Fame in Comedy Duo, Dies at 82
text: Steve Rossi, a suave crooner who rose to fame as the straight man to Marty Allen in one of the most successful comedy teams of the 1960s, died on Sunday at a hospice near his home in Las Vegas. He was 82.

headline: Justices Uphold Emission Limits on Big Industry
text: WASHINGTON — In a big win for environmentalists, the Supreme Court on Monday effectively endorsed the Obama administration’s efforts to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from sources like power plants, even as it criticized what it called the administration’s overreaching.

headline: May I Mash Your Peas and Adjust Your Bib, Sir?
text: Forget packing those small jars. The rise of family travel meets the trend of homemade baby food at a number of resorts, many of them in foreign destinations where parents may worry about food safety.

headline: Inquiry Finds No Political Pacing of Sandusky Case
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania may have taken longer than he should have to investigate claims of sexual abuse by the former Penn State football assistant Jerry Sandusky, but there was no evidence that he tried to slow the case for political purposes as he ran for the state’s highest office, according to a report released Monday.

headline: Preservation Trust Lists Palisades, Wright Home and Remnant of the Slave Trade as Endangered
text: The Palisades in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., whose vista is threatened by a proposed office tower; the only private home designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in Florida; and a Virginia slave trading center that includes remnants of the jail that held Solomon Northup — of “12 Years a Slave” – are among the country’s most endangered historic places, according to the National Trust for Historic Preservation’s 2014 list, which was released Monday.

headline: Last of Syria’s Known Chemical Arms Are Shipped Abroad for Destruction
text: GENEVA — After months of delay, Syria exported the last of its known supplies of chemical weapons components on Monday for destruction overseas, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons announced, calling it a major achievement in a country engulfed by war.

headline: Netherlands vs. Chile: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: These two sides have 13 goals between them, and each has many attacking threats, notably Arjen Robben, and Memphis Depay for the Netherlands, and Arturo Vidal, Eduardo Vargas and Alexis Sanchez for Chile.

headline: A Hospital as a Permanent Home, an Army of Ghostly Spikes and the Fate of “Cool Kids”
text: Inside long-term acute care hospitals, where critically ill patients may remain indefinitely; a British flood reveals archaeological treasures; scientists figure out what happened to the boundary-pushing “pseudomature” students of middle school.

headline: Justice Department Memo Approving Targeted Killing of Anwar Al-Awlaki
text: Following Freedom of Information Act lawsuits, the Obama administration released a 2010 Justice Department memo signing off on killing Anwar Al-Awlaki, an American citizen, without a trial.

headline: Australia vs. Spain: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: This game is likely to be the valedictory for many of Spain’s older stars, who have won two European championships and a World Cup. Expect Australia, which has punched above its weight at this tournament, to give a good account of itself again.

headline: Mississippi Senate Rivals Appeal to Veterans Before G.O.P. Runoff Vote
text: JACKSON, Miss. — The Republican Senate candidates Thad Cochran and Chris McDaniel on Monday continued to make their case to Mississippi voters as part of their closing arguments before Tuesday’s runoff election.

headline: Introducing the British Singer-Songwriter Laurel, an Old Pro at 20
text: Sporting a thrifted plaid shift dress, matching headband, casual-chic white Birkenstocks and a white coat, Laurel Arnell-Cullen blends right into the crowd at a cafe just south of Central Park. A bystander would never guess it was the British songwriter’s first time in the city — let alone that she’s 20 years old.

headline: Annie Missing? No Worries, Dick Tracy Is on the Case
text: The search for Little Orphan Annie is on. Readers were left with a cliffhanger when the “Annie” newspaper strip, distributed by Tribune Media Services, ended in June 2010 with the eternal youngster left missing in Guatemala. Four years later Daddy Warbucks has got his act together and found the best man for the job of finding his ward: Dick Tracy.

headline: Investigator Issues Sharp Criticism of V.A. Response to Allegations About Care
text: In a blistering letter sent to President Obama on Monday, the head of the agency that investigates whistle-blower complaints in the federal government criticized the Department of Veterans Affairs for not digging deeper into widespread allegations made by its own employees of poor or severely delayed patient care for veterans.

headline: Anger and Dismay Online as Egypt Sentences Journalists
text: Updated, 1:03 p.m. | Rights activists, bloggers and journalists in Egypt responded with dismay on Monday after an Egyptian court sentenced three journalists to long prison terms despite a lack of evidence that the men, who worked for Al Jazeera English, had done anything but report on the unrest in the country last summer after the military deposed the elected president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Drawing Lots at World Cup? There Must Be a Better Way
text: The drawing of lots.

headline: Hotel Brand Hopes ‘Unlocked’ Theme Will Unlock Room Doors
text: Almost seven years ago, the Le Méridien hotel chain began efforts to change its image from an undistinguished choice for business travelers to a home away from home for the creative classes. Now, another initiative is on tap in an effort to accelerate that makeover.

headline: Botox Maker Allergan and Valeant, in Takeover Battle, Trade Competing Claims
text: Allergan told its shareholders on Monday not to hand over any stock to Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which last week offered to exchange $72 in cash and 0.83 of a Valeant share for each unit of Allergan stock.

headline: When Should We Be Sorry?
text: “Why are women always apologizing?” This question opens a recent ad for Pantene shampoo, which has sparked a larger debate about gender and politeness: Should women quit saying sorry? Or should we all be more alert to the complexities of apology politics?

headline: Court Releases Large Parts of Memo Approving Killing of American in Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — Lifting a veil of official secrecy from President Obama’s decision to authorize the killing of an American citizen without a trial, a federal appeals court on Monday publicly released large portions of a Justice Department memo that deemed it lawful to target Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born Muslim cleric accused of becoming a terrorist.

headline: House Resists S.E.C.’s Insider Trading Inquiry
text: Members of Congress certainly like to talk the talk, but when it comes to insider trading there seems to be little interest in walking the walk by cooperating with an investigation into a possible leak of confidential information that allowed for lucrative trading.

headline: Ecology in the Age of Us – Double-Decker River Invaders
text: The topsy-turvy nature of “nature” in the age of man (a.k.a. the Anthropocene), is evident all around us.

headline: The Apple Conundrum
text: This week’s challenge was suggested by Greg Ross of Futility Closet, the well-read idler’s miscellany of compendious amusements. The puzzle is one of Mr. Ross’s favorites. I asked him where he happened to find it, and he responded by email:

headline: Claim of Fraud in Afghan Vote Leads Official to Step Down
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s election crisis has twisted through each of the past 10 days, as the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah has wielded boycott and brinkmanship in his quest to expose what he calls industrial-scale fraud against him.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Top Disruptors
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Second Circuit Grants DOJ Request for Additional Redactions of Awlaki Memo
text: The Second Circuit granted the Justice Department’s request to make additional redactions to the Office of Legal Counsel memo signing off on the killing of Anwar Al-Awlaki.

headline: Cleaner Air Linked to Fewer Deaths
text: Air quality has improved significantly in the past 20 years because of federal and state laws and regulations, and researchers in North Carolina have found an associated decline in rates of death from respiratory disease.

headline: Killer Plot
text: During a cocktail party in Robert Galbraith’s (a.k.a. J. K. Rowling’s) endlessly entertaining detective novel “The Silkworm,” the publisher Daniel Chard gives a toast in which he observes that “publishing is currently undergoing a period of rapid changes and fresh challenges, but one thing remains as true today as it was a century ago: Content is king.”

headline: Opening Ceremony Turns to Manga Comic Artist for Gay Pride Week
text: Leave it to the people who own Opening Ceremony to choose bara, the muscle-bound, refrigerator-sized lugs featured in the Japanese cartoon genre known as manga, as the poster boys for New York’s Gay Pride Week. Their store windows facing Howard Street in SoHo will be filled with photorealistic images created by the manga artist known as Jiraiya, grafted onto a collection of casual wear in Kool-Aid colors.

headline: Egypt Sentences Three Journalists
text: An Egyptian court gave two Al Jazeera English journalists seven-year terms and a third a 10-year term after convicting them of conspiring to broadcast false reports of civil strife.

headline: What You Missed From Milan Men’s Fashion Week in 140 Characters
text: Catch up on shows like Prada, Gucci and Marnie from the weekend at Milan Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: Bill Clinton Adds Voice to Wife’s Support of Gay Rights
text: Former President Bill Clinton, in a video message to be broadcast this week, says he was “honored and grateful to be among the voices urging” the overturning of the Defense of Marriage Act, the measure he signed into law in 1996 that barred federal recognition of same-sex marriages.

headline: Knicks’ Raymond Felton Avoids Jail in Gun Possession Case
text: Raymond Felton has reached a plea bargain with prosecutors that allows him to avoid jail, agreeing to plead guilty to a felony gun possession charge in return for a $5,000 fine and 500 hours of community service, his lawyer, Jim Walden, said.

headline: Monday Quandary: When a Child’s First Friends Fade Away
text: This post kicks off a new Motherlode feature: the weekly quandary. We’ll pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread, or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than just that one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: Image of the Day: June 23
text: A widow attending an event in New Delhi to mark International Widows Day.

headline: Stephens Loses Match, and Could Lose Ground to Other U.S. Phenoms
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The pity of it all for Sloane Stephens is that for one seemingly momentum-changing game, she played like a fierce and resolute survivor. Dangling on the edge of elimination, she saved five match points against Maria Kirilenko to force a second-set tiebreaker, where she proceeded to hold double set point.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Rosberg Wins Another Mercedes Duel
text: Nico Rosberg scored his third victory of the year, winning the Austrian Grand Prix on Sunday and holding off his teammate, Lewis Hamilton.

headline: Spicy Quinoa Salad With Broccoli, Cilantro and Lime
text: I love the versatility of quinoa. It can be the building-block ingredient for a salad, as it is in this main-dish salad, or it can be added to salads in smaller amounts, almost as a garnish. Its grassy flavor marries well with cilantro, itself an herb with a grassy, though more pungent, taste. I added sieved hard-boiled eggs for protein – though you could leave them out if you want to make a vegan version of this dish, and toasted pumpkin seeds for crunch.

headline: Long Unarmed, 2 Generals Will Be Reunited With Their Swords
text: The pen might be mightier than the sword for a politician or a journalist, but, except for when it ends a war, not for a general — even for two solitary Civil War sentinels who have been left unarmed in New York City parks for decades.

headline: Chickpea, Quinoa and Celery Salad With Middle Eastern Flavors
text: It’s the sumac (available in Middle Eastern markets) and the herbs – dill, mint, chives – that give this salad its Middle Eastern accents. I love the texture and flavor of the chickpeas, which make for a substantial and comforting dish. It’s all you need for lunch and makes a delicious light supper. I love abundant, thinly sliced celery in just about any lemony salad; you will appreciate it for its texture as well as its flavor.  Of course, you can use canned chickpeas, but if you have the time, try cooking some dried chickpeas to see how good they taste.

headline: Jazz-and-Constitution Diet Can Keep a Mind Sharp
text: Early in “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step,” a documentary about the writer, critic and record producer Nat Hentoff that opens on Wednesday, Mr. Hentoff declares that “the Constitution and jazz are my main reasons for being.” That may seem an odd pairing to anyone unfamiliar with the man or his work, but Mr. Hentoff has nurtured those twin passions since the 1940s.

headline: Red Quinoa Salad With Walnuts, Asparagus and Dukkah
text: I had initially envisioned a salad in which the asparagus was cut into short lengths and tossed with the quinoa. But the colorful asparagus got lost in the quinoa, and since I love the look of the bright green asparagus against the red grain (O.K., “pseudograin”), I remade this and  garnished it with the steamed asparagus. The quinoa, tossed with chives, parsley, walnuts and a lemony vinaigrette, is sprinkled with dukkah before serving, a surprising touch.

headline: New Hurdle in Investors’ Class Actions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday made it harder for investors to band together to pursue claims that they were misled when they bought or sold securities. But the justices did not accept a broader challenge, one that could have put an end to most class actions for securities fraud.

headline: Sketching Superman’s Power
text: The illustrator John Romita Jr., a decades-long veteran of Marvel Comics, is now making his DC Comics debut. His first assignment: Drawing Superman.

headline: Unesco Panel Taps Incan Road, Other Sites, as Worthy of Protection
text: At its annual meeting, the World Heritage Committee under the United Nations has so far designated 29 new sites as being natural or cultural wonders worthy of special protection, including the Qhapaq Ñan, or the Andean road system of the Incas.

headline: In Japan, Hundreds of Shareholder Meetings on Same Day
text: Investors who own shares in Japanese corporations might want to clear their calendars next Friday.

headline: A Candidate for Governor Has Both Parties on Alert
text: DENVER — Tom Tancredo, the firebrand former congressman, Harley-Davidson biker and perennial headache for Colorado’s Republican leaders, was taking fire from all sides last week in the final days of his primary campaign for governor. His rivals were slamming him on the airwaves. Moderate Republicans were warning that Mr. Tancredo’s name on the ballot could doom their chances in crucial races across this swing state.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week Street Style
text: Looks from Milan Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: ‘We’re actually a unique race of people. And if you go down about the third definition, that’s a people that are bound together that have a common sense of unity, a common sense of history, a common language.’
text: TK

headline: Wie’s Win Advances Surge by American Women
text: PINEHURST, N.C. — The men’s and women’s United States Opens, held in consecutive weeks at Pinehurst No. 2, could not have produced a more fitting finale. After Martin Kaymer won the men’s title June 15, the last woman standing Sunday was Michelle Wie, the only player in the field to have competed in multiple professional men’s events.

headline: Missoni’s Summer Surf Safari
text: MILAN — Mamma mia, cowabunga. Angela Missoni is in the grips of surf mania. Following the surfer stylings of her fall Missoni collection, the designer continued the theme for spring. ‘‘We started in winter, why not follow him in summer?’’ she asked.

headline: Pro-Russian Rebels in Ukraine Match Government Cease-Fire
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian separatists declared a cease-fire Monday in a surprise move that they said they hoped would lead to a settlement of the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Stanley Marsh, Cadillac Rancher, Dies at 76, Shadowed by Charges
text: Stanley Marsh, the proudly eccentric and locally prominent millionaire who was best known for commissioning the public art project known as the Cadillac Ranch outside his hometown, the Texas Panhandle city of Amarillo, but whose reputation was badly tarnished by accusations that he had sexually abused teenage boys, died on June 17 in Amarillo. He was 76.

headline: Homer Happiness Lives Only in Memory
text: OMAHA — At the College World Series, where home runs are nearing extinction, the soft clink of baseballs bunted off metal bats is again the predominant sound. And that sound is wearing on coaches, players, fans and N.C.A.A. officials.

headline: When Advertising on Facebook Can Be a Waste of Money
text: In January, we published an interview with a social media marketer, Jeff Gibbard, asking him to assess Facebook’s revamped ad platform. While Mr. Gibbard questioned the value of advertising on Facebook, a reader went even further, commenting: “Until Facebook allows independent third-party auditing of its ads and takes the necessary technical procedures to block ‘ad bots,’ the Facebook platform is valueless and we are staying away from it.”

headline: Official on Korean Soldier Who Killed 5
text: Kim Min-Seok, the South Korean defense ministry spokesman, said the armed soldier attempted suicide as his family pleaded with him to surrender after he killed five colleagues.

headline: Poland’s Prime Minister Says He Won’t Dismiss Officials Caught on Leaked Tapes
text: WARSAW — Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland said Monday that he would not dismiss any of the ministers whose bluntly political and occasionally profane conversations were caught on tape in the back rooms of expensive Warsaw restaurants, unless they are caught engaging in illegal behavior.

headline: American Indians in Confederate Territory
text: On the morning of June 18, 1864, Pvt. Payson Wolf trudged through the streets of Petersburg, Va., with other battered and bloodied Union prisoners of war. The captives were herded into an old tobacco barn with hundreds of other bluecoats to await their fate in the hands of Confederate military authorities.

headline: Finding Old Posts on the Facebook Timeline
text: Q. I was scrolling back through my Facebook Timeline in my web browser and noticed some of my previous posts and photos weren’t there. How do I get them all back?

headline: Oracle’s Deal Won’t Do Much for Its Cloud Computing Efforts
text: Oracle’s $5.3 billion deal for Micros Systems provides an uncertain forecast for shareholders in the database giant. Even if it’s the start of a new deal binge by Oracle’s chief, Lawrence J. Ellison, it’s not at a crazy valuation. But Mircos, a longtime partner, is more of an add-on than a way to supercharge Oracle’s effort in cloud computing.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Canali Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: A Mystery Character in the Story
text: As the immortal Sherlock Holmes remarks to Dr. Watson in “A Scandal in Bohemia,” it is a mistake to theorize from incomplete data: “Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts.” This wise caution applies equally to world-class scientists and ambitious writers hoping to trim a complicated historical era to fit the standard-issue best-seller mold.

headline: Heartbroken, but Hardly Hopeless
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Forget about that last goal. Pretend it never happened, as if that soccer ball never ricocheted off the head of a perfectly positioned Portuguese player and into the United States’ net. Do not dwell on those last 30 seconds of that game on Sunday night in the Amazon that stomped on the throat of an otherwise sublime night.

headline: Scaring Away Black Voters in Mississippi
text: Several right-wing groups have banded together to form a “voter integrity project’ in response to the news that Republican Senator Thad Cochran is courting black Democratic voters in his runoff with the Tea partier Chris McDaniel.

headline: Kerry on Iraq Crisis
text: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference in Baghdad about the future of Iraq, imploring its leaders to unite against ISIS.

headline: How to Make Perfect Burgers Indoors
text: Sam Sifton shows you how to make juicy hamburgers by cooking in rendered fat in a cast-iron pan.

headline: Deconstructing the Perfect Burger
text: How to make a great hamburger is a question that has bedeviled the nation for generations, for as long as Americans have had griddles and broilers, for as long as summertime shorts-wearing cooks have gone into the yard to grill.

headline: Brazil vs. Cameroon: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: To get first place in the group, Brazil must win, preferably by a few goals to be absolutely certain.

headline: Mosquito Bait
text: Q. Is there anything people can eat or drink to cut the odds of mosquito bites?

headline: Criticism for Detroit Article With No Black Presence
text: Since Monica Drake became The Times’s travel editor about a year ago, she has tried to broaden and diversify the section’s offerings.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 17-23, 2014
text: How well did you follow the news this week?

headline: Mexico vs. Croatia: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Mexico needs a win or draw to be sure to advance. Croatia must win.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: A new painkiller is about to hit the market that the F.D.A. approved despite the recommendations of an agency panel, and doctors are afraid it will be the latest gateway to doctor-sanctioned opioid abuse.

headline: Gallery | An Exhibit of Instagram Photos of Kimye with LiLo, Lorde, Damien Hirst and More
text: In this new era, in which a picture is worth a thousand likes (or in the case of Kim Kardashian and Kanye West’s wedding photo, more than two million), it’s easier than ever to peer into the lives of others, even those in the public realm. Now, Liberatum, the self-described “cultural diplomacy organization,” has invited a few big names from the world of New York nightlife to contribute exclusive personal snaps to a monthlong exhibition that opens this Thursday at the recently renovated salon at the W New York, the Living Room. Titled “Tagged,” the show “sets out to explore the new cultural etiquettes that technology has put on the New York scene,” according to Liberatum founder Pablo Ganguli. “With some venues banning photos and others encouraging it, people are still treading the water lightly to determine what is and isn’t appropriate when it comes to mixing social life, photography and technology.”

headline: A High-Living Idealist, Running Guns in 1938
text: The title of Alan Furst’s latest World War II novel, “Midnight in Europe,” could apply to any of them. But don’t be fooled by its generic sound: Mr. Furst, who has by now approached that era and the dread preceding it from so many different cultural and geographical perspectives, remains at the top of his game. This is another fine addition to his elegant, gripping, interwoven set of novels that will someday form a kaleidoscopic map of European powers forced into desperate alliances as they fight for their lives.

headline: Examining a Scandal Within a Scandal About Emails at the I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John Koskinen, testified before the House Oversight Committee on Monday to answer questions about how two years’ worth of emails sent and received by Lois Lerner, the former official at the center of a growing I.R.S. scandal, could have been destroyed, and why the agency waited until just recently to tell Congress.

headline: In G.E.’s Deal for Alstom, French Interventionism Wins Out
text: PARIS — After nearly two months of battle, both the French government and General Electric can finally declare victory.

headline: Review of Handling of Sandusky Case
text: The Pennsylvania special deputy attorney general, H. Geoffrey Moulton Jr., said a review of the handling of the Jerry Sandusky sex abuse case found no evidence that politics had affected the inquiry.

headline: Preacher Challenges Pakistani Leaders
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — All the makings of a grand entrance were in place when the preacher and political dramatist Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri boarded an Emirates jet bound for Islamabad: Thousands of his followers awaited his return on Monday, ready to reignite a protest movement that riveted Pakistan for weeks last year.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Gucci Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Bigger Than Baseball: 25 Million Watch U.S.-Portugal World Cup Match
text: With an audience of 25 million viewers for Sunday’s game between the United States and Portugal, the World Cup is moving into elite territory as a sports property on American television. Ratings for the game were the highest for any soccer game telecast in America and reached more viewers than events like the N.B.A. finals or the World Series.

headline: Cool at 13, Adrift at 23
text: At 13, they were viewed by classmates with envy, admiration and not a little awe. The girls wore makeup, had boyfriends and went to parties held by older students. The boys boasted about sneaking beers on a Saturday night and swiping condoms from the local convenience store.

headline: Dov Charney, American Apparel Founder, Fights to Get His Job Back
text: Dov Charney, the founder and longtime chief executive of American Apparel who was ousted last week by the company’s board, filed a formal notice on Monday indicating that he did not plan to leave quietly.

headline: Stunning New Video View of Swimming Polar Bears
text: Lest you wonder why federal wildlife conservation agencies include polar bears under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, have a look at this video.

headline: Box Office Boom For ‘All the Way’ as Closing Nears
text: “All the Way,” the Broadway drama about President Lyndon Baines Johnson that won Tony Awards this month for best play and best actor for its star, Bryan Cranston, set an all-time record last week for gross ticket sales by a new play.

headline: Barack Obama in 2001

headline: When Ruby Dee met Ossie Davis
text: In an interview from 2002, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee reflect on how they first met acting in a play together.

headline: Maya Angelou’s Earliest Memory
text: In an interview from 2010, Maya Angelou describes her earliest childhood memory and how her older brother, Bailey, was her greatest hero.

headline: Library of Congress to Display Interviews With Blacks, Noted and Unsung
text: Maya Angelou’s earliest childhood memory took place on a train when she was 3 years old. When her brother, Bailey, whom she described as “my black kingdom come,” went to the bathroom, Ms. Angelou thought he had been taken away by a porter. “It scared me to death,” she recounted in a video interview recorded in 2010. “I wasn’t afraid that my mother wouldn’t come back or my father or anyone else. It was always Bailey.”

headline: JetBlue Adds Flat-Bed Seats
text: LOS ANGELES — For the well-heeled traveler flying between New York and Los Angeles, for whom onboard Wi-Fi, roomy leather seats, a Zagat-approved meal and a piping hot washcloth are not enough, airlines have an announcement.

headline: Annoyed With Flying? Don’t Get Mad, Get Advice
text: THE list of things that annoy me when traveling is lengthy.

text: Photos from Egypt, Iraq, Afghanistan and India.

headline: Challenged to Tetris by Pint-Size Rivals, and Sparing None
text: I’M the guy you want to meet at the airport, since I get all kinds of free drink coupons. I get so many of these things I just give them to fellow passengers. I’m a friendly person, but that’s about all I do to connect with other fliers.

headline: U.S. Tie Leaves Emotions Unsettled
text: MANAUS, Brazil — Andy Smith stood among a throng of American fans Sunday night, checking the stopwatch on his smartphone, thinking surely this game would end in ecstatic victory.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Immigration
text: This will hopefully be the week in which I settle all family business — by which I mean that I intend to write the responses to liberal critics of “reform conservatism” than I’ve been promising since long before World Cup season. Having discussed immigration policy in yesterday’s column, I’ll start with that issue, and with William Galston’s Wall Street Journal essay from late last month, which offered praise for the recent reformocon manifesto “Room to Grow” but also suggested that reform conservatives were too often coloring “within the lines” — and in particular, that “if immigration is to today’s Republicans as welfare was to the Democrats of the early 1990s, someone will have to go further.”

headline: Church Rethinks Development Plan; Legal Fight Ensues
text: Seven stained-glass windows more than a story high surround the apse of St. Michael’s Episcopal Church at the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street in Manhattan. The panels, created a century ago by Louis Comfort Tiffany, depict in vivid hues the celestial triumph of the archangel for whom the 206-year-old church is named.

headline: Mormons Expel Founder of Group Seeking Priesthood for Women
text: Kate Kelly, who unsettled the Mormon Church by founding a movement to advocate opening the male-only priesthood to women, was excommunicated by her bishop and his two counselors in Virginia on Monday.

headline: I Had Alice in Wonderland Syndrome
text: A few months ago, my 10-year-old daughter, Paulina, was suffering from a bad headache right before bedtime. She went to lie down and I sat beside her, stroking her head. After a few minutes, she looked up at me and said, “Everything in the room looks really small.”

text: Margo Seibert, with Chris Fenwick on piano, sings “Raining” from the Broadway musical “Rocky,” at the Winter Garden Theater.

headline: Happenings | A Secret Chalet Off Hollywood Boulevard Where the L.A. Art World Gathers
text: Around the corner from a blighted stretch of the Hollywood Walk of Fame, through a back entrance that opens onto a seedy parking lot, there’s a space that feels rather like an alpine chalet. Created by the artist Piero Golia, the unlikely oasis is a salon for those in the know located in the storage of L.A.C.E. (Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions), an artist-run space that has been operating since the late 1970s.

headline: Vitamin D Screening Not Backed by Expert Panel
text: A government health panel on Monday chose not to endorse widespread screening for vitamin D levels in healthy adults, despite research suggesting that a majority of Americans may be deficient in the vitamin.

headline: A Win for Latin America’s Middle Class
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — To fulfill his dream of watching Colombia play in the World Cup, Marco Triana Lozada, an engineer from Bogotá, cobbled together savings to travel to Brazil this month. But to avoid spending money on hotels, he and his friends have traversed the country at night on buses to watch Colombia play, even opting to stay in tents at campsites.

headline: Oral Vaccine for Cholera Found Effective in Africa
text: A new, inexpensive, easy-to-use cholera vaccine that is stockpiled for emergencies worked very well during a cholera outbreak in Africa, Doctors Without Borders reported recently.

text: The agency Sparks & Honey fascinated and disgusted observers in equal measure last week with a presentation that catalogued the interests and values of Generation Z, whose members were born after 1995. But more than anything about these youths themselves, the latest foray into generational forecasting shows that generations are often essentially marketing opportunities.

text: Near the midpoint of a no-nonsense show at the Highline Ballroom on Friday night, Brandy Clark dismissed her backing band and got down to basics: her voice, her guitar and what she called “songs that I’ve written for other people.”

text: Located in the exclusive gated Bald Eagle community, this residence offers an elegant architectural design and layout along with charming private interior and exterior living spaces.

text: If one of Saddam Hussein’s two sons, Uday and Qusay, had turned against dictatorship and emigrated to the United States, the history of Iraq might have taken a different turn. Maybe.
