headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Attractions at Design Miami/Basel
text: The Design Miami/Basel fair — the annual European companion to Design Miami in Basel, Switzerland — has a single objective: facilitating the sale of expensive design objects to wealthy collectors. Yet much like its neighbor, Art Basel, the show can also serve as a resource for enthusiasts and curious window shoppers, who come to see and enjoy the works on view, or survey what’s happening in design now (lots of experimentation with everyday materials, apparently). Without the placards or checklists one would normally find in a gallery or museum, though, it would have been entirely possible for non-experts to meander in and out of the fair’s 50-something booths this year without knowing for sure what’s old and what’s new, or which pieces represent real breakthroughs in materials and process. There were many more novel contemporary works on view than ever before, balancing out the usual glut of 20th-century icons, but it wasn’t necessarily obvious unless you scoured the $30 show catalog.

headline: From Roars to Rhythmic Mallets, a Day for Savoring Exploration
text: Displaced last year by construction, the annual Bang on a Can Marathon was back at the glass-enclosed Winter Garden at Brookfield Place on Sunday. This meant the event’s singular vibe was back, too: both attentive and easygoing, art and commerce.

headline: Microsoft Makes Bet Quantum Computing Is Next Breakthrough
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Modern computers are not unlike the looms of the industrial revolution: They follow programmed instructions to weave intricate patterns. With a loom, you see the result in a cloth or carpet. With a computer, you see it on an electronic display.

headline: Longing Far Above Her Station, Simply but Achingly
text: American Ballet Theater’s performances of “Giselle” at the Metropolitan Opera House last week featured several debuts in the title role and saved the best for last, with Saturday’s return of Alina Cojocaru (who stars in “Swan Lake” this week at the Met). In every case, the interpretation was simpler than the ornate, fervent, virtuosic rendition of Diana Vishneva on opening night. But there are different ways of being simple.

headline: If It’s Broke, Reality TV Can Fix It
text: Watch enough reality television, and one conclusion is inescapable: We can’t do anything right. Run a restaurant. Operate a bar. Manage a hotel.

headline: Neymar Is Making the Most of His Chances
text: Neymar scores his fourth goal of the tournament, putting Brazil up, 2-1.

headline: Early Music and Its Future
text: The new Early Music Festival: NYC, which ended last week, gives reason for cautious hope. You can’t be categorical about its prospects one way or the other, because several more or less similar ventures have come and gone in recent years.

headline: At These Hospitals, Recovery Is Rare, but Comfort Is Not
text: NEW BRITAIN, CONN. — Propped up in a hospital bed, a 75-year-old man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease, must make an agonizing decision. Should he keep struggling until the illness inevitably kills him, dependent on a ventilator, unable to walk or eat or move? Or should he choose a day and a time to have the ventilator disconnected, and die?

headline: A Few Hot Months of Solidarity and Violence
text: The PBS documentary “Freedom Summer” won’t make many lists of the top television programs of the year, but it’s hard to imagine two hours better spent in front of a screen.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
text: Standout accessories from Roberto Cavalli, Giorgio Armani, DSquared2 and more.

headline: A Sunken Kingdom Re-emerges
text: BORTH, WALES — There is a poem children in Wales learn about the sunken kingdom of Cantre’r Gwaelod, swallowed by the sea and drowned forever after. On a quiet night, legend has it, one can hear the kingdom’s church bells ringing.

headline: Diplomatic Note Promises Immunity From Iraqi Law for U.S. Advisory Troops
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that it has accepted from the Iraqi government the same sort of immunity agreement for newly dispatched Special Operations troops that it refused to accept in 2011, when it opted to withdraw all American troops from Iraq rather than keep a residual force behind.

headline: Herpes Infected ‘Since Before We Were Human’
text: About two-thirds of people are infected with one of two herpes simplex viruses, oral (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2). New research says both viruses have been infecting humans and our ancestors for longer than previously thought. HSV-1 has been infecting hominids since before they split from the chimpanzee lineage six million years ago, a new study says. HSV-2 was introduced more recently, the researchers said, making the jump from chimpanzees to human ancestors about 1.6 million years ago.

headline: Brazil Romps Past Cameroon and Into Knockout Rounds
text: BRASÍLIA — An anxious nation and its capital exhaled on Monday. Their beloved national soccer team, which has not played with the precision and dominance that many had hoped for in the World Cup, nevertheless moved on to the next round with a convincing win.

headline: Girl, 14, Is Stabbed Near a Bronx School
text: A 14-year-old girl was stabbed and seriously wounded on Monday afternoon near a junior high school in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Still Exerting a Hold on Science
text: Not long after the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, while the world was reckoning with the specter of nuclear energy, a businessman named Roger Babson was worrying about another of nature’s forces: gravity.

headline: Support for New Mothers
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Where Personal Memories Take Root
text: When it comes to forming memories that involve recalling a personal experience, neuroscientists are of two minds. Some say that each memory is stored in a single neuron in a region of the brain called the hippocampus. But a new study is lending weight to the theory of neuroscientists who believe that every memory is spread out, or distributed, across many neurons in that part of the brain.

headline: The Neanderthal Inside Us
text: Svante Paabo is a Swedish biologist who studies evolutionary genetics.

headline: Monet’s ‘Nympheas’ Kicks Off Summer Sales in London
text: LONDON — One of Monet’s dreamy paintings depicting the water lily pond in his fabled garden at Giverny that failed to sell at Christie’s four years ago, caused a bidding war at Sotheby’s here on Monday night.

headline: Sounds of Danger Disrupt Crabs’ Dinner
text: Mud crabs don’t have ears, but they can still detect and react to noises. When exposed to sounds made by preying fish, the crabs were less likely to feed on their own meals, researchers at Northeastern University reported last week in The Proceedings of the Royal Society B. Listening for danger is a critical part of the crab’s survival strategy that could be hindered by increasing ocean noise, the scientists concluded.

headline: Don’t Turn Up Your Nose at the City in Summer
text: NEW YORK CITY has always had a challenging relationship with odor, which given its density, could hardly be otherwise. And as summer gets going, so does the season of smell.

headline: Full Poll Results
text: The New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,009 adults was conducted June 20 to 22 on landlines and cellphones.

headline: Generic Versions of Toprol XL, a Heart Drug, Are Recalled
text: For years, Dr. Harry Lever, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic, has been warning nearly anyone who would listen of his growing suspicions about generic versions of a widely used heart drug, Toprol XL.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 20 to June 22 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Poll Finds Dissatisfaction Over Iraq
text: Dissatisfaction with President Obama’s conduct of foreign policy has shot up among both Republicans and Democrats in the past month, even though a slim majority supports his recent decision to send military advisers to Iraq to confront the growing threat from militants there, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: College Group Run for Profit Reaches Deal for U.S. Cash
text: Moving to head off a cash shortfall that would disrupt classes for its 72,000 students, Corinthian Colleges announced on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the federal Department of Education that would allow it to continue operating, at least temporarily.

headline: Palestinian Freed in 2011 Is Charged by Israel in a Killing
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man who was among the prisoners released in 2011 in exchange for an abducted Israeli soldier was charged Monday along with his son in the April killing of an Israeli police commander as he drove to a Passover Seder in a West Bank settlement.

headline: In Wimbledon Lottery, Lucky Losers Win a Second Chance
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Luck in tennis is most commonly associated with balls that hit the net cord and dribble over, or shots that hit the racket frame and land square on the line. But there is no luck in tennis quite as important as the luck of the draw.

headline: A Fired Banker and Monroe Capital’s Public Suit
text: When Warren Woo, a deal maker at UBS, left the Swiss bank in 2007 to start his own firm, he named his family office Breakaway Capital.

headline: Mavericks Could Fracture a G.O.P. Senate Majority
text: WASHINGTON — Fear of losing a seat to a Democrat because of a Tea Party upset is one reason congressional Republicans are warily watching Tuesday’s Mississippi Senate runoff and other primary challenges to incumbents. But it is not the sole reason, and perhaps not the most important one, for Republicans this election cycle.

headline: Felix Dennis, 67, Flamboyant Builder of Magazine Empire, Dies
text: Felix Dennis, a flamboyant, boastfully profligate, immensely successful British businessman who built a publishing empire that included Maxim, America’s most successful young men’s lifestyle magazine, died on Sunday at his home in Dorsington, Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He was 67.

headline: F.B.I. Cracks Down on Sex Trafficking
text: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, on Monday said that in the past week law enforcement authorities had arrested 281 pimps and recovered 168 child prostitutes in a nationwide sex trafficking sting. The arrests and recoveries were made in 106 cities, and roughly 10 percent of the prostitutes had been missing from child protective services, the authorities said. In Phoenix, 21 pimps were apprehended, and in Denver 18 prostitutes were recovered, the highest numbers in the operation. More than a dozen children were recovered in other cities, including Chicago and Cleveland.

headline: A Rockefeller Known Not for Wealth but for His Efforts to Help
text: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y. — As a late afternoon sun tinted the room in gold, the children and grandchildren of David Rockefeller, the banker and philanthropist, gathered around a long table this month for a dinner of scallops and vegetables and toasted his 99th birthday.

headline: Massachusetts: Men Get 3 Years for Theft From Marathon Fund
text: Two brothers convicted of filing a false $2 million claim to the Boston Marathon victims’ compensation fund were sentenced Monday to three years in jail plus 468 hours of community service to help amputees and people with brain injuries. Judge Jeffrey A. Locke of Suffolk County Superior Court gave Branden Mattier, 23, and Domunique Grice, 28, a choice of six years in jail or three years in jail, after which they would serve six hours of community service every other Saturday for three years. The judge said the service could include building ramps for people who are handicapped, serving as an aide in a rehabilitation facility or changing bedpans.

headline: On Balance, a Good Ruling on Emissions
text: The Clean Air Act is a complex and often confusing piece of legislation, especially when it comes to confronting the challenges of global warming, which were not fully understood when the original law was passed in 1970.

headline: Dean Foods Receives a Subpoena in an Investigation Into Mickelson’s Trades
text: Federal authorities are seeking information from Dean Foods as part of an investigation into well-timed trades placed by the championship golfer Phil Mickelson and the well-known sports gambler William T. Walters.

headline: Bedouin Trackers Hunting for Clues to Kidnapped Boys
text: BEIT KAHIL, WEST BANK — Maj. Mohammed Mazarib of the Israel Defense Forces ducked into an old stone hut on a hillside above a riverbed here Monday afternoon, quickly determining that footprints inside belonged to soldiers who had beat him there. He nonetheless drew his rifle and shone its spotlight into a hole on the far side of the hut, then grabbed a stick to poke around.

headline: Gnarly in Pink
text: This short film celebrates the “Pink Helmet Posse,” three 6-year-old girls who share an unusual passion: skateboarding.

headline: Mississippi Race Points to Appeal of Partisanship
text: FLOWOOD, Miss. — Regardless of who wins Tuesday’s unpredictable Republican Senate runoff in Mississippi, the fracas has sent a message to incumbents in Congress: It is no longer enough to be a diligent member, quietly representing your constituents’ interests. You have to join the partisan fray.

headline: A Fired Banker and a Firm’s Public Suit
text: When Warren Woo, a deal maker at UBS, left the Swiss bank in 2007 to start his own firm, he named his family office Breakaway Capital.

headline: Transit Hub and Work on No. 7 Line Face Delays
text: Two of the biggest transit projects in New York City are poised to miss approaching deadlines, the latest in a string of delays involving Metropolitan Transportation Authority capital projects.

headline: ‘Gnarly in Pink’
text: Last fall, when passing by a skate park in Encinitas, Calif., near San Diego, we were delighted to find three little girls skateboarding in pink tutus and helmets. We immediately decided to tell their story – in a documentary style as playful and eclectic as our subjects.

headline: In Iraq’s Sectarian Violence, a Show of Each Side’s Worst
text: BAGHDAD — Sectarian violence in Iraq on Monday showed both sides in the conflict at their brutal worst, as Iraqi police officers were reported to have killed scores of Sunni insurgent prisoners along a highway in the south, and militants in the north turned over the bodies of 15 Shiite civilians they had killed, including women and children, only to bomb the cemetery during their funerals, according to one account.

headline: Neil Barofsky, Old Foe of Bank Bailouts, Said to Be a Monitor for Credit Suisse
text: Neil Barofsky was a government gadfly who made a career of needling, and at times pillorying, Wall Street and Washington over the 2008 bank bailouts.

headline: Realizing the American Apparel Chief, Dov Charney, Isn’t Wearing Any Clothes
text: Dov Charney is completely naked. He is dancing in what looks like an office or studio, talking on his cellphone while he jams to “This Must Be the Place” by Talking Heads. Two women are there with him, possibly employees.

headline: A Thin Rationale for Drone Killings
text: The Obama administration on Monday reluctantly released its justification for killing an American citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, whom it considered a terrorist, in a 2011 drone strike in Yemen. But the rationale provides little confidence that the lethal action was taken with real care.

headline: Obama Meets Working Families at Chipotle
text: President Obama talked with working parents at a Washington Chipotle restaurant ahead of his White House meeting on working families.

headline: Rhapsody in Realism
text: A few years ago, I came across an article on a blog that appealed tremendously. It was on a subject that obviously I have a lot to learn about. But it was actually the tone and underlying worldview that was so instructive, not just the substance.

headline: Personal Tack by Obama in an Effort to Aid Parents
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, to hear him tell it, is just another dad trying to juggle the demands of work and family.

headline: New Leader, New Attack on Exports
text: In the real world, markets aren’t perfect.

headline: Alabama: Police Chief to Step Down
text: Mayor Todd Strange of Montgomery said Monday that Chief Kevin J. Murphy of the police would retire amid allegations of mismanagement. Mayor Strange said officials had received complaints about Chief Murphy, and a city inquiry found evidence of “abusive supervision.” Chief Murphy acknowledged that he was “strict” but denied mistreating employees. Chief Murphy will remain on administrative leave for several months before retiring. He has been on leave for much of June after his twin brother, who was facing a felony charge following an automobile accident, committed suicide.

headline: More Egyptian Injustice
text: The conviction of three journalists by an Egyptian court on Monday for doing their jobs is the latest effort by the country’s military-backed rulers to crush all dissent. The alarming verdict sends a chilling and intimidating message not just to other journalists working in the country but to Egyptian citizens as well.

headline: Mexico Finds Itself Knee-Deep in Victory
text: RECIFE, Brazil — When Andrés Guardado of Mexico finally freed himself from a swarm of teammates Monday and emerged back under the floodlights of the crammed stadium here, he crouched along the sideline, pointed a finger down to his knees as he comically wiggled his legs, and vigorously shook his head from side to side.

headline: Lofty Salaries in the Ivory Towers
text: Are university presidents overpaid, or does the compensation appropriately reflect their wide range of management, recruitment and fund-raising duties?

headline: Rifts Among Shiites Further Threaten the Future of Iraq
text: NAJAF, Iraq — From his modest office in the shrine city of Najaf, Iraq’s highest religious authority, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, leader of the country’s Shiite establishment, issued a call to arms asking his followers to join with the government military to stop the blitzkrieg by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: In Time Warp of Soccer, It Ain’t Over Till ... Who Knows?
text: MANAUS, Brazil — Imagine if an N.F.L. coach never knew when to call for the last-second pass, or an N.B.A. star had to guess when to throw up his desperation half-court shot.

headline: The President and the Situation in Iraq
text: Based on nationwide telephone and cellphone interviews conducted June 20-22 with 1,009 adults.

headline: Officers Are Targeted in Contraband Sweep at Rikers Island
text: The authorities fanned out across one of the largest jail facilities on Rikers Island and searched over 100 correction officers for contraband on Monday as part of a large scale investigation into drug trafficking and other criminal activity inside the complex.

headline: Brazil: Polio Virus Detected in Sewage
text: For the first time since 1994, the polio virus has been detected in Brazil, the World Health Organization said Monday. The virus — minute amounts of which can be detected — was found in a sewage sample from an airport near Campinas, in southeastern Brazil. It was collected in March and matched a strain recently found in Equatorial Guinea on the central African coast. There are no reports of any cases of paralysis; for every child paralyzed by polio, health authorities estimate that 200 more are carrying and shedding the virus with few or no symptoms. Because about 95 percent of Brazilian children are immunized against polio, the W.H.O. says it is very unlikely that the virus will spread widely and has not suggested any restrictions on travel to or from the country.

headline: Egypt: Conviction in Sectarianism Case
text: A court in the city of Minya on Monday convicted a Christian reporter of promoting sectarianism and sentenced him to five years in prison. Egypt’s flagship state newspaper Al Ahram said that the reporter, Bishoy Armia, was charged with communicating with an American television station “in order to depict Egyptian Christians as victims of discrimination” and thus “instigate sectarianism.” The newspaper said that the reporter had converted to Christianity and that his former name was Mohamed Hegazy el-Sayed.

headline: Secret Military Mission
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Heather Valadez makes her New York Times debut and, I believe, her constructing debut today with an early-week puzzle that got the “Mission Impossible” theme song playing in my head.

headline: Union Square Cafe Joins Other Victims of New York City’s Rising Rents
text: It is one of the hard truths of New York real estate: Restaurants help revitalize neighborhoods, then are forced to close when their rents skyrocket.

headline: High-Scoring Netherlands Avoids a Matchup With Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Dutch have been here before in a World Cup. In South Africa four years ago on their way to the final, they also swept all three of their games in the first round.

headline: San Francisco Plans to Ban Certain Parking Apps
text: A few weeks ago I arranged to meet a friend for dinner at 8 p.m. in the Panhandle neighborhood of San Francisco, just about in the geographic center of the city. My girlfriend and I left the house around 7:40 p.m. and arrived at the restaurant 15 minutes later.

headline: Panel Backs Rent Increase of One Percent
text: The board that regulates rents for nearly one million apartments in New York City voted on Monday night to allow the lowest percentage rent increase in its 45-year existence, though it rebuffed calls from Mayor Bill de Blasio for a freeze.

headline: Murray and Djokovic Have Little Trouble in Wimbledon’s First Round
text: It is not easy to play the man when all you can see is the legend.

headline: An Activity Tracker With More Than a Hint of Style
text: Withings, the French electronics company, introduced on Monday its second step-counting activity tracker, the Activité, a sleek wrist-worn device.

headline: 2nd Bridge Inquiry Said to Be Linked to Christie
text: Investigations into the Christie administration and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have zeroed in on possible securities law violations stemming from a $1.8 billion road repair agreement in 2011, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: For Rangers’ Moore, Sense of Mission Remains Intense in Off-Season
text: Dominic Moore contributed crucial goals and valuable minutes as the Rangers reached the Stanley Cup finals for the first time in 20 years. He was a leader and the kind of inspirational force that every winning squad needs amid the crucible of playoff pressure. On Tuesday, he will be at the N.H.L. award ceremony in Las Vegas, where he is a finalist for the Masterton Trophy, presented to the player who most exemplifies perseverance, sportsmanship and dedication to hockey.

headline: Testy Exchange Erupts as I.R.S. Chief Is Questioned on Messages
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Darrell Issa of California, the Republican who is leading one of the investigations into the Internal Revenue Service’s scrutiny of Tea Party groups, accused the I.R.S. commissioner on Monday of lying, an allegation that only deepened the partisan mistrust about the motivations behind the numerous congressional inquiries into the matter.

headline: For Women in Midlife, Career Gains Slip Away
text: Tracy Murphy was managing a nonprofit agency five years ago when her mother became seriously ill with heart problems. She promptly left her job to care for her, a task that has consumed Ms. Murphy ever since.

headline: Blue Jays’ Big Inning Helps Keep Yankees at a Distance
text: TORONTO — The Yankees came to Toronto on Monday for the first of three games with the Blue Jays aware that they could return home in a few days as the new leaders in the American League East.

headline: New Lead in 1909 Killing of a Star Officer
text: It was not long after the turn of the 20th century when Giuseppe Petrosino, the New York Police Department’s most effective weapon against organized crime, was sent to Italy to attack the problem’s roots.

headline: Searching for Answers in Very Old DNA
text: As he puts it in the subtitle of his memoir, “Neanderthal Man,” Svante Paabo goes in search of lost genomes. Dr. Paabo, a 59-year-old Swede who leads his own laboratory at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Leipzig, Germany, was the first to extract and sequence the genomes of the ancient humans called Neanderthals and Denisovans, and to compare them with those of modern humans. Genes, and the stories they tell, are texts he reads.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 23, 2014
Feud in Hackensack Pits an Official Against the City
text: The city government in Hackensack, N.J., is embroiled in a not-so-civil war, judging by a lawsuit its top administrator filed on Monday.

headline: China Activist to Stand Trial, Lawyer Says
text: HONG KONG — Prosecutors in southern China have decided to put on trial a well-known human rights campaigner, Yang Maodong, on charges of disrupting public order, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Google’s Nest Labs Joins Race to Define Platform for the Internet of Things
text: Google did not pay $3.2 billion for Nest Labs this year just because it designed a smart thermostat that has redefined that humble household device.

headline: The Reality of Student Debt Is Different From the Clichés
text: The deeply indebted college graduate has become a stock character in the national conversation: the art history major with $50,000 in debt, the underemployed barista with $75,000, the struggling poet with $100,000.

text: delusion •\di-ˈlü-zhən, de-\• noun

headline: Rangel and Espaillat Make Final Push on Eve of Primary
text: On the eve of the Democratic congressional primary, Representative Charles B. Rangel and State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, who is trying to unseat him, held dueling news conferences on Monday a block apart in Washington Heights — a proximity that helped set off a shouting match between their supporters.

headline: Pediatrics Group to Recommend Reading Aloud to Children From Birth
text: In between dispensing advice on breast-feeding and immunizations, doctors will tell parents to read aloud to their infants from birth, under a new policy that the American Academy of Pediatrics will announce on Tuesday.

headline: Bipartisan Report Tallies High Toll on Economy From Global Warming
text: More than a million homes and businesses along the nation’s coasts could flood repeatedly before ultimately being destroyed. Entire states in the Southeast and the Corn Belt may lose much of their agriculture as farming shifts northward in a warming world. Heat and humidity will probably grow so intense that spending time outside will become physically dangerous, throwing industries like construction and tourism into turmoil.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: June 24, 2014
text: What to watch for today as the teams from Groups D and C fight to advance. Check out The Upshot for all the possibilities for how teams can advance.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (TruTV) MOTOR CITY MASTERS Ten car designers show off their expertise and creativity as they divide into teams to build two fully functional (though not street-legal) concept cars in each episode; challenges focus on technology, interiors, body trim and functionality. Each round will be judged by Jean Jennings, former editor in chief of Automobile Magazine; the car designer Harald Belker; and a celebrity, with designers eliminated one by one until only two remain for the final build-off. The winner will receive a 2014 Camaro Z28 and $100,000, and be named a brand ambassador for General Motors. Brooke Burns (above, far left, with Ms. Jennings and Mr. Belker) hosts; Jesse Metcalfe is the guest judge in this series premiere.

headline: Mapping the Risk of Bird Flu’s Spread
text: A strain of bird flu that has infected at least 367 people in mainland China over the past year poses a threat to several other parts of Asia, including the Philippines, Indonesia, Vietnam, Bangladesh and India, according to a new study mapping the risk posed by the H7N9 strain.

headline: Death Penalty Overturned for Wife Who Killed Abuser
text: The Chinese Supreme People’s Court has overturned a death sentence imposed on a woman who killed her husband after years of abuse, in a decision women’s rights advocates and death penalty opponents hailed as a major step forward for women and the rule of law in China. The court ruled that the case must be retried.

headline: Green Bean Salad With Lime Vinaigrette and Red Quinoa
text: This is a green bean salad with quinoa as opposed to a quinoa salad with green beans. Red quinoa is secondary to the green beans here. The two ingredients provide a colorful contrast. The salad is alive with texture, the crisp-tender green beans with the crunchy almonds and the chewy, comforting quinoa. The flavors here are Mexican: lime juice, chile, cilantro, white or red onion. It’s simple to put together but the sum is complex.

headline: Mediterranean Cucumber and Yogurt Salad With Red or Black Quinoa
text: The idea of embellishing a yogurt soup or salad with quinoa comes from Deborah Madison, who uses black quinoa in a brilliant recipe for a soup in her book “Vegetable Literacy.” I used red quinoa to add texture, color and substance to this typical Mediterranean combination – finely diced cucumber, garlic, and thick plain yogurt. Use mint or dill, or a combination, and make sure to dice the cucumber very small.

headline: Poll Watchers Must Stay Outside, Mississippi Officials Say
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Conservative groups’ election monitors must remain outside polling places during the Republican Senate runoff in Mississippi on Tuesday unless one of the two campaigns authorizes a representative to be inside, state election officials said.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 24, 2014
text: “I always felt like I can find another job eventually — but I only have one mother.”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Student Crossword | Dance
text: Test your knowledge of dance by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Kerry Implores Kurdish Leader to Join a Government and Not Break Away
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Secretary of State John Kerry urged the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region on Tuesday not to seek his own state and instead help form a government in Baghdad.

headline: Nominee for South Korean Premier Exits Over Colonization Remarks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye, whose approval ratings have fallen since an April ferry disaster that left hundreds dead, suffered a new political blow on Tuesday as her second consecutive nominee for prime minister stepped aside, amid an uproar over his suggestion that Korea’s colonization by Japan had been “God’s will.”

headline: K.K.R. to Invest in Acciona’s Renewable Energy Arm
text: LONDON — Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has agreed to pay 417 million euros, or about $567 million, for a stake in the international renewable energy business of Acciona, the Spanish infrastructure conglomerate.

headline: Longtime Politician and Veteran Actor Receive Lincoln Medals
text: WASHINGTON — Representative John D. Dingell started his career as a congressional page, shuttling mail from one legislator to another and watching Franklin D. Roosevelt give speeches from the House floor. On Sunday, Mr. Dingell, the longest serving congressman in United States history with nearly 60 years in the House, was awarded the Lincoln Medal for exemplifying the legacy of the nation’s 16th president.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Chiseled Bodybuilder, Frail Clients and a Fitness Story for the Ages
text: In “A Chiseled Bodybuilder, Frail Clients and a Fitness Story for the Ages,” Louie Lazar writes about a former champion bodybuilder from Ghana who opened a small gym in an affordable housing development in Lower Manhattan.

headline: In Kodak’s Hometown, Memory and History
text: Alex Webb and Rebecca Norris Webb, a husband and wife photography team, documented Rochester after Eastman Kodak’s bankruptcy in their new book, “Memory City,” published by Radius Books. Previously they published “Violet Isle,” a volume on modern-day Cuba. Ms. Norris Webb’s book “My Dakota” was featured on Lens in  2012, while Mr. Webb’s book “The Suffering of Light” was featured on Lens in 2011. He is a member of Magnum Photos. Their conversation with James Estrin has been edited.

headline: When Advance Directives Are Ignored
text: In the final two years of her mother’s life, Lisa McAllister started carrying copies of her mother’s do-not-resuscitate and power-of-attorney forms in her purse and her car. Her mother was cycling between the hospital, assisted living and rehab — “a round robin of craziness,” said Ms. McAllister, a retired copy editor — and was clear about not wanting to be kept alive with substantially diminished quality of life.

text: The Mississippi Senate runoff on Tuesday has attracted an unusual number of outside groups, and they are spending heavily on direct voter contact and get-out-the-vote efforts.

headline: Italian Credit Rating Agency Cerved Down 5% in Debut

headline: Morning Views
text: The Obama administration made public a memo explaining the rationale behind a 2011 drone strike that killed an American citizen, Anwar al-Awlaki, in Yemen, The New York Times reports. “But the rationale provides little confidence that the lethal action was taken with real care,” the editorial board writes. “Instead, the memo turns out to be a slapdash pastiche of legal theories — some based on obscure interpretations of British and Israeli law — that was clearly tailored to the desired result.” The board remains unpersuaded that Mr. Awlaki’s due-process rights were given proper consideration. “More documents must be made public. The public is still in the dark on too many vital questions.”

headline: In Our Pages: June 25
text: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: King Peter transfers power to Crown Prince Alexander in 1914; the U.S. Army completes a topographic study of the moon in 1964.

headline: Support Is Thin for Tea Party, but It Retains Its Muscle
text: An upstart challenger wrestles a Republican primary victory from the House majority leader Eric Cantor. Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi faces a vigorous challenge for his seat in a runoff election Tuesday. The pressure on established candidates has many people asking: Is the Tea Party having another moment?

headline: How We Picked a Format for Employee Reviews
text: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to reinstitute employee reviews.

headline: Vertex’s 2-Drug Cystic Fibrosis Pill Shows Promise
text: Vertex Pharmaceuticals said on Tuesday that a combination of two of its drugs had successfully treated cystic fibrosis in closely watched clinical trials, potentially clearing the way for approval of a new option for nearly half the patients with the genetic disease.

headline: Ex-Tabloid Executive Acquitted in British Phone Hacking Case
text: LONDON — She rose from being a secretary in Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire to running it. She called prime ministers her friends. Then she found herself in the middle of one of the most riveting trials in years, accused of illegally intercepting voice mails and other crimes, alongside her husband and her former deputy, who it turned out, was also her lover.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael Tien on Why He Thinks Occupy Central Is a Mistake
text: Hong Kong democracy activists and many “pan-democratic” lawmakers are pushing for new rules for the 2017 election for the territory’s leader, the chief executive, under which any candidate who collects a certain number of signatures can get on the ballot. In the face of opposition from the central government in Beijing, they’re putting their support to the test this month, conducting an informal referendum to gauge public support. So far more than 730,000 votes have been cast in the 10-day poll, and its organizers have vowed to occupy Hong Kong’s central business district in protest if Beijing insists on an electoral system that limits the ballot to its approved candidates.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Sees Quantum Computing as Technology’s Next Frontier
text: Modern computers are not unlike the looms of the industrial revolution, John Markoff reports: They follow programmed instructions to weave intricate patterns. With a loom, you see the result in a cloth or carpet. With a computer, you see it on an electronic display.

headline: Fear or Ignorance Drives Confucius Institutes’ Critics, Xinhua Says
text: Chinese state media on Tuesday defended the spread of Confucius Institutes worldwide, lashing back at a recent call for North American universities to rethink their links with the cultural and language programs, which are backed by the Chinese government.

headline: World Cup 2014: Uruguay Defeats Italy, 1-0, to Advance Out of Group D
text: Uruguay advanced to the Round of 16 with a 1-0 victory over Italy, but the victory was overshadowed by the alleged biting of a player by Uruguay’s Luis Suarez.

headline: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica and England Play to a 0-0 Draw
text: Costa Rica conquered mighty Uruguay and Italy and clinched the Group of Death by tying England.

headline: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Japan, 4-1
text: Japan needed a victory, and help, in order to advance. Instead, Colombia’s late goal-scoring surge ended any hope the Japanese had.

headline: Bank Analysts Say Pfizer-AstraZeneca Merger Still Makes Sense
text: LONDON — Analysts at BNP Paribas think a potential merger between AstraZeneca and Pfizer may not be dead despite AstraZeneca’s repeated rejections of a deal between the drug makers.

headline: Match Recap: Greece Overcomes Ivory Coast in Added Time, 2-1
text: Ivory Coast was a minute away from moving on to the knockout stage, when Greece was awarded a penalty kick, which it deftly converted.

headline: Egypt’s Leader Says He Won’t Intervene in Case of Jailed Journalists
text: Brushing aside protests from the governments of Western countries, including the United States, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt said Tuesday that he would not interfere in the case of three journalists from Al Jazeera’s English-language service who have each been sentenced to at least seven years in prison.

headline: DirecTV and AT&T Make Case to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — AT&T and DirecTV told members of Congress on Tuesday that their proposed $48.5 billion merger would be so good for competition that it would do something that has rarely, if ever, happened: pressure cable companies to lower prices.

headline: Consumers Will Spend More on Health Care in 2015, Report Predicts
text: Growth in health care spending is expected to tick upward next year, in part because consumers who delayed treatment during the economic downturn are now seeking care they postponed, according to a report released on Tuesday.

headline: Tangled Passages
text: As we’ve often noted, long, convoluted sentences are a disservice to harried readers, who may be scanning the paper on the subway or checking their phone in the checkout line. We don’t have to use See-Spot-run syntax, but we should do the hard work of ironing out our sentences so readers don’t have to.

headline: Morning Agenda: Monitor for Credit Suisse Named
text: Neil Barofsky, an old foe of the 2008 bank bailouts, has managed to secure a familiar role: watchdog for one of the world’s biggest banks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. New York State’s financial regulator is said to be close to picking Mr. Barofsky, a former federal prosecutor, as the corporate monitor for Credit Suisse after the bank’s guilty plea to helping American clients evade taxes. Credit Suisse agreed to hire a monitor as part of a related settlement. Separately, a monitor was also installed late last year at BNP Paribas, the giant French bank suspected of violating sanctions provisions.

headline: Middle America’s Take on the Middle East’s Wars
text: A poll shows disapproval of Obama’s foreign policy, but a majority of respondents supported the possibility of drone strikes in Iraq.

headline: Boko Haram Suspected of New Kidnappings in Nigeria
text: Militants are suspected of having abducted dozens more girls and women in northeastern Nigeria, news reports said on Tuesday, reviving concerns about hundreds of schoolgirls who were kidnapped in the same region in April and have yet to be rescued.

headline: Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund Ramps Up Investment Plans
text: LONDON – Norway’s giant sovereign wealth fund said on Tuesday that it would manage its $884 billion portfolio more aggressively over the next three years, taking larger stakes in companies and increasing its real estate portfolio.

headline: Fast Fashion Manufacturing Takes Another Hit
text: Much talk in Britain today about the news that a customer bought a summer dress at Primark — a low-priced high street chain — containing a label with the words “forced to work exhausting hours” stitched onto it.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Summer’s Super Tuesday

headline: Tensions High at Delhi University After Four-Year Program Is Canceled
text: NEW DELHI — Delhi University, India’s prestigious network of colleges, has become immersed in tensions after its four-year undergraduate program was eliminated by a higher education regulatory body on Sunday.

headline: HSBC to Sell Some Swiss Private Bank Assets to Liechtenstein Group
text: LONDON – The British bank HSBC said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell a portfolio of Swiss private banking assets to a unit of the LGT Group Foundation of Liechtenstein.

text: Amid ongoing conflict in Iraq, Secretary of State John Kerry meets with the president of Iraq’s Kurdish region, Massoud Barzani, in Erbil.

headline: Highlights From the Mississippi Senate Primary Runoff
text: Voters head to the polls Tuesday in a Republican Senate primary runoff between Senator Thad Cochran, a six-term incumbent, and State Senator Chris McDaniel, his Tea Party-backed challenger. The Times is on the ground across the state and will provide updates throughout the day.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Thanks, Mom, for Financing My Congressional Bid
text: Twenty-seven-year-old Mike Turner is running for Congress in Oklahoma, with a little family assistance.

headline: Italy vs. Uruguay: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: These teams might have expected to be fighting for first place in the group in this game. Instead they both lost to the astounding Costa Rica and are fighting for survival. The men to watch will be the teams’ controversial strikers: Mario Balotelli of Italy and Luis Suarez of Uruguay.

headline: Intersection | Haut Marais, Paris
text: In the Haut Marais neighborhood of Paris, locals turn to polo, Vanessa Bruno, and Serge Gainsbourg for inspiration.

headline: Costa Rica vs. England: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Costa Rica conquered mighty Uruguay and Italy and is on course to win this Group of Death. Its joyous play has made it many fans’ new favorite, and striker Joel Campbell has emerged as a breakout star. By contrast, England’s fans are morose. The team has not been flat out horrible, but is 0-2 and out of the Cup. Wayne Rooney and company will want a win to salvage some pride.

headline: Endo International to Pay Up to $600 Million for Dava, a Generic Drug Maker
text: LONDON – Endo International said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the generic drug maker Dava Pharmaceuticals for up to $600 million.

text: A peek at what some of the peacocks in Milan were wearing.

headline: Cochran Holds Off Tea Party Challenger in Mississippi
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — With an unusual assist from African-American voters and other Democrats who feared his opponent, Senator Thad Cochran on Tuesday beat back a spirited challenge from State Senator Chris McDaniel, triumphing in a Republican runoff and defeating the Tea Party in the state where the movement’s hopes were bright.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: It’s Valentine’s Day at the Litch
text: Season 2, Episode 6 It’s Valentine’s Day, and love is in the air at the Litch. Crazy, complicated prison love, making it not so much different from love everywhere else. This episode has an almost giddy looseness to it, with dialogue and scenes bleeding into one another – from prison staff into inmates, from Litchfield into Larry’s Brooklyn (Larry – “my sweet, kind, unfocused fiancé,” as Piper describes him). The looseness conveys the messiness of the business at hand – as do the closeups of inmates giving their definitions of love to an off-camera interviewer. (Who turns out to be Piper, with an interest in interviewing that is somewhat duplicitous. More on that below, and while it’s not really much of a spoiler, this is probably a good place to issue the standard spoiler alert.)

headline: Cameron Apologizes for Hiring Coulson
text: David Cameron, the prime minister of Britain, said he was “extremely sorry” for employing Andy Coulson, the former tabloid editor who was convicted of phone hacking.

headline: Read to a Tiny Baby? Yes
text: Future well-baby visits to the pediatrician should include a new prescription: reading. The American Academy of Pediatrics now recommends that its members, and all doctors, tell parents they should be “reading together as a daily fun family activity” from infancy.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: No. 21 Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: When We Read Fiction, How Relevant Is the Author’s Biography?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Adam Kirsch discuss whether knowing about an author’s life deepens or detracts from the pleasures of reading fiction.

headline: 11 Consumer Groups Ask F.T.C. to Investigate CarMax Over Unfixed Recalled Cars
text: Saying that advertisements by CarMax, the nation’s largest used-car retailer, are deceptive, a coalition of 11 consumer groups has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate.

headline: Sperm Donation Puts a New Layer on an Old Friendship
text: For years, my friend Tori and I have had a standing weekly dinner date. We’ve been known to close down a restaurant or two during these epic evenings, gabbing about nothing and everything, all over a glass or three of wine. Tori’s wife, Kelly, often joins us too but I suspect these are mostly on the nights she would like her partner home at a reasonable hour.

headline: Improving Article Accessibility
text: Update: We have moved from Less to Sass and have edited the code in this post to reflect this.

headline: You Should Have Been a Doctor?
text: Earlier this week, a user named Dan Lin posted this chart to Reddit. It depicts the average yearly salary for 820 different jobs in America, based on 2013 data. The chart quickly made the media rounds — and the way it’s been interpreted may tell us something about how we look at jobs and the economy today.

headline: Rise in Home Prices Is Slowing, and That’s a Good Thing
text: The latest readings on United States home prices are the latest confirmation of a slowdown in that area: Prices are still rising in most cities, but much more slowly than they were a few months ago. And that’s news we should cheer.

headline: Beijing Company Drops Objection to ‘Transformers’ Film
text: LOS ANGELES — Beijing’s Pangu Investment Company said it had dropped its demand that Paramount Pictures remove scenes representing one of its properties from “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” which is set to open in China on Friday. Instead, it said it was now blaming “a third party.'’

headline: At Heart of Christie Inquiry, a Law Feared on Wall Street
text: The Christie administration and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are feeling the pressure of a prosecutorial tool that is feared on Wall Street.

headline: On Wellness | A Summer Workout From a Personal Trainer to the Fashion Set
text: Squats, push-ups, lunges, sit-ups: these are the physical drills most of us have been familiar with since elementary school gym class. And according to Will Torres — the personal trainer behind Willspace whose clientele includes Calvin Klein, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, Andy Cohen and the model Ashley Smith — they’re the basis to achieving your ideal body. That may sound like an overly simplistic notion, especially in this era of hybridized fitness routines, but at Torres’s intimate West Village studio, it’s the focus on precision and consistency that render these timeless workouts effective. “There’s no point in progressing to a new exercise if you haven’t perfected fundamental movements like hinging and torque,” Torres says. “And you don’t need a lot of equipment.”

headline: Today in Small Business: Starting Up in Cuba
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Johnny Mann, Leader of Easy-Listening Singers, Dies at 85
text: Johnny Mann, who won two Grammy Awards as leader of the clean-cut easy-listening vocal group the Johnny Mann Singers, died on June 18 at his home in Anderson, S.C. He was 85.

headline: DOJ White Paper on Killing Citizens Deemed Terrorists
text: Unclassified Justice Department “white paper” about the legality of targeting American citizens deemed terrorists for killing, derived from classified Office of Legal Counsel memos about Anwar Al-Awlaki.

headline: New Yorkers Cast Votes in Rematch of Rangel vs. Espaillat
text: During the spirited Democratic primary to represent New York’s 13th Congressional District, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat has taken aim at the long tenure of Representative Charles B. Rangel, arguing that, after 43 years in Congress, his main opponent was too old, too scarred by scandal and too entrenched in the ways of Washington.

headline: Sympathy for the Trustafarians
text: A number of people have asked me to comment on Greg Mankiw’s defense of inherited wealth. It’s a strange piece, oddly disconnected from the real concerns about patrimonial capitalism. But let me focus on two key problems with Mankiw’s analysis – one purely economic, one involving political economy.

headline: Scoop Shops, Snack Bars, Soda Fountains: Share Your Ice Cream Photos
text: Ice cream has the power to evoke to memories of childhood. As part of the Dining section’s coming ice cream issue, we’re asking readers to share memories of their favorite ice creams.

headline: Image of the Day: June 24
text: Female police personnel marching during a parade in Gandhinagar, Gujarat.

headline: Free-Agent Axis Tilts From Anthony to James
text: Carmelo Anthony enjoyed the unique privilege of being the N.B.A.'s most coveted free agent for a little more than 36 hours. That ended Tuesday morning when it was revealed that LeBron James had informed the Miami Heat through his agent, Rich Paul, that he intended to exercise the early termination option on his contract and become a free agent July 1.

headline: Daunting Path to Publication
text: Kevin Birmingham’s new book about the long censorship fight over James Joyce’s “Ulysses” braids eight or nine good stories into one mighty strand. It’s about women’s rights and heroic female editors, about World War I, about anarchism and modernism, about tenderness and syphilis, about how literature can bend an era’s consciousness, about moral panic and about the Lost Generation and the tent it pitched at Sylvia Beach’s Paris bookstore. It isolates a great love story, that of Joyce and Nora Barnacle, one that comes with a finger-burning side order of some of the most cheerfully filthy correspondence in literary history.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Keeps Jennifer Lopez, Keith Urban and Harry Connick Jr.
text: Fox announced on Tuesday morning that Jennifer Lopez, Keith Urban and Harry Connick Jr. would return as judges for the 14th season of “American Idol,” along with the show’s host, Ryan Seacrest.

headline: Methodists Reinstate Pastor, Deepening Church’s Rift Over Gays
text: A Methodist pastor who was defrocked because he presided at the wedding of his gay son is being reinstated in a startling reversal by a large Protestant denomination that, like many, is riven by disagreements over same-sex relationships.

headline: Islamic Extremists Pose New Risks for Religious Minorities in Iraq
text: The incursion of Islamic extremists in Nineveh province, in northern Iraq, is bad for a lot of people, but perhaps no group has more to lose than a minority religious group known as the Yazidis.

headline: M. Patmos’s Sustainable Shades for Selima
text: Marcia Patmos’s women’s wear line M.Patmos may be known for its innovative cashmere knitwear and casual-chic separates, but the brand is equally noteworthy for its commitment to sustainability: Patmos sources organic fibers when possible and employs women’s artisan collectives around the globe. Now, the designer has joined forces with the eyewear mainstay Selima Optique for a limited-edition frame shape — available in an optical or sunglass version — made with water buffalo horn that has been naturally shed by the animals. Each pair is hand-cut in a family-owned atelier in Paris.

headline: Board Cites Confusion by Crew in Air Crash
text: WASHINGTON — A Boeing 777 arriving in San Francisco on a clear, bright day hit the sea wall just short of the runway because the crew did not understand crucial details of the cockpit automation, the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday, recommending changes in training and flight manuals and in the airplane itself.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Talking About Obesity
Wheelies: The Better Bimmer Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Renovations Slated for Smithsonian’s Renwick Gallery
text: The Smithsonian Institution’s Renwick Gallery, which was built by the same architect who designed the Smithsonian Castle in Washington and St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York, will be getting a face-lift, thanks in part to a $5.4 million gift from David M. Rubenstein, co-founder of the Carlyle Group.

headline: Gold Touches Up Sullied Band Shell in Central Park
text: The gift has fallen apart over the years.

headline: Why Some Sources Don’t Sweat the ‘Chilling Effect’
text: A reader, Dale Kelberman of Annapolis, Md., emails with what I like to call a Perfectly Reasonable Question.He writes:

headline: Sudan Said to Revive Notorious Militias
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Sudanese government has reconstituted the janjaweed, notorious militias that terrorized the restive Darfur region for years, making them an official, uniformed force that has recently burned down huts and attacked civilians, according to a new report prepared by the Enough Project, an activist group that aims to prevent genocide.

headline: On a Day of Few Surprises, Nadal’s Victory Restores Natural Order
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It is not often that intrigue and doubt accompany the top-ranked men’s tennis player to the opening round at Wimbledon. It was as if they were stored in the racket bag that Rafael Nadal had slung over his shoulder as he entered Centre Court on Tuesday.

headline: Internet Shares Mexico Coach Miguel Herrera’s Joy and Emotion
text: RECIFE, Brazil — He is one of the most visually delightful characters at this World Cup. He is a charismatic, savvy leader. He is competitive mania personified.

headline: Rebekah Brooks Acquitted in Hacking Case
text: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was acquitted of phone hacking, and the lawyer for her former assistant spoke after his client was acquitted as well.

headline: At the La Brea Tar Pits, A Gala Event Celebrating Flintstones-Style Hair
text: Scenes from the photo diary of Angie Smith.

headline: Tysons, a Northern Virginia Crossroads, Waits Impatiently for the Train
text: It was known as Tysons Corner, a rural crossroads 13 miles from downtown Washington.

headline: Uruguay’s Suárez, Known for Biting, Leaves Mark on World Cup
text: NATAL, Brazil — The most ruthless soccer players often use their hands or elbows or knees to rough up opposing players. The most reckless — or dirtiest — might even use their cleats. Then there is Luis Suárez.

headline: The South American World Cup Bracket
text: Tuesday’s later World Cup matches created a fascinating dynamic for the rest of the tournament: Colombia won Group C, creating an all-South American portion of the bracket.

headline: Hachette Adds Heft to Combat Amazon
text: Hachette Book Group is bulking up and diversifying, steps that could improve its long-term negotiating position with Amazon, the giant online retailer.

headline: Dylan’s ‘Like a Rolling Stone’ Manuscript Sells for More Than $2 Million
text: Bob Dylan’s handwritten, working manuscript for his 1965 hit “Like a Rolling Stone” was sold at Sotheby’s auction on Tuesday for $2,045,000, just over the maximum estimated bid of $2 million.

headline: A Celebrity Steps Back Into the Spotlight
text: Restaurant critics are supposed to be impartial, but I can’t help feeling some proprietary interest in Tavern on the Green. Not a financial interest, except insofar as a profitable Tavern is good for the city’s budget, which, in a fractions-of-pennies way, is good for me as a grumpy taxpayer. It’s more like a civic interest. Tavern on the Green belongs to the city and sits inside the most beautiful public park in which I’ve ever rowed, cycled, struck out in softball, misidentified a confusing fall warbler and illegally consumed alcoholic beverages. I’d let the city keep those fractional pennies if that helped Tavern on the Green live up to its setting.

headline: Colombia vs. Japan: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Like many Western Hemisphere nations, Colombia has had a strong start to the Cup. Expect Juan Cuadrado to send in dangerous crosses that bother Japan’s defense. Japan has just one goal at the Cup and could only draw woeful Greece. This will be a tough spot.

headline: Getting a 9-Year-Old’s View of the Common Core
text: Last week, Javier Hernández explored the Common Core program, a recommended set of academic standards, through the eyes of a 9-year-old student. The piece struck a chord with readers. It drew over 500 impassioned comments and many letters to the editor, several of which were published yesterday. Here, Javier answers questions about the origins of the story and what the reporting was like.

headline: A Year After the Chaos, Many Ranking Points to Defend
text: WIMBLEDON, England — A year after one of the most turbulent Wimbledons in memory, the unexpected stars of an edition of the tournament nicknamed Wimbleweird returned with hopes of rekindling that same feeling.

headline: Greece vs. Ivory Coast: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: After two noble failures at the World Cup, Ivory Coast is on the cusp of finally making the knockout stages. Gervinho has been outstanding and he could well run riot against Greece.

headline: Order denying habeas to Shaker Aamer
text: Order denying request for habeas relief to Shaker Aamer on health grounds.

headline: United Methodists’ Decision to Overturn Defrocking of Frank Schaefer
text: A United Methodist Church appeals committee — a nine-member panel made up of laypeople and clergy — issued this ruling Tuesday. The panel decided to overturn the punishment of Frank Schaefer on the grounds that it was too harsh.

headline: Petition for habeas corpus on health grounds
text: Shaker Aamer, a Saudi citizen and former British resident detained at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, asked a Federal District Court judge to order his release on grounds of poor health.

headline: A Harlem Cultural Connector Makes Her Artistic Debut
text: A chance meeting with an old friend on a subway platform leads to a creative epiphany: it’s one of those only-in-New-York stories, the type that seems more rom-com plotline than real life. But that’s exactly what happened to Felicia Gordon, the founder of the Sugar Hill Culture Club (a loosely knit group of creatives from Harlem to Berlin that has collaborated on everything from short films to a line of sweatshirts worn by Rihanna), who has her first-ever show as an artist in a Harlem pop-up gallery this week.

headline: Guantanamo Detainee Disposition List
text: A 2009-2010 inter-agency task force that reviewed each detainee still at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, when President Obama took office came up with this list of disposition recommendations.

headline: A Contemporary Design Yields to the Demands of Prehistory
text: LOS ANGELES — The Swiss architect Peter Zumthor has modified his grand plans to transform the campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, altering the shape of his building to stretch across bustling Wilshire Boulevard and away from the neighboring La Brea Tar Pits, according to renderings provided by the museum on Tuesday. Critics of the original design had raised environmental concerns, saying it would have cast a shadow over tar pits rich with Ice Age fossils.

headline: I.R.S. Hearing Over Lost Emails
text: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, defended himself against Republicans’ accusations of a cover-up over lost emails.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Taxi Brooklyn’
text: The new NBC series is about a cop who partners with a cabby.

headline: New York Is Star in Video Pitch for Democratic Convention
text: New York City’s bid to make Brooklyn the home of the 2016 Democratic National Convention has attracted all manner of buzz. But with five other cities contending for the event, it is up to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s team to seal the deal with party leaders.

headline: Odd Couple, Chic Borough
text: Leo Romba (Jacky Ido) is an expert body-language reader and a stunning tactical driver, can tell which part of Peru a dab of cocaine comes from, and can throw a perp up against a wall without wrinkling his shirt. In “Taxi Brooklyn,” a goofy tale of an unlikely alliance between cop and cabby, he is the seer and the center of all power, a hero for a troubled borough.

headline: Siemens May Seek Another Alstom Tie-Up
text: Once the dust settles over the Alstom bidding war, Siemens and its French rival may want to revisit the most compelling aspect of the German company’s losing bid: a merger of both groups’ train-making units. Such a union would create the train equivalent of Airbus, the European aircraft maker.

headline: Apologies Become a Tool, Not a Goal
text: In 35 years as a corporate insider, adviser and critic, I’ve been on both sides of dozens of apologies played out in the public domain — and the most striking common denominator is how few of those apologies were either genuinely given or received. In fact, I’d suggest that one reason for supporting Dov Seidman’s call for an apology cease-fire is that the modern apology has strayed far from its purpose — acknowledgment and redress of a wrong — and is simply a tactic played out in a larger zero-sum game of winners and losers.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Climate Change
text: When the “Room to Grow” collection of reform conservative essays dropped last month, some of the most frequent criticisms from liberals focused on topics that the book did not address: In particular, comprehensive immigration reform (the subject of my last post) and climate change legislation. Vox’s Matt Yglesias, for instance, thought it noteworthy that a book “hailed as representing the best, freshest conservative thinking on the pressing issues of the day” has “nothing to say” on how American policymakers should tackle climate change, and he offered the following theory as to why:

headline: Bain Capital’s Andrew Balson Starts New Private Equity Fund
text: Andrew B. Balson, a longtime managing director at the Boston-based private equity firm Bain Capital, has left to start a new investment fund.

headline: Five Things to Ponder About the Mississippi Runoff
text: The polls in Mississippi closed at 8 p.m. Eastern as voters chose whether Senator Thad Cochran or State Senator Chris McDaniel should be the Republican nominee for the Senate in November. We are analyzing vote returns live here. Meanwhile, here are the five outstanding questions to watch this evening.

text: Headliner

headline: 3-D Mammography Test Appears to Improve Breast Cancer Detection Rate
text: Adding a newer test to digital mammograms can increase the detection rate for breast cancer and decrease nerve-racking false alarms, in which suspicious findings lead women to get extra scans that turn out normal, a study found.

headline: Federal District Court Ruling on No-Fly List
text: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon struck down redress procedures for people put on the so-called “no-fly” list who seek to regain a right to board airplanes.

headline: Federal District Court ruling Upholds FISA Amendments Act
text: A Federal District Court judge in Oregon rejected a request to throw out a conviction because of evidence derived from the FISA Amendments Act of 2008.

headline: Turk Who Killed Staten Island Tourist Gets Life Sentence
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish man who admitted killing a tourist from Staten Island last year, after, he said, she resisted his kiss, was found guilty of murder on Tuesday and sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Smiles in Distress
text: A wedding procession inside a Muslim concentration camp in Myanmar.

headline: Climbing for Coconuts
text: A villager climbed a coconut tree inside a confined Muslim village in Myanmar. He gave the coconut to some thirsty reporters from The Times.

headline: Myanmar Hospitality: A Rescue Boat
text: A rescue boat appeared for two Times reporters as sun was falling, a cyclone was approaching and a curfew for foreigners was just 20 minutes away.

headline: European Banks Balk at Cheap Loans, Worried About Strings Attached
text: FRANKFURT — It sounds like an offer too good to refuse: nearly unlimited loans at an annual interest rate of only 0.25 percent.

headline: There May Not Be a There There, or Gold
text: Psst! Wanna buy some collateralized debt obligations? How about a nice credit default swap? Wait! I’ve got just the thing: shares in a plan to exploit the gold reserves of Donogoo-Tonka, that lush South American Eden.

headline: Helped by Federer, and Now Surpassing Him
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Once in a lifetime, everyone should have a Stan Wawrinka experience, the chance to step out of the shadow, take the baton from a world-renowned maestro and say, “Step aside, partner, let me show you how to lead this concerto.”

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: ExIm Irony
text: So it looks quite likely that the Tea Party will claim a scalp from the business lobby, and kill the Export-Import Bank. And there is a case for doing away with the lender – except that this is the worst possible time for it.

headline: A Rarity Bursts Into Bloom
text: BOSTON — “Don’t be afraid to love ballet,” William Forsythe called out as a quartet of Boston Ballet dancers stepped into fifth position on point — feet tight together, arms high — their hips twisting and their heads tilted up toward delicately curved hands. “Show us why you love it!”

headline: British Tabloids After Brooks Verdict
text: Ravi Somaiya, a Times media correspondent, on the fallout from the acquittal of Rebekah Brooks, the former Murdoch newspaper editor, on charges of phone hacking.

headline: In Vermont, a Festival of Cheese
text: More than 40 Vermont cheesemakers and dozens of specialty food, beer, wine, and spirits producers will gather on July 20 for the sixth annual Vermont Cheesemakers Festival in Shelburne, presented by the Vermont Cheese Council.

headline: Enigmatic Moves and Flashes of Drama Against a Towering Cityscape
text: The incongruity of dancing in the financial district is something to which many New Yorkers have grown accustomed. Over the years, dancers have performed in many of the spaces there. At 1 p.m. on Monday, Michael Ingle and Silas Riener, modern dancers of distinction, performed a 30-minute duet by the choreographer Tere O’Connor on a lawn at the Elevated Acre on Water Street.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Lebanon, England and New York.

headline: NBC Completes Upfront Sales as CW Nears Finish Line
text: Two additional big English-language broadcast networks – NBC and CW – have declared that they have finished, or largely finished, the sale of commercial time before the start of the 2014-15 television season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: A Prime Portfolio in Manhattan, Coming Back to Life
text: In a city that can seem to be wringing every last drop of value out of its real estate, while giving block after block a squeaky-clean gloss, a Manhattan loft building at 13 West 27th Street stuck out glaringly on a recent tour.

headline: A Luxe Throwback Timepiece From Baume & Mercier
text: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Baume & Mercier.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Crisis in Greece and at Home
text: Nikos Pilos specializes in covering crisis. For the last 10 years, that has kept him busy chronicling his homeland’s economic and social problems.

headline: Readers Divided on the Legality of Drone Strikes
text: For many readers who commented on our editorial this morning about the legal underpinning of a fatal drone strike, the issue is an easy one: Anwar al-Awlaki may have been an American citizen, but he was obviously a terrorist, because he had aligned himself with a branch of Al Qaeda. Thus the United States was right in 2011 to kill him (and his son) in a drone strike in Yemen.

headline: Big Ten Joins Pac-12 in Pressing the N.C.A.A. to Make Changes
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — For the second time in a month, every university president belonging to an athletic conference has jointly issued a public letter calling for change within the N.C.A.A.

headline: Nostalgia on the Air
text: It’s ’90s teenage-show nostalgia week on Walt Disney Company networks, where a pair of new shows are built on memories of series that went off the air just as the current century was starting.

headline: Everything You Need for the Perfect Picnic
text: To Share: They’ll Even Let You Borrow the Basket

headline: A Hunt to Find the Next Generation of Financial Advisers
text: Joseph H. Clinard Jr. is 76 and spends his days planning for retirement — just not his own.

headline: The Life Behind a Fashionable Front
text: More dutiful than elegant, “Yves Saint Laurent” is one of two new dramas about that beatified French fashion designer. The other feature, Bertrand Bonello’s “Saint Laurent,” had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival last month and posits, with flair and humor, a certain sensual mystery about the shy but passionate couturier and his work. Jalil Lespert’s authorized biopic is the first out of the gate in the United States, however, and it trots out a polite recounting of Saint Laurent’s life in its prime.

headline: Archivist Faults I.R.S. for Not Reporting Loss of Emails
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service did not follow the law when it failed to report a hard drive crash that destroyed emails belonging to a senior official at the center of a scandal over the agency’s treatment of conservative-leaning political groups, the nation’s top archivist said Tuesday.

headline: From Liner Notes to Front Lines of Advocacy
text: “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step: Notes on the Life of Nat Hentoff” is very much in step with the enthusiasms of its nobly bearded 89-year-old subject, the critic Nat Hentoff. The director David L. Lewis presents a man who’s all about the voice — letting it sing, as in the instrumental improvisations of the jazz he loves, and keeping it alive, through his dogmatic defense of the First Amendment.

headline: Ford Expands Truck Recall After Supplier Reviews Records
text: Ford said Tuesday that it was increasing the number of 2014 F-150 pickups it was recalling for a possible steering loss problem from the 372 announced earlier this month to almost 5,700, including about 4,600 in the United States.

headline: Gentlemen Take a Bow in a Theater Tribute
text: “The good Lord created black people, and black people created everything else!”

headline: The Self-Promotion Backlash
text: From “building your personal brand” to “stepping up your social media presence,” we’re constantly inundated with advice about how to promote ourselves. But some are saying that the pressure to self-promote could, ultimately, be hurting us.

headline: Still Together, but Prickly
text: At Rockwood Music Hall on Monday night, Alex Kinsey and Sierra Deaton told a story of how reality television works to create its own reality. As a duo, Alex & Sierra, they were contestants, and eventual winners, on last year’s season of “The X Factor,” the show’s last. A couple, they were visibly enamored of each other. The notoriously sour Simon Cowell was their mentor.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Mediations and Mutiny Backstage
text: The open, empty violin case backstage at Avery Fisher Hall stood as a stark reminder that Glenn Dicterow, the longest-serving concertmaster in the history of the New York Philharmonic, would retire after Saturday night’s concert. It awaited the return of the 1727 Guarneri del Gesù violin that the Philharmonic had lent him as its first among equals.

headline: Improvising With Passion
text: “Transformation: Rhythm’s Roots,” a collaboration between the veteran jazz musician Owen Brown Jr. and the first-rate tap dancer Jason Samuels Smith, advertises itself as a musical response to the recent Oscar-winning film “12 Years a Slave.” But its subject is actually much broader: the hundreds of years of African-American experience from enslavement to the present.

headline: Arias in the Park on a Summer’s Eve
text: If you’re an opera lover looking for a typical young-artist concert, there are four outdoor dates coming up in July to satisfy you, courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera’s annual Summer Recital Series. Three up-and-comers from the company’s roster will be traveling through New York City parks with sunny standards, including the Barcarolle from Offenbach’s “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” and “Là ci darem la mano” from Mozart’s “Don Giovanni.”

headline: Spoons for the Picky
text: In the beginning there was the Word, and the Word was naughty, and then Jonathan Adler put it on a throw pillow.

headline: No Matter the Political Climate, the Conversation on Twitter Turns to the Weather
text: Voters headed back to polling places in Mississippi on Tuesday to cast ballots in the runoff between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Senator Chris McDaniel. In keeping with a race that has generated its share of political conflict, Mr. Cochran’s and Mr. McDaniel’s partisans were active on Twitter describing Mississippi’s second day at the polls this month in a way that was helpful to their candidates. But it seemed like many voters on social media were more concerned with today’s weather than with the state’s political climate.

headline: World Cup Fashion
text: The World Cup — a.k.a. one of the largest sports fashion catwalks in the world.

headline: The World Cup Winners
text: If you, like me, have walked down a city street sometime in the last two weeks — any city street, really, in any city — there’s a good chance you passed someone (or, indeed, many someones) wearing, say, a lurid yellow shirt trimmed in green, or a slightly twee white polo-neck edged in blue, or a blood-red tee with black stripes. And then you, like me, may have scratched your head and thought, “Where are they getting their fashion cues from?”

headline: Ford Reveals All-New 2015 Edge Crossover
text: Ford has announced its all-new 2015 Edge crossover. Using the same vehicle architecture as the Ford Fusion, the Edge features a front camera for better visibility, adaptive cruise control and inflatable seat belts, Ford said in a statement released Tuesday.

headline: Mets Recall d’Arnaud From AAA
text: The Mets recalled the highly regarded catcher Travis d’Arnaud on Tuesday after a 15-game respite in Class AAA to help him retool his swing and rediscover his confidence at the plate.

headline: Taking Effective Action Against the Unstoppable
text: Climate change is not an event in your children’s future. It is bearing down upon you now. And there is nothing you — or anyone else — can do to prevent the hit.
