headline: At Christie’s London Auction, Little Action
text: LONDON – In a hushed salesroom at Christie’s on Tuesday night, paintings and sculptures by Mondrian, Giacometti, Picasso and Pissarro failed to sell, and many things that did sell went for well below their estimates.

headline: Capturing Employees’ Expertise on Camera Before They Hit the Exits
text: SEATTLE — Before a valuable employee quits a job, how does a company make sure a bit of his or her magic stays behind?

headline: George Lucas Shifts Museum Plan to Chicago
text: The filmmaker George Lucas — who struggled to get permission from officials in San Francisco to build a private museum dedicated to his collection of illustrations, comic art, graphic art, animation and other popular art forms — will instead build the museum in Chicago, where he lives part time, said a spokeswoman for Mayor Rahm Emanuel in Chicago on Tuesday.

headline: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Nigeria, 3-2
text: Led by Lionel Messi, who scored two goals, Argentina topped the Group F with a 3-2 win over Nigeria, who also advanced.

headline: World Cup 2014: Bosnia Defeats Iran, 3-1
text: Iran’s slim hopes came to an end and the Bosnians are left wondering what might have been had they played like this against Nigeria.

headline: World Cup 2014: Switzerland Defeats Honduras, 3-0
text: The Swiss are through, with Ecuador drawing with France 0-0, and with those three points will take the second spot in Group E.

headline: World Cup 2014: Ecuador and France Play to a 0-0 Draw
text: The French goal-scoring machine sputtered to a halt, but that did not do Ecuador any good as it was eliminated in the 0-0 draw.

headline: Waiting in the Wings, a Ballerina to Save the Day
text: For the role of Odette-Odile in “Swan Lake” a dancer must achieve one of ballet’s most extreme transformations: from fragile and distant as the swan queen, Odette, to devilish and seductive as the antiheroine, Odile. On Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater began its weeklong run of the ballet, that metamorphosis was interrupted by a more real-world kind of fragility. An announcement at intermission informed us that because of an injury, Gillian Murphy, our leading lady thus far, would not complete the performance; Hee Seo would take her place, swooping in for the Black Swan pas de deux and Odette’s final lakeside moments.

headline: A Neo-Nazi’s Political Rise Exposes a German City’s Ethnic Tensions
text: DORTMUND, Germany — He is known here as SS-Siggi, and with his bulky frame and “Germania” tattoos, he certainly looks the part.

headline: Oklahoma G.O.P. Nominates House Member to Replace Sen. Coburn
text: WASHINGTON — Oklahoma Republicans nominated Representative James Lankford for the Senate seat now held by Tom Coburn in a state that has not sent a Democrat to the Senate in three decades.

headline: Breaking the Law to Go Online in Iran
text: WASHINGTON — WHEN Anthony Bourdain posted a cryptic message on Facebook at the end of May that he and his television crew would be off the social media grid for the next 10 days because they were “truly going to #PartsUnknown,” his fans around the world were intrigued. Was he shooting his CNN show (titled “Parts Unknown”) in a remote desert or on top of a snowy Himalayan peak?

headline: Rethinking the Word ‘Foodie’
text: At a dinner party the other night where people were asked to say a word about themselves, one woman said, “My name is” — whatever it was — “and I’m a foodie.” I cringed.

headline: Errant Rocket in Gaza Is Said to Kill Girl, 3
text: GAZA — A 3-year-old Palestinian girl was killed, and three of her relatives were wounded Tuesday evening, apparently when a rocket aimed at Israel fell short and instead hit the family’s home in the northern Gaza Strip.

headline: ‘Redskins’ Is Bad Business
text: ATLANTA, Ga. — THE moral arguments against the Washington Redskins’ team name, which is considered offensive to American Indians, are by now well known, especially in the wake of last week’s decision by the United States Patent and Trademark Office to strip the team of trademark protections.

headline: Shift in Law on Disability and Students Shows Lapses
text: Fewer than a third of states and territories now comply with federal disability law under a change announced Tuesday in the way the Department of Education evaluates how well public schools educate students with disabilities.

headline: When Nadal Is the Opponent at Wimbledon, a Hammer Is Required
text: WIMBLEDON, England — There was only one way that Martin Klizan was going to defeat Rafael Nadal on Center Court at Wimbledon on Tuesday.

headline: Questions Rebels Use to Tell Sunni From Shiite
text: BAGHDAD — Whether a person is a Shiite or a Sunni Muslim in Iraq can now be, quite literally, a matter of life and death.

headline: The Tappan Zee Bridge Loan
text: When it rains hard in New York, outdated municipal waste treatment plants often fail, sending untreated sewage into state waterways. Upgrading old plants and building new ones has long depended heavily on the federal Clean Water State Revolving Fund. It is capitalized with state and federal money, makes loans to needy municipalities and is constantly under pressure from budget-conscious legislators on Capitol Hill.

headline: Indie Music’s Digital Drag
text: The booze flowed freely in New York last week at the Libera Awards, a three-year-old alternative Grammys for the world of independent music, as awards went to prestige indie acts like Arcade Fire and Arctic Monkeys and executives at small labels congratulated one another about what a great year it was for their music.

headline: Iran: Harvard Scholar’s Body Cremated After Request for Burial in Iran Falters
text: Richard Nelson Frye, a renowned Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered Iranian hard-liners, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday. The Iranian Students’ News Agency quoted Dr. Frye’s Iranian colleague Turaj Daryaii as saying the family had waited more than two months for official Iranian permission to bury him in Isfahan, the ancient capital of the Persian Empire, before deciding to cremate him on June 8. It was not clear what the family intended to do with his ashes. Dr. Frye, who died on March 27 at age 94, had dedicated his career to Iran’s culture and language, and he had written the burial request into his will. He was widely regarded in Iran as a friend, even among some conservatives, but his death coincided with growing resentment by Iranian hard-liners over signs of reconciliation with the United States after decades of estrangement. A month after Dr. Frye died, the leader of Friday Prayer in Isfahan denounced his burial request, calling him a spy and a robber of cultural artifacts.

headline: France: Court Rules on End-of-Life Case
text: France’s highest administrative court, the Conseil d’État, ruled Tuesday that a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the country’s end-of-life legislation. Before a 2008 accident left the man, Vincent Lambert, a former psychiatric nurse, paralyzed and unresponsive, he had repeatedly said he did not wish to be kept alive in such a condition, according to his wife and several family members, who have sought for him to be allowed to die. Given that, the court found that the feeding tube that has kept Mr. Lambert alive could be considered “unreasonable” medical “obstinacy,” and could be legally removed. Mr. Lambert’s parents, who oppose that, have appealed to the European Court of Human Rights, and Mr. Lambert will be kept alive during the months or years of that court’s examination of the case. French law prohibits any medical acts explicitly intended to end a patient’s life, but authorizes doctors to withdraw treatment or administer lethal doses of painkillers under certain circumstances.

headline: Washington State to Require Approval of Packaging for Edible Marijuana Products
text: SEATTLE — Washington State will require its approval of all packaging for edible marijuana products, Gov. Jay Inslee said Tuesday, a pre-emptory move to ban cartoons, toy images and any other labels that might appeal to children.

headline: De Blasio Offers Easier Access to City Money for Special Education
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a series of changes on Tuesday to make it easier for special-needs students in New York to receive private schooling at public expense, a practice that has led to frequent litigation as the city has tried to keep such spending under control.

headline: Woods Is Returning to Action, but Is No Longer in a Rush
text: BETHESDA, Md. — After all the best doctors and all the best aids put Tiger Woods back together again, he returns to competition knowing that he will have only one guide, one source of feedback.

headline: Premium-Cigar Exemption Traced
text: Documents released by the federal government on Tuesday provided clues about how premium cigars got special treatment in federal tobacco regulations proposed recently. The rules, written by the Food and Drug Administration, originally subjected all cigars to federal regulation. But a proposal to exempt premium cigars surfaced after the rules were submitted to the White House for editing last year, the documents show. Matthew L. Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, an advocacy group, said an exemption, if made final, would set a troubling precedent for the future of tobacco regulation.

headline: ISIS and SISI
text: The past month has presented the world with what the Israeli analyst Orit Perlov describes as the two dominant Arab governing models: ISIS and SISI.

headline: Tea Party Mischief on Exports
text: In one of their odder quests, some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States, an obscure but important federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad.

headline: Corruption Sweep at Rikers Island Leads to 22 Arrests
text: A sweep by law enforcement authorities at Rikers Island, part of a monthslong investigation into wrongdoing at the jail complex, led to the arrests of two correction officers on Monday night and more than 20 inmates on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Shake Up Corporate Japan
text: Even for the land that invented Toyota-style efficiency, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is on a tear. His ruling Liberal Democratic Party pushed 98 percent of its bills through Parliament, a success rate not seen in Japan for over a decade.

headline: Refusals to Pay High Drug Prices
text: Pharmacy benefit managers are ramping up efforts to rein in the rising prices that drug makers are charging for some prescription medicines. The trend holds both promise and peril for patients who depend on the drugs to control their illnesses.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Rebuffed
text: A Federal District Court judge on Tuesday rejected a request by a high-profile detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, that the judge order his release because he is suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments. The habeas corpus challenge was brought in April on behalf of Shaker Aamer, 45, a Saudi citizen and former British resident. Judge Rosemary M. Collyer gave her rejection in a terse one-page order; an accompanying memorandum opinion explaining her reasoning was sealed. The Justice Department’s filings in the case were also sealed, but Judge Collyer ordered it to file a public version of her order and its documents by July 9.

headline: Cracker Jack Wants to Break Out of the Ballpark
text: IT would be impossible to put a dollar value on how much “Take Me Out to the Ball Game,” the 1908 song ritually sung by baseball fans during the seventh-inning stretch, has had for the 121-year-old snack named in the refrain, “Buy me some peanuts and Cracker Jack.” But in a segment for “On the Media,” the syndicated public radio show produced by WNYC, Mike Pesca once tried to assess the value, equating it with Cracker Jack placing an advertisement along outfield walls of all of the major league’s 30 stadiums, a marketing campaign that would cost the brand about $25 million a year.

headline: Massachusetts: Court Allows Public to Vote on Repealing Casino Law
text: The state’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a proposal to repeal the state’s expanded casino gambling law can appear on the ballot this fall. The ruling by the Supreme Judicial Court overturned a decision by Attorney General Martha Coakley, setting the stage for what is likely to be a closely watched and expensive campaign. The 2011 law allows for up to three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor to be built in the state. Casino opponents say they have more than twice as many signatures than required to get the question on the ballot; those signatures are being certified. One license has been provisionally awarded in Springfield, pending the outcome of the repeal effort; the slots parlor is under construction in Plainville.

headline: Blue, as in Happy
text: NATAL, Brazil — Victory, even in the group stage of the World Cup, can make Uruguayans feel like champions again.

headline: Manhattan District Attorney’s Office Showing No Leniency in Daredevil Cases
text: Three men who parachuted off the World Trade Center and a speeding driver who circled Manhattan in 24 minutes have attracted plenty of fans on YouTube — thrilling helmet- or dashboard-camera videos of their stunts have been played tens of thousands of times.

headline: After Opening Way to Rebels, Turkey Is Paying Heavy Price
text: HABUR BORDER GATE, Turkey — In normal times, hauling 50,000 pounds of frozen chicken into Iraq is a routine job for Turfan Aydin, a Turkish trucker who has been working the route for years. But the cross-border trade has suddenly all but halted, locked up by the insurgent offensive in Iraq and the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.

headline: Vast Stretches of Minnesota Are Flooded as Swollen Rivers Overflow
text: CHICAGO — Minnesota was besieged on Tuesday by some of its most widespread flooding in years. Water spilled onto streets in downtown St. Paul, crops of soybeans and corn were damaged and a state of emergency was declared in 35 counties.

headline: Tying Federal Aid to College Ratings
text: College and university leaders have been up in arms since President Obama announced last year that the administration would soon deploy a rating system that evaluates schools based on factors like affordability, graduation rates, student earnings and how well institutions serve low-income students. Mr. Obama wants Congress to use the ratings to help guide the allocation of federal student loans and grants.

headline: Clashing Rulings Weigh Security and Liberties
text: WASHINGTON — In two major Federal District Court rulings addressing trade-offs between government powers and individual rights, judges in Oregon on Tuesday upheld a 2008 law permitting warrantless surveillance but struck down a key aspect of the so-called no-fly list that blocks people suspected of terrorism ties from boarding planes.

headline: Suit in Jogger Case May Be Settled, but Questions Aren’t
text: A check for $40 million, or whatever amount of money, can’t settle the history of the Central Park jogger case.

headline: Doubting Putin, Obama Prepares to Add Pressure
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has drawn up plans to escalate sanctions against Russia by targeting its financial, energy and defense industries, but faces resistance from European allies hoping to avoid a broader economic clash with Moscow that would hurt their own businesses.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Stars Take Lead on Risks of Heading
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Long before millions of Americans decided that the United States men’s soccer team was so cool that they couldn’t live without tuning in to watch it, the players on the 1999 women’s national team — remember them? — had set the bar for the sport’s popularity.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 24, 2014
Contract Offer Scorned, L.I.R.R. Faces Strike
text: Fearing a strike on the Long Island Rail Road, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Tuesday that it had expanded its offer to union leaders, granting “everything that they’ve asked for,” with raises of 17 percent over seven years.

headline: Long Absent, Nuclear Expert Still Has Hold on Iran Talks
text: VIENNA — As a team of Iranian negotiators parried with the West last week in increasingly heated negotiations over where the country will be forced to dismantle many of its nuclear facilities, one mysterious figure was conspicuously missing.

headline: 3 Die as Truck Hits Disabled Vehicle on New Jersey Interstate
text: Three men were killed in a crash on a highway in northern New Jersey on Tuesday when a tractor-trailer hit a disabled truck on the shoulder of the road, the authorities said.

headline: Narrow Shift by Washington on Oil Exports
text: As the oil industry pushes the Obama administration to lift a longstanding ban on the export of crude oil, the Commerce Department has granted two Texas companies permits to export a light, processed form of oil, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Like That’s Gonna Happen
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people like to start their crossword puzzles in the same place every time (Holla, my 1 Across-starting posse!) and others dive in anywhere they feel they can gain a toehold.

headline: American Players, Dual Allegiances
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The round-table discussion with Jermaine Jones was standing room only on Tuesday morning at the United States national team’s World Cup training base. But if not for a manager’s tough choice, Jones just might have been holding court at Germany’s camp in Brazil instead, ahead of the United States’ final Group G game Thursday, between the teams.

headline: U.S. Team Recuperates From Humidity of Manaus
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Four teams have returned to the field in this World Cup after having played matches in the heat and humidity of remote Manaus.

headline: Election Results for New York’s 13th Congressional District
text: Precinct maps of the vote in 2014 and 2012.

headline: A Highway Doubling as a Haven
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Near dusk on a recent Sunday afternoon, a crowd of about 50 people mingled around a makeshift stage while warbling, in sloppy karaoke, the lyrics to the Brazilian song “Que Se Chama Amor” (or “That Is Called Love”). Nearby, a group of women sipped wine from paper cups while watching a group of boys kick a soccer ball back and forth. Next to them, a pair of families pushed strollers.

headline: Lawyer Says Boy in Killing May Go Before Grand Jury
text: After a teenager was arrested and charged last week with fatally stabbing a fellow student outside their Bronx middle school, two troubled young lives came into public view.

headline: New York City Council Expected to Approve 2 Plans Aiding Immigrants
text: A long-sought initiative that would provide municipal identification cards to all New Yorkers, including those without legal immigration status, has been finalized, and will come before the City Council for a vote this week, officials said.

headline: A String of Sexual Assaults Puts a Bronx Area on Alert
text: Young people in some parts of the Bronx have a lot to contend with as warmer months arrive. There is a lack of organized activities, residents complain, and few summer jobs. More alarming, around playgrounds, parks and some weekend parties, bullets fly with increasing frequency.

headline: A Battery of Newfound Offense Helps the Mets Romp Yet Again
text: Forget, for a moment, the three home runs hit by the Mets in the first three innings. Forget the nine hits, the seven runs, the newfound aggression, the situational execution.

headline: Yanks’ Rally Goes for Naught As Misplays Prove Undoing
text: TORONTO — The Yankees’ slumbering bats erupted Tuesday night, but poor defense — including two misplays in the same inning by shortstop Derek Jeter — ultimately cost the Yankees in a 7-6 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: John McClure Dies at 84; Produced Classic Records
text: John McClure, a producer and engineer who helped shape some of the most celebrated classical recordings of the 20th century, including acclaimed sessions with Bruno Walter, Igor Stravinsky and Leonard Bernstein, died on June 17 at his home in Belmont, Vt. He was 84.

headline: A Senator Wins a Race He Mulled Not Running
text: JACKSON, Miss. — The question seemed to tug at Senator Thad Cochran throughout his bumpy re-election campaign in Mississippi: Why, after a long, distinguished career — 42 years in Congress, including six terms in the Senate — was he seeking a seventh term?

headline: Establishment Choice Is G.O.P. Pick for Colorado Governor
text: DENVER — Bob Beauprez, a buffalo rancher and a former congressman and community banker, defeated three rivals in a crowded Republican primary election on Tuesday to become his party’s choice to take on Colorado’s governor this November, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Toronto’s Baseball Revival Playing to Reduced Audiences
text: TORONTO — In a city where the last playoff baseball game took place 20 seasons ago, the Blue Jays have been in first place for more than a month. The last time that happened, in 1993, Toronto won the World Series.

headline: Croatian Tennis Star Cilic Rebounds From Suspension, Coached by His Idol
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Marin Cilic was not yet born when Goran Ivanisevic made his Wimbledon debut in the summer of 1988, beginning an often tortuous history at the All England Club.

headline: Former White House Aide Wins G.O.P. Congressional Primary in New York
text: A pair of young Republican candidates emerged from bruising primaries on Tuesday in two congressional districts in New York State where Republicans hope to win Democratic-held seats in November.

headline: Tour a New Building Made of Corn and Mushrooms at MoMA PS1
text: Each year, the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 co-sponsor of the Young Architects Program — a contest in which emerging talents compete for the chance to build a temporary structure in PS1’s courtyard in Long Island City. The projects remain on-site for the duration of each summer, providing both shade and interactivity for PS1 visitors and attendees of the museum’s popular “Warm Up” outdoor concert series.

headline: Time Inc. to Start 120 Sports, a Digital Network, With Pro Leagues
text: It’s a sports network catering to the shortened attention spans of the mobile and social media generation: 240 clips, each two minutes long, across eight hours of daily programming.

headline: For Fitness, Push Yourself
text: Intense exercise changes the body and muscles at a molecular level in ways that milder physical activity doesn’t match, according to an enlightening new study. Though the study was conducted in mice, the findings add to growing scientific evidence that to realize the greatest benefits from workouts, we probably need to push ourselves.

headline: Word of the Day | satirical
text: satirical •\sə-ˈtir-i-kəl\• adjective

headline: Eli Wallach, Multifaceted Actor on Stage and Screen, Dies at 98
text: Eli Wallach, who was one of his generation’s most prominent and prolific character actors in film, onstage and on television for more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Big Jump in Turnout Is Key in Thad Cochran’s Victory
text: Turnout hadn’t increased in a Senate runoff primary election in 30 years until Tuesday night, when a momentous surge of voters allowed Senator Thad Cochran to defeat Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, in Mississippi’s Republican Senate runoff.

headline: In Rematch, Rangel Holds Lead in a Tight House Primary Race
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, seeking a 23rd term, held a slim lead in a fierce battle early Wednesday with State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in their primary election contest, a rematch that was largely fought along ethnic and generational lines.

headline: Voters in Mississippi React to Senator Thad Cochran’s Runoff Victory on Twitter
text: After the heated campaign in the Republican Senate runoff between Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel, voters in Mississippi were ready to sound off on social media about what the race meant. Their perspectives suggested that although this particular day of voting was over, the lessons from the contest were not settled.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) YOUNG & HUNGRY Gabi (Emily Osment), a sassy food blogger hoping to become the personal chef of Josh (Jonathan Sadowski, above with Ms. Osment), a wealthy tech entrepreneur, must prepare a romantic meal for him and his girlfriend as a test to get the job. But when the dinner goes awry, Gabi transforms the disaster into a chance not only for employment but maybe even love. Ashley Tisdale is an executive producer of this new series, inspired by the musings of Gabi Moskowitz, the San Francisco food blogger behind Brokeass Gourmet. Annie Potts, Kym Whitley, Rex Lee and Aimee Carrero round out the cast.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 25, 2014
text: “This is a football World Cup, not about morality, cheap morality.”

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: June 25, 2014
text: What to watch for in today’s games, as teams from Groups E and F battle to advance in the World Cup. For the complete rundown of advancing scenarios, please visit The Upshot.

headline: Cochran and McDaniel Address Supporters
text: Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel delivered remarks to their supporters after the Republican primary.

headline: Student Crossword | Building Blocks of Vocabulary
text: Test your knowledge of vocabulary and its foundations by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: To: Chinese Embassy, United States; Address: No. 1 Liu Xiaobo Plaza
text: Updated, 3:42 a.m.ET|

headline: Sanskrit Newspaper Sees Business Model in New Government
text: The Saturday after Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party’s historic victory in the country’s parliamentary elections was announced, some 40,000 subscribers to a weekly Sanskrit newspaper woke up to a resounding headline:

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Cool at 13, Adrift at 23
text: In “Cool at 13, Adrift at 23,” Jan Hoffman writes about a new study that followed risk-taking, socially precocious middle school students for a decade.

headline: Bobby Flay’s Chicken Surprise
text: Bobby Flay opened a new restaurant, Gato, a few months ago on Lafayette Street in Manhattan. Flay has been a celebrity for the better part of two decades. But he works in the open kitchen at Gato the way people do when they come to New York to make a name for themselves: head down, concentrating, hard. “It’s all I want to do now,” he said recently.

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Hip-Hop’s Newest Old-School Star
text: ‘Everybody just wants to have fun, be with the scene,” Kendrick Lamar said when we met in his cramped quarters inside the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last fall. “Certain people get backstage, people that you would never expect. . . . You ain’t with the media! You ain’t into music! You ain’t into sports! You’re just here.” The rapper, now 27, had just finished his set as the opening act on this stretch of Kanye West’s Yeezus tour, and he was sitting low in an armchair in his trademark black hoodie surrounded by exactly those people.

headline: Ask Well: Diagnosing Fatty Liver
text: Recently, in “Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity,” Anahad O’Connor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about fatty liver.

headline: Crisis in Greece and at Home
text: Nikos Pilos’s career highlights include a stint in Lebanon during the 1988 civil war, coverage of the Yugoslav wars a couple of years later and 100 days living with civilians outside the Green Zone during the height of the Iraq war.

headline: Elvis Costello Treats Carnegie Hall to a Solo Show
text: If Elvis Costello had dived any deeper into his catalog for his solo concert on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand at Carnegie Hall, he would have needed scuba gear. It wasn’t the kind of solo show by an established rocker that treats a bunch of old favorites as guitar-strumming singalongs for longtime fans. The hall was often silent as Mr. Costello offered something else: a continuing, challenging, intimate engagement with his songs, old and new.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Reading Room Refugees
text: Good morning on this damp Wednesday.

headline: China Unveils New Map of South China Sea
text: China is standing tall over its expansive claims to territory in the South China Sea. This week, Hunan Map Publishing House unveiled a new map of China — a vertical representation of the country that includes the vast body of water south of Hainan Island. China’s assertions of ownership in the South China Sea have put it at odds with at least four Southeast Asian nations, which have competing claims, and with the United States, which has said that China’s actions in the region — including having a state-owned oil company place an exploratory oil rig near the Vietnamese coast in May — are creating instability.

headline: New Area of Seafloor Is Mapped in Jet Search
text: CANBERRA, Australia — A commercial vessel under contract from the Australian government has begun mapping the floor of the southern Indian Ocean in preparation for a renewed search for Malaysia Airlines’ missing Flight 370, but that search has been complicated by a complete lack of satellite images of the new search area from the week after the plane disappeared.

headline: David Cameron’s Losing Battle
text: Selecting the president of the European Commission, the powerful executive branch of the European Union, has always entailed a lot of politicking and bluster, and there’s been no shortage of that in advance of a meeting of European leaders later this week. The difference this time is that Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is staunchly opposed to the likely pick, Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg, and that is shaping into a potential turning point for the entire European project. Mr. Cameron has a good case, but he should make sure that his looming defeat does not turn into an irrevocable march toward the “Brexit,” a British exit from the European Union.

headline: In Our Pages: June 26
text: 1939: Camp Ordered Abandoned

headline: Why Government Pension Funds Became Addicted to Risk
text: A public pension fund works like this: The government promises to make payments to its employees after they retire; it invests money now and uses those investments, and the returns on them, to make those promised payments later.

headline: Citizen of the State of New York
text: Is state citizenship the answer to immigration reform?

headline: Morning Views
text: “Some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States,” a federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad, writes The New York Times’s editorial board. “The bank provides loans and loan guarantees to foreign businesses to help them buy American products and services.” The board is critical in particular of the efforts of Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas, who is “leading the charge” against the bank and appears oblivious to the fact that “if the United States dismantled the bank unilaterally, as some lawmakers are advocating, American companies could lose billions of dollars in overseas orders and decide to move their operations to other countries that provide generous export financing.”

headline: In the Darkness of Myanmar’s Camps, Lighter Moments of Life
text: Adam B. Ellick has been a senior video journalist at The Times for eight years. This month a documentary that he made with the columnist Nicholas D. Kristof drew so much attention from the international Muslim community that, for the first time, The Times released an Arabic translation of the video. It was released on Monday. Below, Adam shares some footage that was cut from the main documentary.

headline: What We Learned By Doing Employee Reviews
text: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to re-institute employee reviews.

headline: Delivery Drones Grounded by F.A.A.
text: Delivery drones have barely taken off and they’re already being grounded.

headline: Iran Secretly Sending Drones and Supplies Into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
text: BRUSSELS — Iran is directing surveillance drones over Iraq from an airfield in Baghdad and is supplying Iraqi forces with tons of military equipment and other supplies, according to American officials.

headline: Daily Report: Small Music Labels Say YouTube Employs Strong-Arm Tactics
text: Last year was seen as a great one for indie music, but anxiety about competition and fairness in the digital marketplace runs deep in the independent sector of the music industry. Small labels complain that consolidation by the major record companies has left them squeezed in negotiations with the online music services that now account for a majority of their revenue, Ben Sisario reports.

headline: German Leader Shrugs Off British Opposition on E.U. Post
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany made it clear on Wednesday that Britain would fail if it tried to stop the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as the next head of the European Commission.

headline: East African Court Blocks Paved Serengeti Highway
text: Since 2010, conservationists and wildlife biologists have been fighting Tanzania’s plan to build a paved national highway through the northern part of Serengeti National Park — directly across a migratory path for millions of wildebeests and other grazing mammals.

headline: The Lively Soul of a Decaying City
text: DETROIT — “There are cities that get by on their good looks, offer climate and scenery, views of mountains or oceans, rockbound or with palm trees,” Elmore Leonard wrote. “And there are cities like Detroit that have to work for a living.”

headline: North Korea Warns U.S. Over Film Mocking Its Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea — For years, anaylsts have said that one of the best kept secrets inside North Korea was that the despotic and often virulently anti-American leader at the time, Kim Jong-il, was a closet fan of Hollywood blockbusters, especially James Bond films. His son, the nation’s current leader, appeared to have picked up the bug, allowing the “Rocky” theme to be played at a special state concert.

headline: Angela Ahrendts Finally Speaks at Apple, and It Is Not What You Expect
text: O.K., that’s a bit of an exaggeration. Angela Ahrendts, the former Burberry chief executive lured away to revitalize Apple retail and e-tail did not exactly speak — she wrote a diary entry-cum-inspirational post about her new job, titled “Starting Anew,” on LinkedIn.

headline: Judge Dismisses British Hacking Jury, Hung on Remaining Charges
text: LONDON — It was an unspectacular denouement to Britain’s spectacular phone hacking trial: The jury was dismissed Wednesday after failing to reach a verdict on two outstanding charges against Andy Coulson, a former tabloid editor who had been found guilty of conspiracy to intercept voice mail messages a day earlier.

headline: Listen Up | A Brazilian Rock Band to Get You Into the World Cup Groove
text: It’s World Cup season, and native Brazilians can’t get enough of the attention. “My country is living and breathing soccer more than usual,” says Rafael Rocha, the frontman for the band Wannabe Jalva, which is based in Porto Alegre in the south of the country. “Brazil has kind of stopped for a bit.” Rocha and his bandmates Felipe Puperi, Fernando Paulista and Tiago Abrahão are in an especially celebratory mood these days: they’ve just finished their upcoming, as-yet-untitled EP, and are planning to take their sound — which they’ve curiously taken to calling “uterus-space-groove-rock” — global. “That’s a term we put together only because everybody needs a label,” Rocha explains. “We have so many influences, from newer acts like Queens of the Stone Age to older ones like the Doors. We also have a funk and soul vibe going on. Our music somehow links all of that together … we try not to place any boundaries on ourselves.”

headline: ABC Anchor Shift Signals Morning’s Triumph
text: ABC News on Wednesday announced sweeping changes among its top news personalities, with Diane Sawyer to step down as anchor of the network’s evening newscast in August, replaced by David Muir, a rising star anchor at the network.

text: MADRID — The Spanish monarchy was dragged deeper into a corruption case on Wednesday when Princess Cristina was charged with tax fraud and money laundering by a judge investigating whether her husband and business associates had embezzled millions of dollars in public funds earmarked for sports events.

text: The beginning of the year was not just bad for the United States economy; it was — on paper at least — the worst quarter since the last recession ended five years ago.

headline: Morning Agenda: Searching for Young Financial Advisers
text: A HUNT FOR YOUNG FINANCIAL ADVISERS  |  Wall Street has an aging problem. The average financial adviser in the United States is older than 50, a number that shows no sign of getting lower because relatively few young people are interested in the work, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. Now, as Wall Street turns more to asset management, it must figure out how to attract and retain a fresh pool of talent that is increasingly looking to find its riches elsewhere.

text: Citing copyright law, the justices rejected the streaming service’s model of capturing broadcast signals and delivering them to subscribers.

headline: Rangel Leads in Democratic House Primary
text: The Democratic primary between Representative Charles B. Rangel and his challenger State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat is still too close to call despite a declaration of victory from Mr. Rangel.

headline: With History in Mind, Black Voters in Mississippi Aided Cochran

text: Fifty years ago this week, three young civil rights activists — Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman — vanished in Neshoba County, Miss.

headline: Mountain Lakes, N.J.: A ‘Resort Getaway’ to Call Home
text: Before Herbert J. Hapgood came to Mountain Lakes in 1910, the area was largely woodlands. Over the next dozen years, Mr. Hapgood built a planned community of hundreds of large, Arts-and-Crafts-style houses on lush grounds as summer homes for wealthy New Yorkers. After the Lackawanna Railroad built a station here in 1912, families began seeing Mountain Lakes as a permanent residence.

headline: A Closer Look at 10 of Masterpiece London’s Finest Offerings
text: Sandwiched between Royal Ascot and the Henley Royal Regatta, the fifth edition of Masterpiece London, the annual fine art and antiques fair, opens its doors tomorrow. For one week, everything from 19th-century Italian paintings to a 2013 Italian Maserati will be up for sale on the South Grounds of the historic Royal Hospital Chelsea.“The London Season has made its return,” says the event’s chairman, Philip Hewat-Jaboor, “and I see Masterpiece very much as the glue that cements the astonishing array of activities in these summer months.”

headline: At 30 Rock, Recreating Rotunda With a Nod to the Past
text: There was a time in the 1930s and ’40s when the excitement of attending an NBC broadcast at Rockefeller Center began long before you were ushered into Studio 6B, where Bob Hope held forth, or the astonishing 1,500-seat Studio 8H, home of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra.

headline: The No-Fly List Is Unconstitutional
text: The federal government’s no-fly list, which prevents those suspected of terrorist ties from boarding flights in the United States or flying through American airspace, is reported to include more than 20,000 names—a number that metastasized after the Sept. 11 attacks. There’s a low evidentiary standard for getting on the list. Once on, it’s not only difficult to get off but almost impossible to find out why, exactly, one was added in the first place.

headline: Germany Can Inflict Pain on the U.S., as It Has Before

headline: N.F.L. Makes Open-Ended Commitment to Retirees in Concussion Suit
text: The N.F.L. has made an open-ended commitment to pay cash awards to retired players who have dementia and other conditions linked to repeated head hits, according to documents filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on Wednesday.

headline: Teddy Roosevelt’s Confederate Uncles
text: On June 19, 1864, the Confederacy lost one of its most effective weapons of the Civil War: In the Battle of Cherbourg off the coast of France, the Union warship Kearsarge sunk the notorious Confederate commerce raider, the Alabama. In its two-year career, the Alabama had claimed 65 ships, totaling $6 million, a huge hit to the Union war effort. The Alabama continued to wreak posthumous havoc after the war; since it had been built in England, in the late 1860s the United States pressed a claim for damages, even threatening to invade Canada as compensation.

headline: House Hunting in ... South Wales
text: A RENOVATED HISTORIC HOME NEAR SWANSEA

headline: For Budding Book Lovers
text: Reliability is one of the things book lovers cherish about books. The words books contain are the same on every reading; set a book down, and there it stays, until you are ready to pick it up again. But in two new picture books, “My Pet Book,” written and illustrated by Bob Staake (“The Red Lemon,” “Bluebird,” “The Donut Chef”) and “Brother Hugo and the Bear,” written by Katy Beebe and illustrated by S.D. Schindler, precious books go missing, and have to be found — or recreated.

headline: What It Takes to Legalize Sex Work
text: A bill introduced in Canada by Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s Conservative government would criminalize buying sexual services but would not necessarily make selling them illegal. It follows a Canadian Supreme Court ruling last year that overturned most laws governing the sex trade.

headline: Rangel Wins House Primary Rematch
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, who said he wanted to be able to decide on his own when to retire from a career in Congress that began in 1971, held off a determined challenge by State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat to win the Democratic primary for a 23rd term.

headline: ‘What Would You Think of Living in Luxembourg?’
text: Here’s the opposite of fun: One of your 5-year-old twins has fallen from a tall, dangerous playground apparatus, and possibly broken a bone, and so you are in an emergency room where English is not spoken, trying to have a type of conversation for which Berlitz doesn’t prepare you, and the pain and suffering and maybe long-term well-being of your kid hang in the balance.

headline: Restaurant Report: Suliko Restorani in Hollywood, Fla.
text: If you know Suliko Restorani, it’s probably because of the word-of-mouth reviews that flow among Soviet-bloc immigrants living in South Florida. Unmarked and unadvertised, Suliko opened in July 2013 at the back of Aquarius, a nondescript condominium in Hollywood, Fla., and quickly became the go-to spot for Russian speakers, until recently a majority of patrons.

headline: Scene City: Broadway Comes to Central Park
text: The Public Theater holds its annual gala for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Malaria Prevention, With Both Reward and Risk
text: Alassane Dicko shivered and sweated through part of his childhood. Sick with frequent bouts of malaria, he often missed school. His older brother died of malaria, and so did his best friend. This disease can be cured with a pill, yet it claims about 1,700 lives each day — mainly children in sub-Saharan Africa who don’t take this medicine within a week of falling sick. Even when kids survive, some remain disabled or irrecoverably behind in school. That’s why Dicko, now a malaria researcher at the University of Bamako in Mali, took matters into his own hands when he became a father.Dicko gives malaria medicine to his children before they get the disease during the rainy season — the period when the mosquito-borne illness peaks in Mali. Tourists do something similar by taking malaria drugs prophylactically on trips to Africa, but for decades, health officials have said that Africans should not do so, because the widespread use of a drug eventually renders that drug ineffective. However, Dicko, who studies malaria prevention, has come to believe that the immediate health benefits are worth that risk.After a decade of clinical trials demonstrated that the preventive measure reduces malaria cases by 75 percent, medical authorities reversed their position against it, in areas where it’s most effective. They decided that the number of lives saved outweighs the cost of losing these drugs eventually. “For every drug you give, you will increase the risk of drug resistance,” Dicko says. “But these drugs are efficacious right now, so why don’t we use them and save thousands of lives?”

headline: 36 Hours in Stockholm
text: If Stockholm residents seem particularly smug these days, it’s for good reason. The Swedish capital has long ranked among the loveliest in Europe, with an inner-city beauty characterized by stately architecture and graceful waterways. But openings in outlying neighborhoods — galleries in the north, boutiques in the south, a craft brewery in the suburbs, art in the archipelago — are expanding the limits of the city worth exploring. Add to that Stockholm’s exciting restaurant scene, born from the popular New Nordic food movement, and the hometown pride is perfectly understandable.

headline: Hy-Fi at MoMA PS1
text: In this exclusive video, T tours “Hy-Fi,” a new structure in the Long Island City, Queens museum’s courtyard built with bricks comprised of shredded corn stalks and fungus.

headline: Venus Williams Rallies From Early Hole at Wimbledon

At 34, without a title in a Grand Slam event since 2008 and with just one third-round appearance at a major since 2012, who can resist the temptation of asking?

headline: Classical Playlist: Verdi, Schubert, Michael Gordon and More
text: VERDI: ‘Don Carlo’Jon Vickers, Gré Brouwenstijn, Tito Gobbi and other singers.The Covent Garden Orchestra and Opera Chorus, Carlo Maria Giulini, conductor(Andromeda; three CDs)This live 1958 recording of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” from the Royal Opera in London, though not an ideal performance, is great to have. Of particular interest is Jon Vickers in the title role. Here, Vickers is early in his career before it became clear that he would be the great dramatic tenor of his generation, bringing a powerhouse voice and expressive intensity to roles like Wagner’s Tristan and Verdi’s Otello. This is Vickers in a more youthful, lyric mode, but still singing with chilling power and ardency, despite occasional moments of strain in his high range. The cast boasts Gré Brouwenstijn as Elisabetta, Tito Gobbi as Rodrigo, Fedora Barbieri as Eboli, and Boris Christoff as Filippo II. The great Carlo Maria Giulini conducts a majestic account of the score. The performance comes through cleanly on this remastered recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Q. and A. About Student Debt
text: Dire warnings about student debt have become so common that many people may have a hard time believing that the problem is often exaggerated, as I wrote in my column Tuesday. Sure enough, readers raised several thoughtful questions about the research in the column, which found that large student debts are rarer than widely believed.

headline: Too Much Creative License: Amnesty International Withdraws Iggy Pop Ad
text: The ad was a grabber. Posted a little over a week ago on the website of Amnesty International’s French-speaking division in Belgium, it showed the rock star Iggy Pop, his face battered and bruised, saying, “Justin Bieber is the future of rock ’n’ roll.” Underneath was the slogan: “Torture a man and he will tell you anything.” In smaller letters it continued: “Besides being inhumane, torture doesn’t work. Let’s stop it.”

headline: Appeals Court Rejects Utah’s Ban on Gay Marriage, Prodding Supreme Court
text: DENVER — Expanding a streak of legal victories for same-sex marriage, a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that states may not deny same-sex couples their “fundamental right” to marry, overturning Utah’s voter-approved ban on such unions.

headline: In Iraq, Switching Allegiance Once Again
text: For a few days last week before YouTube pulled the video, “Clanging of the Swords IV” gave a graphic visual account of the violence unfolding in Iraq. The hourlong reel is a mash-up of attacks, allegedly by militants with the Sunni extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, against Iraqi security forces: drive-by shootings; roadside bombings; a beheading. Like most jihadi videos, it has a soundtrack of atonal religious chanting.

headline: Movement and Space Have a Meet-Up
text: The choreographer Jill Sigman, it’s safe to say, is fueled by a sensitivity for perceiving the movement in nature and the nature in movement. Her latest work, “(Perma)Culture,” performed last Thursday at Danspace Project, gathers eight dancers, dozens of ceramic objects, several pieces of sod and a timekeeper — Mary Suk — to explore connections between movement research and permacultural design.

The biennial Brussels Flower Carpet, which combines art, architecture, and landscaping, this year celebrates the 50th anniversary of Turkish immigration in Belgium.

headline: How Select Home Care Is Coping With New Wage and Labor Regulations

The new regulations would push wages higher and require additional overtime hours, increasing costs for Select.

headline: Western Hemisphere Continues Its Romp Through World Cup
text: The World Cup already features an entire portion of the Round of 16 bracket that’s dedicated to South America. It includes Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Uruguay and guarantees that one (and only one) of those four teams will reach the semifinals.

headline: ‘Boomerang Kids’ Article Prompts a Rich Range of Views
text: Within an hour of its publication online on Friday, a New York Times Magazine story about “boomerang kids” – young adults who move back in with their parents after graduating from college – was a hit. During that morning’s news meeting, Karron Skog, the day editor, and Ian Fisher, an assistant managing editor, said they would give the story more prominent promotion based on its web traffic and comment numbers. By 5 p.m. the story had drawn nearly 1,000 comments; by Sunday, when the piece ran in print, it had 1,657 comments.

headline: The Challenges of Starting an Urban Winery
text: Ask most winemakers about the pitfalls of harvest, and they talk about excessive rain or pesky bugs. Lysanne Tusar, owner of the 8th Estate Winery, has a more unusual problem: the rising cost of rent in the city.

headline: German Artist Wins the BP Portrait Award With Depiction of Homeless Man
text: LONDON — A portrait of a homeless man, “Man With a Plaid Blanket,” by Thomas Ganter, has won the BP Portrait Award, the National Portrait Gallery announced here on Tuesday. Mr. Ganter, who is the first German artist to win the prize, an annual award aimed at encouraging artists to focus on portrait-painting, received £30,000 or roughly $50,922 at an award ceremony hosted by the actor Nigel Havers. The prize, which is sponsored by BP, also includes a commission to paint a portrait for the National Portrait Gallery’s permanent collection.

The ladies flock to him first, perhaps attracted by his linen suit, mop of sandy hair and slight British lilt, a product of his bicontinental heritage. headline: Machiavelli in Mississippi
text: There are moments when debates about policy and ideology and The Direction of the Republican Party have to take a back seat to an appreciation of politics-as-politics: The second oldest profession, the game of thrones and transactions, the sleazy science of relationships and favors and dealmaking and turnout and (with apologies to Charlie Sheen) winning. And the spectacle of Thad Cochran — which is to say, yes, the Haley Barbour political machine — pulling out an unlikely comeback in the Mississippi Senate run-off by persuading African-American Democrats to turn out in a G.O.P. primary is such an occasion: A time to savor some of the historical ironies at work, to appreciate the establishment’s back-to-the-wall strategery, and to let the Penn Warren-ish phrase “Barbour brothers” roll over and over on your tongue.

headline: The Art of the ‘Vacationship’
text: “I love to do the thing you’re supposed to do in the place you’re supposed to do it.”

headline: Rate Manipulations May Distort Banks’ Market Risk Models
text: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. She also teaches at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: What Are You Really Worth to Your Employer?
text: Chief executives are always going on about how employees are their companies’ most valuable assets. They say it even as wages stagnate and executive pay skyrockets. They say it amid layoffs and as non-executive jobs are shifted overseas along with company profits.
