headline: A Group Show Celebrates the Art of Cycling
text: Opening tonight at Marlborough Gallery’s Broome Street location is “Joyride,” a group art show that inaugurates the 14th edition of the annual Bicycle Film Festival. For the exhibition — the latest in an annual series of art events tied to the festival — artists such as Ai Weiwei, Tim Barber, Francesco Clemente, Andrew Guenther, KAWS, Richard Prince, Tom Sachs and Kiki Smith have contributed cycling-themed work. Some, like Clemente and Guenther, created pieces specially for the show.

headline: In Inheritance Battle, Judge Sides Against the Perelmans
text: The bitter legal fight involving Samantha Perelman, the daughter of the billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman, came to an end on Wednesday, when a superior court judge ruled that Ms. Perelman’s uncle did not cut her out of her inheritance by unfairly manipulating her dying grandfather.

headline: Small Blasts Across Cairo Disrupt Calm Since Election
text: CAIRO — Five small bombs exploded around Egypt’s capital within two hours on Wednesday, injuring six people in the first such attacks since the election of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi this month.

headline: Between the Lines of the Cellphone Privacy Ruling
text: In a pathbreaking case on Fourth Amendment privacy rights and modern technology, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the police must obtain warrants before searching the digital contents of cellphones taken from people who are placed under arrest. Here are some key points in the opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and a concurrence by Justice Samuel Alito.

headline: Red Bulls and M.L.S. Return to Field
text: They’re back. Well almost.

headline: Google Unveils Android Expansion
text: Sundar Pichai, a senior vice president at Google, spoke about Android’s expansion during his keynote address at the Google I/O developers conference in San Francisco.

headline: Dallas and Cleveland Are Finalists for G.O.P Convention
text: WASHINGTON — The 2016 Republican National Convention will be held in Cleveland or Dallas, the party announced Wednesday.

headline: Goldman Sachs Reorganizes Investment Banking Division
text: Goldman Sachs is combining its consumer retail and health care investment banking groups, according to an internal memorandum sent on Wednesday. The move comes as drug company takeovers and retail advisory deals are on the rise.

headline: G.M. Holds a Corvette Track Day for Potential Customers
text: MILLVILLE, N.J. — There is probably no better way to sell sports cars than to get people talking about how hot they are on a track. Last week, more than 170 people statistically selected by Chevrolet were able to do just that, getting to drive the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray at New Jersey Motorsports Park.

headline: The Supreme Court Saves Cellphone Privacy
text: The nine justices of the Supreme Court — whose average age is 68 — often admit to being unfamiliar with modern technology, if not befuddled by it. While listening to oral arguments in April, Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. asked, with apparent sincerity, why anyone other than a criminal would carry two cellphones.

headline: Medium Hires Tech Writer Steven Levy as It Moves From Platform to Publisher
text: Medium, the online writing system created by Evan Williams, one of the founders of Twitter, has been something of a tabula rasa. Its publishing system and pretty interface have drawn raves, but as a media business it has been tough to pin down.

headline: With ‘Boyhood,’ a Portrait Every Year
text: Accompanying David Marchese’s story about Richard Linklater’s film ”Boyhood,” a 12-year project, is a slideshow of portraits of Ellar Coltrane, who grows up onscreen as the main character. In taking these pictures, Matt Lankes developed a relationship with Coltrane that he hopes will continue beyond the film’s completion. Lankes recently talked a bit about working on a movie for more than a decade.

headline: The First Rule of Stir-Fries: Be Prepared
text: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, while Renee is out of town, Martha lays the groundwork for stir-fries, and answers readers’ questions.

headline: What the Aereo Decision Means for TV
text: The Supreme Court ruled that Aereo violated copyright law, granting television networks a much-desired win that will preserve the status quo — at least for now.

headline: Buffeted by Tumult, Jewish Population in Tunisia Dwindles
text: DJERBA, Tunisia — On a recent Sabbath morning, just five men sat reciting prayers in the sanctuary of the Ghriba synagogue, the oldest synagogue in North Africa and the holiest place for the Orthodox Jews who live here on the resort island of Djerba.

headline: Contentment at a Hell’s Kitchen Diner
text: Dear Diary,

headline: David Muir’s Youth Appeal
text: Some highlights of Mr. Muir’s on-air style. The anchor will take the reins of ABC’s evening news in a move that executives hope will appeal to younger viewers.

headline: Smithsonian Festival Will Stay at National Mall for Now
text: WASHINGTON — The turf war on the National Mall has reached a cease-fire, for now.

headline: For Many Mormon Athletes, Mission Is to Play
text: On Thursday night, an N.B.A. team will select Jabari Parker, a 19-year-old basketball prodigy, with one of the top picks in the 2014 draft.

headline: House Panel Seeks to Block Washington Marijuana Law
text: WASHINGTON — The House Appropriations Committee passed a measure on Wednesday to bar the District of Columbia from using either federal or local funds in carrying out a new law decriminalizing the possession of small amounts of marijuana, a move that could block the law if approved by Congress.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Raf Simons: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: A Selfless Man: David Peace Talks About Bill Shankly and ‘Red or Dead’
text: The British novelist David Peace’s “Red Riding” quartet, which was turned into three films, followed the hunt for a serial killer in Yorkshire. His 2006 novel “The Damned Utd,” about the Leeds United soccer manager Brian Clough, was turned into a movie starring Michael Sheen.

headline: Opening and Sales for the Week of June 26
text: Openings

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Three’s a Trend | At the Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows, Printed Shirts and Ties Get Matchy-Matchy
text: There are so many competing guides, tutorials and rules out there for creating the right shirt-and-tie combination that it all seems a bit arbitrary and overcomplicated. Judging from what we’ve seen at the spring/summer 2015 Milan and Pitti Uomo shows, there might a be a less confusing (and more cheeky) approach to try: shirts and ties that implement the same humorous print. Massimiliano Giornetti, the creative director of Salvatore Ferragamo, paired a tie with a matching shirt emblazoned with grazing giraffes. Marc Jacobs, whose collection featured cool interpretations of pastels and flamingo imagery, showed a shirt and tie, both in a pink fern print, under a dusty rose checked suit that somehow still maintained an edge. The Z Zegna show, which was at Pitti Uomo in Florence this season, displayed a smart balance of athletic wear and fine Italian tailoring. One example was a pentagonal polka dot shirt with an elasticated hem, worn with a matching tie and trainers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, England, the Philippines and Washington, D.C.

headline: Talented Bulgarian Leads Youthful Assault on Big 4
text: WIMBLEDON, England — There is an unmistakable buzz around the hallowed Centre Court when Grigor Dimitrov, a 23-year-old Bulgarian, steps onto the manicured lawn. It is not merely in anticipation that his special lady friend, Maria Sharapova, might make an unscheduled appearance in the players’ box.

headline: Longer Heart Monitoring Backed for Stroke Patients
text: More than a half-million Americans every year have an ischemic stroke, the most common form, which disrupts blood flow to the brain. And at least a quarter of these cases have no apparent underlying cause.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: CLOSED DOORSBy Lisa O’Donnell249 pages. Harper. $26.99.

headline: In a Balancing Act, Carving Space From Ledge to Ledge With a Strut
text: On Tuesday afternoon in the courtyard next to the John Street United Methodist Church in Lower Manhattan, a striking man stood on a narrow concrete ledge and gazed at a small crowd gathered beneath him. The man was Souleymane Badolo, a dancer and choreographer from Burkina Faso who has lived and worked in New York since 2009. The crowd came to watch his “Virgule de l’histoire” (“Comma of history”), part of the River to River Festival.

headline: Italy Gets Real
text: MILAN — Her face a mask of immobility, her skin spray-tanned to the color of bacon, Anna Dello Russo — camera-magnet and editor at large for Vogue Japan — grasped a hand-held clad in the season’s hot accessory, a phone case resembling a bottle of Chanel No. 5.

headline: The Return of Real Blood and Other Medical Norms
text: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the cardiac surgeon and television personality, has been making headlines for all the wrong reasons lately, but when he turns up in the premiere of the new season of “NY Med,” ABC’s documentary hospital series, he’s not much of a distraction. That’s because his patient, a young man who turns out to have a tear in his aorta, is in such agony that he commands all your attention.

headline: Another Spelling Production
text: Candy Spelling uses the Internet, but she can’t bring herself to try dating sites. “They scare me,” she said.

headline: A Mystical Offering of Grateful Devotion
text: With each passing summer Savion Glover slips into the Joyce Theater with a new show that strives to strip tap to its purest spirit. There’s always a mood to go with it. Will Mr. Glover be playful? Withdrawn? Bizarre? This season, he’s intent on showing a more mystical side; “OM” — unsettling, yet hypnotic — falls under weird. Performed on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, the work relies on a spiritual beat to sync the past with the present that begins with Mr. Glover’s decisive feet and emanates through his body in waves of remembrance, homage, allegiance. This is worship.

headline: Senior U.S. Prosecutor Who Fought Wall St. Is Departing
text: After five years of tussling with Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and the giant hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, Lorin L. Reisner is ready for a change.

headline: War’s Lingering Requiem in Vietnam
text: A museum in Vietnam memorialized the work of photographers who died covering the conflict. It includes indelible images by Western and North Vietnamese photographers.

headline: Updating the Gold Standard to Platinum
text: For the last decade, Kaitlyn Cullinane has had her light-brown hair highlighted with golden tones in the winter and lighter ones during the warmer months. This year she decided to try something a little more dramatic.

headline: Even Advice Isn’t Free Anymore
text: Are your friends always coming to you for advice? Maybe you could start a business. Charging for what might once have been informal counsel is becoming more common — and the growing freelance economy may be behind the shift.

headline: Deal to End Senate Rift May Give Democrats Full Control in Albany
text: A group of independent Democrats who share control of the New York State Senate with Republicans agreed on Wednesday to reunite with their fellow Democrats, a move that could shift the balance of power in Albany.

headline: The Man Who Hated Gravity, Part 2
text: In my recent column about Roger Babson, the eccentric tycoon who tried to save humanity from the deadly force of gravity, I noted that for all its perils — death by avalanche, drowning and so forth — gravity is far from a complete villain. It sustains life on earth by holding in the atmosphere. But as you get higher above the planet, the air becomes steadily thinner until, in space, a person without a protective suit would die as surely as a swimmer pulled to the bottom of a lake. Danger lurks above and below.

headline: Knicks Agree to Trade Chandler and Felton to Mavericks
text: Phil Jackson has been fairly methodical in his short tenure as the Knicks’ president.

headline: At Google I/O Conference, Protesters Inside and Out
text: Inside the darkened auditorium of the Google I/O developer conference in San Francisco, 6,000 people cheered, yelled and clapped as Google executives showed off the company’s latest wares.

headline: Which Way Do the Sneaker Prints Lead?
text: Is the runway a two-way street? The thought occurred to one observer as he wended his way through the men’s fashion weeks. One particular style of shoe — the white sneaker, low-topped, often in leather — recurred again and again, on the runway and in the front rows. It raised the question: Do trends trickle down, or do they trickle up?

headline: A Provocateur Prepares to Show His Quiet Side
text: Two days before his men’s wear presentation for Loewe, the first since his appointment as creative director last September, Jonathan Anderson was standing at the company’s soon-to-be-former headquarters on the Rue François Ier in Paris. It would be a goodbye of sorts to the place where he has spent much of his time these last eight months. The presentation will be held at the new offices, on St.-Sulpice. The space will be not only an office and headquarters, but for the first time, the home of the design team, which Mr. Anderson has imported from the label’s native Madrid.

headline: United Church of Christ Joins Sponsors of Gay Games
text: A PROTESTANT denomination known for its longtime support of religious diversity and inclusion has agreed to become a sponsor of the 2014 edition of the Gay Games, to be held in northeast Ohio from Aug. 9 to 16.

headline: Q. and A.: William C. Kirby on ‘Can China Lead?’
text: In the book “Can China Lead?: Reaching the Limits of Power and Growth,” William C. Kirby and F. Warren McFarlan of Harvard Business School and Regina M. Abrami of the Wharton School explore whether China will become the world’s leading power.

headline: Summer With a Fringe Built In
text: Texture was big on the fall runways, which were a frenzy of fur and feathers in artful assemblages and rainbows of colors. No need, though, to wait to try out an artsy-craftsy look for yourself. For summer, think fur-like. Ryan Roche, who works in upstate New York, uses crocheted cashmere for her lovely furry fringe sweaters. Maria Cornejo used a synthetic feather effect for a shrug and as trim on a silk dress. Other labels, like Chloé and Samuji, a young Finnish line to watch, have affixed fringe all over lightweight sweaters and linen dresses. At a recent Acria event to raise money for H.I.V. research and education, the fashionable art director Sofía Sanchez Barrenechea wore an ostrich feather and faille tulip dress from Jason Wu’s spring 2010 collection, proving that not every soiree calls for a brand-new frock, just one you want to reach out and touch.

headline: Little in Common, Save a Continent
text: The New York Asian Film Festival, whose 13th edition begins on Friday, can kindly be described as eclectic. Other festivals may stick to a theme or reflect a particular curatorial vision. The Asian Film Festival is all over the place. (And it’s a very big place.).

headline: Shedding Light on Nazi-Occupied Paris
text: If Jean Guéhenno had never existed, France would surely have had to invent him. A model writer and intellectual who neither collaborated nor accommodated the enemy, he refused to publish a single word as long as his country was under Nazi control. A leading essayist of the Popular Front, regularly skewered by the far right, he vowed, as of July 1940, to confine his thoughts and feelings to a private journal. It is a mystery why “Diary of the Dark Years, 1940-1944,” first published in 1947 and still a standard reference in France, is only now appearing in English in a fine translation by David Ball. Is there something about our own political climate that allows us finally to hear Guéhenno’s voice clearly?

headline: Classic Folk, Tested for Signs of Jazz
text: The West Coast singer Tierney Sutton would seem to be an ideal translator of Joni Mitchell songs into a jazz idiom because so many of them traverse traditional boundaries of pop, rock and folk to be their own thing, whatever you want to call it. Ms. Sutton, who does her own version of the same thing, recently released a mildly experimental Mitchell tribute album, “After Blue” (BFM Jazz), that plays with the songs’ rhythms, inserts improvisatory vocal passages and takes other liberties without bending them out of shape.

headline: Team Player Is Honored With a Solo
text: A festival and a tribute are happily crossing paths in the last week of the New York Philharmonic’s subscription season at Avery Fisher Hall. This week’s program, first performed on Tuesday evening, is the third and last in the orchestra’s Beethoven festival built around the five piano concertos, with Yefim Bronfman as soloist and Alan Gilbert conducting.

headline: Rare Stradivari Viola Fails to Attract Buyer
text: Maybe the rare-instruments market is showing signs of coming back to earth a bit, or maybe Sotheby’s and Ingles & Hayday simply asked for too much money for a fiddle.

headline: More Calls to Fix Music Royalty Rules, but No Accord
text: Two weeks ago, a House Judiciary subcommittee heard from a group of music executives that the complex licensing system is broken, but no consensus emerged about how to fix it. On Wednesday, the same committee heard from a different group of executives that the licensing system is broken, and once again there was no agreement on how to fix it.

headline: Kicking Up Their Heels in Tribute
text: Few shows inspire the same level of nostalgia as “A Chorus Line” does. It opened at the Public Theater in April 1975, moved to the Shubert Theater on Broadway three months later and went on to play 6,137 performances. In the process, it won the Pulitzer Prize, seven Drama Desk awards and nine Tony Awards.

headline: Like Lunch With Monet
text: The garden that opened last month at Ladurée, the restaurant and shop in SoHo, is a 2,600-square-foot oasis designed to evoke Paris. Elisabeth Holder, a president of Ladurée in the United States, said that the green powder-coated metal chairs are airy interpretations of their counterparts at the Luxembourg Garden and the Tuileries, while the black metal trellises on arched windows were inspired by the Hôtel Plaza Athénée. (Visitors will also note that an antique fountain burbles like a messenger from Proust.)

headline: Furnishings Made of Rope: Knotty but No Problem
text: At Thom Filicia’s weekend house, bathroom mirrors are framed in rope, chairs are made out of it and a thick length serves as a stair rail.

headline: Capturing Detroit’s Local Flavor
text: In 2010, Gregory Holm, a photographer and filmmaker, and Matthew Radune, an architect, soaked and froze an abandoned home in Detroit creating a luminous ice sculpture that made a ticklish point about the city’s many foreclosures. The same year, Mr. Holm built a soundstage in an empty fire station and produced a concert with local composers, a youth choir and eccentric instruments like a fire-powered organ.

headline: After the Cows Left Home
text: In the town of Moorenweis, in southern Germany, there are a number of imposing Alpine-style chalets. But the house that Michael Schnabl, 38, and his wife, Bernadette, a 35-year-old actress, chose to make their own was a 19th-century Bavarian farmhouse with a rundown barn.

headline: Botany’s New Boys
text: Des Moines — A medium-size state capital does not become a competitive global city without a public display of shrubbery. As theories of urban development go, that’s a novel one. Yet nabobs in Iowa appear to believe in it so strongly that they are raising $18.2 million to close the dogwood gap.

headline: Melissa Leo’s Theater in the Round
text: STONE RIDGE, N.Y. — From the road, Melissa Leo’s 200-year-old farmhouse would seem to be standard issue for Ulster County, with all the usual trappings: on the porch, a hammock, some wind chimes, a few director’s chairs, an armless mannequin wearing a flowery dress and a baseball cap, her arms strewed about her feet; up above, an enormous peace sign (Woodstock is less than 20 miles away).

headline: At World Cup, Two Unknowns Are Surprise Stars
text: If you’ve been watching ESPN’s nightly World Cup wrap-up show, you have probably seen them — not beneath the swaying palm trees on the Rio de Janeiro beachfront set with the rest of the on-air talent, but squished together in an eight-by-five-foot room. Two scruffy, balding Britons, clutching a miniature banana as a make-believe microphone, riffing on the day’s games. Maybe you’ve even heard them describe the Brazilian star Neymar as “a Japanese manga character come to life,” or the Portuguese forward Cristiano Ronaldo as “a petulant show pony.”

headline: Stretching to Infinity and Beyond
text: Since 1996, the New York designer David Weeks has been turning out furniture, lighting, toys and even wallpaper with gorilla heads. His latest project, the Infinity Screen, is a series of interlocking four-by-six-inch paper modules that can grow to any dimension. The piece came about when the W Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., commissioned Mr. Weeks to design a light installation that required no electricity. He used die-cut paper coated in shiny Mylar to create a fixture that resembled a chandelier. When the project was done, he decided to explore other uses for the technique. “It was an exercise in form,” he said. The panels ($250 a square yard) are made of card stock paper and can be used as a room divider or window covering. A stainless-steel mounting bracket is $150 per 36-inch length. Mr. Weeks will produce the screen in other materials or in printed versions for custom projects. Information: 212-966-3433 or davidweeksstudio.com.

headline: Rustic, Raw and Thoroughly Modern
text: “Cape Cod Modern: Midcentury Architecture and Community on the Outer Cape,” by Peter McMahon and Christine Cipriani (Metropolis Books, $33), reveals one of the East Coast’s best-kept architectural secrets: an enclave of disarmingly unpretentious houses, many inspired by chicken coops and oyster houses. Often made with scavenged wood mixed with raw lumber straight from the yard, the buildings were designed by Marcel Breuer, Eero Saarinen, Serge Chermayeff, Maurice Smith and serious amateurs. In this rich cultural setting, left-leaning figures including Mary McCarthy, Edmund Wilson, Dwight Macdonald and Noam Chomsky dined on plywood tables, bathed nude in brisk waters on principle and exercised elastic morals among the unpainted two-by-fours. It was a summer camp for consenting, distinctly un-Puritanical intellectuals. And the party needn’t be over. Many of the houses are in the Cape Cod National Seashore conservation park, with some recently restored for summer rental and for artists in the off-season.

headline: A Burst of Vivid Colors
text: Niche Modern’s Crystalline Collection of blown-glass pendant lamps includes four shapes that vaguely allude to molecular structures. “Deep down in the core of my being, I love order and mathematics,” said Jeremy Pyles, who founded the company with his wife, Mary Welch. But the main reason that the group burst onto the scene in a flash of eight mostly vivid colors, including a blue inspired by the palette of the Hotel Condesa in Mexico City, had to do with their bulbs. Niche Modern’s existing lamps offered few options for low-energy bulbs, or for the 240-volt varieties used overseas, where the company has been brightening a growing number of hotels and restaurants. The Crystalline series will accommodate both models of the stylish Plumen compact fluorescent light bulb, as well as Niche Modern’s specialty incandescent bulb. The collection is available through July 15 at Lumens.com and following that through Niche Modern. From $550. Information: nichemodern.com.

headline: Sales at Fishs Eddy, Ethan Allen, John Robshaw and DLV Designs
text: Fishs Eddy is discounting some tabletop, glassware and accessories by 50 percent, in-store only, while supplies last (the Dog Decal tray, originally about $23, is about $11); 889 Broadway (East 19th Street), 212-420-9020.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Men’s Wear Shows in Milan
text: In Milan, the best spring/summer 2015 men’s shows were true to the names behind them. Fashion houses celebrated their signature style with throwbacks to archival silhouettes and prints, while newer creative directors seamlessly incorporated their own visions into the DNA of the iconic brands they design for. These five collections represent refreshing new directions anchored in timeless design.

headline: Senior Teams at European Championships in Croatia
text: In the 1960s and ’70s, the battle for the medals at the European Bridge Championship was among just a few countries. Back then, it was vital for the contenders to score as many victory points as possible against the weaker nations. In particular, the strong teams gained many points from superior declarer play and defense. Today, bidding has assumed a more important role. Also, competitive bidding has become much more aggressive.

headline: Seeing Loneliness or Something Like It
text: The weather is always a collaborator in River to River, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s annual festival of site-specific performance, and last weekend it was in peak form. The festival’s organizer, Sam Miller, deserved nothing less; his lineup this year is stellar. Lucid skies, light breezes and just-right temperatures made a dancegoer rejoice in the concept of piers, lawns and seaside cafes as theatrical spaces, as did the stealthy use of those spaces by the artists who occupied them.

headline: Lending Mozart a Left Hand
text: In a time that has brought us renovations and revisions of Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons,” Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony and Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” among other overhauls, do we really need a recomposition of Mozart’s “Coronation” Concerto?

headline: A Carbon Tax and Climate Change
Bidding Farewell to a Home of Visionary Art With Space Travel and a Vodka Shot
text: Welcome aboard Ozet, a colossal spacecraft launched from Moscow in 1929 carrying nearly 700 eager pioneers and a lake full of sturgeon.

headline: Disney Hopes New (and Nostalgic) Formula Will Draw Tweens
text: LOS ANGELES — Disney Channel has a history of serving up programming that defines pop culture for pre-teenage girls: “Lizzie McGuire,” “Hannah Montana,” “Wizards of Waverly Place,” “High School Musical.” But that cable network has not found a new live-action juggernaut in years and its overall ratings are declining.

headline: The Supreme Court Justices Have Cellphones, Too
text: Fourteen years ago, the Rehnquist court interrupted a string of law enforcement victories to rule that when looking for illegal drugs, the police couldn’t simply walk down the aisle of an intercity bus and squeeze the bags and soft-sided luggage on the overhead rack.

headline: The Mississippi Primary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Limits of U.S. Influence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond the Central Park 5
text: To the Editor:

headline: Empathy for Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting Teeth in Her Look
text: The Haut Marais neighborhood in Paris is the epicenter of bohemian bourgeois French style. “What I like about this neighborhood is that it is romantic and fashionable,” said Johanna Lebrun, who was in the area riding her Peugeot bike from the 1950s. “The idea is not necessarily to show off wealth, but to show a cool attitude.” Wearing a floral, flowing Vanessa Bruno dress (which she said was like wearing a painting) and carrying a 50-year-old Hermès bag, Ms. Lebrun was channeling just that attitude. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Navigating National Parks With Light and Rich Digital Guides
text: IT wasn’t long ago that a trip to a national park meant packing books, paper maps, a guide to help identify plants and wildlife, and tools like a compass. Now apps can help with all these things.

headline: World Cup 2014: A Tie Sends France Through and Ecuador Out
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The goals came so easy, and so often, for France in its first two games at the World Cup that one could be forgiven for assuming it might never end. Three against Honduras. Five against Switzerland.

headline: App Smart | Visiting National Parks
text: Kit Eaton explores three apps that will help you get the most out of your trip to Yellowstone, Yosemite or hundreds of other parks.

headline: Night Sky and the Soul
text: To the Editor:

headline: Human Rights in Morocco
text: To the Editor:

headline: GoPro’s I.P.O. Prices at Top of Range, Leading a Wave of Newly Public Companies
text: Updated, 7:19 p.m. | Since its founding in 2004, GoPro has become the biggest name in action videos, its tiny cameras attached to hundreds of surfboards, sports bikes and skydiving helmets.

headline: Michael Walrond on His Loss to Charles Rangel
text: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond, the senior minister at First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem, whom I wrote about in last Sunday’s magazine, drew about 8 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary for New York’s 13th Congressional District. “We are extremely proud of the campaign we have organized, and Mike’s visionary leadership will continue to impact our community through his work at First Corinthian Baptist Church,” his campaign said in a statement yesterday. Walrond called later and said he was relieved the campaign was over and talked about what it was like to run against and lose to Representative Charles Rangel.

headline: League of Legends Sets Game Championship for Korean Stadium
text: Months after the FIFA World Cup in Brazil ends, another World Cup venue will host a very different kind of competition: a championship battle between players of one of the world’s most popular online games.

headline: Egyptian Activists to Stand Trial for Protesting Ban on Protests
text: A prosecutor in Cairo plans to charge 23 opposition activists with violating a new law banning unsanctioned protests for attending a rally last Saturday against the ban.

headline: Creativity Unleashed, With the Help of a Little Pi
text: Raspberry Pi, a tiny computer the size of a credit card, has captured the imaginations of students, educators and tinkerers around the world since it became available in 2012. Earlier this month, the organization behind the computer announced that it had sold its three millionth device.

headline: Boehner to Seek Bill to Sue Obama
text: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, said he intended to file a lawsuit accusing President Obama of failing to carry out laws passed by Congress.

headline: Boehner to Seek Bill to Sue Obama Over Executive Actions
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner announced Wednesday that he would introduce legislation next month allowing the House to sue President Obama over his use of executive actions.

headline: Grimm’s Threats May Have Broken House Rules, Ethics Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Michael G. Grimm of New York, who is already facing criminal charges, may also have violated House ethics rules in January when he threatened a reporter for the NY1 television station who was interviewing him in the Capitol, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

headline: His Earlier Stints Ended by Felonies, Ex-Mayor of Providence Announces He’ll Run Again
text: Ending months of self-generated suspense, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the garrulous and polarizing former mayor of Providence, R.I., whose two stints in office collapsed in felony convictions, announced on his radio talk show Wednesday that he wanted his old job back.

headline: Thad Cochran’s Debt to Mississippi
text: The prospect of electing an intemperate Tea Party candidate who was openly nostalgic for Confederate days was so repellent to many black voters in Mississippi that they did a remarkable thing on Tuesday, crossing party lines to help give the Republican Senate nomination to Thad Cochran, in office for 36 years. Now it’s time for Mr. Cochran to return the favor by supporting a stronger Voting Rights Act and actively working to reduce his party’s extreme antigovernment policies.

headline: Paula Kent Meehan, Co-Founder of a Hair-Care Giant, Dies at 82
text: In the 1950s, Paula Jane Baer, an aspiring actress who had adopted the stage name Paula Kent, came to the realization that she would never match the success of her junior high friend Debbie Reynolds.

headline: The Iraqi Friends We Abandoned
text: LOS ANGELES — “LET’S be perfectly coldblooded about it,” President Richard M. Nixon mused to Henry A. Kissinger. “South Vietnam is probably never gonna survive anyway.” It was August 1972, and Nixon was worried about the inevitable collapse of South Vietnam after American forces withdrew. Mr. Kissinger concurred: “We’ve got to find some formula that holds the thing together a year or two. If we settle it, say, this October, by January ’74 no one will give a damn.”

headline: Speaking to My Father in a Dead Dialect
text: The 18th-century Italian philosopher Giambattista Vico believed that as a civilization progressed, it lost touch with its creative origins. An ancient warrior would never declare “I’m angry”; he would wax metaphorical with “my blood boils.” The Roman poet Horace went a step further, believing that when words died they took memories with them. Just as forests change their leaves each year, so, too, do words: new languages “bloom and thrive” but only after “the old race dies.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Players Cautious, Calling U.S. ‘Very Dangerous’
text: RECIFE, Brazil — Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, is aware of the narrative surrounding the team, of how perceptions of it have changed over the years, of how quickly those can flip.

headline: Tense Vote Spares Polish Government After Recordings Scandal
text: WARSAW — The Polish Parliament voted Wednesday to retain the embattled government of Prime Minister Donald Tusk, despite an embarrassing scandal involving several top officials whose private, often profane conversations in upscale Warsaw restaurants had been bugged for more than a year.

headline: God and Mammon
text: Has contemporary American capitalism become incompatible with Christian values?

headline: Snakes and Thorny Brush, and Children at the Border Alone
text: HIDALGO, Tex. — Border agents drove their patrol vehicles one recent day at dusk through this spit of land on the bank of the Rio Grande. Here, in a place known as the Devil’s Corner, smugglers on the Mexican side have chosen to bring thousands of women and children to American soil.

headline: Michael Bradley, Motor in U.S. Midfield, Needs a Tuneup
text: RECIFE, Brazil — If Landon Donovan was the face of United States soccer, then Michael Bradley was — and is — its motor. Bradley is a mainstay in the American lineup, operating in the midfield and generally acting as a conduit between the team’s defense and attack.

headline: Judge Rejects Effort to Compel Christie to Keep Promise on New Jersey’s Pension Fund
text: TRENTON — A judge on Wednesday denied a bid by public employee unions to force Gov. Chris Christie to make the pension payments he promised in signature legislation three years ago, ruling that the state’s “staggering” $1.7 billion budget deficit left him simply unable to meet that commitment.

headline: S.E.C. Stops City in Illinois From Selling Municipal Bonds
text: Federal regulators went to court on Wednesday to keep a city in Illinois from bringing its bonds to market, an unprecedented step they called necessary to halt a widening securities fraud.

headline: In Puerto Rico, a Proposal for Revamping Debt
text: Puerto Rico’s governor, signaling worsening financial trouble for the island, on Wednesday proposed a legal means to revamp the debt of some its largest public corporations, which provide vital services like electricity.

headline: His Back Mending, Tiger Woods’s Shot Is Next
text: BETHESDA, Md. — After hitting the 10th tee shot of his comeback, Tiger Woods settled into a folding chair to the side of the first tee. The sign taped to the back of the reserved seat read, “Wounded Warrior.”

headline: Facebook Mirrors Tech Industry’s Lack of Diversity
text: When it comes to the gender and ethnic diversity of its work force, Facebook‘s record is on par with the rest of Silicon Valley. It’s overwhelmingly male, white and Asian. And white men dominate the management ranks.

headline: Sales of Hillary Clinton’s New Memoir Drop Sharply in 2nd Week
text: Sales of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s new memoir, “Hard Choices,” declined 43.5 percent to 48,000 copies in its second week on the shelves, according to Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Larry Page on Google’s Many Arms
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One way to think of Google is as an extremely helpful, all-knowing, hyper-intelligent executive assistant. Already, it can remind you about your flight, open up your boarding pass when you get to the airport and offer you driving directions to your hotel when you land.

headline: Stalemate Over Garment Factory Safety in Bangladesh
text: Eight times now, the European-dominated Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh — a group of more than 150 retailers and brands — has forced the temporary closing of garment factories after its inspectors found dangerous conditions.

headline: Another of the Hollywood Sexual Abuse Suits Is Dropped
text: LOS ANGELES — Another of the sexual abuse lawsuits filed in Hawaii against various Hollywood executives and filmmakers by Michael Egan, this one against Garth Ancier, the longtime television executive, was voluntarily dismissed on Wednesday. Lawyers for Mr. Egan filed a brief notice of the dismissal with the United States District Court for the District of Hawaii. The dismissal was filed “without prejudice,” meaning that the claims of statutory rape and other abuse could be refiled.

headline: G.M. Halts Sale of Cruze Sedan Over Takata Air Bags
text: General Motors ordered dealers to stop selling the 2013 and 2014 versions of its most popular car, the Chevrolet Cruze sedan, because of a problem with air bags made by the Japanese supplier Takata, whose products are already the subject of a large recall of other vehicles.

headline: In a U.S. Court, Iraqis Accuse Blackwater of Killings in 2007
text: WASHINGTON — The witness wore a suit with no tie, the top button of his gray shirt undone. He had told this story many times, and now that he was in the United States, telling his story at last to a jury, he appeared neither hurried nor anxious.

headline: Obama’s Weakness, or Ours?
text: The odds are that you think President Obama’s foreign policy is a failure.

headline: In Ghana’s Bags: Gear and $3 Million in Cash
text: BRASÍLIA — An airplane laden with cash descended into Brazilian airspace, or so Ghana’s national soccer team was told on Wednesday, and the question for each player shifted away from the topics of how to stop Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo or whether Ghana had a realistic chance to advance to the second round of the World Cup.

headline: Mississippi Goes for the Money
text: Mississippi has sent us a message. I believe it boils down to: We Want Our Stuff.

headline: Russia and Others Seek Extended Ukraine Truce, but Separatists Balk
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany on Wednesday called for extending the truce between government and rebel troops in eastern Ukraine, even as separatist leaders said that the peace process had collapsed.

headline: Cellphone Ruling Could Alter Police Methods, Experts Say
text: The Supreme Court decision making it harder for the police to search cellphones without a warrant could change procedures around the country, police officials and legal experts said Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Chided for Delays Over Treaty on Weapons
text: The American peace activist who pioneered a treaty that bans antipersonnel land mines chided the Obama administration on Wednesday for not yet having signed it after five years of review. The activist, Jody Williams, said that China — which also has not signed — now appears to have far fewer of these weapons than the United States.

headline: Bergdahl to Be Questioned About Leaving Army Post
text: WASHINGTON — Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl will face investigators seeking to determine his legal future in about two weeks, Army officials said Wednesday, as they described the parameters of an inquiry to decide whether the onetime prisoner of war in Afghanistan intended to desert when he walked away from his combat outpost in 2009.

headline: Beating of Roma Boy Exposes Tensions in France’s Underclass
text: PIERREFITTE-SUR-SEINE, France — With its bleak concrete apartment blocks and clutches of bored, jobless young men, the Cité des Poètes housing project defies its idyllic name.

headline: Blacks Regain Sway at Polls in Mississippi
text: JACKSON, Miss. — For the first time since President Richard M. Nixon’s divisive “Southern strategy” that sent whites to the Republican Party and blacks to the Democrats, African-American voters have come out in force for a Republican in the Deep South.

headline: How Breakfast May Be Served
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., the truth here: How many of you were honestly able to solve the entire puzzle without once thinking of the fortune cookie game where people read their fortunes out loud and add “… IN BED” at the end? No? Just me?

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats United States, 1-0
text: Germany won, 1-0, but the United States still advanced out of Group G, thanks to Portugal’s 2-1 victory over Ghana.

headline: Questions Raised Over Trial for Ahmed Abu Khattala in Benghazi Case
text: WASHINGTON — For the past five days or so, the Libyan suspected of being the ringleader in the 2012 attacks that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, has been steaming across the Atlantic Ocean to the United States aboard a hulking Navy ship.

headline: Violence and Uncertainty Mar Libyan Election for a New Parliament
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — With their expectations battered, Libyans headed to the polls on Wednesday to elect members of a new Parliament, in a vote seen as a critical step in a democratic transition that was overshadowed by an intensifying civil conflict in the eastern part of the country.

headline: On the Ethnic and Racial Paths to Political Power, Nothing Is Inevitable
text: So sue me and revoke my good-government papers. The performance artist known as Charlie Rangel may have a tattered ethics portfolio. But he does a most entertaining election night throwdown.

headline: Shiite Violence Traps Baghdad’s Sunnis, Haunted by a Grim Past
text: BAGHDAD — The bodies arrive in twos and threes most every day in the Baghdad morgue now, a grim barometer of the city’s sectarian tensions. Most have gunshot wounds to the head, some have signs of torture, and most of them are Sunnis.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Pakistani Militants
text: LONDON — The United States imposed economic sanctions on Wednesday against two senior members of the Pakistani militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba and designated its charity wing, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, as a “front organization.”

headline: Derek Jeter’s Birthday Scorecard
text: Derek Jeter of the Yankees was born on June 26, 1974, in Pequannock, N.J. On his 40th birthday, in his final season, here is a look at how he has fared each June 26 during his career. BY ELENA GUSTINES

headline: Man Kills Himself at Beirut Hotel as Security Closes In
text: BEIRUT — A Saudi man blew himself up in a Beirut hotel on Wednesday as security forces stormed it in what Lebanon’s interior minister called a “pre-emptive strike” against a terrorist cell preparing to strike elsewhere, Lebanon’s national news service said.

headline: Sri Lanka: Advisers Set for Inquiry
text: The United Nations named three international experts on Wednesday to be advisers on an inquiry into human rights abuses in the final months of Sri Lanka’s war against ethnic Tamil insurgents in 2009. The three are Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland and Nobel Peace Prize-winning diplomat; Silvia Cartwright, who served as a judge on the war crimes tribunal in Cambodia; and Asma Jahangir, a veteran human rights defender from Pakistan. The United Nations Human Rights Council voted in March to authorize the inquiry. Its 12-member team of investigators is supposed to present preliminary findings as early as September. Whether the experts will be allowed entry into Sri Lanka, which has resisted such an inquiry, remains unclear.

headline: Gifts for Jeter Before 40th Birthday: A Victory Followed by a Day Off
text: TORONTO — Derek Jeter turns 40 years old Thursday, and he is delighted the Yankees will not be playing a game. Not because it gives him more time to celebrate and not because he needs an extra day’s rest.

headline: After Raising Bar, Wheeler Crashes Out in 2 Innings
text: The perplexing sophomore season of Zack Wheeler took another abrupt and wild turn on Wednesday, his first appearance since he pitched a shutout against the Miami Marlins.

headline: World Cup 2014: Portugal Defeats Ghana, 2-1
text: This was a Portugal campaign that never got going. Ghana were pretty punchless today — who knows how much the off-field problems affected them.

headline: Teenie Hodges, Soul Guitarist and Songwriter, Dies at 68
text: Teenie Hodges, a guitarist and songwriter whose lithe touch on songs by Al Green and others helped shape the sound of Memphis soul in the 1970s, died on Sunday in Dallas. He was 68.

headline: Port Authority’s Airports to Get Free Wi-Fi
text: The region’s major airports will finally offer free Wi-Fi to travelers, but the generosity has a time limit: 30 minutes.

headline: Loan Sought for Tappan Zee Work Is Faulted
text: A plan by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the agency building a new Tappan Zee Bridge to borrow a half-billion dollars provided under the federal Clean Water Act has come under fire from nine environmental and transportation groups that argue the money would be improperly spent on basic construction, not enhancing water quality.

headline: Gifts of $300 to Homeless Are Reduced to a Lunch
text: The Tour of Love and Gratitude luncheon at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park took a decisive turn for the worse on Wednesday soon after the 200 or so guests had finished their filet of beef with horseradish and were just about to tuck into their seasonal berries in phyllo cups.

headline: Developer Reaches Deal to Finish 80-Story Tower
text: The developer Larry A. Silverstein plans to resume construction of a long-stalled 80-story building at the World Trade Center site immediately, under an agreement the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved on Wednesday.

headline: 984 Ways the United States Can Advance to the Next Round of the World Cup
text: An interactive matrix of game scenarios based on the outcomes of the U.S. vs. Germany and Portugal vs. Ghana matches.

headline: World Cup 2014: Belgium Defeats South Korea, 1-0
text: The Belgians, picked by some as outside threats to win the tournament, won all three of their games in Group H, with decisive late goals against Algeria, Russia and South Korea.

headline: World Cup 2014: Algeria and Russia Play to a 1-1 Draw
text: Algeria didn’t make it easy for themselves, but advanced to the knockout rounds of the World Cup for the first time with a 1-1 tie against Russia.

headline: Japanese Artists Respond to Fukushima
text: More than three years after a 9.0 magnitude earthquake struck the northern region of Japan, causing a tsunami that killed more than 15,000 people, its effects are still being felt. The impact of the tsunami and earthquake damaged some of the reactors in one nuclear plant in the city of Fukushima, causing radiation to escape into the area — and scarring the national psyche.

headline: A Photographic Memory, Skewed
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Ikea to Increase Minimum Hourly Pay
text: Ikea plans to adopt a wage structure that it says will raise the average hourly minimum wage at its 38 stores in the United States to $10.76 an hour — a 17 percent increase.

headline: Use of Drones for Killings Risks a War Without End, Panel Concludes in Report
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s embrace of targeted killings using armed drones risks putting the United States on a “slippery slope” into perpetual war and sets a dangerous precedent for lethal operations that other countries might adopt in the future, according to a report by a bipartisan panel that includes several former senior intelligence and military officials.

headline: Putting Us All at Risk for Measles
text: One of my 11-year-old twin daughters recently came home from school distraught. When I asked why, she lifted her foot.

headline: Word of the Day | malicious
text: malicious •\mə-ˈli-shəs\• adjective

headline: Aspirin May Cut Pancreatic Cancer Risk
text: A new study adds to the evidence that low-dose aspirin, known to reduce the risk for heart disease, may also reduce the risk for pancreatic cancer.

headline: Purses Vanish, and a 68-Year-Old Is Blamed
text: One purse dangled casually from the back of a restaurant chair, its unsuspecting owner’s attention focused elsewhere. Another sat unattended on a table in a crowded Brooklyn bar.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 25, 2014
Potential No. 1 Pick in N.H.L. Draft Is Only No. 3 Among His Brothers
text: Like many Canadians, the brothers Max, Griffin and Sam Reinhart grew up playing hockey.

headline: Johnnie M. Walters, I.R.S. Chief Who Resisted Nixon’s Pressure, Dies at 94
text: Johnnie M. Walters, a commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service under President Richard M. Nixon who left office after refusing to prosecute people on Nixon’s notorious “enemies list,” died on Tuesday at his home in Greenville, S.C. He was 94.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 26, 2014
text: “It is fair to say that nowadays there is only fear in us.”

headline: South Korea: A Familiar Premier
text: President Park Geun-hye reversed her decision to replace her current prime minister, after two successive appointees stepped aside amid controversies over their qualifications. Prime Minister Chung Hong-won had offered to resign in late April, as the government came under fire for failing to prevent the sinking of a ferry on April 16 that left more than 300 people dead. Ms. Park accepted his resignation but asked him to stay in office while she looked for a replacement. But her first choice, a former Supreme Court justice named Ahn Dae-hee, was forced to withdraw his name amid questions over his earnings. Her second choice, Moon Chang-keuk, a retired conservative newspaper columnist, bowed out on Tuesday. Critics accused him of being unpatriotic after it was revealed that he said during a church lecture in 2011 that Korea’s colonization by Japan in the early 20th century was “God’s will.” This was the first time in South Korean history that a president retained a prime minister who had resigned.

headline: Corrections: June 26, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (Logo) TRAILBLAZERS On the anniversary of the striking down of the Defense of Marriage Act, this special honors Edie Windsor, who challenged the act’s constitutionality, and the lawyer Roberta Kaplan, who took the case to the Supreme Court. Other honorees include the basketball player Jason Collins, the first openly gay male athlete in a major American sport; Netflix’s “Orange Is the New Black,” for its portrayal of rarely seen television characters; and John Abdallah Wambere, the Ugandan gay rights advocate and refugee. Former President Bill Clinton talks about Ms. Windsor and Ms. Kaplan in a taped message. Daniel Radcliffe, Adam Levine, Jared Leto, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, Ed Sheeran, Nate Ruess, Demi Lovato and Iggy Azalea appear at this event, filmed on Monday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York. A Great Big World and Sia, with the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus, perform.

headline: Report of the Task Force on United States Drone Policy
text: This report raises warnings that other countries might adopt the same rationale as the United States has for carrying out lethal drone strikes outside of declared war zones.

headline: Climate Campaign Can’t Be Deaf to Economic Worries, Obama Warns
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama acknowledged Wednesday that his efforts to combat climate change — in particular, Environmental Protection Agency regulations to slash carbon pollution from cars and coal-fired power plants — could raise fuel and electricity prices. And he told environmental advocates that in order to make a credible case for such climate policies, officials would need to acknowledge Americans’ worries about the economic effects.

headline: Issue of Pay for 2 Sets of Workers Tugs at Palestinian Pact
text: GAZA CITY — Abu Raid al-Samouni, 46, a driver and office cleaner in the Foreign Ministry headquarters here, leaves for work before his 14 children wake up each morning, to avoid their pleas for spare change to buy candy. Like the other 42,000 workers hired while the militant Islamic group Hamas ran the Gaza government over the past seven years, Mr. Samouni has received only part of his $350 monthly salary since October; in April and May, there was no paycheck at all.

headline: Chinese Cyclist on Course to Be Country’s First Tour de France Rider
text: A 26-year-old Chinese cyclist is set to be the first person from his country to participate in the Tour de France when the sport’s biggest race begins next week.

headline: Salesforce Takes Its Cloud Model to Health Care
text: Salesforce, the cloud pioneer known for customer management software, is going into health care.

headline: Antarctica via France, and Other Tales of Official Expense-Padding
text: Chinese officials suffer from a reputation for dreary rigidity, but it must have taken ingenuity and stamina to spin an inspection tour to Antarctica into a boondoggle that took in visits to Chile and France.

headline: Student Crossword | Health Literacy
text: Test your knowledge of terms that are key to good health by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: 1969: Spielberg and Snow White
text: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Opium Production on the Rise Worldwide, U.N. Reports
text: UNITED NATIONS — Illegal opium cultivation occupies more land worldwide than ever before, according to the United Nations, largely because of a surge over the last year in Afghanistan, the dominant opium producer.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Major Ruling Shields Privacy of Cellphones
text: In “Major Ruling Shields Privacy of Cellphones,” Adam Liptak reports on the Supreme Court’s decision about warrantless cellphone searches.

headline: Flashy Stock Debuts Help Lift Wilting Chinese Markets
text: HONG KONG — China’s on-again, off-again market for new domestic share sales returned to action in dramatic fashion Thursday, after shares in three companies that made their trading debut all rose by the maximum 44 percent.

headline: A Graduating Kindergarten Class
text: At P.S. 130 in Manhattan, Lily Woo, the school principal, filmed a graduating kindergarten class.

headline: Pressure Loss Is Explored in Vanishing of Jetliner
text: CANBERRA, Australia — Nearly four months after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 vanished into the night, Australian transportation officials said in a report on Thursday that the plane kept flying until it ran out of fuel, most likely because the cockpit crew had become unresponsive, perhaps because of oxygen deprivation.

headline: U.K. Inquiry Finds ‘Truly Awful’ Sexual Abuse by TV Host at Medical Facilities
text: LONDON — The British health authorities said on Thursday that inquiries into sexual abuse by the disgraced television host Jimmy Savile at state-funded medical facilities had revealed “truly awful” episodes involving patients ages 5 to 75.

headline: Semiconductor Makers AMS and Dialog in Early Talks
text: LONDON – The Austrian semiconductor company AMS confirmed on Thursday that it was in preliminary talks about a “possible merger of equals” with the London-based Dialog Semiconductor.

headline: London Stock Exchange to Buy Russell Investments for $2.7 Billion
text: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay $2.7 billion in cash for Russell Investments, the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index.

headline: Mark Sanford’s Path of Most Resistance
text: It had been a 14-hour day of campaign-style barnstorming, but at nearly 11 p.m. there was something Mark Sanford felt compelled to show me. We were hiking across the Coosaw Plantation, an enviable slice of Southern landscape that Sanford’s family owns. Nestled in the marshy South Carolina coastline, it has ancient live oaks and twisting palmettos, cascading Spanish moss and views of the Coosaw River and the Atlantic beyond. But I could see none of it as we walked in the pitch black.

headline: What’s the Matter With Eastern Kentucky?
text: There are many tough places in this country: the ghost cities of Detroit, Camden and Gary, the sunbaked misery of inland California and the isolated reservations where Native American communities were left to struggle. But in its persistent poverty, Eastern Kentucky — land of storybook hills and drawls ­ — just might be the hardest place to live in the United States. Statistically speaking.

headline: Support for Maliki Slips Within His Own Party as Armed U.S. Drones Start Flights
text: BAGHDAD — As the first armed American drones began flying over Iraq on Thursday, Shiite political leaders were locked in meetings to try to decide who should be the country’s next prime minister. For the first time, some of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s own party members expressed doubt that he would be a viable candidate.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Jordanian Court Acquits Islamic Cleric in Terrorism Case
text: LONDON — A military court in the Jordanian capital, Amman, on Thursday acquitted a militant Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada on charges of planning a terrorist attack on an American school there in the late 1990s, the latest chapter in a longstanding legal fight that included a death sentence in absentia, a 10-year court battle in Britain and his deportation a year ago.

headline: A More Nuanced Breakdown of the Supreme Court
text: This is the time of year that the news media rolls out a familiar graphic: nine head shots of Supreme Court justices, arrayed from most liberal to most conservative.

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: June 26, 2014
text: What to watch for in Thursday’s games as teams from Groups G and H battle to advance in the World Cup. For the complete rundown of advancing scenarios, visit The Upshot.

headline: Pirates’ Gamble Produces a Star
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The latest Pittsburgh Pirates phenom is 6 feet 4 inches, strong but rangy, with a left arm that could throw baseballs 87 miles an hour at age 17. He looks more like a pitcher than a speedy outfielder with power and uncanny plate discipline, which is what he is and what Rene Gayo thought he could be.

headline: Ramadan Poses Test to Muslim Players at World Cup
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Down the quiet, tree-lined Rua Gonzaga Bastos, less than half a mile from Estádio do Maracanã, the custodian of this city’s only mosque was preparing for the busiest time of the year.

headline: New York Today: Last Day of School
text: Good Thursday morning to you.

headline: Teabox Seeks to Bring India’s Teas Into Modern Era
text: DARJEELING, India — The tea plantations here in the shadow of the cloud-shrouded valleys of the Himalayan mountains may be the last place to find technological innovation. Many of the colonial-era practices involved in tea-growing and processing still follow the time-honored manual labor and handwritten bookkeeping.

headline: Carney Details New Weapons to Cool British Housing Market
text: LONDON — Mark J. Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, announced measures on Thursday to try to cool England’s blistering housing market, a sector that he and other policy makers have identified as the greatest potential threat to Britain’s economic recovery.

headline: Graduates’ Red Guard Photos Cast Doubt on What They Learned
text: The photographs show a young man, held down in a bowing position by what appear to be five Red Guards, the youthful fanatics who terrorized China in the name of Chairman Mao Zedong during the Cultural Revolution. A conical hat sits on his head, a leather belt chokes his throat, and a sign denouncing him as a traitor hangs from his neck with a nylon cord. But the young man is barely suppressing a grin, and the tableau was staged as part of a university graduation celebration.

headline: Morning Views
text: “The nine justices of the Supreme Court — whose average age is 68 — often admit to being unfamiliar with modern technology, if not befuddled by it,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Yet in a gratifyingly sweeping ruling on Wednesday, the court embraced a central reality of the digital age and protected cellphones from being searched without a warrant during an arrest, except in rare circumstances.” The board is wholly supportive of the ruling. Despite government arguments to the contrary, “the expectation of privacy in a phone’s contents outweighs the immediate needs of law enforcement.”

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Far-Reaching Agenda
text: One way to think of Google is as an extremely helpful, all-knowing, hyper-intelligent executive assistant. Already, it can remind you about your flight, open up your boarding pass when you get to the airport and offer you driving directions to your hotel when you land.

headline: No Order in the Court Without Yiddish
text: Once the sounds of Yiddish filled the streets of New York. Not so much anymore. But a Times reporter, Joseph Berger, grew up with Yiddish. His knowledge of the language helped him cover a recent corruption trial in which a key government informer was a Hasidic developer who employed Yiddish in many of his recorded conversations.

headline: In Our Second Round of Employee Reviews, a Problem Emerges
text: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to re-institute employee reviews.

headline: Challenges Are Many in Predicting House Races
text: In the months leading up to midterm elections, pollsters have a limited number of tools to explain what could happen to the composition of the House of Representatives. And this year, their tools may be more blunt than usual.

headline: North Korea Fires 3 Short-Range Projectiles
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired three short-range projectiles off its east coast on Thursday, a day after it warned of retaliation against the release of an American comedy film involving a plot to kill its leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Senior Prosecutor’s Departure
text: Lorin L. Reisner, who helped overhaul the enforcement unit of the Securities and Exchange Commission before heading the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, is leaving government for the private sector, Ben Protess writes in DealBook. He is expected to join a law firm, though it is not clear which one. Mr. Reisner announced his decision on Wednesday afternoon in an email to the United States attorney’s office, where he has been the criminal division chief since January 2012.

headline: Singular Collection, Multiple Mysteries
text: AFTER my Irish mother died, 15 years ago now, my siblings and I took eons to shake our paralysis of grief and deal with the physical things she left behind. When finally I mustered the energy, or courage, I found, to my surprise, a 1958 paperback edition of “Dubliners” in her night stand.

headline: In Our Pages: June 27
text: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Paris prepares for the most important boxing match in recent years in 1914; Ponies and dogs are entitled to a “first bite” in 1939.

headline: Conventional Steps in a New Frame
text: AMSTERDAM — When a ballet offers you video on stage, a stark set and imaginative lighting, you probably have the strong impression that you are seeing an innovative work. When that work is new, and boasts a collaboration with a famous artist, and is promoted by attractive posters showing a naked body, you are likely to be even more certain.

headline: Live Stream | Louis Vuitton’s Spring 2015 Collection at Paris Men’s Fashion Week
text: The latest men’s collection from Louis Vuitton at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Alcoa Buys Jet Engine Parts Maker Firth Rixson for $2.85 Billion
text: Alcoa, seeking to build out its aerospace division, agreed on Thursday to buy Firth Rixson, a maker of jet engine parts, for at least $2.85 billion in cash and stock.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Fallout from Mississippi Runoff
text: Good Thursday morning from a sunny Washington.

headline: Taking the Time to Listen
text: This interview with Bob Farrell, chief executive of Kewill, a transportation software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Reviewing Google’s Smartwatches  — the LG G and the Samsung Gear Live
text: Google stole a wearables beat on Apple Wednesday at its developers conference in San Francisco by announcing that two watches that use the Android operating system (and can be paired with phones) — one from LG and one from Samsung — would go on sale immediately afterward in the United States. So immediately afterward, I went online to check out “Android Wear.” And my heart sank.

headline: Uighur Scholar Will Fight Charges of Separatism in China, Lawyer Says
text: HONG KONG — Ilham Tohti, a prominent Uighur scholar charged with separatism after he repeatedly criticized China’s increasingly uncompromising policies in Xinjiang, his ethnically divided homeland, told his lawyers on Thursday that he would fight the charges, one of the lawyers said.

headline: New York’s Ban on Big Sodas Is Rejected by Final Court

headline: Job Growth Is Up, Production Down
text: The most important indicators of our economic health are telling very different stories. On Wednesday, news reports made much of the fact that gross domestic product fell at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the first quarter of this year, a decline largely attributable to bad weather. That brings growth over the past year to a disappointing 1.5 percent. Yet the labor market continues to deliver good news, and over the same period, the unemployment rate fell by more than a full percentage point.

headline: NEA Names 4 New Jazz Masters
text: Three veteran musicians and a longtime Chicago nightclub owner have been awarded the 2015 National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Fellowship, a high honor for jazz musicians in the United States. They are Carla Bley, the keyboardist, bandleader and composer, known for her big and small bands and ambitious collaborations with Charlie Haden and Gary Burton, among others; George Coleman, the saxophonist and bandleader, who first became a standard-bearer through his work with Miles Davis and Herbie Hancock in the mid-’60s; Charles Lloyd, the saxophonist, flutist and bandleader, who made popular jazz records in the late 1960s, largely dropped out of jazz for a decade afterward, and has been on a consistent climb since; and Joe Segal, owner of the Jazz Showcase in Chicago since 1947. Each of the recipients, announced on Wednesday, will receive $25,000. They will be honored at an awards ceremony and concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center on April 20, 2015.

headline: Gluten-Free Dining in Italy
text: My wife is gluten-intolerant, and hasn’t eaten wheat in three years. And so, at first thought, my plan for an Italian vacation bordered on insanity. While I’m a huge fan of Italian food, for Jen a week and a half of pasta, pizza and bread — the holy trinity of the Italian table — sounded like a nightmare. As far as she was concerned, 10 days in Italy meant 10 days condemned to salads dressed with oil and vinegar. Even dessert wouldn’t be safe: gelato and tiramisù typically contain wheat.

headline: Marco Rubio Raises the Bar
text: Before I continue with my string of posts on the theme of reform conservatism’s correct views on everything, let me make a brief foray into real-world politics: Yesterday Senator Marco Rubio gave a domestic policy speech, co-hosted by Hillsdale College and the YG Network, that’s worth reading if you’re interested in what a reformist vision looks like when it’s an actual Republican politician (rather than a tribe of conservative scribblers) giving it form and substance. Naturally, it strikes me as a very impressive and encouraging speech. But I think I would say that even if I were less inclined to agree with its policy specifics, because purely as a rhetorical matter, it does something that Mitt Romney didn’t manage to do in 2012 until, well, basically the first presidential debate: That is, it tries to meet non-conservative voters where they are and talk about the issues that they say they care about, rather than lecturing them on what they should be concerned about (too few people are paying income tax! Obama doesn’t like entrepreneurs!) and assuming that they’re already persuaded. It’s a speech rooted in conservative principle without being trapped by the conservative talking points, in other words, and that’s something we saw very little of in the 2012 campaign.

She plans on picking up a few things for her summer wardrobe, too. “I quite like their shorts, which is surprising since normally I’d never be caught dead in shorts,” she says. “The fit makes me feel like Laura Dern in ‘Jurassic Park,’ or a sexy-awkward ’70s camp counselor. headline: Troubled Inquisitor
text: Political novels are full of pitfalls, particularly for a novelist with strong political leanings. Writers may craft their world however they like, so they need not deal with the complexities of reality if it inconveniences their narrative. Ayn Rand’s philosophy can work in “Atlas Shrugged,” for example, because it’s a fantasyland of her creation. A better approach can be found in “The Brothers Karamazov,” in which Dostoyevsky makes his ideological opponents his most articulate characters. Great writers force themselves to confront the challenges the world can throw against what they believe. The poet Tom Sleigh explains this as “the difference between exploring a political emotion, say, rather than a political conviction.” Whereas a political emotion is concerned with the lived experience of how politics impact people’s lives, a political conviction is primarily didactic — it “weaves no web, traps no chaotically buzzing flies — it’s hygienic, and easily put aside when the moment of outrage or conversational animus has passed.”

headline: Deep Cover: Alice Goffman’s ‘On the Run’
text: “On the Run” is, first and foremost, a remarkable feat of reporting. Its author, Alice Goffman, a young sociologist, had an ethnography assignment for an undergraduate class at the University of Pennsylvania, and she, the daughter of the renowned sociologist Erving Goffman (1922-82), didn’t take it lightly. She hung out with an older African-American food service worker at the university, and one thing led to another. Before long, she had moved into an apartment in a poor, largely black neighborhood in Philadelphia, her housemate a young man whose family lived down the block. Goffman became such a part of the fabric of the community that she was harassed by the police, witnessed someone getting pistol-whipped, was even set up on a blind date. And all the while she was furiously taking notes, trying to make sense of what at first glance appeared to be utter chaos going on around her.

headline: A Call to Rally
text: Somewhere along the long, bumpy road of human evolution — between the emergence of Davos Man and the TEDification of everything — a new breed of journalist emerged, specially adapted to the corporatized landscape of the modern media biome. Call him Aspen Man, after his proclivity for Ideas. (Aspen Woman exists, too, but the breed skews male.) Like all journalists, Aspen Man feeds upon stories, studies and statistics, but his unique genius lies in his ability to transform the resulting partly digested mix into brain candy for well-heeled aficionados of Malcolm Gladwell and Thomas Friedman.

headline: Despite New Opt-In Rules, Overdraft Fees Still Baffle Consumers
text: IT has been nearly four years since rules went into effect to help clarify when banks may charge you penalties if you overdraw your checking account using your debit card. But many people remain confused about so-called overdraft fees, a new report finds.

headline: Between the Lines of the Recess Appointments Decision
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday handed down a major decision concerning a president’s power to appoint executive branch officials when the Senate is in recess without going through the confirmation process. The court rejected the validity of four appointments President Obama made in January 2012, when the question of whether the Senate was in recess was in dispute. While on the surface the ruling was a blow to executive power, on a deeper level it was also a victory for executive power because it rolled back an appeals court ruling that had gone much further in restricting such authority.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Begin Again’
text: John Carney narrates a musical sequence from his film “Begin Again.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Clip: ‘Tick, Tick ... Boom!’
text: Lin-Manuel Miranda performs a song from the City Center Encores! production.

headline: Rebekah Brooks on Her Not Guilty Verdict
text: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, said she felt vindicated after being found not guilty of hacking phone messages and other crimes.

headline: Espaillat, Conceding to Rangel, Sets His Sights on Another Race
text: State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat officially conceded to Representative Charles B. Rangel on Thursday and announced his intention to run for re-election to the State Legislature.

headline: Zero for Six
text: For reference: I count at least six distinct predictions of Obamacare doom made by the usual suspects, not one of which has come true. Here they are:

headline: A Prodigious Beginning, Then an Early Ending
text: Moving and maddening in almost equal measure, Brian Knappenberger’s “The Internet’s Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz” is a devastating meditation on what can happen when a prescient thinker challenges corporate interests and the power of the state.

headline: In the Company of Known Strangers
text: I pulled into the gravel driveway of my childhood home, parked my ailing Ford Ranger and practiced the mantra I had invented during my two-day drive from Salt Lake City to Coos Bay, Ore.: “Take a deep breath. Don’t argue with your father. Do this for your mother.”

headline: Celebrate Summer 2014: Ways to Teach the Season
text: Every year as summer hits full swing, we post a list of ideas for teaching and learning about the joys — and challenges — of the season.

headline: John Carney Narrates a Scene From ‘Begin Again’
text: The writer and director John Carney (“Once”) brings his latest film about musicians, “Begin Again,” to the big screen. In this video, he discusses a musical sequence featuring Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.

headline: Hey, Taking Off My Clothes Is Hard Work
text: “La Bare” takes its title from the club it chronicles, a male strip joint in Dallas. The name proves unfortunately apt for a rambling, superficial documentary that straddles the line between exposé and infomercial. Directed by the actor Joe Manganiello (who was inspired by his role in Steven Soderbergh’s “Magic Mike,” set in the world of male revues), this celebratory film argues that male stripping is more strenuous than its female counterpart: It requires a full-fledged act and an athlete’s regimen. We learn a bit about the stagecraft, such as how audience volunteers are selected and why underpants with flies are forbidden.

headline: Artifice, Historical Transcendence and Cactus Plants
text: Celebrating the close of its 50th-anniversary season, Boston Ballet has come to Lincoln Center with two programs at the David H. Koch Theater. The second program, which opens on Friday, includes two masterpieces of different stages of radical modernism, Vaslav Nijinsky’s 1912 “Afternoon of a Faun” and George Balanchine’s 1972 “Symphony in Three Movements.” The first program, which opened on Wednesday, is all postmodern, all chic, all wiseguy, all full of theater games, all laden with production concepts and entirely loathsome.

headline: Caseworker, Into the Woods
text: The unforgettable hero of “Fourth of July Creek” is Pete Snow, a social worker charged with rescuing troubled children in the wilds of northern Montana. At work, he is preternaturally kind and helpful, even in the face of unbearable situations. In this rugged country, way off the grid, it seems there’s no horror he hasn’t seen, from “newly suicided fathers and their wreckage” to “the mother who calls your office wondering if you could take her child, God is telling her to kill him, you better hurry.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Syria and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Paying for Quality Education
text: Early this year, President Obama announced “version 1.0” of his college-rating system at least in part to help clarify what constituted a good investment for students.

headline: Events in New Jersey for June 29-July 5, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: U.S. Prepares for Sale of Bitcoins Seized in Its Raid on Silk Road
text: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | On its face, it looked like a typical government raid: Federal agents shut down an online drug marketplace, seizing millions of dollars of ill-gotten gains in the process.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, the Netherlands, Russia and Germany.

headline: U.N. Official Says Syrian Rules Are Preventing Aid Delivery
