text: Ever since the Security Council reached a hard-won consensus to help United Nations aid agencies deliver food and medicine to Syrians trapped by war, compliance with its resolution has been low. On Thursday, the United Nations’ top aid official told the council that new Syrian bureaucracy had made compliance even lower.

headline: Forced to Hand Over Data, Facebook Files Appeal
text: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorney’s office are in a bitter fight over the government’s demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts.

headline: Facebook Case Over Search Warrants for User Information
text: Facebook has argued that Manhattan prosecutors violated the constitutional rights of its users last year by demanding the nearly complete account data of 381 people, from pages they liked to their photos and private messages.

headline: Fewer Loan Applications
text: Spring failed to inspire a surge in home sales nationally this year, even though mortgage rates are still reasonably low. Although economists insist that the housing market is on an upward trend, abnormal conditions left over from the recession continue to be a drag.

headline: Howard Makes Enough Stops to Keep the U.S. Going
text: The United States, needing only a tie against Germany to advance to the Round of 16, began the game on their heels.

headline: Let the Mass Destruction Begin
text: “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” the fourth film in an apparently inexhaustible, profoundly exhausting series based on Hasbro toys, raises, not for the first time, a basic question: Who are these movies for? This one, like its predecessors, is likely to make a lot of money all over the world, but that only makes the matter more puzzling. The “Transformers” franchise seems like the most baldly and cynically commercial calculation imaginable — it is merchandising-based entertainment at its purest — and yet somehow it does not pander.

headline: Globalfest to Make Its Summer Debut
text: Eleven musical acts, three film screenings, family-friendly performances and an underground bass stage will mark Globalfest’s summer debut, at Lincoln Center on July 27, organizers announced on Thursday.

headline: Court Rules Against Aereo, but Not Against Innovation
text: On Wednesday morning, the Supreme Court handed down a 6-3 ruling that it was unlawful for Aereo, a television streaming service, to capture and stream broadcast television signals to subscribers. The court found that Aereo’s service violated the Copyright Act by not securing permission from broadcasters to enact “public performances” of their programs. This result is a largely seen as a boon to networks and a threat to start-ups, particularly those that use cloud-based technology to allow file sharing.

headline: Say Hi, but Don’t Pry
text: My husband and I were sitting in the waiting room of a fertility clinic, when I recognized a woman who was a friend from college 18 years ago. I hadn’t seen or spoken with her since. Would it have been O.K. to say hello to her in this situation? Could I have asked if she’s married and what she’s up to, the way I would any other friend? How about explaining that we were not there for IVF treatment but for a follow-up, since we lucked out and got pregnant on our own?

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Torture Details for U.S.S. Cole Bombing Suspect
text: Defense lawyers for terrorism suspects at Guantanamo Bay have long complained — and with good reason — that ongoing government resistance to sharing details about mistreatment while in U.S. custody makes it hard, if not impossible to provide adequate legal representation.

headline: Elizabeth A. Sackler to Lead Brooklyn Museum Board
text: Elizabeth A. Sackler has been named chairwoman of the Brooklyn Museum, the first woman in the museum’s nearly 200-year history to serve in that position.

headline: World Cup Captivates America, Except for Ann Coulter
text: Many Americans were excited to learn on Thursday that the United States would advance to the next round of World Cup competition. One who probably was not: Ann Coulter.

headline: With Rangel’s Win, Another Chapter in the Gang of Four
text: Yesterday, Representative Charles B. Rangel won the primary election contest to represent New York’s 13th District in Congress. Darren Sands wrote about the campaign in last Sunday’s magazine, noting that Rangel’s political strength in the community began in the 1980s, when the Coalition for a Just New York ‘‘rallied minority voters and African-American and Latino candidates.’’ The most prominent among the coalition was the ‘‘Gang of Four,’’ which included Charles Rangel, David N. Dinkins, Basil Paterson and Percy Sutton. Sands says that for decades the Gang of Four’s influence went virtually unchallenged, and for now Rangel seems to be holding on. Here’s a selection of what has been said over the years about the Gang of Four and their influence in Harlem:

headline: The Genre, if Not the Song, Remains the Same
text: Before it was a Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, “Once” was a scruffy and charming movie, written and directed by John Carney, about a man and a woman united by their love of music and their unstated but obvious attraction to each other. Filmed at street level in the lived-in parts of a picturesque city, it managed to be touristic and authentic at the same time, partly because the central pair consisted of a native and an outsider. Mr. Carney pulled off the enviable trick of dressing unabashed romantic sentiment in a style that felt rough and real, so that every cliché he touched felt shiny and new.

headline: Fear of Packing
text: We all have our favorites when it comes to the life-changing inventions of the 20th century, and mine is the Baggie.

headline: Rapper Convicted of Murder, Racketeering and Drug Dealing
text: After one day of deliberations, a federal jury on Thursday found a Bloods gang leader from the Gowanus Houses in Brooklyn guilty of all 21 counts he had been tried for, including three murders, racketeering and drug trafficking.

headline: Senior U.S. Prosecutor Joins Paul Weiss
text: A day after Lorin L. Reisner announced that he was stepping down as head of the criminal division of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, the law firm Paul Weiss on Thursday named him as a partner in its litigation department.

headline: Clip: ‘Transformers: Age of Extinction’
text: A scene from the movie.

headline: The Dark Side Gets Its Due
text: Most of us don’t stop for death until it kindly, or unkindly, stops for us. And then there is the new Morbid Anatomy Museum, which will throw the Grim Reaper an enthusiastic welcome party when it opens its doors this weekend in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn.

headline: A 3,000-Mile Road Trip to the World Cup
text: Dado Galdieri, a photographer, followed Chilean fans driving to Brazil in hopes of seeing their team make the finals.

headline: Inner Musings on a Precarious Descent
text: On certain college campuses, Michael Hersch’s new opera, “On the Threshold of Winter,” would come with a boldface trigger warning. The two-act monodrama, which received its searing premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is about illness and death. Its texts, taken from deathbed poems by the Romanian writer Marin Sorescu, offer an unflinching look at the rage, despair and sense of isolation he felt in his final weeks in a Bucharest hospital ward.

headline: Theater Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 27-July 3
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Art as Architecture and as Currency
text: For refreshingly un-Koonsian ideas about sculpture, look no further than the three solo exhibitions now at SculptureCenter. One is a large-scale installation by the midcareer Icelandic artist Katrin Sigurdardottir; the other two are smaller projects by the emerging American artists Liz Glynn and Jory Rabinovitz. Shiny objects and artisanal craftsmanship play a role here, as they do in Jeff Koons’s survey at the Whitney, but so do imperfection, evanescence and parsimoniousness.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Crumbs Bake Shop Set to Delist From Nasdaq
text: The cupcake craze may be getting stale.

headline: A Shift in the Beautiful Game
text: When Spain, Italy and England have all gone home, and the United States is through to the Round of 16 of the World Cup, something has shifted in the beautiful game. Jurgen Klinsmann’s U.S. team has been gritty, cohesive and occasionally explosive, as when Jermaine Jones almost burst the net with his equalizing rocket against Portugal. America, less naïve with each recent World Cup, deserves its place in the knock-out phase.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Stuck in Steerage for the Postapocalypse
text: In the mood for allegory? Have a look at Bong Joon-ho’s “Snowpiercer,” which proceeds from a fantastical premise rich with real-world relevance. After a human-engineered planetary catastrophe (trying to arrest the planet’s warming, we accidentally froze it solid), the remaining people are stuck on a train that never stops moving. A few thousand survivors live in railway cars, sorted into a rigid and ruthlessly enforced social order. In the back are huddled masses fed on gelatinous, insect-based black protein bars and kept in line by a combination of propaganda and brute force. Toward the front, the more fortunate enjoy access to schools, nightclubs, fresh food and the reassurance that they deserve everything they have. An unseen, quasi-mythical entrepreneur is in charge, and a group of rebels have decided to challenge his power and the extreme inequality he represents.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: F.C.C. Issues Snapshot of U.S. Internet Service
text: WASHINGTON — The number of homes in the United States that subscribe to Internet service has grown at a 15 percent annual rate over the last decade, to 85 million. But as much as 30 percent of households do not have a connection faster than dial-up speed, according to government figures released this week.

headline: A Brooklyn Show Celebrates an Inventive Mind of the Midway
text: A KING OF THE MIDWAY,

headline: Dance Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Matchmaker in Reverse
text: The jokes and sight gags fly in exhausting profusion in “The Breakup Guru,” Deng Chao and Yu Baimei’s antic, scattershot romantic comedy. Mr. Deng plays the titular fixer, Mei Yuangui, a successful specialist in terminating the relationships of celebrities and socialites through entrapment, public humiliation and other unsavory methods. (These tactics are accompanied by a lot of mugging and extreme grimacing.) Now, with three trusty helpers, Yuangui has one last job: to help a smarmy, Western-style motivational speaker and “successologist” (Liang Chao) unload his Beijing mistress, Ye Xiaochun (Yang Mi). To that end, Yuangui resolves to trick the mistress into falling for none other than himself. Somehow, for all his overemphatic mannerisms, he succeeds.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 27-July 3
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Environmental Agency Approves $511 Million Loan for Tappan Zee Replacement
text: The New York State agency that lends federal money for sewer plants and other clean-water projects on Thursday approved a $511 million loan to the Thruway Authority for 17 projects that are part of the building of a twin-span replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

headline: From Letter Carrier to a Name in Lights
text: In various incarnations, the animated children’s series “Postman Pat” has been a staple of British television since 1981. The title character is a letter carrier who, along with his cat, Jess, brings joy and generosity to the farm community of Greendale.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 27-July 3
text: Bug Day

headline: Michaels I.P.O. Prices at $17, at Low End of Range
text: The Michaels Companies, the arts and crafts retailer that has spent nearly eight years in private ownership, is ready to make its public markets debut.

headline: Two Lives, Ruthlessly Exploited
text: Every few years, it seems, someone rediscovers the Hilton sisters, the conjoined twins who spent decades as a sideshow attraction and then a vaudeville act in the heart of the last century. They are having a moment again: A new production of “Side Show,” the stage musical inspired by their lives, has recently opened at the Kennedy Center in Washington, and now “Bound by Flesh,” a straightforward documentary by Leslie Zemeckis, is being given a theatrical release.

headline: Spare Times for June 27-July 4
text: NYC Pride Events (Friday through Sunday) The monthlong celebration of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender diversity concludes this weekend with something for everyone. A free rally with performances will kick things off on Friday, from 6 to 9:30 p.m., at Pier 26, in Hudson River Park, at North Moore Street, TriBeCa. It will be followed by a dance party for men, starting at 11 p.m. at BPM, 516 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Women will get their own party at Pier 26 on Saturday, from 4 to 10 p.m.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 27, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” “Snowpiercer” and “Begin Again.”

headline: Mixed Emotions at a Gathering to Say Goodbye
text: Joanna Hogg — where have you been all my movie-loving life? That thought buzzed through my head after, with intensifying greediness, I tore through this British director’s three features: “Unrelated,” “Archipelago” and “Exhibition.” They’re finally receiving American distribution, so if you’re lucky enough to be in New York, run over to the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center and catch them now.

headline: Stiff Drinks and Stiff Upper Lips: Britons on a Tuscan Holiday
text: Because it has no conventional action or schematic story, “Unrelated,” Joanna Hogg’s dyspeptic portrait of upper-middle-class Britons on a summer holiday in Tuscany, is the antithesis of popcorn entertainment. The guests, who span two generations, convene in a spacious rented villa equipped with a large swimming pool and caretakers. The movie observes their leisure activities with a chilly documentary objectivity.

headline: Lost to the Grim Realities of India
text: Mahendra Saini (Rajesh Tailang), the meek, sad-eyed protagonist of Richie Mehta’s touching film “Siddharth,” is a resident of New Delhi, with a wife, a son approaching puberty and a younger daughter. He ekes out a living on the streets fixing zippers, touting his service through a bullhorn, but business has been bad. In the film’s opening moments, he says goodbye to his son, Siddharth, who is leaving on a bus to work in a factory in distant Ludhiana. The boy’s employer, Om Prakash (Amitabh Srivasta), is a distant cousin of Mahendra’s brother-in-law, Ranjit (Anurag Arora). Both are hardened in ways that Mahendra is not.

headline: Slain Libyan Rights Activist Documented Her Last Hours Online
text: Just hours before she was assassinated on Wednesday, one of Libya’s most prominent civil rights activists, Salwa Bugaighis, logged on to Facebook to urge her fellow citizens of Benghazi to head to the polls and vote, despite violent clashes in the streets between Islamist militias and the forces of a renegade general.

headline: When Boy Meets Girl in Ben Franklin Wigs
text: In “They Came Together,” a sloppy, fitfully funny broadside at the romantic comedy, the director David Wain goes after that oft-abused genre with a metaphoric jackhammer — as well as a bat, a machete, a couple of knives, one or two missiles and the sort of sizzling cartoon bomb that Wile E. Coyote used to hurl. Mr. Wain has some expert help with his demolition work, namely his stars, Amy Poehler and Paul Rudd, who with another dozen or so cutups, embody assorted romantic comedy stereotypes with wide smiles, seasoned technique and unfettered spleen.

headline: After More Than 100 Days Away, Tiger Woods Plays Like His Partners: Raggedly
text: BETHESDA, Md. — If it had been a band from the swing era, the Tiger Woods trio would have been booed off the stage Thursday at Congressional Country Club. But it was a golf group, and the crowd, which lined up five deep around the 10th tee and formed a human outline around the 208-yard par-3 hole, was overwhelmingly supportive from start to finish.

headline: In Prisons, Sky-High Phone Rates and Money Transfer Fees
text: Inside the razor wire on Eagle Crest Way, in rural Clallam Bay, Wash., telephone calls start at $3.15. Emails out, beyond the security fence, run 33 cents. Money transfers in, to what pass for bank accounts, cost $4.95.

headline: Navigating the New Publishing World
text: To the Editor:

headline: 178 Years Late, a Briton Replenishes the Alamo
text: SAN ANTONIO — Phil Collins, a member of Genesis and a staple of 1980s-era MTV, arrived at the Alamo here on Thursday carrying a sword and a dagger. Jerry Patterson, the Texas land commissioner, brought two guns, one tucked in his cowboy boot and the other in his waistband.

headline: A Trial in a Troubling Context
text: James J. Bulger, better known as Whitey, was a notorious and widely feared criminal in Boston in the 1970s and ’80s. He disappeared after being tipped off about an impending arrest in 1994, and after that was a famous fugitive. Captured three years ago in California — where he had been living quietly with his longtime girlfriend — Mr. Bulger was tried last summer on a host of charges, including 19 counts of murder. His trial is the subject of “Whitey,” a gripping and troubling new documentary by Joe Berlinger.

headline: Resilient Dreamers
text: Patti Smith and Klaus Biesenbach have teamed up to start a new festival to celebrate the re-opening of Fort Tilden and their adopted community in the Rockaways.

headline: Action by Argentina Seems to Defy Judge’s Order on Bond Payments
text: Argentina made a puzzling and potentially provocative move on Thursday in its landmark legal battle with New York hedge funds, which are suing the country over bonds that it defaulted on over 10 years ago.

headline: Jookin in the Spotlight
text: Lil Buck, born Charles Riley, has bounced from music videos to a Super Bowl halftime show to Lincoln Center. He introduced mainstream audiences to jookin, a street dance born in his hometown, Memphis.

headline: Finally, a Tide of Celebration in the Rockaways
text: PATTI SMITH has been visiting the Rockaways in Queens since the 1970s, when she would venture around the secluded Fort Tilden, the national park and beach, with Robert Mapplethorpe.

headline: Why Immigrant Children Are at Our Door
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Conclusion in Inquiry Into Scott Walker’s Campaign Fund-Raising
text: CHICAGO — A special prosecutor investigating possible illegal fund-raising coordination between the Wisconsin campaign of Gov. Scott Walker and conservative groups has reached no conclusion as to whether there is enough evidence to charge anyone with a crime, the prosecutor’s lawyer said in a statement issued Thursday.

headline: Shapes of an Extroverted Life
text: There are so many strange, disconcerting aspects to Jeff Koons, his art and his career that it is hard to quite know how to approach his first New York retrospective, the Whitney Museum of American Art’s largest survey devoted to a single artist.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Comedy and Carnage
text: There are few circumstances in which it’s comforting to find yourself under interrogation, but Oscar (Kyrre Hellum), the hero of “Jackpot,” is in an especially tight spot. Can he explain how he ended up surrounded by eight dead bodies in a Swedish sex shop — the last man standing, despite never having fired a shot?

headline: In Gaza, Work but No Pay
text: Being a government employee in Gaza does not guarantee a paycheck, as workers hired by rival political factions fight for scarce funds.

headline: Fans Hospitalized in Latest Dance Music Setback
text: In the latest headache for the growing business of electronic dance music, three dozen fans were hospitalized in Boston on Wednesday night after going to a concert by the star D.J. Avicii, apparently for problems related to drugs and alcohol.

headline: Leave Iraq to the Iraqis
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Aplomb, Young Star Passes Test
text: WIMBLEDON, England — If adversity is the best education, the 5-foot-10-inch Madison Keys experienced a competitive growth spurt after dropping the second set of her second-round match here Thursday against the physically overmatched but persistent Klara Koukalova of the Czech Republic.

headline: Money Splits a City Still Mourning Its Firefighters
text: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Smoke drifted from the fire that tore through the chaparral brush on nearby mountains after the flames had claimed the lives of 19 firefighters almost a year ago, immersing this tight community in heartache. In the months that followed, tributes — on storefronts, on bumper stickers and along the mesh-iron fence surrounding Station 7, the firefighters’ home base — stood as glaring reminders of a tragedy no one here has forgotten.

headline: Israel Names Prime Suspects in Abductions
text: JERUSALEM — Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha, both residents of the West Bank city of Hebron, were last seen on the night of June 12, shortly before three Israeli teenagers went missing while hitchhiking a few miles to the north.

headline: Make College Accessible
text: To the Editor:

headline: Libraries and the Young
text: To the Editor:

headline: For British Spy in Iraq, Affection Is Strong but Legacy Is Unfulfilled
text: BAGHDAD — A picture of Gertrude Bell, the British diplomat and spy, still hangs on a wall in the Alwiya Club, the Baghdad clubhouse for the social elite that she established, and black-and-white photographs of her can be found in the collections of the city’s old families.

headline: Militarism and Humiliation Cast Shadow on Germany
text: KIEL, Germany — On June 28, 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm II was preparing to indulge in a favorite pastime: racing his yacht Meteor at a regatta that is still held each year in this seafaring stronghold. When he learned of the assassination in Sarajevo of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir to the Hapsburg Empire, he hastened to Berlin. But he quickly returned to this Baltic Sea port, on which he lavished so much money and time in his frantic race to match or outdo British naval superiority.

headline: The War to End All Wars? Hardly. But It Did Change Them Forever.
text: ZONNEBEKE, Belgium — To walk the orderly rows of headstones in the elegant graveyards that hold the dead of World War I is to feel both awe and distance. With the death of the last veterans, World War I, which began 100 years ago, has moved from memory to history. But its resonance has not faded — on land and geography, people and nations, and on the causes and consequences of modern war.

headline: Belgians Share Their Land With War’s Reminders
text: YPRES, Belgium — The padlocked cage beside the driveway on the Butaye family farm near this town in western Belgium is almost full of rusting bombs again. Since January, Stijn Butaye has collected 46 mortar shells on his family’s 100 acres, World War I munitions he found among the sugar beet and potato fields, sometimes with the help of his metal detector.

headline: In Sarajevo, Divisions That Drove an Assassin Have Only Begun to Heal
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — As the 100th anniversary approaches, the clusters of visitors have thickened at the street-corner museum in Sarajevo’s old town that stands where Gavrilo Princip claimed his place in history on June 28, 1914, firing the shots that killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie, and setting off World War I.

headline: A Battle in Ukraine Echoes Through the Decades
text: MOUNT MAKIVKA, Ukraine — In a conflict that cost millions of lives, destroyed four empires and introduced Europe to the horrors of chemical weapons and total war, the battle on a pine-covered mountain in what is today western Ukraine was a modest affair. A few hundred soldiers died, and the outcome was so muddled that all sides claimed victory.

headline: When the Americans Turned the Tide
text: CHÂTEAU-THIERRY, France — Fifty miles to Paris. That was all that separated a hardened German Army from, perhaps, the end of the Great War. By early 1918, the Germans were rolling through northern France, and French commanders feared they were planning a decisive attack against the capital. First, though, they had to cross a ribbon of green water known as the Marne. And traverse a small forest known as Belleau Wood.

headline: Murdoch’s Letter on Slaughter at Gallipoli
text: In 1915, Keith Arthur Murdoch wrote an 8,000-word letter to Prime Minister Andrew Fisher of Australia, describing what he called “one of the most terrible chapters in our history.”

headline: Destroying Bombs From World War I
text: France’s Department of Mine Clearance is responsible for collecting and destroying unexploded shells still found by the thousands nearly 100 years after the Battle of Verdun.

headline: The Bomb Collector of Ypres
text: World War I relics, including unexploded shells, are exhibited by Stijn Butaye, 26, on his family farm.

headline: At Gallipoli, a Campaign That Laid Ground for National Identities
text: CANAKKALE, Turkey — The trenches are still there, carved in the green hills of the slim Gallipoli Peninsula just across the Dardanelles, the waterway that connects the Aegean and Marmara Seas on the way to Istanbul from the port city of Canakkale. Gravestones adorn the beachheads and lands farther inland, marking the lives of the young men — Britons, Frenchmen, Australians, New Zealanders and their enemies, the Ottoman Turks — who died there, almost a century ago.

headline: Tourists Flock to Damaged Cars
text: A sinkhole that swallowed eight cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., is now attracting tourists.

headline: Heedless of Traffic Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Court Overturns Death Sentence for 1985 Killing
text: MIAMI — With new DNA evidence in hand, a divided Florida Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the death sentence and conviction of Paul C. Hildwin, a man found guilty nearly three decades ago of strangling a woman in Hernando County, Fla. The woman, Vronzettie Cox, 42, whose body was found in the trunk of a car, had been raped.

headline: Tribe, Purveyor of Hummus, Hopes to Narrow Sabra’s Lead With New Campaign
text: HUMMUS, the dip made with chickpeas, is believed to have been eaten for millenniums, but it has flown off deli section shelves in recent years as if it were a novelty. Sales in the United States of refrigerated flavored spreads, a category dominated by hummus, grew 21 percent, to $695.5 million, for the 52 weeks ending May 18, according to IRI, a market data firm.

headline: U.S. Defense Is Bolstered by a New Man in the Middle
text: RECIFE, Brazil — Because the memory of Portugal’s fifth-minute goal against the United States on Sunday was still so fresh, the last thing the team and its fans needed to see Thursday afternoon was another early defensive miscue.

headline: Lock ’Em Up Nation
text: How did the United States, land of the free, become the world’s top jailer? It’s a question asked by visitors from other democracies, and the American citizen who wakes from a stupor to find that our prisons are stuffed with people serving interminable sentences for nonviolent crimes.

headline: In Atlanta, Some Dispute Murder Charge Against Father in Hot-Car Death of Boy
text: ATLANTA — The legal drama that has gripped this city for more than a week comes down to whether a 2011 Hyundai Tucson should be considered the scene of a crime or of a horrible mistake.

headline: Where Killings Are Common, Death of Activist Stuns Benghazi
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Salwa Bugaighis, a Libyan lawyer and civil rights activist, stood on the roof of her home in Benghazi on Wednesday and watched as armed groups fought gun battles on the edges of town.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees’ Lawyers Urge Obama to Approve Release to Uruguay
text: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for six low-level detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, whom Uruguay has offered to resettle sent a letter to the Obama administration on Thursday urging it to act on the deal, which has been awaiting the signature of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel since March.

headline: Artful Guises in the Belle Epoque
text: Popular culture at its most pop produces our modern mythology of superheroes, monsters and galactic conspiracies. But not all myths are created equal. Writing about mid-1950s sci-fi films, the British critic Raymond Durgnat discovered a necessary dialectic that he called “the wedding of poetry and pulp.”

headline: The Supreme Court Was Right to Allow Anti-Abortion Protests
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Even as a committed supporter of a woman’s — increasingly imperiled — right to choose, I must acknowledge that the Supreme Court got it right on Thursday.

headline: Obama: ‘You Guys Are the Reason I Ran’
text: In remarks delivered Thursday, President Obama discussed the ways in which he relates to the problems of common Americans.

headline: High Tension and a Cold Shoulder at Border of Two Koreas
text: PANMUNJOM, South Korea — Lt. Cmdr. Daniel McShane dashed from the rainstorm into the sentry post. Minutes earlier, he had walked up to a strip of concrete that marks the de facto border with North Korea and, through an interpreter, read out a request: An American colonel wanted to meet face to face with his North Korean counterpart.

headline: Clip: ‘Earth to Echo’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Dave Green.

headline: In a Diner With Obama, a Serving of Ordinary Life
text: ST. PAUL — In the first episode in a series the White House is marketing as “Day in the Life” visits ahead of the midterm elections in November, President Obama spent part of Thursday with a mother who had written to him about her struggles.

headline: The Incompetence Dogma
text: Have you been following the news about Obamacare? The Affordable Care Act has receded from the front page, but information about how it’s going keeps coming in — and almost all the news is good. Indeed, health reform has been on a roll ever since March, when it became clear that enrollment would surpass expectations despite the teething problems of the federal website.

headline: Cavaliers Pick Wiggins at No. 1, Bringing N.B.A. Draft Speculation Full Circle
text: As the college basketball season hummed along, speculation of who would be the top pick in the N.B.A. draft shifted from Andrew Wiggins to Jabari Parker to Joel Embiid. On Thursday, as Adam Silver conducted his first draft as commissioner, things came full circle, and it was Wiggins who walked onto the Barclays Center stage sporting a Cleveland Cavaliers hat as the No. 1 overall pick.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 26, 2014
Here Are the 43,634 Properties in Detroit That Were on the Brink of Foreclosure in 2014
text: A mosaic, created with images from Google Maps Street View, shows one of the many enormous challenges facing Detroit as it tries to climb out of debt.

headline: Secrets of the Universe, Embedded in Pop Ditties
text: Airless and earthbound, “Radio Free Albemuth”  resembles a weird artifact from the early days of science-fiction television — a lost episode of “The Outer Limits” or “Tales of Tomorrow.” Based on the novel of the same title by Philip K. Dick (published posthumously in 1985), this lifeless adaptation only proves that making entertaining movies out of hard-to-swallow ideas is as challenging as you might think.

headline: Most Will Be Able to Automatically Renew Coverage Under Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced Thursday that most people would be able to renew subsidized health insurance coverage without filing an application and without going back to HealthCare.gov, the website that frustrated millions of consumers last fall.

headline: Redrawn Lines Seen as No Cure in Iraq Conflict
text: ISTANBUL — Over the past two weeks, the specter that has haunted Iraq since its founding 93 years ago appears to have become a reality: the de facto partition of the country into Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish cantons.

headline: Bleak Prognosis From Both Sides of Aisle in House for Immigration Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — Two leading House lawmakers — one Republican and one Democrat — declared efforts to overhaul the nation’s broken immigration system all but dead for the year, the result of hardening Tea Party opposition and growing mistrust of President Obama among congressional Republicans.

headline: A Dark Horse Is Adjusting to Rising Expectations
text: SÃO PAULO — It was always the neighboring Dutch who painted their houses orange for the World Cup, drove orange cars and wore orange outfits until everything and everyone in the Netherlands was the color of a traffic cone.

headline: Politicians’ Prescriptions for Marijuana Defy Doctors and Data
text: New York moved last week to join 22 states in legalizing medical marijuana for patients with a diverse array of debilitating ailments, encompassing epilepsy and cancer, Crohn’s disease and Parkinson’s. Yet there is no rigorous scientific evidence that marijuana effectively treats the symptoms of many of the illnesses for which states have authorized its use.

headline: In the Eye of a European Political Storm Stands a Quiet Enigma
text: LUXEMBOURG — As millions of Greeks faced misery amid Europe’s debt crisis, Jean-Claude Juncker, the Luxembourger helping to oversee their rescue, was asked at a news conference what would happen if Greece failed to meet the demands of the lenders who had bailed out the country.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Powerful New Consensus
text: WASHINGTON — FOR years, particularly after the 2000 election, talk about the Supreme Court has centered on its bitter 5-to-4 divisions. Yet it is worth reflecting on a remarkable achievement: The court has agreed unanimously in more than 66 percent of its cases this term (and that figure holds even if Monday’s remaining two cases, on the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptive coverage and on public-sector unions, are not unanimous). The last year this happened was 1940.

headline: As a Bandwagon Fills, a Team Fails Forward
text: RECIFE, Brazil — The United States soccer players seemed to pass the ball to Germany more often than they did to their own teammates. Late in the game, two Americans — Jermaine Jones and Alejandro Bedoya — were left splayed on the field after running into each other and knocking heads. Jones had also hit the turf earlier when he ran at full speed into the referee.

headline: This Weekend: A Jeff Koons Retrospective
text: Make this weekend an art-filled one. There’s the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney, a new morbid museum in Brooklyn and an arts festival in the Rockaways.

headline: The Road to Dov Charney’s Ouster at American Apparel
text: In a dimly lit private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan, four board members of American Apparel and their lawyer plotted out their next 24 hours over steaks and red wine.

headline: In Botched Case of Park Jogger, an Altered Life
text: After the man was finished raping the 20-year-old college student and searching her apartment for money, he announced that he had to kill or blind her. He held an ice pick to her eyes, then found a blade. Already he had bound her with telephone wire ripped from the wall.

headline: A 100-Year Legacy of World War I
text: World War I demolished empires and destroyed kings, kaisers and sultans. It introduced chemical weapons and aerial bombing. It brought women into the work force and hastened their legal right to vote.

headline: They Don’t Make ’Em Like They Used To
text: ARROWSIC, Me. — TO reach our house in Maine, my wife and I drive hundreds of miles on highways, cross scores of bridges and even go through a tunnel or two. And as we come down the home stretch on a dirt lane full of rocks and ruts, I am reminded of how a piece of private real estate is a microcosm of our national infrastructure.

headline: As Pakistan Advances Against Taliban, Fleeing Civilians Pour Into Northern Towns
text: BANNU, Pakistan — Pakistan stepped up its drive against the Taliban in North Waziristan on Thursday with heavy strikes and a commando raid on Miram Shah, the district’s largest town, in what military officials described as the prelude to a major ground offensive.

headline: Songs and Scars From Father to Son
text: Benjamin Scheuer, the writer and star of “The Lion,” has a pretty mane of blond hair and a wide, friendly smile that’s cuter than a dozen kitty videos. When he bounds onstage to open the show, guitar in hand and dressed in a natty suit with the tie slightly askew, he looks as if he’s just stepped off a fashion runway, or leapt to life from off an Abercrombie & Fitch shopping bag (albeit fully clothed).

headline: The Disturbing Anthrax Accident
text: It is distressing that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is supposedly expert at handling extremely dangerous pathogens, was so sloppy this month that it potentially exposed more than 80 people at its laboratories in Atlanta to deadly anthrax spores. The incident carries a stark warning that even the best laboratories can slip up, with potentially catastrophic consequences should they be working, as some are, with germs that can spread a lot more readily than anthrax.

headline: Mangrove Menace
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This was the world’s easiest and most enjoyable Friday puzzle I can remember doing in quite a while until I got to the bottom half. That’s when things fell apart for me.

headline: BNP Paribas Expected to Plead Guilty and Pay $8.9 Billion Fine
text: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, according to people briefed on the case. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: The Spiritual Recession
text: For the past few centuries, the Western world has witnessed a contest of historic visions. On the one side was the dream of the beautiful collective. Human progress was a one-way march toward socialism. People would liberate themselves from religion, hierarchy and oppression. They would build a new kind of society where equality would be the rule, where rational planning would replace cruel competition.

headline: In the Shadows of Shrines, Shiite Forces Are Preparing to Fight ISIS
text: KARBALA, Iraq — A dozen miles outside this shrine city, on the edges of the uninhabitable western Iraqi desert, a group of paramilitary policemen provides the only visible line of defense against the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Parts Supplier Delphi Is Scrutinized in G.M. Recall
text: Senate investigators are widening the scope of the inquiry into General Motors’ decade-long failure to recall cars with a defective ignition switch to also focus on the supplier that made the flawed part.

headline: A Unanimous Supreme Court: Abortion Rights Lose a Buffer
text: In the world as Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia imagines it, anti-abortion advocates resemble Eleanor McCullen, a self-described “mother and grandmother” who stands outside a reproductive-health clinic in Boston and attempts to gently “counsel” approaching women out of getting an abortion.

headline: A Unanimous Supreme Court: A Blow to Presidential Appointments
text: When one branch of government routinely abuses its constitutional power in order to prevent another from functioning, the Supreme Court is expected to take notice and stop the abuse. Unfortunately the court failed to do so on Thursday in an important balance-of-power case, raising the prospect that President Obama and his successors could have trouble making necessary appointments to executive posts as the nation’s politics become more sharply polarized.

headline: Events in Westchester for June 29-July 5, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Lew Unveils Small Steps to Augment Loan Modification Program
text: The Obama administration will take further steps to ease foreclosures, rising rents and scarce mortgages, Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary, said on Thursday at a conference observing the fifth anniversary of Making Home Affordable, a suite of federal programs aimed at helping homeowners after the financial crisis.

headline: In Bronx, Joy and Agony for Ghana’s World Cup Match
text: The faithful filed into a tiny back storeroom of the Malata African Market in the Bronx, making their way past the bins of giant yams and the freezer of dried fish, and took their seats in rickety rows.

headline: Events in Connecticut for June 29-July 5, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Remote-Control Brace
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first wearable motorized device that helps people with spinal cord injuries to walk. The device, called ReWalk, consists of a fitted metal brace that supports the legs and parts of the upper body, and a motor that moves the hips, knees and ankles. Users can command it to stand up, sit or walk using a wireless remote control worn on the wrist, but they must be assisted by another person, the agency said.

headline: Events on Long Island for June 29-July 5, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Mets’ Night Features Lots of Outfielders, but Few Runs
text: PITTSBURGH — As the Mets took the field here Thursday, Bobby Abreu went to left field, Curtis Granderson to right and Juan Lagares to center.

headline: Honduras Releases Jailed Florida Crew
text: Six Americans who traveled to the Mosquito Coast of Honduras last month planning to dredge a river but instead ended up in jail were released Thursday.

headline: Knicks Draft Cleanthony Early of Wichita State
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Draft night has not always been kind to the Knicks. Not that anyone needs reminding, but there have been missteps over the years, including the selections of projects. Renaldo Balkman, anyone?

headline: Plan Expedited for Affordable Housing Near Barclays Center in Brooklyn
text: After 11 years of delays, lawsuits and a recession, the developer behind the Atlantic Yards project has agreed to greatly accelerate the construction of affordable housing in a deal that involved delicate negotiations with state officials, the de Blasio administration and a coalition of community groups.

headline: Cuomo Signs Bill Seeking Reforms at Queens Library
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a Queens Library reform bill into law Thursday, a move intended to bring order to a system that has recently been under fire over its use of funds.

headline: How Texans May See a Property Tax Cut
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: When to Use Your Head
text: Should children head the ball in soccer? What  can be done to reduce the risk for brain injury?

headline: New Twists as House Weighs Impeaching a Regent
text: During a special session of the Texas Legislature more than a year ago, a resolution calling for the impeachment of Wallace Hall, a University of Texas System regent, was filed in the House — and according to the leadership, it could have passed.

headline: At Border, Immediacy of a Crisis Supersedes Politics
text: McALLEN, Tex. — The child whose dull eyes came alive when a shelter volunteer handed her a floppy-eared, pink bunny doll does not know she and her mother, who crossed the border with her, are in the middle of a political firestorm.

headline: John Tull, Lawyer Whose Illness Created a Bioterrorism Scare, Dies at 65
text: John Tull, a New Mexico lawyer who was found to have bubonic plague during a visit to New York in November 2002, prompting alarm that the infection might have been caused by bioterrorism, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 65.

headline: The Runway Is Clear
text: If Willy Wonka ran a boatyard, it might be along the lines of Evers Marina and Seaplane Base, on the Bronx waterfront.

headline: Detroit Needs Residents, but Sends Some Packing
text: DETROIT — Ronald Ford Jr. has watched neighbors move away and brick houses on his family’s block crumble to nothing, but he says he wants to stay put and give a chance to city leaders who now promise a renaissance. “I’d like to try to go with the new Detroit if that’s really coming,” Mr. Ford, 49, said, standing outside the house on the city’s east side that he describes as precious, “like a family heirloom.”

headline: Ask Well: Fatty Liver and Diet
text: Recently, in “Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity,” Anahad O’Connor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about what to eat if you have fatty liver.

headline: Word of the Day | savor
text: savor •\ˈsa-vər\• noun and verb

headline: For Young Offenders, a New Confidence Game
text: At the Crossroads Juvenile Center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, shrill buzzers announce the movement of sliding doors, and visitors leave all metal objects in lockers by the entrance. The residents are as young as 10 years old, awaiting trial on charges ranging from trespassing to murder.

headline: Kenya’s Future Clouds as Tensions Rise and Tourists Flee
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The line at the water tank in the Kibera slum is not as long as it used to be. It’s not because of a sudden advent of indoor plumbing. It’s because fewer people can afford a 10-cent jerrycan of water.

headline: Niki Acosta: Camp Boss Covers All the Bases
text: When 200 or so young New Yorkers converge in Battery Park City on June 30 for the first day of a camp run by Asphalt Green, there is one thing they will not have in common with the manager Niki Acosta: She never went to camp as a child. “I went to Y.M.C.A. programs, but it was only weekly, or sporadically,” Ms. Acosta, 28, said the other day in her office, where she was immersed in preparations. Now in her second year at the nonprofit’s downtown outpost (there is also a 5.5-acre campus on the Upper East Side), she said, she has been “gearing up for the first day of camp since September of last year.” Ms. Acosta lives in one half of a two-family house in Woodside, Queens, with a poodle named Otis.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett, above, won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients out of millions — leaving her with little more than her pearls, white Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and monogrammed Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men (Andrew Dice Clay and Bobby Cannavale) Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads, and starts to see light at the end of her terribly dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ” What did Jasmine know about her husband’s unscrupulous business dealings, and when did she know it? “These questions come to haunt ‘Blue Jasmine,’ and as the past catches up with the present, they help drive this moving, sometimes funny film toward its shattering end,” Ms. Dargis added.

headline: N.H.L. Draft Prospect Is Familiar With Pressure
text: Considered by many as the most N.H.L.-ready prospect in this weekend’s draft, Aaron Ekblad is no stranger to playing under immense pressure.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 27, 2014
text: “A painted line on the sidewalk is easy to enforce, but the prime objective of the First Amendment is not efficiency.”

headline: Corrections: June 27, 2014
text: THE ARTS

headline: Shia LaBeouf Arrested for Disorderly Conduct at Studio 54
text: The actor Shia LaBeouf was removed from the Studio 54 theater in Midtown on Thursday and arrested after disrupting a performance of the musical “Cabaret.”

headline: People’s Daily Takes Firm Stance Against Urine Consumption
text: If imbibing urine is not your cup of tea, People’s Daily — the solemn voice of the Chinese Communist Party — is with you on that one. On Friday, the newspaper took time off from its usual encomiums to party leaders to warn people against drinking their own pee.

headline: First if No Longer Foremost
text: It is called the nation’s Mother Court because it was created even before the United States Supreme Court, in 1789, when New York City was the nation’s capital. (In truth, though, the court for what became the Southern District of New York was first only because the opening of the federal court in New Jersey was delayed after a jurist became indisposed.) In “The Mother Court: Tales of Cases That Mattered in America’s Greatest Trial Court” (American Bar Association Publishing), James D. Zirin, a trial lawyer and former federal prosecutor, engagingly introduces readers to some of the signature trials and towering jurists of the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: The Taco Truck Stops Here
text: The sidewalks of Sunset Park are rarely empty. Most mornings, elderly Chinese women gather on a grassy hillside in the Brooklyn neighborhood to do calisthenics to pop tunes. In the evenings, Latino kids race up and down the sloping blocks. And even in a humid drizzle, at least two dozen people lounge against a chain-link fence across from the Jackie Gleason Bus Depot at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street, waiting for tacos.

headline: An Icon of Indian Roads Is Set Out to Pasture
text: “When the Ambassador car was born in 1957 to a newly independent India, it was the height of style and status,” Nida Najar wrote in The New York Times. “It was standard issue to senior civil servants and government officials; its possession implied status, and its ubiquity was a sign of an earlier, seemingly simpler India.”

headline: Student Crossword | Africa
text: Test your knowledge of Africa by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Lawsuit Adds to Concern Over China Commodities Fraud
text: HONG KONG — China’s commodities fraud scandal continues to widen, with more companies reporting losses on bogus aluminum and copper financing deals, while Chinese authorities now say gold contracts have also been faked to secure more than $15 billion in loans.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal
text: In “U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal,” Sam Borden writes about the results of Thursday’s United States-Germany World Cup game.

headline: UniCredit’s Online Unit Raises at Least $916 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON — FinecoBank, an online banking and brokerage arm of the Italian lender UniCredit, said on Friday that it had raised at least 673 million euros, or about $916 million, in its initial public offering in Italy.

headline: U.S. Lays Groundwork to Reduce Land Mines and Join Global Treaty
text: After five years of study, the Obama administration put the United States on a course Friday to eventually sign the global treaty that bans antipersonnel land mines, announcing steps that will gradually reduce the American stockpile and find ways to adjust for any military disadvantage in purging the weapons.

headline: What the Camera Sees, and Doesn’t See
text: The photograph from January 2013 is ethereal: a close-up of goldfish swimming in an aquarium. The water that sustains them is ominously cloudy. Yet, they survive.

headline: Defying Russia, Ukraine Signs E.U. Trade Pact
text: BRUSSELS — Dealing a defiant blow to the Kremlin, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine signed a long-delayed trade pact with Europe on Friday that Moscow had bitterly opposed. He then declared he would like his country to one day become a full member of the European Union.

headline: New York Today: Pick Your Pool
text: Good morning to you on this summer-break Friday.

headline: In Taiwan, Chinese Official Confronted With Voices of Democracy
text: Zhang Zhijun, the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit Taiwan, has said he wanted to hear the voices of its people during his four-day trip to the self-governed island. Demonstrators in Taiwan have tried to meet that request, following him since the start of his visit on Wednesday. And while the official meetings have been less confrontational, with talk of increasing trade and travel across the Taiwan Strait, some local leaders have also talked up Taiwan’s democratic values, a sharp contrast with Communist-ruled China, which considers Taiwan as part of its territory.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: A Minimum Wage That Makes More Sense
text: Travel around this country a bit and, assuming your purchases are not confined to airports and big hotel chains, you will find that prices vary a great deal. Prices in New York State are 15 percent above the national average, while those in Arkansas are 12 percent below average. Housing is about twice as costly in Massachusetts as in Mississippi.

headline: Daily Report: Effort by Facebook to Safeguard Data From the Law Fails, For Now
text: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorney’s office are in a bitter fight over the government’s demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts, Vindu Goel and James C. McKinley Jr. report.

headline: The Agriculture Secretary Sees a Smart (Phone) Solution to GMO Labeling Fight
text: I’ve been at the Aspen Ideas Festival, which has focused this week on next steps for healthy living, including better food choices.

headline: New Signs That China Is Scrutinizing Foreign NGOs
text: An image being passed around the social media site Weibo — posted by the Chinese newsmagazine Phoenix Weekly, among others — shows several men straining to hoist a flag atop rubble, a reference to the iconic World War II image of American troops hoisting the United States flag at Iwo Jima.

headline: Sorry, Harry Reid: Koch Industries Probably Pays a Lot of Corporate Tax
text: In 2010, the economist Austan Goolsbee said something he would come to regret: On a White House conference call, in his capacity as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, he named Koch Industries as an example of a large company that does not pay corporate income tax because of the way it is organized.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: A Photographer Hunting for Light
text: Throughout the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: In Class Action Against Apple and Others, Concerns From the Judge
text: Silicon Valley, at least according to myth, is all about risking everything on an idea. You seize a dream and do not let it go until you make it or they come and repossess your desk. Failure in the valley is admired. It makes you smarter, tougher, more likely to succeed next time.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In the news this week: Supreme Court rulings on abortion protests, cellphone searches and more.

headline: Morning Views
text: “In the world as Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia imagines it, anti-abortion advocates resemble Eleanor McCullen, a self-described ‘mother and grandmother’ who stands outside a reproductive-health clinic in Boston and attempts to gently ‘counsel’ approaching women out of getting an abortion,” writes The New York Times Editorial Board, in response to the Court’s decision to strike down a Massachusetts law that established buffer zones around abortion clinics. The editorial says the ruling “ignores what actually happens on the ground,” including “a long and sometimes violent history of protest at reproductive-health clinics.”

headline: Report Underscores Lingering Doubts in Search for Missing Plane
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — As Australia prepares a yearlong search for the jet carrying Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in an area of ocean floor the size of Croatia or West Virginia, a government report underscores the lingering uncertainty about where the plane went down, noting that it might have fallen in an area of the southern Indian Ocean up to 19 times as large as the new search area.

headline: Why Is the World Silent?
text: TORA, Egypt — In a few days’ time, I will complete 365 days of imprisonment, more than half spent in solitary confinement and under severe limitations in the maximum-security Scorpion wing of Tora prison in Cairo. I have spent the past year thinking about what drove me to where I am today. I have also been thinking about an explanation for why politicians, human rights activists and the media have largely been silent about my case.

headline: China’s Anticorruption Campaign Unseats a Powerful Party Chief in Guangzhou
text: HONG KONG — The Communist Party chief of Guangzhou, one of China’s most populous and wealthiest cities, has been held for investigation by the party’s anticorruption agency, state-run media announced on Friday, one day after he admonished city officials to embrace President Xi Jinping’s campaign against lax discipline.

headline: Morning Agenda: $8.9 Billion Penalty for BNP
text: BNP TO PLEAD GUILTY AND PAY $8.9 BILLION FINE  |  BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. The plea deal, which authorities hope to announce on Monday, will include a statement of facts that outlines how BNP, France’s largest bank, hid the names of Sudanese clients when processing transactions through its American operations.

headline: Oh You Silly Thing, of Course He’s Gay
text: As he descends a staircase in the opening scene of “Vicious,” a new comedy making its PBS debut on Sunday, Ian McKellen overhears his lover, played by Derek Jacobi, reacting to bad news he received on the telephone.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: All They’re Missing Is a Black Market Etsy
text: Season 2, Episode 7 The world is too much with our friends at Litchfield as their various commercial enterprises kick into high gear. And this episode, “Comic Sans,” brings the mounting sense that all this getting and spending will not end well.

headline: How Islamic Fundamentalists Will Rule Mosul
text: From the way they have run Raqqa city and parts of eastern Syria, we can make an educated guess as to how jihadis from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) will govern Mosul. Women probably won’t be able to go out on their own. Coke and other Western products will likely be banned. Suspected thieves may well be detained and might risk amputation, execution or public flogging. As the group sweeps through Iraq in a surprise advance that’s left everyone from Assad to Obama wondering how to halt it, Mosul’s residents just need to look next door for evidence of the extremist group’s notoriously harsh governing tactics.

headline: While You Were Watching World Cup 2014
text: Nobody was watching the skies.

headline: Today in Small Business: How Much Cash Can I Take Out?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Among Gay C.E.O.s, the Pressure to Conform
text: In 2007, John Browne, Lord Browne of Madingley, resigned as chief executive of the British oil giant BP after being outed as gay by the tabloid The Mail on Sunday: “The True story about Lord Browne — by ex-rent boy lover.”

headline: Milan Fashion Week Crowd Honors Dorchester Boycott
text: MILAN — It was nearing midnight. On television screens in the bar of the Principe, on the last day of the men’s wear shows here, a World Cup match was playing. Unusually for this venue, every kick and call could be heard. Roughly half the tables were filled with couples or groups drinking quietly, and at the overstaffed bar, at least five servers waited to fill orders.

headline: Chinese Workers at Iraq Power Plant Said to be Headed to Safety
text: More than 1,000 Chinese workers at a power plant north of Baghdad were being evacuated to the capital city after previous attempts to move them to safety had failed, associates of the workers and Chinese state media said on Friday.

headline: Reliving Childhood Excursions
text: For children of the 1980s, there was no shortage of opportunities to see kids like themselves being heroes, while also being kids, on the big screen. Movies like “E. T.” and “Stand by Me” were hallmarks, placing young people in extraordinary situations and giving them room to explore new worlds just a bike ride away. They showed boys and girls on adventures of their own making, with their parents often on the sidelines. If the new science-fiction film “Earth to Echo,” due in theaters on Wednesday, bears a resemblance to these ’80s movies, it’s because the men behind it were raised on them.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: After 25 Years, Modest Gains at Mumbai Breast Milk Bank
text: MUMBAI — On a recent afternoon, 27-year-old Ashwini Agarwal adjusted her sari as she emerged from the crowded outpatient department at the Lokmanya Tilak Hospital, a public facility that houses the oldest of India’s roughly 14 breast milk banks, established a quarter of a century ago.

headline: An Education of the Heart: The Glenwood Towers Senior Center Prom
text: “Can I have this dance?” a woman in a strapless black sundress said, offering her hand to my son. It was 93 degrees out on the patio at the senior center in downtown Raleigh, N.C. Aidan, dressed in his only suit and a striped tie, said, “of course.” I heard Esther counting the steps for him as she guided him into a waltz. One-two-three. One-two-three.

headline: Russia Abruptly Cancels Rocket Launch
text: MOSCOW — The long-awaited inaugural launch of a new Russian space rocket, the Angara, was abruptly canceled on Friday just minutes before takeoff, the Russian space agency Roscosmos reported.

headline: Shiite Cleric in Iraq Urges Quick Decision on New Government
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s top Shiite cleric on Friday urged the country’s divided political factions to select a prime minister by early next week in a public call for a political solution that increases the pressure on the embattled prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: In Our Pages: June 28
text: 1889: Salvation Army Versus Police

headline: She’s No One’s Idea of a Grandma
text: Susan Sarandon was mildly disappointed that she wouldn’t make the trek to Burning Man this summer. She attended that free-spirited Nevada desert festival for the first time last year, and said she felt safely inconspicuous since “there’s a lot of girls walking around with amazing bodies and no clothes on, so you’re not that interesting.” She even thought about bringing some of Timothy Leary’s ashes with her on a return visit.

headline: Lawyers Defend Hong Kong Rule of Law in Show of Unity Against Beijing
text: Hundreds of lawyers, many clad in black, marched in Hong Kong on Friday to demonstrate their concern that a recent policy paper issued by Beijing poses a threat to the rule of law in the city.

headline: A New Search Zone for Malaysian Jet
text: Officials expanded the hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 into an area farther south. An investigation concluded that the plane was likely on autopilot before it vanished.

headline: Is The Times Ignoring a Scandal at the I.R.S.?
text: Has The Times been interested enough in the politically charged events involving the Internal Revenue Service?

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama Returns, Powers Diminished
text: Good Friday morning from Washington.

headline: A Nudge to Save a Bit More
text: If you’re an active participant in social media, it’s nearly impossible to avoid a running tally of everyone else’s spending. New cars and home renovations are all over Facebook. Vacation photos, exotic meals and charity benefits are a fixture on Instagram.

headline: The Art Crowd Returns to Kent, England
text: The Isle of Thanet, a thumb of land protruding from the Kent Coast in England, has always been a draw for creative types. T. S. Eliot wrote there, referencing “Margate Sands” in “The Waste Land”; Broadstairs was a favored getaway of Charles Dickens; and the 19th-century painter J. M. W. Turner supposedly said “the skies over Thanet are the loveliest in all Europe” — a sentiment no doubt shared by many of the artists who are again coming to the area.

headline: Not So Fast on the Use of Google Glass in Britain
text: LONDON – For tech-savvy Britons, the debut in this country of Google’s Glass headset on Monday was greeted with much fanfare.

headline: Q. & A. | Fashion Designer Duro Olowu on Curating His Second Art Show
text: “Do you think it’s a bad idea to put this on the floor?” asked the fashion designer Duro Olowu yesterday as one of his assistants positioned a bulbous ceramic vessel near the entrance of the Salon 94 Bowery gallery. As he directed art handlers and gallery assistants to arrange a hodgepodge of sculptures, textiles and framed artworks into dense vignettes in preparation for his second gallery show as curator, “More Material,” which opens to the public today, Olowu seemed as hands-on as he would designing a dress in his studio.

headline: A World Cup of the Americas Ends Upbeat First Phase
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — The opening phase of this World Cup ended with Algerians celebrating, and they were hardly the only ones feeling upbeat after a first round to remember.

headline: A Fashionable Role for Julian Assange?
text: No, this is not a joke. Ben Westwood, the 51-year-old son of that agent provocateur Dame Vivienne Westwood, on Friday proved himself heir to his mother’s crusading mantle by announcing he was planning to have Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder, model in his debut fashion show in London this September.

headline: Presenting ‘Play-Doh’
text: The artist Jeff Koons unveils his new sculpture “Play-Doh” in a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. The piece took 20 years to complete.

headline: In Paris, the Bastille Neighborhood Recaptures Its Cool
text: Fifteen years ago, Bastille was the emerging cool neighborhood of Paris. Then, as the masses discovered the south side of the 11th Arrondissement, the inevitable backlash occurred. The city’s self-appointed tastemakers declared the area fini and decamped for points north and west. Bastille descended into a haven of grungy student bars, low-end creperies and charmless fast-food outlets. Over the last year, however, some of France’s most famous restaurateurs, chefs and designers have planted their flags in the neighborhood where the famous prison once stood. Style-savvy upstarts have done likewise, further elevating the area’s profile for epicures and night owls. Little by little, a new crowd is storming Bastille.

headline: At the Month-Mark, Modi Reflects
text: NEW DELHI — On Thursday, as the government headed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi completed 30 days in office, Mr. Modi, with a perceptible confidence in his political persona, reached out to the public through a blog post.

headline: Sleep as a Competitive Advantage
text: At 6 p.m. last Friday, I boarded a plane for Bangalore, India. At 1 p.m. Tuesday, I arrived back in New York after two days of meetings and traveling 34 hours across nine time zones. As you can imagine, I didn’t see much of Bangalore.

headline: R.B.S. to Spend $1.7 Billion on Mobile Banking Growth
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland is making a major bet that consumers in the future will do most of their banking on mobile phones or tablets.

headline: After Buffer Zone Ruling, Abortion Rivals Prepare to Square Off Anew
text: BOSTON — Lorraine Loewen, 74, says she comes here once a week to demonstrate against abortion outside of the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts health care center.

headline: The Perils of Anaerobic Driving
text: Plus: Gazprom vs. the prom; fireworks displays, ranked.

headline: The Real Hedwigs
text: The Broadway success of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” suggests that gender-bending male performance has moved closer to the American mainstream, but it has also been flourishing in clubs around the world. The photographer Magnus Arrevad spent close to five years in several countries, documenting men applying makeup, dressing in elaborate costumes and performing. One of them, Eric Gorsuch, who goes by Mr. Gorgeous, says he has witnessed the transformation of the art form in real time. “I’m superlucky in that I feel like, even looking five years ago till now, so many people today are aware of and acknowledge different kinds of sexuality — gay, straight, bisexual, whatever,” he says. “When society becomes a little more aware of other people’s lifestyles, it allows people to make decisions artistically. For me, if it was 10 years ago, I don’t think I would feel as confident being a male performer doing a parody of a stocking peel in high heels.” Julie Bosman

headline: How to Solve an 88-Year-Old Literary Mystery
text: As Edward and Rebecca Cummings passed the town of Center Ossipee, N.H., in their new 1926 Franklin sedan, it began to snow. They left their home in Cambridge, Mass., hours before, driving a car with high seats, no defroster and a top speed of about 50. Rebecca took over the driving for the last part of the trip to their summer place at Silver Lake.

headline: Reply All: The 6.15.14 Issue
text: THE NEXT FRONT IN THE TERRORISM FIGHT

headline: Looking for the Russia I Once Knew
text: On my last night in Petrozavodsk, in the last months of the Soviet Union, I stood in an unlit back alley buying boots off a soldier from the nearby army base. They were knee-high, and black, and illegal. It was midnight. I was 14. For about a month, I’d lived with a host family as part of a student exchange. In a week, leaving the country, I would wait, sweating, at Sheremetyevo airport while security rummaged through random suitcases, hoping they wouldn’t choose mine. Soviet Army surplus is ubiquitous now, but in 1991, you had to buy it on the black market and smuggle it out. If you got caught, I figured, you probably stayed in Moscow while the rest of your exchange group flew home.

headline: Who Made That Slip ’N Slide?
text: Long before Apple and Amazon were founded in humble garages, another quintessentially if decidedly lower-tech American success story began the same way — only the garage was used as a human launching pad.

headline: Carl Hart: ‘Crack Wasn’t the Real Problem’
text: The Columbia professor talks to Amy Chozick about what the public, politicians and even Public Enemy don't get about drug addiction.

headline: Is It Wrong to ‘Spoil’ World Cup Results?
text: A friend of mine is a soccer fan, but instead of checking scores and highlights of the World Cup while he’s at work, he records every game to watch later on — usually in the evening, sometimes the next day. He gets annoyed when friends “ruin” the outcome of a game before he has had the chance to see it in full; he acts as if we’ve just spoiled the conclusion of “Breaking Bad.” Do I have an ethical obligation not to discuss the outcome of games in my friend’s company until he has caught up? J. S., COLUMBUS, OHIO

headline: The Brave New World of Three-Parent I.V.F.
text: In August 1996, at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., a 39-year-old mechanical engineer from Pittsburgh named Maureen Ott became pregnant. Ott had been trying for almost seven years to conceive a child through in vitro fertilization. Unwilling to give up, she submitted to an experimental procedure in which doctors extracted her eggs, slid a needle through their shiny coat and injected not only her husband’s sperm but also a small amount of cytoplasm from another woman’s egg. When the embryo was implanted in Ott’s womb, she became the first woman on record to be successfully impregnated using this procedure, which some say is the root of an exciting medical advance and others say is the beginning of the end of the human species.

headline: Image of the Day: June 27
text: A memorial ceremony at the Imphal War Cemetery in Manipur to honor the soldiers who died during World War II.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Goodwood Is Addicted to Winning
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Reform Conservatism on Work and Poverty
text: Turning back to this week’s official theme, reform conservatism’s liberal critics, I want to discuss a recent column from my colleague Thomas Edsall that, without mentioning our quasi-movement by name, raises one of the sharpest objections to our program of any left-of-center piece I’ve seen. Where reform conservatives tend to argue for a welfare system and tax code organized more explicitly around work and family, Edsall’s piece makes the case that we’ve already tried something like that approach — have been trying it, in fact, since the early 1990s — and that it has worked out pretty badly, failing completely at its stated work-promoting aims while making life increasingly desperate for the very poor.

headline: U.S. Catfish Program Could Stymie Pacific Trade Pact, 10 Nations Say
text: WASHINGTON — Ten Asian and Pacific nations have told the Office of the United States Trade Representative that the Agriculture Department’s catfish inspection program violates international law, and their objections could hamper Obama administration efforts to reach a major Pacific trade agreement by the end of next year.

headline: Mary Rodgers, Author and Composer in a Musical Family, Dies at 83
text: Mary Rodgers, who wrote songs and children’s books and, by virtue of genetics and serendipity as well as talent, lived at the red-hot center of American musical theater, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Shares of Michaels, Arts and Crafts Retailer, Are Flat on Debut
text: Updated, 5:41 p.m. |

headline: Five Guys and a Mean-Looking Dude
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Kris Van Assch: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Letters: Carter’s Woman Question
text: Carter’s Woman Question

headline: Starting From Scratch
text: Robert Galbraith’s “The Silkworm” is reviewed this week, and with all due respect to Galbraith, the extent of his success may be due entirely to J. K. Rowling. The mystery is the second written by the Harry Potter creator under the pseudo­nym. “I was yearning to go back to the beginning of a writing career in this new genre, to work without hype or expectation and to receive totally unvarnished feedback,” she wrote on her website last year after being unmasked. Oh, well.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FORTY-ONE FALSE STARTS: Essays on Artists and Writers,  by Janet Malcolm. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) Whether she’s observing artists and writers present (David Salle, Thomas Struth) or past (Edith Wharton, the Bloomsbury group), what resonates most here is Malcolm’s cool intelligence and psychoanalytic knack for noticing. The title essay, a 1994 profile of Salle, starts over 41 times, parodying Salle’s own violent juxtaposition of images.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: SONG OF THE SHANK,  by Jeffery Renard Allen. (Graywolf, paper, $18.) Allen’s masterly novel blends the personal story of the enslaved autistic piano prodigy Thomas Wiggins with the history of the Civil War and Reconstruction.

headline: Filmmakers
text: FIVE CAME BACK  A Story of Hollywood and the Second World War  By Mark Harris  Penguin Press, $29.95.

headline: Ghost of the Confederacy
text: Robert E. Lee occupies a remarkable place in the pantheon of American history, combining in the minds of many, Michael Korda writes in this admiring and briskly written biography, “a strange combination of martyr, secular saint, Southern gentleman and perfect warrior.” Indeed, Korda aptly adds, “It is hard to think of any other general who had fought against his own country being so completely reintegrated into national life.”

headline: The Awakening
text: Le Roy, N.Y., a former factory town ­between Rochester and Buffalo, became famous three years ago when 14 girls and one boy were afflicted with undiagnosed verbal and physical tics. Cheerleaders writhing and snarling on the “Today” show: It’s not hard to understand why Megan Abbott, a reliable producer of noir page turners, based her seventh novel, “The Fever,” on the Le Roy outbreak.
