In real life, the underpinnings of the ­teenagers’ outbursts turned out to be psychological. But in “The Fever,” Abbott attributes the epidemic to a curious brand of black magic.

headline: Marooned
text: To quote a line that’s sure to make hearts flutter: “We’re almost completely cut off here.” In THE BONES BENEATH (Atlantic Monthly, $25), “we” is a party composed of Mark Billingham’s supersleuth, Inspector Tom Thorne; a skeleton staff of police officers and crime scene investigators; and two murderers. “Here” is a mountainous island off the coast of Wales, said to be the resting place of 20,000 saints. And being “cut off” from civilization is fair warning that the characters in this thriller are likely to revert to savagery.

headline: Fed’s Balance Sheet Punctuated by a Big Question Mark
text: In the midst of the Federal Reserve’s creative but controversial quantitative easing program — the five-year plan of buying billions of dollars in debt securities each month and forcing down interest rates to historically low levels — the central bank’s balance sheet has ballooned to nearly $4.3 trillion in assets from $800 billion, leaving one large unanswered question hanging over the marketplace: What does the Fed intend to do with all those bonds?

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
text: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..

headline: Nixon and Pelé: No Meeting of the Minds
text: On Tuesday, May 8, 1973, at midday, Richard Nixon received the soccer star Pelé, member of the Brazilian team that won the World Cup championship of 1970. (In 1999, the International Olympic Committee voted Pelé “Athlete of the Century.” He is now 73 and retired.)

headline: Art Matters | The Gallery Queen of Palm Beach Takes L.A.
text: Most art dealers have opened their happy-go-lucky summer shows and are gearing up to close for the dog days come August. Last night, however, Sarah Gavlak — whose Gavlak Gallery in Palm Beach has survived many a balmy winter as the only game in town — opened a new space in Los Angeles. And this time, Gavlak has plenty of competition in her new backyard. The L.A. gallery occupies a former manufacturing plant on Highland Avenue below Santa Monica Boulevard — just a couple of storefronts up from Hannah Hoffman gallery, around the corner from Regen Projects, and just a block or so down from Kohn Gallery’s roomy new digs that opened just last month.

headline: Bargains With a ‘But’
text: A four-bedroom on the Upper West Side listed for $875,000 has been languishing since December. A $385,000 two-bedroom in Manhattan Valley has been available for six months. And a studio in Chelsea with a $299,000 price tag only recently went into contract after nearly a year and $60,000 in price cuts.

headline: Dov Charney, Vying to Regain Control of American Apparel, Seeks to Increase His Stake
text: The pressure is mounting at American Apparel, the retailer of American-made clothing that fired its founder, Dov Charney, last week.

headline: Gunslingers
text: Wonderful title. Head-scratcher of a novel.

headline: L’Étranger
text: “How long can we keep on kidding these people?” George Orwell asked in 1939 after a walk through Marrakesh’s vast squalor in French-ruled Morocco. Orwell, who himself had earlier been a colonial British official in Burma, went on: “How long before they turn their guns in the other direction?”

headline: Fortune’s Daughter
text: At the end, she loved watching SpongeBob and the Smurfs, bidding (by proxy) on antique French dolls and writing enormous checks to her nurse, sometimes two in one day. When she died in 2011 at 104, Huguette Clark was flush with property — apartments totaling 42 rooms on Fifth Avenue, a 23-acre estate in Santa Barbara and a 22-room mansion in New Canaan, Conn., that she had never bothered to ­furnish. (In 1961, her Santa Barbara caretaker quit because he was suffering from the isolation: Clark had reportedly not visited the place since 1953.) Yet despite such splendid real estate, Clark had chosen to spend the final two decades of her life in a series of modest hospital rooms attended by a small circle of extremely well-paid retainers, including her doctor, her nurse, her accountant and her lawyer.

headline: These Ages of Shoddy
text: Henry Petroski, an engineer who’s also a fine writer, has a lament about the decline of good construction in today’s Times. It’s a great read; I’m trying to figure out whether I believe in his premise.

headline: Neighborhood Watch
text: In the middle of the night, a jet-lagged woman, unable to sleep, goes for a walk along a country road in the New England town where her family has summered for generations. Frankie Rowley, newly returned from years of relief work in Africa, is certainly lost in the middle of her life’s journey, and in a dark night, if not precisely in a dark wood. Unsure of her place in the world, unsure whether she has a place in the world, Frankie has come to Pomeroy, N.H., for a life-reassessment disguised as a visit to her parents, who have decided to live full time in their summer house following her father’s retirement from teaching. It’s only after a car passes Frankie on the road, its headlights sweeping past in a disorienting arc, that she realizes the smell of smoke has been in the air for some time.

headline: Inside the List
text: Inner Bloke: Back in 2006, when J. K. Rowling was at work on her seventh and final Harry Potter novel, an unnamed publishing insider told The Daily Express in Britain that “she will soon be in a position where she doesn’t have to write if she doesn’t want to, and if she does, she can write whatever she chooses.” Here’s the update, eight years and three non-Potter books later: Rowling wants to write. But she could do without the distractions of fame; that’s why she adopted the pseudonym Robert Galbraith for her Cormoran Strike crime series, also projected to last seven volumes. (“The Silkworm,” the second entry in the series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, while its predecessor, “The Cuckoo’s Calling,” is No. 8 on the trade paperback list.) “When I ‘unmasked’ myself to my editor,” Rowling says on the official Robert Galbraith website, “one of the first things he said was ‘I never would have thought a woman wrote that.’ Apparently I had successfully channeled my inner bloke!”

headline: Li Na Ousted at Wimbledon; Novak Djokovic Advances
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After leading out of the gates at the beginning of the year, Li Na has now twice become one of the fastest top players to the exits at the last two Grand Slam events.

headline: Between Innings
text: The sport of deciphering baseball — of finding embedded within the history, structure, statistics and conventions of our national pastime some secret cultural code that might cast light on our cryptic national character — was born in 1954. Seven years earlier, Jackie Robinson had signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers to break the sport’s color line, finally giving baseball the conditio sine qua non for any democratic claims it might make. Two years before that, American servicemen in Europe had celebrated Germany’s surrender by gleefully retrofitting the Nuremberg stadium into a ballpark, holding regular games where Hitler had recently rallied the Nazis.

headline: As Bad as It Gets
text: Between 1921 and 1970, the Chicago Bears won eight N.F.L. championships as tenants of Wrigley Field. The Yankees and Tigers have clinched the World Series there, but the Cubs, who have played in the park since 1916, never have. In fact, they haven’t won a World Series since 1908, a stretch of futility longer than that of any other North American sports franchise. What’s the problem?

headline: As Iraq Smolders, The Times Fortifies Its Baghdad Bureau
text: BAGHDAD – Three weeks ago, the Times bureau consisted of two rooms in the BBC house in central Baghdad. The nonresident bureau chief, Tim Arango, had moved to Istanbul, though he had been back many times in the past year as the storm clouds gathered, and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria grew ever stronger.

headline: Moving In, Slowly, to ‘Billionaires’ Row’
text: As soon as Linda Phillips and her husband heard about One57, a luxury 90-story skyscraper that is nearing completion on West 57th Street, they raced from the pied-à-terre they rented at the Time Warner Center across Columbus Circle to take a look.

headline: Saudi King Promises Help in Delicate Effort to Unite Factions in Iraq
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia assured American officials on Friday that he would use his influence with Sunni leaders in Iraq to try to speed the formation of a multisect government there, a senior State Department official said.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: For a government agency that’s flown under the radar for most of its 80-year history, the Export-Import Bank of the United States is getting a lot of attention recently: It’s now at the center of a fight in Congress over the role of government in business. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar look at why the Export-Import Bank is under such scrutiny, and what it means for business in general.

headline: 50 Ways to Love Your Quinoa
text: You’d think I would eventually run out of ideas for quinoa. I’ve posted over 50 recipes on this page over the years. But ideas keep coming and I keep loving this grain (O.K., Paleos, I know, it’s a seed, not a grain. But we use it on the plate like a grain, so that’s what I’ll continue to call it.)

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The French Intifada’
text: This week, Andrew Hussey talks about “The French Intifada”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Alice Goffman discusses “On the Run”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The French Intifada’
text: This week, Andrew Hussey and Alice Goffman.

headline: Ukraine Signs European Union Trade Deal
text: President Petro O. Poroshenko spoke at the signing ceremony of the trade deal between Ukraine and the European Union in Brussels.

headline: When Negativity Is What We Need
text: If your friend is feeling bad about himself, you might try to convince him that everything’s actually O.K. But a new study suggests this kind of reassurance doesn’t necessarily make people with low self-esteem feel better, and some say it’s further evidence against the idea that positive thinking heals all wounds.

headline: Mysterious Art: An Installation Inspired by the Bermuda Triangle
text: Fifty years ago the Bermuda Triangle entered international pop-culture consciousness with a cover article in the pulp magazine Argosy describing a treacherous patch of sea that seemed to swallow up aircraft and ships with alarming and mysterious frequency.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Driven | 2015 Subaru Legacy 2.5i
text: All-wheel drive and invisibility come standard.

headline: New York Parish Fears Losing Daily Dose of ‘Spiritus Sancti’
text: As the Rev. Justin Wylie took the pulpit at the Church of the Holy Innocents in Manhattan last month, anger and anxiety emanated from the pews. The church is the only one in New York City to offer a daily traditional Latin Mass, but an archdiocesan panel had recommended that it be closed.

headline: Defending Devotees of the Latin Mass in New York
text: At the end of his sermon on May 18, the Rev. Justin Wylie, a visiting priest from South Africa, defended the traditionalist parishioners of Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents on West 37th Street in Manhattan. He told them that even if the Archdiocese of New York follows through with a recent recommendation to close their church, they should still insist that the archdiocese provide devotees of the Latin Mass with a spiritual home.

headline: After a Dismal Quarter, a Rosy Outlook
text: THROUGHOUT the economic recovery since the Great Recession officially ended in the summer of 2009, consumers have generally remained doubtful that the economy really has gotten better. Now, as they finally conclude that the business climate has improved, a hitherto perfect recession indicator has sounded a warning.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Snowpiercer’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Snowpiercer.”

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
text: A century after the start of the First World War, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Begin Again’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Begin Again.”

headline: What Happened to the Facebook Phone? Not Very Much, It Seems
text: Facebook has long wanted to be a major part of how you use your smartphone. Now, it looks as if the company has all but abandoned one of its major strategies to do so.

headline: Video: The 2015 Subaru Legacy Feels Better Than It Looks
text: It’s better to look good than to feel good, or so said Billy Crystal channeling Fernando Lamas. Why choose? These days, you can have it all in the midsize sedan segment. The current Fusion, Optima, Mazda 6 and Chrysler 200 all look mah-velous. More important, sales numbers reflect their fashion-forward confidence.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Transformers 4’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Transformers: Age of Extinction.”

headline: Days of Imperial Pleasures and Regrets
text: SANDWICH, England — Jane Gardam’s most famous novel, “Old Filth,” begins with stage directions and elliptical dialogue, which it’s tempting to imitate in describing Ms. Gardam, a writer who unites literary critics in puzzlement over why she isn’t more famous.

headline: Where Old Curiosity Shops Abounded
text: Just when did we let 57th Street slip out of our hands? I mean the fashionable address that had room for the funny little shop, the offbeat bookstore, the aged brownstone, the fragment of a mansion? It is hard to put a finger on any particular new development that crossed the line, but one disappearance sums up for me the long-lost magic of the street.

headline: Military Multipliers of Death
text: In World War I, technical advances in warfare on land, sea and even the air put deadly new tools in the hands of millions, and death and destruction resulted on a scale without precedent.

headline: Broken Windows, Broken Parks
text: A few weeks ago in an interview with The New York Times, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton signaled his distaste for subway showmen, suggesting that their music-fueled cartwheeling was not just a disruption of mass-transit reading habits but, rather, symbolized a sort of latent urban menace. Two decades after he last ran the country’s largest police force, broken-windows policing, the practice of combating minor offenses in an effort to deter more serious ones, hasn’t lost its fascination for Mr. Bratton.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s ‘Hard Choices’ Blocked in China
text: BEIJING — The new memoir of Hillary Rodham Clinton, “Hard Choices,” which gives blow-by-blow accounts of tough discussions with Chinese officials, particularly on human rights, has been blocked in China, according to the American publisher.

headline: A Show House With Lots to Show
text: Starting on Sunday, Holiday House Hamptons will showcase indoor and outdoor living spaces created by 18 interior and landscape designers, each honoring a holiday of its creator’s choosing and often of the designer’s invention. Presented by Hamptons Cottages & Gardens magazine, the event benefits the Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The French Intifada’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Mitchell Cohen reviews Andrew Hussey’s “The French Intifada: The Long War Between France and Its Arabs.” Mr. Cohen writes:

headline: What to Look for in the ‘Penny Dreadful’ Finale on Sunday
text: With just one episode left, the witching hour may finally be upon us.

headline: Martin Indyk, U.S. Mideast Envoy, Steps Down
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Friday that Martin S. Indyk, who led the yearlong American effort to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, was resigning from his position as special envoy.

headline: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Acquiesces to Special Shareholder Meeting
text: Allergan, the maker of Botox, and Pershing Square Capital Management have struck an agreement that will allow for the calling of a special meeting of Allergan shareholders, the latest development in the slow-moving $53 billion takeover effort by Pershing Square and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

headline: ‘Smart Beta’ Investing Lets the Yardstick Pick the Stocks
text: WHEN it comes to investing money, most people want to be smart about it. So an increasingly popular strategy with smart in its name has intrigued certain investors, while turning off others who see it as little more than a marketing gimmick.

headline: My-House-Is-Your-House Rules
text: Painted seashells, a lurid conch, a Pierrot-themed weather vane, a giant starfish waving an American flag, two raffia chickens with googley eyes, an ambitious amount of tern art: If you had to categorize the contents of the beach house I rented that summer under one artistic school, you’d probably go with Alcoholic Gift Shop.

headline: The Times Critics’ Guide to the ‘Transformers’ Movies
text: With “Transformers: Age of Extinction” opening Friday, viewers may be wondering what critics for The New York Times had to say about the previous installments in this enduring saga of flying robot battles. Wonder no more. If you want the current review, it is here.

headline: Yes, if You Cut Taxes, You Get Less Tax Revenue
text: Kansas has a problem. In April and May, the state planned to collect $651 million from personal income tax. But instead, it received only $369 million.

headline: Cameron’s Protests Rebuffed as European Commission Leader Is Chosen
text: BRUSSELS — Despite bitter opposition from Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, European Union leaders voted on Friday to name Jean-Claude Juncker as the next president of the bloc’s powerful bureaucracy, bringing an end to a struggle that had pitted some of the group’s top leaders against each other.

headline: Argentina’s Bond Payment Is Rebuffed by U.S. Judge
text: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday delivered a stern warning to Argentina after the country deposited $539 million with the Bank of New York Mellon for the purpose of paying its main class of bondholders.

headline: The Times’s Coverage Related to Patrick Lavin
text: From the 19th century.

headline: Historical Documents Related to Patrick Lavin
text: Testimony from the manslaughter indictment of Patrick Lavin and the coroner’s report on the killing of Casper Pfost, as well as Patrick Lavin’s retirement certificate.

headline: A Copper, a Dust-Up and Death
text: I found it after reading through the indictment, consulting archival maps and applying the measurements where the original tenements once stood, in Chelsea. Now, on an innocuous patch of crab grass between the corner of a red brick building and a concrete walkway winding through the Chelsea-Elliott housing complex, I was standing on the spot where, 125 years ago, my great-great-grandfather killed a man.

headline: 2 Carmakers to Share a Plant in Mexico
text: FRANKFURT — Daimler and Renault-Nissan significantly expanded their automaking alliance on Friday, saying they would jointly build a production plant in Mexico to build a new generation of compact Mercedes and Infiniti cars.

headline: Looking to Cars, Trucks Step Up Safety
text: Large trucks may be involved in fewer crashes than passenger vehicles, but their size almost guarantees that the consequences of those collisions will be severe.

headline: Letter to Obama Administration About Guantanamo Uruguay Deal
text: Lawyers for six Guantanamo detainees who were offered resettlement by Uruguay earlier this year sent this letter to top Obama administration officials on June 26. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has not acted on the deal.

headline: Seeking Divine Intervention, or at Least Some Lucky Shorts
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — There is a saying in this coastal city of mixed religious heritages and creeds that goes more or less like this: If superstition decided soccer matches, all matches would end in a tie.

headline: Inventive Cocktails That Pack a Low-Proof Punch
text: For all the many virtues of a potent Manhattan, Martini or Sazerac, the all-spirit cocktail doesn’t lend itself well to, say, postwork happy hours or, for that matter, pleasant mornings-after. Happily for the congenitally thirsty, a new wave of complex and inventive low-proof cocktails is popping up, and they’re a far cry from that less-potent fallback drink, the white-wine spritzer. Coming on the heels of the relentless rise of the Aperol Spritz, these new, lighter drinks appeal as much to those with an aversion to strong liquors as they do to the heartiest of drinkers after one dirty martini too many. And as Dinah Sanders, author of “The Art of the Shim: Low-Alcohol Cocktails to Keep you Level,” says, “The more subtle ingredients these drinks often feature don’t overwhelm the palate, so they are generally more food-friendly.” Thanks to exotic sakes, a variety of vermouths, a growing range of bitters, flavorful teas, infused syrups, fresh herbs and wines of all colors and ranges of effervescence, the sky’s the limit in creating easier-to-drink concoctions, as evidenced in the following five recipes.

headline: Head of Dollar General to Retire
text: Richard W. Dreiling, the chairman and chief executive of the discount retailer Dollar General, said on Friday that he was retiring. The move is effective May 30, 2015, or until the company names a successor.

headline: Eastern Garter Snake: The Well-Tempered Slitherer
text: It is not entirely surprising that children who find an eastern garter snake (Thamnophis sirtalis) excitedly tell their friends they found a “garden snake.” This innocuous New York City resident is as happy slithering through neighborhood parks or backyards as through wilder terrain.

headline: Voter-Fraud Claims and Activist’s Suicide Add to Turmoil in Mississippi
text: WASHINGTON — The long and bitter Republican primary fight between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party challenger descended into accusations of voter fraud on Friday, with the defeated candidate, State Senator Chris McDaniel, making clear he would not accept the results anytime soon.

headline: What to Do When Twitter Locks You Out
text: Opening a Locked Twitter Account

headline: Technology as a Path to Product Transparency
text: After I posted yesterday on Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack’s push for using scannable codes to provide consumers with information on food ingredients from genetically modified crops, Ben Grossman-Cohen of the anti-poverty group Oxfam International sent a reaction that merits publication as a “Your Dot” contribution.

headline: An International Art Festival in the Azores
text: Sao Miguel, one of the nine Azorean islands that huddle in the Atlantic, has long attracted visitors with its pastoral setting dotted with cows, waterfalls and volcanoes. But Ponta Delgada, the capital, is transforming into a center for the avant-garde with Walk & Talk, an annual international public art festival.

headline: TUI of Germany Reaches Agreement to Acquire British TUI Travel
text: LONDON — The German hotel and cruise ship operator TUI said on Friday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the British travel and leisure company TUI Travel, in which it is already a majority shareholder.

headline: Taking a Spin: An Odd Turn for Republicans
text: This week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of the uncertainty remaining before the election, offers head-scratching results.

headline: Lawmaker in Manhattan Pleads Guilty to 2 Felonies
text: A New York assemblywoman in her first term became the latest state lawmaker to be forced out of office as she pleaded guilty on Friday to two felonies in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Barclays Investors Express Investment Bank Fears
text: The market’s reaction to allegations that Barclays duped clients in its dark pool reflects more general fears of investment banking. Shares in the bank dropped as much as 9 percent on Thursday after the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, accused Barclays of misleading investors by playing down the number of “predatory” high-frequency traders on its private trading platform for equities. Barclays says it takes the allegations “very seriously.”

headline: Our Economic Growth Is a Mystery. Obamacare Is the Reason.
text: Imagine you decide to replace the engine of a car. You have two goals: To make the car go faster, you put in a more powerful engine, say eight cylinders rather than six. But you also want to make it more fuel efficient, so you add some sophisticated new technologies to cut back on its gas guzzling.

headline: San Francisco Noir
text: San Francisco is well known for its transformations, the most recent one fueled by tech money that has seemingly scrubbed much of the city clean. Evidence of it tends to be easy to mock: the $4 artisanal toast, the shuttle buses carrying workers from the city interior to Silicon Valley, the preponderance of reclaimed wood. But for almost a century, the city has been indelibly linked with an enigmatic genre that might be considered an antidote to all of that: noir.

headline: New Father? New C.E.O.? There’s a Boot Camp for You
text: IN the face of the yelling, B. J. Perlmutt hesitated, then took the plunge. After all, this was boot camp, and wasn’t the point to break you down and make you a man? He was sweating a little but competently finished the task.

headline: Five Stories of Luxury
text: A classic brick Greek Revival townhouse at 10 West 10th Street, one of the more idyllic of the tree-lined residential blocks in Greenwich Village, is poised to enter the market at $24.75 million.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Comme des Garçons Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Obama Chides G.O.P. for Blocking Economic Measures
text: MINNEAPOLIS — President Obama rebuked congressional Republicans on Friday for opposing his economic initiatives, saying they should be held accountable for not doing enough for the middle class.

headline: Retirement Plans Thrown Into Disarray by a Divorce
text: AFTER enduring a divorce four years ago, Mike Miller’s vision for a golden retirement got an unexpected makeover. Mr. Miller had been married for more than 30 years, and now he was single. His longtime dream of a shared retirement was shattered. He was also facing another unwelcome outcome: living in a smaller home and taking fewer vacations.

headline: Transition Ahead for ‘The View,’ as Two Hosts Depart
text: The latest cast changes at ABC’s daily talk show “The View” may signal a more sweeping transition, as two hosts will depart by the end of the summer, and the new participants may include the show’s first permanent male host.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: Alice in Wonderland syndrome, a type of hospital unknown to most of the world and a study on the “cool” kids. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Arraigned on Disorderly Conduct Charge
text: The actor Shia LaBeouf was arraigned on Friday morning on charges of disorderly conduct and criminal trespass after an incident the previous evening at Studio 54, where he was removed after disrupting a performance of the musical “Cabaret.”

headline: Amid the Rap Music, Echoes of an Orchestra Playing in a Dark Past
text: BERLIN — AT various points during shows, the German rapper Kutlu Yurtseven gestures to a bandmate sitting demurely off to the side. That’s the cue for 89-year-old Esther Bejarano, a diminutive woman with a snow-white pixie cut, to jump in with a song. “When will the heavens open up, again, for me?” is one favorite, the refrain of a local carnival tune. “When will they open up?”

headline: John Boehner Deflects Attention by Suing the President
text: President Obama was generous on Thursday in referring to Speaker John Boehner’s proposed lawsuit against him as a “stunt,” a word generally used to mean a playful attempt to get attention. In fact, the suit is a mean-spirited attempt to deflect attention — specifically from the House’s refusal to engage in the act of governing.

headline: Big Ticket | A Grand Gothic Duplex for $16.5 Million
text: A 12-room duplex on upper Fifth Avenue, with a Gothic decorating theme but no Central Park views from its grand primary rooms, sold for $16.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The monthly maintenance is $11,048.

headline: AT&T Names Silver Lake Co-Founder to Its Board
text: To fill an empty seat on its board, AT&T has turned to one of the country’s top investors in technology.

headline: Venus Williams Flashes Old Form at Wimbledon, but It Is Fleeting
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It has been six years since Venus Williams last won a Grand Slam singles championship, a title that came here at Wimbledon.

headline: Broth Spoils the Cooks
text: It’s got hot caldrons, sour plum juice and sliced lotus roots and it seats up to 200 people. Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot, which opened in Edison last month, might be a novelty in New Jersey, but some consider it the Applebee’s of China.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Depression Economics and Climate Policy
text: There’s been a bit of back and forth over “reform conservatism” — which is, depending on your point of view, either an important new trend or an attempt by reasonably sane conservatives to pretend that they aren’t part of an essentially insane movement. And climate change, where the current GOP orthodoxy essentially revolves around a crazy conspiracy theory, is the flash point.

headline: A Beverage for Brazil and the World Cup
text: Capturing the mood of the tournament with a drink that has Brazil’s national liquor as its base.

headline: Kanye: the Professor, Prada’s Revolutionary Runway and Fendi’s Latest Leather Accessory
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Book Review’s ‘Killer’ Cover
text: There was no question that this week’s cover was going to be Harlan Coben on “The Silkworm” by Robert Galbraith (a.k.a. J.K. Rowling). This is Coben’s first review for us, and we’ve had our eye on him as a reviewer for years. And of course, like most media outlets, we missed the first Robert Galbraith novel, before J.K. Rowling was unmasked as the true author. We weren’t going to lose that opportunity again.When the review came in, it more than lived up to our expectations. Here was one of the masters of literary genre fiction writing on someone who is relatively new to the genre, though of course a gigantic success elsewhere in the book world. It was a strong and logical, yet also slightly unexpected match between book and reviewer.

headline: Two Stars With Intertwining Peaks
text: Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, two principal dancers with the New York City Ballet, were married at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd in Chelsea on June 22.

headline: Soros Dabbles in Shareholder Activism
text: Is George Soros turning activist? His $29 billion hedge fund has famously confronted governments. But facing off with a $1 billion United States oil and gas company is novel. The move gives underperforming corporate bosses another scourge to fear.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: New Dylan Thomas Drinking Song Discovered
text: Just in time to comfort British World Cup fans still crying into their beer, a new drinking song by Dylan Thomas is to be published.

headline: Afghan Candidate and Thousands of Supporters Continue Protests
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Thousands of supporters of the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah poured into the streets of Kabul on Friday, blocking roads and clogging squares as they demanded that allegations of election fraud be addressed before ending the political crisis that has stratified Afghanistan for the last two weeks.

headline: More on How We Chose the Hardest Places to Live
text: Our interactive map yesterday on the hardest places to live in the United States provoked, not surprisingly, some lively discussion in the comments section. Several of those comments raised thoughts that were worth addressing.

headline: Vatican Defrocks Ambassador in Abuse Inquiry
text: The Vatican has defrocked its former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, an archbishop from Poland who was accused of sexually abusing boys while he served as the pope’s representative in the Caribbean nation.

headline: Eric Clapton Says He May Stop Touring
text: First Philip Roth quits writing books and giving readings. Now Eric Clapton quits touring?

headline: The Trauma of Parenthood
text: EVERYONE knows that being the parent of an infant is hard. There’s the sleeplessness, the screaming fits to tend to, the loss of autonomy, the social isolation and the sheer monotony of it.

headline: Death by Netflix?
text: Binge-watching has now joined a pantheon already occupied by fast food, alcohol, and sitting on couches: It is extremely popular, and in large amounts, it appears to be deadly.

headline: A Crush of Summer Flavors
text: There are many kinds of frozen concoctions to help you navigate the summer heat.

headline: The Hardest Place to Live in America
text: What does concentrated rural misery look like? Like eastern Kentucky.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: And Sometimes They Dance
text: This is a boy-meets-girl-at-a-barre love story.

headline: Persecution Captured on Film
text: As readers of the blog may know, I’m the journalism student from the University of Notre Dame that accompanied Nicholas Kristof on his annual win-a-trip journey in Burma. While reporting on the ground, I captured a number of my experiences and interviews with members of the Rohingya Muslim minority on film. As always, reader comments and questions are welcome!

headline: Ford Introduces Side-Curtain Air Bags for 15-Passenger Vans
text: Ford announced Wednesday that it had developed its largest air bag for the 15-passenger Transit van.

headline: Pro-Abdullah Rallies Held in Kabul
text: Thousands of protesters in Kabul showed support for presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah’s allegations that mass fraud had been committed in Afghanistan’s presidential runoff.

headline: A Casual Stage Where Steak Is the Star
text: Union Republic houses an expertly outfitted butcher shop, so it is not surprising that its porterhouse and rib-eye steaks, marbled but not gristly and sautéed so quickly that the caramelized exteriors spurt when punctured, are first-rate. Not to be outdone, its mushroom-studded risotto, taco with cubes of silky beef cheeks and even its vegan bowl of cauliflower, leeks and ramen noodles are also exemplary. They are reason enough to head to this latest outpost of innovative cooking in downtown Jersey City.

headline: Investors Who Bought Foreclosed Homes in Bulk Look to Sell
text: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems. But with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

headline: Weekend Reading: Advancing on Bank Penalties
text: Following DealBook’s report that BNP Paribas is expected to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion fine, Wall Street’s attention will soon turn to two civil investigations into the mortgage crisis.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Playing to the Camera
text: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Coach Boldly Moves U.S. Forward
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In late March, just before Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, went into the meeting in which he demoted Martin Vasquez, his longtime assistant, he asked a staff member with U.S. Soccer to knock on the door and interrupt after about five minutes.

headline: The U.S.-Germany Match Through a Social Media Lens
text: The United States-Germany soccer match on Thursday was a roller coaster of emotions. And an analysis of the social media communications before, during and after the match shows the minute-by-minute shifts in sentiment and in subjects discussed, as the American team lost to Germany but moved on in the World Cup competition.

headline: How Records in Group Play Predict World Cup Success
text: Teams’ performance in the World Cup’s group stage often says a lot about how they’ll fare in the knockout rounds. Since 1986, when a version of the current format began, no team has won the championship without winning at least two of three group matches. And six of the seven champions in that time did not lose any group-stage matches — going either 3-0-0 or finishing with two wins and a draw in the group stage.

headline: Hip-Hop From a Holocaust Survivor
text: Esther Bejarano, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp, may be the last thing you’d expect in a hip-hop singer. She uses her music to spread a message against fascism.

headline: AT&T Sells Its Stake in Mexican Telecom América Móvil to Carlos Slim
text: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | AT&T said on Friday that it was selling its $5.6 billion stake in América Móvil, the Mexican telecommunications company, back to its majority shareholder, the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú. The sale comes as AT&T seeks to acquire the satellite television operator DirecTV in a $48.5 billion deal.

headline: Berluti: Spring 2015 Menswear
text: PARIS

headline: Michael Arrington Drops Suit After Rape Accuser Recants
text: Last spring, Jennifer Allen began sharing a harrowing tale of abuse she said she had received at the hands of a former boyfriend — Michael Arrington, the tech investor and blogger.

headline: Follow That Cab! Vintage Checkers Flock to Brooklyn
text: For a few hours, Box Street, a semi-industrial thoroughfare in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, seemed a whole lot like Kzoo.

headline: Revisiting a Checkered Past
text: The Checker cab, a New York City icon, was back on the streets of Brooklyn for a gathering of the Checker Car Club of America.

headline: Confinement as a Kind of Freedom
text: The first voice you hear in “Me and You,” Bernardo Bertolucci’s first film in nearly a decade, is that of an unseen psychiatrist asking his patient, “Allora?” (“So?”) Then the point of view shifts and you see the doctor sitting in a wheelchair, rolling himself closer to his desk and his patient, a troubled 14-year-old boy who looks at the floor and answers, “Nothing.”

headline: A Ride Across America | In Kansas, A Man Cave Becomes a Thriving Family Farm
text: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

headline: Making Everything Shipshape
text: TACOMA, Wash. — As construction crews 5,000 miles away are working to widen the Panama Canal to allow much larger ships to sail straight to the East Coast, this historic port city and others along the West Coast are doing everything they can to avoid becoming superfluous.

headline: With Alstom Deal, G.E. Gains Bigger Foothold as Utility Supplier
text: BELFORT, France – The Alstom and General Electric turbine factories in this French city near the Swiss and German borders sit just a stone’s throw apart. They are so close, in fact, that their employees share a cafeteria, and two-company families are not uncommon.

headline: Fighting for Movies With Pen and Thumb
text: “Life Itself,” the new documentary about Roger Ebert, examines many facets of the nation’s most famous film critic: his newsman background, his exhaustively chronicled battle with cancer that ended in his death last year, his drinking, his wit, his love for his wife, Chaz.

headline: This Time, the Cake Is Fully Baked
text: When Hyundai dipped a toe in the luxury-car waters in 2009, it followed an underdog formula set by Toyota’s Lexus division two decades earlier: Mimic the established brands’ design, undercut them on price and overdeliver on features.

headline: “Is This Cold War II?”
text: On Wednesday June 25, the New York Times and Chatham House convened a panel of former New York Times op-ed contributors in London to debate the future of the West’s relations with Russia in the wake of the Ukraine crisis. The panel included John Mearsheimer, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago and the author of “The Tragedy of Great Power Politics”; Chrystia Freeland, a former Financial Times editor and now a member of the Canadian Parliament; Michael McFaul, the former American ambassador to Russia and now a professor at Stanford University; and Dmitri Trenin, the director of the Carnegie Moscow Center. Roger Cohen, a columnist for The New York Times, moderated. Panelists debated whether the recent crisis was caused by Vladimir Putin’s zero-sum view of geopolitics, whether the Ukrainian people will have a say in the eventual outcome and whether Russia is really a rival to the United States. An edited transcript follows.

headline: 2015 Hyundai Genesis: Upgrading the Upgrade
text: An upward striver fulfills its potential with a splash of style and a new dash of spice.

headline: Fewer Breaks, but Belinda Bencic Makes the Most of Them
text: WIMBLEDON, England — All points in tennis are not worth the same. Some are critical to the final outcome. Others are simply building blocks to reach it.

headline: Digital Success Comes to Radio Broadcaster
text: For years, radio stations have watched as online upstarts like Pandora and Spotify attracted a new generation of listeners. Now, one conventional broadcast network, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment, seems to be gaining a significant audience with its own streaming app.

headline: A Designer Transformed
text: The “Transformers” film franchise has locked the Chevrolet Camaro deep in the subconscious of millions of children who know it as Bumblebee, a robot that disguises itself as a sporty coupe.

headline: Transformers and the Summer Blockbuster
text: The numbers behind “Transformers: Age of Extinction”- expected to gross one billion dollars - and other summer blockbusters this year.

headline: Detroit’s Troubles: A Mosaic Says What Words Can’t
text: Today, an ambitious interactive graphic accompanied a front-page article by Monica Davey about the high rate of home foreclosures in Detroit. The graphic was presented as a mosaic of the more than 43,000 properties that were subject to foreclosure this year. Haeyoun Park, a graphics editor for the national desk, and Matthew Bloch, a graphics and multimedia editor, worked on the project and shared some details about how it came to be.

headline: Love With the Proper Dose of Disdain
text: “Vicious” is not the most informative title. It sounds like a nasty little thriller on FX or Cinemax. As it turns out, it’s a British sitcom on PBS, but it’s nasty, all right. Where else on television are you going to see two superb classically trained actors calling each other a rotting corpse or a big bitch?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.

headline: Hot Streets for Chilly Lawyers
text: “Reckless,” a summer crime-lawyer-melodrama mishmash that begins on Sunday on CBS, is determined to be vacuous, even though, every so often, it hints that it could be more substantive if it wanted to be. That makes it maddening; you’d like to commit to it, but you know that more clichés and indifferent acting are right around the corner.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 27
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes a look at a Congressional primary race and a Central Park luncheon.

headline: 3 Freed in Central Park Jogger Case Thank Supporters
text: Three of the five men whose convictions were overturned in the 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park appeared in front of City Hall on Friday, thanking their supporters and praising Mayor Bill de Blasio for agreeing to settle their longstanding lawsuit against the city.

headline: Pliés With an Elephant, And Other Tales for Men
text: It can’t be easy for a company called 10 Hairy Legs to live up to the playful audacity of its name. Randy James formed his New Jersey repertory troupe in 2012, intending to explore a range of male dancing. (Hence the hair.) That name turned out to be the most offbeat thing about the group, which performed five dances on Thursday, at the start of its run at New York Live Arts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
text: Saudi Arabia and More – Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Sudan, India and China.

headline: Before Night Falls
text: Death typically appears in photographs as an intruder: an unbidden force that sweeps down on a battlefield or leaves survivors pained and bereft. We see the images and know that just hours or moments earlier, the subjects’ lives were intact, the world complete and in order. In Arthur Nazaryan’s photographs of a hospice nurse and her patients, death plays a different role, shaping the scene by its absence, not its presence. It is the reason the characters are assembled, the order toward which the chaos of life is resolving itself; not just their lives, but ours as well.

headline: Building a Full Meal, Bite by Bite by Bite
text: They say there is nothing new under the sun, but the Bartaco concept may be an exception. Bartaco in Westport, an indoor-outdoor locale, offers a limited menu, more snacklike than full service, in a noisy, lively atmosphere, with seating for 110 inside, and for 25 more outside, facing the Saugatuck River.

headline: Tiger Pulls Man From Boat in India
text: NEW DELHI — A man poaching crabs in an eastern Indian tiger reserve was killed by a tiger that leapt into the man’s boat and dragged him into a mangrove swamp in front of his son and daughter.

headline: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Lana Del Rey and her new record, “Ultraviolence.”

headline: Under Cover: The Wonder of an Egg
text: When Jake Silverstein, the magazine’s editor, read the final paragraphs of Kim Tingley’s cover story about three-parent I.V.F., in which she describes a researcher removing nuclear DNA from a human egg, he was struck by an idea for the cover.

headline: Popcast: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
text: The singer Lana Del Rey of Los Angeles, nee Lizzie Grant of Lake Placid, N.Y., elicited some opprobrium in 2011 and 2012, through songs and videos and a first album (“Born to Die”) and a “Saturday Night Live” performance that all seemed, to some, thin or calculated or grandiose or overposed.

headline: Bringing the British Countryside to Life
text: As Elisabeth Fairman, of the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, puts it, the exhibition “Of Green Leaf, Bird and Flower’: Artists’ Books and the Natural World” is something of “a walk through the countryside.”

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
text: Highlights from the men’s collections in Paris.

headline: Time Doesn’t Dim Its Sparkle
text: Time is easily quantifiable yet unknowable, at least as it affects wine. We know wine ages in the bottle, but how will it evolve, and why? We can estimate based on experience, but we are never really sure.

headline: Nepal’s Premier Is Being Treated for Lung Cancer
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Sushil Koirala of Nepal is undergoing radiation therapy in New York to treat a cancerous tumor found on his lung, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.

headline: Christian Sudanese Woman and Her Family in Protection of U.S. Embassy
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — A Christian Sudanese woman who was detained at the airport in Khartoum with her family by Sudanese authorities after an appeals court overturned her conviction and death sentence for abandoning Islam and ordered her set free is now in the protection of the United States Embassy here, her lawyer said on Friday.

headline: A Bridge Deal From Judy Kay-Wolff
text: A few women have been married to more than one member of the bridge Hall of Fame. Judy Kay-Wolff, for example, who celebrated her 80th birthday this month.

headline: The Bride Didn’t Always Wear White
text: LONDON — Queen Victoria wasn’t much of what you would call a fashion plate, especially in her later years. As a widow, she would rarely venture out into public, and when she did, she would be swathed in funereal black, perpetually in mourning for her husband.

headline: 25th Reunion Takes a Turn for the Explosive
text: At most 25th high school reunions, the drama does not rise above the discovery that the prom queen got fat, or the mousy kid who disappeared into the scenery founded an Internet company valued at a few billion dollars. There’s much more in store for the friends reassembling to recall semi-halcyon days in “The Muscles in Our Toes,” a fairly preposterous play by Stephen Belber (“Tape,” “Match”) making its New York premiere in a Labyrinth Theater Company production directed by Anne Kauffman.

headline: The United States of Los Tigres
text: MINNEAPOLIS — About four hours before a Friday night show late last month, the five members of Los Tigres del Norte, the premier band in the accordion-driven musical genre known as norteño, were quietly eating dinner at the restaurant of their hotel here. None of the other diners seemed to have any notion of who they were, and neither did the staff — until a Spanish-speaking waiter spotted them and shyly approached their table.

headline: Riot Music and Puppy-Love Songs
text: Rae Sremmurd

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: If the State Fair Were X-Rated (or at Least a Strong R)
text: Should this review begin with a warning that it deals with the conventionally unmentionable? Or that it refers to images here unprintable?

headline: How the National Anthem Has Unfurled
text: When the baritone Thomas Hampson sings “The Star-Spangled Banner” at the Library of Congress in Washington on Thursday, it won’t sound quite like the familiar tune belted out at ball games and presidential inaugurations.

headline: Prosecutors Ask at Least 8 Years for Martoma in Insider Trading Case
text: Federal prosecutors are recommending that Mathew Martoma, a former trader who worked for the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, be sentenced next month to at least eight years in prison for insider trading, if not significantly more.

headline: Ireland’s First Billionaire Ordered to Sell Assets to Repay Loans
text: DUBLIN — Anthony O’Reilly, Ireland’s first billionaire and the former chief executive and chairman of the H.J. Heinz Company, has been declared insolvent, and on Friday he was ordered to sell his assets immediately to repay loans to one bank exceeding $30 million.

headline: Prophet Goes to Church
text: In the stage version of “ ... Moses(es),” performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last December, the choreographer Reggie Wilson began by introducing himself to the assembled crowd. His dancers followed suit, adding how long they’d spent as members of his Fist & Heel Performance Group. Mr. Wilson then stuffed armloads of silver tinsel into a suitcase. He packs a lot into his dances.

headline: Disparate but Connected
text: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has long been occupied with what he has called the “objectness” of a photograph, its role as a thing in the world and not just as “a conduit of information,” and this has often led to explorations of the relationship between painting and photography in the digital age. A tightly focused exhibition opening Tuesday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art takes Mr. Tillmans’s fascinations and runs with them.

headline: Marathon Tribute to Philip Guston
text: Art can start relationships, and end them. The composer Morton Feldman and the painter Philip Guston had been close for years when Feldman attended an opening of Guston’s in 1970. The work on display was figurative, an abrupt turn from the abstraction Guston had been known for. Feldman was stunned silent. Telling the story much later, he said that the episode ended their decades-long friendship. The two men never saw each other again.

headline: Toasting 30 Years of Raw Exuberance
text: The name Urban Bush Women suggests a fierce and perhaps frightening tribe — something to avoid, if it didn’t also sound like something you really wanted to join.

headline: At 50, a Debut Keeps 4 Guys Young
text: Those pivotal appearances on “The Ed Sullivan Show” weren’t the only Beatles milestones 50 years ago. This year is also the 50th anniversary of the release of “A Hard Day’s Night,” the first of the band’s five feature films and, in many minds, the best.

headline: Same Beck, Different Mood
text: “I’m so tired of being alone,” cries Beck at the top of “Blue Moon,” the lead single from his muted and deliberative current album, “Morning Phase” (Capitol). “I-so-lation,” he sings a couple of tracks later, in the existential refrain of “Wave.” The purity of the sentiment, and the completeness of his commitment, could easily give you an impression about his state of mind: desolate, draggy, half-numb, forlorn. The last time Beck made an album that felt like this — “Sea Change,” a dozen years ago — that impression might have been partly true.

headline: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
text: AN insidious trend has developed over this past third of a century. A country that experienced shared growth after World War II began to tear apart, so much so that when the Great Recession hit in late 2007, one could no longer ignore the fissures that had come to define the American economic landscape. How did this “shining city on a hill” become the advanced country with the greatest level of inequality?

headline: Eking Out a Living to Chase a Dream
text: The boldface names in “The Mysteries” belong to the characters: God, Jesus, Lucifer, the rest of the biblical crowd. The actors playing them off Off Broadway, at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa, are not famous — but they’re young, hopeful and ravenous enough about performing to do it free.

headline: Damned People Got No Reason to Live
text: When Randy Newman released “Faust” as a star-studded concept album in 1995, Rolling Stone magazine wrote that it “breathes new life into a musical-theater tradition hijacked by the likes of Andrew Lloyd Webber.” The very next year, this wry song cycle about a contemporary deal with the Devil hit the stage in a flashy production directed by Michael Greif. Yet after receiving mixed notices in Los Angeles and Chicago, Mr. Newman’s “Faust” receded into the limbo of might-have-been theater successes that got derailed on the road to Broadway.

headline: Following 9 Trips From ‘I Do’ to ‘I Did’
text: Twenty years ago Doug Block began shooting wedding videos to support his true passion, documentary filmmaking. Sure, the money was good. But he soon discovered a far more intriguing aspect. “I could stand just feet away,” he says, “as two ordinary people experience one of the most extraordinary days of their lives.” But after the vows had been uttered and the videos sent on their way, he couldn’t help but wonder what happened next.

headline: Intensity, Instantly, and Hints of Coltrane
text: With improvised music, you get used to seeing a band warm up by degrees. It comes with the aesthetic form, and also with the business model, if it’s a band performing sporadic multiple-night stands. Jazz is full of groups reconvening, recohering, then pacing themselves across a few nights and days. The quintet led by the saxophonist Azar Lawrence, from Los Angeles, is of that form and that model. For the last three years or so, it’s been playing gigs in clubs — often on the East Coast, where all its other members are based — and then everyone scatters and does different things.

headline: The Hoodie as a Tease, and Other Statements From a Sampler of Mixed Moves
text: BECKET, Mass. — “Unreal Hip-Hop,” a showcase organized by the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, seems designed to defy expectations. The performance on Thursday opened with a figure in a hoodie, hunched over and facing away in dim light. That’s an image closely associated, like hip-hop, with black males. This figure, though, turned out to be a white B-girl.

headline: Hewitt Grinds Back From Two Sets Down, but His Upset Bid Fails
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It is often said that professional tennis does not have competitive contrast. Those objecting to that state of affairs should have appreciated Lleyton Hewitt’s attempt Friday afternoon to cut the goliath known as Jerzy Janowicz down to size, inch by tormented inch.

headline: Speak Your Own Truth, on Your Own Terms
text: Billie Jean King loves to connect.  The 70-year-old tennis legend — winner of 39 Grand Slam titles, the Presidential Medal of Freedom and, most famously, the “Battle of the Sexes” match against Bobby Riggs in 1973 — peppers questions like forehand volleys.  Within three minutes of walking into Boulud Sud, near Lincoln Center, Ms. King had learned that the restaurant manager’s mother rowed crew for Syracuse University; asked her interviewer’s partner’s name (and tossed it off casually through the afternoon); and compared notes on the French Open with the waiter.

headline: At Festival, Footfalls of Farewell
text: BECKET, Mass. — The Doubtful Guest, the title character of a 1957 illustrated book by Edward Gorey, is a peculiar creature, with a flat head, a knitted scarf and wings that suggest a penguin’s flippers. It shows up at an Edwardian manor house and stays for 17 years (by the book’s end) with no indication that it might ever leave.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Jeff Koons’ Big Bloom
text: The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Surgical Complications
text: Eight of 16 of the military’s largest hospitals had high rates of surgical complications, such as infections or improperly done procedures, according to a review from the American College of Surgeons.

headline: American Realism by Way of Woodstock
text: Fortunes in the art world — and particularly those defined by the market — change quickly. Take Eugene Speicher (1883-1962), a painter whom Esquire magazine called America’s most important living painter in 1936, but whose name few people know today (and even fewer can pronounce: “Spiker”). “Along His Own Lines: A Retrospective of New York Realist Eugene Speicher,” organized by Valerie Ann Leeds at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art in New Paltz, N.Y., seeks to redress this, examining Mr. Speicher’s career in the context of American realism, but also as an artist who spent months each year in nearby Woodstock.

headline: Scenes from San Francisco
text: In search for noir, with Dashiell Hammett as guide.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Big Bloom
text: BIG BLOOM The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art that occupies the entire museum, including the front moat. On the top floor is Mr. Koons’s latest work, “Play-Doh,” a monumental pile of color. The owners of the work are Maria and Bill Bell. Many of the women’s dresses at the opening Tuesday echoed the colors of the sculpture and recalled the colors of the Fauve painters of early-20th-century Paris and the smaller “Split-Rocker,” left. It contrasts with the colossal “Split-Rocker,” below, covered in over 50,000 dwarf marigolds, zinnias, petunias, wax begonias, impatiens and geraniums, installed above the statue of Prometheus in Rockefeller Center. The sculpture, which exploded to 37 feet tall, was unveiled at a luncheon.

headline: Bulletins From the Gut, From a Quartet at Work in the Park
text: Musical patterns are neat, stable, definite, predictable. Feelings and relationships — well, they aren’t. But they can all be hypnotic, compelling, even obsessive. Warpaint, the four-woman Los Angeles band that headlined Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday night, places its songs at that complicated intersection: where a grid of repetition meets the amorphous crosscurrents of emotion and desire.

headline: Evening Hours | Including the Stars
text: Music, art and dancing to start the summer.

headline: Same-Sex Marriages, 10 Years Later
text: So, what happens to a marriage over the course of 10 years? Make that a gay marriage.

headline: Exploring the Continuity of the Radical
text: Since April, the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum has been commemorating its 50th anniversary with a yearlong series of changing exhibitions. Its galleries are filled with artworks that honor its legacy while highlighting the impact of that legacy on artists practicing today.

headline: Rulings on Abortion and Appointment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Howard Baker, Who Put the Nation Ahead of Himself
Helping a Child With Homework: Two Views
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wheelies: The Electrified Audi Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Something for Tout le Monde
text: Next month, Vox will celebrate its 10th anniversary. This charming restaurant and bar has been a beacon to those navigating the sharp curves of Route 116 in the woodsy isolation of North Salem.

headline: Checkpoint Showdown
text: As the immigration debate focuses on border security, some say that American freedoms are being compromised by interior Border Patrol checkpoints, like the one north of Arivaca, Ariz.

headline: Watching the Workers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good Marital Advice
text: To the Editor:

headline: All the World’s His Stage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ergen Sidelined in Battle With Falcone Over LightSquared
text: The bitter battle between the billionaires Charles W. Ergen and Philip A. Falcone over LightSquared, the bankrupt wireless broadband company, appears to be nearing an end. The twist is that Mr. Ergen is no longer involved.

headline: She Did It Her Way
text: Staten Island has been called the forgotten borough and was home to a nearly forgotten, boundary-pushing photographer named Alice Austen. At the ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, open since 1985 in the working-class neighborhood of Rosebank, some details of her life are still blurred.

headline: Presbyterians Remove Guide After Criticism
text: After months of outrage over a publication that critics say denigrates Israel, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) announced Friday that it was no longer selling the study guide “Zionism Unsettled” on the church’s website.

headline: Shoulder Injury Sends Mets’ Wright Back to New York
text: PITTSBURGH — Mets third baseman David Wright stood outside the visitors’ clubhouse Friday afternoon and explained why he had been scratched from the lineup with a sore left shoulder.

headline: Seaside With Kindred Spirits of Cookery
text: Epic picnics on the beach and fancy dinners prepared in well-equipped and abundantly stocked East Hampton kitchens are among the delectable events evoked by photographs and artifacts in “Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey: Cookbook Revolutionaries in East Hampton.” The exhibition, at the East Hampton Historical Society’s Clinton Academy Museum, includes more than 70 images, an Al Hirschfeld caricature of both men, several hand-drawn menus and various cookware used by the duo, including a fish steamer, a duck press and a bouillabaisse pot.

headline: Afrezza, a New Inhaled Insulin, Is Approved by the F.D.A.
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a form of insulin that is inhaled rather than injected, providing a new option for millions of Americans with diabetes.

headline: Texas: Booking of Migrants to Take Place at 4 Sites
text: Adults with children caught crossing the border illegally in the Rio Grande Valley will be sent initially to Customs and Border Protection stations in Laredo and El Paso, and also to San Diego and El Centro in California, border officials said Friday. Families will be booked for deportation at those sites, and some will remain in detention. Facing a surge of Central American migrants in South Texas, border authorities have been releasing most families with children there. They will soon open a 700-bed detention center for families at a law enforcement training center in Artesia, N.M.

headline: Woods Misses Cut in His Return But Finds ‘a Lot of Positives’
text: BETHESDA, Md. — A major winner rebounded from an opening 74 to make the cut at the Quicken Loans National, but his name was not Tiger Woods. Justin Rose, the 2013 United States Open winner, pieced together a six-birdie, no-bogey round of six-under 65 on Friday at Congressional Country Club to vault from a tie for 83rd into a tie for 11th, three strokes off the lead shared by four players.

headline: Border Patrol Scrutiny Stirs Anger in Arizona Town
text: ARIVACA, Ariz. — Every time Jack Driscoll drives the 32 miles from this remote outpost in southeastern Arizona to the closest supermarket, or to doctor’s appointments, or to a pharmacy to fill his prescriptions, he must stop at a Border Patrol checkpoint and answer the same question: “Are you a U.S. citizen?”

headline: World Cup 2014: Brazil Defeats Chile on Penalty Kicks, 1-1
text: Brazil, the tournament favorite and host, narrowly escaped defeat after Chile’s Gonzalo Jara hit the post with his final penalty kick. Brazil advances to the quarterfinals.

headline: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Uruguay, 2-0
text: Colombia continued its impressive run after finishing its group 3-0 with a 2-0 victory, led by James Rodriguez and his two goals.

headline: If Franz Ferdinand Had Lived
text: FOR over 25 years, Archduke Franz Ferdinand paced up and down in his palaces and castles waiting impatiently for the death of the ever more ancient emperor, his hated uncle Franz Joseph I. As we all know, his wait was in vain.

headline: A Place to Pull Over
text: Have you ever dined in a garage? Joe’s Garage and Grill, a three-month-old restaurant in Riverhead, comes close to providing that experience. The floor is concrete and the rows of windows roll up like garage doors. The automotive theme continues on the menu, where appetizers are listed under Start Your Engines and sandwiches are referred to as The Pile Up.

headline: Friday Night Music: Attack of the Brooklyn Hipsters (Sylvan Esso)
text: OK, at one level this is almost a caricature of hipsterdom. But at the same time Sylvan Esso is really, really good …

headline: Tensions Continue to Simmer as Attacks in Gaza Escalate
text: JERUSALEM — Two Palestinian men suspected of being militants were killed in an Israeli missile strike in Gaza on Friday, according to the military and witnesses, and Israel’s minister of defense warned that he would not tolerate rocket fire from Gaza against Israel or any other attempt to harm Israeli civilians and soldiers.

headline: On Air Force One, No Lightening Up on Burgers and Cake
text: WASHINGTON — A blue-cheese burger with lettuce, tomato and garlic aioli, accompanied by Parmesan-sprinkled fries. Chocolate fudge cake. Pasta shells stuffed with four cheeses, topped with meat sauce and shredded mozzarella, and served with a garlic breadstick. Cake infused with limoncello. Buffalo wings with celery, carrots and homemade ranch dip.

headline: At Wimbledon, Ana Konjuh Spun Her Tale of Faith
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Ana Konjuh has a tattoo on her left wrist that reads, “Faith.” Faith in her prodigious ability, which has helped her become one of the most promising women in the game. Faith in the continuing twists and turns of fate that played an integral role in her move from her quiet hometown, Dubrovnik, Croatia, to Zagreb at 10, leading her to her mentor, the former French Open champion Iva Majoli.

headline: Hong Kong’s Democracy Supporters Chafe at Inequality and Beijing’s Sway
text: HONG KONG — On a recent morning, Agnes Chow, 17, and another teenage activist rode a van through the streets of Hong Kong, urging people through a loudspeaker to vote in an informal referendum for a more democratic way to pick the city’s top leader. But the vote, which has been condemned as illegal by the Chinese government, was about much more than the city’s leadership, she said.

headline: Key Piece in Limbo, Knicks’ President Forges Foundation
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson made clear that he was finished with the formal recruiting process, if it was even fair to describe it that way in the first place. There would be no genuflecting at the altar of Carmelo Anthony, no passionate overtures, no grand promises — other than a well-formulated plan to (eventually) turn the Knicks into a contender.

headline: Airlines’ Rivalry Amplifies Fight Over Bank Guarantees
text: The rise of Persian Gulf airlines has been a boon to Boeing as they snap up its large jets, sometimes with the help of loan guarantees from Washington.

headline: The Accidental Escapee, or the Eyewitness in the Back Seat
text: Bryan McMenamin was all over the news last week when, hands cuffed behind his back after being arrested in a drug bust, he jumped from the back of a police S.U.V. into the driver’s seat and, cuffed hands somehow in front, drove off.

headline: Three Homers by Yankees Compound the Red Sox’ Struggles
text: In the off-season, as the Boston Red Sox were basking in the glow of their World Series victory and the Yankees were retooling, and the teams’ front-office executives were again lobbing insults at each other, the rivalry seemed to have regained some of its acerbity.

headline: While Iraq Burns
text: In the face of a violent offensive by Sunni militants, Iraq’s future as a unified state is becoming less and less likely. As the Sunni militants take hold of a large swath of northwest Iraq, the Kurds, who operate a semiautonomous province in northeast Iraq, are edging toward independence, leaving Shiites controlling Baghdad and regions in the south. Yet Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki seems to have no interest in finding a new way forward from a catastrophe his policies ignited.

headline: The Second Chance Act Proves Its Worth
text: With corrections costs exceeding $60 billion a year, state and local governments are rightly focused on making sure that newly released prisoners stay out of jail instead of coming back in through a revolving door.

headline: New General Motors Recall Includes Best Sellers
text: Adding to the mounting toll of its safety crisis, General Motors said on Friday that it was recalling more than half a million more vehicles, including full-size pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles that can suddenly switch into neutral.

headline: Bobby Womack, Royalty of the Soul Era, Dies at 70
text: Bobby Womack, who spanned the American soul music era, touring as a gospel singer in the 1950s, playing guitar in Sam Cooke’s backup band in the early ’60s, writing hit songs recorded by Wilson Pickett and the Rolling Stones and composing music that broke onto the pop charts, died on June 27 at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 70.

headline: World Cup 2014: A Defiant Chile Seeks to Ruin a Tournament for Its Hosts
text: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — Groups of Chilean fans moved about the streets here on the eve of their team’s game against Brazil. Some were on foot, some rode in packed cars with the red, white and blue flag of Chile fluttering from windows, and many yelled their familiar chant, “Chi Chi Chi, Le Le Le,” while locals looked on, distinctly unamused.

headline: Reporter’s Case Poses Dilemma for Justice Dept.
text: On Dec. 31, 2005, the C.I.A.’s acting general counsel, John A. Rizzo, received an urgent phone call from the White House about a chapter in James Risen’s coming book, “State of War,” detailing a botched C.I.A. operation in Iran.

headline: 100 Years Ago Tonight
text: — George Dangerfield, The Strange Death of Liberal England

headline: Report Finds Health Unit of V.A. Needs Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — The Veterans Health Administration has a corrosive culture that has led to poor management, a history of retaliation toward employees, cumbersome and outdated technology, and a shortage of doctors, nurses and physical space to treat its patients, according to a review presented to President Obama on Friday by one of his top advisers on veterans’ issues.

headline: Taliban Mount Major Assault in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In one of the most significant coordinated assaults on the government in years, the Taliban have attacked police outposts and government facilities across several districts in northern Helmand Province, sending police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses and heralding a troubling new chapter as coalition forces prepare to depart.

headline: Upon Return to Uruguay, Luis Suárez Is Met With Support
text: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — Barred from soccer for the next four months for biting an opponent and obliged to leave his team in the midst of the World Cup, Luis Suárez arrived home in Uruguay before sunrise Friday and was met with cheers and a presidential hug on the tarmac.

headline: Like a Domino, Another Atlantic City Casino Falls
text: The Atlantic Club casino closed in January. Last week, Atlantic City’s newest casino, Revel, filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in two years.

headline: Here Comes the Judge, in Cuffs
text: MIAMI — Lawyers gawked from office windows last month when a BMW S.U.V. swiped a parked police cruiser in the parking lot of a courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, then slammed into a gate over and over again.

headline: An Orchestra of Little Hands and Big Dreams
text: Paul Kirby waved his baton at the group of musicians gathered in the cavernous United Palace Theater in Manhattan on a recent Saturday. Sweat cascaded down his brow as the string orchestra played in front of him.

headline: Syria: Dispute Unsettles Rebel Coalition
text: As President Obama asks Congress for $500 million to help Syria’s rebels, the dysfunction and infighting that have long undermined their fight against the Syrian government spilled into the open again on Friday. The leader of the interim government established by the exile opposition, the Syrian National Coalition, said in a statement that he was firing the head of the Supreme Military Council of the Free Syrian Army and referring its members to a commission to investigate accusations of corruption. The military council responded that the interim government had made a “grave legal error” and did not have any power over it — a position that was supported by the leader of the Syrian National Coalition, Ahmad Assi al-Jarba. Despite being endorsed by the West as the leaders of the struggle against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, none of the bodies involved in the dispute are currently playing a significant role in the civil war. The coalition is widely seen as ineffective, its interim government is little more than a list of names, and the military council has been overshadowed on the ground by rebel formations and extremist groups that have been more active.

headline: Rations Reduced as Demand Grows for Soup Kitchens
text: Old Cantonese women lined up behind a white van, clutching plastic bags to carry away their meals for the night. Behind them came young children clamoring for milk, homeless men in tattered shirts and Mexican immigrants who spoke only Spanish.

headline: For Women Who Saw Combat, a Place to Find Inner Peace
text: JAMESBURG, Calif. — As Melannie Lovercheck was packing last Saturday for her week away from home, she reached into a closet, knelt beneath her Navy lieutenant’s uniform on its hanger and grabbed a pair of black Crocs. The choice seemed logical enough. Where she was going, she would need some kind of waterproof footwear to get from her cabin to the shower room.

headline: Altidore May Return for U.S. in Match Against Belgium
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Forward Jozy Altidore, who left early in the United States’ opening match of the World Cup with a strained hamstring, should be available to face Belgium in the second round, Coach Jurgen Klinsmann said Friday.

headline: G.M.’s Rival Could Teach It a Lesson
text: “How do you change the culture?” the “Today” show’s Matt Lauer asked Mary Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, earlier this week. “How do you go about communicating to the people who have been part of the history of this company for years that things must change?”

headline: The Eggs and Us
text: Let’s talk personhood, people.

headline: A Milestone for Same-Sex Marriage
text: The battle to legalize same-sex marriage saw a historic victory this week when the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver became the first federal appeals court in the nation to declare that same-sex couples have a “fundamental right” to wed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 27, 2014
Growth and Breadth in U.S. Interest in World Cup
