headline: Leslie Manigat, Overthrown in a Coup in Haiti, Dies at 83
text: Leslie F. Manigat, a prominent political figure in Haiti who as its president in 1988 was overthrown in a bloodless military coup after serving in office for less than six months, died Friday at his home in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. He was 83.

headline: Robert Gardner Dies at 88; Filmed Cultural Practices
text: Robert Gardner, an intrepid filmmaker who specialized in anthropological documentaries, examining lives in remote societies around the globe, died on June 21 in Boston. He was 88.

headline: Boy, 3, Found Safe After Grandfather Falls Asleep on Subway
text: Kah-yon Reynolds, a 3-year-old boy from Newark, was missing for several hours on Friday after his grandfather took him on the subway and fell asleep.

headline: Rollin King, Texas Pilot Who Helped Start Southwest, Dies at 83
text: Rollin W. King, a co-founder of Southwest Airlines, the low-cost carrier that helped to change the way Americans travel, died Thursday in Dallas. He was 83. The cause was complications from a stroke he had a year ago, his son Edward King of Dallas said.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE COUNSELOR (2013) Michael Fassbender (above right, with Brad Pitt) portrays the title character — a corrupt, high-flying Texas lawyer who gets in over his head in a drug deal with Reiner (Javier Bardem), a nightclub owner involved with a Mexican cartel promising a 4,000 percent return — in this thriller directed by Ridley Scott from a screenplay by Cormac McCarthy. Mr. Pitt is the Counselor’s wary business associate, Cameron Diaz is Reiner’s predatory girlfriend and Penélope Cruz is the woman the Counselor intends to marry. “From all the ellipses, as well as the eccentric, mesmerizing poetry of his dialogue, Mr. McCarthy appears to have never read a screenwriting manual in his life. (That’s a compliment; this is his first produced film script.),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about what she called a “terrifying, implacable new movie.” In Mr. McCarthy, she added, Mr. Scott “has found a partner with convictions about good and evil rather than canned formula.”

headline: Americans Think We Have the World’s Best Colleges. We Don’t.
text: Americans have a split vision of education. Conventional wisdom has long held that our K-12 schools are mediocre or worse, while our colleges and universities are world class. While policy wonks hotly debate K-12 reform ideas like vouchers and the Common Core state standards, higher education is largely left to its own devices. Many families are worried about how to get into and pay for increasingly expensive colleges. But the stellar quality of those institutions is assumed.

headline: Are Markets Efficient? Even the Supreme Court Is Weighing In

headline: Brazil vs. Chile: World Cup 2014 Live Blog

headline: Lucy Liu’s Directorial Debut on Human Trafficking
text: I traveled to Mumbai in 2010 to direct my first film “MEENA,” based on the first chapter of Nick and Sheryl’s book Half The Sky: Turning Oppression Into Opportunity for Women Worldwide. Even though MEENA is only a 20 minute film and took 5 days to shoot, it has taken nearly four years for it to finally be seen by an audience. The earlier feedback we received was that the content was too strong and that viewers would feel uncomfortable with the aggressive nature of violence in conjunction with children. The premiere of Meena this week was truly transformative. I felt excited and reinvigorated to be surrounded by an audience who were not only engaged by the film’s message, but also curious about how they can become more actively involved in learning about child protection.

headline: Iraqi Army, in New Show of Force, Drives Back Insurgents in Major City

headline: The Dark Pool Iceberg
text: Shareholders and brokerage houses ditched Barclays at the end of last week, and who could blame them? In addition to its involvement in serial financial scandals — including the manipulation of interest rates and gold prices — the bank now stands accused of fraud related to its “dark pool,” essentially a private stock exchange.

headline: Rape Evidence Backlog
text: The failure of police departments around the country to test and analyze evidence connected to sexual assaults shows contempt for victims, public safety and justice. Medical personnel collect saliva, semen, blood, hair and other DNA evidence from victims after an attack in so-called rape kits. These kits, however, often sit unopened for years in police evidence rooms or public crime labs.

headline: Variety: A Cheerful Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — In the same way many people are divided on whether Leo Tolstoy’s opening observation in “Anna Karenina” — that “happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way” — is true, I’ll wager that there will be a divide on whether today’s acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon was easy or difficult. I probably fell somewhere in the middle.

headline: Tiger Woods Hopes to Erase the Supplements Stigma

headline: When Civil-Rights Unity Fractured
text: FIFTY years ago this month, more than a thousand predominantly young, predominantly white volunteers arrived in Mississippi to help local blacks register to vote. “Freedom Summer” is remembered as both a high point of interracial democratic activism and a low point in racial violence, most notably in the brutal murder of three civil rights workers, two of whom were white.

headline: Bolshoi Director Attacked With Acid Returns to Hospital
text: Sergei Filin, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet who was nearly blinded in an acid attack in January 2013, is in intensive care at the Sklifosovsky Research Institute in Moscow, the Russian news agencies Interfax and RIA Novosti reported on Saturday.

headline: McEnroe’s Call for Tournament Line Judges: ‘Out!’
text: WIMBLEDON, England — At every match at Wimbledon, a team of line judges, dressed in matching white pants, striped shirts and blue jackets, stand stoically in formation around the court. Shot by shot, they decide whether balls, some of them moving more than 100 miles per hour, are in or out.

headline: China’s Threat to Wild Tigers
text: EARLIER this year, a police raid on a house party in Leizhou, Guangdong Province, in southern China, revealed a decadent diversion apparently popular among some of China’s elite: watching a tiger being slaughtered and butchered, then gorging on meat that’s considered an exotic delicacy.

headline: A Child of Grass Courts Dreams Anew
text: WIMBLEDON, England — A long Wimbledon day had stretched into evening, and finally darkness, by the time Cara Black settled into a chair, with another victory registered in an illustrious doubles career that has brought her 10 Grand Slam titles with partners female and male. She was tired, expressionless, but only until a question was asked about her beloved grass courts.

headline: The Power of a Deed
text: TUESDAY is the observance of the 20th anniversary of the death of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson — universally known as the Rebbe — who for decades was the charismatic leader of millions of Jews. Commemorations are planned; several biographies have just been released.

headline: Covering New War, in Shadow of Old One
text: THE lead-up to the war in Iraq in 2003 was not The Times’s finest hour. Some of the news reporting was flawed, driven by outside agendas and lacking in needed skepticism. Many Op-Ed columns promoted the idea of a war that turned out to be both unfounded and disastrous.

headline: Britain’s Strange Identity Crisis
text: LONDON — THE United Kingdom is lying on the psychiatrist’s couch. Suddenly the country seems uncertain of its identity, its place in the world, its relationships with its closest family members and its neighbors.

headline: Is Obesity O.K.?
text: Readers discuss an advice columnist’s assertion that pretending that obesity is not a problem may prevent hurt feelings but compromise health.

headline: Life in Iraq Grinds On, Whoever Is in Charge
text: HIS name was Thamir, and he was a pool hustler. He was good enough that when a translator shouted in the pool hall that I wanted to meet the best player in Husayba, the gaggle of men parted, opening the way to him. Thamir grinned wryly, pressed an index finger against his chest and lifted his chin in that universal gesture: You want to talk to me?

headline: They Said It Couldn’t Be Done
text: Less than a year ago, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his forces were sporadically using chemical weapons on rebels and civilians in the civil war. Today, the stockpile that he grudgingly admitted to under international pressure is gone.

headline: How the Terrorists Got Rich
text: A FEW feet from the Bab al-Salam border crossing near the Turkish town of Kilis, there is a shabby cafe where the most interesting items for sale are not found on the menu. The cafe is the final stop for young radicalized men from Europe or North Africa who are planning to slip past the lax Turkish border officers and into Syrian territory. This is where they exchange their passports for cash. When one of us visited the cafe in January, a Belgian passport was for sale for $8,000. A buyer could have it altered for movement to Europe or visa-free travel to the United States. New passport photos were being snapped in the parking lot.

headline: Dale Chihuly
text: Dale Chihuly is a widely collected glass sculptor whose work has been installed in venues as varied as the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and the Bellagio Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

headline: Arsonists and Firefighters
text: WHAT’S the real fight in the Middle East today? Is it just sectarian (Sunnis versus Shiites) and national (Israelis versus Palestinians and Arabs versus Persians)? Or is it something deeper? I was discussing this core question with Nader Mousavizadeh, a former senior United Nations official and the co-founder of Macro Advisory Partners, a geopolitical advisory firm, and he offered another framework: “The real struggle in the region,” he said, “is between arsonists and firefighters.”

headline: Stopping Campus Rape
text: IN the debate over sexual violence on college campuses, two things are reasonably clear. First, campus rape is a grave, persistent problem, shadowing rowdy state schools and cozy liberal-arts campuses alike.

headline: Why Teenagers Act Crazy
text: ADOLESCENCE is practically synonymous in our culture with risk taking, emotional drama and all forms of outlandish behavior. Until very recently, the widely accepted explanation for adolescent angst has been psychological. Developmentally, teenagers face a number of social and emotional challenges, like starting to separate from their parents, getting accepted into a peer group and figuring out who they really are. It doesn’t take a psychoanalyst to realize that these are anxiety-provoking transitions.

headline: What ‘Nurse Jackie’ Gets Right About the E.R.
text: A lot of nurses hate the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie,” which will wrap up its sixth season on Sunday evening. Actually, to be precise, they hate the show’s lead character, the emergency department nurse Jackie Peyton. There’s much to dislike: She is an adulterer, a liar, an unreliable mother and, most significantly, addicted to prescription painkillers. (That’s hardly giving anything away, but be warned: spoilers ahead.)

headline: Once a Militant Stronghold in Iraq, Now a Battleground Again
text: AL-DAIRA, Iraq — At one house, Iraq’s national flag fluttered atop a building that Iraqi soldiers had captured from militants two days before.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 29
text: President Obama asked Congress for $500 million to train and equip “appropriately vetted” members of the Syrian opposition on Thursday as concerns rise about the conflict spilling into Iraq. Ten days ago, Mr. Obama said he would send 300 American military advisers to assess Iraq’s military as it faces Sunni militants.

headline: ‘Be Not Afraid of My Body’

headline: The Right to Write
text: I sat on a panel once with another novelist and a distinguished African-American critic, to discuss Harriet Beecher Stowe’s novel “Uncle Tom’s Cabin.” The critic said, “Of course, as a white woman, Stowe had no right to write the black experience.” The other novelist said lightly, “No, of course not. And I had no right to write about 14th-century Scandinavians. Which I did.”

headline: After the Game, Reality Sinks In for a Lineman
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Kendrick Payne picked up a passenger in his silver Nissan Altima one afternoon last week in downtown Oakland, across the street from the federal courthouse. Payne, a former defensive lineman at the University of California, wore an old Bears workout shirt with his No. 96 printed on the back. His N.F.L. dreams all but gone, he works as a driver for Lyft, a ride-sharing company.

headline: What Is Your Experience in the American Military’s Health Care System?

headline: Struggling Met Contributes By Controlling the Playlist
text: PITTSBURGH — After every Mets home win, the players pour into the clubhouse, bobbing their heads as the hip-hop song “Get Like Me,” by David Banner, thumps through the speakers. For 15 minutes, music blares and the mood is light. Then the clubhouse is opened to the news media, and the players go their separate ways.

headline: With Surge of Chaos in Iraq, a Familiar Problem Knocks on Biden’s Door
text: WASHINGTON — From the first summer of the Obama administration, Iraq has been considered Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s account. But when President Obama called a critical meeting on June 16 to confront the crisis that had suddenly erupted there, Mr. Biden was landing in Brazil to go to a World Cup soccer game.

headline: In Military Care, a Pattern of Errors but Not Scrutiny
text: FORT SILL, Okla. — Jessica Zeppa, five months pregnant, the wife of a soldier, showed up four times at Reynolds Army Community Hospital here in pain, weak, barely able to swallow and fighting a fever. The last time, she declared that she was not leaving until she could get warm.

headline: Rays Cast Aside Emotions as Reality Derails Plans
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The secret to the success of the Tampa Bay Rays, before this season’s startling and spectacular collapse, has been that there are no hard decisions, only necessary ones. A move that may seem wrenching to an outsider is not that way to the Rays.

headline: Stagflation and the Fall of Macroeconomics
text: Simon Wren-Lewis and Mark Thoma write about the rise of New Classical Macroeconomics — basically the rejection of Keynes and the attempted assimilation of macro into micro. Unusually, I have some bones to pick with both, although we clearly agree on the big stuff.

headline: Kids Behind Bars

As my column notes, the United States incarcerates kids at a rate 10 to 20 times higher than in some other industrialized countries; I should have added that it’s 100 times the rate of a few countries.

They have been singing James Rodríguez’s praises all along, in fact, but in the flurry of goals and teams and story lines in this World Cup, there was a chance a few people had not yet noticed Rodríguez. headline: 1914: Assassination of the Archduke Francis Ferdinand was a conspiracy
text: VIENNA — That the assassination of Archduke Francis Ferdinand, the heir to the thrones of Austria and Hungary, and of the Duchess of Hohenberg, his consort, was the result of a widespread plot, the extent of which the actual actors were perhaps unaware of, now appears to be beyond doubt. In case the attempt on the Archduke’s life in Sarajevo failed, other bombs, it is stated, were to have been exploded on the railway as the Royal train was on its return journey from the Bosnian capital. Serious disturbances have taken place in Sarajevo and other towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Yesterday, another bomb was thrown at a street corner in Sarajevo by a young man, a Mussulman being wounded by the explosion. Martial law has been proclaimed in the town. The bodies of Archduke Francis Ferdinand and the Duchess of Hohenberg were embalmed during Sunday night, and were removed yesterday by special train to Metkovich, Dalmatia, on their way to Vienna. The funeral will take place on Friday, the interment being in the mausoleum on the Archduke’s estate at Artstetten. Emperor Francis Joseph will not be present at this ceremony, but will attend a requiem mass on the following day. A representative of a Prague bank in which Archduke Francis Ferdinand’s will had been deposited has arrived in Vienna with the document. It is stated that certain questions of State in which the Archduke was interested will be confided by the Emperor to the new heir to the throne. — From The New York Herald, European Edition, June 30, 1914.

headline: Hong Kong Poll Turnout Buoys Democracy Activists
text: HONG KONG — An unofficial referendum on making the selection of Hong Kong’s chief executive more democratic has attracted votes equal to more than a fifth of the city’s electorate, organizers said Sunday, the referendum’s final day. They voiced hopes that the higher-than-anticipated participation would, along with a protest march scheduled for Tuesday, increase the pressure on the mainland Chinese government to give ground on the issue.

headline: Russian Jets and Experts Sent to Iraq to Aid Army
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi government officials said Sunday that Russian experts had arrived in Iraq to help the army get 12 new Russian warplanes into the fight against Sunni extremists, while the extremists declared their leader the caliph, or absolute ruler, of all jihadi organizations worldwide.

headline: Assisting in Life — and Death
text: Saturday was a watershed moment for the American suicide-prevention effort. In response to decades of public advocacy, San Francisco transit authorities unanimously approved a $76 million plan to construct suicide barriers on the Golden Gate Bridge — where 46 people jumped to their death last year alone. “The time of healing can only begin when the drip-drip-drip of bodies into the raging waters has stopped,” a mother of one jumper told Michael Cabanatuan of The San Francisco Chronicle.

headline: Japanese Protester Sets Himself on Fire at Train Station in Tokyo
text: TOKYO — In a ghastly spectacle of a sort rarely seen in this orderly city, a man set himself on fire in front of horrified crowds at Tokyo’s busiest train station on Sunday in what appeared to be a lone protest against efforts to weaken Japan’s antiwar Constitution.

text: Meshach Taylor, the actor best known as the friendly colleague of four Southern women on the popular sitcom “Designing Women,” died on Saturday at his home near Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (HBO) THE LEFTOVERS Three years after 2 percent of the world’s population suddenly disappeared on Oct. 14, for no discernible reason — Was it an act of God? A natural phenomenon? — the residents of the fictional Mapleton, N.Y., are still searching for answers in this dystopian series created by Tom Perrotta, adapted from his novel, and Damon Lindelof, a mastermind behind ABC’s “Lost.” Churches have closed while cults have formed, including the Guilty Remnant, whose followers wear white, take a vow of silence and chain smoke. One member is Laurie (Amy Brenneman), the mother of Jill (Margaret Qualley), a high schooler, and Tom (Chris Zylka), who has joined another cult led by a man who claims that he can hug the pain out of people. Laurie is also the wife of Kevin Garvey (Justin Theroux, the town’s chief of police, above, speaking with Amanda Warren), whose colleagues worry that he may be losing his mind as he tries to maintain order. The show “may never explain what happened to the people who disappeared, but the measure of its worth is that it may not have to,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “As with any good drama, the mystery lies in human nature more than in the supernatural. Once the show gets going, and it takes more than one episode to do so, ‘The Leftovers’ bores into the characters and the fissures that crack their community so astutely that the cause is almost secondary.”

headline: New York Council Bill Aims to Ease a Parking Burden
text: It is the New York City driver’s public shame — a sentence of solitary front-seat confinement levied against those for whom subways, buses and taxis are insufficient.

headline: With This Video Camera, I Thee Shoot
text: Ever wonder what’s running through the mind of the person shooting your wedding video as he eats your hors d’oeuvres and walks backward down the aisle? If you hired Doug Block, there’s no need to wonder. He’s thinking, “You know what, this would make a pretty good documentary!”

headline: Mets Are Hurt, for a Day, by a Trade That’s Working for 2 Teams
text: PITTSBURGH — Two months had passed since the Mets had traded Ike Davis, and the drama was gone. The team and the player had moved on; both seemed content. They had history — injuries, trade rumors, a competition with Lucas Duda, all of which had seemed so serious at the time — but time had smoothed the rough edges.

headline: After Supreme Court Ruling, Aereo’s Rivals in TV Streaming Seize Opening
text: Mark Ely saw an opportunity, and he took it.

headline: Where Passion Rules, Morality Stands Little Chance
text: PARIS — Nero and Poppea never touch in Robert Wilson’s new production of Monteverdi’s “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” for the Paris Opera, which ends its run at the Palais Garnier on Monday. Their love affair, which drives anyone who gets in its way to death or exile, is one of the most violent portrayed in opera. Yet even during their final, rapturous duet, “Pur ti miro,” on Saturday, the tenor Jeremy Ovenden and the mezzo-soprano Karine Deshayes maintained a sliver of space between their outstretched hands.

headline: On the Legal Front Lines of Same-Sex Marriage
text: For more than four years a group of prominent lawyers led by Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, along with political consultants and Hollywood celebrities, campaigned against Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriages approved by California voters in 2008. The group, the American Foundation for Equal Rights, had two primary goals: to secure a judicial victory in the Supreme Court extending marriage to gay couples nationwide and to increase support for the cause through a public-relations blitz.

headline: Ooh, a Maypole! And Love Interests, With Feathers
text: Siegfried, the prince in “Swan Lake,” spends a lot of time surrounded by women who don’t seem to interest him. In American Ballet Theater’s production, he invariably appears more excited by the arrival of a maypole at his birthday party (Act I) than by the young ladies lining up to dance with him. In Act III, when princesses of the world parade through his court, enticing him with their national dances — Hungarian, Spanish, Italian, Polish — he wants none of them for his bride. “No,” he mimes to the Queen Mother, who has urged him to choose one, causing a flurry of disbelief among his courtiers.

headline: Despite Legal Challenges, Sale of Hopi Religious Artifacts Continues in France
text: The thought of Americans lecturing the French about cultural sensibilities seems like a hard sell in a country still shielding its language from idiomatic blasphemies like “le weekend” and “hashtag.” But the United States Embassy in Paris spent several days last week educating French officials about the strong emotions that have led Native American tribes like the Hopi and Navajo to sue Parisian auction houses — unsuccessfully, time and again — over the sale of sacred objects.

headline: One Who Plays For Pay
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Monday, everyone! It’s a vowel run.

headline: Gilbert & Sullivan Announces Season
text: A witch’s curse, embattled lovers and a gondolier with royal blood will be part of the 2014-15 lineup for the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, the organizers have announced. The season, which will take place at New York University’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, is to begin on Oct. 12 with a benefit gala celebrating the group’s 40th anniversary. That will be followed on Nov. 1 and 2 by “Ruddigore,” in which the Baronet of Ruddigore tries to escape a curse that forces him to commit a daily crime. “H.M.S. Pinafore,” Dec. 26-31, tells the comedic story of a lowly sailor’s plan to elope with the captain’s daughter before finding out that he isn’t as lowly as everyone — including himself — thinks he is. The theme of mistaken identity continues with the season’s final production, “The Gondoliers,” May 15-17. More information is at nygasp.org.

headline: 1939: First Woman Elected Mayor of Dublin
text: DUBLIN — The first woman Lord Mayor of Dublin in history was elected last night. She was Mrs. Tom Clarkes, widow of Fenian leader executed after the 1916 Easter uprising, who herself has been an active Nationalist. The decisive vote which put her into office was cast by the outgoing Lord Mayor, Alderman Alfred Byrne, whom she has previously tried to oust from office on six different occasions. Byrne had been Lord Mayor for nine years. — From The New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 30, 1939.

headline: Remembering World War I in the Conflict’s Flash Point
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — If there was a moment that captured better than any other the light and the dark in Sarajevo’s centenary weekend, marking 100 years since the events here that unleashed the demons of World War I, it came with the opening bars of Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.”

headline: All Jooked Up With Everywhere to Go
text: MEMPHIS — Breakthroughs in an art form happen rarely. Yet on Saturday night in this city, at an event advertised as “launching the World Jookin Federation,” breakthroughs seemed to keep happening all evening long.

headline: Hot Spots, Anyone? Racy Preferred
text: The website is called Vice News, so it’s fair to expect racy images in a film titled “Posing as a Prostitute in a Turkish Brothel: Correspondent Confidential.”

headline: Boxed In, With Room for Creativity
text: For the first show he conceived as director of the Museum of Arts and Design, Glenn Adamson is thinking inside the box.

headline: England Beats Poland at European Championships
text: The European Championships are continuing in Opatija, Croatia. Teams are vying for medals and to qualify for next year’s world championships: the Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup and d’Orsi Senior Bowl.

headline: News Corp. Slowly Putting Phone-Hacking Scandal Behind It
text: Less than three years ago, a phone-hacking scandal at Rupert Murdoch’s British newspapers was seen by some as the beginning of the end of his media empire.

headline: Little Lambs: A Pastoral
text: The local butchers own a farm near the English village where I live and staged a “lambing event” there this spring. They put up a plywood sign cut in the shape of a curly-fleeced lamb on the lane that ran past their drive, which promised fun for all ages and a taste of the countryside. I saw it on the way home from work and decided to take my 4-year-old daughter, Rosy, along as a treat on the weekend. Rosy loves animals and the chance of letting her get close to some of the stars of her nursery rhymes was unmissable.

headline: Blame War, Not Safaris
text: Safari hunting strikes many people as distasteful in the best of times, and during a conflict, as morally outrageous. The Central African Republic is at war again, and two loose-knit coalitions — one mostly Muslim, the other mostly Christian — are massacring each other. Yet the trophy hunting goes on. A few intrepid foreigners are traveling to the eastern parts of the republic to kill Lord Derby Eland, the largest antelope in Africa, and its shy forest cousin, the bongo.

headline: Japan’s Foundering Finances
text: The Abe administration is still waiting for its economic reforms to take off.

headline: Why Not Just Weigh the Fish?
text: Morale these days has fallen pretty low along the corridors of philosophy departments. From one side, we get the mockery of the scientists. Freeman Dyson calls philosophy today “a toothless relic of past glories.” According to Neil deGrasse Tyson, majoring in philosophy “can really mess you up.” Stephen Hawking declares that “philosophy is dead.” From another side, we have to cope with the apostasy of our own leading figures. John Searle describes the field as being in “terrible shape.” Peter Unger says that philosophers are “under the impression that they’re saying something new and interesting about how it is about the world, when in fact this is all an illusion.” What’s going on? Has philosophy gone horribly amiss? Or are there broader cultural factors at work, perhaps something to do with a general decline in respect for the humanities?

headline: New NPR Chief, Jarl Mohn, Vows to Foster Diversity
text: When Jarl Mohn takes the helm as NPR’s chief executive on Tuesday, he will call on lessons learned from public radio in Los Angeles to address what he says is one of NPR’s most pressing priorities: increasing its reach into communities of color.

headline: Let Them Eat Cash
text: A CHINESE millionaire tried to give $300 (and lunch) to homeless men and women in New York last week. This didn’t sit well with the nonprofit New York City Rescue Mission. The Rescue Mission offered to help with lunch, but wouldn’t cooperate in handing out cash. So midway through a meal of sesame-crusted tuna and filet of beef, some 200 homeless people discovered that they would not be getting money. Instead, the Rescue Mission would accept $90,000 on their behalf. You can imagine the anger and humiliation.

headline: Anthrax? That’s Not the Real Worry
text: OFFICIALS at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently discovered that at least 75 workers there had been exposed to possible anthrax infection.

headline: Rubble in India Is Combed, and Builders Arrested
text: NEW DELHI — Rescuers digging through the rubble of a 12-story building that collapsed on Saturday in heavy rains in the southern city of Chennai had by Sunday evening recovered the bodies of 11 people and rescued 21 survivors, with possibly many more people still trapped under the rubble, officials said.
