text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 30
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Bruised Captain Inspires Belgians
text: MOGI DAS CRUZES, Brazil — Vincent Kompany, Belgium’s captain, jumped to head a corner kick during a World Cup qualifying match against Serbia last June. He hoped to land with a goal. Instead, he fell to the ground with a bloodied face, a broken nose, a fractured eye socket and a concussion.

headline: The Water Crisis in the West
text: What are the best ways to share water and ensure it lasts for the foreseeable future?

headline: Tribune Company Hopes to Turn WGN America Into Cable Network
text: Every cable TV network needs one thing to thrust itself into the consciousness of viewers: a signature show that attracts ratings and passionate advocates.

headline: Awakening the ‘Dutch Gene’ of Water Survival
text: NOORDWIJK, the Netherlands — Along a rugged, wide North Sea beach here on a recent day, children formed teams of eight to 10, taking their places beside mounds of sand carefully cordoned by candy-cane striped tape. They had one hour for their sand castle competition. Some built fishlike structures, complete with scales. Others spent their time on elaborate ditch and dike labyrinths. Each castle was adorned on top with a white flag.

headline: For Women, a Bigger Share of the Brightest Stages at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Lindsay Davenport has been coming to Wimbledon, the world’s most prestigious tennis championship, for more than 20 years, but she had never seen anything quite like the second day of this year’s tournament.

headline: Long List of Contenders After Serena Williams’s Defeat
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Three times this year, Serena Williams has arrived at a Grand Slam event as the top seed and heavy favorite, and three times she has lost before the business end of the tournament.

headline: For Email Newsletters, a Death Greatly Exaggerated
text: Here at the Media Equation, we pride ourselves on keeping our readers abreast of the newest technologies and approaches in reaching audiences. So it gives us great pleasure to reveal a radical publishing technology that is catching on in news media companies big and small. Ladies and gentlemen, behold: email.

headline: Newsletters You Might Actually Be Happy to Find in Your Inbox
text: Like most people, I’m careful about handing my email address to anyone, much less somebody who promises to send me messages every working day. But because they sit in my inbox and can be opened (or ignored) at a time of my choosing, I’ve found newsletters keep me in the know about specific topics — which in my case includes media comings and goings. Here are a few newsletters that I follow and others that I hear great things about.

headline: Verizon to Return to Its Former Midtown Tower, but on a Smaller Scale
text: When New York Telephone first moved into its headquarters near Times Square, the company was a monolith that controlled virtually all telecommunications in New York City through a network of wires that snaked into nearly every building. The equipment that connected all those phone lines filled half of the headquarters tower and dozens of other buildings scattered throughout the city.

headline: Kidd’s Power Play Is Bold, if Not Out of Character
text: The lead-in to free agency tends to be a tumultuous time in the N.B.A. Players are weighing their options. Front offices are deciding whom to retain and recruit. Through it all, however, each coach usually has a sense of his team’s direction amid the long off-season.

headline: With Two Victories as a Rookie, the Son of a Nascar Great Roars on His Own
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — The next great Nascar driver has the deep Southern twang of a country singer, a poise that belies his age and a name that was born for this sport.

headline: ‘Live in Levi’s’ Campaign Reunites Levi Strauss With Its Old Agency, FCB
text: WHEN the duo Peaches and Herb, known as “the sweethearts of soul,” got back together, they sang, “Reunited and it feels so good.” Now, an apparel brand reuniting after 16 years with an agency that was its soul mate for almost seven decades is declaring that its clothing feels good enough to live in.

headline: Math Under Common Core Has Even Parents Stumbling
text: GREENWELL SPRINGS, La. — Rebekah and Kevin Nelams moved to their modest brick home in this suburb of Baton Rouge seven years ago because it has one of the top-performing public school districts in the state. But starting this fall, Ms. Nelams plans to home-school the couple’s four elementary-age children.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Charlatans, Cranks and Kansas
text: Two years ago Kansas embarked on a remarkable fiscal experiment: It sharply slashed income taxes without any clear idea of what would replace the lost revenue. Sam Brownback, the governor, proposed the legislation — in percentage terms, the largest tax cut in one year any state has ever enacted — in close consultation with the economist Arthur Laffer. And Mr. Brownback predicted that the cuts would jump-start an economic boom — “Look out, Texas,” he proclaimed.

headline: A Disregarded Request From a Beloved Senator Shakes Up Hawaii’s Primary
text: WAIANAE, Hawaii — For over 50 years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Democrat, was the closest thing modern-day Hawaii had to political royalty: He began representing the state in Washington two years before its most famous citizen was even born. As he lay dying in 2012, Mr. Inouye asked the governor, Neil Abercrombie, to appoint Representative Colleen Hanabusa, a protégée and the daughter of a gas station owner here, to fill his seat.

headline: Online Museum for Springsteen
text: An online museum displaying more than 300 pieces of Bruce Springsteen memorabilia is to officially open its figurative doors on Monday. The virtual museum, blindedbythelight.com, is the product of five years of planning, eight years of amassing a collection of thousands of items and more than three decades of adoration for the Boss by the site’s founder, Michael Crane. Plans are to add 30 to 50 items a month to the site, where they will tell a story that fans might not otherwise see, Mr. Crane said by phone on Sunday from Israel. “For a Bruce fan, this gives you insight into your hero and the way he grew up,” he said. Among the items is an eighth-grade report card, above right, featuring mostly low grades, including D’s in composition, physical education and music. The young Springsteen “didn’t have a great time in Catholic school,” Mr. Crane said. “He wasn’t allowed to be who he wanted to be and to express himself.” Mr. Crane said his favorite item is a photo of Mr. Springsteen and his father on a 1972 visit to Mexico. “Bruce has described their relationship as tumultuous,” Mr. Crane said, “so it’s cool to see Bruce as just a kid laughing with his dad.” Admission is $9.99, which allows a month of access to the site, the ability to download a font that replicates Mr. Springsteen’s handwriting style, the use of a ticket and memorabilia exchange, and entry to a monthly raffle. Mr. Springsteen has no formal involvement with the site.

headline: House Hypocrisy on Insider Trading
text: It was quite the ballyhooed reform of Capitol Hill ethics — an explicit ban on insider trading by members of Congress and their aides enacted two years ago in a bipartisan wave of approval by the Senate and House.

headline: Medical Boards Draft Plan to Ease Path to Out-of-State and Online Treatment
text: WASHINGTON — Officials representing state medical boards across the country have drafted a model law that would make it much easier for doctors licensed in one state to treat patients in other states, whether in person, by videoconference or online.

headline: New Wave of African Writers With an Internationalist Bent
text: More than a decade ago, when the young Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie was struggling to get her first novel, “Purple Hibiscus,” published, an agent told her that things would be easier “if only you were Indian,” because Indian writers were in vogue. Another suggested changing the setting from Nigeria to America. Ms. Adichie didn’t take this as commentary on her work, she said, but on the timidity of the publishing world when it came to unknown writers and unfamiliar cultures, especially African ones.

headline: Pushback on Home Care
text: The salvos keep coming from opponents of a new federal rule to ensure that home care workers are paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. The rule, many years in the making, reverses a misguided policy from 1974 that has long denied home care workers those basic wage protections.

headline: New Rules to Address Campus Rape
text: Federal officials have started paying close attention to sexual assault on college campuses. A White House task force last month issued recommendations on how to combat the problem, and this month the Department of Education published draft rules clarifying how universities can meet federal requirements on campus safety.

headline: Ancient Sport Grows, but Not to U.S. Women
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Tiffany Tran stands 5 feet 1 inch tall and weighs 166 pounds. She is a vegetarian studying for a master’s in biology. She is also a sumo wrestler.

headline: With Rainbow Neckerchiefs, Celebrating Pride and Progress at Parade
text: The color guard leading the annual Gay Pride March down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Sunday carried flags of sky blue, navy blue, red-white-and-blue and rainbow. But, for these marchers, the colors that mattered most were the ones they wore.

headline: Facebook Tinkers With Users’ Emotions in News Feed Experiment, Stirring Outcry
text: To Facebook, we are all lab rats.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Money Trail
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who is toying with the idea of running for president, has yet to show sufficient interest in managing the public’s money in ways that benefit the public. He talks plenty tough, but can he make hard decisions that help ordinary people, even when it might hurt him politically?

headline: Miles From Her Top Competitors, a Young Star Still Outswims Them
text: BETHESDA, Md. — The headwaiter at the steakhouse a few miles from Katie Ledecky’s home smiled broadly when Ledecky walked through the door one night last week with her parents and older brother. He asked her if she was dining out to celebrate her two recent world-record-breaking swims.

headline: With a Lunge and a Parry, a Goalkeeper Helps Costa Rica Advance
text: RECIFE, Brazil — Not every team can conjure attacks out of thin air with grace and panache. Not every goal is a firecracker that enchants the neutral fan. Not every game can be an instant classic, even if this rollicking World Cup has thus far made it seem so.

headline: New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The newly installed director of the National Security Agency says that while he has seen some terrorist groups alter their communications to avoid surveillance techniques revealed by Edward J. Snowden, the damage done over all by a year of revelations does not lead him to the conclusion that “the sky is falling.”

headline: G.M. to Set Payouts in Crashes Caused by Flawed Switches
text: WASHINGTON — A prominent compensation expert hired by General Motors is scheduled to announce a plan here on Monday to distribute money to victims of accidents caused by the automaker’s defective ignition switch.

headline: Flawed Saudi Response Is Cited in Outbreak of the Middle East Virus MERS
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — As the virus tore through the city’s largest hospital, jumping from bed to bed and afflicting scores of people, terror filled the wards.

headline: State Department Documents on Blackwater Episode
text: Documents related to a 2007 inquiry of Blackwater’s Iraq operations and a State Department investigator’s report that the private security firm’s manager there had threatened to kill him.

headline: For Goalkeepers in Brazil, Catching Grief Is Part of the Job
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For years, it has gone without saying in Brazil that fathers do not let their children grow up to be goalkeepers.

headline: Before Shooting in Iraq, a Warning on Blackwater
text: WASHINGTON — Just weeks before Blackwater guards fatally shot 17 civilians at Baghdad’s Nisour Square in 2007, the State Department began investigating the security contractor’s operations in Iraq. But the inquiry was abandoned after Blackwater’s top manager there issued a threat: “that he could kill” the government’s chief investigator and “no one could or would do anything about it as we were in Iraq,” according to department reports.

headline: A Historic Warship, Reborn as a Tourist Draw, May See Another Revival
text: Not many veterans of World War II are coming out of retirement these days, but the rusty old troop carrier known as Circle Line X may be put back to work soon, just a few blocks from Times Square.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 29, 2014
Modern Tools for Mom-and-Pops
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y. — Operators at KES Dispatch keep track of the company’s taxis on a yellow legal pad. They communicate with cars using a two-way radio. Drivers navigate their journeys largely by memory.

headline: One Son Missing, Another Dead, and 2 Mothers Across a Divide
text: The mothers, one Israeli and the other Palestinian, have taken on conspicuous roles in their communities because of their losses.

headline: After West Bank Kidnapping, 2 Mothers Embody a Divide
text: NOF AYALON, Israel — It was about 4 a.m. on a Friday when the police banged on Rachel Fraenkel’s door in this Jerusalem suburb looking for her 16-year-old son, Naftali, and a friend he studies with at a yeshiva in the West Bank. The night before, Naftali had texted his parents saying he was going to hitchhike back home. They had no idea he had never arrived.

headline: Women as Sumo Warriors
text: American sumo wrestlers of all shapes and backgrounds descended on Jackson Hole, Wyo., for the United States Sumo Championships. The women were a small, but proud, contingent.

headline: Hog Hunting for Survival
text: A cowboy turned roughneck reflects on the haves and have-nots in Texas’ Eagle Ford oil boom.

headline: An Adjustment Essential to the Yankees’ Future
text: Brian McCann made seven All-Star teams in nine seasons with the Atlanta Braves, but he also offered something intangible. He became, in some ways, the soul of his team. To the Yankees, McCann’s talent and character were worth $85 million in free agency.

headline: NASA Launching Satellite to Track Carbon
text: On an average day, some 100 million tons of carbon dioxide is liberated from oil and coal by combustion, wafting into the air. The gas traps heat in the atmosphere, resulting in the gradual warming that has alarmed scientists and much of the public.

headline: Judy Vargas
text: Judy Vargas lives in the colonia of Gardendale, Tex., with her grandmother and three young children, whom she supports by cooking at a local restaurant.

headline: Netanyahu Says Security Control Is Vital in Any Accord
text: TEL AVIV — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared Sunday in a hard-hitting policy speech here that under any future peace agreement with the Palestinians, Israel would insist on maintaining security control of the West Bank “for a very long time.”

headline: ‘True Blood’ Recap: Jason Had the Best Dream…
text: Season 7, Episode 2 Talk about fan service! On Sunday night, “True Blood” opened with its two resident studs, the Viking vamp Eric (Alexander Skarsgard) and the Louisiana lech Jason (Ryan Kwanten), getting it on — shirtless, kissing, dim light, chamber music on the soundtrack. It was as if Cinemax had broken into the HBO satellite feed.

headline: U.S. Jobs Data and New-Car Sales for June Are Due
text: U.S. JOBS DATA TO BE RELEASED EARLY IN HOLIDAY WEEK

headline: Sore Forearm Keeping Beltran From Field Duty
text: Carlos Beltran said before Sunday’s game against the Boston Red Sox that stiffness in his right forearm had been preventing him from throwing.

headline: Yolanda Aguilar
text: Heavy oil service trucks pass Yolanda Aguilar’s house in Gardendale both day and night. She hoses the unpaved road each morning to keep the dust down.

headline: Frac Sand Dumping
text: Nora Flores and a local worker discuss a 100-yard trail of frac sand dumped in front of her Gardendale Qwik Stop convenient store the night before.

headline: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Algeria, 2-1, in Extra time
text: Germany overcame an aggressive Algerian counterattack and broke through for two goals in extra time for a 2-1 victory that sent it into the quarterfinals.

headline: World Cup 2014: France Defeats Nigeria, 2-0
text: France broke a scoreless tie late in the match and ended up with a 2-0 victory over Nigeria. France now heads to Rio, to meet Germany or Algeria in the quarterfinal in the Maracana.

headline: Allen Grossman, a Poet’s Poet and Scholar, Dies at 82
text: Allen Grossman, an award-winning poet whose work bridged the Romantic and Modernist traditions, claiming nobility and power for poetry as a tool for both engaging the world and burrowing into the self, died on Friday in Chelsea, Mass. He was 82.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Social activity was measured for the 48 games in World Cup group play from the day before each match through two days after. The first United States game, where it defeated Ghana, generated the most activity the day after, with a score of 155,332.

headline: Boom Meets Bust in Texas: Atop Sea of Oil, Poverty Digs In
text: GARDENDALE, Tex. — From the window of her tin-roofed trailer, Judy Vargas can glimpse a miraculous world. It is as close as the dust kicked up by the trucks barreling by but seems as distant as Mars.

headline: Amid de Blasio’s Pre-K Push, a Bid to Boost Learning at a Weak Point in the Pipeline
text: Mildred Augustin has been providing day care from her home in the Bronx since 2002.

headline: ‘Halt and Catch Fire’ Recap: A Cold Cup of Joe
text: Season 1, Episode 5 They got the computer working! Well, some important parts of it, at least. Now they just need to find a screen. For that, they’ve got to figure out a way to stop offending the Japanese. And they also need to get right with their dads, because it turns out that when you’re trying to revolutionize the personal computer industry, daddy issues are a primary concern.

headline: Rent Cuts for Housing Homeless Hit a Snag
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has long criticized New York City’s use of privately owned apartment buildings to house homeless families, and his administration has, in its first six months, taken steps to reduce the amount that the city pays for these units.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Recap: Trying to Explain What Cannot Be Explained
text: Season 1, Episode 1 “Dogs are just animals, man. They see something like that, and they just snap. All bets are off right there. No more chasing sticks. …They just go primal, man. Same thing’s going to happen to us, it’s just taking longer.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 30, 2014
text: “It feels the same to us. The money that they have, we didn’t have it before. And we don’t have it now.”

headline: Michael Brown, 93, Dies; Industrial Musicals Gave Wings to ‘Mockingbird’
text: Michael Brown, a cabaret performer and songwriter known for his sprightly contributions to the industrial musical, an American entertainment genre that literally sang the praises of vacuums and zippers and autos and steel — and who, as an improbable result of this work, bestowed on his friend Harper Lee the wherewithal to write her only novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” — died on June 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Now Docking Downtown: An Oyster Bar on a Boat
text: For Alex Pincus, the question wasn’t whether Manhattan needed a floating oyster bar and mini-maritime museum on a 72-year-old codfish schooner, but rather where to put it. Now, his vision has become reality in the form of Grand Banks, which will begin serving food and drinks Thursday afternoon on a boat docked off Hudson River Park in TriBeCa.

headline: A Cooperative Hub for Emerging Talent Opens in TriBeCa
text: It’s often said that good design solves a problem. And a year and a half ago, Jean Lin learned that some New York designers had problems of their own. “They had nowhere to show their work in Manhattan,” says Lin, the co-founder of the charitable design organization Reclaim NYC. “They’re not in a showroom like Ralph Pucci, but they’ve grown out of their 450-square-foot bay in Red Hook.” So Lin, along with the marketing consultant Michael Maloney, created Colony, a multipurpose design exhibition space on New York’s Canal Street, which opened to the public last week.

headline: Keeping Your Cool
text: Last year, New York’s first documented heat-related death occurred on July 8, after three consecutive days with temperatures at 90 degrees or above. The victim was a 57-year-old man on Staten Island. The summer before, a record-breaking eight-day heat wave killed four people, three of them with health problems.

headline: Diana McLellan, Gossip Columnist With an Ear to Washington, Dies at 76
text: Diana McLellan, a grande dame of Washington gossip who perforated the pretentious, skewered the powerful and sometimes felt honor-bound to keep fact-checkers from coming between her bons mots and her “darlings,” as she called the devoted readers of her syndicated newspaper column, died on Thursday in Easton, Md. She was 76.

headline: Word of the Day | lagoon
text: lagoon •\lə-ˈgün\• noun

headline: Long a Tormentor of the Yankees, Ortiz Adds Yet Another Chapter
text: In the past decade of the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, few things have endured quite like David Ortiz, the hulking Boston slugger who, even at age 38 and in his 18th major league season, continues to stir up some of his most inimitable qualities against his fiercest rivals.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9 A.M. (TCM) TCM REMEMBERS ELI WALLACH This 11-hour marathon pays tribute to Mr. Wallach, who died on Tuesday at 98, through five of his performances, starting with Curtis Bernhardt’s “Kisses for My President” (1964), with Polly Bergen as the first female president, Fred MacMurray as her ego-bruised husband and Mr. Wallach as a rowdy Latin American dictator. Dore Schary’s “Act One” (1963), in which George Hamilton channels the playwright Moss Hart and Mr. Wallach the producer Warren Stone, follows at 11; “How the West Was Won” (1963), John Ford’s epic about three generations of pioneers, with Mr. Wallach as a train robber, at 1 p.m.; John Huston’s “The Misfits” (1961), starring Marilyn Monroe as a newly divorced showgirl, Clark Gable as an aging cowboy and Mr. Wallach as the ranch hand who devises a plan to round up wild mustangs and sell them to a dog food manufacturer, at 3:45; and Elia Kazan’s “Baby Doll” (1956), Mr. Wallach’s first film — and reportedly his favorite — in which he starred alongside Carroll Baker (above with Mr. Wallach) and Karl Malden as a Sicilian cotton-gin owner who seduces the child bride of his rival, at 6.

headline: Her Father Becomes a Citizen
text: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Did the Finale Surprise?
text: Season 1, Episode 8 Before I begin unpacking everything – and I mean everything – that went down in the Season 1 finale, “Grand Guignol,” a brief clarification/apology: I’m afraid I misinterpreted a fairly central aspect of Vanessa’s two demonic visitors in recent episodes of “Penny Dreadful.” In both instances – explicitly the first time (in all senses of the word) and more obliquely the second time – the encounter is meant to be a figment of Vanessa’s imagination. I spoke of first Sir Malcolm and then Ethan being possessed by this force; this is inaccurate. The reason why she (or whoever) conjured these two particular men was and is a topic worthy of discussion, but only once the facts are straight. I hope they are now, and I’m sorry it took me so long to get there.

headline: Despite Protests, China Official Calls Taiwan Trip a Success
text: The highest-level Chinese official to visit Taiwan since the two sides split at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 described his trip as a success even as he had to cut short his final day of appearances because of aggressive protests.

headline: Corrections: June 30, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Pistorius Wasn’t Mentally Ill When He Fired, Report says
text: LONDON — The trial of Oscar Pistorius, the disabled South African track star, resumed on Monday after psychiatric assessments that could have derailed the proceedings concluded that he was not mentally ill when he killed his girlfriend last year.

headline: Student Crossword | Women Novelists
text: Test your knowledge of women novelists by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Q. and A.: Edmund Malesky on Vietnam and China
text: Edmund J. Malesky, an associate professor of political economy at Duke University, has spent years studying the politics of Vietnam. More recently, he has been working on a governance project involving China. His scholarship on the two countries, both ruled by Communist parties with close ties, has given him a basis for a comparative perspective on the nations’ politics and political economies. In early May, a Chinese state-owned oil company moved an exploratory oil rig into waters off the disputed

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Water Levels on the Rise in the Great Lakes
text: In “Creeping Up on Unsuspecting Shores: The Great Lakes, in a Welcome Turnaround,” Julie Bosman writes about the rising water levels in these bodies of water.

headline: Philips to Combine Lighting Units Into Stand-Alone Company
text: LONDON – Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Monday that it would combine its LED and automotive lighting businesses into a stand-alone company and that it was exploring “strategic options” to raise capital from investors for the combined business.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Kim Tingley on the Promise and Problems of Three-Parent I.V.F.
text: Kim Tingley, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about three-parent I.V.F. Her last feature for the magazine was about a Harvard researcher’s attempts to understand suicide.

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
text: In 1914, as the outbreak of World War I brought mass slaughter to Europe’s battlefields, photojournalism evolved rapidly in the muddy trenches, where 19th century tactics met 20th century weapons. Machine guns, airplanes, tanks, flamethrowers, poisonous gas and submarines were widely used for the first time against doomed troops that were sent by their generals into frontal attacks that left millions dead.

headline: Former Nokia Chief to Join Perella Weinberg as Advisory Partner
text: LONDON – Jorma Ollila, formerly chief executive of the Finnish mobile phone maker Nokia, has joined the boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners as an advisory partner.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: Transforming China’s Movie Landscape
text: Listening to the head of China’s national film authority, it’s as if the Autobots of “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” are locked in battle not with the Decepticons but with Mei Yuangui, the wily main character in a Chinese-produced romantic comedy, “The Breakup Guru.”

headline: Today’s World Cup Matches: June 30, 2014
text: What to watch for in today’s World Cup matches, with four teams vying for two quarterfinal berths, including the two remaining African teams:

headline: New York Today: Behind Grand Central’s Shine
text: Good morning to you on this Monday of a four-day week.

headline: Assessing Zac Posen’s and Claudio Del Vecchio’s Ambitious Plans for Brooks Brothers
text: Zac Posen and Claudio Del Vecchio, the chief executive of Brooks Brothers, are pretty good at keeping secrets — they were in talks for a year before both sides agreed that Mr. Posen would become the women’s wear creative director for the quintessentially American brand, a deal announced on Friday — but now that the news is out, they’re spilling. What do they have planned?

headline: Daily Report: Start-Ups’ Modern Tools Help Small Merchants Compete
text: Operators at KES Dispatch in Mount Kisco, N.Y., keep track of the company’s taxis on a yellow legal pad. They communicate with cars using a two-way radio. Drivers navigate their journeys largely by memory. And in the age of Uber and Lyft, Hiroko Tabuchi reports, the company is desperate to modernize.

headline: China Ends Animal Testing Rule for Some Cosmetics
text: China has removed a controversial animal test requirement for some types of cosmetics, a move praised by animal rights advocates who hope it signals an end to a practice widely scorned elsewhere.

headline: Feeble Inflation and Lending Persist in Euro Zone
text: PARIS — Dangerously low inflation in the euro zone persists while lending to the private sector continues to shrink, official data showed on Monday, problems that will confront European Central Bank officials as they meet this week to plot monetary policy.

headline: Morning Views
text: The New York Times editorial board writes that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey “has yet to show sufficient interest in managing the public’s money in ways that benefit the public.” “He has used dubious strategies to avoid raising taxes,” the board adds, citing multiple instances that have hurt the state. A recent one involves the diversion of funds from a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Hudson River tunnel project to rebuild the deteriorating Pulaski Skyway; it’s being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr. The board says, “Mr. Christie has presented himself nationally as a straight-talking politician who can work with Democrats and attract voters from both parties. That image is taking a beating.”

headline: Vanessa Friedman on Fashion, Politics and Money
text: Vanessa Friedman, formerly The Financial Times’s first fashion editor, started as fashion director and chief fashion critic for The Times and The International New York Times one month ago. She told us a bit about how she started writing about fashion and what readers can expect from her in the Styles section.

headline: When a 20-Year Employee Becomes a Problem
text: This is the last of a series of posts that started with an explanation of why I decided to reinstitute employee reviews.

headline: How Hillary Clinton Is Like John McCain
text: Hillary Clinton’s artificially inflated poll numbers have made her seem like an especially strong presidential candidate, but the Clinton bubble is quickly coming to an end.

headline: The Lost Emails of the I.R.S. Point to a Wider Problem
text: During last Monday’s congressional hearing into the Internal Revenue Service’s loss of emails, Blake Farenthold, a Texas Republican, offered what on first glance seemed a simple solution to archiving agency email: “I went on Amazon and found you could buy a terabyte hard drive for $59. Buy two of them, so $120.”

headline: China’s Antigraft Push Snares an Ex-General
text: HONG KONG — In the most far-reaching public move so far in President Xi Jinping’s drive against corruption in China, the Communist Party on Monday expelled a retired military commander, Xu Caihou, and handed him over for an investigation into accusations that he took huge bribes in return for military promotions.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Shift on Foreclosed Homes
text: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. But now, with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

headline: 1964: France to Curb Vacation Costs
text: PARIS — The French Finance Ministry launched a campaign today [June 30] to hold down the cost of vacation in France. “Operation Vacation,” which begins tomorrow and ends Sept. 15, involves a program of vigilance over the cost of hotels, restaurants, tours, amusements and retail shops in 20 of France’s 90 departments most frequented by vacationers and tourists. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 1, 1964.

headline: What the Reduction in Tonsillectomies Teaches Us About Medicine
text: When I was a child, one of my favorite books was “Curious George Goes to the Hospital.” It told the story of a little monkey who swallowed a puzzle piece, needed an operation to get it out, and got ice cream to soothe his sore throat afterward. It seemed at the time to be a thinly veiled story about tonsillectomy. One of the driving forces behind the publication, I’m sure, was that so many children had their tonsils removed that it was helpful to have a book explaining to children how such a hospitalization would go.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Brand Lab, Minneapolis, hired an employee and promoted another. Brian Gioielli joins as development director; he had most recently been director for major and alumni giving at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design. And Monica Mason, outreach director, becomes program director.

headline: Questions and Answers on the Contraceptives Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday is expected to rule on a pair of challenges to a part of President Obama’s health care law that requires many employers to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives. Here is a look at the parties, the lawyers and the issues in the case.

headline: Andy Coulson to Face Retrial in Royal Phone Hacking Case
text: LONDON — Prosecutors said Monday that they would seek a retrial for Andy Coulson, a former spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron who once edited Rupert Murdoch’s best-selling tabloid in Britain, on charges of illegally acquiring royal telephone directories from police officers.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Contraceptives Mandate for Some Corporations
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that requiring family-owned corporations to pay for insurance coverage for contraception under the Affordable Care Act violated a federal law protecting religious freedom. It was, a dissent said, “a decision of startling breadth.”

headline: What’s News in Washington: Supreme Court Ends Its Term
text: Good Monday morning from Washington.

headline: PPG to Buy Mexican Paint Maker Consorcio Comex for $2.3 Billion
text: The Mexican paint maker Consorcio Comex has agreed to sell itself to PPG Industries, just months after an earlier sale agreement fell apart.

headline: I Think About Divorce a Lot, but Not Because I Want One
text: I was driving home while listening to “Older Americans’ Breakups Are Causing A ‘Graying’ Divorce Trend” on NPR. A man was interviewed who left his wife after 34 years. When asked why he left, he said, “The best thing in common that my ex-wife and I had was raising kids.” When their two sons grew up, he said, “we just didn’t have enough activities, passions, interests that were in common. And when the boys were gone, that just became more and more — to me — obvious.” The story gave an alarming statistic: “Americans over 50 are twice as likely to get divorced as people of that age were 20 years ago.”

headline: Pakistani Forces Begin Assault on Militant Strongholds
text: LONDON — For a decade now, the tribal town of Miram Shah in North Waziristan has been a slow-burning embarrassment to the Pakistani military.

headline: Toshiba and GDF Suez Push Ahead on British Nuclear Plant
text: LONDON — Toshiba, the Japanese industrial giant, and the French utility GDF Suez have announced plans for moving ahead with a new British nuclear power station, adding momentum to the country’s atomic energy program.

headline: Highlights from the Supreme Court’s Decision in Hobby Lobby Case
text: The Supreme Court is expected to rule Monday on whether for-profit corporations may advance claims based on religious freedom. The decision should come shortly after 10 a.m., concluding the court’s term.

headline: Merlin Properties of Spain Slips in Trading Debut
text: LONDON – Shares of Merlin Properties Socimi, a Spanish real estate trust, traded down slightly on their debut in Spain on Monday.

headline: As Recalls Expand, G.M. Offers Plan for Victims of Faulty Ignition Switch
text: WASHINGTON — General Motors on Monday became consumed once again by the safety crisis it cannot seem to shake, announcing the recall of 8.4 million more vehicles worldwide — most of them for an ignition defect similar to the flaw that the company failed to disclose in other models for more than a decade.

headline: A Vintage-Style Model Designed in Honor of a Fallen WWI Hero
text: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Bell & Ross.

headline: 1939: Reporter Doesn’t Expect War
text: Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr., Liberty magazine’s roving correspondent, returned to Paris from Rome yesterday after a month’s flying survey of Poland, Germany, Czecho-Slovakia, Hungary and other European trouble zones. “I’ll bet my shirt there’ll be no war,” said Mr. Vanderbilt, on his arrival last night at the Hotel Crillon. “Germany hasn’t enough wheat, oil, steel and other raw materials to wage a war successfully.” Mr. Vanderbilt said Germany “is in for a partial, if not a total crop failure in its bread basket.” As for the raw material situation, Mr. Vanderbilt said German economists estimate the Reich needs 20,000,000 tons of steel annually, but can count on only 7,000,000 tons. — New York Herald Tribune, July 1, 1939.

headline: On the Next Docket: How the First Amendment Applies to Social Media
text: WASHINGTON — Just four years ago, the Supreme Court issued a hesitant and muddled decision in a privacy case, saying it was best to move slowly when ruling on an “emerging technology before its role in society has become clear.”

headline: Secrecy of Dark Pools Can Blur Both Ways
text: It should not come as any great surprise that a brokerage firm, like the proverbial used-car salesman, would take a few liberties with the truth while trying to sell something. But the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has taken on Barclays by filing a civil suit related to the marketing of its dark pool trading platform, which the bank portrayed as safe for investors when it let plenty of sharks swim in the deep end.

headline: Oldies But Goodies
text: Ah — so we learn that Ezra Klein’s Vox is under attack — as is the current Democratic agenda — because it’s “tired”, recycling ideas from the 60s and even earlier.

headline: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
text: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..

headline: Oscar Pistorius’s Mental Health Report
text: The defense lawyer and prosecutor reacted to a psychiatric report that found Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, was not suffering from a mental disorder when he killed his girlfriend.

headline: Activist Investor Peltz Builds Stake in Bank of New York Mellon
text: The activist investor Nelson Peltz has built up a stake of nearly 2.5 percent in Bank of New York Mellon.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling on Union Fees Is a Limited Blow to Labor
text: The Supreme Court dealt a limited blow to organized labor on Monday by ruling that some government employees did not have to pay any fees to the unions representing them. But the court declined to strike down a decades-old precedent that required many public sector workers to pay union fees. Writing for the 5-to-4 majority, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. concluded that there was a category of government employees — a partial public employee — who can opt out of joining a union and not be required to contribute union fees.

headline: How Music May Make Babies Team Players
text: Moving with a partner to the musical beat may make people more cooperative — even babies as young as 14 months.

headline: For Hotel Guests, a Key and an Airport Lounge
text: Airport lounges have long been a way for airlines to offer exclusive waiting areas for elite-class travelers; now a few hotels are entering the game.

headline: France vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: France failed to score against Ecuador in its last match, but had sent out a B team. Patrice Evra, Mathieu Debuchy and Yohan Cabaye, part of the team that scored eight goals in its first two games, should all return. Nigeria advanced at the expense of Bosnia and Iran, but steps up in class here.

headline: Police Accuse Queens Man of Strangling His Son, 8
text: The man called 911 shortly after 10 p.m. on Sunday with a disturbing message: His wife had left him, and now he believed that he and his 8-year-old son were better off dead.

headline: Financial Futures Pioneer Honors Japanese Consul Who Saved 6,000 Jews
text: Decades before he founded a major financial marketplace, Leo Melamed learned a fundamental lesson about economics as a 7-year-old refugee in Japan.

headline: Bolshoi Director Back at Work After Hospitalization
text: LONDON — Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet director who suffered burns and a loss of vision in an acid attack in January 2013, is back at work after being hospitalized for an allergic reaction that led him to be put in intensive care on Friday.  The Russian news agency Interfax reported on Sunday that Mr. Filin had been released from the Sklifosovsky Research Institute. George Golukhov, the head of the Moscow Department of Health, was quoted as saying his condition was “normal.”

headline: Supreme Court Declines Case Contesting Ban on Gay ‘Conversion Therapy’
text: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear a challenge to a California law that bans “conversion therapy” aimed at changing the sexual orientation of gay and lesbian minors.

headline: New York Summer Stories: In 1887, Mosquitoes by Myriads
text: It’s hot. It smells. The parks are crowded and so is Long Beach.

headline: We’re Moving
text: From now on, you will find us at a new address: nytimes.com/world. We will continue to produce web-only India Ink sketches, analyses, narratives and news stories, but they will appear on the World page, along with the rest of the newspaper’s coverage.

headline: A Little Bit of Realism Can Result in a Lot More Happiness
text: Expectations are funny things. When we start to expect something, we also start to count on it. Once we start counting on something to happen, we start to make plans. Then, if we aren’t careful, we even start to act as if it’s already a reality. In our minds it becomes something that’s guaranteed to happen.

headline: More Bodies Pulled From Collapsed Building in India
text: NEW DELHI — The deaths from the collapse of a 12-story building in the southern Indian city of Chennai rose to 19 on Monday even as some of those trapped were pulled out alive through heavy rains.

headline: A Ravenous Beetle, the Science of Good Fortune and Disco Clams
text: How tiny emerald ash borers may threaten a vast ecosystem; the psychology behind our belief in winning streaks; scientists discover the secret behind a clam’s brilliant undersea light show.

headline: New York Towns Can Prohibit Fracking, State’s Top Court Rules
text: In a decision with far-reaching implications for the future of natural gas drilling in New York State, its highest court ruled on Monday that towns can use zoning ordinances to ban hydraulic fracturing, the controversial extraction method known as fracking.

headline: The Perils of Too Much Happy Talk
text: Most parents want their kids to be happy. But a new study suggests that too much emphasis on happiness might be teaching kids that caring for other people is secondary. And this could actually make kids less happy.

headline: Neil Young and Crazy Horse to Tour With a Substitute Bassist
text: Just as Neil Young was preparing to tour Europe with his occasional backing band, the often raggedly glorious Crazy Horse, the band’s bassist, Billy Talbot, suffered what a spokesman for Reprise Records described in a statement as “a mild stroke.”

headline: Czech Women Continue Wimbledon Onslaught
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The top 10 women in the tennis rankings hail from 10 countries, which is why the surge of Czech players into the second week of Wimbledon is an unexpected curiosity.

headline: For Outsiders, Overuse Isn’t a Worry
text: Jurgen Klinsmann often challenges American players to follow the grand old goal of self-improvement by playing in the Champions League and the fast leagues of Europe.

headline: World Cup 2014: Puzzle 1 of 2
text: A puzzle by Joe Fendel to celebrate World Cup 2014.

headline: Chocolate Ganache
text: How to make the simple French mixture of chocolate and cream, which can be used as a sauce, icing or tart filling.

headline: Loyalty Program Declares, ‘Bacon Lovers, Unite; You Have Nothing to Lose but Your Sizzle’
text: A regional brand of meat products is seeking to grow by capitalizing on a national craze, offering ardent aficionados of bacon an opportunity to find — and join forces with — like-minded fans.

headline: The Smallest World Cup Host City
text: Tens of thousands of international tourists visited Cuiabá, deep in Brazil’s interior, for the World Cup. Residents hope the tournament will put their city on the map.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Saint Laurent Spring/Summer 2015
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Nets Said to Get 2 Picks for Kidd
text: Jason Kidd’s strange tenure as head coach of the Nets has come to a formal end.

headline: Jeremy Murphy Leaves Barclays for Bank of America
text: Bank of America has named Jeremy Murphy a managing director in its consumer and retail investment banking group for the Americas. Mr. Murphy is the latest investment banker to leave Barclays, which is seeking to reduce the size of its investment bank in response to stiffer regulations.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Hobby Lobby Decision
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Older People Often Overtreated for Diabetes, Study Suggests
text: Most people with diabetes are treated with drugs (notably metformin) that don’t put them at risk of unusually low blood sugar, or hypoglycemia, a potentially dangerous side effect. But as patients age and develop other chronic medical conditions, it becomes more difficult for them to tolerate these medications.

headline: Kidd’s Stunt Gives Nets a Chance to Upgrade
text: Once upon a time, there was a celebrated Knicks coach who abruptly quit when his demand for increased organizational power went unmet. Pat Riley was his name. Self-aggrandizement was his game.

headline: Netherlands’ Robben Absolved of Wrongdoing
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil — FIFA said it would not open disciplinary proceedings against the Netherlands forward Arjen Robben, who admitted to diving in Sunday’s victory over Mexico.

headline: Orecchiette With Fresh and Dried Beans and Tomatoes
text: Orecchiette is a great pasta to use with beans, which lodge in the hollows of the little ears. I used lush Good Mother Stallard beans, an heirloom bean that I ordered from Rancho Gordo for this dish, but you can substitute supermarket pinto or borlottis. Cook them simply and use some of the broth for the sauce. If you have marinara sauce on hand you can use that; otherwise take advantage of the tomatoes arriving in farmers’ markets and your garden, and chop up a few of them. No need to cook them if you don’t want to.

headline: Isabella Boylston Promoted to Principal Dancer at American Ballet Theater
text: Isabella Boylston, who has danced in “Giselle,” “La Bayadère,” and “Swan Lake” with American Ballet Theater this season, is taking on a new role with the company: principal dancer.

headline: Ken Watanabe Will Star Opposite Kelli O’Hara in ‘The King and I’
text: Five-time Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara (“The Bridges of Madison County”) and the Japanese film star Ken Watanabe (an Oscar nominee for “The Last Samurai”) will play Anna and the King of Siam in the Lincoln Center Theater production of the Rodgers and Hammerstein classic, “The King and I.” The theater on Monday announced those and other details on the revival, which is scheduled to begin previews March 12, 2015, and opens April 16, 2015, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: Monday Quandary: Nothing Left at the End of the Day
text: In the weekly quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread, or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than just that one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: Ex-SAC Executive, Solomon Kumin, Strikes Out on His Own
text: A former top executive for Steven A. Cohen is testing whether a person needs experience as a trader to raise big dollars for a hedge fund.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Weekend of Hedonism and Hope
text: LONDON — At long last, this town has given us the version of a classic we always wanted, even if we didn’t realize it: the Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor “Antony and Cleopatra.” Yes, of course I know that there is a 1963 movie called “Cleopatra” that stars those two, who notoriously fell in love during the filming.

headline: How One Phish Fan ‘Sees’ Music
text: While listening to Phish, the music writer Mike Hamad developed a way to sketch a road map through a song. He’s hoping his technique will help him “see” the magic in music.

headline: BET Awards 2014 Red Carpet
text: Kerry Washington and John Legend stood out as some of the best-dressed guests on the BET Awards 2014 red carpet. Here are some more looks.

headline: 30 Migrants Found Dead in a Boat Near Sicily
text: ROME — Italian naval personnel discovered the bodies of about 30 migrants in the hold of a fishing boat during a rescue operation off the coast of Sicily, the navy said Monday.

headline: Chocolate Ganache, an Easygoing French Treat
text: Chocolate fudge and hot fudge sauce are American classics, but let’s face it: Fudge is fussy.

headline: Israel’s Search for 3 Teenagers Ends in Grief
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s intense 18-day search for three abducted teenagers ended Monday when their bodies were found buried under a pile of rocks in an open field about 15 miles from where the youths were last seen in the occupied West Bank.

headline: G.M. Unveils Plan to Pay Crash Victims
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, a compensation expert, announced G.M.’s plan to pay families of those who died in accidents caused by a defective ignition switch.

headline: Between the Lines of the Contraception Decision
text: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., writing for the court, declared that family-owned corporations like Hobby Lobby cannot be forced to pay for insurance coverage for contraception for employees over their religious objections.

headline: The Courts and the Changing Culture War
text: For a generation or more, the lines of debate around religious liberty and religion in the public square were relatively clear. As with other culture war issues, religious conservatives tended to be majoritarians and small-d democrats, supporting the rights of legislatures and town councils and school boards to make decisions about issues ranging from creches on greens to school prayer to the disbursement of education dollars to religious schools without interference from the judicial branch. And there was an assumption among many observers — and not only on the religious right — that on matters related to believers’ involvement in civic life, the courts were a kind of vanguard force for secularism, whose efforts would tend to collide with public sentiment and lead to conflict with the democratic branches of government.

headline: Blast Kills 2 Police Officers Near Presidential Palace in Cairo
text: CAIRO — Two police officers were killed Monday in Cairo while trying to defuse explosive devices planted outside Egypt’s presidential palace, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Health Care Law’s Other Legal Challenges
text: Monday’s “Hobby Lobby” decision was just the latest challenge to the Affordable Care Act. Details on the 5-4 decision and other challenges that could — if successful — have even deeper implications.

headline: ScienceTake | Navigating Air and Water
text: For flying and swimming creatures obstructions can be something to avoid, or helpful reference points.

headline: Video: How to Draw a Phish Song
text: When you’re listening to a great piece of music, what are you imagining?

headline: China Sentences 113 to Prison in Xinjiang Region
text: BEIJING — Courts in the Kashgar area of the western Chinese region of Xinjiang have sentenced 113 people to prison terms for a wide range of crimes, including organizing and taking part in terrorist organizations, according to a state media report from Xinjiang.

headline: How Bumblebees and Zebra Fish Navigate Their Worlds
text: All moving animals do their best to avoid running into things. And most living things follow a tried and true strategy — Watch where you’re going!

headline: The Political Repercussions of the Hobby Lobby Decision
text: Normally it’s not a good idea to jump right into the political implications of a major Supreme Court decision like Hobby Lobby, but in this case there’s no point in waiting. This was a political decision and it is absolutely proper for Democrats to use it as a weapon in the midterm election campaign.

headline: The Who to Tour for 50th Anniversary
text: You’ve heard this before: the Who’s next tour, which will begin in December and stretch into 2015, will definitely, absolutely, positively be the band’s last. Pete Townshend, the band’s guitarist and composer, said as much in interviews last October, although only a few days later, his colleague Roger Daltrey – the group’s singer and only other surviving original member – told Rolling Stone that after the 2015 tour, the Who might record some new music and perhaps play occasional concerts, maybe in the context of a theater residency.

headline: Americans Are Shut Out From Final 16s at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — With one felled by an uncooperative leg and another by a booming serve, two Americans exited Wimbledon on Monday and help set another low point in recent American tennis history.

headline: Beyond Rangel, Harlem Wrestles With Its Identity
text: On the streets of Harlem the weekend before the Democratic primary for his congressional seat, Representative Charles B. Rangel and his closest opponent, a Dominican-born state senator, Adriano D. Espaillat, carried on an age-old campaign tradition, snaking along their routes in dueling caravans, blasting songs like “Ain’t No Stoppin’ Us Now” and “I Believe I Can Fly” from the loudspeakers of their campaign trucks.

headline: How Hobby Lobby Ruling Could Limit Access to Birth Control
text: The Supreme Court ruling in the Hobby Lobby case raises at least two questions: How will it affect access to contraception, and what do the drugs and devices the company objected to on religious grounds actually do?

headline: Leprosy, Still Claiming Victims
text: Throughout his adolescence, José Ramirez Jr., now a clinical social worker in Houston, had a shifting array of bewildering symptoms.

headline: Obama Says He’ll Order Action to Aid Immigrants
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday he would use his executive power to make potentially sweeping changes to the nation’s immigration system without Congress, acknowledging the death of his more than yearlong effort to enact compromise legislation granting legal status to 11 million immigrants here illegally.

headline: Insurer Warns Some Pooled Pensions Are Beyond Recovery
text: More than a million people risk losing their federally insured pensions in just a few years despite recent stock market gains and a strengthening economy, a new government study said on Monday.

headline: German Chemical Company’s Curious Goal
text: A $400 million tie-up between the specialty chemical maker Evonik Industries and the German soccer team Borussia Dortmund has few merits for the company’s shareholders. Evonik, Germany’s third-largest chemical company, hopes that the alliance with the club will turn its brand into a global household name. The snag is that Evonik doesn’t do any business with end users.

headline: In Recall Blitz, G.M. Risks Its Reputation
text: DETROIT — The deeper General Motors digs into its vast portfolio of vehicles, the more safety problems it finds.

headline: Court Out of Step With Public on Contraception Coverage
text: The ruling by the Supreme Court on Monday in the Hobby Lobby case runs counter to general public opinion, a recent poll shows.

headline: A Malted Milk Crawl in New York
text: Malt is like a sweet version of umami, the so-called fifth flavor that pops up in ingredients like soy, mushrooms and monosodium glutamate. Just as umami makes savory flavors come alive, malt does the same for sweet. It’s an old-fashioned flavor, a bit tough to describe, but a little nutty, buttery, even earthy.

headline: Are Your Food and Clothes Produced With Slave Labor?
text: All consumers should be outraged by the idea that they’ve bought something – from shrimp to shirts – produced with slave labor. Yet as numerous reports have documented, that is a serious and growing possibility, particularly in the United States, the world’s biggest importer.

headline: France Gives Cold Shoulder to Amazon
text: In a backlash against the retail giant Amazon, France is preparing to impose new restrictions this summer that would bar online merchants from offering free shipments of discounted books.

headline: French Start Slow and Finish Strong
text: BRASÍLIA — In 2010, France was the shame of the World Cup, a team in open revolt against its coach, Raymond Domenech, and it failed to win a game. But four years later, under a new coach, France is among the final eight teams in the tournament, and this time, it has played four games without losing.

headline: Germany vs. Algeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
text: Will Algeria’s dogged play be enough to slow the relentless passing attack of Germany?

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Paris Shows
text: A peek at what some of the peacocks in Paris were wearing.

headline: Hostile Bid for Club Med Threatens Existing Deal
text: PARIS — An Italian private equity investor on Monday announced a hostile offer for Club Méditerranée, threatening a deal agreed to last year in which the vacation resort group would be acquired by French and Chinese investors.

headline: Find Another Name, Belgian Court Tells DSK Sex Club
text: TOURNAI, Belgium — A court in this southwestern Belgian town on Monday ordered a newly opened sex club called the DSK to change its name. The ruling was another legal victory for the man known widely by those initials: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the French politician and former head of the International Monetary Fund who faced charges, later dropped, of sexually assaulting a hotel housekeeper in New York in 2011.

headline: You Say Soft, I Say Serve
text: A few days a week at my office, we conduct something known as the 4 p.m. shame spiral. A small group of us makes a discreet exit from our building to the fro-yo joint across the street, where we pile all manner of cereal and macerated fruit over an overly generous portion of frozen yogurt that has oozed from a giant machine.

headline: Striker Vows His Biting Days Are Over
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Uruguay striker Luis Suárez has issued a public apology for biting an opponent in a World Cup match last week, his third on-field biting incident since 2010, and pledged that there will “never again” be a similar incident.

headline: Movie Aliens, Scary and Cute
text: When I was a kid, the scariest movie I never saw was “Invaders From Mars,” which recounts a sneak alien incursion through the eyes of a boy. It came out in 1953, when my own life revolved around the baseball field the dads in the neighborhood had built in the vacant lot across the street.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Marquez Makes It Eight in a Row
text: Marc Marquez continued his extraordinary 2014 season on Saturday with his eighth victory in eight races in the MotoGP grand prix at TT Circuit Assen in the Netherlands. Marquez, riding a Honda, battled the whole race against rainy weather and a surprising challenge from Andrea Dovizioso, a rider for Ducati. Various mistakes and pits stops for bike changes kept Marquez from securing the lead until the 16th of 26 laps around the track. His win streak duplicates a feat last accomplished by Giacomo Agostini in 1971.

headline: Facebook Says It’s Sorry. We’ve Heard That Before.
text: Sometimes, being wrong on the Internet means having to say you’re sorry.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 24-June 30, 2014

headline: BNP Paribas Admits Guilt and Agrees to Pay $8.9 Billion Fine to U.S.
text: Updated, 9:07 p.m. | After months of heated negotiations, state and federal authorities on Monday announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas, taking aim at France’s biggest bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: Israeli Reaction to Discovery of Bodies
text: Israeli citizens reacted after the bodies of three missing teenagers in the occupied West Bank were found Monday after a nearly three-week search.

headline: After the Trees Disappear
text: This past winter was the coldest Detroit had experienced in 36 years. Across the upper Midwest, cities shivered, and more than 90 percent of the surface area of the Great Lakes froze solid.

headline: Inside Mark Sanford’s Man Cave
text: Mark Sanford finished out the two years of his governor’s term after news broke in 2009 that he left his state for five days for an assignation with his mistress, Maria Belen Chapur — not for a hike of the Appalachian Trail, as he initially said. With his political career practically dead when he left office, he retreated to his family’s 3,000-acre plantation in the South Carolinian coastal county of Beaufort. As part of a spiritual convalescence there, he built a single-room cabin with his sons, on the eastern edge of the property. He took me on a late-night tour there in March, while I was interviewing him for my article about his political recovery in last Sunday’s magazine. ‘‘It doesn’t look like much, but it was pretty hard,’’ Sanford told me. ‘‘It’s not an advanced building by any stretch of the imagination.’’ Inside, the cabin is packed with items from Sanford’s political rise and fall and his family life. I asked him about some of the items.

headline: Falling for the Photo in Staten Island
text: Fifty years ago, a daring and ambitious young photographer met his match between the towers of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

headline: G.M. Internal Investigation Report
text: The results of an investigation overseen by Anton R. Valukas, a former United States attorney, into the company’s handling of a defective ignition switch.

headline: Is It Better to Buy or Rent?
text: The answer to the question depends on many factors. Compare the costs of buying and renting equivalent homes.

headline: At Morgenstern’s Finest, a Swirl of Innovation

headline: Mental Health and the Pistorius Trial
text: Although Oscar Pistorius was found not to have been mentally ill when he killed his girlfriend, the issue of his mental health will most likely persist at his murder trial.

text: “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” the new Broadway musical inspired by the lyrics and life of the rapper Tupac Shakur, had little to shout about at the box office in its first full week of post-opening performances.

text: The hydraulic fracturing debate in New York State has been so intense that Gov. Andrew Cuomo imposed a moratorium two years ago to study the issue.

text: Doctors should stop performing routine pelvic exams, a key component of regular physicals for women, an influential medical group said Monday.

headline: The Hobby Lobby Fallout
text: The Supreme Court ruled in a 5 to 4 decision today that requiring privately owned companies to pay for insurance coverage for contraception violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, a federal law protecting liberties guaranteed by the First Amendment.

headline: Frank Cashen, Who Turned Lowly Mets Into Swaggering Champions, Dies at 88
text: Frank Cashen, the sportswriter turned baseball executive who built pennant-winning teams with the Baltimore Orioles and then transformed the Mets from perennial losers to the World Series champions of 1986, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Easton, Md. He was 88.

headline: For Owners and Brokers, Web Rentals Upend the Hamptons Season
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The photos could hardly do the place justice, and not just because they were pixelated. No picture could have captured those strands of silver and gold shooting through the clouds as the sun set over Lake Montauk, the sloops and fishing boats bobbing alongside the once-rare-now-everywhere yachts.

headline: Apple Expands iTunes U Education App for iPads
text: Apple will soon make another bid to persuade schools to replace textbooks with iPads. Next week, it will introduce a tool for instructors to teach from the tablet.

headline: A Lucy and Ethel for an Age After Blogs
text: “Overshare” was chosen by Webster’s New World Dictionary as the “word of the year” in 2008, and no one overshared more that year than the blogger Emily Gould.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week in 140 Characters
Using Brains, Not Guns, in World War I Trenches
text: Late in the new World War I video game Valiant Hearts: The Great War, a French soldier named Émile is running into battle. The scene is the real and awful Second Battle of the Aisne, and it unfurls, as do so many other notable moments from the war in the game, like an interactive tapestry or a playable cartoon for grown-ups.

headline: After Tightening Pensions, Germany Eases Rules for Some
text: BERLIN — Back in 2007, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government voted to lift the retirement age gradually to 67 from 65, in line with policies being adopted by the United States and other countries concerned about the costs of supporting an aging population. Economists say that move not only stabilized Germany’s public pension system, but also put Berlin in a position to insist during the subsequent financial crisis that other European governments follow suit.

headline: Unwitting Father Confessor in Flight
text: TRAVELING is just part of the deal if you’re running a business. I’m C.E.O. and founder of Rosenzweig and Company, a global executive search firm, and I have to travel a lot. I don’t like airports, and I don’t really like flying, so I try to be as efficient as possible with scheduling.

headline: Mick Jagger Teases Monty Python: ‘Wrinkly Old Men Trying to Relive Their Youth’
text: With Monty Python about to begin its run of reunion (and farewell) shows at the 02 Arena in London on Tuesday, Mick Jagger and Charlie Watts of the Rolling Stones have made a video clip – commissioned by the Pythons, and shown at the troupe’s news conference about the shows on Monday – in which they tease the comedians as being past their sell-by date.

headline: A Belgian Food Truck Feeds the Hungry Fashion Set in Paris
text: Over the weekend in Paris, fashion editors and buyers took breaks from the back-to-back spring/summer 2015 men’s runways to stretch their legs at the MAN trade show, where a diverting lineup included more than just gazing at clothes. The show’s three-day run kicked off with an exhibition of Mote Sinabel Aoki’s photographs; eased into a friendly tournament of petanque, a French ball game; and culminated with a garden party at l’Institut Suédois à Paris. Throughout it all, MAN’s guests noshed on decadent dishes — crispy-skinned roasted chicken over greens, salted mackerel with juniper-roasted cauliflower cream, aged rib-eye, gazpacho, a green pea salad — served out of the Meteor food truck. The photographer Adrian Crispin was on the scene to capture the delicious offerings of Maarten van Essche and Floris Van Looy — and their stylish customers — before the two cooks drove their fine mobile eatery off to their next destination: a seashore in their hometown of Belgium (Ostend, Zeedijk 10), where they’ll be parked this Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

headline: Making It Work, but on Wheels
text: “Project Runway” — yes, it’s still on — begins a new season on July 24 on Lifetime, but perhaps you can’t wait that long to watch high-strung contestants bitch at one another as they design something utterly frivolous, while all over the world people are confronting real problems that have life-or-death consequences.

headline: Shell Game
text: Q. I often include about half of one eggshell in the cup with my soft-boiled breakfast egg. Is eating it good for my health or bad?

headline: Young Life Under a Cloud

headline: After Loud Complaints From French, Silence as BNP Penalty Is Announced
text: PARIS — As the American authorities announced a record penalty on Monday against BNP Paribas for violating United States rules on trading with blacklisted countries, the French political establishment had an unusual reaction: silence.

headline: The Iraq Stain
text: I don’t write much about Iraq and all that these days, but this report from James Risen brings back the horror of the whole thing. And I don’t just mean the fact that we were lied into war; that most of our media and policy elite rushed to join the bandwagon; that the venture led to awesome waste of lives and money.

headline: Clue to Disease’s Spread in a 6,200-Year-Old Grave
text: The oldest Schistosoma egg ever found was unearthed recently in an archaeological dig in Syria, and its surroundings suggest that ancient Mesopotamians may have contributed to the spread of schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease.

headline: The A.P. Plans to Automate Quarterly Earnings Articles
text: The Associated Press announced Monday that it would use computer automation to perform one of the most formulaic tasks for business reporters — writing articles about the quarterly earnings of companies.

headline: Boston Ballet Visits New York With a Bulging Suitcase
text: All ballet companies have their self-contradictions. Boston Ballet is both a much better company than it allowed New York to see last week in its season at the David H. Koch Theater and, occasionally, a more dismaying one. The troupe has the world’s finest current production of “The Sleeping Beauty,” at least two of America’s best classical ballerinas (Kathleen Breen Combes and Misa Kuranaga, wholly unalike), a staging of Balanchine’s “Jewels” with (as seen in 2009) several exhilarating points of text and style absent from New York City Ballet’s, and many other productions that make me wish I had time to visit Boston more often. Its choice of ballets by living choreographers is, however, much more problematic.

headline: Cult Favorite ‘Community’ Is Saved From Cancellation by Yahoo
text: As might be appropriate for a cult comedy, “Community” has been saved again from the cancellation crypt.

headline: Bacon Painting Sets Pace for Auctions in London
text: LONDON — Since Francis Bacon’s “Three Studies of Lucian Freud” (1969) sold at Christie’s for $142.4 million in New York last November a rash of paintings by that Irish-born artist have emerged for sale. The auction at Sotheby’s on Monday night, which kicked off the contemporary art sales here, will be remembered for buoyant bidding on a triptych by Bacon from 1964, which brought $45.4 million, well above its $33.6 million high estimate.

headline: More Time for Sifting Among Clues
text: Hors d’oeuvres, sports highlights, book excerpts — bite-size anything becomes unsatisfying after a while, and you may find yourself craving a full meal, a full game, a full novel. If you’re a history buff, the long-running PBS series “History Detectives” may by now feel like an endless diet of crudités, so you might be intrigued by the news that for July the show is altering its format to allow longer investigations.

headline: Return of a Player’s Sex Romps

headline: Saving Lives and Pushing Paper
text: A keen sense of loss permeates “Code Black,” an affecting love letter from a young doctor to his hospital. Over the years, plenty of similar romances have been immortalized in book form, but this may be the first to play out as a documentary, and is surely the first to emerge from our newly reformed health care climate. You’d think you’d be in for some celebration.

headline: The Broadway Star Who Got Away
text: Fans of Karen Olivo could hardly have been surprised when she belted out what Charles Isherwood of The New York Times called a “rafter-rattling performance” of “Come to Your Senses” at City Center last weekend. They knew this Tony Award-winning actress could sing, so her well-received turn in the Encores! Off-Center presentation of “Tick, Tick ... Boom!,” which grapples with the sacrifices it takes to make a life in the theater, was to be expected.

headline: A Sibling Rivalry Played Out Over Keyboards

headline: After Favorable Schedule and Easy Wins, Murray Arrives at a Test
text: WIMBLEDON, England — A heralded title defense that for four matches has practically been a stroll on the grass is about to become much more interesting and possibly threatening for Andy Murray. Well-rested, on schedule despite recent inclement weather and in fine form, he is looking at a quarterfinal against Grigor Dimitrov, a presumed star on the rise.

headline: An Outpouring of Pride
text: Thousands of people, of all ages, races and sexual orientations, celebrated their respect for themselves and others in Manhattan on Sunday at the Gay Pride March. Here are a few of the participants.

headline: Ana María Matute, Spanish Novelist Marked by Civil War, Dies at 88
text: Ana María Matute, a novelist whose explorations of alienation and the loss of innocence children experienced during and after the Spanish Civil War made her one of Spain’s most popular and acclaimed writers, died on Wednesday in Barcelona. She was 88.

headline: After Bitcoin Auction, Winning Bidders Remain Elusive
text: Since Friday, when the United States Marshals Service auctioned off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins, investors and Bitcoin enthusiasts alike have been eagerly awaiting the results. As the agency began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.

headline: Twitter Buys TapCommerce, a Mobile Advertising Start-Up
text: Twitter on Monday announced that it had acquired TapCommerce, a start-up in Manhattan focused on advertising tailored to smartphone apps.

headline: Extremists in Iraq Attack Shiite Shrine, Killing 6
text: BAGHDAD — Sunni extremists fired mortars into a shrine in Samarra that is sacred to Shiites late Monday, killing six people and damaging the shrine, according to a report on Iraqi state television.

headline: A Grope and a Shrug
text: It was fully a decade ago that Dov Charney, the founder and (at that point) chief executive of American Apparel, decided that the right way to behave in front of a female journalist doing a profile of him was to masturbate. Not once, mind you. “Eight or so times,” according to the story, in Jane magazine, which is no longer around.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Google’s Street View Appeal
text: The United States Supreme Court on Monday allowed a case accusing Google of wiretapping to proceed, undermining the search company’s efforts to put a troublesome episode to rest even as it plans to become more deeply embedded in consumers’ lives.

headline: Should Facebook Manipulate Users?
text: SHOULD we worry that technology companies can secretly influence our emotions? Apparently so.

headline: A Woman at War
text: On June 19, 1864, Pvt. Lyons Wakeman died of dysentery in the Marine U.S.A. General Hospital in New Orleans, after having marched 200 miles and seen combat at the Battle of Pleasant Hill, part of the Union’s Red River campaign in Louisiana. But it would be years before Wakeman’s real identity was revealed: Lyons Wakeman was born a woman, Sarah Rosetta Wakeman.

headline: Questioning the Merits of Propping Up City Hall
text: MILWAUKEE — City Hall, built in the 1890s and still one of the largest of its kind in the country, is slowly sinking.

headline: Those Who Can Afford It Have a Better Way to Fly
text: WE are on the cusp of the Fourth of July weekend, when the fun really begins in air travel, as summer crowds push into already packed planes, challenging the laws of both physics and good manners.

headline: Pretrial Detention Extended for Egyptians Who Protested Ban on Protests
text: Nearly two dozen Egyptian activists, arrested at a protest march on June 21, will remain in pretrial detention until Sept. 13, a judge ruled on Sunday, the news site Aswat Masriya reported.

headline: Feud Between Oligarchs Seen as Cause of Bank Run in Bulgaria
text: FRANKFURT — Even in an Eastern European country with a history of financial panics and political intrigue, it was an alarming picture.

headline: Hobby Lobby Made Fight a Matter of Christian Principle
text: WASHINGTON — For the family behind Hobby Lobby, fighting the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptives mandate all the way to the Supreme Court was a calling, not a choice.
